title: Texas: Panel Rules Agent Can Be Sued Over Shooting Teenager Across Border
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled Monday that a Border Patrol agent could be sued by the family of a 15-year-old Mexican boy he shot and killed even though the boy was in Mexico at the time of the episode. The agent, Jesus Mesa Jr., shot Sergio Adrian Hernandez Guereca on June 7, 2010, through a barbed wire border fence near El Paso. Mr. Mesa and the Obama administration argued that the agent could not be sued because constitutional protections did not apply since the youth was not in the United States. A three-judge panel of the court, in New Orleans, rejected that argument, saying the agents conduct was obviously unlawful, so he did not qualify for immunity.

Eleven million travelers have stayed in Airbnb destinations, according to data shared by the company. Roughly 550,000 homes are now being shared by hosts. Airbnb is more popular in Europe than it is even in the United States. Paris is the largest destination city.

It is part memoir and part meditation on some of the well-known compensation systems he has administered during the course of his career, from the Agent Orange settlement to the 9/11 fund to the Gulf coast compensation fund that Feinberg managed for BP. Where is it written, he muses at one point, that the tort system, and the tort system alone, must be the guiding force in determining who gets what? Its a good question.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 9:40 P.M. (Flix) AMLIE (2001) Audrey Tautou, above, in her breakthrough role, plays a French sprite working as a waitress who lays out elaborate practical jokes as payback for those who offend her friends. When she falls in love with Nino (Mathieu Kassovitz), Amlie finds herself incapable of revealing her feelings and instead turns Paris, recreated through sets and computer-generated imagery, into a kind of treasure hunt as she leaves clues about her identity, and he trails after her. Writing in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell called this comedy by Jean-Pierre Jeunet a sugar-rush of a movie. With its hypnotic sense of romance and a heroine who constantly flirts with failure, he added, the films fastidious complex of flesh and fantasy is a dazzling achievement.

title: Morning Views
description: The New York Times echoes President Obama in urging legislators to pass comprehensive immigration reform. But on Monday, he said the federal government needed additional authority to exercise discretion. The editorial board asks: Does the President intend to change the law that requires such children be given an adequate chance to have their cases heard in immigration court?The law, enacted by the Bush administration, recognizes that many unaccompanied minors are likely to be refugees or victims of human trafficking who need legal and humanitarian help. It also protects them from summary deportation and requires thatthe Border Patrol turn them over to a refugee resettlement office and, where appropriate, to the care of parents or other relatives living in the United States. The Times believes weakening those protections in a misguided effort to discourage new migrants would be a terrible outcome.

Joliot is working independently of his wife, Irene Joliot Curie, with whom he was given the 1935 Nobel award. She is the daughter of Pierre and Marie Curie, discoverers of radium. If scientists can find practicable means to set up uranium chain reactions, then it is estimated that it may be possible to obtain from one pound of uranium as much energy as is at present obtained from 1,250 tons of coal.New York Herald Tribune, July 2, 1939.

title: Chronicler Recalls a Bridges Rising, 50 Years Later
description: On windy days, ironworkers clambered up catwalks, linked the 60 garage-size steel segments that made up the bridge deck, and tiptoed atop the bridges 70-story towers at the risk of their lives. Three men were killed in falls during the construction. The workers or their bosses bore names like Hard-Nosed Murphy and Drag-Up Drilling. One crane operator in a steelyard was James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion from 1935 to 1937, when he lost the crown to Joe Louis.

title: Scenes of Protest in Hong Kong
description: In what may be the biggest demonstration in a decade, hundreds of thousands of people marched in Hong Kong to demand greater democracy.

title: An Even More Nuanced Breakdown of the Supreme Court
description: Last week, my colleagues Adam Liptak and Hannah Fairfield wrote about the divisions among Supreme Court justices. In showing the justices on a spectrum from more to less liberal, they found a series of clusters, a few loners and several telling gaps, not a steady progression from left to right.

title: Twitter Names Ex-Goldman Banker Anthony Noto as Chief Financial Officer
description: Updated with details on compensation package.

title: Amanda Knox Co-Defendant Changes Strategy
description: ROME  In the long-running courtroom drama of the Amanda Knox case, her co-defendant and former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, was relegated by the news media to a minor role, eclipsed by the attention focused on Ms. Knox, a pretty 21-year-old American who captured the public spotlight.

title: Big Bowl With Spicy Brown Bean, Squash and Corn Succotash
description: If you have a problem liking succotash, its probably because of the lima beans, which have a mealy consistency that is not to everybodys taste. Whats not to like, though, if you use another bean? Pintos or borlottis are great, and Good Mother Stallards from Rancho Gordo are luxurious. This succotash has some spice to it, a nice contrast to the sweet corn. Make sure to hold onto the bean broth. I like bulgur with this, but any grain will work.

title: G.M. Sales Rise as Buyers Ignore Recalls
description: It has been a mystery in the auto industry in recent months: How can General Motors, embroiled in a safety crisis that has led to the recall of about 29 million vehicles worldwide this year, continue to have such strong sales?

title: Ruling in Cannibal Case Revives Debate Over When a Fantasy Crosses a Criminal Line
description: In his mind and online persona, Gilberto Valle left little doubt about the depths of his depravation: In communications over the Internet, he imagined subjecting women he knew to sex-related torture and, in some cases, murder and cannibalism.

title: Online, the Lying Is Easy
description: Charles Seife is a pop historian who writes about mathematics and science, but his abiding theme, the topic that makes his heart leap like one of Jules Feiffers dancers in the springtime, is human credulity.

title: Learned Macroeconomic Helplessness
description: One of the oddest, most frustrating things about the six years plus since the Great Recession began is the incessant whining from pundits that its all very complicated, and nobody knows what to do. As Dean Baker says, the story of this slump is remarkably simple; I would give more role to household debt than he does, but basically yes, its a huge slump in housing. Heres residential investment as a percentage of GDP:

title: Two-Bean and Tuna Salad
description: Ive always had a weakness for tuna and bean salad. This one, because I used luxurious Good Mother Stallard beans from Rancho Gordo, is quite the most amazing version of the salad Ive ever tasted. If you want to use a more commonly available bean for it, use pintos or borlottis, but cook them yourself instead of using canned. Then you can use some of the broth in the dressing and the beans themselves will taste better because youre in control of the seasonings. The nutritional values here are based on tuna canned in water, but you could always use tuna in olive oil for a richer version.

title: 1964: Luebke Is Re-elected in Berlin
description: BONN  Heinrich Luebke, 69, was overwhelmingly elected today [July 1] to a second five-year term as president of West Germany. The outcome was never in doubt because the former cabinet minister had been endorsed by both major parties, the ruling Christian Democrats and the opposition Social Democrats. The election, held in West Berlin despite strong Soviet and East German objections, reaffirmed West Germanys insistence that the divided city is the real capital of Germany and some day will serve as such for a reunited nation.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 2, 1964.

title: Tostadas With Smashed Black Beans or Vaqueros, Salsa Fresca and Avocado
description: I have always had a weakness for black bean tostadas. These are not unlike Oaxacan tlayudas, though this recipe doesnt call for that dishs signature extra-large corn tortillas. I used luxurious black and white vaqueros from Rancho Gordo for these, but black beans will also work well. Cook them yourself (dont use canned), because youll need the delicious broth. I dont refry them for as long as I normally would because I like them moist, and vaqueros are starchier than black beans.

title: G.O.P. Power Broker in Albany Accused of Lying to F.B.I.
description: State Senator Thomas W. Libous is a natural in Albanys clubby corridors, a world away from the family grocery store in Binghamton, N.Y., where he worked growing up.

title: Argentina vs. Switzerland: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Lionel Messi is tied for the Golden Boot with four goals. The Swiss gave up just six goals in 10 qualifying matches; they have given up six in just three games at the Cup. More Messi goals to come?

title: Teenager Topples Top-Ranked Nadal in Round of 16
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Until the evening shadows fell on Centre Court on Tuesday, the last time a teenager beat a No. 1 player at a mens Grand Slam event was at the 2005 French Open. The winner then was Rafael Nadal, over Roger Federer, days after Nadals 19th birthday.

title: I Am the Real Nick Cave
description: I went to Graceland once, Nick Cave said. The rest of the band went in, but I stayed out on the curb, smoking cigarettes and feeling sorry for myself. Those last Elvis performances  the ones for television, when he was already sick  I must have watched those clips a hundred times. Theyre like crucifixions. He paused for a moment. I couldnt bring myself to go inside.

title: In Store | A.P.C. Sets Up Shop at the Wythe Hotel
description: The Wythe Hotel has established itself as more than a place to stay in Williamsburg. Last month, it set up a chapel on the roof, where gay couples were married over the weekend during New Yorks Pride Week. And of course theres the locations shop, whose wares change every several months and are usually curated by a local designer or brand. Beginning today, however, the Brooklyn boutique will open the doors to an assortment curated by its first international retailer: the French brand A.P.C.

title: Arugula and Corn Salad With Roasted Red Peppers and White Bean
description: Since you dont need a broth for this composed salad, canned beans will work, though I always prefer the flavor of beans Ive cooked myself. I like to use a white bean, either a cannellini or a navy bean. Ive always loved sweet corn with pungent arugula. I combine the two for a salad bed, which I top with the roasted peppers and beans. So the dish is really two salads, one on top of the other.

title: New York Summer Stories: Getting Out of Town
description: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archive that tell tales of New York City summers past.

title: Facebook Flunks Its Apology
description: Ok so,beginsAdam D.I. Kramers apology for Facebooks recentexperimenton its users feelings. Mr. Kramer, a data scientist at Facebook, went on to explain the experiment in greater detail (Facebook altered some users news feeds, then analyzed the emotional content of their later posts) and to say, my coauthors and I are very sorry for the way the paper described the research and any anxiety it caused.

title: World Cup 2014: Penalty Kick Strategy
description: Midfielder Kyle Beckerman demonstrates his penalty kick strategy, which he says is all about trusting yourself. On the other side of the ball, goalkeeper Nick Rimando says he aims to react, not guess.

title: NASA Delays Launching of Carbon Observatory
description: The launching of NASAs Orbiting Carbon Observatory-2 spacecraft was called off on Tuesday morning, with 46 seconds left in the countdown, when equipment on the launching pad malfunctioned.

title: Wheelies: The Flying Honda Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: American Homes Acquires Rival in Buy-to-Rent Business
description: In what could be the start of a wave of consolidation in the business of buying single-family homes to rent them out, American Homes 4 Rent, one of the largest institutional investors in foreclosed homes, said on Tuesday that it was buying a smaller competitor.

title: Saudi Arabia Donates $500 Million to Help Displaced Iraqis
description: Answering criticism with cash, Saudi Arabia on Tuesday swooped in to address the humanitarian crisis caused by the Sunni insurgency in Iraq, providing $500 million to the United Nations to help the more than one million Iraqis whose lives have been uprooted by the mayhem of recent weeks.

title: The N.S.A. Can Spy on These 193 Foreign Governments
description: The Washington Post has published a 2010 government document indicating that the National Security Agency was authorized, by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, to intercept information concerning 193 foreign governments. According to The Post, the N.S.A. can intercept through U.S. companies not just the communications of its overseas targets but any communications about its targets as well.

title: Whos a Christian? Avoiding Labels in the Hobby Lobby Coverage
description: I heard from several thoughtful readers who object to The Timess description of the owners of two companies in the news because of a major Supreme Court decision on Monday. (The companies are Hobby Lobby and Conestoga Wood Specialties.) That decision said that requiring such family-owned corporations to pay for insurance covering birth control was a violation of federal law protecting religious freedom.

title: Penalties for Companies, but Executives Often Emerge Unscathed
description: Before BNP Paribas pleaded guilty to violating United States economic sanctions laws, the banks chief executive, Jean-Laurent Bonnaf, said in a message to employees that malfunctions have occurred and mistakes were made. It was much more than that, costing to the bank nearly $9 billion. But even then, the misconduct leading to that kind of penalty did not result in criminal charges against any individuals.

title: Flame Retardants Are Everywhere
description: Just over 10 years ago, Dr. Arnold Schecter, a public health researcher in Texas, started finding traces of chemical flame retardants in the breast milk of American women. It appeared that the compounds were carried into the milk from fat in the mothers bodies.

title: Maria Sharapova Ousted by Angelique Kerber at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England  For three grueling sets, Angelique Kerber would not be bullied. In the most exhausting test of her endurance, along with her character, she would not be beaten.

title: 4 Are Rescued Days After Building Collapse in South India
description: NEW DELHI  Four people were rescued on Tuesday from the rubble of a 12-story building on the outskirts of the southern Indian city of Chennai that collapsed three days before. One of them was a 27-year-old man who got up and walked away from the site on his own once he was freed.

title: The Illogic of Employer-Sponsored Health Insurance
description: Imagine yourself in a bar where a pickpocket takes money out of your wallet and with it buys you a glass of chardonnay. Although you would have preferred a pinot noir, you decide not to look that gift horse in the mouth and thank the stranger profusely for the kindness, assuming he paid for it. You might feel differently, of course, if you knew that you actually had paid for it yourself.

title: Orwell Birthplace in India to Become a Museum
description: The ramshackle three-room bungalow in Motihari, India where George Orwell was born in 1903 is being restored and transformed into a museum that will celebrate the life and career of the essayist and author, The Times of India reported. The renovation, which has been under discussion since 2010, when the house was declared a protected site, is being underwritten by the government of Bihar state, which is hoping the museum will become a tourist attraction. Motihari is in northeastern India, near the border of Nepal. Orwell, who was born Eric Arthur Blair, was born there while his father, Richard Blair, was posted in Bihar as an employee of the Indian Civil Service, to supervise the production of opium for export to China.

title: Q & A: Chocolate Ganache
description: The cookbook author Dorie Greenspan and Julia Moskin of the Dining section discussed making chocolate ganache with you, our readers. (The master recipe for chocolate is here.) Their replies to questions and comments from readers are below.

title: Former Newspaper Editor to Oversee Pulitzer Prizes
description: The former editor of The Concord Monitor will oversee the Pulitzer Prizes, Columbia University announced on Tuesday.

title: Noisy Predators Put Plants on Alert, Study Finds
description: It has long been known that some plants can respond to sound. But why would a plant evolve the ability to hear? Now researchers are reporting that one reason may be to defend itself against predators.

title: American Soccer Fans Dominate FIFAs Online Audience
description: For many Americans, FIFA has long been a foreign-sounding jumble of letters rather than the organization behind the World Cup, the globes biggest sporting event. (Where is the S for soccer?)

title: Your World Cup Ethical Questions, Answered
description: Was Luis Surezs bite of an opponent any more unethical than other forms of direct harm, such as a stomp or a professional foul in which the risk of serious injury is more likely? Or does the fact that biting is viewed as uncivilized make it uniquely worse? JACK HIGGINS, posted on Facebook

title: Bonus All-World-Cup Ethicist Column!
description: In his most recent Ethicist column, Chuck Klosterman weighed in on whether its wrong to mention the result of a World Cup match in front of a friend who you know has recorded the game to watch later. We realized that this was just one of many fascinating questions raised by all the flopping, biting and cheering thats been going on since June 12. We asked what other ethical questions you had about the World Cup, and you submitted some great ones via Facebook, Twitter and email. Read Klostermans responses in this weeks bonus column.

title: Post Office to Release a Janis Joplin Stamp
description: Janis Joplin is about to join the small, but growing, pantheon of American musicians honored on postage stamps. On Tuesday, the United States Postal Service unveiled the design for its Joplin stamp, which is to go on sale in August. It is the fifth installment of the postal services Music Icons series, which also includes Johnny Cash, the Tejana star Lydia Mendoza and Ray Charles, all issued in 2013, and Jimi Hendrix, whose stamp was issued in March.

title: Clip: Tammy
description: Melissa McCarthy and Susan Sarandon in a scene from Tammy.

title: Thousands Beat Path to Queens Cemetery to Remember a Jewish Leader
description: The pilgrims had traveled from Montana and Helsinki, eastern Michigan and western Ukraine, waiting for the sun, hanging stubbornly above the Old Montefiore Cemetery in Queens, to disappear on Monday night.

title: Atmospheric Tunes from the Spring/Summer 2015 Paris Mens Shows
description: As is to be expected in Paris, where runway looks tend toward the experimental, most designers sent their clothes down the catwalks this season to the beat of atmospheric music by relatively obscure musicians and bands (the kind of songs you cant always Shazam). While some tracks, like Tuxedomoons Triumphant Procession at Comme des Garons Homme Plus, created a contemplative mood, other presentations showed a sense of humor in the form of lighter, more uplifting fare like Easy Easy by King Krule (at Carven) and LEau A La Bouche by Serge Gainsbourg (at Valentino).

title: Today in Small Business: Skip the Morning Meeting
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Rottapharm, an Italian Drug Maker,  Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Italian drug maker Rottapharm said on Tuesday that it expected an initial public offering of its shares later this month to value the company at up to 1.8 million euros, or about $2.46 billion.

title: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Mens Spring/Summer 2015 Fashion Week Take Their Bows
description: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows  some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above  of 11 fashion visionaries.

title: The Secret of Belgiums Success
description: No, not about soccer. But since were talking about Belgium, a little-known fact is that the Belgian economy has actually done considerably better than its neighbors since the crisis began:

title: Curtain Call | Paris Mens Fashion Week
description: To mark the conclusion of Spring/Summer 2014 Fashion Week, we catalog the bows  some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above  of 11 fashion visionaries.

title: Ever True to You, Local Parlor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Emily Appel, 28, is in charge of spinning the well-regarded burnt caramel ice cream here at Toscaninis, where both the ice cream and the memories are so thick, they could make even an M.I.T. engineer weep.

title: U.S.A. vs. Belgium: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Largely outplayed in group competition, the United States still has a shot against Belgium, which is undefeated since World Cup qualifying began.

title: An Ailing Serena Williams Abandons a Doubles Match
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It was clear Serena Williams was in trouble before the first point of her doubles match Tuesday at Wimbledon.

title: Fresh Ink for the Human Canvas
description: If you are thinking about getting a tattoo, or adding another one to the half-dozen or so you already have, the options of what are available may have multiplied since the last time you visited your tattoo parlor.

title: Pershing Square Said to Hire Credit Suisse for Allergan Fight
description: Updated, 3:48 p.m. | Wall Street banks tend to defend companies against activist investors. But at least one bulge-bracket institution has aligned itself with William A. Ackman, one of the biggest dissident shareholders around, as he takes on the Botox maker Allergan.

title: T.S.A. Fees for Air Trips to Rise
description: While airfares fluctuate constantly with demand, competition and fuel prices, at least one constant in pricing is set to rise: T.S.A. fees.

title: Nets General Manager Wants to Move Quickly to Replace Jason Kidd
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A day after officially cutting ties with Jason Kidd, Nets General Manager Billy King said that he would not consider Kidds actions to be a personal affront and that he had already taken steps to move on.

title: Russell Westbrook Moves Between Oklahoma City and Paris With Ease
description: PARIS  In the last several years, a clutch of National Basketball Association players  like Carmelo Anthony, Tyson Chandler and Dwyane Wade  have emerged as darlings of the fashion world, showing up in the front rows of fashion shows in New York, Paris and Milan, and being featured in photo spreads in magazines such as GQ and Vogue.

title: In BNP Paribas Case, an Example of How Mighty the Dollar Is
description: Even if you are a bank as gigantic as BNP Paribas, $9 billion is a lot of money. Shareholders of the French bank know that all too well, as that is what they are paying in penalties to the United States for a conspiracy to allow money transfers to Sudan and other blacklisted nations.

title: Hong Kong Challenges Beijing
description: On Tuesday, hundreds of thousands of people held one of the largest marches in Hong Kongs history to demand democracy.

title: Graco Recalls 1.9 Million Rear-Facing Infant Seats
description: Under pressure from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Graco Childrens Products has agreed to recall about 1.9 million rear-facing infant seats with a faulty buckle that can make it difficult to free a child during an emergency.

title: Messi, as Always Expected, Rescues Argentina
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Lionel Messi is often the smallest player on the field. But it is clear that he possesses his own gravitational pull.

title: A Straw Purchaser Goes to Jail
description: On Christmas Eve, 2012  less than two weeks after the gun massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School  William Spengler, Jr., 62, shot and killed two firefighters and wounded two others, whom he had lured to his home in Webster, N.Y., by starting a fire. He also wounded an off duty police officer who was driving by. In the hours that followed, shots were exchanged with police, seven houses burned down and Mr. Spengler shot and killed himself. In the burnt debris of his home, police later found the remains of his 67-year old sister, Cheryl, whom he also had shot and killed.

title: The Culture Wars Sore Winners
description: After following some of the more intemperate liberal reactions to the Supreme Courts Hobby Lobby decision yesterday, I thought of this post from Mother Joness Kevin Drum from earlier this year, making the case for a liberalism that owns up to its own culture-war aggressions and success:

title: Compromise at the Supreme Court Veils Its Rifts
description: WASHINGTON  Two very different group portraits of the Supreme Court emerged this term, one familiar and one unexpected.

title: Distracted Diva: The Second Screen Goes to the Opera
description: Do two instances mean the start of a trend  or is it still just an experiment? In June, On Site Opera, a small New York company, presented a production of Rameaus Pygmalion, at which operagoers were encouraged to use Google Glass,the eyeglasslike computer, onto which a translation of the libretto was projected. It was by no means an amateur operation or a frivolous stunt: the technology used to project the subtitles to Google Glass was created by Figaro Systems, the company that makes the seat-back title panels used at the Metropolitan Opera, the Santa Fe Opera and other houses.

title: U.S. Accuses T-Mobile of Overbilling
description: WASHINGTON  T-Mobile, which sees itself as a new kind of carrier, now stands accused of an old-fashioned practice  overbilling its customers.

title: HSBC Settles Fraud Charges Over Foreclosure Fees Paid by the U.S. Government
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Tuesday announced a $10 million settlement with the British bank HSBC, accusing it of fraud over the way it submitted fees to the government when foreclosing on homeowners.

title: Funeral Held for Slain Israeli Teenager
description: Shirel Shaar, the sister of one of the Israeli teenagers killed, and Yair Lapid, the Israeli finance minister, spoke at the funeral for Gilad Shaar in Talmon in the West Bank.

title: Census Considers How to Measure a More Diverse America
description: When Alexa Aviles received her census form in 2010, she was frustrated by the choices. Like all Hispanics, Ms. Aviles, a Puerto Rican who lives in Brooklyn, was first asked to identify her ethnicity and then to answer a question about her race. Ms. Aviles, 41, who works for a nonprofit, thought, Im all of these! In annoyance, she checked Hispanic, and then identified herself as white, black and some other race.

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week One | 21st-Century Concentration Camps
description: For the fifth summer in a row were posing a simple question to teenagers each Friday: What interested you most in The Times this week?

title: Barclays Rehires Tim Luke, an Adviser to Britains Prime Minister
description: Barclays said on Tuesday that it was rehiring Tim Luke, an adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, as a senior banker for its technology, media and telecommunications group.

title: Tinder Is Target of Sexual Harassment Lawsuit
description: Whitney Wolfe, a former executive at the popular dating start-up Tinder, has filed a lawsuit against the company, along with its majority owner, IAC/InterActiveCorp, on sexual harassment and discrimination claims.

title: Prescription Overdose Deaths in Florida Plunge After Tougher Measures, Report Says
description: Prescription drug overdose deaths in Florida fell sharply after the state began strengthening its prescribing laws and stepping up enforcement. Federal researchers said Tuesday that it was one of the first significant documented declines in the nation since the epidemic of prescription drug abuse took hold more than a decade ago.

title: One Goal, Three Perspectives
description: See Germanys goal against the United States from the perspectives of the goalkeeper, a defender and the kicker.

description: A popular destination on the North Carolina coastline dedicated to rescuing and rehabilitating injured sea turtles has relocated, expanded and reopened to the public.

description: To Anticipate: A Shop Finds a Space To Match Its Name

title: Rangers Begin Makeover Only Weeks From Stanley Cup Finals
description: A few weeks after reaching the Stanley Cup finals, the Rangers are a changed team. Enter the 15-year veteran defenseman Dan Boyle and forward Tanner Glass. Exit forwards Brian Boyle and Benoit Pouliot, and defenseman Anton Stralman.

title: Print Matters | In Honor of the World Cup, Three Beautiful Independent Sports Journals
description: Since the World Cup kicked off in Brazil two weeks ago, soccer fever has gripped New Yorkers to a surprising degree. In honor of todays U.S.-Belgium match, a do-or-die affair for the American squad, we take a look at three beautiful N.Y.C.-based sports journals.

title: For Singer, Boundaries Are There to Be Ignored
description: Beck ended the main portion of his show at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday with the evenings only true bit of shtick, unspooling a roll of yellow police tape across the length of the stage. He and his band had just rampaged through E-Pro  a decade-old tune with a nasty guitar riff, its chorus indistinguishable from a playground taunt  and a residual growl of feedback accompanied him in his task. Crime Scene Do Not Cross, advised the tape, inviting a moments reflection on the subject of enforced boundaries and willful transgressions, the crossing of lines and purposes.

description: Headliner

title: U.S. Justice Seems to Fall Harder on Foreign Companies
description: Uncle Sam is cooking up penalties with an anti-foreign flavor. New research suggests that overseas firms like BNP Paribas do in fact pay bigger fines and plead guilty more often than United States companies. One reason may be that prosecutors single out only the most serious cases abroad. But the differences feed suspicions that the United States is playing favorites.

title: Simona Halep Takes Away Zarina Diyass Forehand
description: WIMBLEDON, England  There are many weapons on a tennis court, and the ability to disarm an opponent is as good as it gets.

title: Festival of New Musicals Announces Its Roster
description: The Tony Award-winning playwright David Henry Hwang, the composer Adam Gwon and the composing duo Michael Kooman and Christopher Dimond are among the names represented in this years Festival of New Musicals, produced by the National Alliance for Musical Theater, a national nonprofit organization.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called on congressional Republicans on Tuesday to take quick action to fund infrastructure projects throughout the country, arguing that failing to do so could mean huge layoffs for Americans this year.

description: Simon Wren-Lewis is harsh about the current tight-money crowd, exemplified by the Bank for International Settlements, who are urging tight money despite weak economies, for fear that investors will take excessive risks. But hes not harsh enough.

title: Bees, Brews and Boutiques in Cape May, N.J.
description: Long known for its Victorian bed-and-breakfasts, this historic seaside resort in recent years has seen its once-faded grande dame hotels and low-slung motels get stylish makeovers. Cabanas with beachside refreshment service can now be found a few steps from old-time arcades. As the area increasingly attracts young, affluent visitors, a new generation of proprietors is bringing tastefully appointed boutiques, organic-food shops and laid-back restaurants to the mix.

title: Restaurant Report: Masala Library in Mumbai
description: Are ultramodern molecular gastronomy techniques compatible with a culinary tradition steeped in centuries of history? Thats what Jiggs Kalra, the renowned chef from Mumbai, India, set out to discover in October when he opened Masala Library, his temple of new-age Indian cuisine.

description: Photos from Ukraine, the West Bank, Kosovo and South Africa.

description: At the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, the president urged Congress to replenish the Highway Trust Fund, which reimburses states for their infrastructure projects.

description: OTTAWA  The age when rail travel dominated in Canada has long passed. But the railway-built hotels that era left behind have retained much of the glory and glamour of that period.

description: Mr. Valle had been charged with kidnapping conspiracy and illegally gaining access to a law enforcement database. He was convicted in 2013 but had not yet been sentenced.

description: The United States Marshals Service announced on Tuesday that one bidder had won all of the nearly 30,000 Bitcoins auctioned on Friday.

title: To Strut (and Leap) on a Stage
description: There is no ballet danced better by American Ballet Theater than Frederick Ashtons 52-minute The Dream, 50 years old this year. This is remarkable for three particular reasons. First: The Dream  which on the surface seems a quaint study in Victoriana  is a flawless ballet, deeply witty, intricate and eloquent, full of complex challenges to its dancers, a piece that rewards countless re-viewings.

title: An Uncoiling of Energy and Urgency, Sans Venom
description: The first thing the Agalloch frontman John Haughm does at the beginning of concerts is light incense at the foot of the stage. On Monday night at Irving Plaza, he did that just as (serpens caput), a mesmerizing little goth-folk guitar breather from the bands new album, The Serpent & the Sphere (Profound Lore), was pouring out of the speakers.

title: Popular For a Reason
description: Its summer blockbuster season, so a popular subject of scorn is upon us: the latest Transformers movie. But all the scorn in the world, argues Jeff Nesbit at U.S. News & World Report, will not dissuade us from paying to watch giant robots attack one another. And believe it or not, the large and loud may appeal to something deep within us.

title: Paul Mazursky Dies at 84; Director Showed Me Eras Strength and Foibles
description: Paul Mazursky, an innovative director and screenwriter who both satirized and sympathized with Americas panorama of social upheavals in the late 1960s and 70s in films that included Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice, Blume in Love and An Unmarried Woman, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: When Life Offers Lemons, Zest Them
description: How do you solve a problem like Melissa McCarthy? That question feels inescapable after watching her try to powerlift Tammy, her newest and least funny comedy, all by her lonesome. Ms. McCarthy plays the title bad-luck gal who, shortly after the movie opens, hits a deer and is hit in return, walks away from her broken-down car and into the rest of her tumbledown life. Repeatedly knocked down throughout this knockabout comedy, Tammy takes a licking and keeps on sticking her foot right back in it. Shes a total loser, except in the comedy of misfortune.

title: Chinas Hurdle to Fast Action on Climate Change
description: When the Environmental Protection Agency published in June its new rules to combat carbon emissions from power plants, the American political class lit up in debates over what this meant for the countrys carbon emissions, its coal industry and its economic growth.

As if the United States would never go down, standing there, taking shots like an undersize fighter clinging desperately to a punchers chance. Howard saved with his hands. His feet. His legs. His knees. At one point, Howard even had a shot bounce off the crest over his heart.

description: When I was 17, I had a summer job making ice cream at Peters on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. It was a cinch. You poured the milky contents of a container labeled base into the machine, added your flavorings (chocolate, vanilla, kiwi or what have you) and turned the switch.

description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has throat cancer and will begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, he said in a note to the banks employees and shareholders late Tuesday.

title: Bacon, and a Bed, Sell Well at Christies  London Auction
description: LONDON  It was another buoyant night for postwar and contemporary art at Christies auction here on Tuesday night, and it was, in many ways, an echo of Sothebys sale the evening before. Both salesrooms were overflowing with collectors, predominately from America and Asia, bidding briskly for classic paintings. Even the two artists who brought the top prices were the same  Francis Bacon and Peter Doig.

title: Adopting Tools of Protest for a Level Playing Field
description: In the quest for park equity, many residents in poor neighborhoods have seemed to have little recourse for the sorry state of their cracked basketball courts and out-of-service bathrooms.

title: Advocacy Group Sues 4 Universities in Challenge to Policies It Says Curb Free Speech
description: LOS ANGELES  Arguing that free speech is being stifled at college campuses across the country, a Philadelphia-based advocacy group on Tuesday filed lawsuits against four universities, seeking to force the schools to revise policies that the group says restrict some forms of speech.

title: Justice for Blacks and Whites
description: WASHINGTON  THE Civil Rights Act of 1964, which banned discrimination in public accommodations, employment and federally funded activities like education, would not have passed without the support of House and Senate Republicans who were competing for black votes. And Presidents Kennedy and Johnson would not have advocated for the bill without being pressured to do so by a multiracial grass-roots movement.

title: The Ukrainian Crisis Reaches a New Level
description: President Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine took the fateful step late Monday of ending his unilateral cease-fire in the struggle with separatists in eastern Ukraine, declaring: We will attack and liberate our land. The attacks began shortly after, moving the Ukrainian crisis to a highly dangerous but unavoidable level. Dangerous because Ukrainian forces are woefully ill-equipped and ill-trained to fight what is essentially a civil war, in which Ukrainian civilians are bound to be casualties; unavoidable because neither the rebels nor Russia ever took seriously the negotiations with Kiev and Western mediators. In effect, the long-building showdown has begun, and it is essential for the West to shed any illusions about what is at stake.

title: Give Scotusblog a Seat in Court
description: At a few minutes past 10 a.m. on Monday, as the Supreme Court began to issue the final rulings of the term, 60,000 people  including journalists at major news outlets around the country  were following the live feed of Scotusblog, a website devoted to covering every warp and woof of the courts complex litigation. Since its inception in 2002, the site has become required reading for Supreme Court news and analysis, winning multiple awards.

title: Neomonetarist Delusions
description: Danny Vinik notes that reform conservatives, who are trying either to rescue the right from its intellectual torpor or to provide cover for its fundamental anti-intellectualism  your choice  have gotten a fair bit of lip service for some of their ideas, but none at all for one key proposal: activist monetary policy to assure full employment.

title: Many Sharp Turns in Bergdahls Path to Army
description: KETCHUM, Idaho  In 2003, the year he turned 17, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl left his mark on the wet cement floor of the Strega Tea Bar Gallery and Cafe, a swirling design signed with a florid B. The drawing is a lasting statement that this liberal-tinctured ski resort town, where he took ballet and fencing lessons, met artists and debated philosophy, had become his second home.

title: Gov. Cuomos Plan to Fight AIDS in New York
description: New York City was ravaged by AIDS after the first cases were reported more than 30 years ago, and the plague soared to about 14,000 new cases in the state and nearly 8,000 deaths a year in the city in the early 1990s. Since then, medication and prevention programs have lowered new infections with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, to about 3,000 a year and far fewer deaths. Now Gov. Andrew Cuomo has announced that he wants New York to reduce new infections to 750 by 2020, about the same as the number of new tuberculosis cases each year.

title: Fair Compensation for G.M.s Victims
description: Kenneth Feinberg, the lawyer who oversaw the Sept. 11, 2001, victims fund, has outlined a pretty good plan to compensate people for the deaths and injuries caused by a defective ignition switch that General Motors used in 2.6 million cars. If implemented properly, the plan could speed payments to victims and their families, some of whom have waited years for G.M. to even acknowledge the defect, without forcing them to sue the company.

title: Canadian Antispam Law Whips Up a Storm of Last-Minute Messages
description: OTTAWA  The email has all the markings of malicious spam: an overwrought subject line screaming Urgent Action Required, a message directing the recipient to click a mysterious link.

title: Argentine Fans Feel Right at Home
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Tens of thousands of soccer fans came from all parts of Argentina. It does not matter that there were no tickets left for the match. This seemed an irrelevance. The main thing was to have been here, and to have witnessed Argentina take on Switzerland.

title: People of Influence
description: You cant make this up. The Guardian reported on Sunday that Ukrainians have crowdfunded the first peoples drone to help their army stem infiltration by Russian-supported rebels in Ukraines eastern provinces that border Russia. Last week, Ukraines crowdfunding site The Peoples Project said that it had received enough donations to fund a drone, The Guardian reported. The organizers had originally hoped to buy a state-of-the-art Israeli drone  for $165,000  or a cheaper American one costing $120,000. In the end, however, they managed to build the drone for just $35,000. A designer and other volunteers built the airframe, with a Ukrainian military institute chipping in technical equipment.

title: Union Dues and the Court
Dov Charney Fights to Regain Control of American Apparel
description: Dov Charney, the ousted chief of American Apparel, is forcing a stunning showdown with the companys board, full of twists and turns that few could have predicted when he was fired just two weeks ago.

description: TWO years after GoDaddy began moving away from sexually provocative advertising that sharply divided consumers, the company is seeking to help accelerate the shift with a change in creative agencies.

description: The former Washington mayor reflects on his life and his new memoir.

title: Hobby Lobby Is Only the Beginning
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  THE United States Constitution speaks of the Supreme Courts jurisdiction over cases and controversies. But when social controversies do come before the court, its powers are limited. In Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, which concerned the dispute over the Affordable Care Acts contraceptive mandate, the court may have decided the case. The larger controversy, however, wont be settled so easily.

title: Nutrition Group Lobbies Against Healthier School Meals It Sought, Citing Cost
description: WASHINGTON  When the Obama administration in 2012 announced long-awaited changes to require more fruits and vegetables and less sugar and salt in government-subsidized school meals, no group celebrated more than the School Nutrition Association.

description: Seated at the wheel of his nine-year-old Saturn on Tuesday morning, the engine running, the drivers side window broken into a million pieces, Aharon Charnov patiently spoke into his cellphone.

title: Twitters Revolving Door Spins Again
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitters chief executive, Dick Costolo, has replaced virtually every crucial executive at the company in the last few months as he has struggled to figure out how to get more people using the service.

title: Tourists on Trial in a North Korea Angry at the U.S.
description: North Koreas decision to put two detained American tourists on trial for unexplained hostile acts may have nothing to do with what they did, and instead could reflect the isolated nations frustration that it is no longer viewed as a front-burner issue for the United States, experts on North Korean behavior said on Tuesday.

title: Limits to Books in Prison Draw Creative Foes
description: LONDON  Jailed for making false expense claims, Denis MacShane, a former British lawmaker, suffered another blow when he arrived last December at Belmarsh prison, a grim penitentiary in southeast London, and staff members confiscated the bag of books he had brought.

title: In Once-Mighty A.L. East, Everyone Can Dream
description: Tanyon Sturtze had just finished golfing in Florida on Tuesday when he took a call about Derek Jeter. He was happy to talk. Sturtze pitched for 12 seasons in the majors, with seven teams, but people ask him more about Jeter than any other teammate.

title: Barry, Once Washingtons Mayor for Life, Tries to Shape Legacy With Autobiography
description: WASHINGTON  The City Council was considering whether to end a three-day waiting period for marriage licenses when Marion S. Barry Jr., a councilman who set the bar for bad mayoral behavior long before Rob Ford came along in Toronto, wondered if three days would be enough time for people to get blood tests.

title: BNP Paribas Guilty Plea Is Latest Big Settlement to Bolster New York States Fiscal Position
description: The financial crisis came at a huge cost to New York State. Thousands of jobs were lost, billions of dollars in revenue evaporated and the states reputation suffered a body blow. Now it seems the state is getting pretty good at recouping money from big financial institutions.

description: Puerto Ricos electrical utility is running out of money and time to negotiate a deal with its lenders, part of a broad reckoning for an island that relies on Wall Street to finance some of its most basic functions.

title: Public Schools in New York City Are Poorer and More Crowded, Budget Agency Finds
description: Schools in New York are becoming more congested, federal and state aid has dropped, and the number of students in temporary housing situations, including homeless shelters, has shot up, according to a report on the state of public education the citys budget oversight agency issued on Tuesday.

title: Anatoly Kornukov, Who Led Russian Air Force, Dies at 72
description: Gen. Anatoly Kornukov, a retired commander in chief of the Russian Air Force who in 1983 relayed the order to shoot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007 as it strayed into Soviet airspace, killing all 269 aboard, died on Tuesday in Krasnogorsk, near Moscow. He was 72.

description: The Chicago Bulls were prepared for Carmelo Anthonys arrival. Video boards outside the United Center featured Melo next to the teams logo. Huge depictions of Anthony wearing a Bulls uniform festooned the side of the building. It was apparent that with months to plan the festivities, the teams graphics department had been busy.

title: Deeply Divided Israel Unites in Grief and Sees a Larger Purpose
description: SHAALVIM, Israel  For many Israelis, Tuesday was a day when the national became the personal, and the personal became communal. A day after their bodies were found, the three Israeli teenagers who were kidnapped and killed by suspected Palestinian militants in the West Bank were buried side by side, wrapped in Israeli flags, in a joint funeral that was intimate and attended by a multitude.

title: Printed Points of View
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Dick Shlakman and Jeff Chen are back after Mr. Chen ably assisted Mr. Shlakman in his New York Times debut in February. At the time, Mr. Shlakman modestly admitted that Mr. Chen had done the lions share of the work and, indeed, Mr. Chens name was first in the byline. This time around, however, Mr. Shlakmans name is first, and it makes me wonder if thats a sign that hes acquiring the constructing skills needed to eventually publish under a solo byline. That would be great, because then I could finally use the headline Shlaks Blocks Rock Socks.

description: Tim Howard made his first save 43 seconds in and he ended the game with 16 saves, the most by a goalkeeper in the World Cup since 1966.

description: WASHINGTON  An independent audit of insurance exchanges established under the health care law has found that federal and state officials did not properly check the eligibility of people seeking coverage and applying for subsidies, the latest indication of unresolved problems at HealthCare.gov.

title: Lloyd Garrison, 83, Journalist; Covered Africa for The Times
description: Lloyd Garrison, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times who covered conflicts in Africa during the 1960s, including a secessionist war in Nigeria that resulted in more than a million deaths, died on June 21 at his home in Norfolk, Conn. He was 83.

title: A New Leader for Newark
Protesters in California Delay Transfer of Migrants
description: LOS ANGELES  Three buses carrying migrant families caught illegally crossing the Texas border with Mexico were turned away from a Southern California Border Patrol station on Tuesday afternoon when dozens of angry protesters met them with American flags and signs reading, Illegals out.

title: Yankees Could Use Price, but They May Not Be Able to Get Him
description: In the days before the luxury tax, and in an era when the Yankees farm system was flush with potential superstars, obtaining a former Cy Young Award winner like David Price seemed almost inevitable. Conceivably, the Yankees in those days could have acquired almost anybody they wanted.

title: Lillian B. Rubin, 90, Is Dead; Wrote of Crippling Effects of Gender and Class Norms
description: Lillian B. Rubin, a sociologist and psychotherapist who wrote a series of popular books about the crippling effects of gender and class norms on human potential, died June 17 at her home in San Francisco. She was 90.

title: Benghazi Suspect Said to Corroborate Important Details of Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  The militia leader who has been charged in connection with the 2012 killing of the United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, has provided American interrogators with voluntary statements that corroborate key facts about the attacks, the Justice Department said in a court document filed Tuesday night.

title: Envoy to Afghanistan and Pakistan Will Leave Post
description: WASHINGTON  James F. Dobbins, the veteran diplomat who has served as the United States special envoy for Afghanistan and Pakistan, is leaving government this month, following a tumultuous year in which the Obama administration settled on a plan for withdrawing American forces from Afghanistan but ran into a roadblock in trying to pursue peace talks with the Taliban.

title: Protesters in Hong Kong Confront Beijing Over Elections
description: Huge crowds of demonstrators took to the streets of Hong Kong on Tuesday to express their support for democracy and discontent with the Chinese central governments desire to control how the territorys chief executive is elected.

title: Factors Supporting Khattalas Detention
description: Federal prosecutors argued that Ahmed Abu Khattala should remain in custody until trial because he posed a continued threat to the United States.

title: France: European Rights Court Upholds French Ban on Veils
description: The European Court of Human Rights has upheld a French ban on wearing face-covering veils in public, rejecting arguments that the measure violates religious freedoms and bolstering opponents of strict Islamic dress in other parts of Europe. The ban, which took effect three years ago, set French authorities on a collision course with conservative Muslims who said the wearing of such veils by women was an obligation of their faith. Judges at the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, said Tuesday that the ban was a legitimate attempt to preserve the norms of Frances diverse society and that it did not infringe on Europes Convention on Human Rights. The court was ruling on a case brought by an unidentified Frenchwoman who said the law was discriminatory and violated her freedom of conscience. The 24-year-old woman, a college graduate, requested anonymity for fear of reprisals if her identity became known. France was the first country in Europe to enact such a ban, followed by Belgium.

title: After Retreat, Iraqi Soldiers Fault Officers
description: AIN AL-TAMR, Iraq  The forlorn scenes in the ancient Al-Ukhaidir fortress tell of a government force in deep disarray. Flies circle beneath its high ceilings, above dozens of demoralized men who pass the day sleeping on dusty stone floors.

title: Christian Fhrer, East German Whose Prayers Inspired Protests, Dies at 71
description: BERLIN  The Rev. Christian Fhrer, the pastor in the denim vest whose prayer meetings for peace grew into mass demonstrations in 1989 that inspired East Germans to take to the streets to demand their right to freedom, died on Monday in Leipzig, Germany. He was 71.

title: Wimbledon Mixed Doubles Team Takes a Partnership to Heart
description: WIMBLEDON, England  On Sunday, a relentless drizzle peppered the All England Club for a third successive afternoon, but on the practice courts little could dampen the spirits of Martin Emmrich and Michaella Krajicek, the German-Dutch mixed doubles partners who became engaged two weeks ago.

title: The Light and Luxurious Look for the Fourth of July
description: Dressing for the Fourth of July, its easy to get lost in the red-white-and-blue stars and stripes mindset, or wrapped up in the sea of colorful summery prints. But opting for a few simple, neutral pieces with subtle graphic touches will keep things light and luxurious, and make for more of a statement this weekend against the backdrop of star-spangled fireworks. A tame terry cloth cape from Lisa Marie Fernandez adds drama when layered over simple swimsuits, like this maillot from Eres. Calm separates and accessories  two-toned sandals, a basic tote  round out a minimalist look. And an oversize but understated piece of jewelry, like this cuff from Cline, is just enough to pull it all together.

title: In the Hills of Mexico, Patrn Processes Agave the Old-School Way
description: Patrn Spirits International distills small batches of premium tequila and tequila-based liquors at its rambling hacienda in Atotonilco, a small town in Mexicos hilly Jalisco region thats crawling with Weber Blue agave, a key ingredient for the local tequila industry there. Since 1989, the companys co-founders, Martin Crowly and John Paul DeJoria (of John Paul Mitchell Systems Hair Care Company), and its master distiller, Francisco Alcaraz, have crafted high-end tipples like the amber-tinted Patrn Aejo that today are distributed to 120 countries around the world. Recently, they opened the doors to the Hacienda de Patrn distillery, erected in 2002 and closed to the public ever since, for a behind-the-scenes look at how its small-batch products are made, including a new range of 100 percent agave tequilas being released this month.

title: BlaBlaCar, a Ride-Sharing Start-Up in Europe, Looks to Expand Its Map
description: LONDON  In France, Charlotte Jurdieu has become part of the millions in the sharing economy.

title: Can Exercise Reduce Alzheimers Risk?
description: Exercise may help to keep the brain robust in people who have an increased risk of developing Alzheimers disease, according to an inspiring new study. The findings suggests that even moderate amounts of physical activity may help to slow the progression of one of the most dreaded diseases of aging.

description: stealth \stelth\ noun

title: Mets Cling to Glimmers of Hope After Loss to Braves
description: ATLANTA  Terry Collins sat slumped in a chair and looked down. The Mets had just lost to the Braves, 5-4, had fallen a season-worst 10 games below .500 and were now nine games behind the Braves, who were atop the National League East. Collins, the Mets manager, had just been asked how the team could save its season before it slipped away for good.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 7 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON (2008) Brad Pitt received an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of Benjamin Button, a man born in his 80s in 1918 New Orleans, who ages in reverse into the 21st century, in this adaptation of a short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cate Blanchett, above with Mr. Pitt, is Daisy, the dancer who loves Benjamin at whatever stage he is in. And Taraji P. Henson, who was also nominated, is the nursing home caretaker who raises him when his father abandons him. From Fitzgeralds odd, somewhat unpromising kernel, the director David Fincher and the screenwriter Eric Roth have cultivated a lush, romantic hothouse bloom, a film that shares only a title and a basic premise with its literary source, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that the film sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonists condition in a spirit that owes more to Jorge Luis Borges than to Fitzgerald.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 2, 2014
description: Japan is experiencing a security renaissance. What is remarkable is not that things are changing, but that they are changing with so little fanfare.

title: Arab Boys Death Escalates Clash Over Abductions
description: JERUSALEM  The abduction and killing of a Palestinian teenager whose burned body was found in a Jerusalem forest on Wednesday further poisoned relations between Israelis and Palestinians and prompted international outrage as the police investigated the death as a possible Israeli revenge killing.

title: In Hong Kong, a Potent Visual Echo of Tiananmen
description: Cecilia Ng was born seven years after the Goddess of Democracy statue in Tiananmen Square was destroyed during the bloody 1989 suppression of student-led protests. A quarter-century after the crackdown in Beijing, she and 10 of her friends made a smaller replica of the statue that on Tuesday was planted in the middle of one of central Hong Kongs busiest streets.

title: Time-Lapse Video Shows Steady Stream of Hong Kong Protesters
description: Just how many people participated in Hong Kongs pro-democracy march on Tuesday? As often is the case with protests, the number is a matter of dispute. Organizers say 510,000 people participated, while a Hong Kong police spokeswoman said only that a maximum of 98,600 joined the march at any given time, without giving an estimate for the overall total.

description: Test your knowledge of westward expansion by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: U.S. Vessel to Tote Poison Gas From Syria to Sea
description: ROME  A specially equipped United States vessel, the Cape Ray, loaded toxic chemicals at an Italian port on Wednesday for destruction at sea in the latest phase of an operation to remove and destroy about 1,300 tons of Syrian chemical weapons.

description: LONDON  The Swiss drug maker Roche Group said on Wednesday that it would pay up to $1.7 billion to acquire Seragon Pharmaceuticals, a privately held biotechnology firm focused on developing treatments for breast cancer.

description: In All Jooked Up With Everywhere to Go, Alastair Macaulay writes about jookin, a street dance born in Memphis.

title: Accusations Grotesque, Nicolas Sarkozy Says of Inquiry
description: PARIS  Hours after being put under formal investigation in a corruption and influence-peddling case, Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France, lashed out at the prosecution on Wednesday, saying again that he is innocent and expressing outrage at a case he said was being manipulated for political ends.

title: Wars Lingering Requiem in Vietnam
description: I was 13 when Saigon fell in 1975. I watched the evening news as the last American helicopter lifted off from the United States Embassy roof. In 1977, in the closet of a rented house, I discovered a pile of dusty Life magazines that pictured the Vietnam War: dust, heat, blood, tanks and helicopters, faces contorted with pain and desperation or just impenetrable. 1966, 1967, 1968. Tet, Hue, Khe Sanh, the Perfume River, Ben Tre, Dak To. Dates and names that grabbed and held.

title: Can the G.O.P. Be a Party of Ideas?
description: In May, a handful of prominent legislators gathered at a Beltway think tank, along with some writers and policy experts, to discuss, as the events organizers somberly put it, conservative policy options to further the prosperous society President Lyndon Johnson described in his Great Society address 50 years ago. If this seemed strange, the venue and cast were even stranger: the American Enterprise Institute, a bastion of right-leaning ideology, filled with Republicans, speaking in a language most unlike the one weve heard in recent years.

title: Destination Maternity Rebuffed Twice in Bid for British Retailer Mothercare
description: LONDON  Destination Maternity, the operator of A Pea in the Pod and Motherhood Maternity stores in the United States, said on Wednesday that it had been rebuffed twice recently in takeover approaches to Mothercare, a British retailer of maternity and childrens products.

title: Nestl to Sell Juicy Juice Brand to Brynwood Partners
description: LONDON  The food giant Nestl said on Wednesday that it would sell its Juicy Juice brand of fruit drinks to the buyout firm Brynwood Partners, a frequent buyer of the Swiss companys castoffs.

description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Security researchers have uncovered what they believe is a significant cybercrime operation in Brazil that took aim at $3.75 billion in transactions by Brazilians.

title: China Sees Long Road to Cleaning Up Pollution
description: A trickle of statements from Chinese leaders in recent months have given hope to some residents of Beijing and other smog-choked Chinese cities that they might regularly breathe clean air within a few years. Prime Minister Li Keqiang in March declared a war against pollution, for instance.

title: ING Group Raises $2 Billion in I.P.O. of Insurer NN Group
description: LONDON  The Dutch financial services company ING Group raised 1.5 billion euros, or about $2 billion, in the long-anticipated initial public offering for the NN Group, its European and Japanese insurance and investment management arm.

title: Morning Views
description: Kenneth Feinberg, the lawyer who oversaw the Sept. 11, 2001, victims fund, has outlined a pretty good plan to compensate people for the deaths and injuries caused by a defective ignition switch that General Motors used in 2.6 million cars, writes The New York Times editorial board. If implemented properly, the plan could speed payments to victims and their families, some of whom have waited years for G.M. to even acknowledge the defect. The fund will not satisfy everybody, the board writes, and G.M. could do more. No amount of money is ever going to be sufficient to compensate families for deaths or serious injuries. But that should not stop G.M. from doing all it can to help the people who have been hurt by its mistakes.

title: Oscar Pistorius at Increasing Risk of Suicide, Lawyer Says
description: LONDON  A psychologists report read by the defense at the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius on Wednesday said the disabled athlete  once a major draw at international track meets, including the Olympics  was at increasing risk of suicide without treatment for post-traumatic stress and depression brought on by the killing of his girlfriend last year.

title: How I Learned to Build and Appreciate a Good Board
description: When I started Posse, I knew nothing about company boards or their value. The family lawyer who helped establish our companies suggested that I create a board before I raised our first investment round and that I try to find some high profile people to join it. His objective was to make the team slide in my presentation deck look as impressive as possible. Off I went to enlist some big name folks to join my not-yet-established company.

title: Everyone Expects the Spanish Inquisition
description: LONDON  Something completely different was never going to be on the menu. The record-breaking ticket sales generated by the news that members of the fabled comedy team Monty Python would be reassembling here for a rare onstage reunion were surely not generated by hopes that the old boys had come up with new tricks.

title: Where the Christian Right Is Strong
description: The religious right remains one of the most potent forces in American politics, but Northeasterners could be forgiven for forgetting. Evangelical Christians and Mormons, the two religious groups who most consistently espouse conservative political and cultural views, are basically absent in the Northeastern corridor.

title: Assigning a Dollar Value to Being the Incumbent
description: What is an incumbency worth? About half a million dollars, mostly from business political action committees who know cementing ties to established politicians is a top priority.

title: Daily Report: Management Changes at Twitter Suggest a Company in Turmoil
description: Twitters chief executive, Dick Costolo, has replaced virtually every crucial executive at the company in the last few months as he has struggled to figure out how to get more people using the service, Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac report.

title: Uphill Fight for a Territorys Democracy Movement
description: HONG KONG  A pro-democracy march held Tuesday by a huge crowd of mostly young demonstrators showed the determination of many of this autonomous Chinese citys residents to preserve and expand the freedom they inherited from British rule. But it also brought to light more challenges that may lie ahead.

title: Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Chief Has Curable Cancer
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said on Tuesday in a note to the banks employees and shareholders that he had throat cancer and would begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, DealBooks Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. Doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage, Mr. Dimon said, noting that his condition was curable. Moreover, he said doctors had confirmed that the cancer had not spread beyond the original site and the adjacent lymph nodes on the right side of his neck. He described the prognosis from the doctors as excellent.

title: FinecoBank Shares Rise in Trading Debut in Italy
description: FinecoBank, an online banking and brokerage arm of the Italian lender UniCredit, made its debut on Wednesday on the Borsa Italiana in Milan after its initial public offering last week.

title: 1939: Americans See Faith on the Rise
description: NEW YORK  Dr. Henry C. Link, secretary and treasurer of the Psychological Corporation, which conducts surveys and advises on personnel, announced today [July 2] that more persons in the United States today thought that religion was gaining in influence than thought that it was losing, according to a nation-wide poll. Two years ago, he said, a survey showed that the situation was the other way around. An interesting sidelight which comes out of the study, Dr. Link reported, is that more people in the high than in the low income groups believe that religion is gaining, in influence.  New York Herald Tribune, July 3, 1939.

title: Ira Glasss This American Life Leaves PRI
description: Ira Glass had lost his voice. That gentle, reliably nasal, public radio staple of a voice had been worked hoarse. On any given day, this would be an issue for Mr. Glass, 55, whose award-winning show, This American Life, is broadcast on nearly 600 stations and is consistently the top podcast on iTunes.

title: European Regulators Sign Off on Telefnicas Deal for E-Plus
description: LONDON  European antitrust regulators on Wednesday signed off on the Spanish telecommunications giant Telefnicas long-awaited acquisition of Germanys smallest mobile operator, E-Plus.

title: Iraqi Premier Places Unity Second to Fighting ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi prime minister, in an apparent rebuff to his international critics, said Wednesday that finding a political settlement to the differences among the countrys factions was not as important or urgent as fighting extremist Sunni insurgents.

title: Crazy Love on the Platform
description: Dear Diary:

title: Feeling For | A Home Scenter That Design Aesthetes Can Appreciate
description: For those who consider fragrance an invisible form of art, the olfactive medium has suddenly become much more visible these days, with an influx of objets dart dedicated to perfuming the air. Now on display at Commune Design in Los Angeles: a rather rare trio of wooden scenters designed by the natural perfumer Haley Alexander van Oosten, the nose behind LOeil Du Vert. Crafted from vintage Douglas fir and redwood sourced from furniture makers and local dealers, each piece is entirely unique (as noted by the organic knots and cracks in the grain) and fastened with bronze and copper hardware. Inside, a handblown glass tube holds a custom aromatic oil, composed of California flora, amber and smoky notes, that transforms into a cold vapor to scent your environs.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Sugar-Free
description: The Challenge: A 53-year-old woman has episodes of confusion caused by big drops in her blood sugar. Can you figure out why?

title: Tyson Foods Reaches Formal Deal for Hillshire Brands
description: Tyson Foods formally struck a deal on Wednesday to buy Hillshire Brands for $7.7 billion, weeks after winning a quick bidding war for the company, which makes Jimmy Dean sausage.

title: Fast and Easy Photo Albums for Printing
description: Fast and Easy

title: Slain by a Samurai Who Covets a Wife
description: A love triangle, one of those timeless romantic woes right up there with unrequited devotion, is at the heart of Kaidan Chibusa no Enoki (The Ghost Tale of the Wet Nurse Tree), a 19th-century Japanese ghost story that begins a short run at the Lincoln Center Festival this week. It is the third festival visit by Heisei Nakamura-za, a Kabuki company from Tokyo started by Kanzaburo Nakamura XVIII, who was known for his vibrant and often funny influence on this traditional performance style. Mr. Kanzaburo died in 2012, and his two sons now run the company.

title: Winner of Bitcoin Auction, Tim Draper, Plans to Expand Currencys Use
description: Updated, 8:28 p.m. | When the government auctioned nearly 30,000 Bitcoins on Friday, many bidders were looking for a bargain, hoping to buy the virtual currency at a discount and flip it later for a short-term profit.

title: Whats News in Washington: Abu Khattala Appears Before Judge
description: Good Wednesday morning from an overheated Washington, where temperatures today could approach the century mark.

title: Named for Princess, Young Player May Yet Rule the Court
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The Canadian tennis player Eugenie Bouchard was named for a British princess by a mother with a fascination for the royal family. Twenty years later, that fateful decision has helped endear Bouchard to the fans at Wimbledon.

title: To Hold Senate, Democrats Rely on Single Women
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The decline of marriage over the last generation has helped create an emerging voting bloc of unmarried women that is profoundly reshaping the American electorate to the advantage, recent elections suggest, of the Democratic Party. What is far from clear is whether Democrats will benefit in the midterm contests this fall.

title: On a Roll
description: If you have the kind of children who like to stop and watch construction vehicles doing their work, the kind fascinated by anything with wheels, then Brian Flocas Five Trucks, and Food Trucks!, written and illustrated by Mark Todd, should find a long-term parking spot on their night tables.

title: Casting Time as a Lead Character
description: Twenty years ago, Ethan Hawke, sporting a ratty red turtleneck and a scraggly goatee, first worked with Richard Linklater on the set of Before Sunrise, playing an impulsive romantic who makes a bold pass at a stranger on a train. Over the next two decades, as Hollywood seemed to retrench into critic-proof franchises, that reckless romanticism continued to animate the friends idiosyncratic careers. Altogether, the two men, both Texas born, have made eight unpredictable movies together. On Friday, they will release their most audacious gamble yet, Boyhood, a film so formally bold that it is without an exact precedent.

title: Excavation for Railyard Project Reveals a Hidden Piece of New York City
description: If you think the crush is bad around Pennsylvania Station these days, you should have been here 465 million years ago.

title: Former Heinz Chief Joins Private Equity Firm Advent as Adviser
description: William R. Johnson, a former chief executive of H.J. Heinz, has joined the private equity firm Advent International as an adviser.

title: Chinese Presidents Visit to South Korea Is Seen as Way to Weaken U.S. Alliances
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Xi Jinping of China arrived in South Korea on Thursday for a state visit to a vital American ally, a move that appears to signal his resolve to unsettle Americas alliances in Northeast Asia and fortify his argument for a new security architecture in the region, with China as the dominant player.

title: Lynne Cheney: By the Book
description: The author of James Madison: A Life Reconsidered says the last book to make her cry was Shel Silversteins The Giving Tree: I have to steel myself before I read it to my grandchildren.

title: Empowering Words
description: I have never had a feeling politically, Abraham Lincoln declared in Philadelphia on his way to the White House, that did not spring from the sentiments embodied in the Declaration of Independence. This statement cut to the core of Lincolns deepest reflections on politics and philosophy. The question is, what precisely are the sentiments embedded in the Declaration? This is an issue with which some of our best historical minds  Carl Becker, Garry Wills, Pauline Maier  have grappled.

title: Orange Decides Not to Pursue Deal in French Mobile Market
description: LONDON  Consolidation in the French telecommunications market looks to be on hold for now.

title: McAllister and Ford and Cianci: Second-Chance Politicians Out in Force
description: Electoral seasons often feature a penitent candidate practicing the politics of expiation  apologizing, with or without tears, for some suddenly exposed personal flaw while appealing to voters mercy for a second chance. This season is particularly rich, with three sack-clothed candidates trying again.

title: 1964: Klan Recruiting Drive Starts
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss.  A drive to recruit new members of the Ku Klux Klan was under way here yesterday and appeared to be meeting with some success. Klan posters displayed at the courthouse attracted groups of interested readers. The drive was initiated by Robert Shelton of Tuscaloosa, Ala., Imperial Grand Wizard of the Klan. Posters were thrown in every yard and doorway in this city of 6,000. The posters make the usual Klan claim that White America is threatened by Communism and mongrelization.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 3, 1964.

title: Rightward Bound
description: In July 1977, a law professor and former official in the Nixon and Ford administrations, Antonin Scalia, joined the editorial board of a new magazine called Regulation. It was decidedly not pro-. Its first issue featured an article in which Scalia expressed his contempt for legislation aimed at the platitudinous goals of pursuing the public interest or preventing sex discrimination.  The use of quotation marks was revealing. Here was Nino Scalia, 41 years old and already fully formed: scathing, self-confident and profoundly at odds with the premises of late-20th-century American law and life.

title: Stem Cell Research Papers Are Retracted
description: Two scientific papers that initially electrified biologists by describing an easy way to make stem cells were retracted on Wednesday by the journal that published them after they were found to be riddled with critical errors.

title: Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.: A Village With a Changed Image
description: Two decades ago, Dobbs Ferry, then a working-class village in southern Westchester along the Hudson River, was considered by many the poor stepsister of its immediate neighbors  artsy Hastings-on-Hudson on its southern border and upscale Irvington to the north.

title: Hong Kongs Democracy Movement
description: A pro-democracy march underlined the determination of residents to preserve and expand the freedoms that they inherited from British rule.

title: A Cuisine for the Age of Us  the Anthropocene
description: In late spring, Emma Marris, the author of Rambunctious Garden: Saving Nature in a Post-Wild World, wrote Beyond Food and Evil, a refreshing essay for the Breakthrough Journal on a new generation of chefs celebrating both nature and technology in their cuisine. Ingredients include lichen powder (see the video above). Technology, including devices like the Thermomix, has a Jetsons feel.

title: A Hong Kong Protest for Democracy, in Pictures
Escaping, Literally, in Budapest and Beyond
description: It took only a few minutes after the door locked behind us for the atmosphere in the cramped room to turn tense. A hasty note, left behind on a battered table, warned us that we had only an hour to get out, and it soon became clear that our escape route lay behind a second door.

title: What You Get for ... $1,200,000
