title: By Design | An L.A. Gallery and Shop So Laid Back, Its at the Curators House
description: The unique geography of Los Angeles  both physical and social  tends to encourage the citys burgeoning art and design communities, especially on the artist-friendly east side, to think outside the white gallery box. Case in point: a rotating monthly pop-up known as Either Way L.A., a 150-square-foot exhibition space nestled in the garden studio beneath the hillside home of Julia Leonard, an artist and curator, in the bohemian enclave (and emerging microscale design hub) of Echo Park. I wanted to show people in L.A. some things they havent seen yet, she explains, in an environment that didnt feel as precious as a four-wall gallery. Since she began the project a year ago, Leonard has showcased functional objects by exciting young talents from L.A. and beyond, such as the ceramists Jessica Hans and Morgan Peck. Now up is a show by the artist Dane Johnson, Paintings You Can Wear, a collection of garments hand-painted with abstract geometric shapes. Leonard devises each shows theme in collaboration with the artist or designer on view. Art can be so hard and harsh and it doesnt need to be, Leonard says. I like the idea of running the gallery as if its a group effort.

title: Walking the Walk
description: In the Army there are those who walk the walk, and those who just talk the talk. My drill sergeant at Fort Knox said this to me more than 30 years ago. What he was implying was that there are jobs for soldiers, and jobs for people who just joined the Army for the college plan or to get some skills training.

title: Second Try Puts Carbon Observatory Into Orbit
description: NASAs new spacecraft to sniff carbon dioxide in the earths atmosphere reached orbit on Wednesday after launching from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

description: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from the archives of The New York Times that tell tales of New York City summers.

description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the Libyan militia leader charged in connection with the 2012 killing of the American ambassador and three others in Benghazi must remain in government custody and be held without bond.

title: Defending Champion Is Dethroned by Another Young Star
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Wimbledon is only one tournament, but in many minds it is the biggest, grandest stage in tennis. So let the speculation begin that cracks in the wall of dominance enjoyed by the group known as the Big 4 of the mens game may have finally appeared during Wimbledons second week.

title: Radical Chic
description: Subcultures have long used visual cues to signal allegiances, both to individuals within a movement and to outsiders. Goths wore corsets and black nail polish; punks sported mohawks and tore up the queens tartan plaid. Neo-Nazis were recognizable by their shaved heads, bomber jackets and Doc Martens.

title: Why More Start-Ups Are Sharing Ideas Without Legal Protection
description: In 2011, Andy Moeck was looking for investors for Moeo, a Los Angeles start-up he was building that makes mobile gaming apps based on real-time sporting events. title: When Halibut Was Plentiful
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Food News: Fresh Halibut Now in Peak Supply appeared on June 19 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: A Bright Side to Facebooks Experiments on Its Users
description: Facebooks disclosure last week that it had tinkered with about 700,000 users news feeds as part of a psychology experiment conducted in 2012 inadvertently laid bare what too few tech firms acknowledge: that they possess vast powers to closely monitor, test and even shape our behavior, often while were in the dark about their capabilities.

description: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo  The call came after 8 in the evening, from peacekeepers posted in a remote corner of the countrys restive east. The troops sensed suspicious movement nearby. Venturing out into the forest at that hour was far too risky. Would ground control send a drone to have a look?

description: It is a daily ritual for many New Yorkers who share an apartment with a dog: the walk around the block.

At a meeting at the Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, Mr. Moeck asked a partner to sign a nondisclosure agreement.

description: While many soccer fans eyes were riveted on Brazil, a group of would-be nation-states met in Sweden last month in the ConIFA World Cup, a tournament for teams not recognized by the sports governing body.

description: When the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington  one of the nations oldest privately supported museums  announced in May that its artwork, landmark building and venerable school would be taken over by the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University, the arrangement was presented as a done deal.

description: Every now and again  almost every day, really  the Internet demands a head on a platter, and this week, it came for Robin Thickes.

title: More Casting Announced for An American in Paris Musical
description: Casting has been announced for the new musical version of George Gershwins An American In Paris, directed and choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon, that is to open in Paris in December. The New York City Ballet principal Robert Fairchild, and the Royal Ballet dancer Leanne Cope, had already been named for the roles of Jerry Mulligan and Lise Dassin. Joining them will be actors who have worked both on and off Broadway: Veanne Cox as Madame Baurel, Jill Paice as the society heiress Milo Davenport, Brandon Uranowitz as Adam Hochberg and Max von Essen as Henri Baurel.

title: Subaru to Recall Vehicles With Takata Air Bag Inflators
description: Subaru says it will recall about 8,500 Legacy, Outback and Baja cars from the 2003-4 model years because they are equipped with defective Takata air bag inflators, Michael McHale, a spokesman for the automaker, said on Tuesday.

title: Corinthian Colleges Is Closing. Its Students May Be Better Off as a Result.

title: The Fleeting Benefits of Overseas Corporate Marriages
description: Tax-arbitrage mergers and acquisitions require a deep discount. American companies seeking to relocate by mergers in a bid to slash how much they pay Uncle Sam were a big part of the $1.8 trillion first-half deal boom. The benefits of such ill-conceived combinations will be fleeting, though. The more so-called inversions there are, the more likely the law is to change.

title: Russia Demands New Cease-Fire in Ukraine as Foreign Ministers Seek Path to Peace
description: MOSCOW  In a stern warning that cited civilian casualties in war-torn eastern Ukraine, Russia on Wednesday demanded that the Ukrainian government reinstate a cease-fire and halt its military operation aimed at suppressing the pro-Russian separatist insurrection that has destabilized the region for more than three months.

title: 8 Afghan Air Force Officers Killed in Suicide Bombing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber killed eight Afghan Air Force officers on Wednesday after boarding a bus carrying them through central Kabul, in one of the first major attacks in the capital in months.

title: Mourning, And Rioting, Over Death In Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  As police tear gas wafted through his East Jerusalem neighborhood, the father of a slain 16-year-old Arab, the possible victim of a Jewish revenge attack, mourned with friends who had come to console him Wednesday on the enclosed porch of his two-story stone house. He had just spent seven hours with police investigators.

title: A New York Concert to Honor Mandela, and Stream Online
description: To celebrate Mandela Day on July 18  which would have been Nelson Mandelas 96th birthday  the composer and producer Joel A. Martin, and the South African playwright, director and choreographer Welcome Msomi, have assembled Footsteps of Mandela, a style-crossing work for choir, percussionists and solo voices from the jazz and opera worlds. Mr. Martin and Mr. Msomi will present the work at Riverside Church, where Mandela spoke on several occasions. Mr. Martin said in a telephone interview that he also hoped the performance would be streamed live on the Internet, in high-definition video, but that he was still seeing to the details.

title: Paris Court Rejects Guggenheim Descendants Claim Over Venice Palazzo
description: PARIS  A court here on Wednesday issued a ruling that permits the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation to display art as it sees fit in the Venetian palazzo given to it by the wealthy collector Peggy Guggenheim.

title: Janet Yellen Signals She Wont Raise Rates to Fight Bubbles
description: Janet Yellen just delivered the most significant speech yet in her still-young Federal Reserve chairmanship. It doesnt necessarily send any startling signals about what the Fed will do next month or even next year. But it tells us a great deal about how she will deal with new risks on the horizon from financial bubbles.

title: A Chef in the Field | Bok Choy
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: U.S. Privacy Panel Backs N.S.A.s Internet Tapping
description: WASHINGTON  The federal privacy board that sharply criticized the collection of the phone records of Americans by the National Security Agency has come to a starkly different conclusion about the agencys exploitation of Internet connections in the United States to monitor foreigners communicating with one another abroad.

title: China Expels 3 Officials in Corruption Inquiry
description: SHANGHAI  The ruling Communist Party in China expelled three government officials on Wednesday who had ties to Zhou Yongkang, a former member of the powerful Politburo Standing Committee. The expulsions were the latest sign that officials were preparing to announce charges against Mr. Zhou himself.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

description: An exclusive premiere of a song from the album Havent Got The Blues (Yet).

title: Reactions to Death of Palestinian Youth
description: Palestinian and Israeli officials and a relative of the slain teenager, whose body was found in a Jerusalem forest early Wednesday, discussed the kidnapping and killing.

title: Gin, London Style
description: Gin is the quintessential summertime tipple in Britain, but the traditional Wimbledon gin punch Pimms No.1 Cup has some fresh competition: the Gin & Tonics Garden, a pop-up bar on a secluded lane within the extensive grounds of the Kew Royal Botanic Gardens in London.

title: No One Expects the Caliphate
description: The latest issue of the New Republic includes an essay by Mark Lilla,cited in a pessimistic column by my colleague David Brooks, thats one of the richer takes on our present political-cultural big picture that Ive read in some time. Ive been looking for a news peg on which to hang some comments on Lillas argument, and I think Ive found one in the news that the ISIS terrorist organization, a.k.a. the de facto government of eastern Syria and western Iraq, has taken the high-risk step of actually declaring a reborn caliphate in its conquered territory. The connection here is that one of Lillas themes is the way our ongoing end-of-history erahas constricted the Western political imagination, leaving us unable to reckon with the complexities of a wider world where liberal democracy isnt obviously spreading anymore:

title: Weaning Older Patients Off Sleeping Pills
description: Deprescribe. Its a word I hadnt encountered before, but Dr. Cara Tannenbaum, who holds an endowed chair in geriatric pharmacy at the University of Montreal, told me that its been popping up with exponential frequency in medical journals and conversations among geriatricians.

title: At Thom Browne, Its Not the Plot, Its the Wardrobe
description: PARIS  Under a gridded neon light fixture, perched on plinths in rows of five, 20 models in plastic face masks and gray tailored suiting sat silently. They waited, as did the guests facing them, for Thom Brownes show to start.

title: 9 Worldly Ways to Make a Burger

title: African Leaders Grant Themselves Immunity in Proposed Court
description: DAKAR, Senegal  African leaders have voted to give themselves immunity from prosecution for crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide in an African human rights court that does not yet exist, angering rights groups and puzzling activists on the continent.

title: Ed Sheeran Hits No. 1
description: Ed Sheeran, a 23-year-old British singer-songwriter who has been championed by Taylor Swift, topped the latest Billboard album chart with his second full album, x (Atlantic), beating out Phishs latest release as well as recent hits by Lana Del Rey and Sam Smith.

title: SEMA Garage Takes Aftermarket Parts From Concept to Reality

title: Early Nick Drake Recording to Be Auctioned
description: The English folksinger and songwriter Nick Drake made three extraordinary albums between 1969 and 1972, and for many years, that was all there was. The discs, Five Leaves Left, Bryter Layter and Pink Moon, barely sold; Drakes label, Island, dropped him; and in 1974, at age 26, he died of an overdose of antidepressant medicine.

title: All of Tim Howards 16 Saves Against Belgium
description: Howard made his first save 43 seconds into the game. He finished with 16 saves, the most by a goalkeeper in a World Cup game since 1966.

title: Hes Alone on a Stage, With Tough Characters

But I can say that hes one terrific actor, and a very good playwright as well. That much is clear throughout his solo show, The Bullpen, which takes an extremely funny look at a particularly dreadful situation.

title: The Delights and Challenges of French Guiana

Somehow, along the way, the French muscled their way in to grab a foothold. Make that a toehold: French Guiana today makes up just 0.5 percent of the continent and 0.06 percent of its population, yet accounts for, in my estimation, 99 percent of its baguette consumption.

title: Nets Quickly Hire Lionel Hollins as Their Coach
description: The interviews came and went for Lionel Hollins. He met last year with the Los Angeles Clippers and the Denver Nuggets, who opted for other candidates. In recent weeks, more teams called, including the Minnesota Timberwolves and the Los Angeles Lakers. Hollins did what he could to prepare, and then was left to hope for the best.

title: Man Accused of Killing Brooklyn Boy, 6, in Elevator Pleads Not Guilty
description: The man accused of stabbing a 6-year-old boy to death and wounding a 7-year-old girl in an elevator last month told police officers shortly after they took him into custody, Satan has powers and controls things.

title: Aid From Massachusetts in New Hampshire Race
description: STRATHAM, N.H.  It was a bit of an odd tableau: a former Massachusetts governor endorsing a former Massachusetts senator to represent the people of New Hampshire in the United States Senate.

title: For Bonobos, a Good Fit in Stores as Well as Online
description: Bonobos, the e-commerce business best known for its well-fitted mens pants, was never supposed to have brick-and-mortar shops. Then, all of a sudden, they opened a few and money came pouring in.

title: An Alternative World Cup
description: It was a World Cup full of goals, political intrigue and pressure of an expectant home crowd. Amid equal measures of excitement and agony, penalties decided most of the second round games. In the end, an unlikely champion was crowned.

title: Lindsay Lohan Sues Over a Character in Grand Theft Auto V
description: Have you ever played Grand Theft Auto V and thought that the minor character Lacey Jonas  a young startlet whom players rescue from pursuing paparazzi  seemed oddly like Lindsay Lohan? Jonas is a slinky blonde, like Ms. Lohan, and some players have noted that she sounds like Ms. Lohan, has a line of clothing like Ms. Lohans and has a penchant for complaining about the difficulties of being a star. The game also shows the Chateau Marmont, the West Hollywood hotel where Ms. Lohan racked up a bill of $46,000.

title: The Perfect Drink for Cookouts (or Dugouts)
description: I finally made it to a New York Times Magazine softball game this week. The Central Park evening was like a happy collision between a Hudson River School painting and a Norman Rockwell. Big blue sky, grand old trees  and scrappy journalists, editors and designers in our teams bright green T-shirts.

title: Italian Leader Presses His Case for Budget Relief in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  The presidency of the European Union is largely ceremonial, rotating every six months among the blocs 28 nations. But Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy means to use its new presidency as a platform from which to seek relief for his countrys debt-saddled economy.

title: For Spirits That Can Only Be Tied Down by a Sash
description: GLAMOUR IS A SLIPPERY CONCEPT, defined one season by a neoprene minidress, and the next by a gown cut from stiffened brocade. But in one of those pendulum swings as regular as rent hikes, it is encapsulated this summer in the loose, and louche, kimono, the casual uniform of music festival pilgrims traipsing through Coachella, South by Southwest or Bonnaroo. A stand-in for the trusty jeans jacket or cardigan, the look is being embraced this year by self-styled free spirits of every persuasion.

title: La Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels Opens in NoLIta
description: A sliver of the Sixth Arrondissement has landed on the fringes of NoLIta. An offshoot of La Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels, a renowned wine bar in Paris, opened in New York this May with an extensive wine list that would make a Michelin-starred restaurant blush.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Israel, South Africa, Afghanistan and Kenya.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Loudon Wainwright Offers Another Reason Its Tough to Live in Kentucky
description: In a recent Its the Economy column, Annie Lowrey wrote about the toughest places to live in America, based on research by the Upshot that focuses on six factors: education, household income, jobless rate, disability rate, life expectancy and obesity rate. Harlan, Ky., like many parts of the Bluegrass State, doesnt fare so well. The median income is about half that of the country over all, the unemployment rate is more than twice as high and the life expectancy is seven years lower  all factors that make it one of the 25 hardest places to live in the country, according to the Upshots analysis.

title: Gin, Miami Beach Style
description: Como Hotels and Resorts, the Singapore-based brand of 12 upscale properties, recently opened its first hotel in the United States, the Metropolitan by Como, Miami Beach, which claims to have the citys first artisanal gin bar.

title: Common Back and Leg Pain Treatment May Not Help Much, Study Says
description: A widely used method of treating a common cause of back and leg pain  steroid injections for spinal stenosis  may provide little benefit for many patients, according to a new study that experts said should make doctors and patients think twice about the treatment.

title: The Deadly Politics of Revenge
The Devil Went to Midtown to Serenade the Lord
description: If the Devil were as endearingly funny as Randy Newman at the piano, a season in hell might not be so painful. Mr. Newman, the singer-songwriter known for his wry, bluesy tunes with lyrics etched in acid, portrayed the Lords nemesis on Tuesday night, in a concert performance of his musical-theater adaptation of Goethes Faust at City Center.

title: U.S.A.-Belgium World Cup Game Drew 22 Million Viewers in Ratings
description: With just under 16.5 million viewers on ESPN, and 5.1 million more watching on Univision, the World Cup game on Tuesday between the United States and Belgium was the second-most-viewed soccer game ever on American television, trailing only the United States-Portugal game earlier in this tournament.

title: They Need to Get in the Game
description: SOMETHING ABOUT THE current Wimbledon has me scratching my head  and its not both Williams sisters losing in the third round despite their power groundstrokes, or Li Na and Caroline Wozniacki falling to Barbora Zahlavova-Strycova, who is ranked 43rd. Its not, in fact, anything to do with playing style at all. Rather, it has to do with players style.

title: Bratton Putting Desk Officers on Streets to Fight New Yorks Summer Crime
description: As many as 400 veteran New York City officers assigned to desk jobs in the Police Department will return to the streets this summer as part of a broad push by Commissioner William J. Bratton to head off a seasonal spike in crime.

title: Mixed Predictions About Wearables Like Smartwatches and Google Glass
description: The wearable computing market will be huge. Actually, its a passing fad. (Remember the netbook?) Or it will be a modest hit.

title: Sweating Out Their Differences
description: WASHINGTON  A new muscle-crushing, sweat-inducing workout has infiltrated the inner sanctum of Congress, the members-only gym of the House of Representatives. And it is called, simply, the Markwayne Mullin.

title: Songs of Love and Heartache, Self-Assured and Bittersweet
description: Heres the true love song on the album, Jenny Scheinman said at Le Poisson Rouge on Monday night, holding her fiddle across her midsection like a mandolin. The album in question was The Littlest Prisoner (Sony Masterworks), and the song was Sacrifice, a dirgelike drift of rhyming couplets with a single-phrase melody kneaded into shape through repetition. Ms. Scheinman sang its lyrics  addressed first to a husband and then to their small child  with a deliberative heaviness, as in certain kinds of prayer.

title: Portraits on the Street, in the Moment
description: Jacques Sonck has spent almost 40 years in Belgium making portraits of people  with odd or singular looks  who capture his attention on the street.

title: Edit Your Facebook and Twitter History
description: Molly Wood explains how to download and delete activity on Facebook and Twitter.

title: The Apps  and Airplane Blankets  That Track Our Lives
description: A new app could help people with mental illness get timely treatment, by logging their behavior and sending the data to their doctors. But it may also become part of a larger conversation around how much we want our devices keeping track of us.

title: Swear Off Social Media, for Good or Just for Now
description: SOCIAL media can be a harmless and easy way to keep track of friends, family and news.

title: Yankees Fall Under .500 as Offensive Struggles Continue
description: Joe Girardi conceded recently that there was not much he could do to rouse the Yankees often-lifeless offense. Girardi believes he must be patient and hope that his veteran hitters, who have a record of success, will soon start hitting because big changes to the lineup are unlikely to make much difference.

title: How to Digitally Avoid Taking It to the Grave
description: Planning for control of your personal information after you die used to be as simple as telling someone about the desk drawer or the fireproof box or the safe deposit box at the local bank.

title: Weinstein Company Is Said to Consider Spinning Off TV Unit
description: LOS ANGELES  Just seven months after declaring an ambitious thrust into television, the Weinstein Company, best known for its Oscar-winning film operation, is exploring plans to spin off its TV division into a separate company that could be sold to a strategic partner or taken public.

title: The Facts and Figures Behind Jeff Koonss Massive, Awe-Inspiring Show at the Whitney
description: Like Jeff Koons himself, Jeff Koons: A Retrospective, at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is larger than life. The biggest show the institution has ever devoted to a single artist, it sprawls across all four floors, occupying 27,000 square feet of exhibition space. Included among the 145 works on display is a pastel Koons created last year specifically for T. The show also serves as the farewell party for the Whitneys iconic Marcel Breuer building before the museum relocates to its new Renzo Piano-designed space downtown next year. Here, a few more key figures about this one-of-a-kind, once-in-a-lifetime survey.

title: Jay Nixon Vetoes a Terrible Abortion Bill
description: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri vetoed an extreme measure on Wednesday that would have tripled his states existing mandatory waiting period for women seeking an abortion, to 72-hours.

title: Janet Yellen Says Fed Will Emphasize Stronger Regulation
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said on Wednesday that the central bank did not plan to raise interest rates or alter its stimulus campaign to address concerns about excesses in the financial system.

title: Winner in the Amazon War
description: LOS ANGELES  Nobody expected much from Edan Lepuckis debut novel. Her publisher planned a tiny first printing of 12,000 copies. She was assigned to an editor with almost no experience. Was there a marketing budget? How cute of her to ask.

title: Thinking Locally, So Fighting Globally
description: Beth Macy, a longtime reporter for The Roanoke Times in Virginia, understood how lucky she was when she accidentally uncovered the great, gripping story told in Factory Man. This is Ms. Macys first book, but its in a class with other runaway debuts like Laura Hillenbrands Seabiscuit and Katherine Boos Behind the Beautiful Forevers: These nonfiction narratives are more stirring and dramatic than most novels. And Ms. Macy writes so vigorously that she hooks you instantly. You wont be putting this book down.

title: Playing in a Part of Something Bigger
description: The musicians spilled off the stage when Adam Schatzs rock band Landlady performed on Tuesday night at Rough Trade NYC. By the end of the set, there were a dozen horn players and half a dozen drummers and percussionists along with Mr. Schatz and Landladys core musicians, blaring and pounding as Mr. Schatz pushed the audience to sing along. It was an album party through a show of community. This is such a special way to feel like youre a part of something bigger, Mr. Schatz announced as the musicians assembled. Mr. Schatz, who is also a jazz concert promoter, works with many other bands as well as Landlady, playing rock, funk, jazz, Afrobeat and improvisation. Landladys more-or-less pop songs hold a little of them all.

title: Dutch Women Win European Championship
description: The European Team Championships concluded in Opatija, Croatia, on Tuesday. The results in the womens and open events were unclear until the last boards were finished.

title: Sales at Ralo, C. Wonder, Grace & Favor and Warp & Weft
description: Ralo carpets will discount all hand-knotted Tibetan rugs and handmade pillows up to 60 percent from July 5 through July 13 (a 5-by-8-foot Lhasa rug, originally $5,290, will be $2,116); 29 Howard Street (Crosby Street); 212-966-7661, tibetcarpet.com.

title: Ahoy, Birdie!
description: Haptic Lab, the interdisciplinary design studio of Emily Fischer, a Brooklyn architect, specializes in handmade furniture, quilts and fanciful kites that are produced in collaboration with Balinese artisans.

title: Out of Indonesia, Vintage Teak Furniture
description: Last year, Teak Me Home opened a 2,000-square-foot showroom in Emeryville, Calif., to sell dressers and tables made from old-growth teak salvaged from 100-year-old Indonesian houses. The beauty of the aged wood is that theres more grain in the pattern, said Alexander Elsinga, the founder. He has just introduced four new dining pieces that, like all Teak Me Home products, are made by hand in its Bay Area workshop. Prices range from $1,699 for a 40-inch round table that grows to a 64-inch oblong to $2,299 for an elliptical table that expands from five to nine feet. Famously durable, teak needs little effort to maintain its patina; a monthly wiping with furniture oil or wood polish will keep the wood looking brilliant, Mr. Elsinga said. The company ships nationwide. Information: 510-725-7258 or teakmehome.com.

title: Our Niches, Our Shelves
description: The prospectus for 44 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, a six-story brick apartment building finished in 1940, promised all sorts of modern amenities: Venetian blinds, concealed radiation, radio outlets in every room. But it neglected to herald one of the buildings niftiest architectural features. In one wall of most of the foyers is an arched bookshelf niche, a Moderne version of the china cabinet. Like china cabinets, the niches were intended to be a place for the display of more than just books  where folks could show off their best (and most carefully edited) selves, as an environmental psychologist might say.

title: The Women of Mens Fashion Week
description: Increasingly, female models are showing up on the mens wear runways in Europe.

title: Faith, Severely Tested, in a German Commune
description: Dont believe the title: Nothing Bad Can Happen is a veritable smorgasbord of bad, at least for Tore (Julius Feldmeier), the newest member of a punk-rock Christian commune in Hamburg, Germany.

title: A House That Sips Energy
description: With a voluptuous skin of high-performance fabric, Techstyle Haus is one of 25 projects on display through July 14 at the Solar Decathlon Europe 2014 in Versailles, France. The 800-square-foot amoeba-shaped house was created by students from the Rhode Island School of Design, Brown University and the University of Applied Sciences in Germany to combine passive-house elements with a flexible system of solar panels.

title: State-Shaped Accessories: Form Follows 50
description: Anyone who visits Mary Jo Otsea and Richard Browns home on the Upper East Side cant help but notice that they have a fondness for a certain kind of Americana. On display in a sideboard is an impressive collection of salt-and-pepper shakers, each shaped like one of the 50 states.

title: The Court and Gay Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Match: U.S. Colleges vs. World
So Small but Already a TV Star
description: Zack Giffin is an extreme, or free, skier and tiny-house booster, having made his home for the last three years in a 112-square-foot mobile ski chalet. This year, Mr. Giffin, 34, is a host of a new series, Tiny House Nation, beginning Wednesday on FYI, an A & E Networks channel that used to be known as Bio. When we caught up with him by phone last week, he was on the road for the show, which chronicles those who live the tiny-house life. The chalet, he said, was sitting on a trailer in a lovely field in Lummi Island, Washington State, on my parents property, which is where it lives when we are not around. (He shares it with his girlfriend, Molly Baker, 30, who is also a skier and was away working for a ski sponsor in Austria.) The couple have used their tiny house as an assist to their lifestyle, to help them get close to the mountains, mostly in the Northwest. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

title: Obama in the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunisias Jews Under Strain
description: To the Editor:

title: Timeless Manipulators
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Clients Cool
description: After a dramatic family crisis, Pat Law of Singapore quit her job to start a new kind of social media agency.

title: Civil Rights, Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping Events Starting July 3
description: Fourth of July

title: Sleeping in the Afterthought
description: Even before Hurricane Sandy swooped in two years ago and wiped out 15 years of her work at the Battery Conservancy, where she was director of horticulture  in charge of what she thought of as her 23-acre roof garden  Sigrid Gray had already decided to leave the city.

title: The Garage That Bloomed
description: For five years now, I have been tending a plot  cultivating hostas, lilies and astilbes, gently trying to persuade a hydrangea bush not to depart this earth  in the Lotus Garden, a community garden on West 97th Street between Broadway and West End Avenue.

title: Israels Justice Minister Condemns Incitement on Facebook
description: Israels justice minister denounced a Facebook campaign in Israel on Wednesday that called for soldiers to take revenge on the Palestinian community as tensions spiked in Jerusalem, where an Arab teenager was kidnapped and killed hours after the funerals for three Jewish teenagers abducted last month in the West Bank.

title: There Goes the Neighborhood Cafe
description: I OPENED my first restaurant, Union Square Cafe, nearly 30 years ago, at a time when Manhattan rents were low, crime rates were high and the future of the city seemed, even for an optimist like me, to be an open question.

title: The War on Workers
description: UNIONS have never been uncontroversial in American society, but the battles over labor have grown fiercer in recent years: Witness the fight over public-employee unions in Wisconsin, or the 2012 decision by Michigan lawmakers to join the ranks of right to work states.

title: Shrimps New Path to the Plate
description: STOUGHTON, Mass.  In a warehouse south of Boston, miles away from the citys bustling harbor, James Tran, a semiconductor designer, is incubating an unlikely product: shrimp.

title: The Words, and Works, of Walter Dean Myers
description: The award-winning young adult author Walter Dean Myers, who died on Tuesday at 76, wrote an Op-Ed piece for The New York Times last March in which he bemoaned the paucity of childrens books about black people.

title: Barack the Bear
description: The president is growing hostile to being held hostage  both by the very insular nature of the presidency itself, and by the more stultifying intransigence of Congress.

title: Gay, Widowed and Fighting for What Theyre Due
description: While gay rights advocates were encouraged by the federal governments recent announcement that it would extend more benefits to gay married couples, Gerald Passaro, a 49-year-old former hairstylist, was reflecting on a private victory.

title: A Guide to Changes in Federal Benefits for Same-Sex Couples
description: The Obama administration made regulatory changes last month   that extend more federal benefits to committed same-sex couples. But there are still a few provisions on the books, both at the Social Security Administration and the Department of Veterans Affairs, that prohibit same-sex couples from receiving benefits if they live in states that do not recognize their unions.

title: Harvard to Bring On Specialists to Examine Sexual Assault Claims
description: Harvard University will hire a team of investigators to deal specifically with sexual harassment and assault complaints, and it will end a fragmented approach that allows various parts of the university to handle such cases differently, it said Wednesday.

title: American Apparel Deal Gives Power to Hedge Fund, Not Dov Charney
description: A little-known hedge fund backing Dov Charney, the ousted executive of American Apparel, has emerged as a critical power broker in the battle for control of the struggling retailer.

title: Journalists at Odds With Union Over Role of Voice of America
description: WASHINGTON  Voice of America journalists who are fighting to maintain what they say is their editorial independence are now at odds not only with Congress, but also with their own union.

title: South Sudans Kickboxing Team
description: The photographer Mackenzie Knowles-Coursin documented the team last year, before civil war erupted in the country.

title: Kidd Dismisses Intrigue Without Dispelling Mystery
description: MILWAUKEE  A photograph of a smiling Jason Kidd under the phrase Welcome to Milwaukee shone on a video screen outside Bradley Center on Wednesday. Hardly anyone noticed. The nearby sidewalks were barren on a cold, drizzly morning as Kidd was introduced as the coach of the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: I Couldnt Turn My Abortion Into Art
description: I had just turned 22 and I had the self-esteem of a squashed toad. This may explain why I was having an affair with a married 36-year-old sound mixer whom Id met on a film shoot a couple of months earlier.

title: Pakistan Approves Sweeping Antiterror Bill, Prompting Warnings From Rights Groups
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans Parliament on Wednesday approved sweeping new powers for the countrys security forces, with an antiterrorism measure that the government says is needed to combat the Taliban, but that rights activists warned could result in state-sponsored human rights violations.

title: For Banana Boat, Epic Battles Between Men and Sun
description: Banana Boat is introducing what it says is a first in the sun-care aisle, a mens line, and unlike typical sunscreen advertising filled with sand and surf, commercials for Banana Boat Triple Defense Sunscreen for Men are, in every sense, no day at the beach.

title: Regulators Criticize Chrysler for Delay in Repairing Recalled Jeeps
description: Federal auto regulators, criticized recently for not acting aggressively enough on safety issues, turned some of their fire on Chrysler on Wednesday, saying in a harshly worded letter that the automaker was taking too long to repair 1.6 million recalled Jeep sport utility vehicles.

title: Porsches, Potholes and Patriots
description: The anti-tax crusader pulls out of his driveway in his Porsche, hoping that the neighbors are watching. Hes proud that its the most expensive car on his block. Thats the greatness of America he muses. Thats what we should celebrate on July 4! I spend money so much more wisely than government.

title: Outside Legal Work Proves Fruitful for New Yorks Top Legislators
description: The three lawmakers who lead the New York State Legislature earned as much as $1.1 million combined practicing law in their spare time last year, according to disclosure statements released on Wednesday.

title: Government of Ecuador Can Sue Fugitive Bankers in U.S.
description: The government of Ecuador has the right to sue a pair of fugitive bankers in courts in the United States to recover millions of dollars that the government accuses the men of having embezzled, a Florida appellate court ruled on Wednesday. The bankers, Roberto and William Isaias, brothers who live in Coral Gables, Fla., have been convicted of embezzling $600 million from Filanbanco, a bank they owned in their native Ecuador. The Ecuadorean government sued them in a Miami court to recover a portion of the $200 million the government claims it is still owed. Last year, a state judge in Miami ruled in favor of the brothers, saying that international law did not allow Ecuador to seize properties in Florida. The Third District Court of Appeal overturned that verdict, ruling that the government was trying to recover funds, not seize property.

title: Dimons Cancer and the Fine Line in Revealing Illness of a C.E.O.
description: The diagnosis came out of nowhere: It was leukemia.

title: 2 Companies Accused of Faking Safety Checks at Building Sites
description: A building inspector visited a scaffolding last summer on East 90th Street in Manhattan, where workers were restoring the exterior of an apartment building. The inspector noticed something amiss in the sites safety log: The safety manager who had supposedly signed the log that day could not have done so; he had recently died.

title: Nicolas Sarkozys Many Legal Hurdles
description: The former president of France is facing numerous legal challenges as he considers running for the top office again in 2017.

title: Cheneys Back, Blitzing Rivals and Drawing Scorn
description: As his heart failed a couple of summers after leaving office, former Vice President Dick Cheney slipped into a coma and, by his later account, spent weeks dreaming that he was in a countryside villa north of Rome, padding down a stone path every morning to pick up a newspaper or coffee.

title: The Dispute Over Annual Pelvic Exams
description: Two major medical groups have taken opposing positions on whether healthy, low-risk women with no symptoms should have an annual pelvic exam. The American College of Physicians, the largest organization of physicians who practice internal medicine, strongly advised against the exams, which many women find distasteful or painful. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the leading group of specialists providing health care for women, immediately reiterated its support for yearly pelvic exams for asymptomatic adult women.

title: Another Failure to Regulate Derivatives
description: By the time the Securities and Exchange Commission finalized a rule last month to regulate derivatives under the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, the big banks that dominate the multitrillion-dollar market had already figured out how to game it.

title: Japan and the Limits of Military Power
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has disturbed many in Japan and increased anxiety in Asia by reinterpreting his countrys pacifist postwar Constitution so that the military can play a more assertive role than it has since World War II. While a shift in Japans military role was never going to be readily accepted by many, Mr. Abes nationalist politics makes this change even harder to swallow in a region that needs to reduce tension.

title: U.S. Success Will Take Some More Extra Time
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  Underneath the jingoistic backlash that engulfed Jurgen Klinsmann last month when he dared to say that the United States national team was not currently capable of winning the World Cup was an actual question that is genuinely confusing  particularly to casual soccer fans. When it comes to American soccer, what is success?

title: When the Texas Governor Drops the Official State Footwear
description: HOUSTON  Rocky Carroll was inside his cluttered boot shop here on Tuesday, watching television as the dusty ceiling fan jangled. Dolly Partons white boots were behind him. President George W. Bushs cigar-color alligator boots were by the front door, next to President Ronald Reagans Italian calf. A fly swatter was within reach.

title: The Rise and Fall (and Rise) of Salmon P. Chase
description: On July 4, 1864, four days after President Abraham Lincoln had surprised him by accepting his resignation, Treasury secretary Salmon P. Chase confided to his diary, I am too earnest, too antislavery  [and] too radical.

title: As Deadline Nears for an Iran Nuclear Pact, the Fingers Are Pointing
description: WASHINGTON  With less than three weeks until a deadline for a final agreement between Iran and the West on the future of Irans nuclear program, it is not just the countrys 10,000 working centrifuges that are spinning. So are the key negotiators.

title: Takeover of Kenmore Hotel: Informer Recalls His Complicity
description: It was as if the Fifth Infantry Division had come marching down East 23rd Street.

title: Baseball Let Rodriguez Use Testosterone in Big Year, Book Says
description: WASHINGTON  When the 2007 baseball season began, Alex Rodriguez was still one of the sports untarnished stars, the home-run-hitting antidote to Barry Bonds and other sluggers who had already been linked to the use of performance-enhancing substances.

title: Flights to U.S. Face Scrutiny After Threats Are Reported
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security has tightened passenger screening on many United States-bound flights from Europe, Africa and the Middle East in response to intelligence reports of an increased threat from Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen, officials said Wednesday.

title: The Right Approach to Reading Instruction
New York City Agrees to New Contract With Chief Municipal Union
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and District Council 37, the largest municipal union in New York City, announced on Wednesday a tentative contract that would raise wages by 10 percent and reduce health care costs, resembling the citys new contract with the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Insurers on New York States Health Exchange Seek Significant Rate Increases
description: Some New Yorkers are in sticker shock after receiving notices from their insurance companies saying that they have asked for significant rate increases through the states health exchange next year.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 2, 2014
description: July 2, 2014

title: Immigration Case Ensnares a Get-Tough Sheriff in South Carolina
description: LEXINGTON, S.C.  The weekday lunch rush arrives as a small ritual of suburban pleasure at the San Jose Mexican Restaurant, just across from the tanning salon and the strip-mall multiplex. A mostly white clientele pulls into a parking lot, past a sign with a cartoon peasant tugging on an obstinate donkey. Inside, a mostly Latino work force serves Americanized versions of Mexican classics as a sound system plays syrupy Spanish ballads.

title: Colorado Clerk Wont Halt Marriage Licenses for Gays
description: BOULDER, Colo.  County clerks like Hillary Hall tend not to be bomb throwers. Were procedural, and were cautious, she said, noting that clerks are duty-bound to follow bureaucratic rules for counting ballots, recording property deeds and registering license plates.

title: After Its Exit, U.S. Identifies Opportunities for Its Future
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Seeing the United States players pinging the ball around with purpose, making determined runs upfield and generally setting the tempo of play after falling behind Belgium, many fans may have thought or yelled out the same thing.

title: After Criticism, Investigator Steps Down From the V.A.
description: The head of the Department of Veterans Affairs medical investigation unit has stepped down, the department announced Wednesday, just days after a federal watchdog sharply criticized the department for failing to adequately investigate allegations of poor care within its sprawling hospital system.

title: Stephen Gaskin, Hippie Who Founded an Enduring Commune, Dies at 79
description: Stephen Gaskin, a Marine combat veteran and hippie guru who in 1971 led around 300 followers in a caravan of psychedelically painted school buses from San Francisco to Tennessee to start the Farm, a commune that has outlived most of its countercultural counterparts while spreading good works from Guatemala to the South Bronx, died on Tuesday at his home on the commune, in Summertown, Tenn. He was 79.

title: Class-Action Suit Can Proceed Against Census
description: A United States magistrate judge in the Southern District of New York certified a class-action lawsuit on Tuesday against the Department of Commerce, which alleges that the Census Bureaus use of criminal background checks for part-time workers unlawfully screened out 250,000 African-American applicants. The plaintiffs said the bureau gave applicants with criminal records 30 days to provide court records detailing their criminal history, a request they contend is in violation of federal civil-rights protections. Adam Klein, the lead lawyer for the plaintiffs, said that many of them had difficultly providing documentation or had minor charges against them or had been arrested but not convicted of a crime. African Americans and Latinos are also disproportionately arrested compared with whites, Mr. Klein said.

title: Rain May Spare Fireworks, but Not Other July 4th Plans
description: The grill has been cleaned. The fireworks-spotting spot has been staked out. Reservations and invitations have been made.

title: It Left Parts of Itself in 11 States
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Its not often that we get a history lesson with our crossword puzzles, but todays debut by Luke Vaughn taught me something that I didnt know. I consider that a bonus, and it more than makes up for the fact that I am not one of the better rebus recognizers.

title: Political Pop Quiz
description: Happy July! Lets see how well you can do on this Halfway Through the Year Political Quiz.

title: If Only Thomas Jefferson Could Settle the Issue
description: Every Fourth of July, some Americans sit down to read the Declaration of Independence, reacquainting themselves with the nations founding charter exactly as it was signed by the Second Continental Congress in 1776.

title: State Board Deals a Setback to Apartments in Chappaqua
description: A New York State review board on Wednesday issued a split decision on eight zoning variances being sought for a low- and moderate-income housing project in Chappaqua, the affluent Westchester County hamlet perhaps best known as the home of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Rockets Use Lins No. 7 as Anthony Lure
description: Carmelo Anthony and Jeremy Lin never exactly clicked as teammates on the Knicks. When Linsanity erupted out of nowhere in early 2012, with Lin repeatedly leading the Knicks to victories, Anthony was on the sideline, injured and not looking especially pleased to see someone else becoming the focal point of New York basketball.

title: Girl, 12, Fatally Struck by Stolen Van in Brooklyn; 2 Are Critically Injured
description: A 12-year-old girl was killed and her mother and sister were critically injured in Brooklyn when a stolen minivan jumped a sidewalk and plowed into them on Wednesday, the police said.

title: Trade Talk Grows With Murphys Value
description: ATLANTA  By rule, at least one player from every major league team must be chosen for the All-Star Game this month. This presumes that every team, even the Mets, who are among the most hapless teams in the National League, has at least one deserving representative.

title: Its a huge financial strain.
description: Dr. Lindsay Irvin is a pediatrician in San Antonio, Tex., who says providing vaccines is a financial risk and strain for doctors.

title: The Price of Prevention: Vaccine Costs Are Soaring
description: SAN ANTONIO  There is little that Dr. Lindsay Irvin has not done for the childrens vaccines in her office refrigerator: She remortgaged her home to afford their rising prices. She packed them in ice chests and moved them when her office flooded this year. She pays a company to monitor the fridge in case the temperature rises.

title: Scorn for Tiger Xu, From Official and Unofficial Sources
description: Shock is reverberating in China over the very public expulsion from the Communist Party this week of Tiger Xu, as Xu Caihou, once a Politburo member and deputy head of the Central Military Commission, is now being dubbed, in a reference to the allegations of his corruption. On Thursday, the militarys official newspaper held him up as a negative example for soldiers.

description: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) ABOUT TIME (2013) Richard Curtis (Love Actually) plucks the heartstrings once again in this British tale about a young man (Domhnall Gleeson) who uses the time-traveling abilities he shares with his eccentric father (Bill Nighy) to pursue a lovely American (Rachel McAdams, above, with Mr. Gleeson) by revisiting their interactions until he gets them right. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film a flimsy bit of mildly romantic, putatively comic Anglophile bait.

title: Wheres the Rest of Me?
description: There is no shortage of spherical pendant lights, but there are few with gaping holes in their structure. Neil Poulton, a Scottish-born designer in Paris, has produced an example with tiny LEDs tucked within the frame. The fixture, named Scopas after the Greek sculptor who lived in the fourth century B.C. and who carved a much-copied personification of desire, is composed of black and white painted aluminum circles and is about 20 inches in diameter.

title: After Relative Silence on Hong Kong Protests, Mainland Media Outlets Note Arrests
description: After a day of largely ignoring the big turnout for Hong Kongs pro-democracy march on Tuesday, Chinas news outlets have weighed in  to report on the arrests that followed it.

description: Test your knowledge of holidays celebrated around the world by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Tension Mounts After Apparent Revenge Killing in Jerusalem
description: Updated July 3, 2014: An earlier version of this post was based on the article Tension Mounts After Apparent Revenge Killing in Jerusalem by Isabel Kershner and Jodi Rudoren. The Times has since updated the article, and we have revised our questions to reflect the latest version.

title: Jay Carney: A Little Perspective Is Useful
description: The former White House press secretary talks to Jim Rutenberg about what he learned from working both sides of the lectern.

title: 794 Ways in Which BuzzFeed Reminds Us of Impending Death
description: Sometimes I forget that Im going to die someday, and then BuzzFeed reminds me. In its frenzied onslaught of yellow LOL"s and fail"s and 10 Dogs Who Went as a Different Dog for Halloween lies an existential evasion so strained that it cant help inadvertently evoking the specter of death. The sites effortfully whimsical tone and its compulsion to quantify and classify everything represent the apotheosis of American trivia-focused escapism, served up with an overabundant garnish of trashy and cute and yaaass.

title: The Animal Whisperer
description: A giraffe overcoming an eating problem. Harbor seals being prepared for an eye exam. And a tegu learning how to go through tunnels. How one behaviorist attends to their needs.

title: Portraits on the Street, in the Moment
description: Jacques Sonck has spent nearly four decades on the streets of Antwerp, Ghent and Brussels in Belgium collecting models for his portraits.

title: Zoo Animals and Their Discontents
description: Dr. Vint Virga likes to arrive at a zoo several hours before it opens, when the sun is still in the trees and the lanes are quiet and the trash cans empty. Many of the animals havent yet slipped into their afternoon malaise, when they retreat, appearing to wait out the heat and the visitors and not do much of anything. Virga likes to creep to the edge of their enclosures and watch. He chooses a spot and tries not to vary it, he says, to give the animals a sense of control. Sometimes he watches an animal for hours, hardly moving. Thats because what to an average zoo visitor looks like frolicking or restlessness or even boredom looks to Virga like a lot more  looks, in fact, like a veritable Russian novel of truculence, joy, sociability, horniness, ire, protectiveness, deference, melancholy and even humor.

title: Teenagers Deaths Raise Fears of Shift From Political Struggle to Blood Feud
description: SDEROT, Israel  In this resilient town about a mile from Israels volatile border with the Gaza Strip, the streets were empty on Thursday but the residents expressed defiance as Israeli troops massed around Gaza after a barrage of rockets including three that hit homes here.

description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

description: Good morning to you on this stormy Independence Eve.

description: After reaching out to the next-generation designer community via the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize, the richest and most ballyhooed fashion award for start-ups, well, ever (Thomas Tait, a British-Canadian, was the surprise winner), LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton is proving itself truly committed to cultivating the youth vote.

title: The Doctor Gets V.I.P. Treatment
description: I was halfway through my ride on a recent crisp and sunny Sunday morning, gaining speed as the road on which I was traveling descended precipitously: 25 miles per hour  30  35. I eased on the brakes but my bike abruptly lost its traction and, as if pushed by God, wiped out.

title: Why Polls Can Sometimes Get Things So Wrong
description: In the aftermath of Eric Cantors loss and Thad Cochrans narrow runoff victory, you might be tempted to conclude that political polling is losing its utility.

title: Moving Day for the Declaration and Other Charters
description: In December 1952, a number of mysterious-looking slender crates were brought out of the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., and placed upon mattresses inside two armored Marine personnel carriers. While the Army Band and the Air Force Drum and Bugle Corps played patriotic music, the procession rolled down Capitol Hill.

title: Morning Views
description: The New York Times editorial board is critical of the decision of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to reinterpret his countrys pacifist postwar Constitution so that the military can play a more assertive role than it has since World War II. The board believes the move will only exacerbate tensions in a region where they are already high. Japans military would still face restrictions on what it could do, but it would be allowed for the first time, for example, to help defend an American ship under attack, destroy a North Korean missile heading toward the United States or play a larger role in United Nations peacekeeping operations. Still, the Japanese people remain generally opposed to engagement in conflict of any kind, and The Times believes it is fair for citizens to demand its government assure them that Japan will not revert to its militaristic roots.

title: A Social Media Agency Takes an Edgy Approach
description: Pat Law, who started her social media agency, Goodstuph, in Singapore in 2010, has developed a reputation for being unconventional. She has cropped hair, tattoos and funky glasses, and is openly gay  all of which help her stand out in this prosperous but socially conservative city. I will piss a person off within the first five minutes of meeting them, said Ms. Law, with more than a hint of pride.

title: Tablets in the Workplace: a Corner Office Perk
description: Are tablets taking off in the workplace? Only if youre the boss.

title: Hurricane Makes Landfall on Carolina Coast
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C.  As darkness fell over the Carolina coast on Thursday, anxiety about Hurricane Arthur rose the nearer the strengthening storm moved toward landfall.

title: Google Alerts British News Outlets About Deleting Their Links
description: LONDON  A week after Google started to remove links to online content in Europe, some examples of the type of information that is to be taken down have started to emerge.

title: Morning Agenda: When the C.E.O. Gets Sick
description: Corporate leaders from Steven P. Jobs to Warren E. Buffett and now Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, have wrestled with how  or whether  to go public about health problems, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Julie Creswell write in DealBook. How much to disclose, and when, involves delicate corporate and personal decisions for which there are few hard rules. Executives have no real legal obligation to tell the world they are sick.

title: Daily Report: Winner of Bitcoin Auction Seeks to Increase Currencys Use in Emerging Markets
description: When the government auctioned nearly 30,000 Bitcoins on Friday, many bidders were looking for a bargain, hoping to buy the virtual currency at a discount and flip it later for a short-term profit.

title: European Central Bank Holds Interest Rates Steady
description: PARIS  The European Central Bank left its monetary policy intact on Thursday, choosing to wait for the extraordinary measures it enacted a month ago to work their way through the economy before deciding whether additional action was needed to bolster growth and keep deflation at bay.

title: 1914: Joseph Chamberlain, Veteran Statesman, Dies
description: LONDON  Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, the veteran statesman, died at his London residence, 40 Princes gardens, on Thursday night, on the eve of his seventy-eighth birthday. (He was born on July 8, 1836.) All the members of his family were present. Death was due to heart failure. A short time previously he had announced his intention of retiring from Parliament, in which he had been a representative of Birmingham for thirty-eight years.  Fromthe New York Herald, European Edition, July 4, 1914

title: Looking at Photos the Master Never Saw
description: The photographer Garry Winogrand was known for imposing an artists eye on messy urban life, but when he died in 1984, after a rapidly lethal cancer, he left behind an imposing mess of uncertain artistic value: a third of a million exposed frames of film that he hadnt edited. More than 2,500 rolls  some 100,000 frames  were undeveloped. He had never seen them.

title: Tea Party Favorites Find That Losing Only Widens Their Reach
description: WASHINGTON  Mississippi Tea Party dreams were extirpated last week when State Senator Chris McDaniel lost his Republican primary bid to unseat Senator Thad Cochran. Yet if some of Mr. McDaniels most outspoken contemporaries are any guide, he may actually have greater political influence as a loser.

title: London Transport Regulator Says Uber Can Legally Operate
description: LONDON  In the battle between Europes taxi drivers and the ride-sharing service Uber, score one for Uber.

title: Hiring Is Strong and Jobless Rate Declines to 6.1%
description: American companies are finally getting comfortable enough with the economys prospects to add new workers at a very healthy pace, after years of saying they lacked the confidence to hire people aggressively during a fitful recovery.

title: Q. & A. | Maya Lin on Saving the Planet Through Art
description: In 1981, Maya Lin first caught the worlds attention with her design for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. Three decades later, she is working on what she calls her last memorial: What is Missing?, a nonprofit that blends art and science to raise awareness about the ongoing loss of biodiversity and natural habitats. Mans precarious relationship to nature is also at the center of Lins studio practice, where she uses the tools of a scientist  sonar resonance scans, satellite mapping  to create strikingly minimalist works. Her environmentally-minded site-specific projects, including Pin River  Sandy, a ghostly wall-sized installation that maps Hurricane Sandys flood plain using straight pins, are the subject of the exhibition Platform: Maya Lin, which opens this Friday at the Herzog & De Meuron-designed Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, N.Y. As she readied the show, the artist discussed climate change, arts power to shift perceptions and the place where the land meets the sea.

title: Divas Ready for Another Stage
description: Its not unusual in the history of opera for a singer to gaze longingly at the world of performance that exists outside music. Theater, television and film offer fame of a kind that opera, for better or worse, no longer does. And in an era of entertainment multitasking, of the triple threat and the EGOT (Emmy, Grammy, Oscar, Tony), who wouldnt want to be a star of stage and screen?

description: There can be no question that the United States employment data for June, released on a rare Jobs Thursday thanks to the Independence Day holiday, is good news.

description: The suspect in a hit-and-run crash that killed a 12-year-old girl in Brooklyn turned himself in on Thursday and was arrested on 13 charges, including manslaughter, auto theft and two counts of leaving the scene of an accident.

The difference is shadow unemployment, to borrow a term Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, used at her June press conference.

description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

description: When the European Court of Justice ruled that individuals had a right to ask search engine companies to remove links to web pages that might cause embarrassment, the editorial board, warned that such a right could be used to limit freedom of the press and deny Europeans access to information. That is exactly what seems to be happening.

title: China and South Korea Affirm Antinuclear Goals
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The leaders of China and South Korea sent a strong message to North Korea on Thursday, saying they were united in their opposition to the development of nuclear weapons on the Korean Peninsula, though they fell short on how they would pursue that goal.
