title: Iraqi Militants Release 32 Turkish Truck Drivers
description: ISTANBUL  Islamist militants in Iraq released 32 Turkish truck drivers on Thursday after holding them for nearly a month, Turkish officials said.

title: Only Hours From Napa, but a World Away
description: While Napa Valley and Sonoma are renowned for their world-class wines, tasting trips there generally come attached to luxurious digs, spa treatments, $25 tasting fees, Hummer limos and standstill traffic  and all the no picnicking pretension that goes with that.

title: Set Em Up, Joe, With an F Major
description: Giant teddy bears wandering in the woods with Bjrk. Adults riding stuffed ponies that come to life. Animated versions of the ideas of Noam Chomsky. The director Michel Gondry, the man behind these moments, has always seemed most comfortable in surreal worlds.

title: In Norway, Seeking Munchs Brighter Palette
description: Almost from the start, my trip to Oslo last summer became a voyage of discovery into the life and trials of Norways greatest 20th-century painter, Edvard Munch.

title: An Art Scene by the Sea in Uruguay
description: This January, the Uruguayan musician, writer and visual artist Dani Umpi had a solo exhibition in Punta del Este, a resort town on Uruguays eastern coast. It was held atGalerie Xippas, a sleek showroom recently opened by the Paris-based dealer Renos Xippas. Hanging on the gallerys walls were bright collages made of endless tiny scraps of magazine images, and shadow boxes containing bird faces wearing neon wigs, a vivid display of Mr. Umpis penchant for bizarreness and sarcasm.

title: With Focus and Force, Kvitova and Bouchard Reach Wimbledon Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Petra Kvitova and Lucie Safarova stood just inside the door of Wimbledons Centre Court clubhouse, waiting to be called to their semifinal match. The two have been friends, training partners and Fed Cup teammates in the Czech Republic for years.

title: What Did My Mother the Chemist See in Betty Crocker?
description: Growing up, I loved looking at the photos in my mothers old Betty Crocker cookbook: the chocolate cakes, the cookie house, even the cheese balls and fondues. Then, as an adult, I actually read the text and discovered that woven into the recipes were tidbits of advice for the 1960s homemaker: The man you marry will know the way he likes his eggs. And chances are hell be fussy about them. So it behooves a good wife to know how to make an egg behave in six basic ways.

title: The Rickshaw Drivers of Kolkata, India
description: The rickshaws of Kolkata, India, remnants of British imperialism, are among the last in the world, but phasing them out has been far from simple. In 2005, Chief Minister Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee called them an inhuman practice and pushed for their eradication. But the All Bengal Rickshaw Union protested the ban, claiming that without alternative employment, the drivers would lose their livelihood. The photographer Dougie Wallace, who has a book coming out on taxis in Mumbai, Road Wallah, shot the drivers on these pages, many of whom told him theyve been working for more than 20 years for less than 500 rupees ($8) a day. Still, says Shireen Hyrapiet, an instructor at Oregon State University who has interviewed drivers extensively, many young immigrants see pulling a rickshaw as a means of upward social mobility. Marnie Hanel

title: Reply All: The 6.22.14 Issue
description: THE BOOMERANG KIDS WONT LEAVE

title: Who Made That Wet Suit?
description: In 1951, a U.C. Berkeley physicist named Hugh Bradner devoted some weekend time to improving gear for Navy frogmen. Bradner was a veteran of the Manhattan Project who helped develop the trigger mechanism for the atomic bomb; he was also an avid swimmer and diver. At the time, Navy divers wore constricting rubber dry suits over long wool underwear. When they leaked, the wool got wet and lost its warmth.

title: A Baby Called . . . Well, Not That
description: A writer on the run; picking the perfect pair of jeans.

title: Clean Water for Members Only
description: Back in May, the Portland Water Bureau issued a boil-water notice for the area because of a temporary bacteria scare. Many received word of the potential contamination while at work. The only clean water available at my workplace was from a water cooler, paid for by some  but not all  employees who contribute to an office water club each month. Shortly after the city issued the notice, a member of the club reminded others in the office that the water cooler was only for dues-paying members. Thirsty co-workers could buy bottled water from the lobby or a nearby store. My question: In such a situation, what is the ethical duty to share potable water when clean tap water is unavailable? C.B., PORTLAND, ORE.

title: Vietnam, Real and Reimagined
description: The Hollywood new wave that broke with Bonnie and Clyde receded in the late 1970s, swamped by a surge of feel-good jumbo genre films. Still, a handful of unconventional studio movies swam against the tide for another few years. Walter Hills Southern Comfort was one.

title: 1964: CIA Helped Fidel Castros Sister
description: WASHINGTON  Cuban Prime Minister Fidel Castros sister Juanita, who has defected to Mexico, had been in contact with the United States Central Intelligence Agency for nearly four years, the Herald Tribune learned yesterday [July 2]. Mr. Castros brother Raul, his trusted No. 2 man, protected Miss Castro from the dictators wrath and paved the way for her flight while the prime minister was away from Havana, according to highly placed intelligence sources. Miss Castro informed U.S. officials in 1960 that she was breaking with her brothers regime. The CIA made it easy for her to enter Mexico on June 20. She came out quite openly, said an intelligence source.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 4, 1964

title: Jobs Numbers Raise Questions About Fall in G.D.P.
description: Todays strong jobs report forcefully suggests that employment growth is accelerating. Payrolls have expanded by an average 272,000 jobs per month in the last three months compared with 210,000 over the last year.

title: A Battered Mideast Envoy Steps Down, but Keeps a Bag Packed
description: WASHINGTON  Martin S. Indyk announced his departure from Middle East peacemaking last week with a post on Twitter that said he was battered but unbowed. When that prompted questions from people curious about why he felt that way, he replied that if they knew anything about the nine months of negotiations between the Israelis and Palestinians, you wouldnt have to ask why.

title: Back to New York, With Toddlers in Tow
description: Back before they had children, Denise and Jim Burnham spent three years living in New York. They rented a one-bedroom with a balcony for around $3,400 a month in a Midtown West high-rise.

title: Immigration
description: THE DANGEROUS DIVIDEPeril and Promise on the US-Mexico BorderBy Peter Eichstaedt  Lawrence Hill, $26.95.

title: The State of the Unions Books
description: With patriotism and fireworks in the air this weekend, the Book Review turns its attention to American life and thought, looking at new books by or about Hillary Clinton, Franklin Delano Roosevelt and the Supreme Court, among other subjects.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SOUND OF THINGS FALLING,  by Juan Gabriel Vsquez. Translated by Anne McLean. (Riverhead, $16.) Vsquezs closely observed novel is built on Colombias tragic history with the drug trade. In 1990s Bogot, a young lawyer named Antonio witnesses the assassination of a reclusive friend just out of prison after 20 years. Antonios search for answers leads him back to the 1960s, before Bogot was engulfed by violence whose actors are collectives and written with capital letters: the State, the Cartel, the Army, the Front.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SILKWORM,  by Robert Galbraith. (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $28.) The publishing world is the setting for this endlessly entertaining second novel featuring the detective Cormoran Strike, by J. K. Rowling, writing pseudonymously.

title: Louis Zamperini, Olympian and Unbroken War Survivor, Dies at 97
description: Louis Zamperini, an Olympic runner who as an airman during World War II crashed into the Pacific, was listed as dead and then spent 47 days adrift in a life raft before being captured by the Japanese and enduring a harsh imprisonment, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 97.

title: New York Summer Stories: Air-Conditionings Start in Brooklyn
description: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archives that tell tales of city summers past.

title: Buddhist-Muslim Mayhem Hits Myanmars No. 2 City
description: BANGKOK  The authorities in Myanmar on Thursday declared a nighttime curfew in Mandalay, the countrys second-largest city, after a resurgence of religious violence left two people dead and more than a dozen injured.

title: V.I.P. Room
description: Throw a fit. Youll get whatever you want. Thats the advice given to major donors by a senior fixer working the high-end hotels reserved for guests of the Obama Victory Fund at the 2012 Democratic convention. The campaigns prized financial supporters got everything from S.E.I.U. for Obama thundersticks to exclusive campaign briefings to V.I.P. party-suite passes. Those who complained about lack of access could always write a check to get a higher package, according to a manual for volunteers.

title: Under the Influence
description: If Ken Keseys One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest prefigured the Age of Aquarius, then Don Carpenters semi-autobiographical Fridays at Enricos can be read as the swan song of the entire Love Generation. After Carpenter burst onto the West Coast literary scene in 1966, with his gritty first novel, Hard Rain Falling (reissued in 2009 by New York Review Books), he became an unofficial adviser to fellow Bay Area writers trying to ride Jack Kerouacs coattails. Never a hippie celebrity like Richard Brautigan or a living legend like Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Carpenter was a straight man to the more illustrious neo-Beat and -Dada artists of the era. With his moon face, receding hairline, professional discipline and calm demeanor, he was a steadying antidote to the counterculture bedlam of the tumultuous 1960s and beyond.

title: Independence Days
description: Reviewing a debut novel titled The Orchard Keeper, in 1965, the New York Times critic Orville Prescott chastened its author for nearly submerging his own talents beneath a flood of imitation. That young author was Cormac McCarthy, and the influence whose weight Prescott saw him sagging beneath belonged to William Faulkner. Among the hand-me-down characteristics Prescott noted: the wandering pronouns with no visible antecedents; the recondite vocabulary and coined words; the dense prose packed with elaborate figures of speech; the deliberate ambiguity, the hints and withheld information; the confusion in time and place; and the flashbacks that fail to shed much light into the intermittent gloom. All of these factors, he concluded, made for an exasperating book. But the wonder, he pivoted, is that in spite of them it is also an impressive book.

title: Life Into Art
description: Of all the American artists of the 19th century, James Abbott McNeill Whistler was probably the talkiest. In the 1870s, when he painted his famous portrait of his mother, he was living in London, a high-strung expatriate who saw fit to issue mission statements on what seemed like an hourly basis. Art should be independent of all claptrap, he declared, believing he had stripped painting of sentimentality and moral uplift and the other trademarks of Victorian culture.

title: Escape From L.A.
description: Some dystopian novels, like Cormac McCarthys The Road, explore human relationships in dark, existential post-collapse scenarios, uninterested in either causes or solutions. Others engage with global warming head-on and imagine the possibilities beyond catastrophe, as in Margaret Atwoods ultimately optimistic MaddAddam trilogy. But theres a middle path too  one exemplified by Edan Lepuckis first novel, California, in which characters traverse a cross-section of mid-collapse landscape, framed by the gradual decline of civilization. This approach may seem too optimistic given dire news about melting icecaps and acidic oceans, but it does allow for a reading of the novel as satire, skewering the elements of modern life that have brought us to this tipping point.

title: Patriarch and Pariah
description: A religion whose followers believe that the Earth was created somewhere in the neighborhood of the planet Kolob, and that the Garden of Eden was created somewhere in the neighborhood of Kansas City, Mo., would seem to have so fortified itself against mockery that theres no sport in scorning it. In this respect, Mormonism is an honest reflection of its founder, a man who offers such an easy target that providing even a partial list of his myriad and exotic transgressions feels too easy, like a distasteful piling on.

title: Rural Noir
description: Some stories are so sad, you want them to have the comfort of a gentle storytelling voice. Tom Bouman extends that kindness in DRY BONES IN THE VALLEY (Norton, $24.95), his beautifully written first novel set in the mountainous region of northeastern Pennsylvania that sits atop the Marcellus Shale, a vast geological treasure, prized and exploited for its natural gas resources. With neighbors feuding over whether to lease drilling rights to companies accused of poisoning the environment, its no wonder that a crazy old recluse like Aubrey Dunigan would be testy with anyone he finds hanging around his decrepit farm. But these hills are also overrun with meth cookers, dope dealers and Mexican drug cartels. So just because a stranger is found dead on his property doesnt make poor old Aubrey a murderer.

title: A Peoples History
description: Where else in the world does one have the freedom to contradict oneself? Ilan Stavans asks in A Most Imperfect Union, a witty alternative history of the United States from the arrival of European settlers to the shooting of Trayvon Martin and the Mars rover landing in 2012. Its a prequel to Latino USA  his previous collaboration with the illustrator Lalo Alcaraz, a cartoon history of Latino culture in America  and even more ambitious. This time the focus is on the dispossessed and minority groups of all stripes, as well as individuals known and unknown to most students of American history. What the books have in common, Stavans writes, is sarcasm.

title: Bombers Early Light
description: Englands battles, it used to be said, were won on the playing fields of Eton, the American labor leader Walter Reuther declared in 1940, but Americas can be won on the assembly lines of Detroit. Joseph Stalin agreed. Toasting President Roosevelt in 1943, he stated that the most important things in this war are machines and that the United States was the country of machines.

title: Americanos
description: If its true that  in the long tradition of Don Quixote  all novels are about road trips, then perhaps no novels detail the challenges of the journey more than immigrants tales. The tradition is long and worldwide. The hearts of the downtrodden, the forgotten and neglected, swell with hope at the prospect of starting over somewhere. They collect their courage along with essential belongings and begin the trek to the unforeseen. No matter if the stories theyve heard about the new country are exaggerated and acculturation is a frightening hurdle, it will  it must  be better than the present situation. In this spirit, the characters in Cristina Henrquezs new novel, The Book of Unknown Americans, have come to the United States.

title: Harry Hood by Phish
description: This recording is from the bands performance on Tuesday night in Mansfield, Mass.

title: Pill to Prevent H.I.V. Gets a Prominent Backer: Andrew Cuomo
description: On Sunday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced an ambitious goal: Ending the AIDS epidemic in New York State by 2020.

title: Exploring the Wild Weather of Mount Washington
description: In a feat of careful coordination between bouts of epic snowfall and freezing fog, work on a new museum at the self-proclaimed home of the worlds worst weather is now complete.

title: Beyonc: Genius or Terrorist?
description: In her 2011 hit, Run the World (Girls), Beyonc Knowles,the onetime Destinys Child frontwoman turned solo megastar, demands, Who runs the world? This month, Forbes proffered an answer: she does.

title: No Fragile Flower in This Fight
description: Im fighting hard to keep an equilibrium between the characters, said the playwright Laura Eason, whose Sex With Strangers begins previews on Tuesday at Second Stage Theater .

title: And Fade Out ... but Not Fade Away
description: Life Itself, Steve Jamess documentary on the life of Roger Ebert, is in many ways like a wake at which intimate acquaintances warmly recall their departed friend in all his aspects, foibles and quirks along with his talents and triumphs. Deep currents of love and sorrow flow under the succession of often funny recollections of a busy life. But it is a wake where the departed is still present.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Studebaker Drivers Unite
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: A Typewriters Sorry Exit
description: David W. Dunlap is a metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

title: Gehrig vs. Dempsey
description: Rare footage from April 12, 1935, shows Lou Gehrig and Jack Dempsey sparring at McGoverns gym in Manhattan.

title: Audio: Seeing Phishs Harry Hood
Obama Mocks Congress on Climate Change
description: At the League of Conservation Voters Capital Dinner, President Obama spoke out against members of Congress who say that climate change is a liberal plot.

title: Sheltering in Storm, Family Must Flee as Debris Rains From Brooklyn Bridge
description: With his family taking shelter from a powerful storm under the Brooklyn Bridge on Wednesday evening, Jerome Dilligard darted out into the streets of the Dumbo neighborhood to retrieve their car. When he returned a few moments later, all he could see where his family had stood was a mound of gray rubble.

title: Leaders of China and South Korea Meet
description: With Chinese President Xi Jinping at her side, South Korean President Park Geun-hye called for reunification of the Korean peninsula and stated their opposition to North Koreas nuclear ambitions.

title: If Convicted, Rengan Rajaratnam Faces Light Insider Trading Sentence
description: Rengan Rajaratnam, who is on trial for conspiracy to commit insider trading, would face a much lighter sentence than the 11-year prison term being served by his older brother, Raj Rajaratnam, the former billionaire hedge fund manager, if he were convicted.

title: Daimler Demonstrates a Self-Driving Truck
description: MAGDEBURG, Germany  For Daimler, the truck driver of the future looks something like this: He is seated in the cab of a semi, eyes on a tablet and hands resting in his lap.

title: 11 Artists Who Really, Really Love Their Bicycles
description: The photographer Casey Kelbaugh shot KAWS, Tim Barber, Jason Nocito and other artists exhibiting in the bike-themed group art show Joyride, on view through Aug. 3 at Marlborough Chelsea, with their beloved two-wheeled transport.

title: In Case the Fourths Not With You
description: If youre the patriotic sort, this is definitely your weekend to do that most American of things: sit in front of the television. Rousing, flag-waving concerts and other such fare will be readily available on network TV and cable alike.

title: Quick Stock Sales Toy With Volcker Rules Spirit
description: Investment banks are using quick stock sales to toy with the spirit of the Volcker Rule. Wall Street sold some $23 billion in large trading orders, or block trades, for public companies in the first half of the year, according to Thomson Reuters data. Thats almost as much as initial public offerings have raised. These deals are a handy tool for corporations. But at times, investment banks blur the line between capital-raising and banned proprietary trading.

title: Today in Small Business: Saving the Naked Bean
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Then and Now: Tea Party Also-Rans
description: A sampling of the Tea Partys most outspoken also-rans who have gone on to great influence after their losses. Will Chris McDaniel do the same?

title: A Collectors Dream: 149 Forgotten Dylan Records Found in a Closet
description: Record collectors dream of finding caches of rare discs  collections with music that cannot be found elsewhere, perhaps because the number of known copies is tiny, and which therefore commands considerable value, in financial as well as artistic terms.

title: Luna Park Nostalgia (via Futuristic Technology)
description: Classical masters like Michelangelo, Bernini and Rodin fashioned their canonical works from elemental materials like marble, bronze and clay. These days, however, some sculptors have turned to more populist modes.

title: Filmmakers Face Charges in Death on a Set in Georgia
description: LOS ANGELES  A prosecutor in Georgia said on Thursday that three filmmakers had been charged with involuntary manslaughter and criminal trespass in the death of Sarah Jones, a crew worker who was killed by a freight train on the set of the film Midnight Rider in February.

title: Keeping Track of Hurricane Arthur
description: In the hectic and devastating hurricane seasons of the mid 2000s, a coast-grazing storm like Hurricane Arthur would have been unremarkable. Heres the storms limited coastal surge potential (the maps are helpful but are still listed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration as experimental).But in the news flow ahead of the Fourth of July weekend, theres continuing coverage on news channels.

title: Prepaid Mobile Data Plans for International Travel
Subaru Recalls 660,000 Vehicles for Brake Line Corrosion
description: Subaru is recalling about 660,000 of its newer vehicles in the United States because the brake lines might corrode, according to a report the automaker posted Thursday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: The Luckiest Man, on a Playful Day
description: Four days before the Yankees opened their 1935 season, Lou Gehrig stepped into the gym of the celebrity trainer Artie McGovern on Manhattans East Side.

title: Does America (Ever) Need New Ideas?
description: My colleague Paul Krugman, commenting on a generous profile of some of my reform conservative friends by Sam Tanenhaus in this weekends Times Magazine, is skeptical that any new or new-ish right-of-center policy ideas could meaningfully reshape Americas political debates:

title: Former Players File Objection to Proposed N.F.L. Settlement
description: Seven former N.F.L. players accused the N.F.L. and the lawyers representing more than 4,500 retirees of failing to justify how they reached their proposed settlement that includes an uncapped amount of damages for players with severe neurological disorders.

title: Inside the List
description: By the Numbers: Jordan Ellenbergs math-based guide to life, How Not to Be Wrong, is at No. 15 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. Ellenberg is a star mathematician at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, where the local alternative weekly recently asked him about his specialty in number theory  addition and subtraction and multiplication, all the things you can do with numbers, as Ellenberg put it. Havent we already figured all that stuff out? the reporter wondered, and Ellenberg laughed. We know nothing, he said. Right now we are standing in a tiny circle of light around our feet, and every 1,000 years, we push that circle out just a little bit. Every time someone sticks his toe out beyond that circle, it opens up whole worlds of inquiry. Ellenberg is also a published novelist (I met him at a summer fiction workshop almost 20 years ago), but he told the Madison weekly that one of the things hed learned in his creative writing classes was how much he liked math.

title: All the Conventional Cohabitation, but No Nuptials
description: When Rebecca Eckler and her boyfriend decided to have a baby and move in together three years ago, she had one condition. It wasnt the promise of marriage, which Ms. Eckler deemed so 2003, but of a legally binding document that would dictate what would happen to the couples assets if they ever broke up.

title: Text, Vent, Repeat
description: I have a close friend who is going through a tough divorce. She often sends me long text messages about her horrific situation. I have asked her, on many occasions, to call me or come over to my place to talk because I find it difficult to be empathetic in a text reply. But she ignores me and continues sending long and repetitive text messages. Sometimes I choose not to respond, and she becomes upset that I am not there for her. What should I do?

title: One of American Apparels Biggest Shareholders Sells Most of Stake
description: Unnerved by the recent turmoil at American Apparel and anxious about the companys uncertain future, American Apparels second-largest shareholder has sold a substantial portion of its stake in the company.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Hillary Rodham Clintons Hard Choices
description: This week, Peter Baker talks about Hillary Rodham Clintons Hard Choices; John Williams discusses the weeks literary news; Jeff Shesol talks about Uncertain Justice and Scalia: A Court of One; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Taking Marriage One Year at a Time
description: On our honeymoon in Paris, my husband and I were served breakfast every morning by the same short-haired woman. The breakfast came free with our hotel room: croissants, a basket of bread with its little trough of butter, fresh-squeezed orange juice and caf au laits.

title: The Surprise in the Hobby Lobby Comments
description: Timothy R. Williams is a community moderator, monitoring comments submitted to the website.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Hillary Rodham Clintons Hard Choices
description: This week, Peter Baker and Jeff Shesol.

title: Dow Closes Above 17,000 as Stock Rally Outpaces Economy
description: The stock market, continuing a remarkable ascent that began in the darkness of the last recession, surged past a milestone on Thursday after a strong jobs report indicated that the economy might finally be gaining steam.

title: Wheelies: The Mexican Bimmer Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Think Like a Doctor: Sugar-Free Solved!
description: On Wednesday, we challenged Well readers to solve the case of a middle-aged woman who suddenly began to have episodes of confusion caused by low blood sugars. Her endocrinologist thought she might have an insulinoma, an insulin-producing tumor of the pancreas, but the testing he did seemed to rule out that diagnosis. Nearly 200 of you took on the challenge of trying to figure out what was causing her life-threatening drops in blood sugar level.

title: All in This Together
description: Four years ago, a series of circumstances led my husband and me to move back to the town where I grew up, and then to buy my parents home of 25 years. The home came with a lot of stuff: my mothers colorful porcelain egg collection, my fathers dusty musical cassettes, rooms full of frayed chintz and endless silver in need of polish. It also came with my mother and father.

title: In Paris, the Ultimate Place to Watch a World Cup Match
description: As the World Cup moves into the quarterfinal, semifinal, and final rounds, one Paris establishment is offering the ultimate setting for watching a match: Le Royal MonceauRaffles Paris, the grand Philippe Starck-redesigned hotel situated in the Eighth Arondissement. The hotels private theater, with seating for 99, will screen the playoff matches in live broadcast, enhanced with a few choice amenities. There will be strawberry and basil caipirinhas (in deference to the host country) and a pop-up Veuve Clicquot Champagne terrace (its still France, after all). There will be caramelized popcorn, made by the pastry chef and macaron maestro Pierre Herm, to snack on, and a three-course dinner option from the hotels Michelin-starred restaurant, La Cuisine. And there will be state-of-the-art televisions specially installed by Sony for the occasion. While the setting is opulent (and the dress code specifies no board shorts or flip-flops), the mood will be spirited, according to the hotels manager, Pierre-Alexandre Francin. Guests love the fact that theyre allowed to let loose, scream and shout whenever someone scores a goal, he says.

title: Dell Expands a Program for Tech Start-Ups
description: Dell has expanded its offerings for entrepreneurs with the Founders Club 50, a two-year acceleration program for 50 start-ups in a variety of industries. Dell had already established its own Entrepreneur in Residence program in 2011, started the Center for Entrepreneurs and created The Dell Innovators Credit Fund, a $100 million financing program.

title: From a Night at the Roxy to Capitol Hill
description: U.S. Representative Sean Patrick Maloney and Randy Florke were married on June 21 at a church near their home in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Lime Is of the Essence
description: The origins of the daiquiri are vague and subject to embellishment and apocrypha. This is the case with many classic cocktails. We know for sure that there was a mine in Cuba called Daiquiri, not far from a beach of the same name, but we dont know with certainty that an engineer there concocted the first daiquiri. And while the drink is bound forever to Ernest Hemingway, its most illustrious consumer  from whom one variant takes its name  he was not its creator.

title: An Unrevised View of the Declaration of Independence
description: In the days leading up to the Fourth of July, the New York Public Library has drawn crowds with a temporary display of one of its prime treasures  a copy of the Declaration of Independence written out by Thomas Jefferson. By Thursday, more than 10,000 people had lined up to see it, taking selfies in front of the display case, and in some cases quietly reading passages out loud.

title: A Refreshing Drink for a Complicated Emotional State
description: Two things happened this week that give cause for a drink: In the World Cup, which The Upshot has been following obsessively, the United States lost a valiant game to Belgium and is now out of the contest, and the July 4 holiday is upon us. Rarely has there been a better occasion for a summer cocktail that is at once sorrowful and celebratory.

title: SunTrust Reaches U.S. Settlement Over Mortgage Modifications
description: Federal prosecutors and SunTrust Banks reached a settlement on Thursday in a criminal investigation into the banks tardiness in approving mortgage modifications. The bank will pay as much as $320 million for a combination of consumer relief and housing counseling services.

title: Clicking Their Way to Outrage
description: You neednt Google far for recent case studies of Internet outrage. Log in to a social network and youll find it directed at celebrities and civilians alike. (See: Woody Allen, Stephen Colbert and Justine Sacco, the former communications director for IAC who posted an insensitive Twitter message about AIDS in Africa.) Politicians are a perennial favorite: Chris Christie, Rob Ford, Anthony Weiner. Then theres the bigger game: courts of law, social movements, news media outlets, corporations and governments that have rubbed people the wrong way.

title: A Relationship Where Marriage is Freedom
description: In the close-knit world of New York Citys gay scene, circa 1992, Randy Florke was a somebody: flaxen-haired model, up-and-coming designer, Studio 54 habitu and downtown bon vivant. But on the night he met the man who would become his husband two decades later, he was being treated like a nobody.

title: No Moral, No Uplift, Just a Restless Click
description: Garry Winogrand, who has an ample retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was born on the eve of the belt-tightening Great Depression, came of age in the pumped-up postwar 1950s and was photographer laureate  one, anyway  to the long era of morbid cultural and economic obesity that followed, and continues.

title: Under Cover: The G.O.P. in Boldface Letters
description: Sometimes language is the strongest way to convey an idea, says Gail Bichler, the magazines art director. Thats her explanation for why Sam Tanenhauss article about the Republican Partys identity crisis was given a typographic treatment on the cover this week.

title: If Youre Lighting Fourth of July Fireworks, Whos Holding the Match?
description: Were about to go buy fireworks.

title: Privacy Group Complains to F.T.C. About Facebook Emotion Study
description: Update 6:20 p.m.: This post was updated with a comment from the academic journal that published Facebooks research.

title: Space Pod Alights at the Serpentine Gallery
description: LONDON  For the 15th year, the Serpentine Gallery has commissioned an architect to design a temporary structure on its front lawn in Kensington Gardens here. Generally, those who are chosen have not built anything in Britain before. Over the years, Frank Gehry, Zaha Hadid, Jean Nouvel, Sou Fujimoto and Rem Koolhaas have each planted a pavilion here, some more bizarre than others. This years creation, by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, is a kind of alien space pod resting on 62 tons of giant quarry stones. Fashioned from semi-translucent, glass-reinforced plastic, like the Fiberglas used to build yachts, it arrived in 66 pieces and took six weeks to install. Inside are a cafe and space for events that bring together art, poetry, literature and film by emerging creators.

title: Initial Wimbledon Run Still Drives a Former Semifinalist
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Alexandra Stevenson is sure she had to wear three pairs of socks to fit into the mens tennis shoes she borrowed from her coach during qualifying at Wimbledon in 1999, the year she reached the semifinals.

title: Scores of Militants Reported Killed by Iraqi Army, but Group Seizes Syrian Oil Field
description: BAGHDAD  Almost 200 Sunni militants were killed in battles with the Iraqi Army on Thursday, the Iraqi government said, but the militants group gained potentially significant economic ground in their struggle for leverage in the region, taking control of Syrias largest oil field.

title: At 75, Still Stepping Out of Line
description: Could anything be more steeped in the order and orders of the Old World than those 12 little girls leaving an old house covered with vines, in two straight lines, in rain or shine? It has been 75 years since they made their appearance in Ludwig Bemelmanss classic Madeline with their hair bows and yellow hats: models of propriety being led through the grandeur of touristic Paris (the Opera, the Place Vendme, Notre Dame, the Tuileries). Except, of course, for Madeline, who never quite stayed in place.

title: Making American Ideals
description: Stephen Doyle shows how he created an American flag and turned it into an open box for the cover of this weeks Book Review.

title: Lawsuit Claims Katy Perrys Dark Horse Borrows From Christian Rap Song
description: Katy Perry, who will perform at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, may be making an appearance at a courthouse in St. Louis sometime soon. The Christian rapper Flame, who was born Marcus Gray, and three of his associates  Chike Ojukwu, Emanuel Lamber and Lecrae Moore, the co-creators of Flames 2008 song Joyful Noise,  filed a lawsuit against Ms. Perry and her label, Capitol Records, and others in federal court in St. Louis on Tuesday, charging that Ms. Perry used Joyful Noise without permission in her 2013 recording, Dark Horse, Courthouse News Service reported.

title: Reactions to Hurricane Approaching N.C.
description: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina warned people to not put your stupid hat on as Hurricane Arthur approached the state. Meanwhile, tourists and visitors prepared for the storm.

title: A Mondrian for London
description: Amid Londons booming hotel scene, the Mondrian London, opening Sept. 30, is poised to make a splashy debut  on the Thames riverfront in the increasingly trendy South Bank district.

title: A Few Stories Among Characters
description: The appetizers hadnt even arrived and Lee Grant was already discussing the juiciest portion of her new memoir, I Said Yes to Everything. Did she sleep with Warren Beatty?

title: Bill Cunningham | Breakfast at Tiffanys
description: Just when you expect Fourth of July white, women appear all in black.

title: Bill Cunningham | Holly-Go-Delightfully
description: Just when you expect Fourth of July white, women appear all in black. At 8:30 a.m., 18 women visiting from Australia gathered in front of Tiffany & Company dressed  la Hepburn, with black dresses, long gloves, pearls and exaggerated cigarette holders. Most every morning, youll see tourists brown-bagging that famous meal outside Tiffany. One biker accounted for the weather in a two-piece outfit  call it minimalist black.

title: Three Generations, One Home, One Unavoidable Future
description: When the writer Jennifer Conlin, her husband and her children moved in with her parents, it was a new twist on till death do us part.

title: Racing Canoes in the Hudson
description: New York Outrigger is a paddling club that races using traditional Pacific Island canoes. Each year, it hosts The Liberty Challenge, a 12-mile race in the Hudson River.

title: Couples Taking On I Believe After I Do
description: At the start of The Religion Thing, Mo and Brian, a married couple in their 30s living the high-velocity life of Washington lawyers and lobbyists, are having Mos best friend since college, Patti, and her latest man, Jeff, over for dinner. Its been six, maybe eight, months since the women have talked, let alone seen each other, and Patti has a lot to tell.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: A Castoff Joins a Masters Canon
description: When the British publisher Chatto & Windus agreed in 1933 to publish Samuel Becketts first book of fiction, a collection of 10 interrelated stories titled More Pricks Than Kicks, it asked him for one final story, a culminating wallop.

title: Fighting Summer FOMO
description: Summer, as Americans are amply informed by everyone from Us Weekly to The Wall Street Journal, is supposed to be when you go to the beach, feast on barbecue, watch fireworks, and generally frolic in the sunlight. And if youre indoors  either because you have to be or because you just dont like going outside that much  its easy to feel like youre missing out.

title: Weekend Gas Prices Drop, but Iraq Crisis Is a Threat
description: HOUSTON  Gasoline prices are drifting lower just in time for the Fourth of July weekend, although they remain at the highest levels for this time of year since 2008 mainly because of the crisis in Iraq.

title: Campfire Girls Grow Up
description: At Campowerment, a group of women enjoyed a long weekend of traditional camp athletics and bonding.

title: German Parliament Advances a National Minimum Wage
description: BERLIN  The lower house of the German Parliament voted to establish a national minimum wage for the first time on Thursday  8.50 euros (about $11.60) an hour  to take effect next year. Some lawmakers hailed the step as historic.

title: Varied Sides of One Girl
description: The performance collective Carroll Simmons is obsessed with the Girls creator and star Lena Dunham, no doubt about it. But something more complicated than hate-watching fuels its puzzlingly diffuse parody Too Many Lenas 3: Let Them Eat Cake, directed by David Bernstein at the New Ohio Theater as part of the Ice Factory Festival.

title: Giving Uzbekistan Some Beach Flair
description: The air smells of salt and sunscreen, cumin and lamb, the Silk Road and the boardwalk. Out front is a surf rack slapped with stickers for Futures Fins and Mucho Aloha beer; inside are hulking Central Asian meat pastries the recipes for which reach back to the time of the Khans.

title: A Happy Hunter for a Must-Have Taste
description: At a certain point in life, youre old enough to stop thinking that other peoples jobs sound like fun. But when I heard about Mark Rosati, who is the culinary director of Shake Shack  meaning all 27 branches in this country and 21 internationally, including ones in Istanbul, Moscow and Dubai  I thought his job might be an exception.

title: Evening Hours | The Fine Art of Living
description: Tours, shows, benefits and awards fill the calendar.

title: Unorthodox Bookends Leading the Germans
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  It has been a hot and cold World Cup for Germany: from its bold statement match in steamy Salvador against Portugal to its botched lines and opportunities in the chill and drizzle of Porto Alegre against Algeria.

title: Ladies of the Lanyards
description: WURTSBORO, N.Y.  Be aggressive! B-E aggressive! B-E, A-G-G...

title: Todays Titans Can Learn From Fall of U.S. Steel
description: It has been 55 years since bitter labor relations exploded into one of the longest and most debilitating strikes the United States has ever seen.

title: A New Forum for Charles Rennie Mackintoshs Architecture
description: Scholars are completing an online database of buildings by the Scottish architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh, just as restorers are puzzling over how to rebuild his 1909 wing at the Glasgow School of Art, now in charred ruins.

title: Social Medias Vampires: They Text by Night
description: Owen Lanahans parents demand that his cellphone be stored in the kitchen by 10 p.m., but sometimes he sneaks it into his bedroom. Thats because he considers late-night hours his me time.

title: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Myanmar, Ukraine, Brazil and England.

title: Events in New Jersey for July 6-12, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Services Emerge to Help Out-of-State Students Pay In-State Tuition
description: Figuring out how to pay in-state college tuition for a college student who grew up elsewhere is the ultimate money hack.

title: A Seasonal Staple, Slightly Less Buttoned Down
description: The New York Philharmonics Summertime Classics concerts, which began on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall, are an opportunity to see the orchestra kicking back, its president and executive director, Matthew VanBesien, writes in the Playbill. The musical selections are eminently listenable, an article a few pages later says.

title: Franks Way or the Highway. Or Both.
description: For more than a decade, Bill Loizon has catered Detroit-area events from an old Volkswagen Pickup that he turned into a mobile hot-dog stand.

title: Shifting Contexts, Psychodrama and Meta-Works
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  Abstract painting is on the move in Amy Sillman: one lump or two, a spirited midcareer survey at Bard Colleges Center for Curatorial Studies. It jumps around from paper to canvas to phone and tablet screens, as if to say, Catch me if you can.

title: Glass Puzzle
description: Anchored by a magical early work by Joan Jonas, this small group show, organized by the painter Mary Simpson, runs wild with the theme of multiplied and divided selves. It should be seen especially for Ms. Jonass Glass Puzzle, a video installation from the early 1970s that involves two female performers, two cameras and various ways of distancing the spectator from the action. (Ms. Jonas, who once called the piece a puzzle in space, fed a live performance to a television monitor and then aimed a camera at the monitor, so that we ultimately see a fuzzy view of the women thats further marred by reflections on the screen.)

title: Ed Paschke
description: Think of Ed Paschke, the great American painter who died in 2004, was a formalist in wolfs clothing, or the most abstract of Photo Realists. His dystopic photo-based paintings depict the denizens of a lurid dark side, where crime, race, clubs and an eerie glamour mixed with intimations of violence.

title: Events on Long Island for July 6-12, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Words That Do More Than Signify
description: In 1974 Allen Ruppersberg copied by hand the entire text of Oscar Wildes novel The Picture of Dorian Gray onto 20 6-by-6-foot canvases. Its a safe bet that no one has ever read Mr. Ruppersbergs rendering of the book all the way through. Printed in a pale marker on beige fabric, the words arent easy to decipher. But see for yourself: The whole thing is included in Sites of Reason: A Selection of Recent Acquisitions at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Brice Dellsperger: Body Double: Vous Nen Croirez Pas Vos Yeux
description: The French artist Brice Dellsperger takes cinephilia to absurdist extremes. He makes ultra-low-budget films in which he and a few other actors  usually in drag  recreate scenes and full-length versions of well-known movies, retaining the original soundtracks. He particularly favors Brian De Palma, the director of Body Double, but hes also created interpretations of movies by David Lynch, Stanley Kubrick, Alfred Hitchcock and numerous others.

title: Thin Skin: Six Artists from Beirut
description: Since opening last year, Taymour Grahne Gallery has been a boon to New York, which has few other outlets for contemporary art from the Middle East. Its current show offers an instant education in new painting from, or about, Beirut, the cosmopolitan but perennially embattled capital of Lebanon.

title: Israeli-Palestinian Clashes Escalate
description: Clashes between Israeli security forces and Palestinian protesters continued in East Jerusalem as tensions remained high over the deaths of four teenagers.

title: Some Artists Artists
description: Nobody keeps a closer eye on an artist than other artists. So when Karina Daskalov, a director at Marian Goodman Gallery, was planning the inevitable summer group show, she called on artists she knew best, those already on the Goodman roster, for fresh candidates. Nearly 20 responded, and Some Artists Artists brings some valuable introductions and re-encounters.

title: Events in Westchester for July 6-12, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Stroke Lessons (Time Wasted is Brain Lost)
description: Id like to interrupt this nonstop exploration of paths toward planetary sustainability to recall the importance of sustaining yourself, whatever you do.

title: Abandoning Control on Coney Island
description: Leslie Jean-Bart makes pictures of reflections on the shore and boardwalk, where the image changes in an instant, and nothing is ever fully under his control.

title: Many Hands in Creative Frenzy
description: The Museum of Arts and Design is plunging into the deep end of the biennial pool with a big, messy splash. Part swan dive, part belly-flop, its inaugural edition, NYC Makers: The MAD Biennial, is an ambitious, inchoate, sometimes dissatisfying sampling of visual culture from across the five boroughs.

title: Jobs Rebound, Prosperity Lags
description: The spring rebound in employment has come to pass  just a little later than projected. The economy added 288,000 jobs in June, and tallies for April and May were revised upward, bringing job creation over the past year to 2.49 million, the highest level in five years. The unemployment rate also fell to 6.1 percent, the lowest level in nearly six years, and, even better, the decline was unambiguously good news. It resulted from people getting hired and not leaving the work force.

title: Downloads in Decline as Streamed Music Soars
description: For the music industry, the good news about this years sales is not quite enough to make up for all the bad news.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: Bouncing babies, vaccines and Alzheimers. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Birth Control Order Deepens Divide Among Justices
description: WASHINGTON  In a decision that drew an unusually fierce dissent from the three female justices, the Supreme Court sided Thursday with religiously affiliated nonprofit groups in a clash between religious freedom and womens rights.

title: College Debt and Home Buying
description: Swelling student loan debt is commonly cited as a primary factor in the declining homeownership rate among 25- to 34-year-olds. But are the two really related?

title: Small Army, Philharmonic in Tow
description: HOW many pounds of ice does it take to put on a New York Philharmonic concert in the park?

title: 36 Hours in the Berkshires
description: The Berkshires, I used to think, were nothing special. Only after I left my childhood home in western Massachusetts did I learn that not every American countryside is crisscrossed by so many lines of music and literature, by crumbling stone walls running like half-forgotten stories through farms and woodlands, by ellipses of deep green hills fading to blue. The Berkshires, of course, have been beloved for centuries. Long before their Gilded Age heyday as the Inland Newport, a guillotine-fleeing lady-in-waiting of Marie Antoinette remarked on the regions fertility and majestic forests. A sense of that history is one reason that I keep returning to favorite Berkshire spots. But this summer new attractions and renovations are making their mark on the countys cultural, natural and culinary landscapes, and the decisions youll face every Berkshire morning  old or new? art or the outdoors?  are getting harder than ever to make.

title: German Student Under N.S.A. Scrutiny, Reports Say

title: Syria Aid Needed, Refugee Agency Says
description: The United Nations refugee agency said Thursday that 70 percent of its $3.74 billion emergency budget for helping Syrian war refugees remained unfunded, and it warned of dramatic consequences in the Middle East if donors failed to provide the needed aid. Antnio Guterres, the high commissioner for refugees, also said the total number of Syrian refugees had swelled to nearly three million and was increasing at the rate of 100,000 a month. The international community simply cannot afford to let this growing and increasingly protracted population of refugees fall through the cracks, Mr. Guterres, above, said in a statement on the agencys website. Nor can we fail to support the countries who generously host them. The biggest concentrations of Syrian refugees are in Lebanon, Turkey and Jordan, with smaller populations in Iraq and Egypt.

title: Christies Veto of Gun Control Bill Angers Relatives of Newtown Victims

Chris Christie of New Jersey on Wednesday for vetoing a gun control bill that would have banned the sales of ammunition magazines larger than 10 rounds, after he dismissed it as a trivial approach to gun violence and the embodiment of reform in name only.

title: U.N. Peacekeepers Pay Dispute Is Resolved
description: Diplomats on Thursday resolved an unusually bitter dispute over how much United Nations peacekeepers should be paid. The countries that send troops, mostly from South Asia and Africa, are currently paid an average of $1,210 per soldier per month, a rate that has not changed for about a decade. The payments will increase gradually over the next four years, according to an agreement that is expected to be approved by the United Nations General Assembly, to just over $1,400. The countries contributing troops had wanted a rate of more than $1,700, based on an estimate provided by the United Nations Secretariat. Countries that fund peacekeeping missions  the United States, Japan and France are the largest funders  called that demand unrealistic. The total peacekeeping budget has increased to $8.6 billion, a record, though as the United Nations points out, that is less than 1 percent of total military expenditures worldwide. Each country decides how much of the reimbursement rate goes to individual soldiers.

title: Celebrating a Diverse Music Scene

title: Anniversary in Egypt Draws Protests
description: Protesters held rallies in several Egyptian cities on Thursday in opposition to the militarys ouster one year ago of Mohamed Morsi, the countrys first fairly elected president. The protests in the capital, Cairo, were scattered and in some neighborhoods, small and quickly dispersed by riot police officers. At least one protester was killed. Mr. Morsis supporters have held regular rallies since his ouster on July 3, 2013, but the protests have dwindled in the face of an increasingly harsh government crackdown against Islamists and other dissidents that has included mass killings by the security forces, the arrests of tens of thousands of people and a ban on demonstrations. Separately on Thursday, an explosion in a Cairo apartment killed two people who the authorities said were militants in the process of preparing a bomb.

title: 100 Years Later, Scar Remains From a Strikes Fatal Legacy in Manhattan
description: An infamous explosion of violence a century ago in Colorado, which became known as the Ludlow Massacre, was rock bottom in what has been called the deadliest labor dispute in the nations history. title: Andy Coulson Gets 18 Months in Tabloid Phone Hacking

description: Money often determines where the Tour de France starts, with communities bidding for the right to host the first several days of the race. Exactly how much they pay the organizers is not made public, though the county of Yorkshire, England, has a 10 million, or $17 million, budget for this years start.

title: All-White Is the Style, Whether the Players Appreciate It or Not

title: Iris van Herpen Gets the Andam Prize, but Shes Not the Only Winner
description: Iris van Herpen, the Dutch designer who became famous (or notorious, depending on your point of view) last March when she shrink-wrapped the models at her fall show in plastic, was announced Thursday as the winner of the 2014 Andam prize, one of the oldest, most international and most lucrative of the young-fashion awards.

description: The police have arrested more protesters for their actions in the huge march on Tuesday in which tens of thousands of people took over the streets of downtown Hong Kong.

description: MANTEO, N.C.  Even on a relaxed island in the Outer Banks in North Carolina, it is rare for Mayor Jamie Daniels of Manteo to stand barefoot in someone elses place of business.

description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  Three years after Myanmars ruling generals shed their uniforms and propelled the country on an ambitious journey toward democracy, security forces are back on the streets of the former military dictatorship.

description: After the killings of four young people, tensions between Israelis and Palestinians are high.

description: LONDON  When acting is this focused, your own vision seems to improve miraculously. Watching Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy in Stephen Daldrys laser-sharp new production of David Hares Skylight, at Wyndhams Theater here, you may feel youve been endowed with superhuman insight.

title: Television That Is More Than Childs Play
description: Talking trucks. Dinosaur trucks. Builders who use elaborate trucks. Then there are space adventurers, animal and alien, as well as genies and fairies. Television networks and their online streaming equivalents are awash in new characters intended to appeal to preschoolers.

title: Orange Is the New Black Recap: Taystee! How Could You?
description: Season 2, Episode 9 Just when you think youre not attached to characters, just when you think youre watching at some remove, they have to do something that makes you want to yell NO! at the television, to make you realize how deeply invested you are, how magical the thinking that you might be able to save them from their obvious fate.

title: China Detains 6 Vietnamese Fishermen
description: Chinese ships detained six Vietnamese fishermen in disputed waters between China and Vietnam on Thursday, a move that could heighten tensions between the two countries.

title: Which World Cup Team to Root For, Reconsidered
description: At lunch this week in Rio de Janeiro, I asked a Brazilian friend how many times Brazil had won the World Cup in his lifetime. He said, Once  ummm, no, twice. His incorrect initial answer nailed one of my concerns with a ranking I devised last week, a World Cup Utilitarian Fan Index, which aimed to measure how much aggregate happiness would be created by a particular teams victory. Is the second win in ones recent lifetime really as important as the first? Clearly not to my friend, who forgot about the second one. And he considers himself a pretty avid Brazilian soccer fan.

title: German Man Arrested as Spy Implicates U.S.
description: BERLIN  In the latest turn in the yearlong tensions with Germany over American spying, a German man was arrested this week on suspicion of passing secret documents to a foreign power, believed to be the United States. The American ambassador, John B. Emerson, was summoned to the Foreign Office here and urged to help with what German officials called a swift clarification of the case.

title: Merkel Heads to China to Keep Alive Golden Decade of Deals
description: BERLIN  With some experts warning that the golden decade of rapid growth in German-Chinese trade and dealings may be ending, Chancellor Angela Merkel embarks this weekend on her seventh visit to China, accompanied by top people from German business who, surveys indicate, are still markedly more optimistic about China than are their European counterparts.

title: Google Reinstates European Links to Articles From The Guardian
description: LONDON  Googles efforts to carry out a European court order on the right to be forgotten took another twist on Friday as the company restored search-engine links to several newspaper articles from The Guardian whose delinking had stirred a public furor only a day earlier.

title: Chinese Leader, Underlining Ties to South Korea, Cites Japan as Onetime Mutual Enemy
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Chinas visiting president, Xi Jinping, reminded South Koreans on Friday that their two countries had fought shoulder to shoulder against Japan more than four centuries ago, highlighting what analysts have called the main goal of his visit: unsettling Americas alliances in Northeast Asia.

title: New Offices Reflect Growth of Busy Anticorruption Agency
description: The main symbol on the homepage of Chinas anticorruption agency shows the unadorned, old-school, gold hammer and sickle of the Communist Party, to which it belongs entirely. But that simplicity belies a harried new reality these days the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection is in a flurry of activity as it carries out instructions from the president, Xi Jinping, to pull down tigers as well as flies, or high-level corrupt officials as well as low-level ones, according to people who have worked with it or are familiar with its doings.

title: France vs. Germany: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Germany advanced to its 16th straight quarterfinals, but not before getting an almighty scare from minnows Algeria. Its defense, in particular, looked shaky, which will not do against Karim Benzema, Mathieu Valbuena, Paul Pogba and Frances potent attack, which has 10 goals in four games.

title: Classical Playlist: Ailyn Prez and Stephen Costello, Milton Babbitt, Handel and More
description: LOVE DUETSAilyn Prez, soprano, and Stephen Costello, tenorBBC Symphony Orchestra, Patrick Summers, conductor(Warner Classics) The opera world has a new love couple: the soprano Ailyn Prez and the tenor Stephen Costello, who are married and have been appearing together to acclaim. They have been smart, so far, to carefully maintain individual careers. Their latest husband-wife project, though, is an appealing recording: a program of diverse Love Duets. Ms. Prezs warm, penetrating voice matches well but also contrasts interestingly with Mr. Costellos rich, virile sound. They excel in duets from Massenets Manon, Verdis La Traviata, Gounods Faust and, best of all, the tender Cherry Duet from Mascagnis Lamico Fritz. One Hand, One Heart from Bernsteins West Side Story is disappointing: too somber, slow and self-consciously operatic. But they are charming in Ill Know from Guys and Dolls. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: British TV Entertainer Is Sentenced for Sexual Abuse
description: LONDON  Rolf Harris, once one of Britains most popular television entertainers, was sentenced on Friday to five years and nine months in prison for a range of sexual offenses committed decades ago against girls and young women, one of them as young as 8.

title: Macro Debates and the Relevance of Intellectual History
description: One of the interesting things about the ongoing economic crisis is the way it has demonstrated the importance of historical knowledge. This is only the second global financial crisis serious enough to drive interest rates down to the zero lower bound in most major economies; making sense of it has depended crucially on knowing something about the first.

title: 2 Jobs at Sugar Factory, and a Lump in the Throat
description: Robert Shelton had never seen the floor of what he always called the sugar house until the day this spring when he returned to the Domino refinery. In the 20 years he worked in its char house, the kilns blasting the temperature up to 140 degrees year round, the mounds of unbleached crystals had never dipped below the seven- or eight-foot mark.

description: WIMBLEDON, England  The womens final at Wimbledon will feature the surging Canadian Eugenie Bouchard against the former champion Petra Kvitova from the Czech Republic.

title: 1914: Mercedes Finishes First in Grand Prix
description: The greatest automobile race of the year, the Grand Prix, organized by the Automobile Club de France, ended yesterday on the Lyons circuit in a definite and conclusive German victory. Lautenschlager, driving a Mercedes machine, finished first; Wagner, also driving a Mercedes, was second, and Salzer, another German, in the same make of machine, was third. Never since 1895, when the Automobile Club de France organized its first big competition, the race from Paris to Bordeaux, has an automobile race attracted so huge a crowd. Even the Paris-Vienna and Paris-Madrid contests of 1902 and 1903 were eclipsed. Lyons was hardly recognizable. It was the magnet for hundreds of automobiles and thousands and thousands of spectators. On Friday many of the cafs remained open all night. The streets were lined with automobiles unable to obtain garage, and the pavements were black with a multitude of pedestrians moving, because they could not help it, at a snails pace.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 5, 1914

title: New Delay for F-35 Jets as Defense Department Grounds Fleet After a Fire
description: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department has grounded its fleet of F-35 fighter jets after one of them caught fire as it was preparing to take off at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida.

title: Protecting Parrotfish on the Path to a Caribbean Reef Revival
description: Coral reefs in much of the Caribbean have been badly degraded in recent decades by die-offs of algae-munching sea urchins, high-temperature bleaching events, overfishing, invasive species and runoff from fast-paced coastal development.

title: Navigating Sprawling Indonesia
description: When Elizabeth Pisani set out to research her new book, Indonesia, Etc.: Exploring the Improbable Nation, she passed up any ambition to pin the vast archipelago nation down in a pithy manner.We dont even know how many islands there are, Ms. Pisani said. Some officials say 17,000; others, 15,000. Its an extraordinarily difficult thing for even its own government to get its head around, let alone an outsider like me.

title: On the Absinthe Trail
description: Sunbeams shot through the forest, lighting up the wispy fog on the path ahead. For over an hour Id been walking up the mountain trail without seeing a soul, marching to the off-kilter orchestras of Swiss cowbells ringing their dull symphonies in nearby meadows, to which I added my own contrapuntal exhalations whenever I stopped to catch my breath. For several minutes, I was certain that I had lost my way. But eventually I spotted a sign for the goal I was seeking: La Fontaine Froide, it said, was somewhere up ahead.

title: Exploring Lanai, Hawaii, Rough Roads to Resorts
description: The first clue that Lanai is not just another Hawaiian island comes as your two-propeller plane banks off the Pacific Ocean, crossing stark cliffs rising out of the churning blue water before lowering over fields rustling with scrappy brown shrub, dry and flat in all directions, and onto the single runway at Lanai Airport. There is barely a swaying palm tree, beach umbrella, sparkling pool, or splash of tropical color in sight.

title: Banco Ita of Brazil Sells Insurance Unit to Ace
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Banco Ita of Brazil, Latin Americas largest private-sector bank, announced Friday that it is selling its high-risk corporate insurance unit, Ita Seguros Solues Corporativas, for about $685 million to Ace Limited, an insurance company headquartered in Zurich that trades on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 1939: Nazi Germany Unprepared for World War II
description: BERLIN Germany is faced with seemingly insurmountable obstacles to real preparedness for war, according to the semi-annual economic review of the Reichskredit Gesellschaft, which was published here today. Just at a time when the entire world is studying the Reichs economic position in an effort to determine its war potential, this mid- year report reveals there are still a number of monkey wrenches in the countrys war machinery. Germany apparently is still handicapped by a severe shortage of labor, food products and raw materials. The economic expert, who summarized the report, found that the labor shortage is one of the weakest spots in Germanys militarized economy. Even with the present size of fine armed forces, there is a shortage of one million workers and the only apparent way to increase the number of industrial and building workers is to import more foreign labor and comb out superfluous labor in the retail trades. It is estimated that the country could get 450,000 laborers by the combing-out process.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 5, 1939.

title: Popcast: Metal, Poetry and Satan
description: The poet Michael Robbins, author of Alien vs. Predator, has written that poetry and metal share something: they are arts of accusation and instruction. They are also both persistent arts in which hundreds of mini-audiences  enacted, in metal, through worldwide substreams like black metal, death metal, melodeath, blackened death, doom, et cetera  do not, at this point, add up to a popular culture. And they are arts that have given us new ways to think about Satan, at least as a metaphor for something else. John Milton, meet Nergal, from the Polish blackened-death metal band Behemoth.

title: The Secret of Effective Motivation
description: THERE are two kinds of motive for engaging in any activity: internal and instrumental. If a scientist conducts research because she wants to discover important facts about the world, thats an internal motive, since discovering facts is inherently related to the activity of research. If she conducts research because she wants to achieve scholarly renown, thats an instrumental motive, since the relation between fame and research is not so inherent. Often, people have both internal and instrumental motives for doing what they do.

Between them, the American Contemporary Music Ensemble string quartet gently bopped bows against violins and cello, keeping time with the sinuous mechanized pulse.
