title: Take a Seat, Dockside, for Asian Flavors
description: Wide, white and airy, with shiny wood floors and a blue and white dcor delivered with nautical flair, Harlow East is the quintessential Hamptons restaurant, offering expansive views of the water both inside and out. The restaurant, which opened on Memorial Day weekend, is the Sag Harbor outpost of the Manhattan restaurant Harlow, on East 56th Street. Neither place has anything to do with the Depression-era actress Jean Harlow, but both are named after the 8-year-old daughter of Richie Notar, the owner. Harlow East is located on Long Wharf in the former home of another New York City success story: B. Smith. If you go, try to snag a table on the wide porch under the crisp, navy blue awning to take in the best bay views. After all, youll be paying for it.

title: The Personhood Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Tastes From (at Least) Three Countries
description: A spot of bright style in a drab strip mall, Han Asian Cuisine is crowded on a Friday, on a Wednesday, even on a Monday. Im guessing this popularity reflects the restaurants versatility. The big menu created by the chef and primary owner, James Chen, combines three cuisines, Japanese, Chinese and Thai  with a few Korean add-ons  and mixes corner-take-out favorites with more ambitious offerings.

title: Brazil Takes a Painful Step Forward
description: FORTALEZA, Brazil  It was an enormous win for Brazil, but it came at a gigantic cost.

title: How to Prevent Summer Blackouts
description: ITS July, and its starting to get hot. This month last year  on Friday, July 19, 2013  New York City broke its electricity usage record. The demand strained Con Eds grid until it broke. Within hours, 5,200 Bronx residents were without power. And as more heat rolled in, the blackouts did too, in Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston  no major metropolitan area on the East Coast was spared. Earlier that summer, California, Texas, Illinois and other states fought the same battle with heat-driven peak demand. Canada, Japan, India, Nepal and virtually the entire world face the same issue.

title: Friday Night Dancing: Clones
description: From the season finale of Orphan Black, featuring Jordan Gavaris, Tatiana Maslany, Tatiana Maslany, Tatiana Maslany, and Tatiana Maslany:

title: Introducing the ON? App, the Yo of the Future
description: BRILLIANT. Magical. Revolutionary. These are words no one is using to describe Yo, the new app that lets users send the message Yo to other users and does absolutely nothing else. But here are some words they are using: $1 million has already been staked on its success.

title: Two Kinds of Refreshment Near the Water
description: Want to get yourself in a really great mood?

title: In Messis Shadow, Argentine Fans Find a New Hero to Worship
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentina has been disjointed at the World Cup, relying heavily on Lionel Messi for its goals and a couple of narrow escapes. Messis fellow forwards, Gonzalo Higuan and Sergio Agero, have fumbled, and after Agero was injured, his replacement, Ezequiel Lavezzi, played poorly enough that he was substituted.

title: Yanks Stop Twins but Get Discouraging News on Sabathia
description: MINNEAPOLIS  C. C. Sabathia appeared briefly, unbilled, on the Jumbotron at Target Field before Fridays game between the Yankees and the Minnesota Twins. Sabathia was one of several players who were filmed as they read portions of Lou Gehrigs luckiest man speech, on the 75th anniversary of the July 4, 1939, ceremony honoring Gehrig, who died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis two years later.

title: An Online Shift in China Muffles an Open Forum
description: BEIJING  For the past few years, social media in China has been dominated by the Twitter-like Sina Weibo, a microblogging service that created an online sphere of freewheeling public debate, incubating social change and at times even holding politicians accountable in a country where traditional media outlets are severely constrained.

title: Taking on Hobby Lobby After Turning Away From a Religious Past
description: There are many ways a high school senior might decide on a college: cost, what majors are offered, a decent football team, a really rocking Greek system. But when Sarah Jones was in high school in rural Bristol, Va., she was moved by other criteria.

title: About Those Presidential Polls
description: Perhaps youve heard that Barack Obama was named the worst president since World War II in a recent poll. It isnt all that surprising. Given the current mood of the country, its likely that if St. Francis of Assisi were in the White House, he would be getting terrible ratings, too.

title: Not All Will Follow This Star in the East
description: PRAGUE  THE REV. TOMAS HALIK sat in a nest of books in an art-cluttered apartment a few blocks from his parish at the foot of the Charles Bridge. Shelves lined each room and tall stacks tottered on desks, on tables, across every open space.

title: Who Do We Think We Are?
description: WASHINGTON  AMERICAS infatuation with the World Cup came at the perfect moment, illuminating the principle that you can lose and still advance.

title: Still Further to Go on Land Mines
description: Ridding the world of destructive weapons is a slow and often discouraging process. The international treaty outlawing land mines started out that way but has turned into a success story, with 161 countries joining the pact. Nevertheless, the treaty will not reach its full effect if the United States, the most significant holdout, does not also sign on. President Obama took a step in that direction last week, but it is still not enough.

title: Homicide Charges Likely in Baruch College Fraternity Retreat Case
description: Pennsylvania authorities expect to bring charges against most of the 30 or so Baruch College students who were on a rural fraternity retreat in December when a freshman died after a pledging ritual, a police official said this week.

title: A Truth Widely Held to Be Self-Evident: Its a Glorious Fourth, Rain or Shine
description: They huddled under tents and tarps suspended from tree branches on Friday as the wind and rain swept relentlessly downriver off the George Washington Bridge. They were dressed in garbage bags, fearlessly holding umbrellas in one hand, tongs in the other.

title: Unease in G.O.P. Over Mississippi Tea Party Anger
description: WASHINGTON  The stormy aftermath of Mississippis Republican Senate runoff has sent Tea Party conservatives around the country to the ramparts, raising the prospect of a prolonged battle that holds the potential to depress conservative turnout in November in Mississippi  and possibly beyond.

title: In Reversal of Earlier Strategy, Knicks Ply Anthony With Cash
description: Phil Jackson, the Knicks president, had gone out of his way in recent weeks to emphasize the importance of cap space and financial flexibility, buzzwords for his interest in fiscal responsibility. As Carmelo Anthony approached free agency, Jackson continued to preach the virtues of sacrificing cash for the greater good.

title: Lessons From Argentinas Bond Battle
description: A long-running legal dispute between Argentina and investors who own some of its bonds could force the country to default on its foreign debt by the end of the month. That would be a crushing blow for the already weak Argentine economy and could make it much harder for other troubled countries to restructure their debt in the future.

title: Painted by His Classmates: A Portrait of the Con Artist as a Young Man
description: The 17-year-old from Pennsylvania stood out when he showed up for his freshman year at the University of Arizona, and 50-plus years later, his former classmates remembered him well.

title: House Job, Comes With Free Travel
description: Taxpayers complaining about a do-nothing Congress should take note that free travel junkets by lawmakers and their staffs are on the rise. House members are doing something. Last year, they took more free trips financed by special interests than were taken in any other year since Jack Abramoff, the legendary Republican uber-lobbyist, was sentenced to prison in 2006 for corrupt schemes that gave congressional junketeering a bad name.

title: A Town Wont Let Go of a Coin-Drop Line to the Past
description: PRAIRIE GROVE, Ark.  As the driver of an S.U.V. drifted off to sleep one recent afternoon, her vehicle drifted across a momentarily quiet two-lane highway. It came to rest on grass, but not before hitting a utility pole, an ornamental gas lamp and an upright rectangular structure of aluminum and glass.

title: Another Indictment in Albany
description: It is often said that New Yorks state legislators leave office only when they die, retire or get indicted  which comes pretty close to the truth. Since 1999, according to Citizens Union, 26 state legislators have left office either because they have been charged with a crime or they have been shamed into resigning for ethical lapses.

title: Poised to Gain in Iraq Crisis, Kurds Face New Barriers to Autonomy
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Gasoline stocks in the Kurdish region are running low, requiring rationing and hourslong waits for a fill-up. Hundreds of thousands of civil servants have gone months without a paycheck after Baghdad cut payments to the regional government in retaliation for its exporting oil without permission.

title: My American Family
description: On the Fourth of July 1951, my parents were married. Not long ago, I asked my mother, who, at 87, is still going strong, why they chose that date. I thought there might have been some symbolism. She quickly disabused me. It was because that was the only time the market would be closed, and my fathers family could attend the wedding.

title: Man Accused in Brooklyn Hit-and-Run Had Trouble With Drugs
description: The lawyer for a drug addict charged with crashing a stolen minivan into a family in Brooklyn, killing a 12-year-old girl and injuring her sister and mother, detailed on Friday how he brokered his clients surrender as details about the suspects trail of recent arrests came into focus.

title: Californians Keep Up With Joneses Water Use
description: LOS ANGELES  For all the doomsday proclamations about the historic drought that has this state in a chokehold, here is what Californians have done to save water: not much.

title: How to Redraw the World Map
As They Invade, Argentines Seek Soccer Conquest
description: BRASLIA  There is a new song going around the World Cup, a ditty sung by the Argentines to taunt their Brazilian hosts and longstanding rivals. The gist is simple. It asks the Brazilians how they feel about being bossed around in their own country and tells them to prepare for an Argentine championship on their own soil.

title: Refugee Camp for Syrians in Jordan Evolves as a Do-It-Yourself City
description: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan  A young Syrian salesman stopped into Ahmad Bidawis barbershop for a shave the other day. Music wafted on fan-cooled air. Outside, on what has become the main commercial strip here in one of the worlds largest refugee camps, workers steered handcarts packed with lumber and kitchen appliances through sunbaked crowds hanging out in front of shops.

title: Obama Weighs Steps to Cover Contraception
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, reeling from back-to-back blows from the Supreme Court this week, is weighing options that would provide contraceptive coverage to thousands of women who are about to lose it or never had it because of their employers religious objections.

title: The Emojis We Really Need
description: Last month, some 250 new emojis were rolled out by the Unicode Consortium, which develops software standards. Here are several that they might consider adding to that list.

title: Bruno Zumino Dies at 91; Sought to Tie Together Laws of Universe
description: Bruno Zumino, a physicist who proposed a theory called supersymmetry that promised to help tie together the fundamental laws of the universe but that has yet to be borne out in experiments, died June 21 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 91.

title: At Retooled Maracan, Olympics Are Palpable
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  You come to the Maracan on a pilgrims tiptoes: to see and feel the place where nearly 200,000 fans once watched a World Cup final; where Pel scored his 1,000th goal; where Zico played his last match for Flamengo.

title: Young American Qualifier Says She Has Cancer
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Having reached the second round of Wimbledon as a qualifier, the 18-year-old American Victoria Duval will make her debut in the top 100 of the WTA rankings on Monday, the next step in what has been a steady climb up the rankings.

title: Gerald Robinson, Priest Convicted of Killing Ohio Nun, Dies at 76
description: The Rev. Gerald Robinson, a Catholic priest who was convicted in 2006 of murdering a nun more than 20 years earlier, died on Friday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 76.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 4, 2014
description: July 4, 2014

title: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Defeats Costa Rica in Shootout
description: The Netherlands beat Costa Rica, 4-3, on penalties after 120 scoreless minutes, with substitute goalkeeper Tim Krul making two saves in the shootout. The Dutch advance to play Argentina in the semifinals on Wednesday.

title: World Cup 2014: Argentina Ousts Belgium, 1-0
description: Lionel Messi didnt score but his teammate, Gonzalo Higuan, did to help Argentina defeat Belgium and advance to the semifinals.

title: 11th-Hour Talks Are Key for American Apparel
description: The future of American Apparel hangs in the balance.

title: World Cup Drama Plays Out Among Drivers in IndyCar
description: The IndyCar driver Helio Castroneves is no stranger to the Brazil-Colombia rivalry. A Brazilian, Castroneves is teammates at Team Penske with the Colombian Juan Pablo Montoya, and he lives with his Colombian girlfriend, Adriana Henao.

title: What Ruthless People Show
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Its always nice to have a David Steinberg puzzle on a weekend. Not only do you have to stretch your memory muscles to get the excellent entries that cover many decades, but between Mr. Steinberg and Will Shortz, you have some really entertaining cluing.

title: New Brooklyn Theater Casts Audience in Crucial Role
description: The four plays speak to a grim period in American history, touching on slavery, lynching and broader issues of racism. Two of the plays are by Harlem Renaissance writers, including Zora Neale Hurston. One was commissioned by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People right after its founding at the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side.

title: Emilio lvarez Montalvn, Nicaraguas Pro-Democracy Sage, Dies at 94
description: Emilio lvarez Montalvn, a former guerrilla, political prisoner and government official who in the last quarter-century of his life was often called the wisest man in Nicaragua, died on Wednesday in Managua. He was 94.

title: Frank M. Robinson Dies at 87; Author and Adviser to Harvey Milk
description: Frank M. Robinson, a well-regarded science fiction writer whose credits include a novel adapted for the 1974 blockbuster film The Towering Inferno, and who was also a speechwriter and adviser to Harvey Milk, the San Francisco city supervisor assassinated in 1978, died on Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 87.

title: Obama, at Naturalization Ceremony, Calls for Immigration Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama presided over a naturalization ceremony at the White House on Friday for 25 members of the military and their spouses, the second time he has spent the Fourth of July with new United States citizens.

title: Both Sides Now
description: The Macys Fourth of July fireworks show was over the East River this year; Jersey City set off a display at Liberty State Park.

title: On a Beautiful Day for Brazilians, an Unexpected Dark Cloud
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Neymar has brought a lot of joy to Brazilians in the last few weeks, but he and they were in a lot of pain Friday night.

title: Injuries and Uneven Play Take Some Luster Off a Mets Victory
description: The Mets have been vocal in their support of Jon Nieses bid for an All-Star selection this season, despite his 5-4 record. On Friday, Niese was presented with an opportunity to prove his worth against Yu Darvish, one of the games best pitchers and last years American League leader in strikeouts.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 5, 2014
description: You can hear people running their sprinklers when its dark because they dont want to get caught watering when theyre not supposed to be  its maddening.

title: Corrections: July 5, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Todays World Cup Matches: July 5, 2014
description: What to watch for in Saturdays World Cup quarterfinals:

title: Whats On TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE BEST MAN HOLIDAY (2013) In this follow-up to his 1999 debut, The Best Man, the writer and director Malcolm D. Lee reassembles his earlier films college friends  and reignites old rivalries  during Christmas at the home of the football god Lance (Morris Chestnut, above far left, with, from left, Taye Diggs, Harold Perrineau and Terrence Howard) and his wife, Mia (Monica Calhoun). The author Harper (Mr. Diggs) is now battling writers block and financial woes as his pregnant wife (Sanaa Lathan) nears her due date; the educator Julian (Mr. Perrineau) has learned that his wife (Regina Hall) has a past, available for viewing online; the troublemaking Shelby (Melissa De Sousa) is a reality television diva; and the womanizing Quentin (Mr. Howard) is living large amid celebrities. Mr. Lees film is more traditional than its sexually frank humor might indicate, with faith and charity ultimately given pride of place (right alongside human pettiness), Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. But even if some of the crudeness and the drama feel forced, its hard to hate.

title: Pastrami and Partnership, to Go
description: What began in 1982 as a delicatessen in Ann Arbor, Mich., has expanded into a confederation of establishments governed by a management model that other companies line up to study.

title: When Beliefs and Facts Collide
description: Do Americans understand the scientific consensus about issues like climate change and evolution?

title: Autopsy Suggests Palestinian Teenager Was Burned to Death After Abduction
description: JERUSALEM  Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, spent his last hours before being abducted, beaten and most likely burned to death in one of his favorite places, doing some of his favorite things.

title: They Have Seen the Future of the Internet, and It Is Dark
description: Forecasting is tough. The future comes at us fast today, with too many variables to say much with certainty. Predictions are still useful, though: They are an excellent way to examine the passions of the moment.

title: Driven | 2015 Chrysler 200C
description: An ugly duckling becomes a swan.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, July 6
description: Were situated in the finance capital of the world. We just had to know where to look to connect the dots. Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, after BNP Paribas admitted to doing billions of dollars in deals with Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States and agreed to pay a record $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities. Prosecutors said a charity that owned an office tower on Fifth Avenue was actually a front for the Iranian government.

title: Donors Give More When They Have a Sense of Belonging
description: With the rise of behavioral economics, my profession is no longer so fixated on the theory that people are relentlessly selfish, striving only to maximize their own pleasure. We know, for example, that work is not just eight daily hours of suffering that people endure to make money for their own benefit. People actually like to work if they see meaning in it, and they can be generous with their money, too.

title: The Not-So-New Mother, Finding Balance
description: We were all strangers that spring of 1996. Our only connection was that we had all recently given birth at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., and, as recommended by our doctors, had signed up for the New Mother training class. Once a week, we sat in a circle sharing our concerns as a nurse educator led the discussion. It was like those consciousness-raising sessions from the 1960s. But, unlike our mothers who had gathered to secure their place in the world, we gathered to figure out how to be mothers in spite of it.

title: Shaping a School System, From the Ground Up
description: In the fall of 2011, an eclectic group of people from the San Francisco Bay Area began making regular trips to Lima, Peru. Among them were architects, mechanical engineers, ethnographers, communication designers and education specialists.

title: Kevin Tracey, on Putting It Together (After Taking It Apart)
description: This interview with  Dr. Kevin J. Tracey, president and C.E.O. of the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research of the North Shore-LIJ Health System, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: When Taxes and Profits Are Oceans Apart
description: Heres a question for investors in any big United States corporation with foreign operations: Do you know what the companys tax bill would be if it had to bring its overseas earnings home?

title: Pro-Russian Fighters Routed From Stronghold, Ukraine Says
description: KIEV, Ukraine  With a fierce onslaught of gunfire and mortar shelling, Ukrainian government forces on Saturday expelled pro-Russian insurgents from Slovyansk, a long-blockaded rebel stronghold, government officials and separatist leaders said.

title: A Game of Chairs (and Globalization)
description: Oh, if only we had more business writers like Beth Macy, and more business books like her debut, Factory Man: How One Furniture Maker Battled Offshoring, Stayed Local  and Helped Save an American Town.

title: A Four Seasons at Walt Disney World Resort
description: Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts is opening its first Orlando location this August. The 443-room Four Seasons Resort Orlando at Walt Disney World Resort is set on 26 acres in Golden Oak, a Disney-developed residential community rich with palm trees, lakes and protected wetlands and is the biggest resort the luxury brand has opened.

title: For Bellicose Brazil, Payback Carries Heavy Price: Loss of Neymar
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A Colombian defender named Juan Camilo Ziga ended the World Cup for the Brazilian star striker Neymar on Friday with a nasty knee into Neymars back that fractured one of his vertebrae. It was an ugly play and a bad foul. It deserved, at least, a yellow card.

title: Petra Kvitova Routs Eugenie Bouchard for Wimbledon Title
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Eugenie Bouchard arrived at Centre Court with cool confidence and a ruthless tennis game to match. Bouchard, a 20-year-old Canadian, had captured the affection of her country and of the British tabloids, her looks, play and marketability drawing gawking comparisons to Maria Sharapova.

title: A Mad Scramble for Young Bankers
description: A battle is raging on Wall Street as never before, with powerful factions scrambling for control of a precious resource.

title: 1964: Anquetil Wins Tour de France for the Fifth Time
description: A French television news report about stage 22 of the Tour de France, won by Jacques Anquetil in 1964. (From the archives of Frances National Audiovisual Institute)

title: Californias Extreme Drought, Explained
description: The state is experiencing the worst drought in its history. Find out just how bad the situation is getting and what it means for you.

title: Dealing With Barking Dogs
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Argentina vs. Belgium: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Lionel Messi has lived up to his reputation at this World Cup, at times carrying Argentina despite triple and quadruple coverage. But winning it will require help from ngel di Mara, who scored the game-winner in the last round, as well as Gonzalo Higuan and Ezequiel Lavezzi. Belgium has dispatched Algeria, Russia, South Korea, and the United States. With respect to those teams, its World Cup really begins here.

title: Egypt Sharply Raises Prices for Fuel, Drawing Protests
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian government sharply raised fuel prices early on Saturday, apparently signaling the resolve of the countrys new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, to forge ahead with a series of austerity measures despite official concerns about a public backlash.

title: Swedish Sadomonetarist Setback
description: OK, this is fairly amazing. Ive written often about sadomonetarism among central bankers  the evident urge to find some reason, any reason, to raise interest rates despite high unemployment and low inflation. The most influential hive of this kind of thinking is the Bank for International Settlements, which for some reason commands great respect even though it offers an ever-changing rationale  inflation! Any day now! Or maybe not! Financial stability!  for its never-changing advocacy of tight money. But the place where policy makers most dramatically gave in to this urge is Sweden, where the majority at the Riksbank decided to indulge its rate-hike vice while freezing out one of the worlds leading experts on deflation risks, my friend and former colleague Lars Svensson.

title: Vacation Snapshots With a Professional Touch
description: Many hotels are offering guests the chance to improve their point and shoot game through classes with professional photographers.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  This holiday weekend just keeps getting better and better: a Friday Patrick Berry puzzle, a Saturday David Steinberg puzzle and now a cryptic crossword by Richard Silvestri. That doesnt even take into account the barbecue and fireworks.

title: Philadelphia Rowhouse Fire Kills 4 Children
description: PHILADELPHIA  Neighbors gathered outside several fire-ravaged rowhouses here on Saturday, crying and hugging as they mourned the deaths of four children in an early morning fire that ripped through the block.

title: Georgian Opposition Leader Ordered Jailed Until Trial
description: TBILISI, Georgia  One of Georgias most prominent opposition leaders was denied bail and ordered jailed on Friday until his trial on charges of threatening a regional election official, setting off a political firestorm just days before a decisive second round of local elections.

title: At Zingermans, Pastrami and Partnership to Go
description: It was a typical Wednesday morning at Zingermans Roadhouse, a restaurant in Ann Arbor, Mich., that offers nine varieties of macaroni and cheese and smokes its own hogs for pulled pork. But on this particular morning, in a colorful back dining room, finance was on the menu.

title: Free Video Games Say Pay Up or Wait, Testing Players Patience
description: In the world of gaming, as in life, you get what you pay for.

title: At Moment to Shine, Twins Are Light on Stars
description: Sometimes a city hosts an All-Star Game, and the event lines up perfectly with the local teams fortunes. The Montreal Expos, coming off their only postseason appearance, had four starters in 1982. Pedro Martinez, at the height of his pitching powers for the Boston Red Sox, started for the American League at Fenway Park in 1999. Ichiro Suzuki, in the middle of a spellbinding rookie season for Seattle, led off for the American League at Safeco Field in 2001.

title: If He Walks and Talks Like a Monk, but Has His Hand Out ...
description: In Times Square, amid the dozens of Elmos, Mickey Mouses and superheroes who work the crowds for loose bills, new costumed characters have come to seek their fortunes.

title: Two Generations of Tennis Stars Collide in Wimbledon Mens Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The best of two generations of mens tennis will collide Sunday when Roger Federer plays Novak Djokovic for the Wimbledon title with Stefan Edberg and Boris Becker looking on as coaches of the finalists.

title: Fearing Lawsuits, Sheriffs Balk at U.S. Request to Hold Noncitizens for Extra Time
description: LOS ANGELES  Sheriffs around the nation are openly rejecting the Obama administration policy of holding noncitizens who are accused or convicted of crimes for extra time, which for years has enabled the federal government to begin deportation proceedings for thousands of immigrants. The local decisions are limiting the Obama administrations ability to enforce immigration laws and could significantly decrease the number of immigrants deported each year.

title: Waiting  and Waiting
description: A look at the average time to get five kinds of appointments for new patients in 2013, from a survey of 15 metropolitan areas.

title: Bespoke Bats Are Must-Have Accessories for Picky Hitters
description: NORWALK, Conn.  In his airy new workshop, in a business park less than a mile from the Long Island Sound, Pete Tucci has batting cages, renovated offices, a showroom and a humidor large enough to store more than 13,000 billets of wood.

title: Museums Vast Trove Is Distinctly Offline
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It is fitting that the quietest place at Wimbledon is the library.

title: Children at Gunplay
description: An estimated one-third of American children live in homes with firearms, according to public health research, and 43 percent of these homes have at least one unlocked firearm lying about as an invitation to accidental mayhem.

title: A Rotten Mango Crisis
description: AS an apprentice anthropologist, I once had the misfortune of attempting to converse with the Indian critical theorist Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak. Professor Spivak, who translated the work of the French philosopher Jacques Derrida and wrote the famous essay Can the Subaltern Speak?, was visiting Dhaka, Bangladesh, and I went to meet her. After patiently listening while I asked a series of dumb questions about discursive practice, she turned and said, cryptically, I came for the mangoes.

title: Rethinking the Wild
description: YOU wont hear it on your summer hike above the bird song and the soft applause of aspen leaves, but theres a heresy echoing through Americas woods and wild places. Its a debate about how we should think about, and treat, our wilderness in the 21st century, one with real implications for the nearly 110 million acres of wild lands that weve set aside across the United States.

title: The Next Act of the Neocons
description: WASHINGTON  AFTER nearly a decade in the political wilderness, the neoconservative movement is back, using the turmoil in Iraq and Ukraine to claim that it is President Obama, not the movements interventionist foreign policy that dominated early George W. Bush-era Washington, that bears responsibility for the current round of global crises.

title: Dan Auerbach
description: Dan Auerbach is half of the raw blues-rock duo the Black Keys, which is on a world tour following the release in May of their eighth album, Turn Blue.

title: The Health Care Waiting Game
description: ONE small consolation of our high-priced health care system  our $2.7 trillion collective medical bill  has been the notion that at least we get medical attention quickly.

title: Anxiety in Teenagers
description: Readers discuss physiological and cultural factors that may explain adolescent angst.

title: Indias Role in the Nuclear Race
description: India is seeking membership in the Nuclear Suppliers Group, a 48-nation body established 40 years ago to ensure that civilian trade in nuclear materials is not diverted for military purposes, as was done by India itself. Membership would greatly enhance the acceptance of India as a nuclear weapons state and give it a say in how countries trade in nuclear-related exports.

title: Less Sexy, Better for Sex
description: IN inventing a self-driving car, Google has in one fell swoop struck a blow at masculinity, female empowerment, romance, sex and action heroes. It may even violate two of our three inalienable rights  liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

title: Fine Perfumes of the Animal World
description: One of the odder things about perfumes is how much they have depended over the centuries on the scent of other animals  for instance, ambergris, a fatty excretion of the sperm whale, or the musk from the anal sacs of a civet. In concentration, some of these scents are unpleasant, even noxious. One component of civet is skatole, literally the smell of animal feces. Why not just make up a cologne called Hyraceum  the Ultimate Code of Seduction, advertised in a suitably libidinous whisper? The fine print would reveal that Hyraceum comes from the petrified excrement of the Cape hyrax. (Oh, but it turns out Hyraceum actually exists, at a very reasonable $60 an ounce.)

title: Is Joe Riley of Charleston the Most Loved Politician in America?
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  THE custom here is for a mayors portrait to be hung in the City Council chamber only after he leaves office. But in 2007, folks got tired of waiting for Joe Riley to make his exit, and he was put on the wall while still on the job. Hed been running Charleston for more than 31 years.

title: A Company Liberals Could Love
description: FOR a generation now, liberals have bemoaned the disappearance of the socially conscious corporation, the boardroom devoted to the common good. Once, the story goes, Americas C.E.O.s recognized that they shared interests with workers and customers; once wages and working hours reflected more than just a zeal for profits. But then came Reagan, deregulation, hostile takeovers, and an era of solidarity gave way to the age of Gordon Gekko, from which theres been no subsequent escape.

title: Do I Have the Right to Be?
description: Its a disturbing thought: All of us are alive today thanks at least partly to some mass atrocity that was committed in the past. This is because war crimes, crimes against humanity, genocide and ethnic cleansing invariably affect who is born after them. Who knows how many of us can claim, Even if the Holocaust had not occurred, I would still have been born? And if you can, perhaps because you were conceived before 1933 or shortly afterward without having been influenced in some way by the effects of Hitlerism, what about the Crusades or slavery in America? Anyone who reflects on the unjust death of others will be surprised at how much his or her own right to be is put in question, to the point where his or her place on this earth can appear as a usurpation. This might not be obvious at first so lets slow down a bit.

title: When They Imprison the Wrong Guy
description: ON the day after his 32nd birthday, Michael Morton returned from work to find his home in Austin, Tex., surrounded by yellow police tape.

title: The Real Internal Revenue Scandal
description: There is a scandal going on at the Internal Revenue Service, but it has nothing to do with Lois Lerner or her missing emails. House Republicans have not given up on their noisy crusade to tie Ms. Lerner to what they imagine to be widespread political corruption within the Obama administration, but all they have proved is that the I.R.S. is no better at backing up its computer files than most other government agencies.

title: At Home Abroad, Argentina Shuts Down Belgium
description: BRASLIA  As unlikely as it may seem given the rsums of the two nations involved, including the seven combined world championships, Argentina and Brazil had never reached the semifinals in the same World Cup until this year.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 6
description: On this Independence Day weekend, the Sunday talk shows will be focused on illegal immigration as American officials grapple with a surge of undocumented immigrants, especially women and children, crossing the United States border with Mexico. Last week, President Obama said he would use executive actions to make changes to the immigration system without Congress, blaming Republicans for failure to pass legislation to overhaul the system.

title: How Prophets Get Lonely
description: At Bloomberg View, Leonid Bershinksy weeps over the cruel world that for some reason isnt listening to Jaime Caruana of the BIS, who warns that we must raise interest rates now now now. Why is this prophet so lonely?

title: From East to West, Cultivating Change on the Grass Courts
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Change can be upon us at the All-England Lawn Tennis Club as quickly as the rain clouds and five-year-old roof can roll over old Centre Court, which pretty much means before we know it.

title: Costa Rica vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: On paper, this is the biggest mismatch of the quarterfinals, with the Netherlands a comfortable favorite to stop Costa Ricas Cinderella run. Robin van Persies finishing, Arjen Robbens flicks and tricks and Wesley Sneijders leadership are expected to overwhelm a Costa Rica team that has punched above its weight.

title: Amid Modis Centrist Shift, an Aide With a Turbulent Past Rises
description: MUZAFFARNAGAR, India  Prime Minister Narendra Modis new junior minister for agriculture, Sanjeev Balyan, is a first-time officeholder famous for precisely one thing: After two Hindu men were killed in an altercation with Muslims in his district last summer, he rallied crowds of angry young men from his caste, urging them to protect their own kind.

title: After Barrage of Personal Attacks, Indonesian Presidential Election Tightens
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The allegations have been flying thick and fast as Indonesias presidential election campaign nears its end.

title: Looking for Breakout Star, M.L.S. Pins Hopes on a World Cup Standout
description: Shortly after he signed a professional contract with the Seattle Sounders in 2013, DeAndre Yedlin had tattoos put on his calves that joined to read, Always Remember the Beginning.

title: A Legends Dress, My Mothers Memories
description: When a parents health deteriorates and you have to move her quickly across state borders, the to-do list swells like an air mattress.

title: The Amazons Floating Fields
description: CATALO, Brazil  In this floating village, there is only one way to travel. Students go to school by boat. Pentecostals go to church by boat. Taxis arrive by boat. Even the soccer field is often a boat.

title: A Century-Old Landmark of the Everglades Confronts the Possible End of the Road
description: CHOKOLOSKEE ISLAND, Fla.  The Seminole medicine man climbed the steep wooden stairs to the Ted Smallwood Store and shuffled past the counter used to measure raccoon hides, past the Jeris Hair Tonic bottles, the Sloans Liniment for aches and Dr. Gunns mid-19th-century Home Book of Health.

title: When Justice Isnt Just
description: My Sunday column looks at the flaws in our criminal justice system through the remarkable story of Michael Morton, author of a new memoir. Morton was a middle class guy in Austin with no criminal record, and he came home from work one day to find his wife murderedand himself a key suspect. He spent the next 25 years in prison for murdering her, partly because the authorities suppressed exculpatory evidence. Its as harrowing a story as you can imagine, and its a good starting point for a discussion about what to do to improve the justice system. Three elements of an improvement would be, I think: 1.) an end to the disastrous mass incarceration experiment that began in the 1970s; 2.) an improved network of mental health services, so that prisons and jails are no longer our default mental health system; 3.) improved treatment programs for addicts, so that a failed war on drugs no longer fills up prisons and jails. Thats all a bit glib, I realize, and theres no silver bullet solution the problems of drugs, but its impossible to read Mortons memoir without feeling that the present system is an appalling and expensive mess.

title: Shadow of Brutal 79 War Darkens Vietnams View of China Relations
description: LANG SON, Vietnam  She was 14 when Chinese artillery fire echoed across the hills around her home in northern Vietnam, and hundreds of thousands of Chinese soldiers swarmed across the border. She remembers sprinting with her parents through the peach trees, her waist-length hair flying, as they fled the invaders. They ran straight into the enemy.

title: Militant Leader in Rare Appearance in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Wearing a black turban and black robes, the leader of the self-proclaimed Islamic state that stretches across eastern Syria and much of northern and western Iraq made a startling public appearance, his first in many years, at a well-known mosque in the Iraqi city of Mosul, according to a video released on Saturday whose contents were confirmed by experts and witnesses.

title: Q. and A.: Lyle Goldstein on China and the Vietnamese Military
description: As friction increases between China and Vietnam over the South China Sea, an important question is how Vietnams military, famed decades ago for its resilience and guerrilla warfare, measures up. For the last two months, Chinese and Vietnamese Coast Guard vessels have been jostling each other around a billion-dollar Chinese oil rig that Vietnam says was unilaterally placed in its waters by Beijing. (Beijing says the waters are Chinese.) Warships from both countries lurk in the distance, and from time to time, the Chinese send air force fighters into the rigs vicinity to show they mean business.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: One Whistle, One Point
description: The Red Bulls have played 17 games this season in Major League Soccer and eight, nearly half, have ended in ties. Some were deserved, some fortunate, some disappointing, some enraging.

title: Oaklands Future Can Wait as Beane Makes Big Bet on the Present
description: Billy Beane is all in.

title: New York Summer Stories: Life in the City
description: During this holiday weekend, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archives that tell tales of city summers past.

title: Coming to U.S. for Baby, and Womb to Carry It
description: At home in Lisbon, a gay couple invited friends over to a birthday celebration, and at the end of the evening shared a surprise  an ultrasound image of their baby, moving around in the belly of a woman in Pennsylvania being paid to carry their child.

title: Younger Americans Show Promise
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Its not pretty at the moment, but the cavalry is coming, Patrick McEnroe said last month of the state of American mens tennis.

title: Aggressive Tactics Help Kvitova Make Quick Work of Bouchard
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Petra Kvitova won the points before they really got started, allowing her to collect her second Wimbledon title.

title: Movie Review: Life Itself
description: Geoffrey OBrien reviews Life Itself.

title: Flying the Old-Fashioned Way
description: Gail Bennett has played Mary Poppins before, but for her reprisal of the role at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts, she had to learn completely new dance routines.

title: Movie Review: Earth to Echo
description: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews Earth to Echo.

title: Oh, Say
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Its a really good thing that I am not a professional musician, because my first thoughts when I looked at the words formed by the circled letters in Daniel C. Bryants puzzle was, Those arent the first notes of the national anthem.

title: Beating of Palestinian-American Boy Caught on Video
description: As my colleague Jodi Rudoren reports, a video posted online appears to show Israeli police officers beating a Palestinian-American boy after his detention on Thursday during protests in East Jerusalem that followed the death of his cousin, a teenager who was kidnapped and killed two days earlier.

title: Young Hand, Just Out of High School, Guides a City
description: ARCHER CITY  Kelvin Cletus Green sat flanked by City Council members. He was 18 years old but looked much younger, and as Kim Whitsitt  the city secretary who is also Mr. Greens godmother  whispered to him about the next agenda item, a stranger could be forgiven for assuming he was a student shadowing city officials for his civics class.

title: State Starts to Have Company in Stand on Academic Standards
description: When Texas refused to sign onto a nationwide effort five years ago to develop common academic standards in reading and math  putting $700 million in federal money at risk  the state found itself in lonely territory.

title: Phelps Has Strong Outing for Yanks, but Late Error by Cervelli Wastes It
description: MINNEAPOLIS  David Phelps gave the Yankees a quality start on Saturday. He shut out the Minnesota Twins for six innings, allowed a leadoff homer to Josh Willingham in the seventh and left at the end of the inning, providing a badly needed rest for a taxed Yankees bullpen.

title: Revenue Aside, Legislators See a Need to Cut
description: In one corner, the governments number nerds are telling us that the state treasury will be taking in more money than anyone could have imagined: Thank you, oil and gas industry.

title: Texas Isnt Keeping Up With National Drop in Teenage Births
description: DALLAS  Charmaine Carbs thought that she would be the only senior at her high school to walk across the stage pregnant at graduation. She was wrong.

title: By Talking, Inmates and Victims Make Things More Right
description: NORFOLK, Mass.  For many of his 15 years behind the soaring prison walls here, Muhammad Sahin managed to suppress thinking of his victims anguish  even that of the one who haunted him most, a toddler who peeked out from beneath her blankets the night he shot and killed her mother in a gang-ordered hit.

title: An Elite Club May Add Its Second Woman
description: Hou Yifan of China is on the cusp of becoming just the second woman to crack the list of the worlds top 100 players.

title: Power Struggles in Middle East Exploit Islams Ancient Sectarian Rift
description: RIFFA, Bahrain  Black and yellow concrete barricades block the roads entering this wealthy Sunni enclave, where foreign-born Sunni soldiers in armored personnel carriers guard the mansions of the ruling family and the business elite.

title: Students Joining Battle to Upend Laws on Voter ID
description: WASHINGTON  Civil rights groups have spent a decade fighting requirements that voters show photo identification, arguing that this discriminates against African-Americans, Hispanics and the poor. This week in a North Carolina courtroom, another group will make its case that such laws are discriminatory: college students.

title: Missing 2-Year-Old Girl Is Found Dead in Prospect Park Lake
description: A 2-year-old girl who wandered away from her family on Saturday at Prospect Park in Brooklyn was found dead after an hourslong search, the police said.

title: Abandoning Control on Coney Island
description: Like a cooling salve, the Atlantic waves lapping onto the Coney Island shore had a calming effect on Leslie Jean-Bart. About eight years ago he had gone there seeking peace, his photographic career on hold as he dealt with his mothers dementia.

title: An Upbeat Wright Returns After an Encouraging Stint by a Rookie Replacement
description: Nine days after aggravating an injury to his left rotator cuff, David Wright stepped into the batters box at Citi Field before Saturdays game against the Texas Rangers.

title: A Late Entry Helps the Dutch Avert an Exit
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  With a World Cup quarterfinal in the closing moments of extra time on Saturday, Louis van Gaal, the coach of the Netherlands, made a move that was as bold as it was rare.

title: New York Racing on Display at Belmont Park
description: New York, which has not hosted the Breeders Cup World Championships since 2005, took a small step back onto thoroughbred racings international stage when Belmont Park held its inaugural Stars and Stripes Day on Saturday.

title: Injury and a Loss Eclipse Wrights Return to the Mets
description: Early Saturday, it appeared that luck was turning in the Mets favor. The Mets were coming off a victory the night before, and David Wright was set to return to the lineup after missing the last seven games with a bruised rotator cuff. It also appeared as if the Mets would soon have an excess of healthy starting pitchers.

Pappas of Franklin, Mich. Rabbi Philip Kranz, an uncle of the groom, officiated at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in Manhattan.

description: Anita A. Gupta and Kunal Amreesh Modi were married Saturday in San Jose, Calif. Pandit Uma Shankar Dixit, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Hayes Mansion, a hotel and events space.

title: Elissa Miller-Kay and Warangkana Chomchuen
description: Elissa Pauline Miller-Kay and Warangkana Chomchuen are to be married Sunday at Caffino Ristorante, an Italian restaurant in Toronto. Nathan Cheifetz, a licensed wedding officiant in the province of Ontario, will perform the ceremony.

description: Kasey Marie Wickman and Christopher James Rosen were married Saturday evening at First Presbyterian Church in Portland, Ore. The Rev. Amber Nettleton, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Indu Chugani and Sushil Singh
description: Indu Nanik Chugani and Sushil Kumar Singh were married Saturday at Sakonnet Vineyards in Little Compton, R.I. Amrutur V. Srinivasan, a Hindu priest who became a Universal Life minister so he could officiate in Rhode Island, performed the ceremony.

title: Liza Kaplan, Evan Glucoft
description: Liza Olivia Kaplan and Evan Popik Glucoft were married Saturday evening at Calistoga Ranch, a resort in Calistoga, Calif. Rabbi Stephanie E. Kramer officiated.

title: Imbibing the Joys of a Lusty Poet
description: Before Allen Ginsberg and the Beats descended on San Francisco, there was James Broughton (1913-99), a poet, experimental filmmaker, pansexual free spirit and proto-hippie who, like Ginsberg, was a spiritual descendant of Walt Whitman. His exuberant life and times are recalled in Big Joy: The Adventures of James Broughton, now available on DVD and on demand. Directed by Stephen Silha, Eric Slade and Dawn Logsdon, the documentary captures the euphoric mood of bohemian San Francisco just after World War II and includes many excerpts from his exhortatory poetry. For much of his life, he followed the dictum of his motto, Follow your weird.

title: A Week When Parks Go Pan-American
description: Were not all polyglots yet, but the Latin Alternative Music Conference keeps on pushing. This is the 15th year of a gathering for music that envisions an ever more multicultural United States listening to pan-American kinds of rock, hip-hop and pop. Conference participants strategize by day while, the music theyre so passionate about is presented around the city.

title: Down Memory Lane via Tonya and O. J.
description: Every decade apparently must have its day. Back in 2000, NBC had the two-part movie The 70s. CNN is in the midst of a 10-part documentary called The Sixties. And on Sunday, the National Geographic Channel begins three nights of a wide-ranging documentary titled The 90s: The Last Great Decade?

title: In an Exodus Tale, Myriad Subplots
description: At the beginning of Reggie Wilsons Moses(es), the dancers and singers introduce themselves and say how long each has belonged to his Fist and Heel Performance Group. For some, its one year, for others, more than 20, but it looks as if theyve been performing together forever. They make a formidable tribe, equal parts exuberance and introspection, youth and experience.

title: Corrections: July 6, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Firefighter Dies After Blaze at Brooklyn High-Rise
description: A New York City firefighter died late Saturday after a blaze in a Brooklyn high-rise, authorities said.

title: 1914: America Sends a Million Dollars of Gold to Mexico
description: EL PASO, Tex.  More than a million dollars of gold from big business sources in the eastern States alone have been poured into the Mexican rebel coffers during the last nine months. This is admitted by Constitutionalists of prominence. It is added that since the split between Generals Carranza and Villa much money has been withheld, and the rebel cause now faces serious embarrassment. The bitterness engendered by the clash of the two leaders has loosened tongues, and the facts are now known for the first time. The money has come here in single drafts for $50,000 at a time on two local banks transferring the funds. It is impossible to get documental proof, but it is believed that most of it has gone to the honest needs of warfare. So acute has become the need of more money that Senor Alberto Madero has hurried to New York to impress the capitalists alleged to be financing the revolution with the necessity of funds. General Villa is trying to raise money by concessions for the sale of dynamite and the exportation of cattle. The Pearson and Guggenheim lumbering and mining interests have been allowed to reopen. Unusual protection is being afforded the latter. The New York Herald, European Edition, July 7, 1914

title: With Revenue Roaring, Twitters Advertising Team Is Untouched by Turmoil
description: Twitters top executive ranks have been transformed in the last year, from its general counsel to, most recently, its chief financial officer.

title: 6 Israelis Held Over the Killing of Palestinian
description: JERUSALEM  Confronting the possibility of rising retaliatory violence between Jews and Palestinians, the Israeli authorities arrested six Israelis on Sunday in the killing of a Palestinian teenager, found beaten and burned in a Jerusalem forest last week.

title: Malaysia Is Sending More Ships to Search for Jetliner
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Malaysian government said Sunday that it would step up efforts to search the southern Indian Ocean for Malaysia Airlines missing Flight 370, in the latest indication that a broad international effort to find the plane will continue for many months.

title: Decisions, Management and the Best Day for an Interview
description: PARIS  According to Sidney Toledano, the 63-year-old, long-serving chief executive of Christian Dior Couture, the most important management trait cannot be learned at business school.

title: Slump Stories and the Inflation Test
description: Noah Smith has another post on John Cochranes anti-Keynesian screed, in which he takes on various structural stories about the continuing weakness of the economy. As usual, Noah is very mild and eager to give the benefit of the doubt, although even so theres not much there.

title: The Enduring Appeal of the Something-Free Diet
description: Whether its fat, sugar,glutenor something new,the idea of cutting one item out of our diets seems to maintain its hold on our culture  even if what were supposed to cut changes with time. What is it about getting rid of something that makes it so popular, almost independent of what that something is?

title: Known for Rescues, a Firefighter Dies in a Brooklyn Blaze
description: After the call came in  a fire licking the curtains in a 19th-floor bedroom window, smoke pouring into the night  the fire ladder truck from nearby Hooper Street was the first to arrive on Saturday at the Brooklyn high-rise. Out jumped Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, a 14-year veteran, leading a team of four firefighters into 75 Wilson Street in Williamsburg. It seemed a routine fire, nothing out of the ordinary. Yet minutes after Lieutenant Ambelas, 40, headed into apartment 19B with two other firefighters to look for people who might be trapped, he was carried out unconscious, badly burned and on the verge of death.

title: Brazil Lobbies for Punishment of the Colombian Player Who Injured Neymar
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils soccer federation is pressing FIFA to punish the Colombian player whose tackle caused the injury that has sidelined Brazils top player, Neymar, for the rest of the World Cup.

title: Crowding the Frame
description: W.M. Hunt has collected hundreds of photos featuring crowds forming everything form panoramas to living mosaics.

title: With a Charitable Veneer, Littering the Streets With Collection Bins
description: Kyiesha Kelly was up late washing dishes one night in December when she heard the rumble of a truck outside. Peering out the kitchen window in her apartment, she spotted several men dragging a huge used-clothing collection bin from a truck across the street to the sidewalk in front of the community garden that she helps run in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: London Auctions Cap a Go-Go Season
description: LONDON  The momentum seems unstoppable. Last week in London, Sothebys, Christies and Phillips raised an aggregate 200 million pounds, or about $340 million, from their evening sales of postwar and contemporary art, a 26 percent increase on the equivalent series of sales last summer.

title: Editorial Cartoon
description: The North Korean leader blows his top over the Beijing-Seoul summit.

title: The Debt to Ones Homeland
description: I was not a rat who jumped ship at the first sign of trouble, Leonid Bershidsky, a well-known journalist and media entrepreneur, wrote in mid-June, announcing his intention to leave Russia. I am more a sailor who, seeing that the captain had changed course toward a port of ill repute  and with loudspeakers blaring his intent  quietly, and without panicking, lowered the lifeboat and began rowing toward the port for which all of us had originally set sail.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 5, 2014
description: July 5, 2014

title: Djokovic Back on Top After a Chaotic Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Novak Djokovic clutched the most coveted award in his sport, the gilded silver, two-handled trophy presented to the winner of the Wimbledon mens singles title.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) MILEY CYRUS: BANGERZ TOUR This two-hour concert special, filmed last month, captures the antics of Ms. Cyrus, above, onstage and off as she sings and twerks her way through hits including We Cant Stop and Wrecking Ball in Barcelona and Lisbon.

title: Marching Ahead With Nostalgia
description: A little compare-and-contrast chart, inspired by the assonant names of the conservative writer Dinesh DSouza and the classic march composer John Philip Sousa, appeared over the weekend in The New York Times Magazine. It emphasized their differences. (In the despises category: Mr. DSouza, lefties; Sousa, recorded music.)

title: London Theater Journal: Two Wars, With Song and Sentiment
description: LONDON  If war is indeed hell  and I hear no one contradicting that assertion  then I spent the better part of a day here in the netherworld. The afternoon found me in Vietnam in the mid-1970s, courtesy of a gauzy new revival of the Alain Boublil and Claude-Michael Schonberg musical Miss Saigon. That night I joined a ragged regiment of Irish soldiers during the First World War, via the National Theaters startling production of Sean OCaseys seldom-seen The Silver Tassie.

title: Gruesome Attacks in Kenyan Villages Heighten Fears of a Nation on Edge
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  More than 20 people were killed in two attacks on Kenyas coast on Saturday night  with residents saying that many of the victims had their hands bound and their throats slit  in the latest in a string of gruesome assaults with ethnic undercurrents.

title: Hamilton Wins British Grand Prix
description: SILVERSTONE, England  After a massive accident on the first lap delayed the 50th British Grand Prix at the Silverstone for an hour, British fans were rewarded with an exciting race that ended with a victory for the home favorite, Lewis Hamilton.

title: 1964: Fans Scream for Beatles at Movie Premiere
description: LONDON  Twelve thousand screaming teen-agers packed Piccadilly Circus tonight [July 6] for a look at the Beatles as they attended the world premire of their first film, A Hard Days Night. Also present for the charity premire were Princess Margaret and her husband, Lord Snowdon, but they received a much smaller ovation from the crowd. The Beatles  Paul McCartney, George Harrison, John Lennon and Ringo Starr  were presented to the royal couple in the lobby of the theater. What do you think of the film? asked the princess. I dont think we are very good, maam, Mr. McCartney said with a smile. But the director is very good. As soon as the royal party left, usherettes in dresses printed with the Beatles faces rushed up to the quartet and asked them to sign their dresses. Ambulance men carried off about 20 fainting girls including one who screamed from her stretcher: Let me up! I want to see them!  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 7, 1964.

title: Do You Live in Detroits North End Neighborhood?
description: Times reporters covering Detroits path to recovery are looking to talk to residents of the North End neighborhood about their experiences and what they would like to see improved as the city moves forward.

title: Netanyahu on Death of Palestinian Youth
description: On Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke out on the killing of the youth and said of the crime, We do not differentiate between terrorists, and we will respond to all of them.

title: Ties Strained, Germans Press U.S. to Answer Spy Allegation
description: BERLIN  With mystery enveloping a German intelligence service employee accused of spying  reportedly for the United States  German officials and commentators on Sunday angrily demanded a response from Washington, warning that an already troubled relationship was at risk of deteriorating to a new low.

title: Yankees Make Pitching and Hitting Moves Before Dispatching Twins
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Vidal Nuno arrived at Target Field early Sunday morning. Told by Yankees Manager Joe Girardi that he had been traded to Arizona for the veteran starting pitcher Brandon McCarthy and cash considerations, Nuno spent the next 15 minutes going through the clubhouse, shaking hands and saying goodbyes. He seemed upbeat rather than upset.

title: Afghan Election Dispute Forcing Western Officials to Take a Stand
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A growing number of Western officials are calling for an audit of the ballots cast in the Afghan presidential election, increasing the likelihood that the nations electoral commission will have to formally reassess the June 14 runoff vote even as it prepares to announce preliminary results.

title: Independent Music Labels and Young Artists Offer Streaming, on Their Terms

Now in its 26th season, the series attracts dancers of all stripes: young, old, amateur, professional. They tend to have one thing in common: a fussiness, or a passion, when it comes to shoes. Sometimes footwear choice is a matter of tradition. (Think of cowboy boots for Cajun or lightweight sneakers for acrobatic swing dancing.) DJ EZ has been one of the great popularizers of U.K. garage music in its various forms since the late 1990s. title: Director to Correct Films on Guatemala
description: The director of two documentaries about human rights abuses in Guatemala said that she planned to correct inaccuracies in those films, including blaming the countrys military for a village massacre, The Associated Press reported. The director, Pamela Yates, said in a statement that the decision resulted from investigations into the circumstances surrounding the killing of 17 villagers recounted in her 1984 film, When the Mountains Tremble. The scene took place in Batzul, where a local woman told the filmmakers that the men responsible for the murders wore military uniforms. Later reports and a recent visit by Ms. Yates revealed that the men had been members of guerrilla forces dressed as army soldiers. Ms. Yates said that she intended to make a correction that will clarify what happened in this scene in both that film and her 2011 documentary, Granito: How to Nail a Dictator. When the Mountains Tremble won multiple honors upon its release, including the Special Jury Award at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: No More Anthony on Opie & Anthony
description: The radio shock jock Anthony Cumia has scratched off another of his nine lives: He was fired last week from SiriusXMs Opie & Anthony radio show. The decision came after Mr. Cumia, below, posted what the company described in a news release as racially charged and hate-filled remarks on his personal Twitter account over a run-in with a black woman in Times Square. The tweets, as well as expletive-laced reactions toward his firing, have been removed from his account but can be found online. In the news release, Patrick Reilly, a SiriusXM spokesman, called Mr. Cumias comments abhorrent and wholly inconsistent with the companys values. Fans have taken to social media to express support of Mr. Cumia, some saying theyve canceled their SiriusXM subscriptions. An online petition to reinstate him had reached nearly 7,000 signatures through early Sunday afternoon. The shows other host, Greg Hughes, a.k.a. Opie, posted on Twitter that he was devastated and would meet with SiriusXM on Tuesday. The hosts have a history of trouble. In 1998, Mr. Cumia and Mr. Hughes were fired from a Boston radio station for an April Fools prank in which they extensively, and falsely, reported that the citys mayor had died in a traffic accident. In 2002, their syndicated show in New York was canceled after they broadcast a live account of a couple supposedly having sex in St. Patricks Cathedral. And in 2007, their XM Radio show was suspended for 30 days because of a bit about violent sex and Condoleezza Rice.

title: McCartney Returns
description: Paul McCartney resumed performing Saturday in Albany after illness forced him to take a two-month hiatus. Mr. McCartney, 72, was hospitalized in May in Tokyo with a viral infection, prompting him to cancel parts of his Out There tour in Japan and South Korea and to reschedule United States dates. He is scheduled to perform on Monday in Pittsburgh and on Wednesday in Chicago, with shows nationwide through October.

Foolhardy denial about the severity of rising seas is underway in North Carolina, where the Republican Legislature, prodded by tourism-dependent coastal counties and alarmed homeowners, ordered a state commission of experts to soften its estimate that coastal waters could rise 39 inches by the end of the century. The commission was told to revise its outlook, take into account dissenting views of climate change and produce a forecast of no more than 30 years  in hopes of keeping the estimated sea-level rise to no more than eight inches.

Investigations by the state attorney generals office have documented that the merger gave the hospitals enormous market leverage to drive up health care costs in the Boston area by demanding high reimbursements from insurers that were unrelated to the quality or complexity of care delivered.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) DANGEROUS ACTS STARRING THE UNSTABLE ELEMENTS OF BELARUS (2014) Since 2005, the Belarus Free Theater, including Yana Rusakevich, above, has addressed social and political issues in performances in and around Minsk, the countrys capital and the troupes base, often infuriating the government of President Aleksandr Lukashenko but rallying international supporters like Tom Stoppard and Jude Law. This documentary, directed by Madeleine Sackler, presents some of those works, including Being Harold Pinter, in which actors struggle to break free of a plastic sheet, and Minsk 2011, which pantomimes a police crackdown on a peaceful protest. The scenes of protest and police brutality include footage gleaned from hundreds of hours filmed in collaboration with a cinematographer in Belarus (whom Ms. Sackler directed over Skype) and then smuggled out of the country, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. The Belarus Free Theater, whose members are as articulate as they are talented, continue to spread the message of determined resistance to oppression.
