title: Morning Views
description: It looks as if Massachusetts made a serious mistake in 1994 when it let its two most prestigious (and costly) hospitals  Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Womens Hospital, both affiliated with Harvard  merge into a single system known as Partners HealthCare, writes The New York Times editorial board. Investigations by the state attorney generals office have documented that the merger gave the hospitals enormous market leverage to drive up health care costs in the Boston area by demanding high reimbursements from insurers that were unrelated to the quality or complexity of care delivered. The board warns that the situation in Massachusetts offers a cautionary tale to other states about the risks of big hospital mergers and the limits of antitrust law as a tool to break up a powerful market-dominating system once it is entrenched.

title: When Senate Polls Start to Matter
description: This table shows how the accuracy of polling improves as Election Day nears.

title: Money Is Raised; Now Lessigs Super PAC Must Win
description: The super PAC to end all super PACs reached its fund-raising goal in just over two months, but now comes the hard part: winning elections.

title: Helvetia Agrees to Buy Rival Swiss Insurer
description: LONDON  The Swiss insurer Helvetia said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Nationale Suisse for about $2 billion in cash and shares in a deal that would create the third-largest insurer in Switzerland.

title: Iraq: Where the Stories Find You
description: BAGHDAD  My late father-in-law, Peter Webb, a wonderful English grocer from Brighton, used to ask me the same question when I came back from a trip to some difficult or awful place. How do you get your stories? He was never quite satisfied with the answer, probably because I never much improved on it.

title: How Small Businesses Really Use the Export-Import Bank
description: Exports are crucial to Dry Corp, a company that makes waterproof medical cast covers, and its sister company, Dry Case, which makes waterproof cases for smartphones, tablets and other gadgets. Together, the two companies employ 21 people, and each one sells about $1 million in products a year. About 17 percent of those sales come from overseas.

title: British Hospital Operator Spire Healthcare Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Spire Healthcare Group, a British operator of hospitals, said on Monday that it expected its initial public offering in London to value the company at about $1.6 billion.

title: Eduard Shevardnadze, Foreign Minister Under Gorbachev, Dies at 86
description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who as Mikhail S. Gorbachevs foreign minister helped hone the new thinking, foreign and domestic, that transformed and ultimately rent the Soviet Union, then led his native Georgia through its turbulent start as an independent state, died on Monday. He was 86.

title: Morning Agenda: Curbing International Money Transfers
description: As regulators crack down on the financing of terrorists and drug traffickers, many big banks are ending or limiting the business of transferring money from the United States and other countries, moves that are expected to lead to higher costs for immigrants sending money home to their families, DealBooks Michael Corkery writes. While Mexico may be most affected, the banks retreat over the last year is also affecting other countries in Latin America and parts of Africa.

title: 1914: Welsh Beats Ritchie on Points
description: LONDON  The worlds lightweight boxing championship changed hands last night at Olympia, with Freddy Welsh, the British champion, winning the premier title from the American holder, Willie Ritchie, on points. Approximately eight thousand spectators watched the contest in Olympia. There were many women to lend refinement and beauty to the proceedings, but not so many, I should say, as last week, when Bombardier Wells met Colin Bell. This, perhaps, is explained by the fact that the Bombardier is an unusually strong drawing card with the feminine boxing enthusiasts.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 8, 1914.

title: A Possible Solution to Toilet Stink in China
description: Using public toilets in China can often be a challenging undertaking, particularly for those not practiced in the art of squatting. But researchers in China have come up with a new technology that they say can help eliminate one of the most noxious of problems to plague Chinas public lavatories: the overpowering stench.

title: Whats News in Washington: Immigration Fireworks
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where heat and humidity are due to return after a blissful holiday weekend.

title: Pope Asks Forgiveness From Victims of Sex Abuse
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis on Monday used his first meeting with victims of clerical sexual abuse to offer his strongest condemnation of a crisis that has shaken the Roman Catholic Church, comparing priests who abuse minors to a sacrilegious cult, while begging forgiveness from victims and pledging to crack down on bishops who fail to protect children.

title: A Louis Vuitton Chronograph Timepiece Inspired by Motor Racing
description: In this weekly series, the mens fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Louis Vuitton.

title: Setting the Table for Migrating Monarch Butterflies
description: I havent heard of any adult monarch butterflies arriving in the lower Hudson River Valley yet, but at least at our home the table is set for these migrants, which have had a very tough time at both ends of their continent-spanning range in recent years, with suburban sprawl in the Northeast, intensified corn production in the Midwest, deforestation in Mexico.

title: Iraqi Parliament Wobbles Over Forming Government
description: Iraqs political process appeared near collapse for several hours on Monday after the Parliament said it would be at least five weeks before members would even try to elect a speaker, the first step in the process of forming a government.

title: Learning Lear': A Kings Gotta Eat
description: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses King Lear for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: European Union Juggles Its Problem Children
description: ROME  NATOS first secretary general, Gen. Hastings Ismay, once said that the Western defense alliance was created to keep the Americans in, the Russians out and the Germans down.

title: China Denies Entry to an American Scholar Who Spoke Up for a Uighur Colleague
description: BEIJING  When Elliot Sperling, an American professor, landed here in Beijing after a 12-hour flight from the New York area last weekend, he found himself dragged by border officers into a back room in the airport for an interrogation. They then marched him back to the same United Airlines jet that he had flown in on, despite the fact he had arrived with a valid one-year tourist visa.

title: Egypts President Expresses Disappointment Over Conviction of Three Journalists
description: CAIRO  President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt expressed disappointment in remarks published Monday at the conviction of three journalists from Al Jazeeras English-language service, saying that their sentences had negative consequences and that he preferred that the journalists be deported rather than put on trial.

title: Analytics: Boomerang Kids Talk Back
description: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the July 6 issue of the magazine.

title: Not Knut
description: Gavyn Davies takes on the de facto debate between the hard-money men at the BIS and the monetary doves, and frames it as a conflict between Keynes and Wicksell. But I dont think thats right. The BIS position is in fact just as inconsistent with Wicksell as it is with Keynes. That doesnt mean that the BIS is wrong (although I believe that it is); it does mean that its view is much stranger and harder to defend than Davies suggests.

title: Tele2 of Sweden to Sell TeliaSonera Its Norwegian Business
description: LONDON  The Swedish telecommunications company Tele2 said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Norwegian business to its larger rival TeliaSonera in a deal that values the business at about $744 million.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Insider Trading Case
description: The Justice Departments long run of insider trading convictions may be near an end as the trial of Rengan Rajaratnam comes to a close this week. Prosecutors have had a series of setbacks that whittled down a case that started out with seven charges and now consists of a single count of conspiracy. And that count only covers losing trades.

title: Today in Small Business: Factory Man
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: The Battle Over Reconstruction
description: On the morning of July 4, 1864, as Congress was preparing to adjourn for the summer, Abraham Lincoln was busy in an office at the Capitol signing bills. Senator Charles Sumner hovered nearby in a state of intense anxiety. George Boutwell, a representative from Massachusetts, paced nervously. Senator Zachariah Chandler of Michigan kept asking anyone who would listen if one particular bill had been signed. Told no, he spoke with Lincoln who, according to the presidents secretary John Hay, said, this bill was placed before me a few minutes before Congress adjourns. It is a matter of too much importance to be swallowed in that way.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: American Advertising Federation, Washington, named seven executives as the 2014 inductees into the Advertising Hall of Achievement, for ad professionals who are age 40 or under. The honorees, to be inducted on Nov. 18, are Lauren Connolly, executive vice president and executive creative director at BBDO New York, part of the BBDO North America division of BBDO Worldwide, which is owned by the Omnicom Group; Sarah Hofstetter, chief executive of 360i, part of Dentsu; Ross Martin, executive vice president of Scratch, part of the Viacom Media Networks unit of Viacom; Erika Nardini, chief marketing officer at AOL; Elias Plishner, executive vice president for worldwide digital marketing at Sony Pictures Entertainment, a division of Sony; Bozoma Saint John, global head of marketing at Beats Music, which was recently acquired by Apple; and Jennifer S. Warren, senior vice president and chief marketing officer at RadioShack. Mr. Plishner will also receive the Jack Avrett Volunteer Spirit Award, presented to an inductee for public service.

title: Paris Couture Week: Atelier Versace Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: New Scarlett Work Among Highlights of Ballet Theater Season
description: American Ballet Theater will celebrate its 75th anniversary season with programs that include newly commissioned works and new productions alongside works by choreographers who have been significant in the companys history  among them Michel Fokine, Frederick Ashton, Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins and Antony Tudor. The season will open with a 12-day residency at the David H. Koch Theater, on Oct. 22, 2014, and will run through December 2015.

title: 1964: Sinatra Shielded From Press
description: PARIS  Frank Sinatra, who more often rasps than croons to the press, arrived here yesterday for what he described as a few days amusement. Casualties from the running ruckus were reported to be two photographers slightly injured in brawls with the bodyguards, known as gorillas in French journals. Get the so-and-so out of my way, Sinatra shouted at the photographers. He then reportedly pulled a couple of small firecrackers from his pocket, lit and tossed them into the milling throng.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 8, 1964

title: Grilled Vanilla-Ginger Pineapple
description: Sherry Yard has a wonderful recipe in her first cookbook, The Secrets of Baking, called Roasted Voodoo Vanilla Pineapple. She roasts her pineapple with the dried vanilla pods that you save after youve scraped out the seeds, and fresh ginger. She inserts the pods into the flesh of the pineapple, a great idea if youre roasting the pineapple for a long time.

title: Grilled Watermelon and Feta Salad
description: I love watermelon and feta salad, whether the watermelon is grilled or not. The sweet, juicy watermelon against the salty, creamy feta and pungent onions is a winning combination. This version introduces heat and char. Throw the watermelon slices, with the rind, onto the grill after or before youve grilled your meat or fish or vegetables. Grill them on both sides until just charred, then cut away the rinds and dice up the melon for the salad.

title: Crpes With Grilled Peaches and Apricots
description: Heat deepens the flavor of both peaches and apricots, and grilling adds one more seared dimension. The trick here is to grill the fruit just until it colors and softens, but not to let it burn or collapse. I find that 3 minutes on one side is sufficient for peaches, and 2 minutes for apricots, with about 1 minute on the other side.

title: New York Summer Stories: Its Too Hot
description: City Room has dug up articles from The New York Times archives during the past week that tell tales of city summers past.

title: Arugula Salad With Grilled Apricots and Pistachios
description: Pungent arugula contrasts beautifully with fruit of all kinds. Grilling the apricots deepens their flavor and makes them stand out against the arugula even more. Youll be able to make this beautiful salad only during the summers short apricot season, and even then, you should buy the fruits at the farmers market so you can sample them to make sure they are juicy and sweet.

title: The Other Greenhouse Gas, Feeling Lucky in Sports, Animal Madness
description: Scientists argue over the importance of controlling methane emissions; why its a good thing that the World Cup is all about luck; what humans can learn from grieving animals.

title: Grilled Figs With Pomegranate Molasses
description: These are wonderful. First you toss them in a mix of balsamic vinegar and olive oil, then you grill them on both sides just until they soften and grill marks appear (at which point they are warm all the way through and just beginning to become jammy), then you remove from the grill and brush with pomegranate molasses. Its a match made in heaven. Serve while the figs are still warm, as a first course with goat cheese, or as a dessert with ricotta or yogurt.

title: Tentative Results in Afghan Presidential Runoff Spark Protests
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans already tumultuous election grew more perilous on Monday after the announcement of preliminary presidential runoff results that were rejected by the candidate Abdullah Abdullah, leading some of his most powerful supporters to call for protests and even the forming of a breakaway government.

title: Ads for Zoo Exhibit Give New Meaning to Animal House
description: It is relatively easy these days, thanks to social media, to make monkeys out of stars. A campaign for the Los Angeles Zoo, now underway, is hoping to make stars out of monkeys.

title: Christian Dior: Winter 2014 Couture
description: Paris

title: Photographing Grief
description: Throughout the Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: World Cup 2014: Puzzle 2 of 2
description: This week we continue to celebrate World Cup 2014 (in case you missed it, here is last weeks post) with a challenge featuring a critical component of any soccer match, particularly at the highest levels: the penalty kick. The puzzle was suggested by Marco Moriconi, who lives in Rio de Janeiro.

title: New Pink Floyd Album Coming in October
description: The news was leaked in what seemed an aside: On Saturday, the author Polly Samson, who is married to David Gilmour, Pink Floyds guitarist, went onto Twitter and tweeted, to her 17,100 followers:

title: Facts & Figures: Healthier With Same-Sex Parents?
description: An Australian survey of same-sex parents found that their children scored higher on measures of health and family cohesion than the general population.

title: Couture Fashion Week (So Far) in 140 Characters
description: The winter 2014 couture shows in Paris are in full swing and our staff has been reporting from the front rows and behind-the-scenes. See a collection of their tweets so far.From Dior:

title: British Phenom Charli XCX on Sudden Success, Singing With Iggy Azalea and What Made Madonna Special
description: The British singer-songwriter Charli XCX was just another would-be star trying to make it onto the charts when Icona Pops I Love It, written by XCX, became one of the biggest hits of 2013. A torrent of success has followed, which has included penning tracks for the hottest names in music and singing the hook for the current hit Fancy alongside Iggy Azalea. Here, XCX talks about the origin of Fancy and premieres the ASTR remix of her new song, Boom Clap.

title: For Head of New York Tourism, 55 Million Visitors Isnt Enough
description: Fred Dixon is not replacing Neil Patrick Harris in Hedwig and the Angry Inch on Broadway, but he still has one of the hardest acts to follow in New York City.

title: Winning a Battle of the Mind, Not to Mention the Backhands
description: Novak Djokovic went to hell and back to win his second Wimbledon title Sunday.

title: James Simons Gives $50 Million to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory
description: James H. Simons, a retired hedge fund titan who used mathematical strategies to become a billionaire, is financing a new medical research center that plans to apply similar strategies to investigate serious diseases.

title: Testimony in Clippers Case Begins, but Sterling Doesnt Take the Stand
description: LOS ANGELES  A lawyer for Rochelle Sterling turned with a grand gesture and allowed his eyes to sweep over the courtroom as he asked for his first witness.

title: Hamas Vows Vengeance for Israeli Strike
description: Hundreds of mourners gathered in Gaza on Monday for the funeral of two of the militants killed in an Israeli airstrike earlier the same day, and a Hamas spokesman pledged to avenge their deaths.

title: Iraq  or Sunnistan, Shiitestan and Kurdistan
description: When the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria launched its 2014 assault on Iraq, the ensuing chaos ignited familiar discussions about the future of the countryand the possibility of a three-state solution.

title: Fire Damages Acclaimed Bay Area Restaurant
description: David Kinch, a Northern California chef who has been widely hailed for paying meticulous attention to the seasons and the elements, suffered a setback early Monday morning when a fire roared through Manresa, his restaurant in Los Gatos, Calif. near San Jose.

title: Ball? Strike? It Depends: Is the Pitcher an All-Star?
description: They would rather not talk about it, but umpires may be just as star-struck as the average baseball fan.

title: Dangers of Weekend Emergency Surgery
description: A new study suggests that emergency surgery done on children during the weekend results in more complications and deaths than similar surgery done during the week.

title: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Benefits From Rosbergs Hard Luck
description: Lewis Hamilton, who assumed the lead when his teammate, Nico Rosberg, dropped out on the 47th lap, took the victory Sunday in the British Grand Prix at Silverstone. The win, coupled with Rosbergs no-points nonfinish, helped Hamilton close to within four points of his teammate in the seasons driving championship. Rosberg, whose Mercedes had a gearbox failure, had been leading by 29 points entering the race; he had finished every previous grand prix this season.

title: Pope Meets Clergy Sex Abuse Victims
description: Pope Francis spoke after meeting with six victims of clerical sex abuse.

title: Paris Couture Week: Schiaparelli Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Pope Francis Apologizes to Abuse Victims
description: Pope Francis met over the weekend with six victims of abuse by Catholic clergy, denounced attacks on children in religious terms during a special Mass this morning and warned bishops of the Roman Catholic Church that they will be held accountable for their actions toward the abused and the abusers.

title: Corner the Market on Summer Squash
description: Suddenly it is summer at the market. Make a wish for a summer vegetable or fruit and most likely it is there. Shaded tents now brim with green beans, tomatoes, eggplant, even corn. More stalls are piled with cherries and red currants and peaches and tiny sweet strawberries.

title: Watching the World Cup, and Watching Children See Dishonesty Pay Off
description: What do you tell your children when cheaters win?

title: Spy Scandal Tails Merkel All the Way to Beijing
description: BEIJING  The visit to China by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany was supposed to focus on business, but financial matters were overshadowed Monday by a spy scandal at home  reportedly involving the United States  and Chinas wartime history with Japan.

title: Welcome to the Everything Boom, or Maybe the Everything Bubble
description: In Spain, where there was a debt crisis just two years ago, investors are so eager to buy the governments bonds that they recently accepted the lowest interest rates since  1789.

title: Glimmerglass to Offer Mozart, Vivaldi, Verdi and Bernstein for 40th Anniversary
description: The Glimmerglass Festival, which presents a summer season of opera at the graceful Alice Busch Opera Theater in Cooperstown, N.Y., will celebrate its 40th anniversary in 2015 with four productions, the company said Monday. As in recent seasons the prospectus includes three operas and a musical  although the musical, Leonard Bernsteins Candide, has a foot in both worlds. It started its life in the theater, while in recent decades it has been presented more regularly in opera houses (it was a staple at the New York City Opera).

title: Pilot Dies in Plane Crash in Long Island Sound
description: The pilot of a single-engine airplane died on Monday after his craft crashed into the waters of the Long Island Sound, Coast Guard officials said. Investigators have yet to determine the cause of the crash or to release the name of the pilot.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Anthropocene (Age of Us)
description: Nathanael Johnson, Grists excellent food and sustainability blogger, offer to mediate a conversation between the ethicist and author Clive Hamilton and me over our differing views of this age of us, known increasingly as the Anthropocene.

title: Alcohol Remains a Leading Killer
description: Excessive alcohol consumption, including binge drinking, is responsible for 10 percent of deaths among working-age adults in the United States, according to a recent study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Sam Tanenhaus on the G.O.P.s New Intellectuals
description: Sam Tanenhaus, writer at large for The New York Times, wrote this weeks cover story about an influential group of young intellectuals feeding ideas to the Republican Party. He is the author of, among other books, The Death of Conservatism.

title: Studying May Make You Nearsighted
description: Can too much studying ruin your eyesight? Maybe. A German study has found that the more education a person has, the greater the likelihood that he will be nearsighted.

title: Officer Separations Break More Than Years of Service
description: How does it feel when the country for which youve lost youth, relationships and health wants to get rid of you? It feels like betrayal. If the Army is our family, then this is divorce.

title: Ackmans Hedge Fund Offers Slate of Directors for Botox Maker Allergan
description: Pershing Square Capital Management unveiled a proposed slate of directors on Monday that it hopes to elect to the Allergan board.

title: Friend Says Boston Bombing Suspect Spoke of Building Bomb
description: BOSTON  A federal prosecutor told jurors on Monday that a college friend of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, believed that his friend had been involved in the attack and tried to cover up incriminating evidence.

title: The 10 Books That Made Debut Novelist Will Chancellor Want to Write One of His Own
description: The author Will Chancellor spent a decade working on his debut novel, A Brave Man Seven Storeys Tall (out tomorrow from Harper), the tale of a would-be Olympian turned one-eyed wanderer named Owen Burr who goes missing, and his professor father who follows his trail to Athens, Berlin and Iceland. Whenever Chancellor lost his path, he turned to these novels for guidance and inspiration. In each of them, he explains, I saw more of myself and finally accepted that I had to spend my life writing.

title: In Craziness of Free Agency, a Levelheaded Approach
description: LOS ANGELES  If it was not apparent by now that Pau Gasol is cut out a little differently, consider the outside interests of Gasol, the sublimely skilled, ever so polite and supremely conscientious 7-foot center.

title: In Performance | Jan Maxwell
description: A scene from Anthony Giardinas play The City of Conversation, about three decades in the life of a Washington socialite.

title: A Departure for A.D.M. in $3.1 Billion Deal
description: Archer Daniels Midland is going merger wild  sort of.

title: More on American Colleges Standing in the World
description: Last week I wrote that, contrary to conventional wisdom, there is no reason to believe that American colleges are, on average, the best in the world. A number of people who responded, including several in letters to The Times, raised issues worth addressing more broadly.

title: No Need to Demonize High-Frequency Trading
description: Bart Chilton, a former commissioner of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, is a senior policy adviser at DLA Piper and the author of Ponzimonium: How Scam Artists Are Ripping Off America.

title: A Video Debut from Rick Rubins New Protgs, Angus and Julia Stone
description: It goes without saying that if the renowned, elusive music producer and Def Jam Records co-founder Rick Rubin gets excited about someone, theyre probably destined for great things. Now the man who turned the Beastie Boys and the Red Hot Chili Peppers into icons has tapped the Australian folk-blues sibling duo Angus and Julia Stone as his new protgs. Its few and far between that I hear something that really excites me, says Rubin, whos notorious for rarely speaking to the press. I heard their music and it really moved me. They make the kind of songs that I can listen to over and over again for a long period of time. They have hypnotic, poetic depth. What Rubin didnt know when he contacted the pair  who started making music together in 2006  was that not only did they have no plans to write any further songs at the time, but they flat-out werent getting along at all. It was only when I reached out to them that they decided to get together to make the album we eventually made, and through that process had a family healing and are better friends today than they, I think, have ever been, Rubin says. None of this was intentional. It just happened, and its a pretty beautiful part of the story.

title: Signs of an Afghan Crisis, There on Election Day in June
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With the Afghan election commission releasing preliminary results that seemed too inflated to be trusted, the stage is set for even more conflict over the political process here.

title: G.M. Resists Recalling Trucks Over Brake Lines
description: Under pressure from federal regulators and legislators, General Motors this year has been reviewing past safety problems. That has resulted in 54 recalls affecting about 25.7 million vehicles in the United States.

title: Does That Cat Have O.C.D.?
description: It was love at first pet when Laurel Braitman and her husband adopted a 4-year-old Bernese mountain dog, a 120-pound bundle of fur named Oliver.

title: Giambattista Valli: Winter 2014 Couture
description: Paris

title: A Sound Tour of the World, Accompanied by Birds
description: The sculpture garden at the Museum of Modern Art is separated from the museums lobby by an expansive wall of glass. It speaks to Mozarts continued reach over the music of today that in little more than a month, I have heard recent reworkings of his melodies on both sides of that wall.

title: Fiddling While Iraq Burns
description: Iraqi politicians are acting as if their country werent under mortal threat from Sunni extremists. Instead of quickly forming a government so leaders can concentrate on rallying the country to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the new parliament on Monday postponed its next session until Aug. 12.

title: Russia Urges Bulgaria to Resume Building Gas Pipeline
description: Russias foreign minister urged the European Union on Monday to allow construction to resume on a natural gas pipeline that Moscow is backing.

title: Altered N.F.L. Settlement Wins Judges Approval
description: A federal judge approved a preliminary settlement between the N.F.L. and lawyers for the more than 4,500 retired players who sued the league, accusing it of hiding the dangers of concussions and repeated hits to the head.

title: Box Raises $150 Million in New Financing as It Moves Toward an I.P.O.
description: Updated | 7:04 p.m. Box, the online storage provider on its way to going public, has raised $150 million from two investment firms as it bides its time before completing its initial public offering, the company said on Monday.

title: Paris Couture Week: Christian Dior Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Weekly News Quiz | July 1-7, 2014
description: How well did you follow the news this week? Test yourself to see how you do against others.

title: Pasta With Burst Cherry Tomatoes
description: Melissa Clark makes a summer pasta salad with burst cherry tomatoes, scallions and mint that has something bright and lively in every bite.

title: What the Therapist Thinks About You
description: BOSTON  David Baldwin wasnt sure how he had come across the other day in group therapy at the hospital, near the co-op apartment where he lives with his rescue cat, Zoey. He struggles with bipolar disorder, severe anxiety and depression. Like so many patients, he secretly wondered what his therapist thought of him.

title: Months Full of Meredith Monk Performances
description: Meredith Monk will spend next season celebrating the 50th anniversary of her first New York concert  a work called Break, at the now defunct Washington Square Gallery, in September 1964  with concerts all over Manhattan and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The timing could not be better: as the current occupant of the Richard and Barbara Debs Composers Chair at Carnegie Hall, Ms. Monk has a spotlight and resources greater than she has had for most of the 50 years since that first show.

title: Not Only Pretty, They Pop
description: Long-simmered tomato sauces are just right in winter, when youre looking to spend hours next to the stove in the company of a steaming, bubbling pot. But summer demands something brighter and fresher, dishes that feature the seasons ripest produce but do so with minimal cooking time.

title: The Letters That Warren G. Hardings Family Didnt Want You to See
description: Warren Harding is not the most beloved of American presidents. Two of the earliest polls to assess presidential popularity, conducted in 1948 and 1962, ranked him last and last among chief executives. Harding served only briefly, from 1921 to 1923, before he died in office, but his administration has been widely regarded as visionless, ineffectual and corrupt. He slashed immigration quotas, appointed his cronies  one of whom, his secretary of the interior, accepted bribes from oil companies in what became known as the Teapot Dome scandal  and brought an end to the famously reform-minded eras of Teddy Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson. Perhaps the best that can be said about Harding is that he seems to have been conscious of his defects. I am not fit for this office and should never have been here, he once conceded.

title: Woman in Custody After Leaving Baby on Subway Platform
description: The subway train doors opened at the Columbus Circle station around noon on Monday, and a woman stepped out onto the platform pushing a stroller with a 6- or 7-month-old girl inside. Moments later, the police said, she stepped back into the train alone.

title: In Fair Verona, Where Soca Music Now Plays Under Starry Skies
description: Hip-hop music from the nearby baseball diamond wafts into Verona. A stray tabby and a cloud of fireflies crowd its lanes. At Romeo N Juliet, a free performance staged in an amphitheater at Marcus Garvey Park by the Classical Theater of Harlem, the distractions of an uptown summer evening compete with a centuries-old tragedy.

title: The Daily Do | Feathers In Lieu of Bangs at Schiaparelli
description: T shares the best hairstyles from the runway.

title: In Winnipeg, a Museum Honoring Human Rights
description: The Canadian Museum for Human Rights  billed as the first museum dedicated to raising awareness of national and international human rights issues  will open on Sept. 20 in Winnipeg.

title: The Myth and Magic of Pic de Bugarach
description: This past weekend, Yvette Monahan published a book of photographs about a rural area in south-central France between the Mediterranean Sea and the Pyrenees mountains. At the regions center is a mountain called Bugarach. Monahan spent a year taking pictures of the mountain and its surroundings, which have a rich mythical history. I was enchanted by the photos in her book, The Time of Dreaming the World Awake, when I saw them recently, so I reached out to her and got her to tell me what sparked her interest in this French spot:

title: Debate Continues on Hazards of Electromagnetic Waves
Thodore Gricault at Jill Newhouse
description: The French Romantic Thodore Gricault will forever be identified with The Raft of the Medusa, a wrenching, ripped-from-the-headlines painting of disaster at sea that set off a political controversy in France and has since inspired contemporary artists like Martin Kippenberger and Thomas Hirschhorn. But he was also drawn to quieter subjects, to judge from an intriguing show of drawings, watercolors and small oil paintings.

title: Ford Recalls 92,000 Vehicles for Driveshaft Problem
description: Ford is recalling about 92,000 sedans and crossovers in North America because of a problem with the front, right half shaft, which means the vehicles can cause drivers to experience the loss of drive function suddenly, the automaker said on Monday.

title: Beehive Air-Conditioning
description: Q. Why are honeybees drinking water from my birdbath?

title: Couture Fashion Week Street Style
description: Street style looks at Couture fashion week in Paris.

title: Roger Cabn: Canto Boricua: The Two Islands
description: Roger Cabn was born in Puerto Rico in 1942, came to New York as a child and has lived here ever since. But like most Nuyoricans of his generation, he has shuttled back and forth, which explains the title of this refined and cordial solo show of his black-and-white photographs from the 1970s.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, Afghanistan, Bosnia and Washington.

title: One Way to Solve Private Equitys Recruiting Problem
description: Hardly anyone on Wall Street is happy about the way private equity firms recruit low-level employees from investment banks. But there are signs that the process may be starting to change.

title: Meyer Vaisman: In the Vicinity of History, 5774
description: In his first solo show in New York in over a dozen years, Meyer Vaismans paintings home in on the issues of appropriation, authorship and self-reference that he pursued in New York in the early 1980s. Then he was fresh from Caracas, his birthplace, and in his early 20s but already quite prominent as a partner in International With Monument, the hot East Village gallery that gave Jeff Koons his breakthrough exhibition, and as a member of the short-lived Neo-Geo trend, showing at galleries like Sonnabend and Jay Gorney Modern Art.

title: Former Barclays Chief Robert Diamond Takes to Twitter
description: Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former chief executive of Barclays, has joined the Twittersphere.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: For Broadway, a Tepid July 4 Week
description: The big-budget Broadway musicals Bullets Over Broadway and Rocky, the hit shows Kinky Boots and Once and the star-studded plays The Cripple of Inishmaan (with Daniel Radcliffe) and Of Mice and Men (with James Franco) were among several Broadway productions with soft ticket sales during the Fourth of July holiday week, according to box office data released on Monday.

title: New Field Tests May Curb Kissing Bug Disease
description: Six different rapid diagnostic tests have proved reliable in detecting Chagas disease without having to wait for laboratory confirmation, according to a study by the medical charity Doctors Without Borders and the World Health Organization.

title: Supports/Surfaces at Canada
description: Big, shiny Chelsea galleries are not the only ones that can present missing chunks of recent art history. Canada, working with the Paris-based Galerie Bernard Ceysson, is staging the first American survey of some painters of the relatively unknown French Supports/Surfaces art movement, which was active in the late 1960s, 70s and early 80s. With so much of current abstraction in back-to-basics mode, the show is timely, revealing the strengths and pitfalls of its artists approach. Some of this stuff looks alive and pertinent; some of it looks ordinary and inert.

title: Social Anxiety
description: Does social media help shy people open up? Some relish the chance to connect with others without the awkwardness of the face to face. But for others, the Internet is just as bad as the physical world  or even worse. And the question of shyness may open up into bigger questions about how we experience social life online.

title: Emily Mae Smith: Novelty Court
description: Bucking the messy abstraction trend, Emily Mae Smiths Pop-style paintings comment on sex and gender with satirical ingenuity. Two posterlike works on view in this pint-size gallery mimic the cover of The Studio, a late-Victorian art magazine, with the title lettered at the top and the Art Nouveau-style image of a female artist painting in her studio rendered in thin black lines on white grounds. To each of these genteel images, Ms. Smith has added the realistic, semi-transparent color image of a much-enlarged piece of fruit  a banana and a tomato  highlighting the idea of the woman as a desirable commodity.

title: Hitting the Ceiling, Then Moving Up
description: Sia goes over the top almost immediately on her new album, 1000 Forms of Fear. When the chorus of Chandelier arrives, a simulated orchestra crashes in, and her voice appears in a strenuous high register, belting, Im gonna swing from the chandelier,  with an I-dare-myself upward leap on the last syllable of chandelier. Still aloft, she repeats from the chandelier and leaps even higher. Its showy, impulsive, shrewd, gripping and maybe a little unhinged, and so is the rest of the album.

title: Youth Tsunami in Arab World
description: These days, alarming news continues to spill out of the Middle East. Syrias continuing civil war has claimed tens of thousands of civilian lives. Iraq  where the prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite, has stoked sectarian conflict by refusing to form an inclusive government  is hurtling toward civil war, as Sunni militants, led by the Qaeda splinter group ISIS, have moved close to Baghdad. Farther east, the Taliban are resurgent in Afghanistan.

title: Back to the Beginning of Elemental Emotions
description: Late one night on Second Avenue, the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker practiced walking and turning in the studios of New York Universitys Tisch School of the Arts. To the music of Steve Reich and Bach  she couldnt decide which to use  she played around with permutations of these elemental steps, adding a spiraling torso or swinging arms on top of precisely placed feet.

title: Russian Arrested in Guam on Array of U.S. Hacking Charges
description: A Russian man accused of being one of the worlds most prolific traffickers of stolen financial information was arrested in Guam on Saturday, according to the Secret Service.

title: Would Warren G. Harding Have Fared Better in 1971?
description: As Gail Collins teased in her column this weekend, the magazine has obtained access to a trove of letters that Harding wrote to his longtime mistress, Carrie Fulton Phillips, between 1910 and 1920. People have known about these letters for half a century  they were front-page news when they were discovered in 1964  but theyve mostly been locked up until now. In 1971, the Harding family agreed to donate the letters to the Library of Congress (also front-page news) on the condition that they remain sealed for 50 years.

title: Istanbul Deftly Takes Contrasts in Its Stride
description: ISTANBUL  During one particularly eclectic afternoon here at the end of June, I watched the whirling dervishes in their serene ritual at the 15th-century Mevlevi Lodge and then dashed out to observe an exuberant gay pride parade marching down Istiklal Street, the citys bustling pedestrian shopping boulevard.

title: Fishermen Hang On to Livelihood in Morro Bay
description: Faced with increased competition from corporate fish processors in bigger ports, fishermen in Morro Bay, Calif., have set up a community quota fund.

title: The Lag Time for Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: American Apparel Creditor Calls In $10 Million Loan
description: After weeks of intense wrangling, one of American Apparels longtime lenders, Lion Capital, has demanded immediate repayment of a $10 million loan it made to the troubled retailer, after negotiations over new terms failed, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.

title: Replaced by an Algorithm
description: To the Editor:

title: At Dior, Historical References Translated to Modern Style
description: As editors piled in for the Christian Dior fall 2014 couture presentation today, taking in the classic white orchids that lined the walls around the futuristic runway space (shaped a bit like a round U.F.O.), the collections theme a connection between old and new, past and present began to make itself apparent. The show began, and the houses artistic director Raf Simons launched his audience into a sort of time travel with his range of references. He embellished archetypal silhouettes likeloose, flapperesque dresses; wide-through-the-hips, Marie Antoinette-style gowns; and baggy, one-piece flight suits with anachronistic details like sophisticated embroidery and fresh prints. Among the many knockout looks in the show, it was hard to ignore the ornate justacorps jacket with a matching gilet underneath. Finished off with a simple black top and trousers, it made for a truly modern ensemble that ushered the couture era right into the now.

title: The Supreme Courts Ruling on Union Contributions
description: To the Editor:

title: Proof and Campus Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: Earthlike Planets May Be Merely an Illusion
description: In 2010, astronomers were stirred by the discovery of Gliese 581g, a distant Earthlike planet that orbited its star just closely enough to allow for surface water, and possibly life.

title: Stolen From Cradle, Now Back to Rage
description: Young adult television typically cleaves into two camps  its either about the absurd comedy of teenage life, or its unending tragedy. The plotlines arent that different, but in the first category, characters respond to pain with charm and wit, while in the other, their shoulders droop, and they stew in bad lighting.

title: An Undead Tale of the Teenage Years
description: LONDON  And just when you thought youd had your fill of young vampires in love, along comes a ravishing little romance of the undead thats guaranteed to warm  and break  your heart, even as it chills your blood. Let the Right One In, which is bringing limelight to endless night at the Apollo Theater here, turns your emotions inside out in a way you probably havent experienced since you were a teenager.

title: Acropolis Maidens Glow Anew
description: ATHENS  For 2,500 years, the six sisters stood unflinching atop the Acropolis, as the fires of war blazed around them, bullets nicked their robes, and bombs scarred their curvaceous bodies. When one of them was kidnapped in the 19th century, legend had it that the other five could be heard weeping in the night.

title: An Athlete Who Needs More Than a Ponytail
description: Skylar Diggins, 23, is a point guard for the Tulsa Shock. She was a basketball star at Notre Dame, where she holds the record as the all-time scoring leader. These days, when not in uniform (the Womens National Basketball Association regular season runs through mid-August), she might be modeling for Nike or appearing at red carpet events with Jay Z and her Roc Nation management agency. A native of South Bend, Ind., Ms. Diggins now lives in Tulsa, Okla.

title: Ancient Bird Had Some Feathers Just for Show
description: German scientists found a new specimen of Archaeopteryx, the 150-million-year-old winged creature thought to represent the transition from dinosaurs to birds, with well-preserved feather markings. The bird, described in the journal Nature, had feathers on its hind limbs that researchers said were more likely used for display than for flight.

title: Germany Proposes a Road Tax Aimed Primarily at Foreigners
description: BERLIN  The German government announced plans on Monday to charge a road-use fee on all cars using roads and highways in Germany, a measure aimed at the foreign-registered cars that make an estimated 170 million trips to and through the country each year.

title: Giving Tofu the New Look It Deserves
description: Its not likely that tofu will become anyones favorite food; this we know. Those who grew up in households where it was well prepared may relish it, but for the rest of us its a bit of a requisite, something we think we should eat in place of chicken or eggs whenever we can stomach it.

title: Brad Hintz, Top Bank Analyst, to Retire
description: Brad Hintz, who became known as one of the premier bank analysts after a career at some of Wall Streets most powerful firms, will retire from Sanford C. Bernstein & Company to teach at New York Universitys Stern School of Business.

title: Picking Lesser of Two Climate Evils
description: Climate scientists long ago settled among themselves the question of whether human emissions of greenhouse gases are a problem, concluding that we are running some grave risks. But the field still features vigorous debate about how bad global warming will get, how quickly, and how to combat it.

title: Saul Leiters Black-and-White World
description: Though he was famed for his color photography, Saul Leiters earliest work was in black-and-white, and just as personal and powerful as his later images.

title: Ash Borers and a Deluge of Data
description: Invasive Species

title: Forced Out: High Rent Alters a City
Seeker, Doer, Giver, Ponderer
description: James H. Simons likes to play against type. He is a billionaire star of mathematics and private investment who often wins praise for his financial gifts to scientific research and programs to get children hooked on math.

title: Learning the Secrets of E-Commerce in China
description: There has been much buzz about the initial public offering of Alibaba, Chinas e-commerce giant. The company is the top player in an increasingly crowded and diverse Chinese online sales market that features corporations looking to order large quantities of manufactured goods; small business buying items in lots of, say, 25 pieces; and consumers looking for a single product.

title: A California Oil Field Yields Another Prized Commodity
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  The 115-year-old Kern River oil field unfolds into the horizon, thousands of bobbing pumpjacks seemingly occupying every corner of a desert landscape here in Californias Central Valley. A contributor to the states original oil boom, it is still going strong as the nations fifth-largest oil field, yielding 70,000 barrels a day.

title: Soccer, a Beautiful Game of Chance
description: Ive been watching the World Cup with some frustrated American social scientists. When they see an underdog team triumph with a miraculous rebound or an undeserved penalty kick, they dont jump up and scream Goooaaalll! They just shake their heads and mutter, Measurement error.

title: New T.S.A. Rules for Electronics on Flights Bound for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  In response to intelligence reports about plots being hatched by Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen, the United States has, for the first time, asked officials at more than a dozen foreign airports to confiscate from passengers any electronic devices that cannot be turned on, American officials said on Monday.

title: Making Films in Bulgaria Can Bring Pleasures and Frustrations
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  It looks like an authentic corner of Brooklyn, right down to the entrance to an imaginary subway and the no parking sign.

title: Lenders Agree to Give Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority More Time to Repay Debt
description: Puerto Ricos struggling electric power authority reached a temporary deal with some of its lenders on Monday, buying the agency a little more time as it sorts out its troubled finances.

title: Flowers Foods PAC Gives to Democrats, First Time in Decades
description: On June 10, the Flowers Foods PAC did something it had not done in 20 years: It gave money to a Democrat. Three, actually.

title: Should Germans Read Mein Kampf?
description: WASHINGTON  GERMANY is once again passing through the wringer of its past. At issue this time are not the deeds but the words of Adolf Hitler and the planned republication of his infamous manifesto-as-autobiography, Mein Kampf, a book that has been officially suppressed in the country since the end of World War II.

title: To Camp, or Not to Camp
Security Firm Described Simulation as Real Hack
description: BAE Systems Applied Intelligence, a defense, aerospace and security company, recently noted in a report that one of its clients at an unnamed hedge fund lost millions of dollars because of a cyberattack. But the incident was, in fact, a simulation run by the security firm itself.

title: Orange Is the New Black Recap: Is Anyone Trustworthy Around Here?
description: Season 2, Episode 10 I dont think Ive ever been so happy to be so wrong: Nicky didnt do the drugs!

title: An Activist Investor Helps a Solar Power Company Turn Itself Around
description: Two years ago, the solar power company SunEdison was in a crisis.

title: Writing Alone, Together
description: For the better part of my writing life, Ive been alone. By this I mean I have written alone, spending my days in the kind of voluntary solitary confinement that is necessary to the business of getting the right words out of my head in the right order.

title: No Punishment on Neymar Hit
description: FIFAs disciplinary committee Monday rejected a request by Brazils soccer federation to punish the Colombian player whose tackle knocked Brazils top player, Neymar, out of the World Cup.

title: To Cut Costs, Federal Workers Become Nomads
description: WASHINGTON  The most sumptuous room in the headquarters of the General Services Administration has floor-to-ceiling oak panels, chandeliers and a working fireplace carved of French limestone.

title: Investors Are Buying Troubled Golf Courses and Giving Them Makeovers
description: When the Gaillardia Golf and Country Club opened in 1998, it was to be the crown jewel of golf in Oklahoma City, complete with an 18-hole P.G.A. championship course and a 55,000-square-foot clubhouse of Norman-style architecture. The Gaylord family, best known as Oklahoma media moguls and owners of the Grand Ole Opry, sank a reported $59 million into the project.

title: Knutty Asset Prices
description: Neil Irwin has a nice piece about high asset prices that actually ties into my Wicksell discussion from earlier today.

title: Group Promoting Referendum on Marijuana Submits Signatures
description: Advocates for the legalization of marijuana in Washington announced Monday that they had collected more than twice the signatures required to get a measure on the November ballot. The districts Board of Elections has up to 30 days to check that the group promoting the measure, the D.C. Cannabis Campaign, had collected valid signatures from at least 22,500 voters. The effort could lead to a confrontation with Congress, which controls the districts budget and can intervene in local lawmaking.

title: Fan Sues After Untimely Nap Brings Unwanted Attention
description: The television cameras at baseball games often catch fans in semi-embarrassing moments, and good sports announcers are adept at poking gentle fun at spectators when the action on the diamond slows down.

title: Clinton Defends Her Handling of a Rape Case in 1975
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton  responding for the first time to new criticism about how she handled the defense of a rape suspect in 1975  said she had asked to be removed from the case, in which her client was accused of sexually assaulting a 12-year-old girl.

title: The Creative Climate
description: In the current issue of The Atlantic, Joshua Wolf Shenk has a fascinating description of how Paul McCartney and John Lennon created music together. McCartney was meticulous while Lennon was chaotic. McCartney emerged out of a sunny pop tradition. Lennon emerged out of an angst-ridden rebel tradition.

title: No Signs of Fabrication in Imprisoned Al Jazeera Crews Reports From Egypt
description: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt expressed regret in remarks published Monday over the convictions of three journalists from Al Jazeeras English-language service, saying that it would have been better to simply deport them than put them in prison.

title: In Bulgaria, Corruption and Mistrust Turn Promise Into Pain
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  The lines of panicked depositors in this threadbare capital evaporated as quickly as they appeared in what may have been the shortest banking crisis in history  or potentially the prelude to something more tumultuous.

title: A Dwindling Transportation Fund
description: Business advocacy groups say lawmakers inaction on infrastructure spending threatens the economic recovery.

title: Alfredo Di Stfano, Soccer Great for Real Madrid, Dies at 88
description: Alfredo Di Stfano, an Argentine soccer star who built a legendary career when he moved to Europe in the 1950s and led Real Madrid to five straight Continental club championships, died on Monday in Madrid. He was 88.

title: U.S. Scrutiny for Banks Shifts to Commerzbank and Germany
description: A trail of illicit money led the American government on a hunt through the European financial system, generating criminal cases against banks in Britain, Switzerland and most recently, France.

title: The Messy World of Smart Guns
description: The Andy Raymond rant is a thing to behold.

title: Coalition Prods Congress on Transportation Fund
description: WASHINGTON  With both the legislative calendar and the Highway Trust Fund nearly exhausted, a broad coalition of business groups and labor unions will push this week to shake Congress from its stasis and approve federal infrastructure spending before transportation projects begin to dry up in August.

title: New Yorks Mapmaking Scandal
description: In his 2010 campaign for governor, Andrew Cuomo promised to end partisan gerrymandering, in which lawmakers draw their own districts. He failed to do that, and instead, as governor, signed onto a set of legislative maps in 2012 that were carefully designed to keep legislators safely in their jobs.

title: The Long Wait to See a Doctor
description: Americans are already experiencing long waits to get doctors appointments, and experts say the delays are bound to get worse when millions of previously uninsured Americans get health coverage under the Affordable Care Act. That is the sobering news from a new survey of wait times conducted by Merritt Hawkins, a physician staffing firm, which polled some 1,400 medical offices in 15 large metropolitan areas across the country.

title: Germany and the Minimum Wage
description: The federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour is obviously too low. So is the Democrats proposed increase to $10.10 an hour by 2016. If the minimum wage had merely kept pace over time with inflation, average wages or productivity growth, it would be between $11 an hour and $18 an hour today.

title: Expensive Internet and Other Hotel Peeves
description: WE all have had serious complaints about the way airline service has deteriorated in the last 15 years or so, so I was interested in a recent list of complaints about the other most important aspect of business travel: hotels.

title: Alan J. Dixon, 86, Is Dead; U.S. Senator Who Championed Illinois
description: Alan J. Dixon, a two-term United States senator from Illinois in the 1980s and early 90s who was known for keen attention to constituents needs and an old-fashioned glad-handing style that won him the nickname Al the Pal, died on Sunday at his home in Fairview Heights, Ill. He was 86.

title: Four Horrific Killings
description: In the space of a few weeks, the brutal killings of four teenagers  one Palestinian and three Israelis  have inflamed tensions in Israel and the occupied territories, potentially igniting a conflict that could be even more vicious than the intifadas of 1987 and 2000. It is the responsibility of leaders on both sides to try and calm the volatile emotions that once again threaten both peoples.

title: For Brazil, Winning Trumps Aesthetics
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil  Brazils national soccer team is the embodiment of the beautiful game, an 11-man samba performance that dazzles fans of any country and leaves its opponents both flummoxed and flat-footed.

title: Appellate Courts Ruling on Arizona License Rule
description: A three-judge panel said it could find no legitimate state interest to justify treating young immigrants in a federal program differently from other noncitizens whose work permits Arizona had traditionally accepted as proof of authorized presence in the United States.

title: Court Blocks Arizona Policy of Denying Drivers Licenses to Some Immigrants
description: PHOENIX  A federal appeals court on Monday blocked Arizonas policy of denying drivers licenses to young immigrants who have received work permits and avoided deportation under an Obama administration program.

title: Fliers Facing Fewer Rewards
description: For airline passengers, rewards programs may not seem so rewarding anymore.

title: When Slow and Steady Doesnt Help
description: WHEN I was younger I spent a lot of time following the Grateful Dead and Phish around the United States. I was a backpacker so I stayed at a lot of campgrounds and hostels. I really felt that made me a pretty savvy traveler.

title: How England, Italy and Germany Are Dominating the World Cup
description: Tables showing which professional soccer leagues are most represented in each round of the World Cup

title: The Immigration Debates Twin Issues
description: As tens of thousands of unaccompanied minors cross into the United States this year, immigration reform is stalled. The issues are related but not the same. Heres why.

title: N.B.A. Salary Cap Maximizes Free Agents Difficulty
description: In recent days, the basketball-watching world has turned its attention from midlevel exceptions to flight-tracking software. (What, exactly, was that plane belonging to the Cleveland Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert doing in South Florida over the weekend?) Not that there ever was any doubt, but N.B.A. free agency has officially moved into its familiar terrain of thinly veiled chaos.

title: Opposition Rally in Nairobi
description: Opposition supporters gathered for a rally in Nairobi.

title: Blink and Its Gone: A Farewell Column About Chasing the Ever-Changing New York City
description: I came of age in the prewar apartment canyons of the Upper West Side of Manhattan. As we wended our way back from high school, a buddy and I would stop by the 91st Street soda stand and pick up the tabloids. We read as we walked, gorging on Pete Hamill, Murray Kempton, Jimmy Breslin and Jse Torres, a boxing champion who became a pretty damn good columnist.

title: Immigrant Surge Rooted in Law to Curb Child Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON  It was one of the final pieces of legislation signed into law by President George W. Bush, a measure that passed without controversy, along with a pension bill and another one calling for national parks to be commemorated on quarters.

title: Before He Leaves, Michael Powell Shares His Favorite Gotham Columns
description: Michael Powell wrote the Gotham column for a little more than three years, covering wayward bishops, egocentric governors, and varieties of suffering and inspiration.

title: Snack Food for Hikers
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This one didnt play like a Tuesday for me, but its a cute idea. Your mileage may vary, of course. Bruce Venzke and Gail Grabowski are back, and today they are hanging out in BARS.

title: Wall Street Offers Clinton a Thorny Embrace
description: As its relationship with Democrats hits a historic low, Wall Street sees a solution on the horizon: Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Samsung Foresees a Decline in Profit
description: The next big thing is here, as Samsung Electronics likes to say in its ads. But fewer people appear to be buying it.

title: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats Brazil, 7-1
description: The scoring began in the 11th minute when Thomas Mller tallied his fifth goal of the Cup after being left unmarked in the box. But it was the brief period from Minute 23 to Minute 29 that devastated Brazil.

title: Opposition Rallies Its Ranks in Kenya, Peacefully
description: NAIROBI  They started streaming in at dawn on Monday, thousands of people, the crowd slowly building as the sun rose. Men in rubber swamp boots. Men in thin suits. Men in raggedy trousers and ripped T-shirts, men from the slums.

title: Aid Elusive, Crimea Farms Face Hurdles
description: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea  Sergei V. Tur, a significant landowner, scowled beneath his desert camouflage cap as he watched a hulking combine chew through one of his golden barley fields, reaping part of what he predicts will be the best harvest in Crimea in three years.

title: Not Over Till Overtimes Due? Met Labor Strife Bares Secrets
description: The operatic drama and larger-than-life passions usually subside at the Metropolitan Opera when its season ends for the summer, but not this year.

title: Proposed Precinct Plan in North Carolina
description: The Cleveland County Board of Elections proposes combining five precincts into two and reducing the number of polling places in Shelby, N.C.

title: Q. and A.: John Delury on Chinese-South Korean Ties
description: The visit of President Xi Jinping of China to Seoul last week underscored how Beijing is intent on warmer ties with South Korea, already a strong economic partner. During the visit, Mr. Xi and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea agreed on the need to keep North Koreas nuclear ambitions in check but papered over substantial differences on how to reach that goal. Perhaps more important, the visit reflected tensions among Seoul and Tokyo, the United States key allies in the region, as China tries to exploit South Korean wariness of Japan stemming from Japans colonial dominance of the Korean peninsula in the early 20th century.

title: Mistrust in North Carolina Over Plan to Reduce Precincts
description: SHELBY, N.C.  When Alan Langley, a Republican member of the local elections board here, explains a new proposal to consolidate five voting precincts into two, it sounds procedural and well-meaning: He speaks of convenient parking and wheelchair access at the proposed polling places, and of saving more than $10,000 per election.

title: A Power Struggle Across Continents
description: The World Cups final four has two classic matchups, with European powerhouses taking on equally dynamic teams from South America. Germany and Brazil go first, on Tuesday afternoon, followed by the Netherlands and Argentina on Wednesday. Here is a look at both games.

title: Nets Low-Key Introduction Reflects New Coach
description: The Nets elected Monday to introduce Lionel Hollins as the 19th coach in franchise history in their standard news conference room at Barclays Center, underground, adjoining the locker rooms, eschewing the pageantry that accompanied last years introduction of Jason Kidd.

title: Indonesian Candidate Masters a System He Is Said to Disdain
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  For a candidate accused of questioning the value of democracy, Prabowo Subianto appears to be a highly efficient campaigner.

title: Grieving a Firefighter Who Saved a Sons Life in May, and Died on Saturday
description: A little boy dangled 15 feet in the air, his arm and head in danger of being crushed by a metal roll-up gate that had risen without warning as he and his friends were playing around it.

title: Training Document From the New York Fire Department
description: A Fire Department document posted to an internal website, and in all firehouses and EMS stations, gives instructions for precautions to take when dealing with Collyers mansion conditions during a fire.

title: Firefighters Have Name for Deathtrap Homes
description: Just this May, the Fire Department of New York posted training materials on its internal website detailing some of the difficulties encountered while battling blazes in homes brimming with hoarded belongings: blocked entryways, deep-seated fires and debris piled so high that, in smoke conditions, a firefighter crawling atop can accidentally crawl out a window.

title: Emergency Starter and Hot Bats Lift Yankees to Satisfying Victory
description: CLEVELAND  There could have been ways that Mondays game unfolded better for the Yankees. Maybe their emergency pitcher, making his first career start, could have lasted seven innings instead of six. Or their $85 million catcher, mired in a four-month slump, could have laced four hits instead of just three. Or maybe their lineup could have chased the Cleveland Indians starter in the second inning and not the third.

title: Neymars Injury Sidelines Effort to End World Cup Racism
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  After an episode in Peru earlier this year in which Peruvian soccer fans subjected a Brazilian player to racial abuse by imitating the sounds of monkeys, President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil swiftly pledged a World Cup against racism, declaring, Sports should be no place for prejudice.

title: A Taxi Alternative, UberX, Offers Lower Fares
description: For years, the smartphone apps storming New York Citys professional driving industries presented an implicit trade-off: For a bit more money, passengers could find a ride more efficiently  and, if they chose, travel on a more opulent set of wheels.

title: Ukraine Rebels Are Retreating for Last Stand
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Separatist rebels retreated Monday from positions in eastern Ukraine, apparently blowing up bridges, and began building barricades in the two largest cities, Donetsk and Luhansk, in anticipation of a final stand against advancing government troops.

title: Police Fire on Hummer as Suspect Flees on Staten Island
description: Police officers opened fire on a stolen sport utility vehicle early Monday near the Staten Island side of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge during a search for a suspected carjacker, officials said.

title: Jihadis Tug at Edges of a Staunch American Ally
description: MAAN, Jordan  Hanging from the facade of a shuttered bank on a bustling market street in this sunbaked town were two large, white banners emblazoned with black letters.

title: How Birth Year Influences Political Views
description: Peoples political views are particularly shaped by events they experience between 14 and 24.

title: U.S. Official Ordered Out of Bahrain After Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  Bahrain on Monday ordered the senior United States official on human rights to cut short his visit and leave the country after he met with the nations main Shiite opposition group.

title: Last Ball Rumbles Down a Village Bowling Alley
description: Tom Shannon recalled the first time he stepped inside the old bowling alley on University Place for a friends birthday party in 1994.

title: Intel, Qualcomm and Others Compete for Internet of Things Standard
description: If the stakes are big enough, companies will compete even for something that is supposed to be free to all comers. And over the next few years, very little stands to be bigger than the Internet of Things, or IoT.

title: Word of the Day | diffuse
description: diffuse \di-fys\ adjective and verb

title: Art of the Deal: A Broker Who Knows When to Go All In

title: Venezuela: Stolen Matisse Painting Returned
description: Venezuelan authorities on Monday welcomed home a painting by the artist Henri Matisse more than a decade after it had disappeared from a Caracas museum. The painting, Odalisque in Red Pants, was recovered in 2012 by F.B.I. agents in Miami when they arrested two people and charged them with trying to sell the long-missing artwork. Officials do not know when it was stolen from the Contemporary Art Museum of Caracas, where it was part of the museums collection, because the thieves put up a fake version of the painting in its place  a ruse that was discovered in 2002. Photographs showed that the fake, which experts said was crudely executed, was in place at least as early as 2000. News of the paintings recovery two years ago caused a stir in Venezuela, and officials on Monday made a show of bringing it home, with a live television broadcast from the Caracas airport. When it was recovered, American officials said the painting was worth $3 million.

title: India: Shariah Courts Rebuffed
description: Indias Supreme Court ruled Monday that Shariah courts, which are run by the dictates of Islamic law, had no legal status and were not legally binding. In the courts judgment, fatwas, or orders declared by Muslim clerics, were deemed to have no legal status though they were not found to be illegal, and individuals may follow the Shariah rulings if they wish. The court said, however, that a religious leader has no authority or powers to impose his opinion and enforce his fatwa on anyone, adding that legally sanctioned fatwas have no place in independent India under our constitutional scheme.

title: A Victory for Same-Sex Unions
description: The marriages of gay men and lesbians who work for the United Nations Secretariat will be recognized by the organization if they have been wed in a jurisdiction where same-sex unions are legal, including New York. Previously, the secretariat, the body of employees who work under the secretary general, deferred to the laws of a staff members home country in classifying his or her marital status: Same-sex unions were recognized by the United Nations only if the employees home country deemed such marriages to be legal. The change, said the organizations deputy spokesman, Farhan Haq, reflects Secretary General Ban Ki-moons support for greater equality for all staff. The new rule was announced in an internal staff bulletin, Mr. Haq said Monday. It expands the civil rights of gay and lesbian employees, even as many of the United Nations member states, including Uganda, whose foreign minister assumes the presidency of the United Nations General Assembly in September, crack down on their own gay and lesbian citizens.

title: U.N. Report Calls for Public Sanitation Funding
description: Nearly one billion people worldwide defecate in the open, and such bad sanitation practices can endanger the health of children who live and play nearby, the United Nations said in a report released Monday. The report, which calls for greater effort and funding to redress inadequate sanitation, measures the worlds progress on the so-called Millennium Development Goals intended to improve the health and well-being of the global poor. The report notes some advances: A greater number of children are living past their fifth birthday. As many girls as boys are enrolled in primary school. Extreme poverty has been halved since 1990. But about one in five people in the developing world still lives on less than $1.25 a day; about 25 percent of the worlds children suffer from stunted growth, reflecting the effects of chronic hunger; and nearly half of all pregnant women did not see a doctor during their pregnancy.

title: New York State Pavilion Receives $5.8 Million for Restoration

title: Your Eyes Are Happier Than Your Stomach
description: Not long ago at a restaurant that regularly tweets photos of dishes as lush as one of Monets lily ponds, I found myself poking cautiously at perfect circles of glossy black sauce, discs of potato pure that looked like white roses and cylinders of gnocchi so tiny they seemed to have been pushed out of a drinking straw. Tiny, delicate flowers and tender sprigs of leaves gently rested here and there as if a woodland nymph had casually tossed them from a basket before running off to play hide-and-seek with a den of baby field mice. The dish was definitely ready for its close-up. It was also, by and large, very cold  no surprise given how long it must have taken to squeeze and tweeze everything into position.

title: As Chanel Proves, Its Chic to Match Your Bag to Your Dress
description: The fashion set was eager to see what Karl Lagerfeld would come up with after last seasonssuburban supermarket extravaganza of a runway. His fall/winter 2014 couture presentation held today didnt compete with that infamous show, but instead fell on the other end of the eye-candy spectrum, offering a look that was restrained yet undeniably chic. The collections pared-back sensibility was inspired by a now-defunct 1930s Le Corbusier apartment on the Champs lyses. Like that apartments mash-up of design motifs a gold baroque mirror that sat atop a modern outdoor fireplace, for example Lagerfelds designs married the old and new. Case in point: this modern-silhouetted maxi dress with ornate gold embroidery. Paired with a coordinating messenger bag, it made for a standout look that lent fresh new meaning to the term matchy-matchy.

title: Jake Hoffman (Yes, Hes the Son of Dustin) Makes His Debut as a Director
description: If Jake Hoffman looks familiar, its not just because of his striking resemblance to a certain icon of the silver screen with whom he shares a surname. The 33-year-old  who, yes, happens to be the son of Dustin Hoffman  has been acting since the age of 7, when he appeared in his fathers classic film Rain Man (he was an extra eating pancakes in a diner). Since then, he has been cast in I Heart Huckabees, Arrested Development and The Wolf of Wall Street (in which he had a small but memorable role as the shoe designer Steve Madden) and he even played his own fathers grandson in HBOs ill-fated series Luck. Since graduating from NYUs film school in 2003, Hoffman has tried his hand at writing and directing, and completed a trio of short films. Now, with the release of his debut full-length feature, Asthma  which he wrote, produced and directed, and which premiered today at the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival in the Czech Republic  Hoffman is staking out a film career on his own terms.

title: Iranian Reporter Faces 2 Years in Prison and 50 Lashes

The verdict, which she learned about in a phone call on Monday, also calls for her to receive 50 lashes.

Then this morning at Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld interrupted his parade of white dresses with a soft, billowing light-blue dress complete with equally full feather sleeves. If the success of his Moschino French fries phone case is any indication, the bags, available for pre-order now, will be a hot commodity. And as the recent mens-wear shows in Europe revealed, statement-making backpacks are for big kids, too. The young woman (in the slide show) carried a bag from Nasir Mazhar, a London designer known for his logo-heavy brand of club-kid streetwear. Multiple attendees were spotted with Chanels graffiti-printed number . Any of the bags here can be a playful accessory for travel or a day at the beach now, or serve as that all-important conversation starter come back-to-school season.

He has been an author, a member of a special unit of the Navy and a television host.
