title: Zalman Schachter-Shalomi, Jewish Pioneer, Dies at 89
description: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi, who was considered the spiritual father of the Jewish Renewal movement  an influential camp of religious pioneers who reintroduced to synagogue services ancient Judaic traditions of mysticism and meditation, gender equality and ecstatic prayer  died on Thursday at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 89.

title: No Word on Anthony as Knicks Get to Work
description: LAS VEGAS  Phil Jackson needed about 10 seconds Tuesday afternoon to traverse a small patch of real estate that stretched from a gymnasium door to an idling sport utility vehicle. He greeted several members of the news media who were awaiting the end of a summer league practice at a high school before he offered some unsolicited advice.

title: The First Cannabis Store in Seattle
description: The first stores legally selling recreational marijuana in Washington State opened on Tuesday. Cannabis City was the first in Seattle.

title: Religious Groups Letter to Obama
description: President Obama is planning to sign an executive order barring discrimination against gay men and lesbians by companies that do government work, but major faith organizations asked for exemptions for groups whose religious beliefs oppose homosexuality.

title: More Charges to Come Against Libyan Over Benghazi
description: The Justice Department said Tuesday that it intended to file additional charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, the man being held in the 2012 attacks that killed the United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, and three others. At a hearing in Washington, the government said several factors would determine when it would file the charges, but it did not say what those factors were. Judge Christopher R. Cooper of United States District Court said the case would proceed slowly because of its complexity. He scheduled a status hearing for Sept. 9. A week ago, a magistrate judge ruled that Mr. Abu Khattala should remain in government custody and without bond.

title: Afghanistan: Taliban Strike in Deadly Bombing
description: In one of the deadliest Taliban attacks in recent months, 10 Afghan civilians, two Afghan police officers and four Czech soldiers were killed when a suicide bomber riding a bicycle attacked a village north of Kabul. The attack occurredTuesdaymorning, as the soldiers were assessing the security situation in the village ofQalander Khel of Bagram district in Parwan Province. Such attacks have grown increasingly rare as international forces have withdrawn, or stayed within their bases.

description: WASHINGTON  The secretary general of the NATO alliance warned on Tuesday that Russia was playing a double game in Ukraine, issuing conciliatory public statements while massing its forces along the border and smuggling arms and equipment to separatists inside eastern Ukraine.

description: The Human Brain Project is Europes flagship contribution to neuroscience. Established last year and funded by the European Commission, the project was meant to rally scientists and computer engineers around developing better tools to study how the brain works.

title: A Recent History of Chanels Couture Show Sets
description: Chanel is known for building over-the-top stage sets whose sense of drama rivals, and in some cases eclipses, the clothes. At the houses fall/winter 2014 couture presentation yesterday at the Grand Palais, however, the setting was more modest, if no less elegant, than expected. Karl Lagerfeld showed his standout collection in a relaxed setting inspired by a 1930s Le Corbusier apartment. Minimalist, intimate-feeling rooms at either end of the space were each adorned with a gold oval baroque mirror sporting the trademark interlocking-C logo, placed over a digital fireplace.

title: This Is Our Youth
description: Americas young people, as a group, are becoming more out of shape with every passing year, regardless of their familys economic situation, a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports. title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (FYI) ROWHOUSE SHOWDOWN The Biography channel, now rebranded as FYI, continues to unfurl new programming throughout the month. In this home makeover show, Carter Oosterhouse, above, oversees three design teams as they each renovate a dilapidated home in a distressed neighborhood in Cincinnati while living together in the house in an effort to raise the areas property values. Each week the teams will transform a different room on limited time and money, with the designer Kathy Kuo and the Cincinnati-based house flipper Jim Bronzie judging the results. The team that most increases the value of its home will receive $50,000 and a feature on the Dwell magazine website, whose editor in chief, Amanda Dameron, will judge the finale. In Tiny House Nation, at 10, John Weisbarth and Zack Giffin tour ingenious small spaces  among them, a micro-apartment in New York City, a transformed caboose car in Montana and a mini-mobile home for taking road trips  while helping families construct their dream dwellings in no more than 300 square feet.

title: Ground Battles in Afghanistan Contribute to Surge in Civilian Casualties, U.N. Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Driven by increased ground combat between insurgents and government forces, civilian casualties in Afghanistan surged 24 percent through the first half of the year, reaching their highest levels since 2009, according to the United Nations. The findings were released just as a Taliban attack unfolded in the densely populated center of Kandahar, the main city in southern Afghanistan.

title: Iraqi Premier Blames Kurds for Advances by Militants

title: Morning Views
description: For-profit colleges are lobbying hard to weaken rules proposed by the Obama administration that would deny federal aid to career training programs that burden students with crippling debt and worthless credentials, writes The New York Times editorial board. Citing the example of Corinthian Colleges, one of the countrys largest operators of for-profit colleges and trade schools, the board argues that such rules need to be strengthened and that federal oversight generally needs to be broadened. Corinthian Colleges relies so completely on funding from the government to cover its operating budget that a delay in the delivery of federal aid as part of an investigation threatened to shut down the chain entirely. If Congress required such operations to get more of their revenue from private sources, then more institutions would be forced to produce higher-quality programs that students would be willing to pay for, the board writes.

title: The French Do Buy Books. Real Books.
description: PARIS  One of the maddening things about being a foreigner in France is that hardly anyone in the rest of the world knows whats really happening here. They think Paris is a Socialist museum where people are exceptionally good at eating small bits of chocolate and tying scarves.

title: What I Learned From Firing My Employee of 20 Years
description: A business owner of no particular distinction, in an unfashionable industry, without a record of success or a vast fortune to substantiate his opinions, is given a chance to write about his company in The New York Times. He tries to tell a long, complicated story with a large cast of characters, a story that started two decades ago but concentrates on events covering the last two years.

title: Plan to Give Former King Immunity Splits Spain
description: MADRID  When he gave up the Spanish throne recently after nearly four decades, Juan Carlos I forfeited some perks and privileges, not least among them immunity from legal proceedings. And in the weeks since his son Felipe took the crown, Juan Carlos has gotten a glimpse of what it might be like to be treated by the courts like any other citizen, including the threat of two paternity suits.

title: Does Birth Control Coverage Pay for Itself?

title: Morning Agenda: Prosecutors Perfect Streak Ends
description: Since the governments crackdown on insider trading in the hedge fund industry became public in 2009 with the arrest of Raj Rajaratnam, federal prosecutors under Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, had secured 85 insider trading convictions and guilty pleas without one defeat. But on Tuesday, that perfect streak came to an end, Matthew Goldstein, Rachel Abrams and Ben Protess write in DealBook. After just under four hours of deliberation, a federal jury found Rengan Rajaratnam  the younger brother of Raj Rajaratnam, who was convicted of insider trading in 2011  not guilty of conspiracy to commit insider trading with his older brother.

title: 1914: Aviators Attempt London-Paris Return Flight
description: In British and French aviation circles interest now centres in the international race from London to Paris and back,upon which fourteen pilots are expectedto start to-morrow morning. Since M.Blriot first astonished the world by flying across the Channel, aviation has advanced so extraordinarily that a cross-Channel flight is now regarded as a mere incident in the days work. Aviators have flown from London to Paris and vice versa so frequently that the feat has become a mere commonplace. At the same time the race to-morrow will constitute a severe test both of the machines and their pilots. The New York Herald, European Edition, July 10, 1914

title: Making Fun
description: Summer vacation offers children unstructured time rich with opportunities for creative projects, and three new crafts books suggest ideas for a range of activities to inspire young artists and their adult assistants. Theres no dearth of crafting books on the market, but as with cookbooks, novelty makes old techniques seem freshly appealing. Parents will recall from their own childhoods the basic skills required: cutting, gluing, taping, tracing, sewing and pom-pom making. But even pom-pom pros can use a refresher course every couple of decades, and the craftiest readers may find a few tricks to be learned from experts who take their projects to new heights.

The leadership of President Vladimir V. Putin inspires little confidence, the survey found. title: Classical Playlist: West Side Story, Schubert, Haydn and More
description: BERNSTEIN: West Side StoryAlexandra Silber, Cheyenne Jackson and others.San Francisco Symphony, Michael Tilson Thomas, conductor(SFSmedia; two CDs)Do we need another recording of West Side Story performed by a full symphonic orchestra? Absolutely when its this one, taken from live performances in 2013 that Michael Tilson Thomas conducted with the San Francisco Symphony at the orchestras home hall. The cast, led by Alexandra Silber as Maria and Cheyenne Jackson as Tony, who bring youthful ardor, beguiling voices and dramatic immediacy to their roles, is ideal. This is a nearly complete version of Bernsteins score, with lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. The symphonic richness of the playing is an asset. But even better is the stylish naturalness and clarity that Mr. Thomas draws from the players, and the inspired cast. (Anthony Tommasini)

Mr. Harris, who has a pleasantly husky baritone, is offhandedly suave. Cool but winning, he doesnt go in for seductive wiles or conspicuous emotional display. description: WASHINGTON  A new report based on documents provided by Edward J. Snowden has identified five American Muslims, including the leader of a civil rights group, as having been subjected to surveillance by the federal government.

title: 1939: Spinsters Block Tulsa Airport
description: TULSA, Okla.  Two spinster sisters who have an intense dislike for noise have prevented air liners from landing in Tulsa for the last week by the simple expedient of erecting two fifty-one-foot radio masts over their house, which is next to the airport. As soon as the aerials went up, the Civil Aeronautics Authority classified them as a grave hazard and forbade the use of the airport. Threats had no effect. For the time being, the sisters are enjoying tranquillity, and the American Airlines, which use the adjacent landing field, admit they are stymied. The New York Herald, European Edition, July 10, 1914

title: James Pattersons Maximum Ride Books to Be a Series on YouTube
description: James Patterson, the novelist whose blockbuster books have sold more than 300 million copies, is setting his sights on another medium: Internet video.

title: Wheelies: The Future Infiniti Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Air Sirens Puncture Life in Affluent Tel Aviv Suburbs
description: NESS ZIONA, Israel  The sirens wailed about 8:30 a.m. on Wednesday in this orderly suburb south of Tel Aviv. Two rockets were whizzing here from Gaza.

title: Once in a Blue Moon
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  To paraphrase one of the cartoon characters of my formative years, be vewy, vewy quiet: Were hunting missing words. And theyre tricky; you wont hear them sneaking around.

title: Paris Couture Week: Maison Martin Margiela Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Kenny Kingston, Psychic to the Stars, Dies at 87
description: Kenny Kingston, a psychic to the stars who communicated with the rich, the famous and the titled  many of them disembodied, he maintained  died on June 30 at his home in the Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: How Is Your Small Business Making Use of Big Data?
description: Weve just published an article about how small businesses are finding ways to make use of big data. One example is Brian Janezic, 27, who owns two Auto Wash Express self-service locations in Tucson. Mr Janezic said he was standing in one of his locations when he realized, We have machines that automatically size and wash a car, mix chemicals, activate pumps, turn on lights  and here I am still counting inventory by hand.

title: Mamphela Ramphele, Veteran of Anti-Apartheid Struggle, Quits Politics
description: JOHANNESBURG  Mamphela Ramphele, a prominent veteran of the struggle against apartheid, raised great expectations in early 2013 by entering politics and starting a new party. A black woman who had two children with Steve Biko, the anti-apartheid martyr, and went on to forge a formidable career as a medical doctor, business executive and managing director at the World Bank, she seemed such a compelling candidate that South Africas main opposition group even proposed a merger with her fledgling party.

title: Something Gained, Something Lost
description: Ive got to get out of this crowd.

title: Urban Legends Told Online
description: In early June, two 12-year-old girls in Waukesha, Wis., were charged with attempted murder in the attack on a third girl, a classmate whom they had invited for a sleepover. Prosecutors say the girls lured their victim into playing a game of hide-and-seek in the woods. When in the woods, the prosecutors say, they attacked her with a knife, stabbing her 19 times. The victim was discovered by a bicyclist and rushed to the hospital; she is said to be recovering from her injuries.

title: Hope for Frogs in Face of a Deadly Fungus
description: In the 1990s, a disturbing silence began to settle across the world. From mountain lakes to tropical streams, the music of singing frogs began to disappear.

title: A Familiar Destiny to Photograph the New China
description: Sim Chi Yin had a cushy expat life in Beijing working as a reporter for The Singapore Straits Times, writing long feature stories and sometimes taking photos. The company paid for her education at the London School of Economics in exchange for eight years of employment. She had health insurance, a pension and job security.

title: Voting Totals Reveal Crucial Boost From Blacks in Thad Cochrans Victory
description: The precinct level returns in Hinds County bolster the theory that a surge in black, Democratic turnout allowed Senator Thad Cochran to defeat Chris McDaniel, a Tea Party-backed state senator, in last months Republican primary runoff in Mississippi.

title: Somali Police and Intelligence Chiefs Fired After Militant Attack
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalias prime minister fired his police and intelligence chiefs on Wednesday following a brazen attack in which Islamist militants blasted their way into the inner sanctum of the presidential compound here.

title: Reform Conservatism and Paul Ryan
description: In the wake of the Times Magazines profile this weekend of les reformocons, both Jonathan Chait and Danny Vinik have noted what Chait calls the near-total absence of Paul Ryans name from a story that concerns itself with the kind of wonkery that has long defined the House Budget Chairmans brand. Chait suggests that this reflects a shift away from Ryan-style apocalypticism on fiscal issues among right-of-center policy entrepreneurs. Vinik, meanwhile, argues that a split between Ryan and reform conservatives over taxes might be in the offing, since the former veep nominee is more likely to side with a WSJ-style always cut the top ratevision than with proponents of something like Mike Lees family-friendly approach.

title: 2014 Emmy Nominations: What to Expect
description: Thursdays announcement of the Emmy nominations will almost certainly include a face-off between two of the years most lavishly praised dramatic series, even though one of them really is not a series.

title: Senate Confirms Obama's Pick for Housing Secretary
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted on Wednesday to confirm Julin Castro as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, catapulting the young mayor of San Antonio to the national stage and putting him in charge of the agency as it grapples with a sluggish housing recovery and efforts in Congress to overhaul the nations housing finance system.

title: Fed, Confident in Economy, Details End of Bond-Buying Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it planned to stop adding to its bond holdings in October, in a sign of its confidence that the economy is gaining strength even as the central bank gradually withdraws its support.

title: Sultry Univision Ads Help Steer Women From Soaps to Soccer
description: In the months before the World Cup, Univision began to unveil its plan to reach female viewers, many of whom are devoted to its daytime talk shows and telenovelas.

title: Britain to Review I.P.O. Process After Criticism of Royal Mail Offering
description: LONDON  The British government began an informal review on Wednesday of how it pursues initial public offerings of government assets in the wake of questions about whether the Royal Mail offering last year was properly priced.

title: Parent on a Smartphone, With Almost No Guilt
description: Heres why my colleague Farhad Manjoo spent last week alternating between his smartphone and his 3-year-old, and why he says You Dont Have to Feel Very Guilty About Using Your Smartphone While Parenting.

title: Threes a Trend | Flat-Footed Boots on Couture Runways
description: Last seasons couture tennis shoe is this seasons modest flat boot. It first appeared in the fall/winter 2014 couture shows at Atelier Versace, an unexpected runway for such tame footwear. (To her credit, Donatella Versaces suede mid-calf gogo boots were topped with dazzling diamant buckles.) The trend then began to take shape at Schiaparelli, where perhaps the only toned-down aspect of the designer Marco Zaninis fanciful and eclectic presentation were the short pointed boots in luxurious monochromatic crocodile and printed leopard. And at Chanel, a single over-the-knee leather boot style, which appeared once in buff and once in black, broke up the onslaught of flat sandals with ribbons that tied around the ankle.

title: With Eye on LeBron James, Cavaliers Trade Guard to Nets
description: LAS VEGAS  The Nets appeared to solve their problem at backup point guard Wednesday by reaching an agreement to acquire Jarrett Jack from Cleveland in a three-team trade that had everything to do with the Cavaliers eagerness to create maximum financial flexibility in their pursuit of LeBron James, a free agent.

title: Short Film by Springsteen and Zimny Unveiled
description: At the end of June, Bruce Springsteen put a teaser on his website, asking his fans to return for the premiere of Hunter of Invisible Game, which he described as a short film by Thom Zimny and Bruce Springsteen. That raised a few questions: the title is that of one of the more darkly introspective songs on Mr. Springsteens most recent album, High Hopes, suggesting that he might be simply unveiling a promotional clip.

title: Adidas Joins Wearable Stampede With Fitness Tracker
description: There are a few things that should give pause to Adidas, the footwear and apparel maker, as it enters the so-called wearables market.

title: Falcones Hedge Fund Files Suit Against Dish Network Over LightSquared
description: A battle between two billionaires over LightSquared, the wireless broadband company, has played out for months in bankruptcy court. Now one of the billionaires, Philip A. Falcone, has picked a fight with his adversary in a new arena.

title: Pope Francis Names New Leadership for Vatican Bank
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis continued his efforts to modernize and reorganize the Vatican finances on Wednesday, by appointing a new leadership for the scandal-tainted Vatican Bank, streamlining other operations and signaling future changes to the churchs global media operations.

title: Suits and Sneakers in the Bronx
description: Southern Boulevard in the Bronx is a shopping hub for jeans, gold chains and sneakers, with Jordans being elevated to a wardrobe staple. When the Bronx native Javier Lopez is not working in politics, he stays loyal to his sneakerhead roots, matching his outfits with a pair from his collection of nearly 100. This interview has been edited.

title: Argentina vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Argentina beat the Netherlands on penalties, 4-2, after 120 scoreless minutes, and will play Germany in Sundays final with the World Cup at stake.

title: A Growing Arsenal of Homegrown Rockets Encounters Israels Iron Dome
description: JERUSALEM  For the moment at least, the hostilities between Israel and Gaza are partly a fight between rockets and interceptors  between the varied and improved arsenal of rockets possessed by Hamas and its allies, like Islamic Jihad, and the antimissile systems of Israel.

title: Draghi Calls for Closer Economic Integration in Europe
description: The president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, said on Wednesday that countries in the euro zone should be compelled to take steps to improve the performance of their economies in the same way that they are already required to observe rules on government spending.

title: Greece Plans Another Bond Offering
description: ATHENS  Three months after returning to international bond markets following a long exile, Greece said on Wednesday that it was planning to sell bonds again in an effort to capitalize on the growing demand for short-term euro zone debt.

title: Argentines Sing of Brazils Humiliation, Loudly and in Rio
description: As the Brazil team has come spectacularly undone in the World Cup, the pain for the host country has been compounded by the prospect that its hated rival, Argentina, could still lift the championship trophy on Sunday in Rio de Janeiros fabled Estdio do Maracan, after Argentina won a tense semifinal against the Netherlands in a penalty shootout on Wednesday afternoon.

title: For Vaporizers, Smoke Means Fire
description: Hip-hop artists like Wiz Khalifa rap about them regularly. If you pay attention, youll see one tucked into the palm of a passer-bys hand on the street. Whoopi Goldberg wrote fawningly about hers, and shortly after, The New Yorker posted an article titled, Vaping for Yuppies.

title: Handy Liquor Bar in SoHo
description: SoHos night life dwindled last year when several well-liked bars, including subMercer,  and Miladys, abruptly closed, leaving the neighborhood vulnerable to sticky-fingered Cronut pilgrims and fro-yo fiends. Bringing much-needed adult refreshment to this district is Handy Liquor Bar, a cozy cocktail den opened in April by the night-life swami Matt Levine.

title: Marriage Gone Sour? Go Home to Ma Bell
description: From the Oz stories to Harry Potter, there have always been books that attracted a crossover following of adults and young readers. Most recently, the runaway popularity of John Greens The Fault in Our Stars, and then anything else John Green has written, more than proved the point. Stephen Colbert defined the phenomenon this way: As far as I can tell, a young adult novel is a regular novel that people actually read.

title: Bieber to Be Charged in Egging of Neighbors House
description: The Los Angeles County district attorneys office took its time: back in February, a spokesman for the sheriffs department said it had ample evidence that Justin Bieber egged a neighbors house, causing what the department estimated at $20,000 of damage. But it took until now for formal charges to be filed. That is expected to happen on Wednesday at Superior Court in Van Nuys, Calif., where Mr. Bieber is to be charged with a single count of misdemeanor vandalism, The Associated Press reported.

title: An Ad Campaign for Whistleblowers
description: Federal bureaucrats commuting to work in the nations capital are finding fresh food for thought as they wait for the bus  glossy six-foot posters with an open invitation to blow the whistle on bad stuff happening at the office. Daniel Ellsberg, the patriarch of whistle-blowers who outraged the Nixon White House with his mega-leak of the Pentagon Papers, is depicted on the posters with a plea to tell the truth with documents that reveal lies or crimes or internal projections of costs and dangers.

title: Armadillo to Aa: Flavors of a World Cup Journey
description: Language had failed us, so Ruben Dada had resorted to charades to demonstrate which wild animal found in the Surinamese rain forest he was offering to cook up for me.

title: A Dash of Whimsy, With Leftover Stars
description: The experimental filmmaker Jodie Mack grew up around the family business of posters and merch. From a Florida warehouse her parents supplied music retailers and others with the cultural wallpaper that decorated countless bedrooms in the 1990s  from the bands and celebrities du jour to the dorm-room patron saints Belushi, Marley and Guevara.

title: In a Buenos Aires Barrio, a Quiet Metamorphosis
description: Just south of the hip Palermo Soho neighborhood, a staunchly working-class Buenos Aires barrio is undergoing a quiet metamorphosis. Long home to the citys Jewish community, Villa Crespos streets are lined with mom-and-pop shops, onetime factories and faded colonial facades that have mostly remained outside the trendsetters purview. But given its prime location  enterprising real estate agents are trying to rechristen the enclave Palermo Queens, much to the chagrin of longtime residents  an influx of hip restaurants and boutiques was inevitable. At the moment, the neighborhood still feels removed from the citys hubbub, but more locals are descending upon its cobbled lanes.

title: Downtown Las Vegas Jumps Again
description: From its frontier infancy through the mid-20th century, the only Las Vegas was downtown Las Vegas. But the city center known as Glitter Gulch lost the glamour battle post-1960 with the newer Strip, a stretch of Las Vegas Boulevard South with room for massive resorts featuring Egyptian pyramids and dancing water fountains.

title: The Roar Over the Funds of the Crowd
description: Eight times a week, Zach Braff stands on a Broadway stage and bellows, in a nebbishy kind of way, No more compromises!

title: Prisons of Gender and a Generation
description: Not only actors but also directors can be typecast, particularly strong stylists like Max Ophuls and Michelangelo Antonioni. Ophuls has been dismissed by some as a froufrou formalist, Antonioni as a poet of the privileged. Neither is noted for his social consciousness, but their complexity is evident in new Blu-ray releases of two relatively obscure films, Ophulss Caught (1949), made under the name Max Opuls, and Antonionis I Vinti (1953).

title: Paris Couture Week: Jean Paul Gaultier Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Helga Traxler.

title: Bolshoi Arrives With Drama, Some Onstage
description: The overture to Rimsky-Korsakovs The Tsars Bride begins with unassuming courtliness and swiftly ramps up to seething passion. It is, in a way, a microcosm of the work as a whole: a historical fantasy that quickly reveals itself as a vibrant blood-and-guts drama.

title: First-Class Fares, on Sale
description: GiltCity.com, a website that offers local deals on everything from spa services to concerts in 13 major cities, will begin a flash sale Thursday, July 10, encouraging shoppers to get out of town in style, aboard first-class flights on Delta Air Lines.

title: Trey Songz Is No. 1; Slow Sales for Thicke
description: This week on the music charts, the amorous R&B singer Trey Songz scores his second No. 1 album, Iggy Azalea holds her perch with the top single, and Robin Thickes latest album flops after a social-media campaign went bad.

title: Radio Ad on Possible L.I.R.R. Strike
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is alerting Long Island Rail Road commuters about the potential of a walkout by its workers.

External Drives Bring Data Storage Back Home
description: BUYING digital copies of movies, music and video games can free up shelf space in your entertainment center, but you still have to store those digital files somewhere.

description: Paris

title: Big Short Case Raises Questions About Finra Arbitration
description: Deeb Salem, the former Goldman Sachs trader who helped devise the firms brilliant and highly profitable proprietary bet against the mortgage market, has never been shy about trumpeting his accomplishments. Mr. Salem no longer works at Goldman  he decamped to GoldenTree Asset Management, a New York hedge fund, in 2012  but his continuing lawsuit, which contends the firm shortchanged him about $21 million in bonus and deferred compensation during the years after the financial crisis, raises fresh questions about the fairness of Wall Streets compensation practices, its willingness to make scapegoats out of former employees and the arbitration system  run by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority  that everyone who deals with Wall Street is forced to use to resolve monetary disputes.

title: Shopping Events in New York City Starting July 10
description: Sunny Style

title: Lufthansa to Start Low-Cost, Long-Distance Airline
description: PARIS  Scrambling to find more ways to shave costs and improve profitability, Lufthansa of Germany announced on Wednesday a plan to expand its domestic low-cost operations by creating a new, no-frills airline for long-distance flights, possibly to popular leisure destinations in Southeast Asia.

title: Viktor & Rolf: Winter 2014 Couture
description: Paris

title: A Modern Fairy-Tale Dress at Valentino
description: The mood at todays Valentino fall/winter 2014 couture show was par-for-the-course romantic. The wood-plank runway bedecked with moss and branches suggested a mythical forest to arriving guests, and what followed was a dance of ethereal, fairy-tale-like fashion moments. Subtle ballet references danced throughout the collection: leather belts on many of the looks mimicked the wraparound leotards worn for warm-ups, while delicate, knee-high lace-up sandals evoked the ties of toe shoes. The muted, wearable collection had its share of standout moments, but it was hard to forget this intricately embroidered pleated wrap minidress that felt at once folkloric and resolutely modern.

title: A Test Run at 19,000 Feet
description: Before Jeremy Jones could attempt to climb and ride a massive peak in Nepal, he simply needed to get back on his snowboard after weeks without riding. This task led to a test runat 19,000 feet.

title: Summer Nights, Late and Spooky
description: Its amazing what joy good air-conditioning and a midnight movie can bring, and the Film Society of Lincoln Centers series Freaky Fridays  a delightfully unsettling meeting of horror, kink and 35 millimeter running through August (albeit at 11 p.m.)  offers plenty. Among the perverse pleasures are David Cronenbergs parricidal nightmare The Brood (1979), Kathryn Bigelows outlaw vampire movie Near Dark (1987), Herk Harveys fever dream Carnival of Souls (1962) and Liliana Cavanis lurid The Night Porter (1974), each for 10 bucks or less.

title: In Stormy Year, Yanks Lose Anchor as Tanaka Heads to D.L.
description: CLEVELAND  Their offense has sputtered and their starting pitching has crumbled, and yet three months into the season, the Yankees have remained competitive. It is easy to recognize why: When their ace, Masahiro Tanaka, pitches, the Yankees tend to win.

title: Deep in Debt, Sarkozys Party Might Have to Sit Out Next Election
description: PARIS  Frances main conservative opposition party has disclosed that it is more than $100 million in debt, leaving it financially crippled and further impairing its ability to take on President Franois Hollandes governing Socialists and head off the growing strength of the far-right National Front.

title: The New Business Casual Is Still Uptight
description: Every workplace imposes certain behavioral standards on its workers  dress this way, talk that way, get lunch here and not there. Learning these standards is, were told, a big part of being successful. But what do we do if theyre constantly shifting, or if were not even sure what they are?

title: Strategy at the European Team Championships
description: What is the textbook approach to leading against small slams and grand slams? Should you be aggressive or cautious?

title: Video: Snowboarder Takes a Test Run at 19,000 Feet
description: Higher Unplugged looks at the making of the film Higher, which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

title: Europe Fines Servier in Pay-for-Delay Crackdown
description: BRUSSELS  Fines totaling 427.7 million euros ($581.8 million) were imposed Wednesday on several European drug makers, including the French company Servier, for keeping more affordable forms of a popular heart treatment off the market.

title: Kerry Presses China to Abide by Maritime Laws to Ease Tensions
description: BEIJING  In a closed-door session at a high-level gathering of Chinese and American officials here on Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry urged China to follow maritime law in nearby seas to reduce regional tensions, a senior American official said.

title: The Kids Arent All Right, and Neither Is the School
description: Coercive Christianity has been having a rough time on television of late. In May, PBSs Independent Lens broadcast God Loves Uganda, a devastating documentary about dubious work being done there by some evangelicals. And now, Showtime offers Kidnapped for Christ, an inside look at a school in the Dominican Republic where a certain breed of American parent hoped that God and discipline would straighten out their teenage children.

title: Tangled Web of Memories Lingers After a Breakup
description: The last thing I remember was the tears running in rivulets down my cheek as I confirmed that, yes, I did want to delete the picture on my Facebook page.

title: Veteran Diplomat Said to Be Picked as Third Envoy in Syrian Conflict
description: A veteran Italian-Swedish diplomat, Staffan de Mistura, has been tapped to try to achieve what two seasoned envoys could not: craft a peace deal for Syria.

title: Obama on Economic Progress
description: The president spoke about the countrys post-recession improvements at a campaign event in Denver, and said Republicans were blocking legislation that would help the middle class.

title: Zynga Changes Board to Comply With Nasdaq Rules
description: Companies naming new members to their boards is normally a routine affair. For the game maker Zynga, the appointment of Regina E. Dugan, a Google executive, to its board has special significance because it moves the company out of the Nasdaq Stock Markets penalty box.

description: Andy Newman, a Metro desk reporter, needed a document from the city. Therein lies a tale.

description: A cantor whose sexual abuse case split the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn was sentenced on Wednesday to two years in prison, as expected under a plea deal struck in May.

description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: IBM Wants to Invent the Chips of the Future, Not Make Them
description: IBM plans to spend $3 billion over the next five years on research and development for computer chips, both to stretch the limits of conventional semiconductors and to hasten the commercialization of exotic new designs.

title: Nagin Sentenced on Corruption Charges
description: After former Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans was sentenced on charges including bribery and fraud, Matthew Coman, an assistant United States attorney, spoke about the effects of Mr. Nagins actions.

title: Democrats Will Vote to Undo the Hobby Lobby Decision
description: The Supreme Courts ruling last week in the Hobby Lobby case wasnt based on a fundamental right found in the First Amendment or anywhere else in the Constitution. When the justices said that closely held corporations have religious rights that let them refuse to pay for insurance plans that cover contraceptives, they based their decision on a 1993 law passed by Congress, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

title: Very Modern Problems Set in a Navajo World
description: A weakness for drink is only one of the problems encountered by the Native American characters in Sydney Freelands debut feature, Drunktowns Finest.

title: This Time, the Main Attraction
description: No one wants to be upstaged by a toilet, especially in his first appearance as a lead actor in a New York production.

description: T shares the best hairstyles from the runway.

title: A Butcher, a Baker, a Luxury-Handbag Maker
description: There are no crystal balls in fashion, but there are, at least, weather vanes. Some savvy interpreters point the way the wind is blowing. One is Christopher Kane, the young Scottish designer, whose next-big-thing status was, in effect, confirmed by the Kering investment in his label. So when he announced in September that he would open his first London store, the question was where.

title: U.S. Will Broaden Sanctions to Deter Violence in Congo
description: WASHINGTON  The United States will expand sanctions on groups in the Democratic Republic of Congo, making it easier to target those who are trying to instigate violence and disrupt peacekeeping efforts in that country, the White House announced on Tuesday.

title: Scene | Dawn of the Planet of the Apes
description: Matt Reeves narrates a sequence from Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, featuring Jason Clarke.

title: About That Photo of the Reformicons
description: To capture the spirit of the reformicons for the July 6 cover story about the emerging band of intellectuals in the Republican Party, Eric Ogden photographed members of the group in Gunston Hall, the historic mansion in Virginia that belonged to George Mason. Ogdens group portrait, which alluded to paintings of the founding fathers, inspired readers to analyze who was included (This is the Republican idea of diversity?) and what they were doing (Whos going to sweep up that mess on the floor? The rest of the country?). Ogden recently discussed how the photo came about  and whats on those pages on the floor.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Bosnia and China.

title: Beacons of Creativity, Flung From Rooftops
description: The current exhibition about Trisha Browns dances on Governors Island occupies just one large room at the Lower Manhattan Cultural Councils Arts Center. But (despite its unappetizing subtitle Embodied Practice and Site-Specificity) it is a room to linger in for more than an hour. It contains memorable objects, rare photographs and four screens; and each screen plays a continuous loop of Ms. Browns choreography.

title: Adrift in a Sea of Good Humor
description: Scandinavians dont complain. Not even about ethnic stereotyping.

title: On the Sidelines of the Tour de France
description: Every Tour de France, spectators stake out their spots to catch a glimpse of the peloton as cyclists race past the countryside.

title: Haunted by History, but Gifted in Sharing It
description: When a satellite of the Ravensbrck concentration camp, in Germany, was liberated in May 1945, a young Polish Roman Catholic named Zofia Posmysz walked out and drew her first free breath since being sent to Auschwitz-Birkenau more than three years earlier. With 20 other women, she walked back to her hometown, Krakow, a distance of nearly 500 miles, and started a new life as a journalist for Polish radio.

title: In Small Trials, 2 Drugs Go Far in Soothing Symptoms of Eczema and Psoriasis
description: New drugs that block highly specific parts of the immune system are showing remarkable promise in treating two maddening skin diseases, eczema and psoriasis, according to papers published Wednesday in a leading medical journal.

title: 3 Days of Peace, Music and a Concierge
description: Michael Lang, who helped make rock history as a co-founder of the Woodstock festival, had never forgotten the 800-acre Winston Farm in Saugerties, N.Y., where the festival was supposed to take place. We thought it was perfect, Mr. Lang, 69, said in a recent telephone interview, a wistful note in his voice.

title: Personal Computings Big Three Get a Little Bigger
description: Three companies are pulling away from the pack in the PC business.

title: New York City Ballet Names Justin Peck as Choreographer
description: Justin Peck, the New York City Ballet soloist, has been appointed resident choreographer at City Ballet just two years after creating his first piece for the company. Mr. Pecks appointment, announced on Wednesday, makes him the second person to hold this position at City Ballet, after Christopher Wheeldon, who was the companys resident choreographer from 2001 to 2008.

description: No one said it would be easy, but here are the tools that make it possible.

description: For decades, Chinese citizens have chafed at the countrys hukou, or household registration, system, with its controls over where they can live, study, work, marry and have children.

description: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Going Back to Her Roots, Sometimes in Sync, Sometimes Not
description: Fase, Four Movements to the Music of Steve Reich, by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, is a remarkable work, adopting the methods of American Minimalism while swerving away from its ascetic tone. When Ms. De Keersmaeker created it, in the early 1980s, she was barely 20, a student at New York University. And on Tuesday, when Fase was performed at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, that amazing precocity was matched by longevity: The choreographer, at 54, dancing her demanding composition with as much electricity as ever.

title: The Violence in Israel and Gaza
The Past as Road to Tomorrow
description: PARIS  Fashion can occasionally seem as if it exists in its own bubble. (An allover sequined diaper catsuit? Who would wear that?) But this season, the Paris couture shows played out against a background of almost palpable conflict, from the organized and (mostly) entertaining  Federer vs. Djokovic; Brazil vs. Germany  to the unexpected and dismaying: Israel vs. Hamas, the civil war in Ukraine. Escapism was not on the agenda.

title: What Kind of Kitchen Backsplash Will Appeal to Buyers?
description: Q. Ive decided to install marble countertops in my kitchen. What kind of backsplash would appeal to buyers?

title: Reading Hobby Lobby in Context
description: To grasp the full implications of the Supreme Courts Hobby Lobby decision, it helps to read it not in isolation but alongside the courts other major religion case of the term, Town of Greece v. Galloway. Issued eight weeks before Hobby Lobby and decided by the same 5 to 4 division, Town of Greece rejected a challenge to a town boards practice of beginning its public sessions with a Christian prayer. A federal appeals court found the practice unconstitutional, concluding that it violated the First Amendments Establishment Clause by conveying an official endorsement of one particular religion.

title: Playing to the Paleo Crowd
description: An elimination diet inspires Kimberly Dobbins to create an allergy-friendly snack bar company.

title: From Bruce LaBruce, a Perfume All About Obscenity
description: The Canadian art filmmaker Bruce LaBruce is no stranger to transgression. His work has depicted pornographic bloodbaths, zombie necrophilia and amputee fetishism. By those standards, his latest project, Obscenity, the subject of a new show at the New York gallery the Hole, might seem rather tame. Like the artist Francesco Vezzolis notorious Greed, a mock advertisement that starred Natalie Portman and Michelle Williams having a cat fight over a perfume bottle, its a critique of fragrance campaigns, but it bears LaBruces unmistakable stamp.

title: What You Need to Build a Patio
description: No one said it would be easy, but here are the tools that make it possible.

title: Richard Meiers High and Mighty Beach House
description: The story of how Richard Meier, one of the worlds most-celebrated architects, came to design a small, one-bedroom house on a barrier island likely destined for extinction goes back nearly a half-century.

title: Where the Curtains Were Made of Iron
description: Some 350 Cold War-era artifacts, including teacups, tables and surveillance equipment used by the East German secret police, have replaced most of the furnishings in the Neutra VDL Studio and Residences in Los Angeles for Competing Utopias: An Experimental Installation of Cold War Modern Design From East and West in One Context, opening to the public on Sunday. It takes a disorienting look at the parallel universes on either side of the Iron Curtain, a Twilight Zone-like scenario where everything is the same  except that its different. The similarity of objects from the East and West are pretty remarkable, said Bill Ferehawk, who organized the show with Justinian Jampol, founder of the Wende Museum and Archive of the Cold War, and Sarah Lorenzen, the VDL Houses director. They use no labels, so unless visitors consult the iPads in the room, only clues like German phrases on coffee cans will hint at the dcors origins. As Ms. Lorenzen said: We want people to wonder: How is history manufactured? How do stories get told? How different are we really? Through Sept. 13; neutra-vdl.org.

title: Ode on a Spanish Urn, Filled With a Citys Tap Water
description: Bilbao, the northern Spanish city, has a new contribution from a design superstar: not a museum or a bridge this time, but a ceramic water pitcher. Patricia Urquiola, the Spanish-born Milanese designer, has created H2O Bilbao, a pitcher based on the kaiku, an ancient Basque wooden milking and cooking vessel. Ms. Urquiola said she borrowed the classic form to pay tribute to Bilbaos excellent tap water.

title: Putting the Oh! in Patio
description: Theres a fine line between pragmatism and masochism, and I just crossed it.

title: Sales at Michele Varian, Jensen-Lewis, Yves Delorme and Marimekko
description: Michele Varian is discounting some furniture and decorative pillows by up to 70 percent through Sunday (a metal postal desk, usually $2,956, is about $1,774); 27 Howard Street (Crosby Street); 212-343-0033, michelevarian.com.

title: Plants With Roots Attached
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It is through Allen Bush, the seedsman and raconteur, that I lay claim to the 400-year-old legacy of the Dutch engraver and floriculturist Emanuel Sweert. On a cloudless Saturday morning not long ago, Mr. Bush rummaged in his backyard and cut me a clump of a purplish iris. It was an ordinary looking plant, not yet in bloom  hardly noticeable in his oversize city lot.

title: The Flora and Fauna Chronicles
description: Theres a lot of talk about habitat gardens, but how many gardeners have watched a zebra swallowtail butterfly laying its eggs on a pawpaw leaf and then noticed the fuzzy larvae feeding on the leaves, which contain compounds that make the swallowtails unpalatable to birds? Two giants of the natural gardening world, Rick Darke and Doug Tallamy, have collaborated on their best work yet, The Living Landscape: Designing for Beauty and Biodiversity in the Home Garden (Timber Press, $39.95). It documents the layers and creatures of a healthy landscape, like ants carrying seeds of bloodroot and trillium back to their nests, and the blue-gray gnatcatcher nesting in a beech. Mr. Darke, a photographer as well as a plantsman and designer, took most of the gorgeous images, though Mr. Tallamy, an ecologist, offers inspiring close-ups of bugs and birds.

title: London Theater Journal: Mind Games
description: LONDON  Heres to certainty, says Queen Elizabeth II, raising a glass of gin and it (just a small one) to Margaret Thatcher. The words produce a hollow echo in Handbagged, Moira Buffinis lively stretched-out sketch at the Vaudeville Theater here, because it is far from certain that the reigning monarch of Britain ever made such a toast to such a drinking partner.

title: Smiljan Radic: A Rock Star Among Architects
description: Two weeks ago, a translucent pod of glass-reinforced plastic, poised atop enormous sandstone boulders, appeared on a curve of lawn in Kensington Gardens in London. The folly, which one reviewer called a collision between an extraterrestrial egg and a Neolithic burial site, is by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, whom the nearby Serpentine Galleries chose to create a temporary structure in its front yard. It is the 14th year that the museum has commissioned a Serpentine Pavilion, always turning to an architect who has not previously built in Britain, and the unveiling of the park installation has become a closely watched summer ritual.

title: Office High Jinks
description: A cozy art-filled living room, a sleek white kitchen, a Yorkshire terrier padding about: Artspaces new office at 75 Broad Street in the financial district feels more like home than work. The three-year-old company, an online marketplace for contemporary fine art, moved from the Flatiron district last year to a loft that Catherine Levene, a founder and the chief executive, called a large white box. She hired the New York designer Maria Gabriela Brito to help personalize the space with art that is sometimes sold off the walls and features like Eurostyles Farid chairs, upholstered in a newspaper pattern, for the conference room, below. She nixed a few of Ms. Britos wilder ideas, like a bright red pendant lamp in the entry, and insisted on retaining some dull but ergonomic desk chairs. Catherine is afraid of color, Ms. Brito said with a smile.

title: Summer Bedding: Cover Artistry
description: There are two things that Im obsessed with, said Richard Mishaan, an interior designer in Manhattan. Linens and china: they can elevate your life.

title: After Long Stalemate, Argentina Breaks Through in Shootout
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Regulation and extra time brought 120 minutes of scoreless exasperation in a World Cup semifinal on Wednesday that was by turns tense, cautious, clumsy, gripping and stubbornly unyielding.

title: Paris Couture Week: Valentino Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Start-Ups Make Political Organizing Mobile-Ready
description: With Congress nearly frozen in place and big donors taking on growing influence, start-ups are moving into the political breach.

title: Man Sentenced to 17 Years for Beating Roommate to Death at Queens Nursing Home
description: A former resident of a nursing home in Rockaway Park, Queens, was sentenced on Wednesday to 17 years in prison after pleading guilty to bludgeoning his roommate to death last year with the metal footrest of a wheelchair.

title: World Cup Despair in Brazil
description: Brazilians explain what it feels like to lose really, really badly.

title: Obama Presses Perry to Rally Support for Border Funds
description: DALLAS  President Obama on Wednesday directly challenged Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to rally Republicans in support of a $3.7 billion emergency measure aimed at solving the humanitarian crisis caused as thousands of Central American children have crossed the Mexican border.

title: The Crisis of Children at the Border
description: The humanitarian crisis of unaccompanied minors from Central America arriving at our Southwest border has brought out the worst in some of our politicians.

title: A Threat to Internet Freedom
description: New rules proposed by the F.C.C. could divide the Internet into fast lanes and slow lanes, violating the central concept of net neutrality.

title: Co-Author of Bull-Running Guide Is Gored in Pamplona
description: My own final introductory words of advice are simple: if you want to guarantee youll survive running the bulls, stay off the street and watch it from a balcony.

title: On Losing Interest
description: No, its not about boredom. Instead, a further thought on the question of who might be upset about low-interest-rate policies. Low policy rates plus quantitative easing have indeed meant much lower interest earnings across the board, and this is a serious hit to the incomes of those who own interest-bearing assets. So who are we talking about?

title: Detroits Art May Be Worth Billions, Report Says
description: A new expert appraisal of the Detroit Institute of Arts collection, which some creditors are demanding be sold to help pay municipal debts in the citys bankruptcy case, has found that the works could be worth $2.7 billion to $4.6 billion.

title: A Threat to Internet Freedom
description: The last few months have been critically important for the future of Internet freedom and access.

title: A Palestinian Mothers Fear in East Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  THERE was a huge crash, and I felt the ground shake under my familys home. We heard the first explosion just as we had finished our iftar meal ending the daily Ramadan fast and settled down in front of the television. Out the window, I could see people running in the streets of Beit Hanina, my Palestinian neighborhood. Then came a second crash, and a third.

title: How Coffee Fueled the Civil War
description: It was the greatest coffee run in American history. The Ohio boys had been fighting since morning, trapped in the raging battle of Antietam, in September 1862. Suddenly, a 19-year-old William McKinley appeared, under heavy fire, hauling vats of hot coffee. The men held out tin cups, gulped the brew and started firing again. It was like putting a new regiment in the fight, their officer recalled. Three decades later, McKinley ran for president in part on this singular act of caffeinated heroism.

title: Deal Allows University of Texas President to Keep Job for Now
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The University of Texas has been engulfed in recent days in a long-simmering clash over turf, personality and ideology that has roiled the states political establishment, highlighted questions about the direction of public universities and brought the president of the flagship campus here close to being fired.

title: Green Eggs and Politics
3 Rikers Officials Charged in Brutal Beating of Inmate
description: Two New York City correction officers and a captain were arrested Wednesday on charges that they handcuffed and beat an inmate unconscious with a baton at Rikers Island and then falsified documents to cover it up, the authorities said.

title: The Tennis Pros Daughter
description: For 13 summers, my father worked as the tennis pro at a yacht club on Nantucket.

title: Sizing Up Black Markets and Red-Light Districts for G.D.P.
description: PARIS  As the spokesman for the National Association of Sex Clubs in Spain, Jos Roca has fielded all sorts of offbeat inquiries. But rarely has he been more flummoxed than when he received a call late last year from the government statistics agency.

title: Space Probe Might Lack Nitrogen to Push It Home
description: A do-it-yourself team of engineers trying to lasso an aged but operational NASA space probe may have run into an insurmountable obstacle: Tanks on the spacecraft that were once full of nitrogen gas, needed to fire the thrusters, appear to be empty.

title: Taxi Commission Blocks Lyfts Entry Into New York City
description: Looks like those pink mustaches wont be growing in Brooklyn anytime soon.

title: Migrants and the Middlemen
description: The largest and arguably most effective antipoverty effort in the world is financed by the poor themselves. Last year alone, migrants in rich countries sent an estimated $404 billion to their families in developing countries. The money pays for daily needs, as well as for health, education and emergencies.

title: 29 Minutes That Shook Brazil
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil  It started, innocently enough, in the 11th minute.

title: Health Insurers Are Trying New Payment Models, Study Shows
description: Health insurers are experimenting with new formulas for reimbursing doctors and hospitals, slowly moving away from the traditional approach of basing payments on the numbers of tests and procedures performed, according to a survey of Blue Cross insurers, among the most dominant plans in the country.

title: Fleeing Gangs, Children Head to U.S. Border
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  Anthony O. Castellanos disappeared from his gang-ridden neighborhood on the eastern edge of Hondurass most dangerous city, so his younger brother, Kenneth, hopped on his green bicycle to search for him, starting his hunt at a notorious gang hangout known as the crazy house.

title: Campaign Atmosphere Amid Detroit Vote on Debt Plan
description: DETROIT  Until now, this citys journey through bankruptcy has been a drama played out mostly by lawyers and mediators in courtrooms and conference rooms. But as thousands of city workers and retirees approach a Friday deadline to cast votes on the citys plan to emerge from debt  a plan that depends in part on cutting their benefits  Detroit has taken on the feel of an all-out election campaign.

title: An Error Puts a Church on George Carlin Way
description: It took three years for comedians and Catholics to find a mutually agreeable way to rename part of a Manhattan street after George Carlin, the merrily vulgar comic who made religion a frequent target of his acerbic monologues.

title: LeBron Jamess Latest Feat: Bringing a Frenzied League to a Freeze
description: LAS VEGAS  He is the most powerful force in the N.B.A., his imprint extending beyond the four Most Valuable Player awards and the two championships, the endorsement deals and the merchandise sales. In recent days, LeBron James even proved capable of slowing the frenzy of N.B.A. free agency to little more than a crawl, his options spread before him like an all-you-can-eat buffet at the Bellagio.

title: Race Is On to Profit From Rise of Urgent Care
description: NORWALK, Conn.  Start in Room 4, just beyond the reception area: A man is having blood drained from a bruised finger. Over in Room 1, a woman is being treated for eye trouble. Next door, in Room 2, a boy is having his throat swabbed.

title: U.S. Naming a Monitor for the Police in Newark
description: NEWARK  The federal government will appoint a monitor to oversee this citys Police Department as it moves to address longstanding allegations of brutality, discrimination and neglect of civilian complaints, officials said on Wednesday.

title: A Harsh Climate Calls for Banishment of the Needy
description: LONGYEARBYEN, Norway  As governor of Norways northernmost territory, Odd Olsen Ingero commands a police force with just six officers and a single detention cell for an area twice the size of New Jersey. Even that is overkill: Nobody has been locked up here in the capital of Svalbard since last summer. And that was for just two days.

title: Afghanistans Dilemma
description: Abdullah Abdullah, one of two candidates for president of Afghanistan, and his supporters are pushing the country toward a dangerous point by calling the election a coup and threatening to establish a parallel government. He is correct in demanding that charges of rampant electoral fraud be thoroughly investigated. But stoking outrage among his supporters with incendiary language does nothing to ensure a credible and peaceful outcome. The better course is to join his opponent, Ashraf Ghani, in ensuring an outcome that Afghans can believe in.

title: Saving Water in California
description: California is in the third year of its worst drought in decades. But you wouldnt know it by looking at how much water the states residents and businesses are using. According to a recent state survey, Californians cut the amount of water they used in the first five months of the year by just 5 percent, far short of the 20 percent reduction Gov. Jerry Brown called for in January. In some parts of the state, like the San Diego area, water use has actually increased from 2013.

title: Donald Sterling Shouts at Wife in Courtroom
description: LOS ANGELES  As the third day of the trial that will determine the fate of the Los Angeles Clippers drew to a close, Rochelle Sterling, the estranged wife of the teams embattled owner, left the stand and approached her husband, who sat in an aisle seat in the first row.

title: Reputation for Zeal Precedes Republican Leading New Benghazi Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Trey Gowdy was cutting the grass in the front yard of his Spartanburg, S.C., house when Speaker John A. Boehner called with a special assignment.

title: Religious Freedom in Peril
description: A Sudanese court in May sentences a Christian woman married to an American to be hanged, after first being lashed 100 times, after she refuses to renounce her Christian faith.

title: Defense Lawyer Ends Preet Bhararas Streak in Insider Trading Cases
description: The defense lawyer who spoiled Preet Bhararas perfect record in hedge fund insider trading cases has finally gotten a haircut.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 9, 2014
description: July 9, 2014

title: The Rant Agenda
description: So little time, so much bad behavior to complain about.

title: Chinese Hackers Pursue Key Data on U.S. Workers
description: WASHINGTON  Chinese hackers in March broke into the computer networks of the United States government agency that houses the personal information of all federal employees, according to senior American officials. They appeared to be targeting the files on tens of thousands of employees who have applied for top-secret security clearances.

title: Senate Committee Presses N.C.A.A., Signaling Interest in Direction of College Sports
description: WASHINGTON  Members of a United States Senate committee on Wednesday took their turn demanding answers from the N.C.A.A., signaling that Capitol Hill has a growing interest in weighing in on the future of college athletics.

title: Brazilians Grumble and Take Stock After Crushing World Cup Loss
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  As Brazil tried to absorb the shock of its 7-1 loss to Germany in the World Cup, the rout offered a vivid reminder of how the fortunes of the national soccer team can mirror how Brazilians view their society even as other traumas recede into history.

title: Former Cuomo Aide Hired as Executive at Airport Business
description: ALBANY  Less than two weeks after leaving the public sector, a former top aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has been hired by a travel restaurant and boutique operator doing business at both of New York Citys major airports.

title: Republicans Say Ex-I.R.S. Official May Have Circumvented Email
description: WASHINGTON  Lois Lerner, the former Internal Revenue Service official at the center of an investigation into the agencys treatment of conservative political groups, may have used an internal instant-messaging system instead of email so that her communications could not be retrieved by investigators, Republican lawmakers said Wednesday.

title: A Not-So-Subtle Meditation on Sugar
description: As people streamed out of the Kara Walker installation A Subtlety on a recent Sunday afternoon to buy an ice cream cone from one of the trucks idling outside the old Domino Sugar Factory on the Williamsburg waterfront, I wondered how many thought about the jarring contradiction: paying homage to the bodily harms involved in the harsh industrial process inherent in refining sugar, then consuming the industrial concoction that is a Mister Softee-type ice cream cone.

title: Reebok Founder Proposes 95-Story Tower With Casino for Jersey City
description: Real estate brokers have long described New Jerseys gold coast, stretching from Jersey City to Weehawken, as the sixth borough of New York City, where apartments offer the best views of the Empire State Building.

title: Patchwork Makeup of Rebels Fighting Ukraine Makes Peace Talks Elusive
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  One rebel group, Oplot, comes from the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv. Another, the Russian Orthodox Army, is composed of Russians and Ukrainians. A third, named for a river, Kalmius, is made up mainly of coal miners.

title: Polls Slow Japans Plan to Revise Constitution
description: TOKYO  Japans prime minister, Shinzo Abe, appears to have slowed efforts to expand the role of the military just days after announcing a reinterpretation of the countrys pacifist Constitution, a historic and controversial change.

title: Obama Administration Defends Israeli Airstrikes but Cautions Against Ground War
description: WASHINGTON  As the fighting between Hamas and Israel intensified, the Obama administration publicly defended Israels right to carry out airstrikes to stop Hamass rockets while privately cautioning it against ordering a ground attack into Gaza.

title: Roberto Medina, Founder of Rock in Rio Festival, Takes it to Las Vegas
description: ROBERTO MEDINA, the Brazilian music impresario behind the huge Rock in Rio festival franchise, gazed through the floor-to-ceiling windows of his luxury Manhattan apartment one afternoon recently, looking west over the Hudson River in the direction of his next frontier: Las Vegas.

title: Prescription Fraud Charges for Prominent Manhattan Dermatologist
description: A Manhattan dermatologist often quoted in magazines and on television was arrested on Wednesday at her Park Avenue office on charges she wrote fake prescriptions for painkillers, using the names of her patients, filled them at pharmacies and kept the pills for her own benefit.

title: Dish Asks F.C.C. to Block Comcast-Time Warner Cable Merger
description: Dish Network, a satellite television provider, has urged regulators to reject a deal between its rivals that it said would reshape the countrys television and broadband markets.

title: Staten Island Carjacking Suspect Is Questioned in 2 Killings
description: Detectives on Wednesday were questioning a Staten Island man who was arrested on charges of carjacking a Hummer and trying to ram it into police officers near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, seeking to determine whether he had any connection with two killings in the borough over the weekend, a police official said.

title: Knicks Continue to Court Him, but Anthonys Future Is Unclear
description: Carmelo Anthony has offered few clues about his future, and it was more of the same Wednesday when his tenure as a free agent reached eight days.

title: Ex-Inmate Threatens Columbias Paper, Police Say
description: The year was 1972 and the crime was front-page news: a 65-year-old Columbia law professor on his way home was stabbed to death during a mugging. The Columbia Daily Spectator, a student newspaper, published a series of articles on the investigation. Mayor John V. Lindsay called for a citywide manhunt. One of those arrested was Daniel Mingues, a 16-year-old nearby resident, who eventually pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of robbery and was sentenced to up to seven years in prison.

title: Budget Is Key Test for Indias New Government
description: MUMBAI  As Indias newly elected government prepares its first national budget, the business community is watching whether Prime Minister Narendra Modis development-focused campaign promises translate into tangible economic reform.

title: France Aims to Curb Potential Jihadis From Leaving Country
description: PARIS  Amid international concern over the threat posed by Western jihadis returning from training or combat in Syria, the French government will soon propose legislation authorizing it to block suspected proponents of Islamic terrorism from leaving France, top officials announced Wednesday.

title: Closing Arguments in Case of Doctor Accused of Overprescribing Drugs
description: Joseph Haeg only saw Dr. Stan Xuhui Li for less than a year, but during that time he transformed from a robust outdoorsman with an old back injury into an unkempt derelict, his speech slurred, his skin pallid, his eyes glassy, a man so addicted to painkillers his sister said she hardly recognized him.

title: Gee Handcuffs Braves in Return to Help Mets Win Fourth Straight
description: Around mid-May, when Dillon Gee first began rehabilitating his strained back muscle, he decided to grow a beard. Through the rest, the treatment and a setback, and as he worked his way back, he did not shave for two months.

title: 6 Are Killed in Shooting in Houston Suburb
description: Two adults and four children were killed at a home in a Houston suburb on Wednesday, in a shooting that appeared to have stemmed from a domestic dispute, the authorities said.

title: Egypt Silent as Neighbors Wage Battles
description: CAIRO  Again and again over decades, Egypt has leapt in to play the role of mediator during hostilities between the Palestinians and the Israelis, including the time two years ago when Egypts president, Mohamed Morsi, helped broker a cease-fire after eight days of bloodshed in the Gaza Strip.

title: Counterterrorism Chief Stepping Down
description: Matthew G. Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, is resigning after three years, a time during which the threat from Al Qaeda shifted from its headquarters in Pakistan to its affiliates in places like Syria, Iraq and Yemen. Most Americans may not know Matt Olsens name, but every American is safer because of his service, President Obama said in a statement released by the White House. Mr. Olsen has not set a date to leave the job, but it is expected to be in the next few months, after a successor is selected, a spokesman said. The National Counterterrorism Center is the nations terrorism information clearinghouse.

title: U.S. Counterterrorism Chief to Step Down
description: WASHINGTON  Matthew G. Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, is resigning after three years, a time during which the threat from Al Qaeda shifted from its headquarters in Pakistan to its affiliates in places like Syria, Iraq and Yemen.

title: A Natural Beauty Emporium Opens on Nantucket (and Online)
description: In Gaelic, the word follain means healthy, wholesome and sound. Follain, a beauty storefront in Bostons historic South End, lives up to its moniker, stocking all-natural, made-in-the-U.S. products ($10-175) that are both safe and effective. Now, just in time for vacation season, the local favorite has spawned a new seasonal outpost on Nantucket  and, for those who cant make it to the island this summer, a new e-commerce site.

title: A Summer Clam Feast at the Long Island Home of the Chef Anita Lo
description: At around 4:30 in the afternoon, when the tide is low on the south shore of Long Island, April Bloomfield, Elizabeth Falkner and Anita Lo carry kayaks down to the water. Theres no path, so they make their own as they go, clearing tall, wild sea grass with the viciously sharp blade of a scythe that Lo picked up in Hong Kong. Then they climb into their boats and glide away. A school of mirrored shiners moves past. Plovers hop around the frothy shore and small, see-through jellyfish float by, but the chefs are not distracted. They came to dig clams for dinner. This looks good, Lo says, when they reach a grassy island in the middle of the cove. Lets drop our anchors.

title: Striking Portraits From Pre-Civil-War Lebanon
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: The Physical Exam as Refuge
description: There are few situations where we expect to disrobe and have our bodies touched by relative strangers. The physical exam is one of the unique characteristics of the doctor-patient encounter; a visit to a doctor doesnt seem the same without one. Yet, increasingly, theres less and less of it. Visits are shorter and doctors have to spend most of their time at the computer filling out the endless electronic medical records that have come to define the modern medical transaction.

title: Word of the Day | disgorge
description: disgorge \()dis-gorj\ verb

title: Dick Jones, Who Gave Voice to Disneys Pinocchio, Dies at 87
description: Dick Jones, an actor whose face should be more familiar than it is, given the dozens of movie and television roles he played from the time he was a child, but whose boyhood voice  the voice of Pinocchio in the original animated Disney film  remains indelibly memorable, died on Monday at his home in the Northridge section of Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: Newest Health Insurance Customers Are Generally Happy
description: Weve known for a few months now that lots of people signed up for health insurance this year in new marketplaces. A new survey shows that the people who did so are also pretty happy with their purchases.

title: In Yankee Debut, McCarthy Provides a Needed Lift
description: CLEVELAND  The Yankees rotation lost a member on Wednesday, but it officially gained one, too. The newest starter, Brandon McCarthy, debuting hours after the team learned that its ace, Masahiro Tanaka, would be out indefinitely with elbow inflammation, was acquired to complement him  not to replace him.

title: How to Read the Polls in This Years Midterms
description: With four months to go until this years midterm elections, perhaps the only thing clear about the fight for the Senate is that it will pose challenges to public polling.

title: Paul Horn, a Founding Father of New Age Music, Dies at 84
description: Paul Horn, a flutist and saxophonist whose mellow, meditative recordings helped lay the groundwork for New Age music, died on June 29 at his home in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 84.

title: Rosemary Murphy, 89, Emmy Winner Familiar to Broadway, Dies
description: Rosemary Murphy, an Emmy Award-winning actress long ubiquitous on television, stage and screen, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Three Men Die in Car Crash in East Orange, N.J.
description: Three men were killed in a car crash in East Orange, N.J., on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

title: Seymour Barab, 93, Composer of Playful Operas, Dies
description: Seymour Barab, a composer known for his whimsical chamber operas on such stirring subjects as passion, poison and pizza, died on June 28 in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 10 P.M. (TLC) LEAH REMINI: ITS ALL RELATIVE Ms. Remini, above, the former King of Queens star who last year left the Church of Scientology after more than 30 years, invites cameras into her home, where she; her husband, Angelo; and their daughter, Sofia, interact  sometimes loudly  with an extended cast of characters including Ms. Reminis mother and stepfather, her sister and brother-in-law, a nanny, a security guard and a personal assistant. The series begins as an argument leads Ms. Remini and her sister to agree to hold a living funeral for their mother, the better for her to find out what her daughters really think of her.

title: Corrections: July 10, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 10, 2014
description: When prosecutors wanted to discuss the case, they asked us to meet at their office, because they were afraid to come here. If they were afraid, imagine us.

title: Can American Apparel Be Saved?
description: The struggling clothing brand has reached a deal with New York investment firm Standard General. But will it provide rejuvenation or just short-term stability?

title: Obama on Immigration
description: After meeting with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, President Obama spoke about the political challenges of resolving the immigration situation.

title: Cloud Computing Giants Add to Open Source Credentials With Kubernetes
description: A modest and geeky announcement by Google and a couple other big tech names on Thursday may be the summers biggest development in a continuing fight over the future of huge global computing.

title: Student Crossword | The 50 States
description: Test your knowledge of the 50 states by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: 6 Qs About the News | This Is Our Youth
description: In This Is Our Youth, Gretchen Reynolds writes about a new study about young Americans physical fitness.

title: India Unveils Budget to Lift Economic Growth
description: NEW DELHI  Burdened with extraordinary expectations after a campaign that promised good days are coming, Prime Minister Narendra Modis center-right government presented a budget on Thursday aimed at increasing investment, improving infrastructure and reviving manufacturing, though it fell short of the drastic overhauls necessary to rein in spending.

title: SSP Group, an Airport Food Retailer, Raises About $826 Million in London I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The SSP Group, a food and beverage retailer at airports and train stations, saw its shares climb on Thursday after it raised about $826 million in its initial public offering in London.

title: On the Sidelines of the Tour de France
description: Covering the Tour de France is not easy. Over three weeks and more than 2,000 miles, photographers have to play a game of high-speed leap the frog with the competitors, racing ahead of the pack as road conditions allow and hoping for a decent shot as the cyclists sweep past them. And then they do it all over again.

title: A Headbangers Headache
description: Dancing at a heavy-metal concert could be bad for your health.

title: Low-Grade Nuclear Material Is Seized by Rebels in Iraq, U.N. Says
description: LONDON  Iraq has notified the United Nations that Sunni militants seized nuclear material from a university in the northern city of Mosul last month as they advanced toward Baghdad, the nuclear regulatory body of the United Nations said Thursday.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.
