title: Morning Views
description: The largest and arguably most effective antipoverty effort in the world is financed by the poor themselves, writes The New York Times editorial board. Last year alone, migrants in rich countries sent an estimated $404 billion to their families in developing countries. Known as remittances, these transfers could see a rise in transfer fees as big banks likeBank of America and JPMorgan Chaseare leaving the money-transfer business. Bankers claim regulation has become too onerous in the wake of recent settlements over money laundering connected to remittance transfers. But The Times believes banks want out because they face dwindling profits from cash transfers. Over the last five years, there has been a successful global effort to lower remittance costs through greater transparency, better technology and other innovations. If banks cant profitably transmit remittances, then other secure, low-cost options must be found.

title: How the Rise of Cellphones Affects Surveys
description: Do you know anyone who doesnt own a cellphone? Just a few years ago, you probably would have said yes, but today, those folks are a small minority. As of December, 7 percent of Americans did not have a wireless phone. And 4 in 10 adults have eliminated their landline and use a cellphone exclusively, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Preventions National Health Interview Survey. The rise of cellphones has forced a transformation in the polling field.

title: 1964: New Premier Takes Office

These were the first official acts of the ten-member cabinet after the 44-year-old Mr. Tshombe presented the ministers formally to President Joseph Kasavubu. Removal of the curfew on Leopoldville, imposed seven weeks ago after a rash of bombings, was expected to spark wild celebrations.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 11, 1964

title: Artists Look Beyond the Arab Spring

Here and Elsewhere, on view at the New Museum, at 235 Bowery, Lower East Side, from July 16 through Sept. 28, features 45 artists from Amman, Beirut, Cairo, Dubai, Ramallah and Sharjah, among other cities. There are artists looking at conflict and wars, but we did not want to restrict this to the Arab Spring, said Massimiliano Gioni, the museums associate director, who worked with a team of curators. This is not a show in which the artists are forced to illustrate historic changes.

title: In Time-Lapse Videos, the Magic Unfolds

A former laser physicist at NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Mr. Lang ditched his day job at a fiber-optics company 13 years ago to devote his life to folding paper. Dozens of his featherweight creations are on display here at the Art Center College of Design: a peregrine falcon and an emperor scorpion, a stag beetle and a bull moose, all fashioned with such skill and lifelike detail, they appear ready to leap off their pristine white pedestals. The complex pieces require days of work and hundreds to thousands of folds. Viewers spend as much time enjoying their beauty as they do marveling at just how these animal figures were made, without cuts or glue, from a single sheet of paper.

title: 1939: Finnish Fascists Lose Election
description: HELSINGFORS  Finlands Fascists suffered the most spectacular defeat in their history in the general election concluded in Finland recently. The defeat came on the heels of a ban in 1938 against the patriotic national movement, the Fascists organization in Finland, by the Finnish Minister of the Interior, M. Kekkonen. After Swan Lake, which runs throughnext Sunday, are Don Quixote (July 22 and 23) and Spartacus (July 25 to 27). Since the productions lean toward the musty side  Yuri Grigorovich, the companys former artistic director, choreographed both Swan Lake and Spartacus it might be best to focus on the dancers. Along with Mr. Hallberg and Ms. Zakharova, there is the young Olga Smirnova, who performs Swan Lake opposite Semyon Chudin next Saturday and next Sunday, and the boldly enticing Maria Alexandrova as Kitri in Don Quixote onJuly 22.As for Spartacus? description: My Brightest Diamond

title: Dropping the Mask, With Egos in Check
description: The creators of the British electro-soul collective Jungle may have many self-taught skills, but dancing on roller skates is not one of them. When the duo released their celebrated EP The Heat last fall in their native Britain, they took an enigmatic route, keeping their faces and names under wraps. The video for the title track featured a pair of synchronized skaters in tracksuits. Confusion ensued.

title: False Starts Before Cables Golden Age
description: In the golden age of the high-class cable drama, its easy to forget that no cable channel started its life with such fare. HBO and Showtime? Movies. AMC? Old movies. USA? Sports. ABC Family? Pat Robertson.

title: In U.S. Data, a Baffling Contradiction
description: The first quarter of this year was the worst for the United States economy since the depths of the Great Recession in early 2009.

title: Guiding and Gliding, the Urban Bush Women
description: From their debut in a Manhattan loft 30 years ago this month, in a dance performance that Jennifer Dunning called deeply affecting and stylishly produced in The New York Times, the Urban Bush Women have gone on to win awards, tour internationally and take part in cultural diplomacy for the State Department.

title: From Baby Fat to Stubble: Growing Up in Real Time
description: The first shot in Boyhood, Richard Linklaters tender, profound film, is of a cloudy sky. The second is of a boy staring up at that sky, one arm bent under his head, the other flung out straight on the ground. Hes a pretty child with calm eyes, a snub nose and a full mouth. Its a face that you get to know and love because, even as this child is watching the world, youre watching him grow. From scene to scene, you see the curve of his jaw change, notice his thickening brows and witness his slender arms opening to embrace the world and its clear and darkening skies.

title: Feet Planted on a Choreographic Riddle
description: At the beginning of every project, the choreographer Tere OConnor asks himself a basic question. As he said recently over coffee near his West Village apartment: What am I doing? What is dance trying to do?

title: Look East, West and Inward
description: ISTANBUL  On a recent evening here, young people tossed Frisbees on the grassy lawns of an American-style college campus, while elegantly clad patrons sipped wine before a concert featuring the soprano Diana Damrau and the harpist Xavier de Maistre.

title: Homesick Strangers Among Us
description: Were the unknown Americans, says a character in Cristina Henrquezs second novel, the ones no one even wants to know, because theyve been told theyre supposed to be scared of us and because maybe if they did take the time to get to know us, they might realize that were not that bad, maybe even that were a lot like them.

title: Unlikely Warriors
description: I have to confess  my love of elephants made me apprehensive to review a book about their role in World War II. But as soon as I began to read Elephant Company, I realized that not only was my heart safe, but that this book is about far more than just the war, or even elephants. This is the story of friendship, loyalty and breathtaking bravery that transcends species.

title: The Fault in Our DNA
description: In his 2007 book A Farewell to Alms, the economic historian Gregory Clark argued that the English came to rule the world largely because their rich outbred their poor, and thus embedded their superior genes and values throughout the nation. In her comprehensive takedown, the historian Deirdre N. McCloskey noted that Clarks idea was a bold hypothesis, and was bold when first articulated by social Darwinists such as Charles Davenport and Francis Galton in the century before last. Indeed, over the past 150 years, various white Western scientists and writers have repeatedly offered biological explanations for Caucasian superiority. They have repeatedly failed because, as McCloskey noted, none ever mounted a credible quantitative argument.

title: The Settlers
description: On a trip to Lusaka, Zambia, last year, I kept chasing an energetic and jittery Chinese man, the only staff member of a Chinese mining company willing to talk to me after his firm had been involved in several scandals in which both Chinese and Zambian employees were either killed or injured on the job. Zambia, with its abundant copper ore deposits, is one of the most important investment destinations for China. His English was excellent, and he liked to talk  and talk. After telling me about how much he loved the country and its people, he sometimes went into a rant about how Zambian miners liked drinking and money too much, and did not like to work hard. It was that mentality, he continued, that had caused his company all its troubles (not the workplace-safety and low-pay grievances of which it was accused). But even though the Zambian government had repossessed his companys mines, this man wasnt leaving. He was now working as an interpreter for the government.

title: Wedding Q. & A.
description: Invitation to an Etiquette Disaster

title: Andr Greipel Wins a Sprint at the Tour de France
description: REIMS, France  Just when it looked as if Marcel Kittel might win all of the sprint finishes at this years Tour de France, another German sprinter, Andr Greipel, was first across the line at the end of the 194-kilometer (120-mile) stage form Arras to Reims on Thursday.

title: As Gold and Gambling Lose Their Luster, Deadwood Seeks a Spark
description: DEADWOOD, S.D.  This old Western town of gunfights and gambling is going through an identity crisis.

title: Direct From the Acme Animation Co.
description: He wasnt famous for chomping on carrots, outsmarting hunters or painting realistic tunnels on the sides of mountains, but Chuck Jones was as important to the history of animation as Bugs Bunny or Wile E. Coyote. Jones spent the 1930s through the 1960s directing many of the most manic and inventive Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies shorts featuring those beloved Warner Bros. characters; he went on to direct and produce more ambitious animation before his death in 2002.

title: Betting on Diesel Cars, Exxon Is Set to Expand Belgium Refinery
description: LONDON  At Dimitris Polivious car repair shop, customers are increasingly turning up with diesel-powered vehicles.

title: Google Launches European Venture Fund
description: LONDON  In a sign that Europes tech scene is coming into its own, Google announced that its venture capital unit had started a $100 million fund to invest in the regions start-ups.

title: In China, Four Seasons of Design
description: Isabelle Pascale, founder of the boutique Wuhao in a preserved corner of Beijing, showcases the work of contemporary Chinese and Western designers.

title: Obamas FunnyorDie.com Video Nominated for Emmy
description: President Obama may have a future in Hollywood. The FunnyorDie.com video starring Mr. Obama and Zach Galifianakis was nominated for an Emmy on Thursday in the category of short-format live-action entertainment programs.

title: Brazils BTG Pactual to Acquire Reinsurer
description: SO PAULO  BTG Pactual of Brazil announced on Thursday that it was buying Ariel Re, a reinsurance company based in Bermuda and London, from the Global Atlantic Financial Group, a privately held insurance company that was spun off from Goldman Sachs in 2013.

title: Rowin, Rowin, Rowin on the River
description: IF you want a workout thats strenuous, frightening, frustrating, thrilling, exhausting, challenging and serene all at the same time, try rowing in an eight-oared boat on the Harlem River.

title: A Fugitive Who Stops to Smell the Flowers
description: Road to Paloma, a leisurely drama about family, brotherhood and Native American rights, plays out on the dusty highways and barren landscapes of an American West that seems frozen in time. Using that quality to powerful effect, the director, Jason Momoa, and his cinematographer, Brian Andrew Mendoza, shore up a simple plot with a richly atmospheric palette of coppery light and caramel sunsets that makes even urgent events seem almost soothing.

title: Cancer Sidelines Japanese Composer
description: The Japanese composer and keyboardist (and, occasionally, actor) Ryuichi Sakamoto posted a note on his website on Thursday saying that he has throat cancer, and has decided to cancel his performances at the Sapporo International Art Festival of which he is the guest director.

title: In Rubble of Gaza Seaside Cafe, Hunt for Victims Who Had Come for Soccer
description: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip  About a dozen local Palestinians gathered Wednesday evening at the Fun Time Beach cafe, a beachside eatery of plastic chairs, umbrellas, walls of cloth and palm leaves, a container for a kitchen and a small bathroom, to watch the World Cup match between Argentina and the Netherlands.

title: A Spectacle of Pop Idol Proportions
description: Theres a moment of giddy self-declaration (O.K., one of many) in the splatter canvas of pop pageantry that is Katy Perrys Prismatic World Tour. It comes during This Is How We Do, a flippant anthem of consumption featured in one of Ms. Perrys recent commercials for a major cosmetics brand. On Wednesday night, in her sold-out show at Madison Square Garden, its staging involved an inflatable car, a riot of neon Lycra and a flotilla of parade balloons, including one for the emoji pictograph widely known as smiling pile of poo.

title: Hidden Pleasures Lie Within
description: If you ask, the patient people at Khao Kang will identify the dozen unlabeled dishes on the steam table for you, but this will not necessarily help. Their one-word descriptions (shrimp, chicken and, repeatedly, pork) tell nothing of the layers of flavor, surprises and comforts to be found here, in one of the sincerest Thai restaurants in New York City.

title: For One Team, Its Sink or Swim
description: Four teenagers winning an academic contest might not seem to merit a documentary. Happens all the time, right? But in Underwater Dreams, the teenagers are Latinos  and illegal immigrants, four of the many who could gain citizenship through the Dream Act  from a low-income high school in Arizona. They win against many colleges, including M.I.T., in a robotics challenge. And their unlikely achievement, in 2004, reverberates a decade later, helping the students who followed them at Carl Hayden Community High School to have more confidence and even, in some cases, propelling them to work as engineers and as leaders in Dreamer groups.

title: Reform Conservatism and the Culture War
description: After my foray yesterday into the specific case of Paul Ryan, let me return to broader critiques of reform conservatism, picking up threads from E.J. Dionnes long essay on our little movement and some ofAndrew Sullivans comments this week. I first read Dionnes essay some time ago and intended a long point-by-point rejoinder; Ive read so many (far harsher, less thoughtful) critiques since, however, that upon re-reading the essay seemed marvelously fair-minded, and worth recommending even if I obviously have disagreements with its substance. But heres a prescriptive passage thats worth commenting on:

title: Dont Bring That Boyfriend Home
description: Folding social realism into a woman-in-peril thriller, Honour confronts the problem of so-called honor killings among British Muslims with brash economy and first-feature zeal.

title: Field of Misfits
description: The story of the Portland Mavericks could slip easily into the same lineup as Bull Durham or Major League: A baseball outsider starts an independent team in Oregon, holds open tryouts that draw castoffs and rejects, then watches his wild bunch beat more talented clubs.

title: The Car That Witnessed the Spark of World War I
description: A century ago, Archduke Franz Ferdinand, the heir apparent to the Austro-Hungarian throne, and his wife, Sophie, the duchess of Hohenberg, were killed in Sarajevo while riding in a Grf & Stift open-topped touring car. It was the event that ignited World War I.

title: Backsliding Into Brutality to Avenge a Daughter
description: Those expecting Nicolas Cage theatrics in Rage  and why not, with a title that practically cries out for a rhyming tagline  may be disappointed. Mr. Cage underplays in his latest role, as a father out for justice after his daughters violent death, and its at least an attempt at a change-up. But the hand-me-down showiness and sluggish storytelling by the director, Paco Cabezas, underline the monotony in this ordinary revenge thriller.

title: A Smitten Boy Senses an Opening and Seizes It
description: Washed in the colors of surf and sand, and moving to the languid rhythms of swaying palm trees, The Empty Hours is like a mental vacation from the noise and bombast of the summer blockbuster. No convoluted plot or high-wattage star distracts from its meandering observations and mellow performances; no crass jokes or car chases disrupt its delicate, yearning mood. In other words, this second feature by the Mexican director Aarn Fernndez is a delight.

title: Sarah Palins Impeachment Plan, Rejected
description: Sarah Palins argumentif one can call it thatin Breitbart a few days ago that its time to impeach President Obama isnt gaining much traction among Republicans with actual power. Andrew Kaczynski of BuzzFeed has pulled together quotes from elected officials with no interest in trying to add Mr. Obama to that exclusive club composed of Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton (Richard Nixon was not actually impeached). Whats notable is that their lack of interest is entirely practicali.e. they wont say the president doesnt deserve impeachment, only that its not going to happen.

title: Guys With Lots of Mileage, on the Road
description: The road movie, that asphalt playground of fast cars, masculine prerogative, gangland sprees and occasional feminist cri de coeur, is such a durable American genre that you can fly the idea halfway around the world, drop it on Iceland, rev up a car the size of a military tank and still make it work. This pretty much describes what happens in Land Ho!, a delightful tale of two longtime friends of a certain age, Colin (Paul Eenhoorn) and Mitch (Earl Lynn Nelson), who embark on a classic journey of self-discovery generously embellished with laughter, otherworldly beauty and philosophical inquiries into the nature of existence perfumed by the aroma of cheerfully smoked joints.

title: Collecting Books That Are Just Covers
description: Anything that looks like a book but is not one interests Mindell Dubansky, a preservation librarian at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. For 20 years, she has been buying antiques with simulations of covers, spines and pages.

title: With the End of Days Near, a Sect Is Torn
description: As It Is in Heaven opens quietly yet with unmistakable joy as the camera tracks a white-robed young woman through gracious rooms and lush gardens to the banks of a sparkling river. Joining the other members of her small religious sect, she watches their prophet (John Lina) baptize a new recruit (Chris Nelson) and give him the name David.

title: Britains Schindler, a Reluctant Hero
description: In 1988, the BBC program Thats Life! aired an episode dedicated to Sir Nicholas Winton, a British stockbroker who rescued 669 mostly Jewish children from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia in 1939. In the wake of Sir Nicholass 105th birthday last May, a segment from that episode went viral.

title: Candidates Raise Specter of Cheating in Indonesian Presidential Election
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Political tensions in Indonesia rose on Thursday, a day after the countrys hotly contested presidential election, as the supporters of the two candidates raised fears about possible cheating during days of vote tallying.

title: If You Read This, You Might Never Drink a Latte Again
description: Lattes have a lot to answer for. To some, drinking one makes you a snob. To others, it makes you a spendthrift. But neither of these perceptions may be particularly accurate  and in fact, the latte can tell us a lot about how America thinks about food, work and money.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Evidence of H.I.V. Found in a Child Said to Be Cured
description: A child in Mississippi who was thought to have been cured of H.I.V. with aggressive drug treatment immediately after birth is now showing signs of infection with the virus, federal health officials announced Thursday  a serious setback to hopes for a cure for AIDS.

title: That First Step Is a Doozy
description: On New Years Eve, four despondent Londoners determined to end it all simultaneously converge at a favorite suicide destination atop a tall building. After jockeying for position (who goes first?), followed by some perky commiseration, they agree not to hurl themselves into oblivion but to postpone their rendezvous with death until Valentines Day, at which point they will return and make the leap. In the meantime, they form a cheery mutual support group, meeting here and there around London and even traveling together to Spain.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Yemen, Gaza City, India and Spain.

title: Fighting Trash and Noise at Parks Weekly Revelry
description: Responding to complaints from residents tired of the raucous behavior and piles of trash left behind in northern Riverside Park, the New York City parks department on Thursday announced a plan to deal with the problem through stepped-up enforcement and additional cleanup crews.

title: In Spanish Language, With Womens Voices
description: Across Latin America, girls celebrate their 15th birthday as their quinceaera, the beginning of young womanhood. So it was appropriate that intrepid, idealistic women  Ana Tijoux, from Chile, and Danay Surez, from Cuba  were the standouts at the first concerts of the 15th annual Latin Alternative Music Conference, which continues through Saturday. It presents rock, pop and hip-hop, often bilingual, from across the Americas at free concerts and club events.

title: Sex-Role Reversals in Sondheim
description: Our Time, the opening number of KT Sullivan and Jeff Harnars iconoclastic Stephen Sondheim show at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Wednesday evening, is the optimistic dawn-of-a-new-age anthem from Merrily We Roll Along. Its the 1950s, and there are nothing but blue skies and bright futures ahead in the lives of its nave musical-theater hopefuls gazing forward with starry-eyed confidence.

title: Funeral Held for New York Firefighter
description: Thousands of uniformed firefighters gathered for the funeral of Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, who died Saturday searching for victims in a burning high-rise apartment building in Brooklyn.

title: Birth of a Career
description: I am 11 years old. Practically every adult I meet asks me, What do you want to be when you grow up? This would be really cute if I was 4 and could say, Fireman. But Im in the fifth grade and have no idea what I want to do for work 10 years from now. How can I respond that wont get me in trouble with my parents?

title: Unlikely Tenants Filling a Neighborhood Vacancy
description: In 2009, when a bad economy left commercial spaces vacant across New York City, an itinerant nonprofit art group called No Longer Empty started filling some of them  a storefront on West 23rd Street, the closed-up Tower Records on lower Broadway  with art. This summer, the organization adds a twist to its mission by working on premises that have yet to be occupied, an in-progress 13-story affordable-housing complex called the Sugar Hill Building located on West 155th Street in Washington Heights.

title: Scant Interest in F.H.A. Program
description: A government program aimed at helping underwater homeowners refinance into more-affordable, reduced-principal loans has captured only a sliver of the borrowers thought to be eligible in the four years since its introduction.

title: Devil Swipes a Violin, but the Band Plays On
description: Feather Gatherers, part of the Ice Factory festival, a wellspring of singular drama, unfurls in some fantastical Serbia of the mind, a Slivovitz-soaked realm of peasant blouses and folk superstitions. Produced by the Drunkards Wife, an experimental theatrical troupe, and loosely adapted from Stravinskys dance-theater piece LHistoire du Soldat, this bleary, madcap musical tells the story, more or less, of a nave soldier (Jess Barbagallo) who falls prey to the wily Devil (Juliana Francis Kelly).

title: Daniel Heidkamp
description: The three main shows at White Columns form a meditation on current painting tactics. In one small gallery, Patrick Berran very capably meets the demand for Minimalist paintings made by largely hands-off methods  in his case, layers of photocopy transfers dominated by a pattern that reads as leopard skin or moisture condensation, depending on its size. Nearby, Jennifer Nichols works with thin, bright acrylic, creating abstract tumults of transparent brushwork and, more recently, calmer arrangements of letterlike shapes. Both artists show promise, but so far they are operating within fashionable styles rather than making the work that only they can make.

title: Long Days, Extra Innings
description: New art books include textured dreamscapes by Lee Bontecou and full-size reproductions of Charles M. Schulzs Peanuts.

title: Knud Lonberg-Holm: The Invisible Architect
description: The Danish-American architect Knud Lonberg-Holm, the first European to teach the Bauhaus curriculum in America, belonged to that white-hot, manifesto-propelled moment in the 1920s when de Stijl principles were being translated into three-dimensional space. A dozen of his limpid gouache renderings of Michigan houses, all masterly compositions of point, line and plane, show buildings broken into constituent walls, roofs, floors and columns. With a palette of photographic black, white and gray, accented in blues and reds, he created weightless abstractions; solids and voids intersect in optical puzzles. He brushed calligraphic proposals for the new streamlined building types of the Machine Age  gas and radio stations  with a fierce graphic energy. His radically angled photographs of Americas traffic jams, skyscrapers, fire escapes and power lines found their way into Amerika, the German architect Erich Mendelsohns photographic essay of American cityscapes. Letters from Theo van Doesburg, Walter Gropius and Mies van der Rohe authenticate his position as a peer. Buckminster Fuller wanted to write a book about him.

title: Eileen Ford, Grande Dame of the Modeling Industry, Dies at 92
description: Eileen Ford, the grande dame of the modeling industry who influenced standards of beauty for more than four decades while heading one of the most recognizable brands in the trade of gorgeous faces, died on Wednesday in Morristown, N.J. She was 92.

title: Amy Poehler Explains Whats Funny About Sweden
description: Will Ferrells wife is Swedish. Aubrey Plaza once dated a Swedish exchange student. Patrick Duffy is a big star in Sweden because of Dallas. Illeana Douglas appears in Easy to Assemble, a web series for Ikea, the Swedish home-furnishings company. Gene Simmons likes Swedish women.

title: A Pilots 1938 Flight of Doom and Memory
description: PHILADELPHIA  The choreographer Matthew Neenan has created ballets across the United States. In 2009, he was the grand-prize winner in Sacramento Ballets Capital Choreography Competition; Ive seen premieres by him in Vail, Colo., and Memphis.

title: This Weekend | What to Watch on TV
description: Alessandra Stanley, a television critic for The Times, previews three new series.

title: Questions and Answers About Indias New Budget
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modis new government in India has unveiled its first economic road map aimed at increasing investment, improving infrastructure and reviving manufacturing, even while curbing borrowing. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the economy would expand at an annual rate of 7 to 8 percent within three years, but warned that the global slowdown had created a difficult environment for growth. The plan received a mixed reception.

title: A Place of Serene Excitement, Inside and Out
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  In a time of hubristic museum expansionism, the beloved if rather fusty Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute here has managed something distinctly surprising: It has gotten bigger and better.

title: Savory Lanes That Are So Not Food Courts
description: REAL New Yorkers dont do malls. Or amusement parks, unless theyre a little decrepit and dangerous. Or food courts, unless theyre crowded and ethnic. Or street fairs, unless theyre right outside and cant be avoided.

title: A River Runs Through It: The Amazon as Inspiration
description: Waterweavers: The River in Contemporary Colombian Visual Arts and Material Culture at the Bard Graduate Center is the most unassumingly beautiful show Ive seen in New York this summer. And with its glades of abstract patterning, eddying pools of woven fiber, and projected images of water sluicing through galleries, its visually the coolest.

title: Harps vs. the Usual Hubbub
description: Members of the New York Philharmonic departing in a bus after a concert Wednesday evening in Prospect Parks Long Meadow were saluted with cheers and waves, like a triumphant soccer team leaving a stadium. The event, conducted by Alan Gilbert, was the opener in the orchestras free parks concerts series, and the police estimated that it drew 15,000 people.

title: If Gatsby Were Coming of Age Today ...
description: Affluenza begins in September 2008, as an investment banker (Roger Rees) blathers to the protagonist, Fisher (Ben Rosenfield), about a going-out-of-business sale for the baby boomers. He quotes Rudyard Kipling on the law of the jungle and tells Fisher, an aspiring photographer, that his pictures capture the decline of a generation of overindulged kids.

title: Ashes to Ashes, Dust to Powder
description: At the grassy summit of a low hill outside the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., the metal cargo containers of two 14-foot box trucks rise vertically like twin towers, their cabs buried underground. Its a sculpture called At Least They Died Together (After Dash) (2013-14), by Dan Colen, and its a memorial to his friend Dash Snow, who died of a drug overdose in 2009. It appears as an incongruous eyesore against the backdrop of its bucolic surroundings. Visitors may notice that the thin skins of the truck boxes have holes in them. During the exhibitions opening, Mr. Colen threw rocks and hammers at them, while drummers of the two-person band I.U.D.  one atop each of the truck ends  played thunderously.

title: Many Sacrifices, but Few Perks for Events Volunteers
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The day after Brazil lost to Germany in the host countrys worst World Cup loss ever, thousands of volunteers slipped on their official teal blue shirts, slid on their official dark pants and perhaps pulled the brim of their official hats down low to head to another day of working at this event, which began last month as the nations pride but is now its raw humiliation.

title: The Talk of Sun Valley (Its Not Just About Deals)
description: Updated, 6:47 p.m. | SUN VALLEY, Idaho  It may be hard to believe, but the Allen & Company conference isnt just about hushed merger talks in side rooms or on the golf course.

title: Good News in High Places
description: President Obama may have a future in Hollywood.

title: Obama and Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: The Top 10 Moments of Fall/Winter 2014 Paris Couture Week
description: The fall 2014 womens couture shows, which began Sunday, wrapped up yesterday in Paris. From the fashion to the haute joaillerie to the off-the-runway star sightings, these were some of the seasons most memorable moments.

title: Stanley Fischer Urges Congress to Expand Feds Mandate
description: Stanley Fischer, the Federal Reserves new vice chairman, said on Thursday in his first public remarks that regulators had made significant progress in improving the resilience of the financial system.

title: Soccer in Brazil, and Outside the Worlds Glare
description: Mauricio Lima went to remote villages, up the river and even to a prison, to document his countrymens passion for the sport, and their lives, during the World Cup.

title: Theater Listings for July 11-17
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, show times and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: An Illustrated Guide to Eccentric Baseball Pitches
description: Bruce Schoenfelds article on the all-but-extinct screwball piqued my curiosity: Are there any other marginalized pitches out there on the brink of falling off the table, as they say of a particularly nasty split-fingered fastball? As it turns out, there are. And the gyro-ball and the Trekkie, to name two, could borrow a bit of the limelight being cast on the screwball in this weekends magazine. So I asked Jason Polan, an illustrator with experience drawing a screwballer, to interpret some of these pitches for us. Catch, in no particular order:

title: Movie Listings for July 11-17
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Cleveland Hopes LeBron James Does Not Break Its Heart Again
description: CLEVELAND  The city that leads with its chin has jutted it out there one more time. In a sort-of, maybe, please-dont-hit-me-again fashion.

title: Despite a Pledge by Samsung, Child Labor Proves Resilient
description: DONGGUAN, China  After work, the three teenage girls giggle and pull at one anothers hair. But when questioned, they admit their common secret: They use false papers to work illegally here at the factory that makes mobile phone components for one of the worlds biggest brands, Samsung.

title: Break the Immigration Impasse
description: AMERICAN citizens are paying 535 people to take care of the legislative needs of the country. We are getting shortchanged. Heres an example: On June 10, an incumbent congressman in Virginia lost a primary election in which his opponent garnered only 36,105 votes. Immediately, many Washington legislators threw up their hands and declared that this one event would produce paralysis in the United States Congress for at least five months. In particular, they are telling us that immigration reform  long overdue  is now hopeless.

description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Urg. Glug. Mmph. My head feels like its stuffed with oatmeal.

description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Here and here and here.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for July 11-17
description: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Despite Exposure of Madoff Fraud, New Ponzi Schemes Emerge
description: When the money was rolling in from investors, Scott W. Rothstein, a lawyer in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., bought his wife, Kimberly, more than $1 million in jewelry, including an opulent 12-carat yellow diamond ring. He lived in a multimillion-dollar waterfront mansion and regularly wrote big checks to charities and politicians.

title: Dance Listings for July 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Questcor Reveals Adverse Events Data for Acthar for First Time
description: For years, Questcor Pharmaceuticals has highlighted the potential benefits of Acthar, its immune-system drug, while saying little about its ill effects.

title: Barcelonas Cannabis Culture
description: In Barcelona, government officials worry that Barcelonas members-only cannabis clubs are becoming a magnet for marijuana tourism.

title: Marijuana Clubs Rise Out of Decades-Old Spanish Laws
description: BARCELONA, Spain  On a recent evening, two vacationing German college students, armed with addresses they had gotten off the Internet, were trying to get into one of Barcelonas new marijuana clubs.

title: Tracking Sun Valleys Most Wanted Guest: Marissa Mayer
description: Updated, 8:20 p.m. | SUN VALLEY, Idaho  Ask many attendees  and certainly everyone in the press corps  assembled at the Allen & Company conference here who was the guest with the most buzz, and the list of potential answers will almost certainly include Marissa Mayer.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for July 11-17
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Let Em Eat Dirt
description: In the tardy twilight of a Puget Sound evening, we caught a glimpse of a boy, maybe 6 or 7, playing in mud exposed by low tide. Ankle-deep in vibrant muck, he called out a discovery to his father.

title: U.N. Finds Most People Now Live in Cities
description: UNITED NATIONS  More than half of humanity now lives in cities, and even more will soon. The world will have to confront how to make cities more fit for human habitation.

title: Shadowy Rebel Wields Iron Fist in Ukraine Fight
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Late one afternoon last month, as separatist militia fighters and Ukrainian forces exchanged fire, a small-time thief by the name of Aleksei B. Pichko left his home on the southern edge of Slovyansk and headed for an abandoned residence at 17 Sadovaya Street. He had been drinking, and wanted to see what could be stolen from there, according to documents recovered at the rebel headquarters after their retreat over the weekend.

title: Form, Function and Beauty Span Eons in Met Acquisitions
description: Objects have long been considered a poor cousin to paintings, but not at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where two recent acquisitions spanning centuries and civilizations were as functional as they were decorative. One is an early Roman vessel used as a cinerary urn; another, a group of 20th-century Venetian glass designs by the Italian architect Carlo Scarpa, was on view last winter.

title: The Art of Water Recovery
description: Imagine that you run a company that sells bottled water. You spend lots of money, and use lots of energy, pumping the water out of the ground, purifying it and transporting it for sale. Then, one day, you discover that a large number of bottles never make it to the stores. They are falling through holes in the trucks.

title: Q. and A.: Rana Mitter on the Legacy of World War II in Asia
description: When Chinese President Xi Jinping spoke at an event in Beijing on Monday commemorating the 77th anniversary of the start of full-scale war with Japan, he warned against efforts to downplay Japans brutal occupation of China. It was a stark reminder of how the events of that era continue to shape the geopolitics of Asia today, as China and Japan square off over territorial disputes and Beijing voices concern about Japans moves to lift  longstanding restrictions on its military forces.

description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Apart from Germany, the Champagne fizz has suddenly gone flat at a World Cup that was being hailed earlier as the best in recent memory.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With the viability of the Afghan government at stake, a new plan by the United Nations to ease the deepening presidential election crisis here appeared to falter nearly as quickly as it was proposed, posing a new obstacle to resolving the dispute just hours before Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here early Friday.

title: Natural Gas Pipeline Plan Creates Rift in Massachusetts
description: NORTHFIELD, Mass.  Standing on a dirt road outside his aging barn, Walter Jaworski, a former veterinarian turned cattle rancher in this rural part of north-central Massachusetts, points south across his 200 acres of forest and pasture to a nearby tree line. If things dont go his way, he says, thats about where a new natural gas pipeline will slice through his land on a 180-mile journey from central New York to a transmission hub north of Boston.

title: Homeland Security Secretary Testifies
description: Jeh Johnson, the Homeland Security secretary, spoke before the Senate Appropriations Committee on President Obamas emergency appropriations request to deal with the border crisis.

description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans pushed back Thursday at President Obamas request for nearly $4 billion to help stem the surge of young migrants from Central America to Texas and to deal with the humanitarian crisis there, signaling that they expected concessions for their legislative approval.

title: Google to Tour Europe to Discuss Privacy
description: LONDON  Google is about to start a grand tour of Europe.

description: REIMS, France  Seeing the Tour de France in person usually involves waiting around, sometimes for hours, to catch a glimpse of riders that often lasts for seconds. Now some people are going through all that trouble to turn their backs on the race.

title: Who Wants a Depression?
description: One unhappy lesson weve learned in recent years is that economics is a far more political subject than we liked to imagine. Well, duh, you may say. But, before the financial crisis, many economists  even, to some extent, yours truly  believed that there was a fairly broad professional consensus on some important issues.

title: Commitment in Texas to Fiscal Restraint Adds Burden for Education
description: Stacked up against other states, Texas public schools have consistently ranked among the bottom five nationally in per-student spending. And even with a growing population of economically disadvantaged and English-language learning students, some performance measures are on the upswing.

title: New Envoy for Syria Appointed
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Thursday that he had appointed Staffan de Mistura, a veteran diplomat of Italian-Swedish heritage who has led United Nations missions in Iraq and Afghanistan, to be the new special envoy responsible for seeking an end to the conflict in Syria. Mr. Ban said Mr. de Mistura, whose appointment had been expected by other diplomats, would be working to stop all violence and human rights violations, and promoting a peaceful solution to the Syrian crisis. Mr. de Misturas predecessor, Lakhdar Brahimi, resigned two months ago in frustration. He had replaced Kofi Annan, the former secretary general who called the Syria job mission impossible. Mr. Ban also said that he had appointed Ramzy Ezzeldin Ramzy, an Egyptian diplomat, as Mr. de Misturas deputy.

title: Bahrain: Opposition Under Fire
description: The government on Thursday charged two leaders of Bahrains largest opposition group with illegally meeting an American official, escalating a feud with the United States that began after the official, Tom Malinowski, was expelled from Bahrain this week. Mr. Malinowski, the assistant secretary of state for democracy, human rights and labor, was ordered to leave after Bahrains government, an ally of the United States, accused him of interfering in the countrys affairs by meeting with members of the opposition group, al-Wefaq. Khalil al-Marzooq, one of the leaders, said he and Sheikh Ali Salman, the groups secretary general, were questioned by prosecutors on Thursday about their talks with Mr. Malinowski.

title: Despite Silence From Anthony, Jackson Is Confident in Knicks Chances
description: LAS VEGAS  Phil Jackson emerged Thursday afternoon from the cocoon of silence known as the N.B.A.s free agency moratorium with an announcement: He had no news.

title: Early Returns on Health Care Reform
description: It will take a while to understand fully how the Affordable Care Act affects the quality of health care and access to doctors in this country. But a new survey offers encouraging reviews from people who signed up for private plans or Medicaid during the first enrollment period from October 2013 through March 2014.

title: Spree of Violence Ends With Murder Charges
description: The violent crimes piled up with a rapidity rarely seen in the bedroom communities of Staten Island: a gunpoint robbery ending in a killing; a second killing several miles away; and a carjacking of a Hummer sport utility vehicle nearby.

title: Lawsuit Contends Surveillance Database Is Too Lax on Reporting Criteria
description: WASHINGTON  Intent on not overlooking clues about any terrorist plots after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the government spread a now-familiar slogan: If you see something, say something. Less visibly, it built a national database to better harness reports of suspicious activity in the hunt for terrorists.

title: Once Again, Art in Russia Carries Moral and Political Overtones
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  The white nights are an enchanting time in Piter, when darkness never falls and a carnival atmosphere settles over the grand palaces, canals and broad Neva. Between the rock concerts, sailing regattas, river cruises and palatial museums bursting with brilliant exhibitions, a visitor longs to forget the struggle in Ukraine and all the jingoism and repressive politics that increasingly shape the image of Russia in the West.

title: Bahrains Bad Decision
description: Bahrain would seem an unlikely country to expel a senior American diplomat on a trumped-up complaint, since the Persian Gulf state is home to the United States Navys Fifth Fleet and depends on America for its defense, especially against Iran. Yet the government did just that, forcing Tom Malinowski, the State Departments assistant secretary for human rights, to cut short an official visit on Tuesday because he met with members of an opposition party. Then on Thursday, it compounded the error by charging the leader of Bahrains biggest opposition group with holding an illegal meeting with Mr. Malinowski.

title: Kerry to Join Talks on Iran as Deadline Draws Near
description: VIENNA  With the Vienna negotiations over Irans nuclear activities making halting progress at best and a deadline looming, the Obama administration announced Thursday that Secretary of State John Kerry would fly here this weekend to assess whether a deal is possible  and perhaps to begin negotiating an extension in the talks that both sides said they had wanted to avoid.

title: Cancer Survivors Apply Tenacious Spirit to Bay Cleanup
description: The waters of Flushing Bay, within view of La Guardia Airport, are some of the more polluted around New York City. The bay has poor circulation, and during heavy rainfalls sewers spew raw waste into the water from nearby homes and businesses.

title: Killing of Palestinian Youth Puts an Israeli Focus on Extremism
description: JERUSALEM  Even as the Israeli public offers strong support for airstrikes on Hamas fighters and their weapons stocks in Gaza, there is a good deal of reflection over the coldblooded killing of a Palestinian teenager that helped lead to the latest increase in violence.

description: Documents from J. Edgar Hoover, then the director of the F.B.I., and other top bureau officials show the speed and haste given to setting up the Jackson, Miss., field office in 1964.

description: Of all the headaches of her current book tour  the declining sales, the constant travel, the interviews that generated unkind headlines about her familys wealth  this one may sting Hillary Rodham Clinton the most: Her memoir, Hard Choices, has just been toppled from its spot on the best-seller list by a sensational Clinton account by her longtime antagonist Edward Klein.

title: Despite Earlier Loss, U.A.W. Creates Union at VW Plant
description: In an unorthodox move, the United Automobile Workers announced on Thursday that it was forming a union local in Chattanooga, Tenn., to represent workers at the Volkswagen plant there even though a majority of the plants workers voted in February against joining the union.

title: No Charges in Killing of Driver After Chase
description: A Secret Service officer and Capitol Police officer will not be charged in the shooting death of Miriam Carey, who last October led officers on a car chase from the White House to the Capitol before crashing, the United States attorneys office for the District of Columbia said Thursday. A statement said that federal prosecutors found insufficient evidence to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the officers used excessive force. Ms. Carey, 34, of Stamford, Conn., drove into a White House checkpoint and then hit a Secret Service officer. After a chase, two officers opened fire on her vehicle. Her child, who was also in the car, was uninjured.

title: Massachusetts: Decision on Health Site Expected
description: Officials will know by early August whether the state can move forward with its own retooled health exchange or join the federal marketplace. The states Health Connector sputtered last fall when it was updated to meet the requirements of the Affordable Care Act. In May, officials said they would simultaneously improve the states exchange with new software and prepare to join HealthCare.gov if they could not get the Connector working properly. The leadership at a Thursday board meeting of the Connector said that, after a successful demonstration of the new software, federal officials told them to continue the dual-track approach until early August, when a decision will be made.

The Mets had run off their longest winning streak of the season and their bats had come alive, against the rival Atlanta Braves no less.

title: These Fruits Were Made for Grilling
description: On the Fourth of July, before the meat and fish hit the grill, I decided to throw on some fruit. Ive always loved the way roasting summer stone fruit like peaches and apricots deepens their flavors, and I thought a sizzle on the grill might do the same. It did. Just a few minutes on each side  enough to create griddle marks on a peach or an apricot and soften it, but not so long that the fruit collapses, brought out the juices and warmed the fruit through. When I removed the peaches and apricots from the grill I tossed them with a little honey and lemon zest.

description: Ted Steeg, a documentarian whose best-known films have been seen by millions of cursing, carping, cranky, choleric and incontrovertibly captive audience members, died on July 7 in Manhattan. Mr. Steeg, who produced the informational movies long shown to prospective jurors throughout New York State, was 84.

description: In a letter dated July 1 and addressed to Edith Ramirez, the F.T.C. chairwoman, Andrew DeVore, associate general counsel of Amazon, criticized the agencys unwillingness to depart from the precedent it set with Apple.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Starz) FROZEN (2013) Warm up your vocal cords. This Disney 3-D animated movie musical produced Let It Go, the Oscar-winning power anthem, written by Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez, on seemingly every childs (and quite a few adults) lips since its release in November. Chris Buck and Jennifer Lee directed this fable about Elsa (the voice of Idina Menzel), an ice princess cursed with a frigid touch, and Anna (Kristen Bell), her younger sister and best friend. When Anna falls for a handsome prince (Santino Fontana), Elsa forbids them to marry, casting their Scandinavian kingdom into eternal winter with a wave of her hand. Horrified, she retreats to an ice palace atop a mountain, but sibling love sends Anna plowing through drifts and up glacial ridges in search of Elsa, confident that she can reverse the spell. Allegorically, Frozen lacks the purity and elemental power of a classic myth like Beauty and the Beast, but at least its storytelling is fairly coherent, and its gleaming dream world of snow and ice is one of the most visually captivating environments to be found in a Disney animated film, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this blockbuster, inspired by Hans Christian Andersens The Snow Queen. There are moments when you may feel that you are inside a giant crystal chandelier frosted with diamonds. Josh Gad plays Olaf, the snowman sidekick (above, with Anna and Kristoff, voiced by Jonathan Groff) who would rather be a beach bunny, in this Oscar winner for best animated feature.

description: BEIJING  Chinas central bank is investigating a report by state television that a major Chinese bank is helping clients transfer large amounts of money overseas in a program that violates currency controls, Xinhua, the state-run news agency, said Friday.

title: The Post-Post-Apocalyptic Detroit
description: In downtown Detroit, at the headquarters of the online-mortgage company Quicken Loans, there stands another downtown Detroit in miniature. The diorama, made of laser-cut acrylic and stretching out over 19 feet in length, is a riot of color and light: Every structure belonging to Quickens billionaire owner, Dan Gilbert, is topped in orange and illuminated from within, and Gilbert currently owns 60 of them, a lordly nine million square feet of real estate in all. He began picking up skyscrapers just three and a half years ago, one after another, paying as little as $8 a square foot. He bought five buildings surrounding Capitol Park, the seat of government when Michigan became a state in 1837. He snapped up the site of the old Hudsons department store, where 12,000 employees catered to 100,000 customers daily in the 1950s. Many of Gilberts purchases are 20th-century architectural treasures, built when Detroit served as a hub of world industry. He bought a Daniel Burnham, a few Albert Kahns, a Minoru Yamasaki masterwork with a soaring glass atrium. Theyre like old-school sports cars, said Dan Mullen, one of the executives who took over Quickens newly formed real estate arm. These were buildings with so much character, so much history. They dont exist anywhere else. And it was like, Buy this parking garage, and well throw in a skyscraper with it.

title: Soccer in Brazil, and Outside the Worlds Glare
description: Mauricio Lima has been in Brazil for the World Cup. Not exactly at the games, mind you, but going deep into the hearts  and jungles  where love of the game sustains and thrills (at least until the Brazilian teams loss this week to Germany). He has ventured to a floating village where children kick improvised soccer balls along narrow docks, to a prison where inmates make balls, to an amateur tournament where teams and beauty queens compete together and to indigenous villages that are an overnight boat ride away from the nearest World Cup match.

title: Morning Views
description: Bahrain would seem an unlikely country to expel a senior American diplomat on a trumped-up complaint, writes The New York Times Editorial Board. Yet the government did just that, forcing Tom Malinowski, the State Departments assistant secretary for human rights, to cut short an official visit on Tuesday because he met with members of an opposition party. The Board clarifies that the expulsion as well as a subsequent charge against the opposition group raise doubts about the willingness of the ruling al-Khalifa family, members of the Sunni minority, to find a compromise with the Shiite majority, which is demanding democratic reforms and a bigger role in governing. The Board calls Bahrains moves outrageous and, should Bahrain and the United States fail to resolve its differences, predicts disastrous consequences for Bahrain, its neighbors and the United States since the last thing the volatile region needs is more sectarian divisions and instability. So far, the Obama administration, which has worked to maintain ties with the monarchy despite human rights concerns, has responded weakly. It must go further to show that such behavior is unacceptable.

title: From Twitter, a Growing Collection of Communicative Conservationists
description: A Facebook post by the environmental journalist John Platt directed me to an excellent Twitter list of  at last count  89 conservation biologists, journalists, educators and other people focused on using new communication tools to foster wildlife conservation and animal welfare. The list was assembled by the editors of The Dodo, a website tracking biological wonders (the sea turned black by shoals of anchovies) and issues (the use of bullhooks on circus elephants) that arise when Homo sapiens interacts, for good or ill, with other animals.

title: Orange Is the New Black Recap: Go Ahead, Girls, Take a Break From Your Values
description: Season 2, Episode 11 Were pushing toward the apocalypse here  or at least, the season finale  so it feels appropriate that weve got a crusading nun leading the charge. After resisting the hunger strike, Sister Ingalls has finally reignited her passion for protest and become its most ardent participant. She would seem to lend gravitas to this fledgling movement, especially as the other new recruits cant decide on their demands. Soso and Yoga Jones want the black bathrooms fixed, restrictions on segregation, and an end to the compassionate release policy that dumped poor demented Jimmy on the street. Leanne and Angie want more dessert, field trips and visits from musical acts like Johnny Cash.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week Five | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In The Times this week: news about the crisis caused by the tens of thousands of unaccompanied minors who have crossed into the United States this year.

title: Dont Laugh: Berkeley Plans to Give Free Marijuana to the Poor
description: Earlier this month, Berkeleys City Council voted unanimously for an ordinance that would provide free medical marijuana to patients with low incomes. If the ordinance passes its second reading in August, marijuana dispensaries will have to set aside 2 percent of their product  which must be of equivalent quality to the marijuana theyre selling at market prices  and give it free to city residents with incomes below $32,000.

title: Morning Agenda: Global Stock Markets Shaken
description: GLOBAL STOCK MARKETS SHAKEN | The European markets have been exuberant for months, with investors eager to make bold bets on risky assets like Portuguese bonds, Spanish construction companies and Greek banks. But investors received a jolt on Thursday when shares of Portugals second-largest bank, Banco Esprito Santo, were suspended from trading, prompting fears that the bank might need to be rescued, Landon Thomas Jr. and Peter Eavis write in DealBook. The move sent highflying stocks and bonds in Portugal plummeting, forced two Spanish companies to suspend bond offerings and brought concerns over the health of Europes banking system.

title: Uber, Lyft and a Road Map for Reinventing the Ride
description: When the hail-by-smartphone car service Uber and its competitors make news, it is usually for something like the raucous protests against them by cabdrivers across Europe, or for bizarre incidents like the (now-former) Uber driver who reportedly took a passenger on a high-speed chase this week in Washington.

title: 1964: Dance Marathon in Paris
description: PARIS  The huge doors of firehouses throughout the city swung open this afternoon and thousands of Parisians invaded gaily decorated courtyards to start off the annual dance marathon coinciding with the anniversary of the fall of the Bastille. By tomorrow evening, scores of competing bals will have sprung up at most of the major intersections and squares, and seemingly nearly all of Paris will be kicking high in a polka or weaving in a conga line. With a frenzy matching the revolutionary fervor in the streets on July 14, 1789, many will pursue the dancing until dawn on Tuesday. The hardiest then will rest briefly before hustling over to the Champs-lyses for the annual military parade. Officially, July 14 has been celebrated as a national holiday only since 1880. The parliament then, it has been said, wanted to endow the Third Republic with a fte day comparable to those established under previous regimes. Although nearly a century had passed since the Revolution, strong but futile protests were delivered in parliament against the official glorification of a day associated with the parading of decapitated heads on spikes in the streets. Some of the rites marking that first official commemoration continue to be observed today. Others have been modified or have disappeared.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 13, 1964

title: Obamas Humanitarian Immigration Crisis
description: On July 8, President Obama requested $3.7 billion dollars from Congress to address the growing humanitarian crisis on the border between the United States and Mexico. Since October, more than 52,000 children traveling from Central America have already been apprehended and the U.S. government now faces the question of how to handle processing them. In the meantime, the children keep coming: Estimates of how many children will cross the border this year now surpass ninety thousand.

title: Anticipating a Showdown, Ukraine City Empties Out
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Train tickets are sold out in all directions. Shipping companies are booked weeks in advance. For rent and for sale signs are plastered on stores and apartments like political posters during campaign season.

description: MOSCOW  When he speaks about Ukraine at all these days, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia focuses on worthy subjects like humanitarian aid, distinctly turning down the flame underneath the political speech that erupted with the annexation of Crimea in March.

description: Dear Diary:

title: Vacation Experiences That Only Money Can Buy
description: JAMES BARBER yearned to travel to exotic places when he was a boy reading National Geographic. Now 71 and a successful business owner, he is able to indulge that love in far-flung destinations during trips created exclusively for him and his family.

title: More City Hall Change: A Mayor Taking a Break
description: New York is a city of workaholics, and its mayors are no exception. In three terms, Michael R. Bloomberg did not take a week off  ever. Rudolph W. Giuliani ignored weekends and spent holidays corralling officials on the phone.

title: Looking for a Housemate, Not a Mate, in Later Life
description: WHEN Marianne Kilkenny was in her mid-50s, she decided shed had enough of living and working in Silicon Valley but was not sure what to do next.

title: Rift With Kurds Widens as Iraqi Leader Replaces the Foreign Minister
description: BAGHDAD  The dangerous struggle between the leadership of Iraq and the countrys Kurdish minority intensified Friday as the Kurds seized two oil production facilities in Kirkuk Province and the prime minister appointed a temporary replacement for the foreign minister.

title: A Storied Ceramics Workshop Where Visiting Artists Can Get to Work
description: You wont find Umbertide, Italy, in most guidebooks. This town in northeast Umbria has little to recommend it: no churches with vibrant frescoes, no hilltop vistas, no Michelin-starred restaurants, not even a first-rate pizzeria.Umbertide is so ordinary, in fact, that The Companion Guide to Umbria, the 1969 classic armchair reader on the province, singles it out as the only second-tier town in the region that is not worth even a short visit.

title: Kerry Pushes for Solution to Afghanistan Election Crisis
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Obama administration had hoped that after years of frustration with President Hamid Karzai, a successful election in Afghanistan would finally produce a leader who could stabilize the country while working with the United States to allow an orderly withdrawal of American troops and end its longest war.

title: Imperial Tobaccos Ambitions Challenge Its Balance Sheet
description: Investors think Imperial Tobacco has much to gain from a possible $56 billion merger of its United States peers, Reynolds American and Lorillard. The combination would require a large sale of assets to assuage antitrust regulators, and these forced sales could present bargains for Imperial. The snag is that Imperial is short of cash  and the assets available may not be that attractive.

title: For Biggest Cities of 2030, Look Toward the Tropics
description: REALLY big cities used to be primarily in rich countries. But as the world has urbanized, that has changed.

title: Spice Boys To Men
description: Transgressive Yiddish; regional profiles.

title: The Future Sure Looks Better From the Past
description: On July 5, 2010, the 25th anniversary of the release of Back to the Future, Total Film magazine tweeted an exciting image to its 30,000 followers. The image showed the dashboard clock of Doc Browns famous time-traveling DeLorean, from the second Back to the Future film, in which Doc, Marty and Jennifer travel to the future  and the date displayed was July 5, 2010! Countless fans  along with everyone from The Guardian to the films producer, Frank Marshall  retweeted, favorited and emailed the DeLorean dashboard in euphoric celebration. The future had finally arrived.

title: 12 Food Orders and the People Who Delivered Them
description: For thousands of delivery people in New York, work is hectic, usually anonymous and often perilous when it involves bicycles. Young Jang, a photographer, orchestrated rare moments of sustained contact between customer and employee when she ordered food several times a day from her apartment and asked the deliverymen to pose for pictures. One of them, Muhammed Bella, works at Westside Brewhouse, where he waits on tables most days and pitches in as a deliveryman on Mondays. He says the customers are curt and rude much of the time. They treat you bad, says Bella, a native of Nigeria who lives in the Bronx. Not everybody. But when you try to deliver to them, some people are drunk. They act up. I say nothing. I just say, Thank you, have a good day, bye.  Julie Bosman

title: Accounting Principles
description: My spouse and I earn too much to contribute to a Roth I.R.A. Recently, we learned that it is legal to contribute to a traditional I.R.A. and then convert it into a Roth. My understanding of the Roth is that people who make over a certain income shouldnt benefit from its advantages. My spouse says that because it is legal to roll a traditional I.R.A. into a Roth, there is nothing unethical about doing so. Is this a case in which the law and the ethical standard conflict? S.R., TENNESSEE

description: The actor talks to Dave Itzkoff about taking a break from playing jerks and striking a delicate balance between work, family and watching hockey.

title: Who Made That Ice Pack?
description: Physicians have long made use of the medicinal powers of cooling. Hippocrates wrote that cold water is to be applied when there is a hemorrhage, or when it is expected. During the French Armys ghastly retreat from Moscow in 1812, Napoleons surgeon in chief, Dominique Jean Larrey, used ice and snow to numb soldiers before field amputations.

title: My Mothers Miracle-Water Cure
description: When my mother pulled up in front of our house in a flatbed truck, my stomach dropped. It was summer, and shed been away for two weeks. Her boyfriend was carrying a large plastic container. I knew there would be trouble. My younger brother, Dan, who was not quite a teenager yet and used a wheelchair to get around, rushed to the front door to lock it.

title: All My Friends Are White
description: My son is 6. Last week, I found him sitting on the floor, hugging his knees. Whats wrong? I said.

description: Luis Surez, who was suspended from all soccer activities for four months after biting an opposing player during the World Cup, will return from his ban with a new club: Barcelona.
