description: To mark World Population Day, the Population Institute has posted an informative set of two-sided informational graphics on encouraging and troubling demographic trends and issues: Population By the Numbers.

title: Stop Making Sense
description: Her blood sugar was dangerously low, and her words were incoherent.

title: 1939: Peace Raid Made Over France
description: LONDON  More than 120 of the finest heavy and medium bombers of the British Royal Air Force participated today [July 11] in the most impressive and significant sham air raid yet staged in air-conscious Europe. Taking off in succession this morning from their aerodrome in the English Midlands, the British planes pointed southward and spread their wings out over France. Never before had so many military planes of one country carried out an expedition of this character over the territory of another. The only information given the squadron commanders before they left the ground was that their destinations were somewhere in France. Sealed orders, when broken in the air, instructed the heavy bombers, totaling about eighty units, to make a round- trip, non-stop flight to Bordeaux, the French port on the Bay of Biscay, a two- way distance of nearly 1,200 miles. Similar orders provided a shorter flight for about forty medium bombers passing above the French cities of Le Treport, Orleans, and Le Mans, near Cherbourg. Their cruising radius is more restricted.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 12, 1939

title: Letters: Whose Argument?
description: Whose Argument?

title: In Connecticut, Breaking a Barrier Between a Suburb and Public Housing
description: NEW HAVEN  Dillard Bennett has lived for most of his life in the shadow of a 12-foot-tall chain-link fence that divides his public housing project from an adjacent suburb. He had to go the long way around to make a trip to a shopping center or to visit his pastors home.

title: A Rare Bond
description: Your dog may love you, but does your dog jump onto your shoulder every morning and nuzzle you as you shave? Your cat may purr with pleasure when you feed it, but does your cat try to coax tempting morsels into your mouth, to please you? Anyone who thinks the bond between man and dog or cat is the supreme human-house pet attachment will have to reconsider after reading Martin Windrows touching account of the bird who changed his life, a possessive and characterful tawny owl named Mumble who was his domestic companion for 15 action-packed years. In the wild, a tawny owl is lucky to reach the age of 5; Mumble, living with the author in South London and later in rural Sussex, enjoyed three times that life span.

title: A Supremely Cool Friend
description: Memoirs about cats and dogs are nearly as common as cats and dogs. Rarer animal companions have to wait longer for their literary turn, like Margaret Stangers That Quail, Robert (1966) or, more recently, Brian McGrorys Buddy: How a Rooster Made Me a Family Man and Matt Whymans Oink: My Life With Mini-Pigs.

title: Bookshelf: Great Outdoors
description: New picture books include John Burninghams Picnic.

title: Foodies
description: HARVEST  Field Notes From a Far-Flung Pursuit of Real Food  By Max Watman  Norton, $24.95.

title: Paperback Row
description: A HOUSE IN THE SKY: A Memoir,  by Amanda Lindhout and Sara Corbett. (Scribner, $16.) In August 2008, Lindhout  a 27-year-old Canadian traveler and fledgling television reporter  was kidnapped in Somalia along with a photojournalist named Nigel Brennan. This account of Lindhouts 460 days in captivity is more than a gonzo adventure tale gone awry; its a powerful coming-of-age story and a narrative of forgiveness and spiritual triumph.

title: Editors Choice
description: FOURTH OF JULY CREEK,  by Smith Henderson. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) In Hendersons deeply impressive novel, an overburdened social worker becomes involved with a near-feral boy and his survivalist father in 1980 Montana.

title: Teenagers Rule
description: Chris Weitzs The Young World tells of a Manhattan dominated by tribes of swaggering, self-possessed adolescents, some buzzed on attention-deficit medication, cruising through the city while adults cringe in the shadows, fearing for their lives. Oh, no, that was my teenage daughters diary of her life in eighth grade last year. (Sorry for the joke, darling; I would never read your journal, really.) But in Weitzs novel, those things do happen  save that the adults are all dead. Indeed, Weitz takes that familiar, real-world theme of precocious autonomy and carries it to its logical end: What if Manhattan was not just dominated by adolescents but actually ruled by them in a Hobbesian world of violence and savagery?

title: Health Official on Childs H.I.V. Return
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director, discussed the case of a child who was thought to have been cured of H.I.V. and is now showing signs of infection.

title: On the Move
description: As Americas postwar baby boomers grew up, dipped a toe or more in child psychology studies at college and started families of their own, childrens book publishers took note of a new, pop cultural sensitivity to a wide array of developmentally-based childhood trials and tribulations. Picture books about potty training, tantrum throwing, the death of a pet and other emotionally charged topics proliferated, and were often shelved together at the library under the catchall heading of bibliotherapy. Some authors explored these concerns more artfully than others. Judith Viorst (Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day) and the late Charlotte Zolotow (The Hating Book, Williams Doll) proved to be masters of the genre, their dry-eyed wit, empathic touch and storytelling prowess easily a match for their good intentions.

title: Avatar
description: Steve Brezenoffs third young adult novel, Guy in Real Life, begins when two teenagers literally collide one night in St. Paul, Minn. Lesh Tungsten, a metal-head with a heart of gold, steps in front of a bicycle ridden by Svetlana Allegheny, an artsy-craftsy dungeon master given to talking to herself in French, and the encounter leaves a deep impression on them both. Svetlana, because she is furious with Lesh for causing her sketchbook to fall into a puddle; Lesh, because Svetlana looks like an angel.

title: Romeo and Juliet in Crown Heights
description: Even before Devorah Blum meets the lanky West Indian nerd who will derail her plans to remain an unfailingly obedient Hasidic girl, there are signs shes wavering. Like No Other, Una LaMarches second young adult novel, begins as a hurricane bears down on New York City. Devorahs 18-year-old big sister, Rose, is about to give birth to her first baby prematurely. In the sweltering hospital waiting room, Devorah, dressed in a long wool skirt and tights for modestys sake, envies other girls sitting near by who are wearing shorts and tapping on cellphones, despite a sign forbidding their use. Devorah, 16, isnt allowed a phone, because her family is part of the strict Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic movement. She used to admire how Rose, who had a wild side, read fashion magazines on the sly. Now, she laments how her sister has grown meek in marriage. Devorahs own imminent future as a doting wife and teenage mother doesnt look so bright to her anymore.

title: Into the Deep
description: In October 1873, 12-year-old Tommy Picco knocked on the door of the Rev. Moses Harveys house in Newfoundland, holding something enormous and strange. While out fishing, Picco and his companions had been attacked by a devil-fish, or giant squid. Hed finally beaten back the monster by hacking off its tentacles. One of the tentacles was 19 feet long. Picco thought Harvey might like to buy it.

title: Out of Step
description: The ballet world is incestuous  insular and intensely intimate, full of young, beautiful people who work grueling hours and share in one anothers triumphs, setbacks and neuroses. No wonder, then, that dancers professional and social lives become inescapably entwined, and that fictional works revolving around ballet so often default to melodrama.

title: Adaptation
description: At the heart of Kathryn Mas haunting first novel, The Year She Left Us, is a young woman who loses her way. Ari is 18 and home from a summer in China, where she worked for a company that takes Western families with adopted Chinese girls on heritage tours. They visit the orphanages and, sometimes, the places where the abandoned babies were first found: police stations, department stores and random patches of dirt by the side of the road. For these orphans, their Finding Day may be the closest approximation to the simple commonplace most of us take for granted  a birthday.

title: The Indiscreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie
description: Published in English last year, The Dinner, by the Dutch writer Herman Koch, became an international best seller in part by occupying that slender intersection between literary and commercial fiction. Its prose has the direct, undemanding quality of an airport novel, its story the momentum of a page turner. Yet its more literary devices  an elegant structure, with each section titled by course, Aperitif, Appetizer and so on, as a single restaurant dinner progresses; a narrator who seems increasingly unreliable  suggest a greater complexity, an ambition to achieve Higher Things.

title: School for a Scoundrel
description: The name Seneca brings a particular image to mind: a gaunt, half-naked old man, glaring wildly, his veins open, his lifeblood seeping into the small bath beneath him after he was forced to commit suicide. Painted by Rubens, memorialized by Dante in his first circle of hell, gilded into medieval manuscripts alongside Plato and Aristotle, Seneca has come to represent the perils of proximity to absolute power. The central question of James Romms Dying Every Day is this: When we confront this tragic Roman wordsmith, tutor to the emperor Nero (and, some argue, the power behind that terrible throne), who stares back at us? Is it a tyrannodidaskalos, a tyrant-teacher? Is he the ultimate exemplar of Stoicism, a would-be philosopher king? Or is Seneca simply an accretion of history, a phantom constructed to fit our ravening for heroes, for antiheroes and for the sensational in the stories of antiquity?

title: Rage Runs Through It
description: Jim Stegner  the narrator of Peter Hellers second novel, The Painter  burns hot. When rage finds him, everything goes dark at the edges. Kind of tunnels down to the target. This temper drove him, years ago, to pull a .41 Magnum and shoot a known sex offender point blank.

title: Inside the List
description: The Fur Flies: Comedy is like sex, or subatomic particles: The more you try to analyze it, the more elusive it becomes. So its probably futile to look too closely at Joan Riverss latest book, Diary of a Mad Diva, new at No. 7 on the hardcover nonfiction list. But what the heck. As its title suggests, the book is structured as a conventional diary that happens to be filled with the authors brand of rapid-fire politically incorrect jokes  in the second entry, Rivers contrasts herself favorably with Anne Frank: Ive written six books, and Anne? She didnt even complete her one. Rivers is unavoidably outr  racist, sexist, raunchy, crass  which isnt to everybodys taste. (Another way comedy resembles sex, and maybe subatomic particles  Im no scientist  is that different folks like different strokes.) But readers seem divided as to whether Rivers is truly meanspirited or whether its all a provocation, a persona she slips into as easily as the fur coat shes wearing on her books cover. When the CNN anchor Fredricka Whitfield suggested as much in a recent interview, noting that Rivers is a well-known animal rights advocate and wondering whether the fur was there just for its shock value, Rivers went ballistic. Are you wearing leather shoes? Then shut up, she said, before storming off the set. I dont want to hear this nonsense. She didnt seem to be joking.

title: Asian Families Travel a Long Way for Summer Camp
description: After hours spent performing cartwheels, American show tunes and a series of jazzy dance routines in a cramped studio on West 28th Street in Manhattan, 8-year-old Futaba Kawakami left  TADA Youth Theater  camp earlier this week, clammy and slightly hoarse. She pulled off her new camp T-shirt, the one with the slogan Sing! Dance! Act! emblazoned on the back, and marshaled enough energy to ask her mother for ice cream. Then they headed off to 16 Handles in Chelsea.

title: Affordable Day Camps Help Working Parents Enjoy the Summer, Too
description: ITS July, prime time for swimming, hiking and slurping watermelon. But if both you and your spouse work and you have school-age children, you may have another perspective on summer: as the season when you must juggle your schedule and scrounge up affordable child care until school reopens.

title: All-Star Smashup in Cincinnati
description: On Tuesday evening, July 14, 1970, 51,838 fans jammed into the spanking-new poured-concrete paradise of Cincinnatis spare-tire-shaped Riverfront Stadium for Major League Baseballs 41st All-Star Game. While the spectators waited for the game to start, transistor radios blared out that weeks top hit, a version of Mama Told Me (Not to Come) by Three Dog Night.

title: Saving for Bucket List Thats Likely to Evolve in Years Before Retirement
description: When most of us imagine retirement, our minds wander to what well get to do then that we dont have enough time for now. If were lucky, we can push the uncertainty of our investment performance and future health out of our minds and picture all the fun well have. Thats what will make the decades of saving worthwhile, after all.

title: Why You Should Tip More Than You Do Now
description: For most of my life, Im ashamed to admit, I didnt leave a tip for the housekeeper in the hotels in which I stayed. My wife always did, but I somehow didnt pay attention. Only recently did I wake up to just how little these folks earn and how exhausting their jobs typically are.

Hosted by Olivier Saillard, chief curator, and French Vogue, and held in honor of both the museums new show  Les Annes 1950s  and its new acquisitions, made possible by a special 100,000-euro annual fund created by French Vogue this year, the evening was notable for three things:

title: In San Francisco, Artists Take Over Outdoor Advertising Spaces
description: In San Francisco, where tensions between established artist communities and Silicon Valley continue to rise, Luke Groesbeck, a former tech worker and the founder of the fledgling public art organization Art City, wants to help his hometown reinvest in the former.This is a city with a major arts and cultural legacy, he says. How do we honor that? Then an idea came up and I got fixated on it: What happens when you turn an entire city into a gallery? Is it possible?

title: A Brief History of Pro-Immigrant Conservatism
description: Warren Buffett and Bill Gates dont seem like such an unlikely pair. Both are extremely wealthy, both have made sizable contributions to the American economic and innovative spheres, and both are staunch progressives who have worked together on many initiative in the past, such as Mr. Gatess foundation, and Mr. Buffetts Giving Pledge. But, add the famously conservative casino-magnate Sheldon Adelson into the mix, and youve got an unlikely partnership, indeed.

title: Expectations vs. Reality at the World Cup
description: Everyone always expects the worst from big sporting events before they begin, and this World Cup was no different.

title: A Move to Extend Visiting Hours at Hospitals
description: I recently had to leave a hospital, where I was keeping a friend company after his cardiac procedure, when visiting hours ended at 8 p.m. I wasnt worried, because my friend was otherwise healthy, mobile and alert. He wasnt taking drugs that might have caused confusion or dizziness. And he was only 60, which in my world is practically adolescent.

title: Drug Makers AbbVie and Shire Officials Meet to Discuss Merger
description: Updated, 2:06 p.m. |

title: The Escape Artist': Thomas Beller Talks About J. D. Salinger
description: Thomas Bellers J. D. Salinger: The Escape Artist is partly a look at Salingers early life and career, and partly a memoir about the New York that Beller grew up in and sees reflected in his subjects work. In a recent email interview, Mr. Beller discussed Salingers reclusion, the development of his style, how The Catcher in the Rye holds up today and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Vintage Motorcycles in the Garden State
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Because Stuff Is Not Nonsense
description: There was a moment in the 1980s when many fashionable Manhattanites decorated their apartments like country houses, furnishing them with patchwork quilts, dried flowers and weathered pie safes. The look was second nature to Mary Randolph Carter, the Ralph Lauren executive who codified it in her 1988 design and entertaining book, American Family Style, which was photographed at her Upper East Side apartment as well as at Muskettoe Pointe Farm, her parents home in Virginia, and elsewhere.

title: Country Music History in Motion
description: The singer Marty Stuart has been documenting legendary figures in country music from an intimate, personal perspective on stage and on the road.

title: Buick Sheds Its Old Fogy Image and Lifts G.M.
description: As General Motors teetered on bankruptcy just a few years ago, its venerable Buick division seemed on the brink of extinction. The oldest active automobile brand in North America and a car once known as the moving couch for its plush interiors, Buick catered to a population of people over 65. Sales had fallen to just 102,000 vehicles in 2009.

title: The Words of the World Cup
description: Which team will win the World Cup on Sunday: the one thats perceived as powerful, focused and committed? Or, its rival, described mostly as confident and full of flair, but unconvincing?

title: C.D.C. Closes Anthrax and Flu Labs After Accidents
description: After potentially serious back-to-back laboratory accidents, federal health officials announced Friday that they had temporarily closed the flu and anthrax laboratories at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and halted shipments of all infectious agents from the agencys highest-security labs.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: smallpox, sedentary teenagers and binge drinking. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Gwen Stefani Returns to the Runway, Ellen DeGeneress Lifestyle Line and Kendall Jenners Couture Debut
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Twitter Reacts to LeBron Jamess Return to Cleveland
description: Compared to The Decision four years ago, LeBron James quietly dropped his latest franchise shift into the social media sea Friday. As his story hit the Internet via an essay he co-wrote for Sports Illustrated, he posted this unremarkable link to it on Twitter:

title: My Brooklyn, Then and Now
description: The floor-to-ceiling windows provided a panoramic view of Manhattan. But I was more interested in the foreground, below me  Brooklyn.

title: Lawrence of Sardinia
description: I dont care for islands, D. H. Lawrence once wrote, an attitude I happen to share, though my wife doesnt, which is how we found ourselves in Sardinia last spring.

title: 36 Hours in Graz, Austria
description: Ask most travelers about Austrian cities beyond Vienna, and youll probably hear suggestions to go to Salzburg or Innsbruck. Austrians, however, might tell you that Graz  their countrys second-largest city, with a population of just over 300,000  is a better choice for many tourists, thanks to its rich design, art and culinary scenes, and wine and produce from the surrounding south Austrian state of Styria. Built around the Schlossberg, an ancient hilltop castle, Styrias regional capital is home to scores of boutiques, shops, restaurants and museums, many housed in restored Baroque-era buildings in the citys well-preserved Old Town. You might not expect to find such a cultivated metropolis two hours down the road from Vienna toward Ljubljana, but Graz has a palpable joie de vivre, thanks in part to the presence of its six universities and over 40,000 students.

title: Restaurant Report: Peumayen in Santiago, Chile
description: A quick visit to Santiago may leave the impression that typical Chilean food is limited to steak sandwiches and completos, the ever-present hot dogs smeared with avocado. In an effort to change that, the restaurant Peumayen attempts to reawaken the ancestral cuisine of some of the countrys native peoples: the Mapuche, Aymar and Rapa Nui.

title: Hotel Review: Waldorf Astoria Panama in Panama City
description: Rates

title: Summer School for Anchovies
description: This week, scientists at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif., noticed an enormous school of anchovies gathering near the coast. Pressed into a huge swarm, an estimated one billion of the tiny fish are taking cues from their neighbors, carefully coordinating their every move.

title: The German 71 Cocktail
description: Few people are more worthy of a toast this week than members of the German national soccer team. They defied the modest expectations of their fans and produced one of the most incredible displays in World Cup history by thrashing Brazil  the favorite and host  7-1. So in honor of the Nationalmannschaft, as theyre known, we bring you this weeks Upshot cocktail: the German 71.

title: Seeing Johannesburg Through Artists Eyes
description: In the Ferreirasdorp section of Johannesburg, I passed a group of young men who had set up an informal carwash business with buckets of soapy water arranged by a curb, and as I turned a corner, there was Nelson Mandela.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: The Blooper Reel: Cleveland Fans Arent Used to Such Good News
description: Johnny Football. The Republican Convention. Now the second coming of the disgraced hometown hero LeBron James. Could  gasp  things finally be working in Clevelands favor?

title: Teenagers in The Times | June 2014
description: This slide show taken from Richard Linklaters Leading Boy features images from the new film Boyhood, which details the journey from childhood to adolescence of one Mason Jr., played by Ellar Coltrane.

title: Digital Humanists to Catalog Notes Scrawled in Books
description: The Wall Street Journal recently made a tongue-in-cheek attempt to determine the most unread book of the summer using Amazons Popular Highlights feature, which tracks the passages in any given book that have been most frequently highlighted by Kindle users, taken as an indirect measure of which books were barely read past the introduction. (Heres looking at you, Thomas Piketty.)

title: Garth Brooks Planning First New Studio Album Since 2001
description: The country music superstar Garth Brooks released his last album of new studio material, Scarecrow, in November 2001, roughly a year after he announced that he intended to retire from performing and recording to spend time with his family. Since then he has made occasional appearances on the concert stage and on television, and since 2009 he has been inching toward a full comeback.

title: A Damaging Distance
description: DAYS after Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was gunned down in 1995 by an Israeli Jew who opposed compromise with the Palestinians, Shimon Peres, the acting prime minister, held a news conference. He was asked why more had not been done to protect Mr. Rabin from people like his assassin, Yigal Amir. Mr. Peres replied that it had never occurred to the authorities that a Jew could do such a thing.

title: Carmelo Anthony Keeps the Knicks Waiting on His Decision
description: LAS VEGAS  Phil Jackson, clad in a red plaid shirt, watched the Knicks summer league team take on the Dallas Mavericks on Friday afternoon from a spot in the bleachers at Cox Pavilion. With General Manager Steve Mills sitting to his right and members of the front office assembled around him, Jackson looked at ease. He hardly fiddled with his phone.

title: A Dance Battle Begins
description: A crew prepares itself for a dance battle at the Salaam Kivu International Film Festival in Goma.

title: Robert Wilsons Video Portraits of Lady Gaga to Have First American Showing
description: Although Robert Wilson is best known for his experimental theater works, including several genre-redefining opera collaborations with Philip Glass (most famously, Einstein on the Beach), he has created an expansive series of visual art works. Among them is a series of what Mr. Wilson calls Video Portraits of artists and performers including Mikhail Baryshnikov, Winona Ryder, Brad Pitt and Isabella Rossellini. He uses high-definition video as the canvas, and costumes, lighting, makeup, gesture and narrative to put his subjects in perspective, usually with references to other art works.

title: The Directors of Land Ho! On Their Icelandic Adventure
description: Land Ho!, Martha Stephens and Aaron Katzs sweet and often hilarious road film about a pair of older men who travel to Iceland to reclaim their youth, began as something far less ambitious. I wanted to go on a vacation to Iceland, says Stephens, whose first two films, Passenger Pigeons and Pilgrim Song, were well-received indie outings. As she researched her trip, however, Stephens saw the opportunity to use the countrys breathtaking landscapes for a more creative purpose. She enlisted Katz, the director of the mumblecore favorites Dance Party USA and Quiet City, whom she knew from the University of North Carolina School of the Arts, to help write the script and co-direct, and the pair cast Stephenss second cousin, Earl Lynn Nelson, an oculoplastic surgeon, and the indie actor Paul Eenhoorn (This Is Martin Bonner), as the films jocular leads, Mitch and Colin.

title: As Reynolds Looks Ahead, a Familiar Leader, Susan Cameron, Guides the Way
description: When the tobacco company Reynolds American confirmed on Friday that it was in discussions with Lorillard about a multibillion-dollar merger, the news hardly came as a surprise.

title: Best of the World Cup, From The Upshot
description: The World Cup has proved to be a hit not only around the world  as usual  but also in the United States. Television ratings are up, and online discussion has flourished. Here at The Upshot, we too have had a great time watching and analyzing the tournament. Below is a collection of our greatest hits from the last month, many of which can shed light on the final two matches in the tournament.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: All About the Terraces
description: A one-of-a-kind duplex penthouse, one of just four residences carved in 2005 from the 1913 Amory S. Carhart Mansion at 3 East 95th Street and an elegant, newer adjoining limestone structure that replaced a former school at No. 5, is poised to enter the market at $34 million.

title: The Rings, the Cake, the Rice ... the Insurance?
description: Picture a rustic wedding in a verdant California park, the nervous couple about to walk the aisle. Now, picture a firefighter rushing in and telling everyone to immediately evacuate because of a wildfire.

title: Unity in a Strange Land
description: Philip Montgomery calls his photographs of New York Citys various Islamic communities an unfinished project, one driven by changing perspectives and questions. He began in 2009 as a new arrival from California and fresh from photographing Sufi Muslims in Kashmir. In an unfamiliar city, Mr. Montgomery, now 26, said he felt a yearning to work my way back to the kind of connected communities I saw in Kashmir.

title: Real Data on Illegal Gun Sales
description: A recent survey of gun dealers on illegal transactions yields new information on how criminals obtain guns.

title: Chronicling the Monumental
description: Five years ago in Mannahatta, Eric W. Sanderson imaginatively envisioned the natural landscape that Henry Hudson would have witnessed when he sailed into New York Harbor. Now Ted Steinberg, a Brooklyn-born history professor at Case Western Reserve University, engagingly explores what happened to that natural environment in the four centuries since in Gotham Unbound: The Ecological History of Greater New York (Simon & Schuster).

title: Arts Sanctuary in a War-Torn City
description: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo  When Petna Ndaliko was a boy, he would head downtown to watch kung fu movies at the Cine Virunga here.On Saturdayand Sundayevenings, his parents would take him to the theater. When he got older, Mr. Ndaliko became an actor himself, performing for the first time in a show at the auditorium next to this citys Roman Catholic cathedral.

title: Big Ticket | Rupert Murdochs Trophy Pad, Expanded
description: The glassy 57th-floor getaway that doubles as the bottom level of the media mogul Rupert Murdochs four-tier vertical compound at the pinnacle of One Madison, the slender 60-story tower on the southeast side of Madison Square Park, sold for $14.927 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: In Gaza, Airstrikes and Economic Stress Make for an Anxious Ramadan
description: GAZA CITY  War during Ramadan has a particular tension. It is not just the normal anxiety of airstrikes in a crowded city, no matter how carefully Israel tries to target them. But the holy month of Ramadan falls this year in a particularly hot and humid Gaza July, and observant Muslims are fasting, not even drinking water, until sunset and iftar, the evening meal.

title: Matt Long: Trading Surf for Turf
description: The professional sand sculptor Matt Long spends most of the summer carving castles along the Jersey Shore and Coney Island, but he saves spaghetti omelets, guitar playing and gardening for Sunday. The 59-year-old has been featured on the Travel Channels Sand Masters, is the founder of the online shop Can You Dig It Sand Tools, competes in international sand sculpturing events, and has been hired by companies to erect elaborate designs, most recently a plane in Wildwood Crest, N.J., to promote the new Disney movie Planes: Fire and Rescue. Unless someone requests the Taj Mahal or something, I just make sand castles up as I go, he said. Mr. Long lives in West Brighton, Staten Island, with his wife, Nina, 59, and his daughters, Katrina, 34; Madeline, 26; and Emily, 21.

title: How Good Are Cavaliers Now? And Four Other Questions
description: LeBron Jamess decision to return to Cleveland makes the Cavaliers an instant contender and a favorite to win the N.B.A. title, according to manyoddsmakers, even though James himself acknowledged that it will take time to build a winner. The decision also raised many questions, which may not be answered any time soon.

title: Dead in the Water: A Long Island Ferry
description: It is now clear that before the end of the month, should various labor disputes fail to resolve themselves, workers for the Long Island Rail Road will go on strike, an outcome that would jeopardize the commute of 300,000 working people each weekday. But it is not the fate of this population that ought to concern us, not during the peak of summer, when the genuinely endangered are the 26-year-olds with juice bottles full of vodka who depend on the train to get them to the Jennifer Convertibles sofas at their weekend quarter-shares in Westhampton. Millennials, it would seem, have already endured enough.

title: As Senate Spotlight Is Given to Vulnerable Democrats, G.O.P. Finds a Dimmer
description: WASHINGTON  Very little is happening in the Senate these days, but what passes for action has a lot to do with re-electing Democrats  or blocking their re-election.

title: A Ride Across America | Campfire Cooking in the Rockies
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, theyll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: A Prophetic Dream Come True
description: Broadway actress Patina Miller and David Mars were married on June 14, at the Foundry in Long Island City, N.Y.

title: The 2015 GMC Yukon SLT and Yukon XL Denali
description: GMCs big boys get a slightly new look for 2015. Above, the new GMC Yukon XL Denali.

title: Driven | 2015 Chevrolet Suburban LTZ
description: An 80-year-old still does the chores in a big way.

title: Room for the Family. Bodyguards, Too.
description: They line up a dozen deep behind the Capitol in Washington, mostly black General Motors S.U.V.s  Chevrolet Tahoes and Suburbans or their GMC equivalents  waiting to shuttle important people to important places. Or to lunch at Chipotle.

title: A Fig Tree Dies in Brooklyn, and in Other Boroughs
description: By late spring, Nelson Ryland knew that something was wrong. Normally, the fig trees in his backyard in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, would be plush with verdant leaves and sending up sprays of new branches. This year, though, while the Bronx seedless grape vine, the hydrangea bushes and the black-eyed Susans in his garden flourished, his eight fig trees stood stark and lifeless.

title: Uber's Travis Kalanick Explains His Pricing Experiment
description: Of the several entrepreneurs who are trying to shake up urban transportation, Travis Kalanick of the smartphone-summoned car service Uber has made some of the boldest moves. In my article about the strategic battle between Uber and its rivals, Mr. Kalanick explains that he sees the 20 to 25 percent sharp price cuts announced this week for its UberX service as a way to increase ridership. Here is more from the conversation, lightly edited for length and clarity.

title: London Theater Journal: The Despot Behind a Desk
description: LONDON  The hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death, as Richard III is described by one of his many detractors, has been thoroughly domesticated. As portrayed by Martin Freeman at Trafalgar Studios here, the most fearsome psychopath in Shakespeare seems dangerous only in the manner of a persistent insurance salesman who might sell you a policy you dont really need.

title: On Stage and in His Life, the Leading Player
description: When Patina Miller performed Magic to Do in the opening number of Pippin, she wore a top hat and swung from a trapeze, over a stage full of contortionists, tumblers, dancers and acrobats.

title: Photographers of the Inadvertent
description: Although the tunneling for the Second Avenue subway is going on far below the street, on the surface whole blocks are in chaos, strewn with barriers, fences, ventilators and huge elevated construction sheds. It was just as much an obstacle course in the early 20th century, when our first subways were built, as we can see from hundreds of thousands of photographs, now divided like a broken Greek vase among various institutions, at least two dealers, several collectors and, on occasion, sale tables at flea markets.

title: Citroens Adjustable Suspension
description: Citrons suspensions use a hydropneumatic system instead of steel springs. The result is a smooth ride with excellent road-holding. The system also provides adjustable ride height and self-leveling.

title: Shoe Prints, Dripping Blood and Groping
description: John Walsh cant seem to stop trying to catch criminals, and who can blame him? But his latest series, The Hunt With John Walsh, is a schlocky disappointment.

title: Doubts on Fasting Before Cholesterol Tests
description: The National Institutes of Health and other groups recommend fasting for nine to 12 hours before taking a blood lipid test, but a large new study provides further evidence that fasting is probably unnecessary.

title: Measuring Ramadan
description: WE are in the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. During this time, as prescribed by one of the five pillars, or obligations, that make up the foundation of Muslim life, hundreds of millions of followers are abstaining from eating and drinking (and a host of other activities, like smoking and sex) between dawn and sunset.

title: Silver Lake to Pay $29.5 Million to Settle Suit on Collusion
description: The private equity firm Silver Lake has agreed to pay $29.5 million to settle accusations that it colluded with its rivals to drive down the prices of corporate takeovers before the financial crisis, according to a court filing on Thursday.

title: With Merger, Tobacco Takes On Technology
description: Disruptive technology can spur takeovers as companies, fearing for their business, race to bulk up and acquire innovators.

title: Work Out, Then the Wok
description: Perhaps you have seen him, the Zen master of Zen Palate, doing his daily exercise routine in the middle of Midtown Manhattans morning rush.

title: Man Charged in Staten Island Crime Spree Pleads Not Guilty
description: A man accused in a crime spree that included two unrelated murders only 15 minutes apart was ordered held without bail on Friday after he entered a plea of not guilty in State Supreme Court on Staten Island.

title: Examining a Fathers Role in a Toddlers Death
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  On a Friday morning in March 2012, Leanna Harris entered a medical office here and underwent an ultrasound to get a glimpse of the baby she and her husband would name Cooper. The grainy, black-and-white footage was uploaded three days later to the YouTube account belonging to her husband, Justin Ross Harris, with a gleeful caption: First video known as Cooper!

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Weekend Reading: Have You Even Tried the Potato Salad in Sun Valley?
description: Zack Danger Brown can raise more than $43,000 on Kickstarter to pay for his potato salad. Surely there is someone at the Sun Valley conference who can make use of his talents. Or technology and media titans could make use of these delicious potato salad recipes from The New York Times. DealBook recommends Sam Siftons grilled fingerling-potato salad with chipotle bacon vinaigrette. Mmm, bacon.

title: Summer Car Safety: Look Before You Lock, and More
description: The terrible accusations against Justin Ross Harris, the father accused of intentionally leaving his 22-month-old son, Cooper, to die in a hot car because he wished to be free of the burdens of parenting, make it easy to mentally file Coopers tragic death under the category things that will never happen to my family. People in Tuscaloosa, Ala., Mr. Harriss deeply conservative hometown, are having a hard time believing what happened, as Richard Faussett and Alan Blinder write in The New York Times, even as prosecutors and the Georgia police and prosecutors have provided details of the actions of of Mr. Harris and his wife on June 18, the day the boy died.

title: The Body of Salem, Its Nerves Frayed
description: LONDON  The Puritan torturers who try to break the spirit of John Proctor, the honor-bound hero of Arthur Millers The Crucible, have nothing on the devastating revival of that play that recently opened at the Old Vic. As directed by Yael Farber, this three-and-a-half-hour production applies unrelieved pressure to your nerves  and, it would seem, muscles that include the heart  until youre a submissive puddle of pity and terror.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: What gives with C.E.O./founders recently? Some have been behaving badly, facing allegations of sexual harassment or making inappropriate comments. Its even led to a few getting fired. But when they lose their jobsif we needed another reminder that C.E.O.s arent like the rest of usthey fight to get them back. Case in point: Dov Charney, the founder of American Apparel.

title: The Children of the Drug Wars
description: CRISTIAN OMAR REYES, an 11-year-old sixth grader in the neighborhood of Nueva Suyapa, on the outskirts of Tegucigalpa, tells me he has to get out of Honduras soon  no matter what.

title: This Tour de France Never Leaves New York
description: On Sunday, French expatriates, Francophiles and fans of old French cars and motorized bicycles will gather to celebrate Bastille Day  a day early  with a rally through the streets of Manhattan.

title: Citrons Last American Gasp: French, Futuristic and Desired by Few
description: One Thursday last fall, Brian Brandt got a phone call from The Americans, the FX Networks period drama about Cold War-era Soviet spies living in a Washington suburb. An anxious member of the production staff explained that the show, filmed in a Brooklyn studio and at locations around Long Island, needed a car repaired  and back on the set the following Tuesday.

title: The 1973 Citron SM
description: Brian Brandt of New York City fell in love with Citrons as a teenager and now owns three of the cars. He drives his 1973 SM about 6,000 miles a year.

title: Wheelies: The Classic Gas Prices Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: An Argentine and a German, but No Sign at the Vatican of a World Cup Rivalry
description: ROME  They have prayed together and embraced each other as brothers, but Pope Francis and his predecessor, Benedict XVI, now pope emeritus, find themselves confronting an odd sort of schism: their two countries are competing in the finals of the World Cup on Sunday.

title: The 1911 Mercer Type 35R Raceabout
description: A racing legend made in New Jersey heads to auction.

title: In Their Ardor and Sweep, Hints of an Emerging Gold Standard
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  To watch New York City Ballet at its open-air summer home at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center on Thursday afternoon was to be made forcefully aware not just how well the company is currently dancing but with what exuberance. Next week, when Moscows legendary Bolshoi Ballet opens at the David H. Koch Theater in Manhattan  and two weeks later, when it arrives here  it will be judged by two standards: memories and films of its own past achievements, and the highest standards of todays foremost American companies.

title: Jersey-Born, Racetrack-Bred and Headed to the Monterey Auctions
description: BLENHEIM, Ontario  Wind-in-the-face fun: Thats what it is like to ride in the passengers seat of a bright yellow 1911 Mercer Raceabout driven swiftly down a road here in the Canadian countryside an hour east of Detroit. At the wheel, Don McLellan, an owner and manager of the restoration arm of RM Auctions, is all smiles as he steers and shift gears, thoroughly enjoying the response of the light but powerful car.

title: Fixes for Pistons and Driveshafts
description: BMWs needing new driveshafts and Honda CR-Vs with balky windows are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: A Summer Trip Quashed, but Not the Whining
description: Ive just had to cancel a vacation I was looking forward to for months, and this has left a gaping hole in my world: the need to find the right people to complain to about it.

title: Cool Noodle Dishes That Defy the Season
description: When the weather is sweltering, pasta served at cool room temperature can be wonderful. Im not talking about last nights congealed lasagna straight from the fridge, although I wont discount any food choice on a really hot day.

title: Week in Pictures for July 11
description: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes the funeral of a fallen firefighter, the Obelisk in Central Park and Fourth of July celebrations.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Theyre Dropping Like Middle Initials
description: In 1991, I was preparing to publish my first book, about a year I spent teaching junior high school in Japan. Stephen Birmingham, the author of Our Crowd and an acquaintance of my parents, offered to give me a blurb but recommended one change: that I drop the middle initial from my name on the cover. As a 26-year-old, baby-faced writer, I was eager to appear older and more sophisticated, so I ignored him.

title: Like a Beach Bro, Nestled in a Mellow Reggae Groove
description: Are there five more worrisome words in the world than You guys like reggae music?

title: Bill Cunningham | Tricolor
description: Dressed for the Fourth of July.

title: After the Titillation, a Series Gets Sexy
description: Its not about sex.

title: Bill Cunningham | Tricolor
description: Visitors to the city celebrated the Fourth of July weekend wearing red, white and blue T-shirts at Rockefeller Center, with its 200 flags; at Battery Park, for their trip to the Statue of Liberty; and in Times Square. Sapphire blue is a summer hit, as seen in the mosaic aquarium in the 57th Street windows of Bergdorf Goodman, recycled from holiday windows.

title: A Long, Quiet Tour Stage Ends in a Tight Finish
description: NANCY, France  The crashes that have marked most of the first week of the Tour de France continued as the peloton rode through World War I battlefields on Friday.

title: Laughter Amid Melancholy
description: Joe DiPietros Clever Little Lies is scheduled to run at Guild Hall from July 16 to Aug. 3 with the same cast and director as its world premiere at George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., last year. Information: guildhall.org or (631) 324-4050. Following are excerpts from Ken Jaworowskis review that was published online in The New York Times on Dec. 5, 2013; the full text is here.

title: Fleeting Artworks, Melting Like Sugar
description: One of the most substantial works of art to hit New York in years was with us for only two months. This week, the final vestiges of Kara Walkers A Subtlety, or the Marvelous Sugar Baby were removed from the old sugar shed of the Domino factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which will make way for apartments.

title: Russian Farewells, Quartet by Quartet
description: LENOX, Mass.  Far from shirking challenges, the Emerson String Quartet has, in its 37 seasons, tended to seek them out. It is not enough, for example, merely to scatter the six Bartok quartets (which the group recorded for Deutsche Grammophon, winning a Grammy Award in 1990) among mixed programs; the Emerson has repeatedly performed all six works in a single long evening.

title: A Forgiving Spirit, Despite Those Sharp Red Nails
description: Charles Busch, the playwright and sometime drag performer, has the gift of comic gab like few other entertainers. Innately funny, endearing and acutely intelligent, he also has claws. For an audience, the possibility of being scratched, although remote, lends his humor a bracing edge.

title: A Voice in Her Head Comes Into Her Home
description: CHICAGO  Sandra Oh, who spent 10 seasons playing a good doctor on televisions Greys Anatomy, is now portraying a woman confronting a potentially very bad one in the Victory Gardens Theater production of Ariel Dorfmans Death and the Maiden here. Ral Castillo, of the HBO young-gays-in-San-Francisco series Looking, stars alongside Ms. Oh as her husband, with the veteran Chicago actor John Judd playing the third role of the nefarious (or is he?) doctor.

title: Eni Chief Angers Unions With Plan to Close Refineries
description: LONDON  The new chief executive of Eni, the Italian energy giant, has put himself on a collision course with workers and possibly the Italian government with a plan to close much of the companys unprofitable refinery network in Italy.

title: A Multibillion-Dollar Question for Airbus and Its A330
description: TOULOUSE, France  Inside a 185-acre assembly hall in this quiet corner of southwestern France, a dozen of Airbuss best-selling wide-body jets stand in various stages of construction.

title: Digitizing the Family History
description: Q. What is the easiest way to convert an old typed manuscript of our family history into an electronic format so everyone in the family can get it by email?

title: The World Awaits the F-35, the Latest in Flying Firepower
description: The business battle between Boeing and Airbus traditionally dominates the Farnborough International Airshow. But this weeklong event, which starts on Monday in Hampshire, England, is also a showcase for some of the worlds most sophisticated flying weaponry, which perform dazzling displays in the hope of luring prospective government clients.

title: Undead Plane Passengers in a Medical Whodunit
description: The Centers for Disease Control dont always get a good rap. In The Walking Dead they were an empty shell that almost got the cast killed before self-destructing in a fireball. So in the new FX series The Strain, beginning on Sunday, its nice to see the agency getting some respect. You could make a drinking game out of the times its mentioned in tones usually reserved for superheroes or counterintelligence outfits. This crime scene is now under C.D.C. authority! the hero declares, and no one on screen laughs.

title: They Pay a High Price Amid the Cash Registers
description: Imagine that youve died and gone to hell, and damnation turns out to be a job at Walmart with a psychotic boss and a No Exit directive from corporate headquarters.

title: The Hudson Project Begins
description: Campers began arriving at the Hudson Project, a three-day music festival in Saugerties, N.Y., on Thursday night, bringing their face paint, sequins and fluorescent bikinis.

title: Fertility Clinics Scan for the Strongest Embryo
description: Annika Levitt initially resisted the fertility clinics suggestion that only one embryo  rather than the usual two or more  be transferred to her uterus because she was too small to risk carrying more than one baby.

title: Impressions of Brooklyn
description: A selection of images, from moments to meals.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: At Sun Valley, Deal Speculation if No Deal Talks

title: With Older Parents, Stepping Gingerly Through Lifes Daily Minefield

It means we cleared the paths adequately that day.

Ive always been disturbed by the way religion is so often used to incite people towards divisive behavior, she said of the interactive show, which is scheduled to run through July 27. It prompted me to think of ways to motivate individuals to re-examine their personal value judgments.

By the time you get to your table, youre more than ready to sink into one of the padded armchairs and order a drink.

title: Turkey: Prime Minister Looks Ahead
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Friday outlined his vision for his presidential campaign, promising to expand rights and liberties, improve welfare programs and build up Turkeys economy. On Aug. 10, for the first time, Turkeys president will be chosen directly by the voters, rather than by Parliament. The presidency has been largely a ceremonial post, but if Mr. Erdogan wins, as is widely expected, he is likely to try to expand the powers of the office. Mr. Erdogan has been the most powerful figure in Turkish politics for a decade. His opponents fear that if he is elected president, he will face no checks on the autocratic tendencies he has displayed in recent months while confronting challenges from street protests and a corruption inquiry. Speaking to more than two thousand supporters in Istanbul on Friday, Mr. Erdogan offered few details but vowed to expand democracy in Turkey if elected and to expand its role in international affairs.

title: South Sudan: Refugee Crisis Worsens
description: The United Nations refugee agency said Friday that the number of South Sudanese fleeing for neighboring nations is expected to reach as many as 715,000 by years end, more than double the number envisioned when the agency began a funding appeal four months ago for refugees from South Sudan, which has been ravaged by a civil war and is on the verge of famine. The ongoing conflict and worsening humanitarian situation inside the worlds youngest nation is fueling a refugee exodus into Ethiopia, Kenya, Sudan and Uganda at a much higher rate than initially anticipated, an agency spokeswoman, Melissa Fleming, said in a statement on the crisis in South Sudan. The agency revised its funding appeal to $658 million from the original $371 million and warned that without urgent contributions, the consequences could be drastic. In another barometer of the worsening crisis, the charity Save the Children warned that a cholera outbreak that first appeared two months ago had spread, infecting more than 2,600 people and killing more than 60. Pete Walsh, Save the Childrens director in South Sudan, said in a statement that the countrys overstretched health service was plagued by widespread shortages of lifesaving supplies, as desperate parents are coming to clinics with children who are already considerably weakened by the disease.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) GRAVITY (2013) A medical engineer (Sandra Bullock, above) and an astronaut (George Clooney) become stranded high above Earth when debris from a satellite destroys their space shuttle in this intense spectacle, directed by Alfonso Cuarn. You have to see it to believe it, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Nothing in the movie  not hand tools or chess pieces, human bodies or cruise-ship-size space stations  rests within a stable vertical or horizontal plane. Neither does the movie itself, which in a little more than 90 minutes rewrites the rules of cinema as we have known them. The film was nominated for 10 Oscars and won seven, including best director and best cinematography.
