title: 1914: Brady Climbs The Mnch in Just Ten Hours
description: LITTLE SCHEIDEGG, Switzerland  The ascent of the Mnch made on Saturday by Mr. J. H. Brady, of Baltimore, was accomplished in face of the most unfavorable conditions, and the route chosen on the northern side of the peak was one of the most difficult. The progress of Mr. Brady and the two Grindelwald guides, Christian and Peter Kaufmann, who accompanied him, could be observed nearly all the time through glasses from the Seiler Hotel, at Little Scheidegg. The party took ten hours to reach the summit. The ascent of the Mnch peak, although its altitude is not quite as great as that of the Jungfrau, is one of the most difficult climbs in the Bernese Oberland. From Little Scheidegg, at the foot of the Eiger  which with the Mnch and the Jungfrau forms the Interlaken group of peaks, of which the Mnch is the central one  the journey requires at least thirteen hours, with a stop for rest and sleep at the Guggi Hut, where climbers for the Mnch and the Jungfrau part company. The Mnch was first scaled by Dr. Porges, of Vienna, in 1857. Its altitude is 13,465 feet, and the climb from the Guggi requires between nine and ten hours. It cannot be undertaken by anyone but a most experienced climber, as the difficulties to be overcome are innumerable.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 14, 1914

title: Certain Mobile Apps Covet New Real Estate: The Lock Screen
description: App makers have long vied for prime real estate on smartphones, coveting in particular a spot on the home screen, the front page where many people place their most frequently used apps.

title: The Emotional Whiplash of Parenting a Teenager
description: Being a teenager is hard  being the parent of a teenager may be even harder. Any parent of an adolescent knows the pain of being rejected, neglected, or artfully critiqued by their teenager. But being pushed away is only the half of it. Raising teenagers becomes that much more stressful and confounding when teenagers interrupt weeks of frostiness with moments of intense warmth and intimacy.

title: Palestinians Flee Northern Gaza as a Cease-Fire Appears Elusive
description: GAZA CITY  Several thousand Palestinians, defying the urging of Hamas to remain in their homes, fled areas in northern Gaza early Sunday after Israel warned them through fliers and phone calls of major attacks to come.

title: From Benghazi to the Boardroom: The Road to the $7 Billion Citigroup Settlement
description: Updated, 8:23 p.m. | The stage was set for another public shaming of a Wall Street bank.

title: Stretching Yoga Into a Social-Justice Pose
description: Should yoga be taxed? Washington, D.C., has decided that it should  and the question of whether that policy should expand is part of a larger debate about yoga, its customers and its labor force.

title: Jersey City Officer Is Fatally Shot While Responding to Robbery Report
description: JERSEY CITY  When he was a teenager, Melvin Santiago was held up at gunpoint by a robber outside a gas station on the citys west side. The experience made him want to become a police officer so that he could help make the neighborhood safer for his younger brother and the cousins he would go bowling with every other weekend.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: The Thierry Henry Show
description: HARRISON, N.J.  According to the conventional wisdom, what is missing from the Red Bulls roster is the proverbial No. 10, soccers on-field quarterback who leads the attack and is a towering figure in the midfield.

title: 1939: England Bans Revengeful Wills
description: LONDON  One of the foundations of English law  that a person of sound mind may will his property to whom he likes  was set aside today [July 13] by the inheritance family provision act which came into operation in the British Isles. The act provides for nullification by court order of revengeful wills in which husbands or wives cut off their widow or widowers and children with a contemptuous shilling or nothing at all, leaving them destitute while the money goes to charity, to persons outside the family or to some freakish cause. Testators are given self-defense, however, in a clause permitting them to append a side statement to their wills setting forth the reason for ignoring the dependants. The courts will take such a statement into consideration when dealing with a contested will. Those who may benefit under the act are limited to a widow or widower, unmarried daughters of any age, sons under twenty-one and sons or daughters who cannot earn their living because of mental or physical incapacity. If any such persons contest a will, a court will decide whether reasonable provision has been made. If not, the court may tear up the will and redistribute the assets of an estate.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 14, 1939

title: Bookstore Owner Takes On a Union, Shocking a Liberal Bastion
description: He hung photographs of Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr. above the cash registers, and filled the nooks and crannies with scholarly books. He threw open his doors to local authors, provided a home for the Queer Book Club and created a weekly story time program for children (in English, Spanish and Mandarin).

title: New Planet of the Apes Rules the Weekend Box Office
description: Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, the latest entry in the simian-power film series from 20th Century Fox, took in an estimated $73 million at the domestic box office, as Hollywood shook off its dreary performance over the Fourth of July holiday and fierce competition from a World Cup final match on Sunday. The film topped the weekend box office, placing ahead of Paramounts Transformers: Age of Extinction, which ranked second, with $16.5 million in sales, and about $209 million since its release on June 27. Dawn of the Planet of the Apes handily beat the performance of its predecessor, Rise of the Planet of the Apes, which took in $54.8 million on its first weekend in August 2011 and went on to sell $176.7 million in tickets at the domestic box office.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 10:30 P.M. (Ovation) SERENITY (2005) A small crew aboard a spaceship led by Capt. Malcolm Reynolds (Nathan Fillion) tries to scrape together a living smuggling cargo from one fringe of the universe to the next in this film written and directed by Joss Whedon. But the crew members off-the-radar existence is threatened when an agent (Chiwetel Ejiofor) of an oppressive government tracks them down, intent on killing a teenager aboard the ship (Summer Glau, above). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis compared this science-fiction adventure with the Star Wars movies by George Lucas. Scene for scene, Serenity is more engaging and certainly better written and acted than any of Mr. Lucass recent screen entertainments, she wrote. Mr. Whedon isnt aiming to conquer the pop-culture universe with a branded mythology; he just wants us to hitch a ride to a galaxy far, far away and have a good time.

title: Americans and Iranians See Constraints at Home in Nuclear Negotiations
description: VIENNA  Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here early Sunday in an attempt to rescue negotiations with Iran that have stalled on the question of how large a nuclear infrastructure that nation will be permitted to have over the next decade or two. But he quickly confronted the fact that the problem might be less at the negotiating table here than with mullahs in Tehran and members of Congress in Washington.

title: Deadlock Blocks Iraqi Leadership Vote as ISIS Makes Gains Toward Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  As Iraqs deadlocked Parliament was again unable to reach a deal to name a new speaker on Sunday, Sunni militants carried out a raid near Baghdad, a symbolically significant attack signaling their intent to move closer, even if only by a few miles, toward the Iraqi capital.

title: Lorin Maazel, an Intense and Enigmatic Conductor, Dies at 84
description: Lorin Maazel, a former child prodigy who went on to become the music director of the New York Philharmonic, the Cleveland Orchestra, the Vienna State Opera and several other ensembles and companies around the world, and who was known for his incisive and sometimes extreme interpretations, died on Sunday at his home in Castleton, Va. He was 84.

title: Germany vs. Argentina: World Cup 2014 Final Live Blog
description: Germany and Argentina meet in a showdown for the World Cup title.

title: Ukrainian Forces Close In on Rebel-Held Luhansk
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Ukrainian forces battered the outer suburbs of the rebel stronghold of Luhansk on Sunday, pushing deeper than ever but falling short of retaking the city.

title: Nepal Retracts Permission for Tibet Monks Cremation
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Under scrutiny from China, Nepals government announced on Sunday that it had retracted its permission to allow the cremation of a prominent spiritual figure in Tibetan Buddhism to be held on its territory.

title: Statement by Player Erases the Last Doubt
description: LAS VEGAS  Nothing about the process happened swiftly or easily. Even an expected announcement that Carmelo Anthony was re-signing with the Knicks took more than a day to be publicly delivered. But after months of uncertainty about whether Anthony would return to New York, what were a few more hours of waiting?

title: Paul Pierce, Leaving Nets, Is Said to Reach Deal With Wizards
description: The Nets shocked the basketball world at the 2013 N.B.A. draft by snapping up Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce of the Boston Celtics in a trade.

title: The Hudson Project: Kendrick Lamar, Griz, !!!, Z. Z. Ward
description: I had expected a big influx of weekend festival-goers on Saturday, the second day of the Hudson Project, but I didnt see one. It was still a relatively cozy event, with sightlines for everyone at outdoor stages and room inside the tents for all who wanted to be there. On Saturday, only one tent set had a big spillover outside, probably by choice; it was hotter and muddier inside. That was the set by Griz  a whomping, quick-changing barrage of hip-hop, funk, reggae and ska, including shamelessly crowd-pleasing oldies like Shout! and Wild Cherrys Play That Funky Music.

title: Holder Voices Extreme Concern About Terrorist Bomb Makers
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. expressed extreme, extreme concern on Sunday over reports that bomb makers from Yemen responsible for the 2009 underwear-bomb plot are now in Syria cooperating with foreign militants there, possibly to develop new, nearly undetectable explosive devices.

title: The World Cup Is Nearly Over  but Not the Spirit of Soccer
description: Coming off its sound defeat of Brazil in a World Cup semifinal, the German national soccer team will face off against Argentina this afternoon in the final match of the tournament.

title: Its Not the Economy, Stupid
description: One thing about the Obamacare denialists: they dont give up. First nobody but the sick would sign up, so wed have a death spiral. Then it was OK, a lot of people have signed up, but they wont pay  and anyway, even more people have lost coverage. Now they face evidence like this:

title: French Rider Gains the Yellow Jersey on the Eve of Bastille Day
description: MULHOUSE, France  In time for Bastille Day, Tony Gallopin, a French rider, took the Tour de France lead on Sunday.

title: Neil Young Cancels a Concert in Israel
description: Neil Young has canceled a concert scheduled for Tel Aviv this week because of hostilities between Israel and Hamas. The concert, with Mr. Youngs band Crazy Horse, was scheduled for Thursday at Hayarkon Park in Tel Aviv.

title: Peak Performances to Offer 14 Premieres
description: The Peak Performance series is celebrating its 10th anniversary  and that of the opening of its home, the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University, in Montclair, N.J.  with a season that includes 14 music, dance and theater premieres.

title: A Woman at the Center, Drifting to the Fringe
description: Price of Fame completes Sylvia Jukes Morriss two-volume character study of Clare Boothe Luce, one of the 20th centurys most ambitious, unstoppable and undeniably ingenious characters. The whole project weighs in at a mere 1,296 pages, so it does not even set the Morris house record. This author is married to Edmund Morris, whose splendid, three-volume Theodore Roosevelt totaled almost twice that page count.

title: A Life on the Podium
description: Lorin Maazel, a former child prodigy who went on to hold the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic and several other ensembles around the world, was 84.

title: Mechanical and Sensual, Still Baring Shoulders Decades Later
description: The Lincoln Center Festivals retrospective of four early works by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker offers the opportunity, rare in contemporary dance, to track the development of a major artist piece by piece. And development is not synonymous with improvement.

title: Mrs. Terrible, Before She Met Her Czar Ivan
description: Making a rare appearance in New York, the Bolshoi Opera and Ballet have arrived from Moscow for, in effect, a jam-packed two-week residency courtesy of the Lincoln Center Festival. Opera fans might feel shortchanged: Starting Tuesday, the company is presenting elaborate productions of three ballets: Swan Lake, Don Quixote and Spartacus. But the only operatic offering? A pair of concert performances of Rimsky-Korsakovs The Tsars Bride.

title: Hall of Famers at the Summer North American Championships
description: The American Contract Bridge Leagues Summer North American Championships begin on Thursday in Las Vegas. The Hall of Fame ceremonies and dinner take place late that afternoon.

title: Walken as Captain Hook in NBCs Peter Pan
description: Christopher Walken, below, will grab the hammy role of Captain Hook in NBCs new live version of Peter Pan, the networks follow-up to its hugely successful live musical for this past holiday season, The Sound of Music. Robert Greenblatt, NBCs top entertainment executive, announced the casting of Mr. Walken on Sunday in Los Angeles at an annual gathering of television critics. Mr. Greenblatt cited Mr. Walkens early experience as a song-and-dance man as well as his numerous well-received appearances as a guest host of Saturday Night Live. NBC plans to mount the production, Peter Pan Live!, in December. The network still needs to find a Peter. Mr. Greenblatt had no announcement on that front, although he did confirm that the network had pursued Kristen Bell (Frozen), but could not work out a schedule for her because of her commitment to the Showtime series House of Lies. Mr. Greenblatt did say that NBC would stick to the tradition of hiring a female star for Peter, after originally thinking that a man might be considered for the part.

title: Germans End Long Wait: 24 Years and a Bit Extra
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  For years, Brazilians had a phrase they would inevitably utter when things went wrong. Imagina na Copa, they said after an endless traffic jam or a construction accident or an ugly rash of violence dominated the news  imagine if this happened during the World Cup. It became a foreboding warning, a pre-emptive sigh at the presumed disasters that lay ahead.

title: A Political Comedy for Off Broadway
description: Mario Correas political comedy Tail! Spin! is to open Off Broadway at the Lynn Redgrave Theater just as this falls midterm elections are heating up, the shows producers announced on Sunday. The play was warmly received at the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. Dan Knechtges will return as director, and Rachel Dratch (Saturday Night Live) will reprise her roles as Wives, Tails, Beards & Barbara Walters. Other roles are expected to be cast this month, Billy Zavelson, one of the shows producers, said by phone. Tail! Spin! uses texts, emails, tweets and remarks from four politicians disgraced by sex scandals: Anthony Weiner, Mark Foley, Larry Craig and Mark Sanford. It has been updated to include material from Mr. Weiners unsuccessful run for mayor of New York and Mr. Sanfords election to Congress, Mr. Zavelson said. And if another scandal of this ilk happens, well add that to the show, too, he said. Tail! Spin! is to begin previews on Sept. 18 and will open on Oct. 1.

title: The House That Romeo Built
description: You know the routines by now: Romeo Santos has been doing this for too long. There will be a woman of ample proportions, and Mr. Santos will sing Un Beso to her, then kiss her, then encourage her to let her hands roam free on his body. There will be admonishments to the men in the audience about how they arent satisfying their women. There will be a microphone stand, parts of the stage and even the air itself that spend long stretches of time on the receiving end of Mr. Santoss gyrating pelvis.

title: A Game as Literary Tutorial
description: When he was an immigrant boy growing up in New Jersey, the writer Junot Daz said he felt marginalized. But that feeling was dispelled somewhat in 1981 when he was in sixth grade. He and his buddies, adventuring pals with roots in distant realms  Egypt, Ireland, Cuba and the Dominican Republic  became totally sucked in, he said, by a completely radical concept: role-playing, in the form of Dungeons & Dragons.

title: Battle for the 2014 World Cup Trophy
description: Germany, just off a stunning victory against Brazil, faced off with Argentina, whose star player Lionel Messi faced the biggest test of his international career. Germany won in extra time.

title: Mets Surge Into the All-Star Break on a Wave of Confidence
description: The Mets celebrated the last win of their best homestand in four years by shaking hands and patting one another on the back. They had just won their eighth of 10 games against Texas, Atlanta and Miami, a 9-1 victory over the Marlins on Sunday at Citi Field.

title: An Original Tough Career Woman
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  The most famous aria of Donizettis Lucrezia Borgia is the title characters last. In Era desso il figlio mio, the power-hungry femme fatale of the title laments the loss of her son, whom she has unwittingly poisoned, in an explosion of vocal fireworks. Its also an aria that Donizetti cut when he revised the opera in 1840, seven years after its Milan premiere, in an attempt to focus the drama more sharply.

title: An Incoming Conductor Brings a Sunny Outlook
description: LENOX, Mass.  The weather here at Tanglewood, the beautiful summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, often seems to reflect the mood of the institution. How frequent were those terrifying thunderstorms and winds during and after the last years of James Levines tenure as music director, rife with illnesses and cancellations?

title: A Bride Finds Her Gown, and a Groom
description: The official English title of the Bollywood confection Humpty Sharma Ki Dulhania is Humpty Sharmas Bride. Yet, at the start, Kavya (Alia Bhatt), the heroine, is weeks away from an arranged marriage to someone else. Insisting that if she cant choose her groom, she should at least wear a designer gown, Kavya travels to New Delhi to earn money and buy one.

title: Using Speech and Instruments, but Mostly Singing Feet
description: As the American Tap Dance Foundation wisely realizes, feet get hot in the summer. But at Tap City, its friendly weeklong festival that wrapped up on Saturday, little makes them bleed. (The vibe here is more summer camp.) On Thursday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Symphony Space, the gaiety continued with Tap and Song, an eclectic program, directed by Tony Waag, intent on highlighting the breadth of the art form  from vaudeville and comedy to contemporary styles  by showing how tap dance is a form of music.

title: Q. and A.: Cathy Giangrande on Chinas Museum Boom
description: Whether celebrating fine art or ancient artifacts, salt or signboards, China increasingly has a museum for most tastes  and a few that can be found nowhere else, such as one devoted to whistling kites. As money has piled up in recent decades, Chinese are turning to culture and the country is in a museum-building boom.

title: Eerie Encounter
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  We last saw MaryEllen Uthlaut back in 2010, when she made her debut in The New York Times crossword puzzle and she returns today to remind us that everything is not always as it seems when we look up into the night sky.

title: Zine Makers Grab Their MetroCards and Go to Work
description: One woman drew cartoons in an artists notebook. Another snipped off pieces from a subway map, then pasted them onto a white paper. Yellow fliers that read Service Changes along with Zine Residency! were taped to subway car walls. And a black banner with the words Zinesters in Residence hung from a railing.

title: Poor Sanitation in India May Afflict Well-Fed Children With Malnutrition
description: SHEOHAR DISTRICT, India  He wore thick black eyeliner to ward off the evil eye, but Vivek, a tiny 1-year-old living in a village of mud huts and diminutive people, had nonetheless fallen victim to Indias great scourge of malnutrition.

title: The Hudson Project: A Storm Stops the Music
description: With a torrential thunderstorm moving on Sunday afternoon, the Hudson Project music festival in Saugerties, N.Y., was shut down and the site evacuated. Organizers hoped to resume the event if they could fit more music in before another band of storms.

title: Boeing Optimistic That Export-Import Bank Will Get Funding
description: LONDON  The head of Boeings commercial aircraft division said on Sunday that he was optimistic that the United States Congress would ultimately agree to reauthorize funding to the Export-Import Bank, which guarantees billions of dollars in loans to foreign buyers of its airplanes.

title: Spies Like Us
description: HAMBURG, Germany  Is it because they know us so little  or because they know us too well  that the Americans cant stop spying on us Germans?

title: Editorial Cartoon
description: Uncle Sam has a rat problem.

title: Even on Nantucket, a Funeral Home Is a Luxury
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.  The hole at the cemetery was dug. The flowers had arrived, family and friends had gathered, food was ready for the reception. All that was missing was the deceased. Doris Davis could not make her own funeral.

title: Discrimination Is Un-Christian, Too
description: Much to the chagrin of womens rights advocates, Hobby Lobby has won its legal battle  but claims of victory for religious freedom must be emended. Make no mistake: This is no victory for the freedom to exercise Christian principles. Though employers like Hobby Lobby are now free to deny women access to contraceptives through their employer-subsidized health plans on the basis of religious objection, they will be violating their own purported Christian principles if they do. While Christians are not compelled by their faith to engage in religious practices that impose upon the freedoms of others, they are compelled  by their belief that all persons, men and women, are created in the image of God  to oppose discrimination.

title: In a First Since the 1990s, a Large Bulgarian Bank Goes Bankrupt
description: After a tumultuous month for the Bulgarian financial sector during which thousands of fearful depositors lined up to pull their savings out of two banks, the countrys central bank has said it will start bankruptcy proceedings against one of the lenders.

title: No One Is Rooting for Him Harder Out There
description: ABERDEEN, Scotland  The golfer and the caddie were on a bucket-list course thousands of miles from home, two friends bonding over their shared affinity for the game and for competition.

title: Samsung Considers Its Counterattack as Rivals Erode Cellphone Profit
description: What goes up must come down. That principle seems to be coming true for Samsung Electronics, the worlds top cellphone maker, whose profit is falling in part because of pressure from its price-cutting rivals in China.

title: Lindt Nears a Deal to Buy Russell Stover Candies
description: The Swiss maker of Lindt chocolate is closing in on a deal to acquire Russell Stover Candies, the storied American boxed-chocolate maker, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Caddie Who Mastered the Game
description: Near the end of the film The Greatest Game Ever Played, the story of the 20-year-old amateur Francis Ouimets upset of the celebrated British golfers Harry Vardon and Ted Ray in the 1913 United States Open, Vardon, played by the actor Stephen Dillane, congratulates Ouimet in the locker room.

title: Rivalry Begins for Sisters With Ambition
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  Shortly after she was selected in April as the No. 1 overall pick in the W.N.B.A. draft by the Connecticut Sun, Chiney Ogwumike moved into her own apartment. During her first visit, Ify Ogwumike, Chineys mother, presented her second-oldest daughter with a housewarming gift that carried a not-so-subtle message, a study guide for the Graduate Record Examination.

title: Can a Jury Believe What It Sees?
description: LOS ANGELES  LAST week the F.B.I., the Drug Enforcement Administration and other federal law enforcement agencies instituted a policy of recording interrogations of criminal suspects held in custody. Only a minority of states and local governments have a similar requirement, but the new rule, which applies to nearly every federal interrogation, will most likely spur more jurisdictions to follow suit. Its not far-fetched to think that such recordings may soon become standard police practice nationwide.

title: Whiting Petroleum to Buy Kodiak Oil & Gas
description: Whiting Petroleum Corporation on Sunday said it would buy Kodiak Oil & Gas Corporation for $3.8 billion in stock, and assume $2.2 billion of Kodiaks debt.

title: The View From the Handlebars Makes Its Debut
description: NANCY, France  Television production of the Tour de France is a technological and logistical marvel involving fleets of motorcycles, helicopters and airplanes. But it lacks one element that has long been a part of motorsports broadcasting: onboard live cameras.

title: Marijuana Is at Center of Feud in Capital
description: WASHINGTON  A law to make marijuana possession in the District of Columbia punishable by only a $25 ticket, one of the laxest drug laws in the nation, has ignited a feud between Washingtons mayor and a Republican House member days before it is to take effect.

title: The Skeleton Garden of Paris
description: I am at the Jardin des Plantes, in the Fifth Arrondissement on the Left Bank of the Seine. Here we find one of the worlds oldest zoos, still officially called a menagerie, various greenhouses and rows of brilliant dahlias book-ended by statues of Jean-Baptiste Lamarck and Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon. We also find the various galleries composing the National Museum of Natural History. These include, not least, the Gallery of Paleontology and Comparative Anatomy, a two-floor exhibition hall built in preparation for the 1900 World Fair, where the skeletons and preserved tissues of thousands of animal species are on display: the massive jaws of sperm whales, cross-sections of elephant molars like great petrified mille-feuilles, countless miniature bat skulls under tiny glass domes.

title: After a Mejia Save, Improvisation Beats Premeditation
description: Jenrry Mejia of the Mets was one strike away from ending the game, and the fans at Citi Field were on their feet. Mejia composed himself, unleashed a nasty slider and broke into an elaborate celebration. He slapped his glove twice, lifted his arms and his right knee, then slammed them down. It looked like a dance inspired by Ray Lewis.

title: Tech Scene in Myanmar Hinges on Cellphone Grid
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Images of Steven P. Jobs and Mark Zuckerberg adorn the walls of Myo Myint Kyaws creative digital agency. He says they inspire him. But he imagines neither man ever worked in an environment where Internet connections were so unreliable that a file transfer often involved delivering electronic documents across town by taxi.

title: Prospects Show Promise in Their Pop
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Chiseled into a limestone wall on the Legends Club level of Target Field is the number 573, several feet high, representing the career home run total of the Hall of Famer Harmon Killebrew.

title: For a Weekend, Ukraine Rebels Make Love, Not War
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  It was a weekend of love in this city of war.

title: Obamacare Fails to Fail
description: How many Americans know how health reform is going? For that matter, how many people in the news media are following the positive developments?

title: The Buck Stops With Me
description: In trying to lay the blame for the border crisis on the White Houses doorstep, House Speaker John Boehner exploded at a press conference on Thursday, saying of the president:

title: With Return of Anthony, Knicks Quietly Edge Ahead
description: Ah, Carmelo, you coquette, its good to have you back.

title: Companies That Offer Help With Student Loans Are Often Predatory, Officials Say
description: Student loan debt hovers at more than $1 trillion, a threefold surge from a decade ago, and a record number of college students who graduated as the financial system nearly imploded have an average debt load of more than $20,000.

Vaccines May Be Costly, but They Save Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Doctors Run Late
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Gambling on Casinos in New York
description: The timing is worthy of note. As trucks in Albany were unloading reams of documents describing 17 proposals for four new casinos in New York, Moodys Investors Service was issuing its latest report on gambling  downgrading the national gambling business from stable to negative. In other words, just when New York is proposing to ramp up its gambling business, the financial community is souring on the idea that casinos are an easy answer to state and local financial problems.

title: Dirty Tricks, Tea Party Suicide and Rising Mississippi Anger
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Mark Mayfield, one of the founders of the Mississippi Tea Party, had lost his political appetite.

title: Poison Shot From Guns
description: Sometimes the gross ineffectiveness of Congress is a boon to the nation by heading off a plainly regressive result. This was the case last week when a partisan Senate dispute over election-year gun politics had the unintended effect of killing off a pernicious proposal to bar environmental controls over lead ammunition and fishing sinkers that increasingly threaten fish and wildlife. The poisonous effects of ingesting lead fragments have been documented in numerous studies  the latest counting more than 120 species of birds in North America suffering from the thousands of tons of lead scattered annually by sportsmen.

title: Success for Brazil, Just Not on the Field
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  When Mario Gtze settled a crossing pass with his chest and volleyed a goal that won the World Cup, German fans roared in ecstatic release. Those from Brazil were nearly as delirious, even if it was out of relief as much as celebration.

title: How Race Skews Prosecutions
description: In the legal stratosphere where Supreme Court justices sit, racism may appear to be largely a thing of the past. But down on the ground, where citizens and law enforcement encounter each other daily, race still matters. That is the key finding of an extensive report issued last week on the prosecutorial practices of the Manhattan district attorneys office, one of the biggest and busiest in the country.

title: As Strike Threat Looms, Stalled L.I.R.R. Talks Carry Hint of the Past
description: As the Long Island Rail Road lurches toward a possible strike that could shut it down as soon as Sunday, the long-running dispute between the railroad and its unions carries echoes of the last time workers walked out. But in the final week before the strike deadline, the gap between the two sides is actually much smaller this time around.

title: Kansas Ruinous Tax Cuts
description: There was a windstorm of hasty excuses in recent weeks after Kansas reported that it took in $338 million less than expected in the 2014 fiscal year and would have to dip heavily into a reserve fund. Spending wasnt cut enough, said conservatives. Too many rich people sold off stock in the previous year, state officials said. Its the price of creating jobs, said Gov. Sam Brownback.

title: In a Latino Enclave, the World Cup Puts Everything on Pause
description: Something unusual happened on Sunday afternoon on the streets of Jackson Heights, Queens: Quiet.

title: Brazilians Go Back to Real Life
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazil suffered mightily with its national teams 7-1 rout at the hands of Germany in the World Cup semifinals last week, but the authorities here breathed sighs of relief as the tournament came to a close on Sunday with Germanys victory over Argentina, amid muted street protests and a display of Brazils ability to successfully organize sporting megaevents.

title: Jerusalems Damaged Link
description: A light rail line connecting Arab and Jewish neighborhoods in Jerusalem was damaged during riots. Some Arab residents would rather not see the line re-opened.

title: After Lapses, C.D.C. Admits a Lax Culture at Labs
description: ATLANTA  Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, spent much of Wednesday completing a report that would let the public see, in embarrassing detail, how the sloppy handling of anthrax by scientists at its headquarters here had potentially exposed dozens of employees to the deadly bacteria.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 13, 2014
Germany Outlasts Argentina for the World Cup
description: Both Germany and Argentina had solid chances throughout the game, but Germany finally scored in the 113th minute, lifting the country to its fourth World Cup title.

title: Grief and Evacuation in Gaza

title: A Coveted Candle Line Branches Out into Personal Perfumes
description: The tastefully designed, subtly scented candles of Maison Louis Marie continue to draw distinguished noses to the doorsteps of fashionable outposts like Fred Segal in Los Angeles and Assembly in New York, and all the Steven Alan stores across the country in between. And today, the Belgian behind the brand, Marie du Petit Thouars, introduces her first collection of personal fragrance oils, four of which borrow the delicate bouquet of some of her most coveted candles, and one of which is being introduced for the first time. Each scent from my collection represents a person, place or memory of my family and childhood that is created through blends of notes that utilize vast arrays of the botanical world, she says. Another of her dearest childhood memories inspired her to create the oils, four of which are unisex, in the first place. I remember when I was a child, I went on a fishing trip in the Mauritius Islands with a master perfumer from the Guerlain family, she says. He had created a perfume inspired by a woman with whom he had fallen in love with and wanted to reveal her sensuality through a perfume. I was absolutely charmed by this  what a beautiful gift to be able to give someone.

title: Le Grand Aioli: a Culinary Ode to Bastille Day

The pungent emulsion referred to as the butter of Provence is predictably the hero of the meal; however, it is arguably its accompaniments that make it truly grand. Served in bowls or the heavy mortars in which it is made, the aioli becomes a centerpiece flanked by an array of whatever is best from the market that day. Languid, unstructured and designed for sharing, at its best le grand aioli is a celebration of summers bounty andesprit.

title: Morning Views
description: Kansas took in $338 million less in taxes than it expected in the 2014 fiscal year, reports The New York Times editorial board. Spending wasnt cut enough, said conservatives. Too many rich people sold off stock in the previous year, state officials said. Its the price of creating jobs, said Gov. Sam Brownback. However, The Times says that the reason was the spectacularly ill-advised income tax cuts that Mr. Brownback and his fellow Republicans engineered in 2012 and 2013. The cuts, which largely benefited the wealthy, cost the state 8 percent of the revenue it needs for schools and other government services. Kansas under Mr. Brownback has shown states cannot cut their way to prosperity. They need to use every tool of government to nurture growth, and those tools require money.

title: At Dinner Tables, a Restless Obama Finds an Intellectual Escape
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama had just disembarked from Air Force One and was still on the tarmac in Rome when he turned to his host, John R. Phillips, the American ambassador to Italy, with an unexpected request: How about a dinner party tomorrow night?

title: Bram Cohens Straights and Flushes
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Bram Cohen, creator of the BitTorrent file-sharing protocol and the companys chief scientist as well as a co-founder. After the puzzle well hear from Mr. Cohen about his approach to innovation, including his inspiration for this weeks challenge.

title: After the World Cup, Glory and Heartache
description: Soccer fans in Berlin and Buenos Aires during the final match of the World Cup.

title: Another Favorite Crashes Out of Tour
description: LA PLANCHE DES BELLES FILLES SKI STATION, France  With seven climbs, many so steep that they made walking a chore, Mondays stage of the Tour de France to a modest ski resort was expected to be difficult. But the 10th stage may also prove key to the final result, as the favorite Alberto Contador crashed and quit after breaking his leg and Vincenzo Nibali regained the leaders jersey with a thrilling attack.

title: Looking Back at Nadine Gordimers Life and Work
description: Accepting the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1991, Nadine Gordimer, the South African writer who died on Sunday at 90, said: I am what I suppose would be called a natural writer. I did not make any decision to become one. I did not, at the beginning, expect to earn a living by being read. I wrote as a child out of the joy of apprehending life through my senses  the look and scent and feel of things; and soon out of the emotions that puzzled me or raged within me and which took form, found some enlightenment, solace and delight, shaped in the written word.

title: Some Democrats Steer Clear of Obama. Others Denounce Him.
description: When an unpopular president faces a difficult midterm election, candidates from his party tend to avoid him and try to focus on local issues, but the nationalization of politics has made this strategy increasingly difficult. Instead, some red-state Democrats are going out of their way to talk about President Obama more than other Senate candidates from their party  and not always in a good way.

title: Science Best Sellers
description: 1 QUIET by Susan Cain. Crown. Introverts  one-third of the population  are undervalued in American society. (1)

title: AbbVies Bid Played Into Hands of Shire Boards Merger Expert
description: When AbbVies overtures for the Dublin-based drug company Shire were first announced last month, The Guardian newspaper in Britain declared in a headline: Shire Chairwoman Susan Kilsby: mergers expert now resists one.

title: U.N. Council, in Unanimous Vote, Backs Aid Delivery to Syrians in Rebel Areas
description: Despite objections by Syrias government, the United Nations Security Council voted 15 to 0 on Monday to authorize cross-border convoys of emergency aid for millions of deprived Syrian civilians in rebel-held areas, without prior approval by the Syrian authorities.

title: A Skateboarders Guide to His Galaxy
description: Growing up in San Francisco, the writer Sean Wilsey was an ardent skateboarder. He says he never went anywhere without his board. He skated in his room when it rained. He loved the kickflips and heelflips of the pioneer skater Rodney Mullen  tiny, precise things that seemed like the work of Swiss watchmakers, with perfect balance and total concentration  and worshiped the grace and style and imagination of the street skater Natas Kaupas, who could jump onto a wall, riding it like a wave, moving from the horizontal to the vertical with supernatural ease, defying the laws of physics.

title: 1964: Offer of Return to Congo
description: LEOPOLDVILLE  Premier Moise Tshombes government today [July 14] invited the family of murdered premier Patrice Lumumba to return to the Congo from its voluntary exile in the United Arab Republic. Mrs. Lumumba and her four children left for Cairo in 1961 shortly after Mr. Lumumba was murdered in Katanga, where he had been sent for safekeeping by the Leopoldville authorities who ousted him from power. Mr. Tshombe, who was president of Katanga at the time, has been accused of complicity in Mr. Lumumbas death. It was not immediately known whether Mr. Tshombe would attempt personally to persuade Mrs. Lumumba to return.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 15

title: 21st Century Fox Melds Its Television Broadcasting and Studio Units
description: The media giant 21st Century Fox announced on Monday that it was combining its broadcasting company and studio group into one business, reflecting the broader changes sweeping across the television landscape as global and digital outlets for programming proliferate.

title: A Goldman World Cup Streak Weighs on Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Soccer fans in Brazil might be forgiven if they asked Goldman Sachs to back another team.

title: A New Translation App from Frommers
description: Perhaps you already know that buongiorno is the appropriate greeting in Rome. But what about the concept of bella figura? The new translation app from the guidebook publisher Frommers covers both linguistic and cultural interpretations.

title: American Psycho Musical Coming to Off Broadway
description: Patrick Bateman is snaking back to New York. The investment banker-cum-serial killer at the center of Bret Easton Elliss 1991 novel, American Psycho, will be singing and dancing amid spatters of blood in a musical adaptation at Second Stage Theater starting in February, executives there announced Monday.

title: Secret Reaches Beyond Tech Set, and Raises $25 Million
description: Secret, the app that lets people post messages anonymously, has been beloved by the tech insiders who use the service to gossip about their jobs and love lives.

title: A Deluge of Reader Complaints on Israel-Palestine Coverage
description: I was away and off the grid last week but have been keeping up on the news  and on complaints from readers.

title: Loft Tenants Fight for Legal Protection
description: When Mark Veeder went to visit a friend living on Greene Street in SoHo in 1992, in the short time it took him to get upstairs and glance out the window, he saw someone was breaking into his car. Still, when the friend mentioned his landlord might have a place available on Crosby Street, Mr. Veeder, an event and marketing planner then living on the Upper West Side, jumped at the chance.

title: Robert Gardner and Peter Matthiessen
description: In a 1996 interview, Robert Gardner and Peter Matthiessen discuss their 1961 trip to New Guinea, which resulted in Mr. Gardners film Dead Birds and Mr. Matthiessens book Under the Mountain Wall.

title: Eclectic Offerings at Baryshnikov Arts Center
description: The world premiere of a score for handmade music boxes, clavichord, accordion and prepared auto-harp, by the composer and toy piano virtuoso Phyllis Chen, and the United States premiere of Illusions, by the Russian playwright Ivan Viripaev, are highlights of the Baryshnikov Arts Centers fall 2014 season, the center announced on Monday.

title: A Virtual Elephant
description: Magic Leaps Little Elephant animation illustrates one type of experience that the companys human computing platform will be able to deliver.

title: Former Dewey Executives Seek Dismissal of Case, Saying They Were Scapegoats
description: Updated, 1:46 p.m. | Three former top executives at Dewey & LeBoeuf, charged by New York prosecutors with breaking the law in a failed bid to keep the struggling law firm afloat, contend they always intended to pay back the firms lenders and bond investors.

title: Science Visuals
description: This collection of columns takes a look behind the numbers to show hidden trends and relationships over a range of science and health topics.

title: A Photographic Muse Beyond the Ruins
description: Not content to tell the typical tale of a down-and-out town, William Widmer allowed Pine Bluff, Ark., to change his photojournalism.

title: Church of England Votes to Accept Women as Bishops
description: LONDON  After years of deadlock and division, the Church of England voted on Monday to allow women to become bishops, overturning centuries of tradition and overcoming a long-running dispute that had undermined the unity of Anglicans.

title: A Mysterious Organ, Virtual Reality Sickness and Practice Makes ... Perfect?
description: Scientists begin to shed light on the placenta, an important organ that we rarely think of; virtual reality companies work out the kinks in their immersive worlds; research shows that practice may not be as important as once thought.

title: Julia Turner Is Named Editor in Chief of Slate
description: The online magazine Slate on Monday named Julia Turner its editor in chief, succeeding David Plotz, who is stepping down after six years in the job.

title: U.N. Resolution on Syrian Aid
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously voted to authorize cross-border convoys of emergency aid to Syrians in rebel-held areas without prior approval by the Syrian authorities.

title: Learning Lear': A Real Run-Through, and a Sneak Peek
description: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses King Lear for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: Ex-Judge Leading Inquiry Into Child Abuse in Britain Steps Down
description: LONDON  Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, a former senior judge asked to lead an inquiry into child abuse allegations in Britain, stepped down from the job on Monday, citing concerns of a conflict of interest because her brother, Michael Havers, was attorney general in the 1980s.

title: Discussions With L.I.R.R. Appear to Have Collapsed
description: Six days before a possible strike on the Long Island Rail Road, negotiations appeared to collapse on Monday, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority acknowledged a gulf with its unions, and labor leaders said they would proceed with plans for a walkout on Sunday.

title: Real-Life Illness in a Virtual World
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, FLA.  A 3-D animated creature, affectionately named Gerald, appears to walk in circles while floating in front of an elaborate viewer that resembles something from an optometrists office. Though only half a foot high, and with four arms, he looks remarkably lifelike through lenses that transmit what computer scientists and optical engineers describe as a digital light field into the eyes of a viewer.

title: Holder Discusses Citigroups Settlement
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. held a news conference to discuss the landmark resolution in a mortgage securities investigation of Citigroup.

title: Britains Denial of Some Visas to Russians for Air Show Stirs Outcry
description: MOSCOW  Officials in the Russian aviation industry lashed out Monday at Britains refusal to grant visas to some members of a state delegation to the Farnborough air show over Russias actions in Ukraine.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Ben Austen on Detroits Possible Rebound
description: Ben Austen, a contributing editor at Harpers Magazine, wrote the July 13 cover story about Detroits prospects for revival. He also wrote an article for the magazine last year about housing activism in Chicago.

description: A peek at what some of the guys and gals in Berlin were wearing.

description: American perceptions of China continued to lose ground in the past year, although only slightly, according to a survey by the Pew Research Center released Monday.

description: Residents of the West Village will soon see something unusual arriving at the shiplike building on Seventh Avenue that used to house part of St. Vincents Hospital: ambulances.

title: LinkedIn Acquires Start-Up Newsle
description: Unlike some other Silicon Valley companies like Facebook and Google, LinkedIn has been relatively quiet on the deal-making front. And when it does do a deal, it is usually small.

title: Monday Motorsports: Marquez Wins Ninth Consecutive MotoGP Race
description: Marc Marquez continued his perfect 2014 MotoGP season, winning his ninth race in a row on Sunday at the rain-slicked Sachsenring in Germany. He also broke a lap record at the track that had stood for six years.

title: Posthumous Recognition
description: EMERYVILLE, Calif.  Glenn Burke was 27 when he walked out on Major League Baseball, his promising career as an outfielder undone mostly by the burden of being a semicloseted gay man. It was 1980, and it was more important, Burke later explained, to be himself than to be a professional baseball player.

title: In Defense of Indispensable Dad
description: Last summer, in a failed attempt at humor, Clorox ran an online ad that declared, Like dogs or other house pets, new dads are filled with good intentions but lacking the judgment and fine motor skills to execute well. Although the company pulled the ad amid a flurry of scorn from the online commentariat, it nevertheless played to a remarkably widespread stereotype  that fathers are somehow unfit to raise children.

title: Bigfoot and Yeti, as Elusive as Ever
description: Legends of mysterious part-human creatures have circulated for centuries, and those stories persist today in cultures around the world, from Yeti in the Himalayas to the Almas, or wild man in Central Asia to Sasquatch, a.k.a. Bigfoot, in North America.

title: With Storms Expected, Philharmonic Cancels Central Park Concert
description: The New York Philharmonics planned concert in Central Park on Monday evening has been canceled because of forecast thunderstorms. A spokeswoman for the orchestra said the decision had been made by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, in consultation with the New York Police Department, the Central Park Conservancy and the orchestra.

title: Israeli Suspects Lawyers Discuss Case
description: Lawyers for Israelis accused in an apparent revenge killing of a Palestinian teenager discussed the charges against their clients.

title: Walkabout: A New Patent for Airplane Seats Is Short on Leg Room
description: Tight FitCould your airplane seat become more uncomfortable? This new Airbus patent for seats resemblingbicycle saddlessuggests that yes, it could. (The Washington Post)

title: Weekly News Quiz | July 8-14, 2014
description: The World Cup, Israel and more, including an experimental 10th question wed love your opinion on. Would you like one like it once a week?

title: Bastille Day With a Philadelphia Twist
description: Twenty years ago, Terry Berch McNally and a few fellow Philadelphia restaurant owners ran down to the stone walls of the nearby abandoned Eastern State Penitentiary. Lets storm the Bastille, Ms. McNally said, Champagne and French bread in hand. Then it dawned on her. Oh my gosh, she said, this sounds like an event. We could do this.

title: Bastille Day With a Philly Twist
description: For 20 years, the city of Philadelphia has staged a spirited and unconventional re-enactment of the French Revolution at Eastern State Penitentiary to celebrate Bastille Day.

title: David Mitchell Is Tweeting a New Short Story
description: David Mitchell, the British novelist whose books include Ghostwritten and Cloud Atlas, had a surprise for admirers of his work on Monday. Mr. Mitchell, who lives in Cork, Ireland, logged onto Twitter and began sending out a new short story, 140 characters  Twitters limit  at a time. The Guardian reports that Mr. Mitchell expects to devote 280 tweets, delivered over the next seven days, telling the tale, which focuses on a teenage boy who has found his way into his mothers Valium stash.

title: The Advanced Metrics of Attraction
description: The essayist Alain de Botton has been writing a great deal lately about crushes, those sudden infatuations aroused by the merest of stimuli  the way she subtly rolls her eyes at a blowhards pronouncements, her intentional dropping of a glass to attract a waiters attention, the way he casually uses his iPhone as a bookmark. In beautiful prose laden with examples, Mr. de Botton describes how attraction can cascade into exultation but, alas, gradually dissolve into disillusionment and a slow vanishing of the mirage.

title: Atlantic City Strives to Rise as Casinos Fall
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Over the Fourth of July weekend, this town was packed. Hotel occupancy soared to 95 percent, and shoppers coursed through the outlet stores opposite Trump Plaza. At Revel, the citys newest casino resort, the lively, dressed-up crowd gazed out through the floor-to-ceiling glass to see the surfers riding the days last waves onto the wide beach.

title: In France, a Yearly Feast of Fish
description: STE, France  This Mediterranean port town is famous for its annual Worldwide Festival of electronic music, seven miles of glorious beaches and fish.

title: A Sports Cover Inspired by a Celebrity Wedding
description: On Saturday, the Sports section had extensive coverage of LeBron Jamess move from Miami to rejoin the Cleveland Cavaliers. The news was presented in a unique way on the sections front page. We asked Jason Stallman, the Sports editor, what inspired the display.Like most of our greatest journalism achievements, this one was inspired by The New York Posts coverage of Kimye.

title: Restoring Internet Explorer 11 to Windows 8.1 App Tiles
description: Q. I just noticed Internet Explorer is gone from the apps displayed on my Windows 8.1 screen. The browser opens, but only in the Desktop mode version. How can I get the app version back?

title: Tropical Fish, Where They Dont Belong
description: As the oceans warm because of climate change, tropical fish are moving into temperate waters, a new study reports. Researchers writing in The Proceedings of the Royal Society B say that fish like the plant-eaters above threaten the kelp forests and the sea grass meadows that they graze on. Significant damage has already been seen in the waters near southern Japan and in the Mediterranean.

description: Rest in peace, Archie Andrews (1941-2014).

description: This afternoon, Dean Baquet, executive editor of The Times, announced another step in a restructuring of the newsroom meant to meet the demands of digital news. He named Arthur Gregg Sulzberger to a new senior editors position. Here is his memo:

title: A 52-Million-Year-Old Window Into the Future
description: The fossil of an ancient hedgehog just two inches long, no bigger than a shrew, was discovered in British Columbia.

title: Ugly Reality Intrudes On World Cups Glow
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  When Mario Gtze scored the goal that won Germany the World Cup on Sunday, it was the 171st goal of the tournament, equaling the highest total in World Cup history. This was fitting: The 64 games in Brazil were by turns exciting and enthralling, captivating and compelling. Many longtime observers called it the best World Cup in memory. On the whole, it is hard to disagree. This was amazing theater.

description: SAUGERTIES, N.Y  Was the Hudson Project a festival or the rehearsal for a festival?

title: Recreating Mars in a Lab, and Finding Water
description: In 2008 Nilton O. Renno, an astrobiologist at the University of Michigan, noticed small globules in pictures taken by the Mars lander Phoenix. Over time, the globules seemed to coalesce.

description: Q.A cacophony of birds ruins my sleep every day at 2:30 a.m., louder and louder each year. Why is this happening on the upper west side of Manhattan?

description: Updated, 6:01 p.m.

title: Ready for Unreal Reality? You Need to Calm Down
description: Vacuous wives have been all over television for a while, with a fresh batch arriving over the weekend in Bravos awful Game of Crowns. On Tuesday, they invade made-for-the-Internet fare as well: Hulu introduces The Hotwives of Orlando. The Hulu series is a parody of the others but, unfortunately for it, the genre is already well beyond parodying.

title: In Amsterdam, a New Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Raises the Bar
description: Created from six of the Dutch citys most beautiful 17th- and 18th-century brick townhouses, the Waldorf-Astoria Amsterdam, five years in the making, sets an impressively high bar for a new sort of stylish and discreetly luxurious European hotel.It does so by offering a carefully curated contemporary approximation of the genteel lives of the burghers who originally built these mansions during Hollands Golden Age, the period during the 17th century when the country led the world in everything from trade and maritime supremacy to art and science. So thoughtful and boutique-like is the design, youd never guess it comes from Hilton (the corporate chain that owns the Waldorf-Astoria name).

title: Young Women Under Pressure
description: Elenas Aria, the third of four early pieces that the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker has brought to this years Lincoln Center Festival, is commonly characterized as a transitional work. Made in 1984, it was her first dance to use spoken text and film. The program note describes it as a result of self-questioning, a search for a way forward. And on Sunday at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, when it was performed in New York for the first time since 1987, thats what it looked like: the work of a young artist who has hit an aesthetic wall and hasnt yet discovered how to get past it.

title: Responding to Readers on The Data of Hate
description: I have received a lot of great questions and comments about my article, The Data of Hate, which analyzed the makeup of the membership of Americas largest hate site, Stormfront.

title: Food Curated | Razzas Bread and Butter
description: While he was learning to make a better pizza, the chef Dan Richer of Razza Pizza Artigianale in Jersey City was seduced by the process of baking bread.

title: On the Nature of Our Regime
description: As an interlude between reform conservatism and  posts, I want to return to the Mark Lilla essay on our present political situation that I commented on a couple of weeks ago, this time to quibble a little bit with its title. That title is The Truth About Our Libertarian Age, and most writers Ive seen commenting on the essay from my colleagueDavid Brooks to Andrew Sullivan to Damon Linker have tended to basically accept Lillas formulation, which links the spread of cultural individualism (defined as an outlook with treatsas axiomatic the primacy of individual self-determination over traditional social ties) to the durable triumph of neoliberalism in political economy, and places both under the umbrella of a libertarianism ascendant.

title: Video: Razzas Bread and Butter
description: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

title: Digital Love, Consolidated: IAC Buys HowAboutWe Dating Site
description: IAC/InterActiveCorp has made one thing crystal clear: The company wants to be the leading player in the digital dating market.

title: Drug Shows Promise for Common Cause of Infertility
description: Researchers have found a more effective treatment for one of the most common causes of infertility.

title: A Pile of Steak, for Lunch or Dinner
description: Consider making the immensely engaging Ribeira Sacra mencas your house wine. Yes, their rich earthiness may call for hefty slabs of meat, but they can also accompany a roast chicken or even broiled lobsters with grace. And their occasionally subtle vegetal notes, reminiscent of cabernet franc, mean that summers ratatouille, stuffed peppers and tomato salads are also within reach.

title: A Side Project for All-Stars
description: Part of an occasional series on vintage comics.

title: Cheney Family Discusses Political Playbook
description: WASHINGTON  For those wondering what the conversation is like around the Cheney family dinner table, it does indeed involve politics.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Study Discounts Testosterone Therapy for Early Prostate Cancer
description: For decades, millions of men with early prostate cancer have been placed on drug therapy to suppress their production of testosterone, despite such significant side effects as impotence, diabetes and bone loss. Now a large new analysis has concluded that so-called androgen deprivation therapy does not extend the lives of these patients.

title: A Space Thats Fully Inhabited Can Make Little Seem Big Enough
description: As the final World Cup match began on Sunday, so did an event of much tinier proportions. Tucked away on a quiet block in SoHo, around the corner from roaring crowds at neighborhood bars, the picturesque Elizabeth Street Garden hosted Small Stages, a dance piece by Ellen Cornfield for five performers, a few chairs and, most diminutively, a square platform measuring six feet on each side.

title: One Tough Job for an Undercover Cop: Fooling a Soccer Ball
description: When Robert Rodriguez started his El Rey cable network this year with one original series  an adaptation of his own vampire film, From Dusk Till Dawn  it seemed wise to take a wait-and-see approach. Would El Rey function as anything more than its bosss personal television sandbox?

title: How Do You Get to Carnegie Hall? Talent
description: The 8-year-old juggling a soccer ball and the 48-year-old jogging by, with Japanese lessons ringing from her earbuds, have something fundamental in common: At some level, both are wondering whether their investment of time and effort is worth it.

title: Draghi Sees No Risk of Eurozone Bubbles
description: Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, said on Monday that he did not see a risk of widespread asset bubbles in the eurozone, even if some markets were frothy.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Ukraine and Brazil.

title: Wine From a Sacred Place
description: If you travel widely enough around the grape-growing regions of the world, you gather ample testimony of the driving, historic human desire to make good wine. What else could explain the compulsion to plant vines on ridiculously steep hillsides in the Mosel and the Rheingau, in the northern Rhne Valley, in Priorat and the Douro, and in Ribeira Sacra in the Galicia region of northwestern Spain?

title: Its Almost Like Being in Love With a Fantasy
description: CHICAGO  Brigadoon, the musical about a Scottish town that lives for a day only to disappear for a century, may be in danger of achieving a similar evanescence. Although it was the first hit show from one of the American musical theaters most successful teams  Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, who went on to write My Fair Lady and Camelot  this early romantic fantasy has faded to the fringes of the repertoire, and has not been seen on Broadway since 1981.

title: Many Fliers Are Confused About Security Over Devices
description: FOR business travelers flying into the United States from Europe, the Middle East and Africa, there was a lot of confusion last week over the announcement that laptops, cellphones, smartphones, tablets and other personal electronic devices would not be allowed onto flights in carry-on baggage at more than 15 international airports if they were found to have dead batteries.

title: With Twitter's Help, Watch Congress Edit Wikipedia
description: In the Wikipedia entry for Tim Huelskamp, a Kansas Republican who has angered the House Republican leadership, somebody with a Congressional computer recently added a profile-boosting section labeled National Conservative Leader.

title: Pelvic Exercises for Men, Too
description: Kegel exercises have long been considered womens work. Because they tone the pelvic floor muscles that support the uterus, doctors encourage women to do them during pregnancy and continue them for life. Done for a few minutes a day, Kegels can ease childbirth, help with recovery, prevent incontinence  even improve your sex life.

title: London Theater Journal: Shadowlands
description: LONDON  Members of this countrys ruling class traditionally hightail it out of town for the country before summer breaks its first sweat. But I had heard that Henry and Anne and Jane and Katherine and all those Thomases (including the inevitable Cromwell) had reversed that tradition and relocated to the city, where they were said to be thriving.

title: A Puppet Who Just Wants to Eat His Sandwich
description: The office safety manual is Franks most trusted companion. When he suspects pigeons of plotting against him, he seeks its advice.

title: Hearty Cravings, Sometimes Unfulfilled
description: Chrissy Teigen is not a picky eater.

title: Lawmakers From Texas Will Offer Border Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Two Texas lawmakers say they plan to introduce a bipartisan bill on Tuesday intended to combat the humanitarian crisis at the nations southern border and make it easier to send migrant children from Central America back to their home countries.

title: Where Virtual Meets Real
description: Many of the best video games create distinctive places for their players to visit: Rapture, the cratered libertarian society on the bottom of the ocean, from BioShock; Liberty City and Los Santos, the fun-house mirrors of New York and Los Angeles, from Grand Theft Auto; the jungles and savannas of Central Africa, from Far Cry 2.

title: Awkward Moments, and One Important One
description: I JOINED my familys company, Banfi Vintners, in 1993 after I graduated from Georgetown. Were wine importers based in Old Brookville, Long Island. My first job with the company was in marketing and events so I traveled around the country to meet with sales teams. Now one of my main responsibilities as a co-C.E.O. is managing our operations in Italy. I still do a lot of events since Im responsible for getting our message out to the public. Wine is very personal, rooted in history, culture and romance. When people choose a wine, its based on more than price and packaging. There has to be a connection, and thats my job.

title: New Albums by Honeyblood, John Hiatt and the Fred Hersch Trio
description: HONEYBLOOD

title: Arizona Enlists a Beetle in Its Campaign for Water
description: LEES FERRY, Ariz.  In this corner of America known for its vast landscapes, rugged mountains and deep river canyons, signs of the havoc created by the minuscule tamarisk beetle are everywhere.

title: The Mysterious Tree of a Newborns Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Minutes after a baby girl was born on a recent morning at UCSF Medical Centerhere, her placenta  a pulpy blob of an organ that is usually thrown away  was packed up and carried off like treasure through a maze of corridors to the laboratory of Susan Fisher, a professor of obstetrics, gynecology and reproductive sciences.

title: Son of Dead Sea Scrolls Scholar Is Sentenced to Two Months in Jail
description: Five years after he was arrested in a case that tested the limits of free speech on the Internet in New York State, a man convicted of using fake email accounts to impersonate and malign his fathers academic rivals was sentenced on Monday to two months in jail.

title: On TV by Popular Demand, for Better or Worse
description: Two sets of fans received some good news recently: Community die-hards could rejoice at the revival of their favorite seriesby Yahoo, and Neil Gaiman adherents could celebrate the fact that the authors 2001 novel, American Gods, would be adapted to air on Starz. But as more fan favorites get new lives, some are starting to question the wisdom of the reboot.

title: Helsinki Divided on Plan for a Guggenheim Satellite
description: HELSINKI, Finland  City boosters in this Nordic capital dream of a Guggenheim museum of Finnish wood rising near the Baltic Sea and one day drawing millions of tourists and cruise passengers. But the huge costs of the proposed development are stirring a backlash here against an institution that is ordinarily accustomed to eager suitors.

title: Saying Sorry, but for What?
description: The plumber in my apartment was having the kind of bad day I recognize well, although my sympathies were absent for the moment. Summoned to address a cranky toilet, he had set off a chain of events that culminated in a cry of alarm deep within the bedroom closet, followed by the unmistakable sound of gushing water.

title: Hong Kong to Deliver Report on Electoral Reform to Beijing
description: In December 2007, Donald Tsang, the chief executive of Hong Kong at the time, told Beijing that a majority of the public hoped to elect the regions leader by one person, one vote in 2012, writing in a report that that expectation should be taken seriously and given consideration. A few weeks later, Beijing said no: The earliest possible year for such a vote would be a decade from then, in 2017.

title: New Contraceptive Shot Being Released in Africa
description: An easy-to-use new form of the injectable contraceptive Depo-Provera was introduced last week in Burkina Faso, the first of four African countries in which it will be rolled out this year.

title: Carmakers Are Central Voice in U.S.-Europe Trade Talks
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  Its a task that makes sense only by the logic of international trade strictures  which is why negotiators for the European Union and the United States are eager to change the rule book.

title: Ticking Viral Bombs, Left in Boxes
description: WASHINGTON  After the Sept. 11 attacks, fears that terrorists or the regime in Iraq might unleash a secret stash of the smallpox virus led Vice President Dick Cheney to call for a mass vaccination of the American public, an action President George W. Bush rejected.

title: A Focused Hunt for a Victim to Avenge Israelis Deaths

title: Group of Law Professors Urges Obama to Deny Religious Exemption in Order
description: More than 50 constitutional law professors urged President Obama on Monday not to include a religious exemption in an expected order barring federal contractors from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity. Conservative religious leaders want the rule, still being drafted, to exempt religious groups that object to homosexual behavior. But legal experts, organized by Katherine M. Franke of the Columbia University Law School, said in an open letter that church groups are already allowed to favor members of their faith in hiring, and that a new exception would allow employers to discriminate using taxpayer dollars and enshrine a second-class legal status for gay, lesbian and transgender workers.

title: Egypt: Opening for the Old Guard
description: An Egyptian court on Monday lifted a ban that prevented members of the political party of former President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted in 2011, from standing in parliamentary and local elections, state media reported. The courts decision, which said that party members who had not been convicted of crimes should not be excluded from public life, appeared to pave the way for the rehabilitation of members of Egypts once-disgraced old guard. Mr. Mubaraks National Democratic Party, which dominated politics for decades, was dissolved after his ouster. The Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that won successive elections after Mr. Mubaraks fall, was swept from power during a military takeover of the government last year and banned as part of a crackdown on political opposition. Experts say a new election law is likely to further constrict Egypts political life, producing a legislature subservient to the new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, while reviving some of the patronage networks that thrived under Mr. Mubarak.

title: India: Court Stays Executions for 2 Convicted in Gang-Rape Case
description: The Supreme Court of India on Monday temporarily stayed the execution of two men convicted of raping and murdering a 23-year-old woman on a bus in New Delhi in 2012, said their lawyer, A. P. Singh, in a case that drew international attention, prompted an outcry in India and led to the strengthening of sexual assault laws. The court on Monday stayed the executions of Vinay Sharma and Akshay Kumar Singh; the executions of two other defendants were also stayed by the Supreme Court in March after appeals were filed. All four were convicted of the crimes and sentenced to death last September. The district court that convicted the men categorized the case, in which the victim was repeatedly assaulted with iron rods on a moving bus, as the rarest of the rare, a designation that allowed the application of the death penalty. The four defendants plan to continue their appeals, and a final hearing is scheduled for August, said Manohar Lal Sharma, a lawyer for two of the defendants. Another accused, a juvenile at the time of the crime, was sentenced to three years in prison, and a sixth hanged himself in his prison cell.

title: Haiti: A U.N. Cholera Pilgrimage
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations visited Haiti on Monday and sought to assure Haitians that he was committed to ending a cholera epidemic as quickly as possible, but he did not acknowledge his organizations possible complicity in causing it, the subject of at least two lawsuits filed in the United States. In a speech in Los Palmas, a village ravaged by the disease, Mr. Ban called the visit a necessary pilgrimage that was aimed at expressing solidarity with the cholera victims. He has been seeking to raise $2.2 billion to eradicate cholera, which has killed more than 8,000 people in Haiti since 2010. It was absent from the country for nearly 100 years until after the January 2010 earthquake. Forensic studies have identified the cholera bacteria as an Asian strain carried by Nepalese members of a United Nations peacekeeping force in Haiti. Stanley N. Alpert, a lawyer representing Haitian victims in a lawsuit, called the secretary generals speech devoid of any sense of responsibility for the fact that the U.N. brought the cholera to Haiti and it should have gone into overdrive to shut it down.

title: A Pastry Chef Masters the Veggie Burger

Hes still obsessed. He has served his own veggie burger to David Chang, who posted a close-up to Instagram (1.8K likes), declaring it the best hes ever tried. Questlove asked Headley to serve the burger at his food salon. And this Sunday, the guy who turned the most profoundly uncool snack on the planet into something sought after will serve his patties to the public at his first pop-up, Superiority Burger on the Lower East Side.

The deal diverts the possibility of civil war and offers a chance for a peaceful transition of power after more than a decade of presidential rule by Hamid Karzai.
