description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress on Tuesday that the financial markets remained in reasonable health despite signs of bubbles in some areas, including the stocks of social media and technology companies.

title: James MacGregor Burns, Scholar of Presidents and Leadership, Dies at 95
description: James MacGregor Burns, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer and political scientist who wrote voluminously about the nature of leadership in general and the presidency in particular, died on Tuesday at his home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 95.

title: With Woolmark, Public School Becomes the Winningest Brand of the Year. Theres a Lesson Here.
description: Public School, the mens wear brand designed by Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow, has just added yet another feather to its cap, winning the mens half of the American regional leg of the Woolmark prize. This follows being named mens wear designers of the year at the CFDA awards in June, which followed winning the 2013 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards, which followed the 2013 CFDA Swarovski Awards for mens wear. Oomph. Thems a lot of trophies in a year.

title: Review Board Examining Extending Currency Benchmark Window
description: LONDON  The Financial Stability Board said on Tuesday that it was preparing to recommend that the window for determining currency benchmark rates be widened as part of a series of proposals to potentially reshape foreign exchange markets.

title: F-35 Fighter Jet Cleared to Resume Flights
description: The Pentagon on Tuesday lifted an order grounding all of its new F-35 fighter jets, but said they would operate under restrictions that would keep the plane from appearing at the Farnborough International Airshow in England this week.

title: On the Neo-paleo-Keynesian Phillips Curve (Wonkish)
description: In a previous post I mentioned, sort of in passing, that recent data actually look like an old-fashioned pre-accelerationist Phillips curve  that is, unemployment determines the inflation rate, not the rate of change of the inflation rate.

title: Corn, Squash, Red Onion and Tomatoes Stir-Fried in Coconut Oil
description: With a big bunch of Thai basil in hand, I wanted a sweet stir-fry with Thai flavors. I stir-fried the vegetables in coconut oil, and I loved the results. The medley has that coconut fragrance without the heaviness it would have with coconut milk. I served the vegetables with black rice, which was beautiful, but any other rice, noodles or grains like quinoa would work. Make sure that your corn is sweet and your tomatoes are juicy. You can also use the lower-priced tomatoes for sauce that may be at your farmers market.

title: China Clarifies its Plans on Setting a CO2 Emissions Peak
description: Updated, 11:28 a.m. | With climate treaty negotiations expected to intensify next year, China is signaling that it may soon set the timetable for hitting an eventual peak in its emissions of carbon dioxide, the most important human-generated greenhouse gas. The signals came on Monday from Xie Zhenhua, Chinas lead climate treaty negotiator, speaking at a German climate conference. Heres coverage by Xinhua, Chinas government-echoing news agency:

title: With Eye on Election, British Premier Shuffles Cabinet
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain shook up his government on Tuesday in an effort to present a fresher, less abrasive and more diverse face to voters with the next general election just 10 months away.

title: Immigration Advocate, Detained on Texas Border, Is Released in Visa Case
description: McALLEN, Tex.  Jose Antonio Vargas, who has chronicled in minute detail the twists and turns of his life as a Filipino living illegally for years in the United States, was detained by the Border Patrol for most of the day on Tuesday and then released with a notice to appear before an immigration judge.

title: Qatari Soccer Empire Buys a Foothold in Europe
description: EUPEN, Belgium  In the southeast corner of Belgium, there is a town of about 20,000 that is known, to the extent it is known at all, as a key battleground during the Battle of the Bulge and, more recently, as the center of the tiny slice of this country that speaks German instead of French.

title: Belafonte and Collins to Join Expanded Seeger Festival
description: Seeger Fest, the five-day tribute to the folksinger Pete Seeger and his wife,Toshi Seeger, assembled by one of his grandsons, opens on Thursday evening with a screening of he 2007 documentary,Pete Seeger: The Power of Song,at Pier 46 on the Hudson River, and includes events in the Bronx and in several towns in the Hudson Valley before winding up with two Manhattan concerts  at Damrosch Park, as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors, on Sunday; and at Rumsey Playfield in Central Park, part of SummerFest, on Monday  with performances by friends, colleagues and musicians inspired by Mr. Seeger, who died in January. The events are all free.

title: Dispute Is Settled Over Broadcast Rights to Golden Globes
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood Foreign Press Association settled its longstanding legal dispute with Dick Clark Productions over rights to produce the annual Golden Globes awards show, The Hollywood Reporter said on Monday. The association had sued the production company in 2010, claiming that it improperly renewed broadcast rights to the show with NBC, without permission of the association.

title: Budget Office Lowers Its Estimate on Federal Spending for Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  The growth of federal spending on health care will continue to decline as a proportion of the overall economy in the coming decades, in part because of cost controls mandated by President Obamas health care law, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said on Tuesday.

title: Remembering Nadine Gordimer, a Lioness of Literary Activism
description: At 90 years of age, the South African writer Nadine Gordimer died Sunday, leaving behind a global legacy of both art and activism. By the time she won the Nobel Prize in 1991, at age 68, her obituary in The Mail and Guardian (South Africa) recalls, she had 10 novels, nearly 20 collections of stories or essays and innumerable pieces of journalism to her name.

title: Chinese Hackers Extending Reach to Smaller U.S. Agencies, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  After years of cyberattacks on the networks of high-profile government targets like the Pentagon, Chinese hackers appear to have turned their attention to far more obscure federal agencies.

title: Courtly Meals From Buvettes Queen
description: Brussels sprouts are not in season. They are available at the supermarket, though, small containers full of green California golf balls shipped great distances to satisfy the tastes of people who want such things year-round. We know we should shun them in favor of what the farmers market has now: young cabbages from the field across from the sheep; rhubarb from along the stone fence; real strawberries; local radishes. It is smart to shop and cook and eat seasonally. It tastes better. It is better.

title: What Happened When Martha Stewart Got a Drone
description: If you have lingering questions about drones  particularly about whether they can take nice pictures of a farm  allow Martha Stewart to reassure you. She recentlyposted the following on her blog:

title: MoMA Names New Architecture and Design Curator
description: Martino Stierli, a Swiss art history professor, has been appointed chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, Glenn D. Lowry, the museums director announced Tuesday.

title: Cardinal Relievers Tumultuous Road Leads to an All-Star Ending
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Those who know Pat Neshek understood the significance of it all. A St. Louis Cardinals relief pitcher, he entered a Hyatt Regency ballroom a few minutes late for the National League All-Stars media session Monday afternoon. Something else had required his attention.

title: Casualties in Moscow Subway Derailment
description: Witnesses described the morning rush hour crash that killed 20 people on Tuesday, as officials opened an investigation into the cause.

title: Border Tensions Rise Between Ukraine and Russia
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukraine and Russia traded increasingly bitter accusations of cross-border hostilities on Tuesday, deepening a shadowy war of real attacks or orchestrated sabotage that increasingly threatens to draw the two countries into direct conflict.

title: A Spoonful of Medicine May Put Children at Risk
description: Each year, about 10,000 people contact poison centers in the United States, afraid that they gave too strong a dose of medicine or were confused by measurement directions, according to the American Association of Poison Control Centers. About three-quarters of the callers are parents trying to administer medicine to children younger than 12, often baffled by such options for measuring as milliliters, milligrams, teaspoons, tablespoons and droppers.

title: For Proof Wall Street Is Changing, Look at Citigroup's Numbers
description: Its easy to be cynical about Wall Street reform. Nothing ever changes. The big banks get bigger and more powerful than ever. Too Big to Fail is worse than ever.

title: Kerry on Nuclear Negotiations
description: Secretary of State John Kerry announced that intense nuclear negotiations with Iran have yielded tangible progress, but that significant gaps remain.

title: 1964: Brezhnev As Successor?
description: MOSCOW  Leonid I. Brezhnev emerged today [July 15] as the man most likely to succeed Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. Mr. Brezhnev, Soviet president since May, 1960, gave up the largely ceremonial post to devote himself fully to Communist party affairs. His place as president was taken by First Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan, 68. Western diplomats said the change in party assignments, unquestionably made with Mr. Khrushchevs personal approval, represent a marked promotion for 58-year-old Mr. Brezhnev.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 16, 1964

title: The Shadow Universe Revealed
description: Recently astronomers have used a cosmic web imager to visualize simulations of dark matter, showing how the large scale structure of the universe grows and the nests in which galaxies are hatched.

title: Yellen Testifies on U.S. Recovery
description: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress that an ailing job market and stagnant wages justify keeping interest rates low.

title: Mulford Farm Prepares for the East Hampton Antiques Show
description: Once again, Mulford Farm in East Hampton, N.Y., a 3.5-acre property with a restored 17th-century farmhouse, is the backdrop for the annual East Hampton Antiques Show, Saturday and Sunday. The show, a benefit for the East Hampton Historical Society, offers furnishings from more than 55 antiques dealers from around the United States.

title: A Feminist in the Forest
description: Germaine Greer, the Australian author of The Female Eunuch (1970), that garrulous classic of second-wave feminism, has been a lifelong agitation artist. In her heyday she tangled with William F. Buckley and Norman Mailer, her skeptical blue-gray eyes boring holes through to the backs of their heads. Her sound bites, lanky good looks and proclivity for posing nude prompted Life magazine to call her, on its cover, the saucy feminist that even men like.

title: The Gay Mormon Known Sperm Donor From Utah
description: Whenever I find myself in a social situation that could use the aid of an icebreaker, some of my friends are a bit quicker than I would like to offer me up as conversational fodder.

title: Walking Through History in Ireland
description: Travelers can explore the archaeological riches of Irelands northwest coast through new walking trips from the Toronto-based active adventure company Butterfield & Robinson.

title: Hedwig Recoups on Broadway
description: The critically acclaimed Broadway musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch has turned a quick profit in just 15 weeks, with robust tickets sales driven in large part by the popularity of its star, Neil Patrick Harris.

title: Investors See Pricing Power in Tobacco Deal
description: American trustbusters deciding whether to approve Reynolds Americans deal with Lorillard will want to heed the markets message. The combined market value of the No. 2 and No. 3 cigarette makers in the United States has jumped more than $10 billion since merger talk surfaced. Those gains cant be justified by the cost savings on offer. Expectations of an increase in pricing power, through the creation of an effective tobacco duopoly, may best explain investors enthusiasm.

title: Janet Yellen on the Everything Bubble
description: Last week we wrote here about how virtually all major asset classes on earth are relatively expensive compared with their historical values. We called it the Everything Boom, with a worrying asterisk that it could be, or become, the Everything Bubble.

title: Filings Aimed at Challengers to Corcoran Takeover
description: Lawyers for the Corcoran Gallery of Art and its art school filed papers in Washington on Monday challenging an attempt by a group to block a takeover of the Corcoran by the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University.

title: After Reynolds Buys Lorillard, Few Big Tobacco Deals Remain
description: Reynolds Americans acquisition of its smaller rival, Lorillard, is sure to face antitrust scrutiny in Washington. In the United States market, the deal will create a virtual duopoly, with Altria remaining the largest cigarette seller.

title: No Comment Necessary: Down to a Womans Level
description: At a Friday meeting of conservative women, Representative Renee Ellmers of North Carolina said her male colleagues could improve their messaging by bringing policy discussions down to a womans level.

title: Obama Presses Congress for Long-Term Transportation Bill
description: McLEAN, Va.  President Obama on Tuesday pressed Congress to break a deadlock over a long-term transportation spending bill, arguing that Republicans were more interested in trying to score points on cable TV than in fixing the countrys roads and bridges.

title: Litmus Test for Regulators Over Money Market Funds
description: Soon after the financial crisis, Congress created an elite group to hunt down risks that might cause another global collapse.

title: Though Scorned by Colleagues, a Climate-Change Skeptic Is Unbowed
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  John Christy, a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, says he remembers the morning he spotted a well-known colleague at a gathering of climate experts.

title: Still Walking on Air, Germans Touch Down for World Cup Party
description: BERLIN  Germany paraded its pride and its festive side on Tuesday when hundreds of thousands of fans gathered on a joyous, sun-kissed day to welcome home their victorious World Cup soccer squad.

title: Garth Brooks Sets a Single Tour Date After Canceling Irish Shows
description: When Garth Brooks announced the decisive end of his retirement, last week, he left his fans with news of a new recording contract, a forthcoming album and the availability of music in downloadable form, and promised that the details of a world tour would be forthcoming. On Monday evening, he announced the first stop, a concert at the Allstate Arena in Rosemont, Ill., on Sept. 4. And so far, thats it: it was unclear on Tuesday whether Mr. Brooks planned to announce the tour one date at a time  a tip of the hat, perhaps, to the British author David Mitchell, who is spending this week publishing a short story on Twitter, 140 characters at a time  or would announce the full tour shortly.

title: A Stampede for Freedom
description: In early 1864, the Union Army began enlisting black soldiers in Kentucky, but Capt. J. Bates Dickson, an enlistment officer in the state, didnt expect much  they might come singly and in squads, but not waves. Indeed, despite tens of thousands of fighting-age black men in the state, turnout was paltry  after all, Kentucky was still a slave state, and enlistment was restricted to free blacks and to slaves whose owners permitted them to go. Most slaveholders and their allies resisted black enlistment by any means possible, often with cruelty and violence.

title: The Latest News That Isnt
description: At this point, we all have heard that print media is dying and that online journalism rests upon shaky business models. But at least fake news is thriving, right? Not so fast.

title: Immigration Activist Detained in Texas
description: Jose Antonio Vargas, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and an activist for immigrants, like him, who do not have legal status, was detained at McAllen-Miller International Airport on Tuesday.

title: In Performance | Tine Thing Helseth
description: The Norwegian trumpeter performs I ensomme Stunde composed by Ole Bull.

title: Okwiri Oduor Wins Caine Prize for African Writing
description: Okwiri Oduor, a 25-year-old Kenyan who studied law but switched to writing, has won the 2014 Caine Prize for African Writing. The award was announced Monday at the Bodleian Library in Oxford, England. This annual prize, for a short story by an African writer published in English, was first awarded in 2000 to highlight literary talent from the continent.

title: Beware John Cornyns Humane Immigration Act
description: Senator John Cornyn, the Texas Republican, has offered a bill that he says will solve the crisis of unaccompanied migrant children at the southern border.

title: Pebble Beach Concours to Feature Grand Prix Centennial Cars
description: An exhibition celebrating the centennial of the 1914 Grand Prix of the Automobile Club of France, which will include the winning Mercedes, the race trophy and five other cars of the era, will be on display at the Aug. 17 Pebble Beach Concours d'lgance in California, it was announced by Sandra Button, head of the concours.

title: Its Woods and Its Royal Liverpool, but Its Not 2006
description: HOYLAKE, England  On his way to the British Open, Tiger Woods stopped in Geneva and spent the day touring a Rolex factory. He has reason to be preoccupied with time.

title: At Stella 34, Fresh Pasta to Go
description: To Take: A Parade of Pasta in Herald Square

title: Extremists Make Inroads in Pakistans Diverse South
description: MIRPURKHAS, Pakistan  In a country roiled by violent strife, the southern province of Sindh, celebrated as the land of Sufis, has long prized its reputation as a Pakistani bastion of tolerance and diversity.

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 3 | A Teenage Waitress on Unblinking Eyes Track Employees
description: Another week, another wonderful set of student entries in our Summer Reading Contest.

title: Eugene Kadomskiy Is Thinking Big With Urbo
description: Headliner

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Internet Behemoths
Race of Attrition Continues, Even on a Rest Day
description: BESANON, France  Short of its halfway point, this years unusually cruel Tour de France has raised several questions. Did the organizers go too far in their attempt to liven up the first week of the race with difficult routes? Are riders taking excessive risks? And, above all, with Chris Froome and Alberto Contador removed by crashes, can anyone beat Vincenzo Nibali?

title: When Climate Change Floods Your Heart
description: In 2100, I will live in Florida.

title: A Brooklynized Take on the Populist Musical, Courtesy of Yeasayers Front Man
description: What happens when two Brooklyn guys dream up a musical about the ravages of industry on a small town in contemporary gilded-age America and cast it full of indie-rock intelligentsia? Something like what would have happened if the Byrds Gene Clark restaged Jesus Christ Superstar as a series of Dorothea Lange tableaux. Break Line: the Musical (Secretly Canadian), a new project written by the Yeasayer front man Anand Wilder and his longtime friend, the pianist Maxwell Kardon, features a cast of musicians from Vampire Weekend, Man Man, Dirty Projectors, MGMT, Suckers, Kishi Bashi and Sinkane, among others, in telling the tale of a coal-mining Pennsylvania town called Greenbelt. The result mixes earnest politics, open-throated Broadway belting and sly psychedelic instrumentation.

title: In Illinois, a Challenge to Services Like Uber
description: The ride-sharing services UberX, Sidecar and Lyft may soon find it almost impossible to operate in Illinois.

title: Away From Home but Not the Kitchen
description: GIRONA, Spain  El Celler de Can Roca has climbed to the summit of world gastronomy without ruffling the simple routines of the family that runs it. The restaurant, in this city about an hours drive northeast of Barcelona, is owned and operated by three brothers who still lunch on their moms food every day in the nearby restaurant where they grew up, learning about cooking while playing soccer among the tables and chairs.

title: In London, You Can Join the Show
description: Almost 30 years after Back to the Future first hit theaters, time travel is about as realistic as Doc Browns flux capacitor. But as of July 24, you can visit Californias Hill Valley between 1955 and 1985  as in the movie, but in the flesh  via London.

title: Eating Across Texas, Puffy Tacos to Frito Pie
description: Lisa Fains blog, Homesick Texan, is predicated on food nostalgia. From her New York kitchen, she conjures recipes of the kind of comfort food and Tex-Mex dishes she knew growing up in the Lone Star State, often updated with fresh ingredients.

title: Restaurant Report: Hog Island Oyster Bar in San Francisco
description: In 1983, when two young marine biologists planted oyster seed on a Tomales Bay intertidal tract about 50 miles north of San Francisco, little did they know their Hog Island Oyster Co. would grow into a bay-to-bar juggernaut with nearly $12 million in annual sales and a trio of retail locations.

title: Arbitration Clauses Let American Apparel Hide Misconduct
description: The real lesson from the ouster of Dov Charney at American Apparel is the danger of arbitration clauses.

title: Stroke Rates Are Declining
description: The incidence of stroke in the United States has declined significantly over the past two decades, a new analysis has found.

title: Harper Lee Says New Book Not Authorized
description: For an author who is as famous for her reclusiveness as for her work  a single but extraordinarily influential novel, To Kill a Mockingbird  Harper Lee has been awfully public lately. An on-again, off-again lawsuit against the Monroe County Heritage Museum, in Monroeville, Ala., Ms. Lees hometown, over what she said was the unauthorized use of her book brought her into the spotlight several times from October 2012 to this May.

title: Philharmonic Cancels Tuesdays Park Concert
description: The New York Philharmonics second attempt to pay tribute to Lorin Maazel, its former music director, who died on Sunday, has come to grief. The orchestra was to have performed a concert at Central Park on Monday evening, part of its annual series of free outdoor concerts, and had announced that in memory of Mr. Maazel, Alan Gilbert would conduct Samuel Barbers Adagio for Strings. But when dire weather predictions led to the orchestra to cancel the concert on Monday afternoon, the tribute was moved to the Tuesday evening concert in Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx.

title: Big City Book Club Discusses Lush Life
description: This concludes our live discussion of Lush Life. Thanks to all who participated. Anyone who missed the conversation should feel free to post comments here throughout the week. We will soon announce the next selection of the Big City Book Club.

title: Chilled Corn Soup
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make a delicious cool corn soup with garlic, buttermilk and basil.

title: Suit Seeks to Establish Right to Record New York Police Officers
description: A federal lawsuit, which cites arrests of people who recorded police confrontations or activity, was filed on Tuesday asking a judge to declare that people have a right under the First Amendment to film or record officers working in public places.

title: Motivating Corporations to Do Good
description: Is it nave to expect corporations to assist in addressing the social, economic and environmental challenges of the day?

title: Corporate Medicis to the Rescue
description: ROME  Since early July, workers have been carefully unscrewing the steel scaffolding that for months has obscured much of the ancient facade of the Colosseum. Slowly, this monolithic symbol of Rome is coming into view again after the first portion of a 25 million euro ($34 million) refurbishment that underscores how Italy is coming to rely on private aid to preserve national treasures.

title: Germanys Defense Against the N.S.A.: Typewriters
description: In the television series Battlestar Galactica, by which I mean the most recent version, the human race is essentially saved from extinction because there are no fancy computer networks or other interconnected devices aboard the Galactica, an old spacecraft designed to resist infiltration by angry robots.

title: London Theater Journal:  A Carousel That Really Moves
description: LONDON  When June starts bustin out all over in the exuberant production of Carousel at the Arcola Theater here, you might wish you had been equipped with riot gear. Flying arms, legs and torsos look as if theyre in imminent danger of colliding with one another and with the audience, too. Hormones, with which the rowdy young things onstage are abundantly equipped, suddenly seem like dangerous weapons.

title: Hauser & Wirths Newest Outpost in English Farm Country Is Now Open
description: In Somerset, an English county marked by rolling farmland, the new and much-anticipated Hauser & Wirth outpost finally opened its doors today. T first profiled the project in April, in the Spring Design 2014 issue, with a first look at the arts center being carved out of a working farm there. The story focused on the farmhouse at Durslade Farm, a property that had been abandoned for 10 years and then left untouched for 50 before being restored and renovated by the Paris-based architect Luis Laplace. Its six guest bedrooms were then filled with pieces by Hauser & Wirths impressive lineup of artists, including Pipilotti Rist and Paul McCarthy, and the grounds were landscaped by none other than Piet Oudolf, the Dutch garden designer behind home-like public gardens such as the High Line in Manhattan.

title: Controlling the Home, Google Style
description: When Google goes after the home, it goes big. And maybe it goes after control, too.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Building the Front Page
description: Tom Bodkin is design director, chief creative officer and a deputy managing editor. Each day, after the best stories and photos are selected by top editors, he sketches the layout of the front page, which will determine the rest of the news sections design. We asked him about the process.

title: The Risks of Hillary Clintons Quasi-Campaign
description: Hillary Clinton is not running for president  at least not by her own admission. But its been a month since the start of her Hard Choices book tour, and nearly all the elements of a presidential campaign have emerged. There are boisterous crowds, speeches, interviews, an appearance tonight on The Daily Show, lists with names and email addresses, attacks from the opposition, and gaffes.

description: After a restless cross-country search in which two curators logged more than 100,000 miles in airplanes and rental cars, the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art  founded by the Walmart heiress Alice Walton  announced Tuesday that it had finalized its artist list for an ambitious fall show that will present a snapshot of unheralded 21st century American art.

title: Life Without Cars
description: Ive been following some of the discussion about Uber, Lyft, and all that, and I have a few unoriginal thoughts. Well, strictly speaking they are original, in the sense that I havent read them anywhere else  but surely theyre out there. So this post is partly a bleg for references.

title: Would-Be Rescuers of Wayward Spacecraft Previously Solved a NASA Mystery
description: Before reviving a zombie spacecraft, Dennis Wingo and Keith Cowing traveled to the past to rescue a trove of early moon photographs that otherwise would have been destined for oblivion.

description: The number of children crossing the U.S. border alone has doubled since last year. Answers to key questions on the crisis.

description: Intel has returned to the good old days, at least for a quarter. Longer term, it wants to enter a new and more complex world.

description: On April Fools Day 2008, a former music publicist and retired dominatrix named Erin Norris signed the lease on a derelict Brooklyn storefront where she intended to open a sausage restaurant called Grindhaus. Almost immediately, the universe began sending her a message: dont.

title: This Age of Infallibility
description: The estimable Sarah Kliff tabulates all the predictions of Obamacare disaster that didnt come true; she puts it at seven major themes, ranging from the website will never work to nobody will sign up. We can presume, then, that people like John Boehner  who declared that it would never work and that more people would lose insurance than gain it  are spending some time now trying to understand how they could have been so wrong.

description: Photos from Israel, Gaza City, Somalia and Afghanistan.

description: The senior vice president for NPRs news operations said Tuesday that she is leaving public radio to run a division at The Atlantic that creates conversation-driven events around topical issues.

description: The last few years have seen a puzzling and welcome new trend in health care spending: Instead of going up and up, increases have slowed way down.

title: Biennials Bright Young Things, Ages 77 and 84
description: LOS ANGELES  Prominent artists like Cindy Sherman and Mark Grotjahn have bought the work. Galleries on both coasts are beginning to promote it. Now the expressive, comics-inspired pottery of the husband-and-wife team Michael Frimkess and Magdalena Suarez Frimkess (hes 77 and shes 84) has become a sleeper hit of the Hammer Museums biennial, thanks to a younger generation of local artists who have been bringing it to light.

title: Money-Spending Decisions, Made Once and for All
description: For more than a decade, my family and I have gone to Jackson Lake in Wyoming for whats become our favorite summer vacation. Because the trip includes a boat, we make arrangements to rent a mooring for the boat so we dont have to take it in and out of the water each day.

title: Teetering on the Line Between Good and Evil
description: The Divide, a legal drama that begins on Wednesday, is surprisingly good. But whats most surprising is that its on WE, a cable channel best known for shows like L.A. Hair and Marriage Boot Camp.

title: Doomed by Quality, but Not Concept
description: Sad to say, the only surprise about the closing of Holler if Ya Hear Me, the new musical featuring the songs of the rapper Tupac Shakur, was that it didnt come earlier. When the show opened to downbeat reviews on June 19, many expected it would close within a week.

description: Nearly two years to the day that Marissa Mayer took the helm at Yahoo, the companys turnaround is still a work in progress. And its fortunes are still very much tied to its stake in Alibaba, the private Chinese Internet company expected to go public next month.

title: Playing the Waiting Game, Quixotically
description: One of the paradoxes of MTVs 16 and Pregnant and Teen Mom franchise is how small a role sex plays. Theyre shows premised on sex that include barely any talk of it, as if its protagonists, once they become parents, dont crave the thing that got them there. (Until they become parents again, that is.)

description: What we really want, if were honest, is a pill or a shot that would allow us to stop worrying about ever sinking into dementia.

title: Introducing a Poet Who Works in 3-D
description: The writer Alex Butler may live in brownstone Brooklyn, but thats about the extent of her similarities to the young literary set. A licensed social worker, she has also worked for the designer Jane Mayle, served as a production assistant onthe set of Sex and the City and recorded a series of humorous performancevideos. It was the loss, in quick succession, of both her parents  and Butlers experience as her mothers caretaker during a harrowing illness  that spurred her to turn what had been a secret hobby into a career. But rather than sit down at a laptop and type about the experience, she began speaking words and dialogue into a Dictaphone  and later her computers camera which led to not one, but two books: her debut memoir, Walking the Night Road, due out next year from Columbia University Press, and Circling the Same, a 41-poem meditation on loss. The latter newly availableonlinethrough its publisher, the Los Angelesbased gallery and art-book pressOhwowis as much art object as literature: Butlers words are printed alongside photographs fromthe artists Mirabelle Marden and Andrea Longacre-White. Both of these artists work, and what I imagined were their intentions, reminded me of a world altered by grief, she explains.

description: LONDON  Jacob Epstein has agreed to carve a mate, Eve  for Adam, his lonely three-ton version of primitive man  for a glimpse of whom rollicking holiday crowds at Blackpool, Lancashire, lined up during the week end and paid an admission fee of a shilling a time. Laurence Wright, who brought Adam to Blackpool, said today that Epstein had accepted his offer to sculpt Eve for 15,000. Epstein said Wright will use six tons of pink Derbyshire alabaster for the companion piece, double the quantity from which Adam emerged.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 17, 1939

title: Netherlands Held Liable for 300 Deaths in Srebrenica Massacre
description: PARIS  A Dutch court ruled on Wednesday that the government was liable for the deaths of about 300 victims of the 1995 Srebrenica massacre in Bosnia, Europes worst ethnically motivated mass murder since World War II, saying that a United Nations team of Dutch peacekeepers had failed to prevent those deaths.

title: Gtech of Italy to Acquire Slot Machine Maker for $4.7 Billion
description: Gtech, the operator of the Italian lottery, has agreed to acquire the slot machine maker International Game Technology of Las Vegas for $4.7 billion in cash and stock.

title: Stalking the Shadow Universe
description: For centuries people have found meaning  or thought they did  in what they could see in the sky, the shapes of the constellations echoing old myths, the sudden feathery intrusion of comets, the regular dances of the planets, the chains of galaxies, spanning unfathomable distances of time and space.

title: A Master of Illusion Endures
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  The cafe here on Westminster Street that was the location for a future Woody Allen movie looked like an elaborate stage illusion, surrounded by large screens that focused light into the restaurant, while also concealing any action within from onlookers outside.

title: Kimpton Now Rewards How You Act, Not Just How Long You Stay
description: Hotel loyalty programs generally measure guests commitment by the frequency of their stays. But Kimpton Hotels aims to discern  and reward  true passion with its new Kimpton Karma Rewards program, beginning Wednesday.

title: A Tiny Wire, and a Big Train Wreck
description: MOSCOW  The snapping of one small, improperly installed wire caused a Moscow subway crash this week that killed 22 people, investigators said on Wednesday. The police arrested a senior track foreman and his assistant.

title: Note to Cadres: Hands Off the Black Audi and Chauffeur
description: You can take away a Chinese officials dignity, as frolicsome videos on the Internet show. You can take away, at least for a while, gluttony on the public purse, chandeliered offices and vacations abroad in the guise of inspection tours. But can you take away that ultimate perk of the respectable cadre  the black car with intimidatingly tinted windows, an equally intimidating medley of official insignia, passes and a faithful driver?

title: Greek Fugitive Is Arrested in Athens Shootout
description: ATHENS  Greeces most wanted terrorist, Nikos Maziotis, the self-professed leader of the leftist guerrilla group Revolutionary Struggle, was arrested on Wednesday after a shootout with the police in the middle of a busy shopping district and popular tourist spot in Athens.

title: BlackRock Results Show a Shift Away From Stocks
description: With stock market indexes near record highs, investors committed more money to BlackRock in the second quarter, helping increase profit for the giant asset management firm.

title: Morning Agenda: Murdoch Pursues Time Warner
description: The media giant 21st Century Fox, the empire run by Rupert Murdoch, made an $80 billion takeover bid in recent weeks for Time Warner but was rebuffed, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. The bold approach could put Time Warner in play and might again ignite a reshaping of the media industry, prompting a new spate of mega-mergers among the nations largest entertainment companies.

title: Portugal Telecom and Brazil Phone Giant Revise Merger Terms
description: LISBON  Portugal Telecom and Oi of Brazil said on Wednesday that they had renegotiated the terms of their planned merger to salvage a deal threatened by the financing problems of the Esprito Santo group, which is controlled by Portugals most powerful family.

description: Dear Diary:

title: Tomas Maier Seeks an Entirely New Fashion Niche
description: Recently, I was talking to the designer Tomas Maier, a.k.a. the creative director of Bottega Veneta, one of Kerings brands, and the eponymous designer of a line that last winter got a cash infusion thanks to a joint venture with said big luxury group. We got onto the subject of What happens next? with his own brand. The topic isnt so surprising, but part of the answer was.

title: A Robot With a Little Humanity
description: As a graduate student at M.I.T. in the 1990s, Cynthia Breazeal studied with the roboticist Rodney Brooks and explored the idea of social robots that were designed to interact and collaborate with humans.

description: [Watch the official video for Lucia by Hiss Golden Messenger.]

title: Assad Begins a Third Term in Syria, Vowing to Look After Its People
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Feted by supporters, whom he hailed as the victors of his countrys brutal civil war, a triumphant President Bashar al-Assad was sworn in on Wednesday for a third seven-year term after an election that was widely seen as a gesture of calculated defiance toward the United States and others in the West and in the Arab world seeking his ouster.

title: Pakistani Airstrikes Target Haven for Qaeda and Taliban Fighters
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani fighter jets killed at least 35 people in attacks on militant bases in a remote part of the North Waziristan tribal district, the military said Wednesday, hours after local residents reported that an American drone strike in the same area had killed 20 people.

title: Treasury Urges End to Foreign Tax Flights, but Quick Action Is Unlikely
description: Updated, 9:40 p.m. |

title: South Korea Begins Naval Drills With the U.S.
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. GEORGE WASHINGTON  Fighter jets roared off an American aircraft carrier into a gray sky on Wednesday as the United States kicked off a joint naval exercise off the west coast of the Korean Peninsula, with the South Korean president, Park Geun-hye, calling for strong punishment if North Korea initiated a military provocation.

title: Whats News in Washington: Boehner Moves Ahead With Plan to Sue Obama
description: GoodWednesdaymorning from Washington. Heat and humidity are taking a brief hiatus, but there will be no such relief for relations between President Obama and House Republicans.

title: Behind Subways Phantom Hotel Entrance, Neither Arias Nor Opulence Linger
description: The management of the Astor familys Hotel Knickerbocker was baffled.

description: A report out on Tuesday from the Violence Policy Center confirms yet again the lunacy of Americas loose gun policies.

title: Miamis Coastal Climate Calamity  in Super Slo-Mo
description: Ive differed with Time Magazines fine correspondent Michael Grunwald on the importance of the Keystone pipeline (Grunwald, me), but cheered him on earlier this week on Twitter after climate campaigners attacked him (Grunwald a denier and polyanna?) for challenging an overheated Guardian account of the impacts of rising sea levels on Miami (Grunwalds home turf). (The Guardian story was an echo of a May feature in The Times.)

title: L.I.R.R. Negotiations Resume With Different Tone
description: Four days before a possible strike, the Long Island Rail Road and its unions resumed talks on Wednesday and pledged to continue informal discussions throughout the night  a conspicuous shift in tone after negotiations broke down earlier in the week.

title: Ya Gotta Have Faith
description: Jared Bernstein sends me to Congressional testimony on the state of the economy  his and Larry Kudlows (pdf). Jareds remarks are, of course, sensible. Kudlows are  well, kind of amazing.

title: Deadly Typhoon in the Philippines
description: Typhoon Rammasun has killed at least 10 people in the Philippines, and forced tens of thousands to evacuate.

title: Fantasies of Personal Destruction
description: A correspondent directs me to a piece in Forbes about yours truly that is both funny and scary.

title: Briarwood, Queens: A Quiet Refuge Bounded by Traffic
description: The neighborhood of Briarwood in central Queens borders the Kew Gardens interchange, one of the citys most congested traffic hubs, but is home to residents who value a quiet, low-key way of life. With its single- and multifamily homes and large co-op and rental complexes, it is an affordable refuge for a diverse mix of middle-class New Yorkers.

title: Roche Reports Mixed Results in Trial of an Alzheimers Drug
description: Roche, the pharmaceutical company, on Wednesday reported mixed results in its latest trial of an Alzheimers drug. It said that while the drug did not slow progression of the disease over all, at the highest doses it did seem to delay a decline in mental ability in patients with mild cases of Alzheimers.

title: For Friends in the Know
description: OPENING A STORE is easy, right? You pick a bustling neighborhood thick with people, put your space near other businesses likely to attract the sort of people you think will appreciate your wares, fling open your doors and  voil  retail Valhalla. Youll be fighting them off at the door.

title: Fauna, Flora and Freighters in the Danube Delta
description: I once heard an unusual tale about an Indian investment broker working in Bucharest, Romania, who had become enchanted by the Danube River Delta region, with its lonely canals, floating reed beds and silver onion-domed monasteries alongside quaint blue cottages in fishing villages one could only reach by boat.

title: 57,000 Reasons Immigration Overhaul May Be Stalled for Now
description: WASHINGTON  The crisis on the border with Mexico is rapidly overtaking President Obamas plans to use executive action to reshape the nations immigration system, forcing him to confront a new set of legal, administrative and political complications.

title: The Rise of Cafe Culture in New York
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Need for a Sidewalk Cafe Society appeared on July 5 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: Simplifying Measuring Medication for Children
description: Parents trying to administer medicine to children younger than 12 are often baffled by such options for measuring as milliliters, milligrams, teaspoons, tablespoons and droppers. In A Spoonful of Medicine May Put Children at Risk Jan Hoffman describes new efforts by professional associations to persuade manufacturers and pharmacists to adopt a uniform unit for liquid medicines: the milliliter. She describes the mistakes in dosing made by parents grabbing kitchen spoons, confusing teaspoons and tablespoons, and misreading instructions. Of 287 parents interviewed shortly after they had finished giving medication to their children that had been prescribed at the emergency departments at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan and Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn, more than 40 percent of the parents had not measured correctly.

title: Family Behind Hobby Lobby Has New Project: Bible Museum
description: WASHINGTON  The evangelical Christian family that owns Hobby Lobby, the chain of craft stores, made history two weeks ago when the Supreme Court overturned the Obama administrations mandate that family-owned companies must provide contraceptive coverage to their employees.

description: ROSWELL, GA.

title: London Theater Journal: A Hellish Vacation
description: LONDON  What a pristine room, all sparkling white from floor to ceiling, with not a speck of dust in sight.

title: Indian Clubs Ban on Dhotis in Favor of Western Attire Draws Protests
description: NEW DELHI  A regional leader in southern India on Wednesday condemned sartorial despotism after a posh English-style cricket club denied entry to several men wearing traditional Indian wraparound garments, telling them they could enter only in full trousers, shirts or T-shirts with collars, as rules posted outside the club say.

title: Ron Howard to Direct Documentary on Beatles Performing History
description: Having presented a sweeping autobiography of sorts in The Beatles Anthology, nearly 20 years ago, Apple, the Beatles company, is returning to its archives. The company announced Wednesday that it will produce a new documentary focused on the bands touring years. The film, which is as yet untitled, will be a collaboration between Apple, White Horse Pictures and Imagine Entertainment, and will be directed by Ron Howard.

title: Reflecting on a Decade of Murdoch Deals
description: Bold deals are nothing new for Rupert Murdoch.

description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Why You Are So Stressed About Stress
description: NPR conducted a study about how stressed out we are as a country, and the results, released last week, show that one in four Americans reported feeling stressed in the last month and one in two has experienced a major stressful event in the last year.

title: House Hunting in ...Newfoundland
description: A WATERFRONT CHALET-STYLE LOG CABIN IN NEWFOUNDLAND

title: BMW Recalls 1.6 Million Cars Over Defective Takata Air Bag Part
description: BMW is recalling about 1.6 million 3 Series cars from the 2000-6 model years, including about 574,000 in the United States, over a concern that the front-seat passenger could be injured by metal shards from a deploying air bag in a crash, the company said Wednesday.

title: Board Book Roundup: Babies Delight
description: New books include Little Pear Tree by Rachel Williams.

title: In Expansion, BMW to Make China-Only Models
description: FRANKFURT  The German automaker BMW said Wednesday that it would significantly expand its operations in the fast-growing Chinese market, doubling the number of models it produces there and extending its alliance with a local partner, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings.

title: Say Yes to Undress, Then Things Get Complicated
description: In case you missed the news that traditional courtship is dead, naked people on VH1 stand ready to enlighten you. And in case you thought that television networks had evolved beyond trying to attract viewers with cheesy titillation  ditto.
