description: When a financial titan like Laurence D. Fink lobbies Washington, the natural instinct is to make sure the citizenry pats itself down to check that everyone still has their wallets, watches and belts.

title: 1964: Hostility Shown to Goldwater
description: PARIS  The world reacted emphatically to Barry Goldwater today and most of the reaction was hostile. From London to Paris to Bonn to Moscow, commentators denounced the Arizona senator as a reactionary and a cold-warmonger. Only in Madrid and Johannesburg and a few other cities were voices of approval raised as the news flashed around the world of the senators nomination as the Republican presidential candidate. In London, the pro-Labor mass-circulation Daily Mirror said: The corpse of much that is decent and wise and tolerant in American society is in the coffin, although the lid has not yet finally been screwed down.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 17, 1964

title: Brazilian Private Equity Firm Near Closing on $1 Billion Fund
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The investment firm Gvea Investments, founded by the former Brazilian Central Bank president Arminio Fraga and Luiz Henrique Fraga in 2003, is near final closing on a new private equity fund that could exceed $1 billion, two people familiar with its plans said.

title: Small Businesses Are Finding Bank Loans Easier to Come By
description: Jake Fitzsimmons opened his first Stuft Burger Bar in Fort Collins, Colo., in 2010, after the worst recession in decades. It turned out to be an excellent time to open a burger joint  Coloradans were downsizing their dinners out  but a terrible time to apply for a loan.

title: A New History in the Making for Hoylake
description: HOYLAKE, England  Bernard Darwin, Charles Darwins grandson and a Hall of Fame golf correspondent, wrote long ago, Hoylake, blown upon by mighty winds, breeder of mighty champions.

title: Stir-fried Rice With Amaranth or Red Chard and Thai Basil
description: Amaranth is a beautiful green with small red and green leaves that grow, bush-like, off medium-thick stems. I get it from Asian vendors at the farmers market, where I can also find Thai basil. I cut away the very tough ends but use the more tender parts of the stalks. A good substitute here would be red chard, whose stems can be diced and included in the stir-fry. You could also use beet greens, but Id omit the stringy stems. I spiced this Thai-influenced stir-fry with sriracha, but that spicy chili sauce is optional.

title: Stir-Fried Turkey Breast With Snap or Snow Peas and Chard
description: Shopping for ingredients for this weeks recipes in my farmers market, I found young, tender snap peas that were almost as delicate as snow peas. I had part of a bunch of Swiss chard and used both vegetables. I like using turkey breast cutlets in stir-fries; theyve already been cut to a uniform thickness, so all you need to do is slice them across the grain to get even pieces that cook in minutes.

title: Paul Gibson Jr., New York Citys First Black Deputy Mayor, Is Dead at 86
description: Paul Gibson Jr., a lawyer and an airline executive who in 1974 became New York Citys first black deputy mayor, died on July 11 at his home in Jamaica, Queens. He was 86.

title: Money Alone Wont Secure Time Warner for Murdoch
description: Rupert Murdoch has one last big takeover left in him. Time Warner makes the perfect swan song for the 83-year-old media mogul. The HBO-to-Looney Tunes conglomerate sits at the top of a pyramid where content is king, has no controlling shareholder and poses few insurmountable antitrust hurdles for 21st Century Fox. But winning will not just be a matter of price.

title: Changyuraptor, Large Species of Flying Dinosaur, Is Discovered
description: Scientists have discovered a large species of flying four-winged dinosaur that may have relied on a long, feathery tail to prevent crash landings.

title: Randall Stout, Architect Tied to Nature, Dies at 56
description: Randall Stout, an environmentally sensitive architect who earned a national reputation for designing dynamically shaped regional museums, mostly in his native South, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 56.

title: Analyzing Next Steps, Airbus Chief Is Closely Watching Google and Facebook
description: LONDON  Thomas Enders, the chief executive of the Airbus Group, has not been shy in his public admiration for the speed and scale of innovation that has been achieved by American high-technology giants like Google, Facebook and SpaceX. But it is only recently that he has begun to consider such companies potential future aerospace partners.

title: Marvel Will Introduce a Female Thor This Fall
description: Marvel Comics revealed on Tuesday that Thor, the God of Thunder and the son of the Norse god Odin, will be replaced by a woman. The character, who Marvel has revealed few details about, will star in Thor, God of Thunder, a new series that begins in October, written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by Russell Dauterman.

title: An Apartment as Co-Star
description: Of course, Between Riverside and Crazy is by Stephen Adly Guirgis, a playwright whose distinctive style extends to his titles. Longtime admirers of this wistfully poetic writer know that he favors references to places in New York or New Jersey (Our Lady of 121st Street, The Little Flower of East Orange), hard consonant sounds (The _______ With the Hat) and a sense of careening movement (Jesus Hopped the A Train).

title: Vintage French Cars Turn Heads
description: Owners of old French cars paraded through New York City to showcase their classics.

title: Francophiles Celebrate Bastille Day With French Cars and Bikes
description: For the last 15 years, the Greater New York Citron and Velosolex Touring Club has lent its charms to the annual French Institute Alliance Franaise Bastille Day street fair on 60th Street and 5th Avenue. The fair celebrates French culture and food, but the collection of classic French cars and motorized bicycles has always added a splash of style and color.

title: U.S. Is Said to Plan to Send 6 Detainees to Uruguay
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has secretly notified Congress that the military intends to transfer six low-level Guantnamo Bay detainees to Uruguay as early as next month, according to people with knowledge of the communication. All six have been approved for transfer for more than four years.

title: With DC59 Motorhead, Dyson Looks to Create the iPad of Vacuums
description: More than a decade ago, Dyson, the British company known for its line of powerful and expensive vacuum cleaners, quietly began working on an ambitious project to displace its own best invention.

title: Nine in Egypt Are Convicted in Sex Assaults
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian judge on Wednesday sentenced nine men accused of sexual assault to terms of 20 years to life, handing down the lengthy penalties weeks after the government pledged that sexual violence against women would be more severely punished.

title: For a Parting Gift, Do You Want a Grapefruit or a Meatball?
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Denny McLain was the original Adam Wainwright, and Mickey Mantle the original Derek Jeter.

title: Whisky, Summer Style
description: Scotch whisky might not seem like a natural fit for lighter summer cocktails. The adjectives you hear applied to these whiskies  peaty, earthy, even mediciney  may not immediately suggest beach-ready drinks. But in fact the smokiness or salinity of Scotch whiskies is the very reason they can do so well in citrus-infused drinks with a bit of sugar: they stand up to the sweetness. And just as the complex layers of flavors and aromas of straight whisky open up when you add water, they also sing when combined with the ingredients in these three warm-weather Scotch drinks, created by bartenders from Glasgow, New York City and Los Angeles.

title: A Westerners Inside View of Alibaba Successes and Failures
description: After studying Chinese in the early 1990s and hosting a travel show on state-run television in China, Porter Erisman went to work for a public relations firm. Then, during the dot-com boom in 2000, he joined a tiny, Chinese Internet start-up called Alibaba.

title: Should Janet Yellen Be Giving Us Stock Picks?
description: Eighteen years ago, when Alan Greenspan wanted to send a message that he worried the stock market was getting a little bubbly, he did it with a typically inscrutable phrasing buried in an otherwise unremarkable speech.

title: Classical Playlist: Schumann, Mozart, Brahms and More
description: WORKS BY SCHUMANN AND JANACEKMarc-Andr Hamelin, pianist(Hyperion)The pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin brings commanding technique, elegant musicianship and imagination to a program of suites about, variously, rural life, nature and children. Janaceks On the Overgrown Path, Book I is a 30-minute compilation of mood pieces, character pieces and short works inspired by folk music. Mr. Hamelin searches out the strangeness in the music while conveying the character. He gives a beguiling, lively account of Schumanns overlooked Waldszenen (Forest Scenes) and brings freshness and distinction to his familiar Kinderszenen (Scenes of Childhood). (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Today in Small Business: Same-Day Delivery
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Is Truvada, the Pill to Prevent H.I.V., 99 Percent Effective? Dont Be So Sure
description: Truvada, the once-a-day pill to help keep people from contracting H.I.V., is on the cover of this weeks New York magazine, and Tim Murphys cover story focuses on how the pill is changing sex by drastically reducing gay mens fear of infection.

title: The Moderate Revolution in Kansas
description: A surprising political revolt is now brewing in Kansas, one that could provide a model for breaking the stranglehold of the hard right on the Republican Party  if enough people join in.

title: Are Banks Fighting Over Your Business?
description: In an article we just published, Jake Fitzsimmons describes how last fall he and his partner induced four banks to compete for the opportunity to loan them money. Mr. Fitzsimmons co-owns Stuft Burger Bar, which was making plans to open its third restaurant in northern Colorado. We went into it at the front and said were going to take the best initial opportunity, Mr. Fitzsimmons said. Our hope with that was that they would give us their best offer originally, knowing that we were looking at other banks. In the end, three of the four banks came back with bids.

title: Weather May Not Affect Back Pain
description: Many people think the weather affects their back pain, but a new study shows they are probably wrong.

title: Yellen Says Restraining the Feds Oversight Would Be a Grave Mistake
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserves chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said on Wednesday that it would be a grave mistake for Congress to adopt legislation proposed by House Republicans constraining the Feds management of monetary policy.

title: Witness Accounts of Gaza Attack That Killed 4 Boys
description: Foreign correspondents reporting from Gaza on Wednesday offered visceral accounts of a deadly attack that killed four children on the beach outside a hotel in which the journalists were staying. Tyler Hicks, a New York Times photographer, was among those who rushed from the hotel to the beach as a desperate scramble unfolded to save the lives of other children wounded in the shelling.

title: Easy Ways to Get More Vegetables on the Table, More Often
description: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. Last week, Renee did her first stir-fry, based on last weeks advice and a recipe like those found here.Hello Martha,

title: Sweet and Sour Stir-Fried Radishes With Their Greens
description: We always toss out radish greens, but we shouldnt. They are as nutritious as any green, and they have a pleasantly bitter flavor that is very much like that of turnip greens, which are a close relative. The bitterness works very well against a sweet and sour stir-fry sauce. The radishes should be barely cooked. This is a great dish for large, colorful breakfast radishes. The big bunches I get at my farmers market weigh a pound, sometimes a little more. Use 2 bunches if yours are smaller.

title: Some Top Money Managers Push for Fed to Start Raising Interest Rates
description: The Fed is out of step with Wall Street, say some of the countrys wealthiest investors.

title: Pelosi, in Reversal, Says She Opposes Speeding Child Deportations
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, reversed course on Wednesday and said she would not back changes to a 2008 law that gave certain undocumented immigrant children broader legal rights to enter the United States.

title: App Smart | Avoiding Sunburns
description: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can help you avoid too much sun exposure, as well as give you tanning advice and hydration tips.

title: Your Time in the Sun, Measured to the Minute
description: I WOULD bet that more than once over the last several weeks you have forgotten to put sunscreen on before you went outside, even though we all know the dangers of getting too much sun. As in so many situations, your smartphone can come to the rescue, with sunshine prediction and advice apps.

title: To Reassure Time Warner Employees, Bewkes Takes to the Small Screen
description: Jeffrey L. Bewkes has gone digital.

title: Noriega Sues Video Game Maker Over Portrayal in Call of Duty
description: Manuel Noriega, the former dictator of Panama, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against the maker of the popular Call of Duty: Black Ops II video game, saying his image was used in the game without his permission.

title: Gene Therapy Is Used to Adjust Pigs Heartbeat
description: By injecting a gene into a pigs heart, scientists have created a biological pacemaker that can regulate heartbeats, an achievement that eventually may lead to an alternative to electronic pacemakers in some people.

title: Saturday Night Live Loses 4 Performers
description: Updated, 3:44 p.m. | Not many comedians will know what it is like to be a cast member of Saturday Night Live; at least Brooks Wheelan, John Milhiser and Nol Wells can say they were part of that NBC late-night comedy franchise for one year. But all three of those featured performers who joined SNL in last fall  a season that began with Tina Fey poking fun at the dispensability of the shows rookie players  are now gone.

title: Boys Drawn to Gaza Beach, and Into Center of Mideast Strife
description: GAZA CITY  The four Bakr boys were young cousins, the children of Gaza fishermen who had ordered them to stay indoors  and especially away from the beach. But cooped up for nine days during Israeli bombardments, the children defied their parents and went out Wednesday afternoon, the eldest shooing away his little brother, telling him it was too dangerous.

title: Reform Conservatism and Foreign Policy
description: The recent dust-up between Rand Paul and Rick Perry (among other Paul critics) makes for a good occasion to add another entry tomyserieson critiquesof reform conservatism  this time, responding to the suggestion that our movement either doesnt offer any foreign policy ideas, or else is shackled to the carcass of Bush-era neoconservatism. The former critique is, in a way, complimentary, a testament to our tendencys newfound influence (first they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they demand that you supply a foreign policy agenda as well ); the latter strikes me as mostly ill-founded but somewhat understandable. Heres Andrew Sullivan making bothat once:

title: Did a Headline on Germanys Global Might Go Too Far?
description: When Germany won the World Cup earlier this week, not just the sports pages of The Times took note. The news pages featured a story on the joyful mood in Germany, but the headline bothered some German readers, who said it played into offensive stereotypes. It read: Germans See World Cup Win as Symbol of Global Might.

title: Mystery Solved on Names and Money Behind Thad Cochran Ads
description: One of the oddities of the oddity-filled Mississippi runoff between Thad Cochran and Chris McDaniel was the newspaper ads aimed at turning out black voters for Mr. Cochran, the Republican senator who narrowly won the June 24 election.

title: Detroit Institute of Arts Receives Nearly $27 Million From Businesses
description: More companies are digging into their pockets to help save the collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts from being sold off to help pay municipal debts in the citys federal bankruptcy.

title: Lena Dunhams Book Tour Is a Hot Ticket
description: Lena Dunhams coming tour to promote her book Not That Kind of Girl, is already partly sold out, nearly three months before it kicks off in New York City on Sept. 30, and only a day after Ms. Dunham announced her itinerary on Twitter.

title: The Trials of Graham Spanier, Penn States Ousted President
description: On the day the police arrived at the home of Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach, to arrest him on multiple counts of child sexual abuse, Graham Spanier was beginning his 17th year as Penn States president. It was an extraordinary tenure, and one that had seemed most likely to continue for many more years. A man of ceaseless energy and considerable ego, Spanier led the university as it grew from a remote outpost of American higher education into a top-tier public university.

title: Euro Comes Back Into Investor Favor
description: FRANKFURT  The euro appears to be regaining favor with international investors.

title: Apple Could Pay $400 Million in E-Books Price-Fixing Case
description: The number is in for how much Apple might have to pay to consumers to settle charges of conspiring with publishers to raise e-book prices: $400 million.

title: Russia Plans to Reopen Post in Cuba for Spying
description: MOSCOW  Russia has decided to reopen an electronic eavesdropping post in Cuba that it closed more than a decade ago, reaching out for a onetime symbol of its global superpower status, Russian officials and newspaper reports said on Wednesday.

title: The Big Electoral Consequences of Splitting California Six Ways
description: The supporters of a proposal to split California into six states say they have enough signatures to place their proposal on the ballot in 2016.

title: Bank of America Still Struggles to Churn Out Solid Earnings
description: Bank of America is stuck in a low-profitability trap. Several businesses at the bank actually put in a good showing for the second quarter. The trouble is, Bank of America as a whole is still struggling to churn out solid earnings  even after aggressive cost-cutting.

title: South Africa Cycling, With Cultural Side Trips
description: VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations new tour, Cycling South Africa: Cape Town and the Garden Route, includes more than sightseeing.

title: Dusting Off the 2-Iron and Bracing for the Links
description: HOYLAKE, England  Players take great care setting the table for the British Open, a formal  and for many, foreign  event. For this one week, many will take out and polish off a club that, like a salad fork, is reserved for special occasions. It is the 2-iron, the nearest thing the golfers have in their bag to a repellent for the British links courses biggest pest, the pothole bunker.

title: Game of Thorns
description: In 2011, when Jasmin Larian was 21 and a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology, she started making silk floral crowns in her spare time for herself and her friends to wear out on the town. Her designs were modest  white and pink roses on a simple wire frame  but they sparked immediate reactions from strangers.

title: Republicans and Democrats Agree, the C.D.C. Was Incredibly Sloppy
description: Republicans and Democrats in the strife-ridden House of Representatives miraculously found common ground at a hearing today. The subject: the sloppiness of researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in mishandling dangerous pathogens and sending them out to other laboratories without completely inactivating them. The universal response: dismay and incredulity.

title: Refugee From Sitcom Land, Guzzling a Bile Cocktail
description: For seven seasons, the writer Mark Roberts served as an executive producer on Two and a Half Men. Apparently, this has made him angry. Dangerously angry. Batten-down-the-hatches, threat-level-red, oh-God-I-think-he-might-actually-stroke-out angry.

title: Raising Stakes on Russia, U.S. Adds Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama imposed a new round of sanctions against Russia on Wednesday, targeting some of the crown jewels of the countrys financial, energy and defense industries in what officials described as the most punishing measures taken to date by the United States in retaliation for Moscows intervention in Ukraine.

title: Sia Scores Her First No. 1 Album
description: Sia Furler, the Australian-born musician who writes monster hits for Rihanna and Beyonc yet has had an uneasy relationship with fame in her solo career, has scored her first No. 1 album.

title: And You Thought Your Teenage Years Were Tough
description: What a difference four years make. The summer of 2010 brought Michael Korytas So Cold the River, a long, spooky, overplotted book that featured haunted mineral water and a hotel that brought The Shining to mind. The summer of 2014 brings Those Who Wish Me Dead, a lean, propulsive action-adventure thriller with a raging forest fire as its backdrop and with much more finesse than that description might suggest. The ingenious tricks and conversational wit of Those Who Wish Me Dead dont usually come with this territory.

title: S.U.V.s and Crossovers Eclipse Sedans in Popularity
description: Americans dont seem to like station wagons much, but their slightly trucklike counterparts  sport utility vehicles and crossovers  have swelled in popularity over the last few years.

title: E.U. Meets to Consider More Sanctions on Russia
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders met here on Wednesday under pressure to strengthen their response to Russia after the latest spasm of violence in Ukraine and to overcome divisions about who should become the blocs next foreign policy chief.

title: California Death Penalty System Is Unconstitutional, Federal Judge Rules
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  A federal judge ruled Wednesday that Californias death penalty system is so arbitrary and plagued with delay that it is unconstitutional, a decision that is expected to inspire similar arguments in death penalty appeals around the country.

title: Refusing to Quit, American Is Surrounded by Cheers After a Lonely Finish
description: OYONNAX, France  The American rider Andrew Talanskys hopes of winning the Tour de France effectively vanished after two crashes last week. But he became another kind of cycling hero Wednesday: the rider who would not quit when he probably should have.

title: Emergency Routine in Israel: 30 Seconds to Run for Cover
description: ASHKELON, Israel  The usual crowd had gathered behind the police cordons after a rocket struck the yard of a house in this seaside town in southern Israel on Wednesday: police officers, a bomb disposal squad, neighbors, municipal social workers, reporters and television crews.

title: Excerpt: Piece of My Heart
description: A scene from the number I Want Candy from the musical Piece of My Heart, about the songwriter Bert Berns.

title: Many-Hit Wonder, Out of Obscurity
description: Even in his mid-1960s heyday, Bert Berns was barely known beyond the obsessives who studied songwriters and producers credits on 45 r.p.m. records and LP album jackets. And then, after his death in 1967 at the age of 38, something truly odd happened: Though the songs he wrote and produced, like Twist and Shout and Hang On Sloopy, proved to have durability, growing in stature and popularity as the years passed, Bernss own reputation receded even further into obscurity.

title: The Lake Is Frozen in Time
description: Returning to New York after nine years, the Bolshoi Ballet  the most heroically warm-blooded of ballet companies  seems keen to prove that it has reverted to the ghastly artistic torpor it enjoyed in the last two decades of the Soviet era. For a short time this century (thanks principally to the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, who was for a few years its artistic director), this flagship company became an important center of new choreography and home to major revivals that changed Russias and the worlds view of dance history. But the three productions that its showing as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, all deriving from an earlier era, have been seen here before  a lot  and none of them are good.

title: My Gigolo Is Waiting (Hes Much More Fun)
description: Looking at someone elses marriage is a bit like hearing about someone elses dream  unless something truly awful happened, its kind of a bore.

title: Making Discreet House Calls for the Rich and Mortified
description: College students eager to study something that could actually secure them a job after graduation might consider majoring in fixing. Fixers  people who make the mistakes of rich and famous idiots go away  are popping up regularly on scripted television these days, which presumably means theyre in demand in real life as well.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: 3 Things to Know About Niacin and Heart Health
description: Recent studies published in The New England Journal of Medicine are adding to concerns about the safety and effectiveness of niacin, a popular drug for the prevention of cardiovascular disease. The studies reveal that although this B vitamin can reduce triglyceride levels, raise good cholesterol levels (HDL) and reduce bad cholesterol levels (LDL), it does not produce the benefits that patients and their doctors might expect. And the studies are revealing serious harms. Here are three things you need to know about niacin.

title: Clad in Shorter Skirts, the Better to Let Loose
description: The final installment of the Lincoln Center Festivals retrospective of early works by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker began with something conspicuously absent from the preceding three pieces: a man.

title: World Cup Withdrawal
description: WASHINGTON  If you are like me, you are suffering from post-World Cup depression.

title: On the Trail of True Grit: A Tale Comes to Life
description: On a January night in Fort Smith, Ark., on a desolate block off the main drag of Garrison Avenue, I was having a nightcap of Knob Creek on the rocks at Does Eat Place, after consuming two tamales with chili, a three-inch-thick eight-ounce filet and a couple of glasses of cabernet sauvignon. The motley collection of sports and historical memorabilia hanging on the walls cultivated a divey atmosphere consistent across Does eight Southern locations.

title: Easily Encrypt Your Email
description: Molly Wood explains how you can use several tools to encrypt your email and lock down your communications.

title: Easier Ways to Protect Email From Unwanted Prying Eyes
description: ITS time to face reality: Pursuing digital security should be as much of a no-brainer as locking your door before you leave the house.

title: House Committee Debates Suing Obama
description: Members of the House Rules Committee discussed the merits of a lawsuit against President Obama over his use of executive powers.

title: Bombs and Blood: Photographing Gaza
description: What has it been like to photograph the conflict in the Gaza Strip this past week? Tyler Hicks, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer, has been there for The Times. On Wednesday he photographed the aftermath of the killing of four boys on a beach. We asked him about his experience since he arrived.

title: Despite Security Breach, eBay Posts Profit and Sees Steady Growth
description: EBay on Wednesday showed slow but steady growth in the latest quarter despite a wide-ranging security breach.

title: This Is the Best Anti-Superhero Movie of the Summer
description: Bong Joon-hos Snowpiercertakes place on a train carrying the survivors of a human-engineered disaster that has frozen the earth. While the poor are forced to cram into tight quarters and eat disgusting protein blocks, the rich eat sushi or sit knitting in an orange orchard. The setup has inspired comparisons to our pre-apocalyptic world  but just what Snowpiercer says about that world is a matter of some debate. (Be warned: Spoilers follow.)

title: A Smartphone for Consumers Who Want Privacy
description: IF theres a symbol for the idea that privacy is on peoples minds, its the Blackphone.

title: Exit Roils Supporters of Womens Theater
description: Julie Crosbys abrupt departure as the producing artistic director of Womens Project Theater has led most of its advisory board and several members of the board of directors to quit, saying that her exit endangers the 36-year-old theater.

title: Hounded by Reality, Staging a Fairy Tale
description: The cast of The Snow Queen was rehearsing in a cramped Midtown studio, the floor littered with costume pieces, props and musical instruments, as staff members watched and took notes. Oh, the journey is the end, and the end is the beginning, the actors sang, ahead of their own beginning: the opening of their production, which runs through Sunday in the annual New York Musical Theater Festival.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Syria and Japan.

title: Bessies Dance Prize Nominees Announced; Choreographers Honored
description: Nominations for one of the dance worlds most prestigious annual prizes, known formally as the New York Dance and Performance Awards, but better known as the Bessies (after the influential teacher Bessie Schonberg), were announced on Wednesday by the Bessies selection committee.

title: Star Anchors Real Sin May Have Been Hypocrisy
description: The Chinese term for schadenfreude is xingzai lehuo (), and it does not take long for the sentiment to surface at the mention of Rui Chenggang, the smooth-talking state television anchor who was handed to prosecutors last Friday.

title: A Different Aging in Place
description: I have a confession. Im 47 years old, and I still live at home. Sort of; I do have my own apartment. But I still live in the house I was born into, a five-story Brooklyn Heights townhouse.

title: Burt Shavitz, the Worlds Most Famous Retired Beekeeper
description: In the new documentary Burts Buzz, Burt Shavitz, a founder of the cosmetics company Burts Bees, reveals himself to be the ultimate homebody.

title: From Sows Ear to Silk Purse
description: Nathan Devine, the founder of Retrash.com, likes to point out that his new book, also called Retrash, is printed on 100-percent recycled paper. This is fitting: The illustrated, self-published book, which was financed through a crowdfunding site, celebrates the work of 82 artists and designers who use recycled materials. Like Jason Podlaski, who makes furniture from broken skateboard decks, and Gilles Eichenbaum, who turns teakettles into stunningly delicate lamps.

title: Debt Shall Have No Dominion
description: Update: Douglas Elmendorf, director of the CBO, emails me to point out that there is (and it says so in the report) a tilt to nominal growth and interest rates, so that growth exceeds interest for the first decade but falls below it thereafter. This means that there is a bit of a debt spiral post 2025 or so. But its still nothing like the rhetoric.

title: Old Friend, New Collections
description: No question, Buddy Warrens first Manhattan antiques store, Cranberry Hole Road, was an original. It had a coffee bar downstairs and a place for Mr. Warren to conduct family therapy sessions upstairs. That boutique closed in 2004, but the psychologist-turned-interior-decorator-and-licensed-contractor is back with another retail adventure. His new self-named shop (left photo) sits in a 19th-century building on the Lower East Side that began life as a barn. About a third of the items are Mr. Warrens own concoctions, like an iron cage table with a base sliced from an 18th-century marble column and a glass top ($950, seen in right photo). The rest ranges from cleansing bars made by a New Hampshire beekeeper ($6) to authentic Windsor chairs ($14,000 for a set of eight). Coffee is still served, but upstairs is now for workshops on themes like organization. 171 Chrystie Street (Rivington Street). Information: 212-727-8400 or buddywarren.com.

title: Should I Replace My Mustard Toilet, Sink and Tub Before Listing the Apartment?
description: Q. The toilet, sink and tub in my bathroom are all a very retro shade of mustard. Should I replace them before putting my apartment on the market?

title: All You Need Is Love and $189 a Night
description: For those who want to relive the Age of Aquarius, there is the Hotel Dylan, which opened last month in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Divide and Conquer
description: For apartment-bound New Yorkers who dream of discovering new rooms, Joel Klein, a builder in Brooklyn, offers them not by addition but by subtraction. His Tudelu wall, which glides up and down on motorized rollers, provides visual separation along with soundproofing as good as any Sheetrock, he said. The coated-vinyl surface is decorative, too, and can be customized with any motif: an ersatz library, say, or rural scene, portrait, supergraphic or solid color.

title: The Internet of Things
description: David Rose, the author of Enchanted Objects, sees a future where we can all live like wizards.

title: Large Round of Layoffs Expected at Microsoft
description: Updated, 8:35 a.m. | Microsoft on Thursday announced it would cut up to 18,000 jobs, which amounts to almost 15 percent of its work force.

title: Discounts at Kim Seybert, Ameico, Lalique and Patch NYC
description: Kim Seybert accessories are up to 65 percent off through Sunday (a set of four Indian Summer beaded place mats, originally $512, is about $282); 212-564-7850, kimseybert.com.

title: Criminal Software, Government-Grade Protection
description: The arms race between criminal hackers and targeted companies just became a little more military, with serious implications for business.

title: Working All the Angles
description: How does this space become an event? was the question Scott Bruckner posed to the architects he hired to remodel the 3,800-square-foot apartment he bought in a new building in TriBeCa in 2007, for $6.5 million. Mr. Bruckner, a financier who had spent much of his career working overseas and had returned to New York to join Perella Weinberg Partners, an international asset management firm, had been in the apartment for about a year. And while it was big and airy and I liked the location, he said, it was little more than a static white space.

title: Putting Magic in the Mundane
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS.  David Rose was taking this reporters photo. Every 30 seconds, with a cracker-size plastic clip he wore on the placket of his short-sleeved blue plaid shirt.

title: When Scientists Commit Fraud
For-Profit Colleges, Supported by Taxpayer Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Lessons From Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Martel Enters the Hall of Fame
description: LAS VEGAS  Two players were voted into the Hall of Fame this year by their peers: Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif. (Meyers was featured in Mondays column.)

title: A Fathers Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: Buyouts for Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: The Role of University Trustees
description: To the Editor:

title: Stunts, Tricks and Effects (Boredom Not Allowed)
description: Pilobolus knows how to pack a lot into two hours. On Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, opening night of that companys annual monthlong run there, the bang-for-your-buck variety included magic tricks, gymnastic stunts, large-scale shadow puppetry, stripteases and, just when you thought things couldnt get more explosive, a short film of stuff blowing up (household items mostly, in slow motion, courtesy of the Danish TV show Dumt & Farligt). To ensure our sustained overstimulation  lest we feel bored (not allowed)  video interludes like that one filled the transitions between the five works on Program A.

title: Rescuing a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: And Then the Singer Dances in a Hooded Leopard Suit
description: The Cuban percussionist and singer Romn Daz spreads a strong, cool presence evenly through a room. When hes a sideman, he makes the side fold into the center; when hes the center, he radiates power without anxiety, letting the focus shift.

title: The Dangers of Private Planes
description: SUMMER is the season when the pilots of private planes like to take to the skies. But summer flying often means thunderstorms and extreme changes in weather that can lead to accidents. Its also a time to think about a system that doesnt do all it can to protect those pilots and passengers. Flying in small private planes is far riskier than flying in commercial aircraft.

title: Time Warner Chief on Murdochs Bid
description: Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief of Time Warner, confirms the rejection of 21st Century Foxs $80 billion bid in a video sent to employees and posted online.

title: On the Nice Internet, Caring Is Sharing
description: On a bright afternoon, Alex Magnin, chief revenue officer of the website Thought Catalog, strolled through Dolores Park in San Francisco, sipping a cup of green tea. Mr. Magnin, 29 and clad in a rumpled plaid shirt, was visiting from Brooklyn, where Thought Catalog is loosely based (most contributors work out of their homes), to connect with some of the sites West Coast staff members.

title: She Wears Her Feelings
description: Lining both sides of the Avenida lvaro Obregn, a main artery in the Roma Norte neighborhood of Mexico City, are the remnants of a strong European influence  so strong that many of the old buildings survived the 1985 earthquake, while more-modern structures crumbled. Today, converted pastel-colored houses dating from the early 1900s contain restaurants, boutiques and popular mezcal bars. Camila Sarasola Montiel often wanders through the sculpture garden that divides the main avenue, drawing style inspiration from the mix of old and new. This interview has been edited. FRITZIE ANDRADE

title: Funding Circle, a Peer-to-Peer Lender, Raises $65 Million
description: Silicon Valley has been working on new ways to bolster the flow of capital to small businesses, one of the nations main engines of economic growth. Those efforts took another step forward on Wednesday, when Funding Circle, a so-called peer-to-peer lending network, announced that it had raised $65 million in new funding and appointed Robert K. Steel, the chief executive of Perella Weinberg, to its board.

title: The Mystery in the Machine
description: LOS ANGELES  During the six years I begged my husband to get me pregnant, I kept certain images locked away in a mental hope chest. The first was the moment of conception  one of those lazy Sunday afternoons, post-brunch and newspaper, pre-dinner and a compelling HBO lineup, the two of us resting atop rumpled sheets.

title: Icahn and Ackman Publicly End Feud With an Embrace
description: A dispute between two billionaire investors, Carl C. Icahn and William A. Ackman, ended with a phone call a few weeks ago and, on Wednesday, a public embrace.

title: The Scrunchie Grows Up
description: Last summer, Katalina Sharkey de Solis was watching the 1988 film Heathers with her friend Ruthie Friedlander when she had a fashion epiphany. In the movie, the scrunchie, so ubiquitous in the 80s and early 90s, was a sign of power. Ms. Sharkey de Solis, who is a managing director at an ad agency, was ready for the comeback.

title: Sheltering Sky in Williamsburg
description: Yes, they exist: die-hard Manhattanites who still regard Brooklyn as a wasteland roamed by wolves. Their outpost could be Sheltering Sky, a month-old rooftop bar in Williamsburg named after Paul Bowless novel about a weary New Yorker who flees civilization for the Saharan wilderness.

title: Obama Hints at Extension for Iran Nuclear Talks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Wednesday that there had been real progress in several areas in negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program, and he hinted that he might extend the talks beyond the deadline on Sunday in order to reach a final agreement.

title: Music Holdings Are Noticeably Absent in Proposed Fox-Time Warner Merger
description: If the takeover of Time Warner by 21st Century Fox goes through, one company would hold sway over a vast array of media assets, including two Hollywood studios, multiple broadcast and cable television channels and properties like HBO. Yet should a merger happen, it would also be defined by what assets are under one umbrella.

title: Lightly Worn, Heavily Shared
description: After Brenda Edmondson lost 50 pounds over the course of a year, she wanted to buy a new wardrobe. But first, she needed to get rid of her old clothes. I decided I needed to purge my closet, said Ms. Edmondson, 47, who lives in Brentwood, Tenn.

title: Father and Son; Making Photos While Breaking the Rules
description: Jeff and Henry Jacobson, father and son who are both photographers, discuss their visual influences and making pictures on film and on Instagram.

title: Reclaiming Our (Real) Lives From Social Media
description: One day in the early 1920s, a young Ernest Hemingway rushed along the streets of Paris seeking shelter from a downpour. He soon came upon a warm cafe on the Place St.-Michel and ducked inside.

title: Sales and New Products in New York City
description: Sales

title: Data Delayed Is Democracy Denied
description: WASHINGTON  BILLIONS of dollars are being spent in the run-up to this Novembers midterm elections. The Supreme Court has struck down limits on campaign spending by corporations and unions, as well as overall caps on individual donations to candidates for federal office. More and more money is also being spent through ostensibly independent super PACs and nonprofit entities.

title: Effort to Avoid Vote on Fracking Falters in Colorado
description: Efforts by leading Colorado Democrats to head off a costly and divisive election-year fight over oil and gas drilling appeared to crumble on Wednesday as Gov. John W. Hickenlooper announced that he did not have enough support to pass a compromise law giving local towns more control over fracking in their backyards.

title: Tunisian Whom U.S. Accused of Plotting Terrorist Acts Is Sentenced to Time Served
description: A Tunisian man whom prosecutors had accused of seeking to engage in terrorist acts against targets in the United States and other countries was sentenced on Wednesday to the time he had served in prison since his arrest 15 months ago.

title: Tears for the Border Children
description: The fight over how to process and care for masses of children from Central America who have crossed into this country is quickly becoming a spectacle of the obscene.

title: The Cultures Along the Waterfront
description: A different crowd gravitates to each of three coastal spots in New York.

title: President Obama on Russian Sanctions
description: At the White House, the president discussed his administrations escalated sanctions against Russia.

title: No Place Like Home
description: Summer in the city used to mean open fire hydrants, barbecues on fire escapes and those dreaded street fairs. Lounging by the water? You were lucky if you made it to the freak show called Coney Island once.

title: New York City Summer Pop-Up Events
description: Whether its a temporary store or limited-run art, New York is awash in pop-up events. Here are our suggestions for the rest of the summer, but you can pick and choose as you like.

title: Three Tips To Finding Social Media Balance
description: Social media starts out as something you check occasionally, but before long, it takes over your life. You stop reading books or sitting with yourself quietly. Instead, you check Facebook. Then check it again. And again.

title: Casting the Catwalk, Saint Laurent Style
description: PAT CLEVELAND SKIPPED off to Paris in the early 1970s, intending to ditch her career. I thought, Im going to stop modeling, Ms. Cleveland reminisced the other day. Her plans were derailed when, wearing a poncho and jeans, she encountered the designer Fernando Sanchez, who directed her glance toward a second-story window where his friend Yves Saint Laurent stood gazing at her avidly.

title: Light Therapy for Home Use Catches On
description: In January, Jill Addeo, 49, visited the Park Avenue office of Dr. Z. Paul Lorenc, a plastic surgeon, seeking to reduce her hyper-pigmentation and wrinkles from sun damage and aging.

title: Jamie Biden: A D.J. Related to a V.P.
description: AGE 32

title: Senate Expected to Focus on G.M. Lawyers Role
description: DETROIT  A Senate panel on Thursday will zero in on how General Motors hid a deadly vehicle defect for years, and what can be done to prevent corporations from keeping safety issues secret from consumers and regulators.

title: Heineken Hopes Star Power Will Do the Trick
description: NEIL Patrick Harris is, as the saying goes, a man of many talents: actor, singer, comedian, awards show host and star of television, film and Broadway. For a campaign that is to begin on Thursday, it is his skills as a magician that may come in handy.

title: What Standards of Child Labor Should Apply Overseas?
Months After Washington Landslide, Hopeful Steps Forward
description: DARRINGTON, Wash.  The Miller familys bluegrass band, Blueberry Hill, has deep roots in this little mountain town on the edge of the Oso landslide, which killed more than 40 people in late March in a few shattering seconds of geological upheaval. Aida Miller, 19, who sings and plays the mandolin, and her brother, Forrest, 17, a banjo player, were both born here.

title: A Potential Combination of Two of Hollywoods Most Successful Studios
description: LOS ANGELES  What for years has been a whisper in Hollywood  the possible consolidation of major studios in the face of tough industry economics  has become a starkly real option with the disclosure on Wednesday that Rupert Murdochs 21st Century Fox made an $80 billion bid to acquire Time Warner Inc.

title: President Obama on Middle East Fighting
description: At an appearance at the White House, the president discussed the ongoing conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: C.D.C. Director Admits to Pattern of Unsafe Practices
description: Under sharp questioning from members of Congress on Wednesday, Dr. Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, admitted that recent laboratory accidents involving flu viruses and anthrax were not isolated mistakes, but rather part of a broader problem of unsafe practices at the agency.

title: De Blasio Takes a Vacation, and a Calculated Risk
description: Vacations are not so simple when you happen to be the mayor of New York.

title: In Pursuit of Bluefish on Venerable Party Boat
description: Plumb Beach, Brooklyn: Brawny and brutish, with teeth like stilettos, a bluefish on the line is bound to wake you from the lassitude brought on by even the most dolorous winter. This season, I looked on with mounting interest as the Internet ignited with reports of bluefish action.

title: For Iraq, Debacle in Tikrit as Forces Walk Into Trap Set by Militants
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi troops and their militia and volunteer allies were on the verge of declaring victory over Sunni militants holding the strategic town of Tikrit and were about to hoist the Iraqi flag over key government buildings, when, a survivor recalled Wednesday, the doors of hell opened.

title: Texas: Actress Gets 18-Year Sentence in Ricin Case
description: An actress was sentenced Wednesday to 18 years in federal prison for mailing ricin-laced letters in May 2013 to President Obama and former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York. The actress, Shannon Guess Richardson, 35, pleaded guilty to possession of a toxin for use as a weapon. Prosecutors said Ms. Richardson placed ricin onto letters sent to Mr. Obama, Mr. Bloomberg and Mark Glaze, at the time the director of Mayors Against Illegal Guns. Ms. Richardson, who played a zombie on The Walking Dead, among other small roles, had falsely accused her husband of mailing the letters.

title: Through Lens, 4 Boys Dead by Gaza Shore
description: GAZA CITY  My day here began at 6 a.m. Photographing something as unpredictable as war still has a routine.

title: Jeters Farewell Helps Reverse All-Star Games Ratings Slide
description: Derek Jeters mission on Tuesday night, whether he knew it or not, was to increase the audience for the All-Star Game, the last one he will play in.

title: V.A. Official Says Fixing Issues at Root of Waiting-List Scandal Will Cost Billions
description: Fixing the problems that led to the waiting-list scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs will cost $17.6 billion over the next three years, the agencys acting secretary told lawmakers Wednesday, requiring the hiring of about 1,500 doctors and 8,500 nurses and other clinicians.

title: Obama Likely to Seek Additional Time for Nuclear Negotiations With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said on Wednesday that he believed the United States had a credible way forward in its nuclear negotiations with Iran, and strongly suggested that after consultations with Congress, which has been threatening additional sanctions, he would seek an extension of the talks beyond Sundays deadline.

title: In Modern Media Realm, Big Mergers Are a Bulwark Against Rivals
description: When the news broke on Wednesday that 21st Century Fox, Rupert Murdochs huge media and entertainment company, made an $80 billion offer to buy Time Warner Inc., another big media conglomerate, it seemed like a seismic jolt in the business landscape. If the deal is ever consummated, 21st Century Fox, a public company in name only that the Murdoch family essentially controls, would oversee much of the content consumed by Americans.

title: Leading Through Great Loss
description: In the carnage of Gaza and the Middle East, the most unlikely people have stepped forward from their grief to offer moral leadership.

title: In a Potential Merger, Numerous Pieces
description: From sports and movies, to news and prime-time entertainment, theres little a combined Time Warner and 21st Century Fox wouldnt touch. Here, a look at what the divisions of each company contain.

title: Shunting the Homeless From Sight
description: Is homelessness a crime? The question was answered forthrightly in the negative last month by a federal appeals court ruling that struck down a Los Angeles ban on citizens living out of their automobiles as a desperate necessity in hard times. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit pronounced the ban  an important part of the citys anti-homelessness campaign  to be a broad and cryptic law that criminalizes innocent behavior.

title: Affirmative Action Survives in Texas
description: For the second time since 2011, a federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld the policy at the University of Texas at Austin to consider race as a factor in some of its admissions decisions. The ruling could well put the affirmative action issue back before the Supreme Court as soon as the coming term.

title: Keep Negotiating on Irans Nukes
description: Despite six months of negotiations, it seems unlikely that Iran and the major powers will complete an agreement limiting Irans nuclear program by a self-imposed July 20 deadline. But they have left open the possibility of extending talks for up to six more months.

title: A Symbol of City Hoops, and Now Globalization
description: The rain is tossing down monsoonal outside, but inside the gym in the South Bronx, Im about to watch a glorious basketball heist.

title: Bergdahls Lawyer Sees a Rare Case With Myriad Legal Options
description: SEATTLE  The legal road ahead for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, whose capture by the Taliban in Afghanistan in 2009 is under investigation by the Army, is both narrowly constrained by Army procedures and at the same time open to almost complete discretion in what course the Army might take, from exoneration to court-martial, his lawyer said Wednesday.

title: International Coach Prepares for N.B.A. Debut
description: LAS VEGAS  J. R. Holden was furious with himself as he headed to the bench for a timeout. Here he was, late in the finals of EuroBasket 2007  the tournament to determine the champion of Europe  and Holden, a naturalized Russian, was wondering if his citizenship might be revoked.

title: Time Warner Chiefs Turnaround Effort Opened the Door to Foxs Bid
description: On a Saturday in early June, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief executive of Time Warner, got an email from Chase Carey, the president of 21st Century Fox, proposing lunch.

title: Political Duel for California Governor Spans Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Gov. Jerry Brown has a little-known Republican challenger campaigning against him across California, taunting him on issues from taxes to transit. But his most formidable Republican adversary is turning out to be a fellow Californian who wields his power from an office 2,700 miles away: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the incoming House majority leader.

title: Questions of Justice in Tunisia as Ousted Leaders Are Freed

title: The Weird, Scary and Ingenious Brain of Maria Bamford
description: Maria Bamford has a mantra of sorts, and here it is: Do the work. Three words, three syllables. An easy, orderly thing. She tells it to herself when she wakes up in the morning, whether its at her bungalow in a middle-class neighborhood on the outskirts of Los Angeles or at a Holiday Inn in Boston or a Marriott in Bloomington, or any of the other highway-side hotels she hits for one night before moving on. Do the work. Its a stay against paralysis, against the descent of dread. Its less dramatic than seize the day! more affirming than stop overthinking everything! It is functional, and thats what shes trying to be. Do the work. She repeats it on airplanes, in taxis, on the long walks she takes to calm her nerves before a show. Sometimes she amends it to: Just do the work, the just a reminder that shes not, after all, performing surgery on babies. Theres another, more refined version, too. Do your bits, shell tell herself, resigned to the idea that this may always be a struggle. Just do your bits.

title: 10 Questions for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey
description: Chris Christie has returned to the national spotlight in recent weeks, attending the National Governors Association meeting in Nashville, a media and technology gathering in Idaho, and making a campaign trip to Iowa. Mr. Christie, a New Jersey Republican and potential presidential candidate in 2016 who is recovering from political wounds caused by a lane-closure scandal, sat down with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC on Wednesday at CNBCs Delivering Alpha conference in New York to discuss his party, his states pension shortfall, the bridge-closure controversy and his presidential prospects. What follows is a condensed, edited transcript of the conversation.

title: A Tenacious Show Finds a New Stage
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, MASS.  Even by the standards of the long and winding development process for your average Broadway musical  in which books get overhauled, songwriting teams are replaced, and directors are given the ax  the journey of the Kander and Ebb show The Visit, adapted from Friedrich Drrenmatts 1956 satire of greed and revenge, has seemed particularly tortuous and misfortune plagued.

title: Aftermath of Deadly Gunfight in Pakistan
description: The attack outside of Lahore was about a mile from the country estate of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and lasted for several hours.

title: Are More Companies Offering Health Insurance? For an Answer, Look to Massachusetts
description: For years, The Agenda has reported dueling predictions from economists and other pundits about whether businesses, especially small businesses, will stop offering health insurance rather than comply with the requirements of the Affordable Care Act. For an example, see Ezekiel J. Emanuels claim that by 2020, more than 80 percent of private-sector workers will buy their own insurance.

title: New Guidelines Proposed
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo offers the first of several new proposals to strengthen ethics laws.

title: Goodbye to Cloth Diapers, and Ideal Motherhood
description: I cloth diapered my daughter until she was 2, and she began using the toilet. And when I had my son, I was determined to continue. After all, I loved cloth diapering. I loved talking diapers with moms at the park and in forums online. I learned about washing strategies and making my own detergent and became fluent in diaper speak: soaker pads, Kushies, liners, Flips. And do you like AIOs or prefolds?

title: Not Open to Compromising
description: Governor Cuomo says he will not accept a watered-down agreement on ethics.

title: The Challenges of Empire
description: As a supplement tomy last post, which ended by discussing some of the difficulties inherent in devising a point-by-point foreign policy agenda  difficulties thatthe horrific news from Ukrainethrow into sharp relief  let me quote from a new essay from The American Conservatives editor, Daniel McCarthy, onthe subject of liberalism and empireand (he argues) the dependence of the former on the latter. The essay as a whole is an extended discussion of our current end-of-history era, engaged with some of the same questions asMark Lilla,Steven Pinker, and other writers frequently discussed in this space. But its conclusion speaks directly to the moments foreign policy debates, offering critiques of both the anti-imperial left and the interventionist right, qualified sympathy for what McCarthy calls anti-liberal anti-imperialists(like his magazines founder, Pat Buchanan, and the late George Kennan, who are among our greatest critics but preach what a liberal nation will not hear), before coming around to a qualified endorsement of a conservative realism in the service of a liberal empire:

title: Elaine Stritch, Broadways Enduring Dame, Dies at 89
description: Elaine Stritch, the brassy, tart-tongued Broadway actress and singer who became a living emblem of show business durability and perhaps the leading interpreter of Stephen Sondheims wryly acrid musings on aging, died on Thursday at her home in Birmingham, Mich. She was 89.

title: The Red Carpet at the ESPYs
description: Cameron Diaz and Jessica Alba were among the best dressed at the award show.

title: Shubert Organization Set To Add New World Stages
description: The Shubert Organization, a major Broadway player that owns 17 of the 40 theaters there, is positioning itself to move into the commercial Off Broadway sector in a significant way with the acquisition of the New World Stages complex, according to three theater executives with knowledge of the expected deal.
