description: Question:

title: An Edification Vacation
description: Before I turned left in Manhattan and drove some 420 miles to the Chautauqua Institution in the southwest corner of New York State, I asked a worldly and cultured New York City friend what she knew about the place. Its in Westchester, she advised me, but I think its pronounced Chappaqua.

title: Officials Security Details Bring Neighbors Peace of Mind and Headaches
description: WASHINGTON  Outside Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.s Northwest Washington colonial and Secretary of State John Kerrys historic Georgetown Federal, armed security guards wait with car engines humming.

title: Small Packages Hold Great Pleasure
description: They sounded cute, brisket tots, and looked it, dark checkers of meat breaded and crisped, faintly ridiculous in their mini casserole dish. They made me laugh, and then I tasted one. It had the flavor of meat, rich and deep, but the near weightlessness of a dolls pillow or a dandelion puff.

title: July 17 Updates on Malaysia Airlines Plane Crash in Ukraine
description: The New York Times was tracking developments in the crash of a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 with 298 people aboard in eastern Ukraine near the Russian border on Thursday. Correspondents in Washington, Moscow and in eastern Ukraineprovided updates. Sabrina Tavernise (@stavernise on Twitter) reported from the crash site and Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) reported information gleaned from social media.

title: Acrostic Answer
description: Acrostic answer for January 26, 2014

title: Afghanistan Begins Audit of Presidential Election
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan election workers on Thursday began auditing the votes cast in last months presidential election runoff, monitored by American and United Nations observers.

title: Remembering the Life and Work of Elaine Stritch
description: When health problems forced Elaine Stritch to leave New York in 2013 and head for her home state of Michigan, James Barron, writing in The New York Times, explained in one sentence what generations of fans loved about an actress who was as comfortable singing Ladies Who Lunch at the Cafe Carlyle as she was delivering a zinger in A Delicate Balance. After a hard-driving, hard-drinking life, wrote Mr. Barron, Ms. Stritch is irascible and indomitable and, to theatergoers or cabaret devotees of a certain age or mind-set, irresistible.

title: Excerpt: Pump Boys and Dinettes
description: A scene from the number Highway 57 from the Encores! Off Center production of Pump Boys and Dinettes.

title: Younguns With a Yen for Wisdom
description: A little strip of lonesome highway has plopped down at City Center, where a flavorsome revival of the chicken-fried musical revue Pump Boys and Dinettes plays through Saturday as part of the Encores! Off-Center series. Should you pull off the road for a fill-up, a Coke and a piece of pie, youll find amiable company in the shows beaming cast members, who make like a big old human jukebox as they sing of the daily grind in a gas station (the pump boys) and the roadside coffee shop nearby (the dinettes).

title: For-Profit Colleges Under Investigation
description: It seemed until recently that regulators and law enforcement agencies would never rein in the predatory for-profit colleges that enrich themselves and their shareholders by misrepresenting their programs, saddling students with high-cost loans and then shoving them out the door with useless degrees or no degrees at all. The situation began to change in 2011, when a group of state attorneys general led by Jack Conway of Kentucky joined forces to investigate a growing number of complaints from students who had been exploited. With so much happening at the state level  36 attorneys general are now involved  federal agencies had no choice but to take notice.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Delay in Case Against Rengan Rajaratnam
description: Acquitted of insider trading, the former hedge fund manager Rengan Rajaratnam may now avoid a separate court battle with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Oh, Mama! That Queen of Denmark Takes Over
description: Hamlet is indecisive. His mother, however, is a lot more resolute. In the first scene of Howard Barkers Gertrude: The Cry, the American premiere of this 2002 play by PTP/NYC at Atlantic Stage 2, she orders Claudius to kill my husband. Then she strips naked and demands sex from him astride her husbands corpse.

title: Playgrounds for Kids Who Cant Run and Jump
description: The first time I buckled Ruth in a swing she was 18 months old, but looked younger from the emaciating effects of cerebral palsy. Born in Uganda and quickly abandoned, she had spent much of her first year in an orphanage, which sent her to Maine for six months of physical therapy. Friends signed up to host her.

title: Amateur Video of Malaysia Airlines Crash
description: After a Malaysia Airlines jet crashed in Ukraine on Thursday, several amateur videos were posted online.

title: Markets of the Once Fragile Five Countries Are Now Soaring
description: The Fragile Five have become the Fantastic Five.

title: Russian Reliance on Chinese Loans May Blunt the Impact of U.S. Sanctions
description: MOSCOW  With the latest round of sanctions against Russia, the United States Treasury Department said it had increased the cost of economic isolation for key Russian firms, like the state oil company Rosneft and the banking arm of the natural gas giant Gazprom.

title: M.T.A. Chairman on the Averted Strike
description: Thomas F. Prendergast, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, on the agreement reached with Long Island Rail Road labor unions to avert a potential strike.

title: Flaws in How Mississippi Reports Elections Add to Its Problems
description: Amid the allegations of fraud and the legal wranglings over the Mississippi Republican primary and runoff elections last month, one thing is clear: The lack of timely, useful election results has not helped assure citizens the election was fair.

title: With Surge in Child Migrants, New York Forms Task Force on Aiding Them
description: New York City officials have formed a task force in response to the surging population of unaccompanied migrant children from Central America who have arrived in the city in recent months and swamped community-based groups in search of help for their deportation cases, health issues, school enrollment and other urgent needs.

title: President Obama on the Crash in Ukraine
description: At an event in Delaware, President Obama discussed the crash of a Malaysia Airlines jet, calling it a terrible tragedy.

title: At a Football Powerhouse, Her Teams Rolled, Too
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  The womens gymnastics coach at Alabama, Sarah Patterson, used to run into Pat Summitt, the storied former womens basketball coach at Tennessee, at Southeastern Conference events.

title: New York Proposes First State Regulations for Bitcoin
description: New York States top financial regulator has taken a big step to bring Bitcoin and other virtual currencies under its purview.

title: Finnish Pride Takes Another Blow From Microsoft Job Cuts
description: Finland has staked much of its national pride on the worldwide growth of Nokia, based on the outskirts of Helsinki. And many Finns still hold a lot of affection for the companys handsets.

title: Regulators Come Up With Own Plan to Coordinate Bank Supervision
description: David Zaring is associate professor of legal studies at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Maps of the Crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17
description: A Malaysia Airlines flight with nearly 300 people aboard crashed in eastern Ukraine near the Russian border on July 17.

title: The Woman
description: Clare Boothe Luce has a lot to answer for.

title: Should Republicans Do Anything About the Border Crisis?
description: I havent commented on the border situation since my column a few weeks ago, mostly because its the kind of situation (there are so many these days) where its easier to say what should have been done in the past than to figure out what the correct policy course is right now. But as House Republicans debate what kind of legislative response they intend to support, I want to say something briefly about the argument that they shouldnt back any response at all, on the theory that since the president has already claimed sweeping, dubiously-legal powers over spending flows and immigration enforcement, fixing the mess should be his responsibility alone.

title: The String of Safest Airline Years Is Over
description: The year 2012 was the safest since World War II for air travel, and 2013 was even better. Because of the two Malaysian Airlines crashes  including the airline that went down Thursday over Ukraine  this year will not be the safest on record. But it is less of an outlier than many might expect.

title: James Franco, Poet
description: If you were alive in 1985 and happened to buy Eddie Murphys album How Could It Be (featuring the hit single Party All the Time), then you may have asked yourself  in addition to wondering what shape of Band-Aid is best suited to the human ear  why it is that artists who are vastly successful in one genre feel the need to dabble in another. Because they do, a lot. Sometimes its just the case that they happen to be very good at more than one thing (by all accounts, Steve Martin is a genuinely excellent banjo player). But often there seems to be something else going on.

title: Scientists Name a Newly Discovered Water Mite After Jennifer Lopez
description: Scientists who discover new things  from microorganisms to galaxies  get to name them, and often they name them after public figures, usually ones they admire. Arnold Schwarzenegger has a muscular-looking beetle named after him; there are trilobites (an extinct, prehistoric arthropod) named for Mick Jagger and each of the Sex Pistols; and Frank Zappa has at least five animals named for him, including a jellyfish and a spider.

title: Malaysia Airlines Flight: History's Lessons in Crisis Management
description: On Oct. 27, 1962, at the zenith of the Cuban missile crisis, President Kennedy learned that an American U-2 spy plane had unintentionally penetrated Soviet air space near Alaska, drawing a complaint from the Soviets. He was concerned that the Soviet leader, Nikita Khrushchev, or those around him, might view the incursion as the deliberate forerunner of a full-scale United States invasion of his territory, which could lead quickly to nuclear war. He persuaded them that it was an accident. Of the American pilot, Kennedy bitterly said, There is always some son of a bitch who doesnt get the word.

title: AbbVie-Shire Deal Is Expected, in a Flight to a Lower-Tax Locale
description: Updated, 8:41 p.m. | The biggest deal of the year is set to be announced on Friday morning, as the pharmaceutical giant AbbVie plans to announce a $53 billion acquisition of Shire, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Poetry Profiles: Four Way Books
description: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Martha Rhodes, the director of Four Way Books.

title: By the Bees on My Chinny Chin Chin
description: Beauty is in the eye of the bee-holder. At least, thats the case in Aylmer, Ontario, on July 25, when Clovermead Apiaries hosts its 10th annual Worldwide Bee Beard Competition. The event brings together teams of insect aficionados who strut their stuff on a catwalk  while covered in thousands of confused bees  in a contest for charity to crown the queen (or king) of bee beards.

title: At Berls Brooklyn Poetry Shop, Balm for the Borrower
description: Poetry may be a noble vocation, but poets are generally an impecunious lot. Resigned to significantly less than blockbuster sales and often saddled with student loans, theyre on intimate terms with arrears. A handful of them will gather Friday night at Berls Brooklyn Poetry Shop for Write Off Debt, a reading that revolves around the concept. Organized by Ashleigh Lambert and featuring her fellow poets Max Cohen, Dustin Luke Nelson, Allyson Paty, Niina Pollari, Christopher Salerno and Emily Toder, the evening aims to imagine fresh approaches to debt.

title: 7 Indicted in $50 Million Pump-and-Dump Scheme
description: The former husband of The Sopranos actress Jamie-Lynn Sigler was indicted on Thursday along with six other defendants in a pump-and-dump stock scheme.

title: D.C. Decriminalizes Marijuana: Pot Politics Buds Along the Potomac
description: A marijuana decriminalization law took effect in the District of Columbia at 12:01 Thursday morning, but House Republicans are trying to turn back the clock.

title: Throwback Thursday | Disneyland Opens in 1955
description: Were experimenting with a new weekly feature were calling Throwback Thursday (or #tbt, as it is known on social media).

title: Glorious Views, Fancy Steps and Painful Memories
description: Like all performers at the Fire Island Dance Festival, Marcelo Gomes was awed by his surroundings when he participated for the first time in 2010. The sun, looking like a burning tangerine, descended behind him as he danced, before extinguishing itself in the bay.

title: For a Smooth Ride, Look Someplace Else
description: WAITING in line to see the Kara Walker exhibition in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, not long ago, I noticed an off-road cycling course across the street, where numerous children in helmets were zipping around. It looked like fun, so I returned on a recent sunny afternoon for what I thought would be a light two-wheeled frolic.

title: A Dukes Gilded Haven, Recreated in Paris
description: PARIS  Sections of 18th-century gilded walls and paintings of deities are sprawled across the floor of a warehouse on this citys outskirts. After nine decades in limbo, this architectural salvage is being reorganized  into period rooms that will rival Versailless for inventiveness and visual impact.

title: A New Book Explores the Art of Plants
description: From Monets Water Lilies to Andy Warhols Flowers, plants have been a perennial subject of interest for artists. Strange Plants, the first title from the new L.A.-based art book publisher Zioxla, is a celebration of this ongoing relationship. A mix of in-depth interviews with photography, paintings and sculpture from established and emerging artists, the tome ($30, available online today) explores the roles that plants play both in the creative process and in artists personal lives.

title: Fallen Bodies, Jet Parts and a Childs Pink Book
description: GRABOVO, Ukraine  Incongruously, given that the plane fell from more than 30,000 feet, many of the bodies strewn about in the smoldering wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 were largely intact. A woman in a black sweater lay on her back, blood streaming from her face, her left arm raised as if signaling someone. Another victim, naked except for a black bra, lay on the field, her gray hair mixing with the green grass, one leg broken and her body torn.

title: Using a Camera to Make More Than Memories
description: When an art show reaches the end of its run, it usually goes gently into the archives. Lately, however, a number of exhibitions from the 1960s and 70s have been coming back to haunt us.

title: To Kill a Friendship
description: Why does the writing make us chase the writer? Julian Barnes asked in Flauberts Parrot. Why cant we leave well enough alone? Why arent the books enough?

title: Cuomo on Avoiding Rail Strike
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York discusses an agreement that averted a Long Island Rail Road strike.

title: Warming Times in a Cold Land
description: Attention, moviegoers interested in aging who thought The Iron Lady was too depressing, Nebraska was too depressing, and Amour was off-the-charts depressing. Ive got a tip for you: Land Ho!

title: Wheelies: The Mustang Numbers Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Call to Fight Malaria One Mosquito at a Time by Altering DNA
description: Every year, malaria-carrying mosquitoes kill more than 600,000 people, most of them children. Over the centuries, people have battled those mosquitoes in numerous ways, like draining swamps, spraying insecticides and distributing millions of bed nets. And yet malaria remains a menace across much of the world.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: This Weekend: Bolshois Swan Lake
description: This weekend the Bolshoi Ballet brings Swan Lake to Lincoln Center; The Long Shrift, directed by James Franco, plays Off Broadway; and WEs new legal drama, The Divide, is on TV.

title: Hito Steyerl: How Not to Be Seen
description: Beginning with an unprintable adjective, the subtitle of Hito Steyerls latest New York show identifies it as a Didactic Educational Installation. But dont be misled. The show confirms that Ms. Steyerl (pronounced STYE-rill) is among the most rigorous yet playful artist-filmmakers today, and unusually skilled at working her mediums and messages into an experience of form that is anything but didactic.

title: IBM in Tug of War Between Legacy and the Leading Edge
description: For IBM, the challenge is to convert the future of technology into an opportunity rather than a threat.

title: The Morgan Gets a Gift: A Lichtenstein Trove
description: Scholars tend to seek out the Morgan Library & Museums archives as a place to research old masters and 19th-century drawings, or to peek at the letters that modern masters like Chagall and Dubuffet wrote to the art dealer Pierre Matisse. But a recent gift from the Roy Lichtenstein estate will now make the Morgan a destination for classic contemporary artists, too.

title: Events on Long Island for July 20-26, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Justice Department Indicts FedEx in a Drug-Shipping Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  FedEx, the worlds second-largest package-delivery company, was indicted Thursday in connection with a Justice Department investigation into illegal pharmaceutical shipments, according to a person with knowledge of the governments long-running investigation.

title: The Two Faces of Soave
description: Its no longer news that Italy makes great white wines. In the bad old days, the Italian whites available in the United States tended to be insipid mass-marketed brands or campy contrived bottles. But since then, a revival has introduced the world to wonderful selections from the Valle dAoste at the farthest reaches of Italys northwest, from Alto Adige and Friuli-Venezia Giulia in the extreme northeast, from Sicily at the southernmost end, and from just about everywhere in between.

title: What to Eat With Italian Soave
description: When I was quite small, I remember my mother telling me that if you put salt on your watermelon, it would taste sweeter. I never quite bought that theory  the salt made it weird to me. I still do not salt my watermelon. But I do like something that comes close: a savory, salty component that I have found does complement melon quite nicely. This was brought home to me on many occasions, traveling in Greece, Jordan, Israel and elsewhere in the Middle East, where watermelon and feta or a similar salty white cheese is often on the breakfast buffet.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Israel, Gaza City, Ukraine and Afghanistan.

title: A Machinery for Living
description: A good artist-organized show functions a bit like a master class, an artwork and a tour of the artists library or record collection. This exhibition, organized by the photographer Walead Beshty, does all of these well.

title: Mickalene Thomas: Tte de Femme
description: With their asymmetrical eyes, sequin-adorned cheekbones and swipes of bright lipstick, the subjects of Mickalene Thomass new collage-paintings could be Picassos Demoiselles glammed up for a night at Studio 54.

title: Robert De Niro Sr.: Paintings and Drawings, 1948-1989
description: Thanks to the promotional efforts of his son, the actor Robert De Niro, the painter Robert De Niro Sr. (1922-93) is getting some well-deserved posthumous attention. A documentary in which the son talks movingly about his father was on HBO recently. This beautiful exhibition presents works from five decades.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

description: A tour of the aspiration tower, the brainstorm rotunda and other hot spots.

description: In the court of Internet advertising, sometimes its hard to be the king.

title: Letters: The Confederate Dead
description: The Confederate Dead

title: Behind the Escalations in Gaza
description: A look at why Israel and Hamas have repeatedly chosen to intensify the violence at every stage of the continuing conflict.

title: Pay Your Taxes, Kill the Neighbors
description: Kill or be killed isnt the official tag line of The Purge: Anarchy, but it fits. It would also make a more suitable title for this satisfyingly creepy, blunt, down-and-dirty thriller, one of those follow-ups that improves on the original. Once again, its a new morning in future America, and crime is still down, as is unemployment. The only thing that appears to be keeping the peace and assuring prosperity is the government-sanctioned annual bloodletting, that one night a year in which the citizenry can run amok without punishment. The word anarchy is purely superfluous.

title: Back to the Future: Another High-Tech Twist on Tap-Dancing
description: BECKET, Mass.  In the 1989 film Tap, the old-timer character played by Sammy Davis Jr. has an idea for how to save tap-dancing, how to make it contemporary and popular again. The idea is to hook up tap-dancers to synthesizers. As realized in the film, the great dancer Gregory Hines taps, and in place of the nuanced music of his feet come 1980s video game noises. Its ridiculous, especially since the real future of tap was present in the film, in the form of the teenage Savion Glover.

title: Palestinian Youth Who Was Abducted and Killed Struggled to Stay Alive, Indictment Says
description: JERUSALEM  In the moments before he was kidnapped at dawn on July 2, Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, suddenly sensed that there was something suspicious about the two casually dressed Jewish teenagers who were asking him directions. He tried to move away and call a friend, then shouted and struggled as the two youths forced him into a waiting car driven by an adult relative, according to court documents released on Thursday.

title: Single-Family Homes as Rentals
description: Bulk purchases of single-family homes by hedge funds and private-equity firms have been the focus of media attention over the last few years, but individual investors are also showing interest in the market, albeit with less vigor as home prices rise.

title: Concussions in Sports: The N.C.A.A.s View
Drunk Self-Indulgence as the Stuff of Drama
description: Good luck trying to criticize Derek Ahonens The Qualification of Douglas Evans, produced by the Amoralists. Mr. Ahonen, who stars as the titular Douglas, has already beaten you to the punch, and its a killer combination. Heres a character reviewing Douglass first play: You wrote a masturbatory play about your stupid relationship with some stupid girl and then you stupidly starred in it and were equally as bad at playing yourself as you were at writing about yourself.

title: This Procedure May Improve Your Brain  and Uncover the Real You
description: People are fascinated by the idea of enhancing themselves  by, say, 10,000 hours of practice or drugs to improve cognitive performance. Now a noninvasive, 20-minute procedure called transcranial direct-current stimulation, or tDCS, may be able to help us learn a language faster, increase our alertness and curb food cravings. It has been shown to help hasten stroke rehabilitation, ameliorate chronic pain and treat even major depressive disorders.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Clare Boothe Luce
description: This week, Sylvia Jukes Morris talks about Price of Fame; John Williams and Parul Sehgal talk about the weeks literary news; David Lehman discusses the state of poetry in the age of Twitter; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Far From Home, an Arab Summer
description: Most of our New York museums give us gussied-up versions of what we already know. The New Museum was created almost 35 years ago to do the opposite, to give us art we barely knew existed. With Here and Elsewhere, it thrillingly fulfills that mandate.

title: Daimler Announces Details for 2016 Smart Fortwo and the Forfour
description: Daimler released details in Berlin on Wednesday about its redesigned Smart Fortwo and Smart Forfour city cars. The automaker says the next-generation models, while still diminutive, include a number of improvements. The two models were developed in partnership with Renault.

title: Where Fancy Took Flight
description: The Four Horsemen of the Glass Tower Apocalypse have passed judgment on West 57th Street, and that is that the little buildings shall be scythed to the ground, and in their places shall rise magnificent glass temples. The streets quirky little shops have all but disappeared.

description: Amid the hundreds of tips on illegal guns that flow into the New York Police Department each year, there was something wrong with Tip No. 7590.

title: Now Its Really Meg Whitmans H.P.
description: Meg Whitman has added chairwoman to her business card.

title: Q. and A.: Bill Porter on Journeys, Poets and Best-Sellerdom in China
description: For more than 30 years, Bill Porter has been one of the most prolific translators of Chinese texts, while also developing into a travel writer with a cult following. Under the pen name Red Pine, the 70-year-old resident of Port Townsend, Wash., has translated over a dozen books of poetry and religious texts, including collections of poems by Hanshan and Song Boren, the Daoist classic Dao De Jing and numerous Buddhist sutras. Under his own name, he has also published travel works like Zen Baggage: A Pilgrimage to China and Road to Heaven: Encounters With Chinese Hermits.

title: Inventive, Cheaper Tools for Learning a Language
description: To learn a new language travelers often turn to time-tested solutions like Rosetta Stone, Pimsleur or actual classes with native speakers. Yet a number of new, creative and often more affordable tools are aiming to help you rattle off table for two and how much does this cost? in no time.

title: On the Road, Finding Savings on Your Phone
description: Lets assume youre already a savvy user of travel apps that save you money on the road. You know Gas Buddy can tell you whether the gas station just up the road is cheaper than the one youre currently passing, and you would never exchange currency without checking the current market exchange rate on Oandas Currency app. You dont pay for text messages to new friends abroad or family back home in the States, thanks to WhatsApp, Heywire and their kin. (For more guidance to travel apps, read past New York Times coverage here, here, here and here.)

title: A Garden Divine: Beware of Snake
description: Its one of the greatest stories ever told, the Bibles tale of God, Adam, Eve and the Serpent in the Garden of Eden, as related in Genesis 2:4 to 3:24. Derived from Babylonian mythology, it circulated in Jewish oral tradition before being written down in the 10th century B.C. Its not long: In English translation, it amounts to fewer than 1,300 words. Despite its brevity and antiquity, it remains as resonant today as ever.

title: Recitals That Linger, a Festival That May Not
description: On most days of the two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival, a popular annual venture sponsored by Mannes College the New School for Music, there are two piano recitals each evening. So it was on Wednesday, the third full day of the festival. For the early-evening Prestige series, which mostly presents exceptional younger artists, the award-winning 32-year-old German pianist Alexander Schimpf played a varied program culminating with Beethovens mighty Hammerklavier Sonata. Later that evening, the Israeli pianist Alon Goldstein, admired for the refinement and imaginativeness of his performances, played a formidable program on the Masters series. The recitals were presented at the intimate concert hall of the Mannes College building on the Upper West Side, which seats just 275.

title: Staring at the Flame
description: I reckon I spent five hours at most in Philip Seymour Hoffmans close company, six at a pinch. Otherwise it was standing around with other people on the set of A Most Wanted Man, watching him on the monitor and afterward telling him he was great, or deciding better to keep your thoughts to yourself. I didnt even do a lot of that: a couple of visits to the set, one silly walk-on part that required me to grow a disgusting beard, took all day and delivered a smudgy picture of somebody I was grateful not to recognize. Theres probably nobody more redundant in the film world than a writer of origin hanging around the set of his movie, as Ive learned to my cost. Alec Guinness actually did me the favor of having me shown off the set of the BBCs TV adaptation of Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy. All I was wanting to do was radiate my admiration, but Alec said my glare was too intense.

title: As Boy Woos Girl, Whimsy Is in the Picture

Nominally a romance about a boy and a girl, the movie is more rightly a feature-length expression of Mr. Gondrys love of whirring, purring creations, including the doorbell that scuttles like a large ring-a-ding insect and the upright piano that whips up cocktails and the mouse that makes mischief and the mechanical cloud that sails over Paris and, and, and. ...

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) LEE DANIELS THE BUTLER (2013) Inspired by the real story of Eugene Allen, Mr. Daniels follows a White House butler, Cecil Gaines (Forest Whitaker, above), and his wife, Gloria (Oprah Winfrey), as history  particularly the civil rights movement  unfolds over seven presidential administrations in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called a brilliantly truthful movie on a subject that is usually shrouded in wishful thinking, mythmongering and outright denial. Robin Williams portrays Dwight D. Eisenhower; Liev Schreiber is Lyndon B. Johnson; and Alan Rickman is Ronald Reagan, with Jane Fonda as his wife, Nancy; Cuba Gooding Jr. and Lenny Kravitz are the fellow butlers who become Cecils close friends; and David Oyelowo is the older son whose politics Cecil eschews. In part, their story is a chronicle of the generational misunderstanding that has occurred in upwardly mobile families of every background, especially in the baby boom era, when educated and restless young people turned against the parents who had sacrificed so much on their behalf, Mr. Scott wrote. The Butler has the historical insight and the generosity of spirit to honor the father and the son equally, and to look with skepticism at eachs point of view. He added: We remember those who marched and who stood up for themselves in the face of injustice. It is good to remember that, to paraphrase Milton, they also stand who only wait and serve.

But beyond calls for an international inquiry, they showed few signs of immediately following the United States in imposing harsher sanctions on Russia.

title: In a Musical Pairing, Old Hands Guide a New Face
description: Queen + Adam Lambert were only two songs into their concert at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night when Mr. Lambert dropped to his knees, as if worshiping Brian May, who was playing one of the shows many lead guitar solos. It was an acrobatic move; once on his knees, Mr. Lambert bent back until he was nearly horizontal. It was also, as a show of fealty, a preview of the rest of the concert.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: AbbVie Clinches $54 Billion Deal for Shire in a Move to Reduce Taxes
description: Updated, 8:33 p.m. | The pharmaceutical giant AbbVie agreed on Friday to buy its European rival Shire for around $54 billion, in the biggest takeover deal so far this year.

title: New York Today: A Strike-Free Weekend
description: A cool Friday morning to you.

title: Life in Prison, With the Remote Possibility of Death
description: On Wednesday, a federal judge ruled that Californias use of capital punishment was unconstitutional because the system was excessively arbitrary.

title: Negotiations with Iran
description: Discussions about Irans nuclear enrichment program are set to continue.

title: Daily Report: Googles Earnings Highlight Its Struggle With Mobile Advertising
description: In the court of Internet advertising, sometimes its hard to be the king, Mike Isaac reports.

title: Black Southern Voters, Poised to Play a Historic Role
description: Southern black voters dont usually play a decisive role in national elections. They were systematically disenfranchised for 100 years after the end of the Civil War. Since the days of Jim Crow, a fairly unified white Southern vote has often determined the outcome of elections.

title: All Aboard the (Officially Renamed) Grand Rivers and Mountains Train
description: Chinas high-speed rail network is a source of great national pride, with more than 60,000 miles of dedicated track, as of the end of 2013  more than in any other country in the world.

title: Strategies for Covering a Losing Team
description: Whats it like to spend day after day with a losing team? Tim Rohan, who covers the New York Mets, is learning first hand. The Mets have had a tough year. Theyre 45-50, though the picture has brightened a bit lately.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week Six | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In The Times this week: an Anatomy of a Scene video in which the director, Matt Reeves, narrates a sequence from Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.

title: 1939: London and Warsaw Skeptical
description: LONDON  There were ample indicationstoday [July 18] that both British and Polish official quarters continue to be highly skeptical of Berlin reports that Adolf Hitler is now prepared to seek a peacefulsolution of the Danzig issue on the basisof terms which could be considered by Warsaw. Almost as if these reports had not been broadcast Poland issued today a new warning to the Fuehrer. A semiofficial communiqu issued in Warsawread: Quite apart from the manner in which Germany may desire to incorporate Danzig in the Reich, Polish political quarters declare that the very fact of such an incorporation would constitute an inadmissible violation of the present political and juridical state of affairs and would evoke the appropriate response.This response, if previous Polish declarations are to be trusted, would be in the form of the use of force by Warsaw to restore the status quo ante in the Free City. In a declaration in the House of Commons at the beginning of last week Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain made it clear that should Warsaw determine to resist an attempted change from within or without in the status of Danzig, Britain, backed by France, would come to its aid.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 19, 1939

title: Morning Agenda: AbbVie Wins Deal for Shire
description: ABBVIE CLINCHES $54 BILLION DEAL FOR SHIRE | The pharmaceutical giant AbbVie agreed on Friday to buy the Irish drug maker Shire for around $54 billion, the biggest takeover deal so far this year, Mark Scott writes in DealBook. The deal will allow AbbVie, based outside Chicago, to reincorporate in Britain and reduce its tax bill, representing the largest ever inversion as United States companies rush to pursue the financial advantages of moving overseas, even as lawmakers move to crack down on the increasingly popular maneuver.

title: Morning Views
description: The Ukrainian conflict has gone on far too long, and it has become far too dangerous, writes The New York Times editorial board. There is one man who can stop it  President Vladimir Putin of Russia, by telling the Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine to end their insurgency and by stopping the flow of money and heavy weaponry to those groups. It will take some time to establish who shot down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, but however it happened, it is the worst catastrophe of an increasingly costly and brutal conflict that could and should have ended long ago.

title: A Fresh Look at Iron, Plankton, Carbon, Salmon and Ocean Engineering
description: Two years ago this month, an edge-pushing environmental entrepreneur and a company formed by a Native Canadian village set off a wave of international protest by dispersing a pink slurry of 100 tons of iron-rich dust over one of the 60-mile-wide ocean eddies that routinely drift across the salmon feeding grounds of the Gulf of Alaska.

title: A Palace of Wonders
description: VARESE, Italy  The Lombardy region of northern Italy is known for its many villas of delight  the ville di delizia that aristocratic Milanese families built in the 17th and 18th centuries as summer escapes and settings for lavish entertainments. Varese, in the foothills of the Alps, was a magnet for these estates, several of which are clustered on the parklike hill of Biumo Superiore. At its crest sits the Villa Menafoglio Litta Panza, the most storied, thanks to its longtime owner, Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, the Milanese businessman whose adventurous tastes and ardent appetites made him one of the most important art collectors of the last century.

title: G.E. Results Reflect Shift Away From Finance Unit
description: General Electric reported second-quarter results on Friday that reflected its steady return to its industrial roots, as the giant conglomerate looks to accelerate the shift.

title: Marc Jacobs Gets a New C.E.O.: Why It Matters
description: So LVMH has appointed Sebastian Suhl, currently chief executive of Givenchy, to be the new C.E.O. of Marc Jacobs. He will replace Bertrand Stalla-Bourdillon, who will be reassigned within the group. In turn, Mr. Suhls job at Givenchy will be taken by Philippe Fortunato, latterly of Louis Vuitton. Oh, the tangled webs these executives weave!

title: Mets Fans at the Handicap Elevator
description: Dear Diary:

title: Learning to Make Work More Like Summer Camp
description: WHEN Leanne Robinson saw an ad asking, Why not get paid to travel? she had no good answer. Why not?

title: A Japanese Artist Launches Plants Into Space
description: Flowers arent just beautiful to show on tables, saidMakoto Azuma, a 38-year-old artist based in Tokyo. His latest installation piece, if you could call it that, takes this statement to the extreme. Two botanical objects  Shiki 1, a Japanese white pine bonsai suspended from a metal frame, and an untitled arrangement of orchids, hydrangeas, lilies and irises, among other blossoms  were launched into the stratosphere on Tuesday in Black Rock Desert outside Gerlach, Nevada, a site made famous for its hosting of the annual Burning Man festival.I wanted to see the movement and beauty of plants and flowers suspended in space, Azuma explained that morning.

title: Stir-Fries With a Touch of Thai
description: I love my summer stir-fry weeks. The list of ingredients sometimes looks daunting, but think of the effort required to put a stir-fry together as family time. Start the rice, pour yourself a glass of wine, put others to work measuring and chopping, and visit while you prep. Once your mise en place is ready, have the others set the table while you make the stir-fry in under 10 minutes. You barely heat up the kitchen.

title: Understanding the Philosophy Behind Your Investment Portfolio
description: PICKING a financial adviser who understands what you want has never been easy. Broker or independent adviser? Lone wolf or team player? Holistic planner, numbers-crunching investor or backslapping golfer?

title: July 18 Updates on Malaysian Plane Crash in Ukraine
description: On Friday, Open Source continues to follow the aftermath of the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in rebel-held eastern Ukraine to supplement the latest coverage of New York Times reporters on the ground. Updates below mix breaking news reports with new information on the investigation into the disaster and the reaction to the tragedy gleaned from social networks.

title: Leading AIDS Researcher, Always Traveling, Is Killed on His Way to a Conference
description: AMSTERDAM  As the airport lounge filled with passengers waiting to board Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, a renowned professor rushed to the gate while texting a colleague, saying that he was superbusy.

title: When News Breaks and Keeps Breaking
description: Tom Jolly is an associate managing editor in charge of night operations in the newsroom.

title: Onstage Again, With Fame Tempered
description: Onstage at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, Ally Sheedy listened from a cheap wooden chair as her director, James Franco, leaned against the sets kitchen counter and gave her some feedback. It was a Tuesday afternoon, and the cast of Robert Boswells The Long Shrift had just finished its second preview: an unusual time for a performance at this scruffy walk-up theater in Greenwich Village, but so it goes when the movie-star director is also acting on Broadway in Of Mice and Men.

title: Video Reviews of Sex Tape, Mood Indigo and Wish I Was Here
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Sex Tape, Mood Indigo and Wish I Was Here. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Who Made That Scotch Tape?
description: The particulars are hard to pin down, but everyone seems to agree that Scotch tape, the now-famous brand, originated as a slur. Back in the 20s, Scotch was a synonym for cheap. Richard Drew, a 23-year-old research assistant at Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, was trying to create a sticky-but-not-too-sticky adhesive tape for auto painters to use on two-tone paint jobs. When he erred on the not-too-sticky side, one of the car-painters asked, Why so Scotch with the adhesive? and a brand name was born.

title: Forbes Media to Sell Majority Stake to Hong Kong Investors
description: Updated, 7:36 p.m. | Forbes Media, publisher of the magazine that is perhaps the most famous chronicler and evangelist for American-style capitalism, agreed on Friday to sell a majority stake in itself to a consortium of Asian investors, concluding a protracted sales process in which a number of prospective bidders dropped out.

title: The Limits of the Law in Insider Trading
description: The remarkable winning streak of Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, came to an end a little over a week ago when Rengan Rajaratnam, the younger brother of the convicted hedge fund operator Raj Rajaratnam, was acquitted of one count of conspiracy to commit securities fraud. That leaves Mr. Bharara with a still-remarkable 85-1 record in insider trading cases. But that one loss deserves an asterisk.

title: 1964: Anti-Negro White Is Shot
description: ATLANTA  Restaurant owner Redell Crosby last night shot and critically wounded a 22-year-old white man who entered his integrated restaurant with other whites shouting that Negroes should leave. The shooting coincided with racial outbursts in other Southern cities, including St. Augustine, Fla., and Philadelphia, Miss. Police said five white men who entered Mr. Crosbys drive-in restaurant were arrested and charged with assault in a scuffle that preceded the shooting. The victim of the shooting was identified as Maurice Lawson of Atlanta. Mr. Crosby was arrested and charged with wounding Mr. Lawson. He was released on $1,500 bond. Detective Tony Quave said Mr. Lawson and the five told the Negroes in the restaurant, You just have to go. Mr. Quave said the white men attacked two of the Negroes, punching one in the nose, before Mr. Crosby pulled his pistol. Mr. Crosby held his fire and ordered the white men to leave. All left except Mr. Lawson, who advanced on the restaurant owner with a beer bottle. Mr. Crosby then began shooting. A few blocks from Mr. Crosbys restaurant, a white man and his son were wounded by blasts from a shotgun fired by Negroes from a passing car.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 19, 1964

title: Could the Mets Finish Above the Yankees? Its Possible
description: The Mets have not had a winning season since they haplessly said goodbye to Shea Stadium in 2008, their loss on that seasons final day eliminating them from playoff contention.

title: Whats News in Washington: White House Faces Dual International Crises
description: GoodFridaymorning from a sunny and not-too-humid Washington.

title: Antitrust Regulator to Examine British Banks
description: LONDON  Britains antitrust authorities said on Friday that they expected to open a formal investigation into the countrys retail banking industry, citing potential barriers to competition that include the control of a national network of branches by four big banks that offer free banking to many customers.

title: As Officer Is Mourned, Jersey Citys Tension Is Exposed
description: JERSEY CITY  Friends came to mourn the boy who made good, the one who was robbed on the streets of this city as a teenager and decided he would try to keep them safe for others. Colleagues from near and far came to pay respects to a fellow police officer, a 23-year-old rookie who was gunned down while on duty. And strangers came to send a message that they were tired of the violence.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: Pacemakers, pills for H.I.V. and World Cup fitness. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: 36 Hours in Dakar, Senegal
description: West Africas hub for nongovernmental organizations and international agencies, Dakar draws a cosmopolitan mix of travelers to its dusty downtown streets and surf-pounded coastline. Its a city of hustlers and traders, bargainers and touts, eager to show you something or sell you something and not always dissuaded by a polite non, merci. Keep saying it. Daytime streets are crowded with men in sharp suits and women rustling in the hand-dyed polished cottons called bazins. At night, intimate restaurants offer Lebanese and French-influenced dishes or simple but fresh grilled fish with Creole sauce. Much later, the dance clubs in Plateau and Almadies, along with the calls to prayer, resound into the early morning.

title: On a Generals Trail, Summoning Americas History
description: When we told friends last year that we had decided to move from Europe to the mountains of western Maryland, we got the same response (complete with italics) over and over:

title: Hotel Review: Motel One Edinburgh-Royal
description: Rates

title: Eisenhowers Baseball Secret
description: About a century ago, a young baseball player from Abilene, Kan., struggled with the distinction between professional and amateur sports. This was Dwight D. Eisenhower, the future World War II Allied supreme commander in Europe and two-term president of the United States.

title: The Data-Driven Home Search
description: When Eugenia Spektor and her husband decided it was time to leave Long Island City for the suburbs, they knew the kind of community they wanted to live in, but werent sure they could find it. Their list of wants was straightforward: good public schools for their two children, a train commute of no more than an hour, walking distance to town, an easygoing atmosphere. The characteristics they hoped to avoid were harder to divine: success-crazed moms, high-pressure schools and, since they work full time, a predominance of stay-at-home parents.

title: A Ride Across America | In Wyoming, a World-Class Burger and an Honest Butcher
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, theyll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: Amazon Unveils E-Book Subscription Service, With Some Notable Absences
description: After months of speculation, Amazon on Friday introduced a digital subscription service that allows subscribers unlimited access to a library of e-books and audiobooks for $10 a month.

title: Mickelson Considers Two-Under-Par Round an Encouraging Sign
description: HOYLAKE, England  Phil Mickelson posted his first below-par score in a major since his spectacular finishing round at last years British Open, but his two-under 70 at Royal Liverpool on Friday was anything but easy.

title: A Century of Verse
description: This week, we review several new collections of poetry. Will the work of todays bards age as well as the last centurys best?

title: A Former Prodigy Continues to Break Ground in Collaborations
description: Theres a disarming spirit of generosity in the musicianship of Julian Lage, and a keener sense of judicious withholding. A guitarist with roots tangled up in jazz, folk, classical and country music, he has spent most of his life bathed in a bright, expectant light.

title: Mans Death After Chokehold Raises Old Issue for the Police
description: The 350-pound man, about to be arrested on charges of illegally selling cigarettes, was arguing with the police. When an officer tried to handcuff him, the man pulled free. The officer immediately threw his arm around the mans neck and pulled him to the ground, holding him in what appears, in a video, to be a chokehold. The man can be heard saying I cant breathe over and over again as other officers swarm about.

title: Charlie Rangel's Charitable Giving Shrinks Along With Fund-Raising Clout
description: When Charlie Rangel was riding high as Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, one way Mr. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat, helped his profile was by giving hundreds of thousands of dollars to charitable organizations. Those days are long gone.

title: Library to Host Sesame Street Exhibition in New York
description: Devoted fans of Sesame Street may remember an episode in 1978, the shows ninth season, when Big Bird got a library card, followed by several more episodes devoted to finding and reading library books. Other characters have spent time at the library over the years as well. At the New York Public Library, the efforts made by the shows writers, producers and Muppet stars to help children think of libraries as fun places to visit have not gone unnoticed. So when Sesame Street begins its 45th season in September, the library will give it a party, with some help from Sesame Workshop, in the form of an exhibition, Somebody Come and Play: 45 Years of Learning on Sesame Street.

title: Obama Says Plane Was Shot Down From Rebel-Held Ukraine Area
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that the United States believed that a Malaysian jetliner was shot down by surface-to-air missiles from an area inside Ukraine that is controlled by Russian-backed separatists.

title: Republicans Respond to the Ukraine Crash byBlaming President Obama
description: The Gaza Strip is in flames, Israeli troops and tanks rolling in for what is certain to be a bloody military operation in which the regions battered civilians will once again absorb most of the pain. Meanwhile governments around the world are scrambling to find out who shot down a Malaysian airliner in eastern Ukraine (probably Kremlin-backed secessionists) and why (probably by accident). There are thousands of questions to answer about this nightmare, which is a direct result of the fact that there are gangs of armed men fighting with powerful and dangerous weapons in one of the most volatile places in the world, where Russia bumps up against Western Europe.

title: Fork Over Those Eggshells!
description: They arent what you might think of as typical sanitation workers, but Haley Rogers and Lisa Brunie-McDermott, two Sanitation Department employees, are women with a mission: to persuade New Yorkers to separate orange peels, eggshells and other organic waste from the rest of their trash.

title: The Immodest Scope of Reform Conservatism
description: This will hopefully be the last post for a while with the word reform conservatism in the title (sex, pop culture and religion all deserve more attention), and by the standards of the series it will be relatively brief. Since so many of the criticisms of the reformist tendency have focused on issues where there either isnt a definite reform position or where our ideas are more modest and incremental than the received wisdom about what American conservatism must do, Im concerned that my responses  whether on immigration, foreign policy, the culture war, or climate change have contributed to the sense that reform conservatism somehow has an ambition problem  that its a plausible first step toward a new right-of-center agenda, but lacks (or hasnt yet been gutsy enough to advance) the Big Ideas that conservatism really needs to matter in American policy debates again. (See David Frum, Kevin Drum, Bill Galston and others for variations on this theme.)

title: Kia Recalls 52,000 Souls for Steering Problem
description: Kia Motors is recalling nearly 52,000 Soul hatchbacks from the 2014 model year because the steering system may fail, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: Russia Lays Blame for Malaysia Airlines Crash on Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlin and its military on Friday called the downing of a passenger jet over Ukraine the Ukrainianss responsibility and rejected accusations that Russia was involved, with senior officials demanding a thorough, impartial international investigation.

title: I <3 U
description: Outsourcing text affections; Daryl Halls new project.

title: Martin Lawrence: All I Wanted Was to Right the Ship
description: The comedian and actor talks to Dave Itzkoff about returning to television and good health and letting his daughters in on his past.

title: But I Didnt Know Filming Fights Was Wrong!
description: At my high school, two students were expelled for getting into a fight wherein a teacher was injured. In addition, two students who filmed the fight  and later circulated the video among students  were also threatened with expulsion. Expelling students for filming fights is unheard-of in my district. The school said it had grounds to expel the two who took the video, as outlined by the handbook given to all students: Students may be disciplined for any other misconduct which is deemed by school authorities to be disruptive or to interfere with the educational process. There seems to be no rule, however, explicitly banning filming and circulating a fight. How much does students ignorance of a rule matter when determining a punishment? Is it ethical for a school to expel students for something they reasonably dont know to be wrong? NAME WITHHELD, CLEVELAND

title: Reply All: The 7.6.14 Issue
description: CAN THE G.O.P. BE A PARTY OF IDEAS?

title: The Great Escape
description: We were in the dozy postlunch free-play time, that period when the camp counselors sneak off for a smoke, confident that the kids in their charge are too full of sloppy Joes to get into too much trouble.

title: The Pageant King of Alabama
description: Bill Alverson has advice for everyone. But if you ask for it, be forewarned that you might not like it.

title: Destination: Tokyo
description: After whats known as the lost decades of economic stagnation in Japan, metropolitan Tokyo exudes fresh vitality: A recent TripAdvisor survey ranked it the best tourism city in the world, home to more Michelin three-starred restaurants than any other city. (And a museum devoted to Cup Noodles in nearby Yokohama.) Visiting Tokyo, where preparations for the 2020 Summer Olympics are underway, requires a certain shift of perspective, according to Matthew Pillsbury, whose photographs from Japan appear on these pages and will be shown at New Yorks Bonni Benrubi Gallery in September. Pillsbury describes Tokyo as full of slightly weird but engaging sights  like all the Mickey Mouse paraphernalia on teenage boys or the jagged arrangement of mirrors above an escalator in a downtown store. Youre walking into this shopping mall, and your world is suddenly fragmented, Pillsbury says. Theres something really beautiful about it. Julie Bosman

title: G.E. Aims to Raise $3 Billion in Synchrony Financial I.P.O.
description: General Electric could raise as much as $3.4 billion from its planned spin-off of its North American retail finance unit, Synchrony Financial, according to documents filed on Friday.

title: His Fair Ladies
description: In Andalusia, Ala., Bill Alverson, a lawyer, teaches would-be beauty queens to express themselves.

title: Y. A. Crossover
description: SHE IS NOT INVISIBLE  By Marcus Sedgwick  Roaring Brook, $16.99.

title: Driven | 2015 Lexus NX200t F Sport
description: The next big crossover from Lexus is small.

title: Inside the List
description: Enemy Territory: The Southern novelist Anne Rivers Siddons is a fixture on the best-seller list  The Girls of August, new this week at No. 13, is her 13th book to land on the hardcover fiction list. So is 13 a lucky number for Siddons? Maybe not, judging from the largely disappointed comments readers are posting online about The Girls of August. But Siddons has overcome negative reviews before. As a student at Auburn University in the late 1950s, she was fired from the campus newspaper for defying the administration with a scorching column in support of integration (an incident that later found its way into her novel Heartbreak Hotel). Never write a column when youre mad or sick or disgusted, or all three, she proclaimed early in the offending essay. These are the things that make bad little columnists get reprimanding letters from the intelligentsia. Only the greenest, foolhardiest, most nave amateur would broach a forbidden subject in Enemy Territory. . . . Meet an amateur par excellence. Later in the same column she mulled the word tolerance  Its a grown-up word. Children and mobs do much better with four-letter ones  and criticized people who were content to let their moral petticoats drag in the good old Southern mud. Auburn finally did integrate in 1964, seven years after that column, and the school eventually forgave Siddons for her justified dudgeon. It awarded her an honorary doctorate of humane letters in 1997, and organized a tribute to her last fall on the anniversary of the columns publication date.

title: Stop the Clocks
description: The emblematic Man, any man, every man  dazed, heartsick, utterly bewildered  suddenly pushes away his dinner and gets up from the kitchen table. He cant take it any longer  the overwhelming, claustrophobic grief, which has hollowed him out  and so he decides to go there. But where is there? Thats what the emblematic Woman, any woman, every woman, cant figure out. Thats what she wants to know. She understands, this woman who is also a mother, a wife, that there is no place to go when youve lost a child. You are already wounded by disaster, forever bereft. In an instant we were cast out / to a land of exile, she remembers. But this man cant sit still any longer. The trouble has taken him over again. And so he sets out to go there anyway. It has been five years, and he is determined to see his dead son one more time, though no one has ever made the journey and come back alive. Like a figure in a myth, he is going to walk across a divide, leaving the living behind, the innocent ones, who still exist inside of ordinary time.

title: Picture Everyone Naked
description: Its always wrong to judge a poem by its retweets, but when a literary work, by a poet not world famous for something else, gets hundreds of thousands of shares, likes and other such notices online, within weeks of publication, its time to ask why. That is what happened, in 2013, to Patricia Lockwoods Rape Joke. Like rape itself, Rape Joke was no joke: The rape joke is that you were 19 years old, it began. The rape joke is that he was your boyfriend. . . . The rape joke is that you had been drinking wine coolers. Wine coolers! Who drinks wine coolers? People who get raped, according to the rape joke. To readers who had suffered similar outrages, Lockwood offered wit and a fed-up solidarity; to others, the poem brought news.

title: Sing to Me, O Muse (But Keep It Brief)
description: Maybe I dreamed it. Don Draper sips Canadian Club from a coffee mug on Craig Fergusons late-night talk show. Are you on Twitter? the host asks. No, Draper says. I dont  he pauses before pronouncing the distasteful verb  tweet. Next question. Do you read a lot of poetry? Though the hero of Mad Men is seen reading Dantes Inferno in one season of the show and heard reciting Frank OHara in another, the question seems to come from left field. Poetry isnt really celebrated anymore in our culture, Draper says, to which Ferguson retorts, It can be  if you can write in units of 140 keystrokes. Commercial break.

title: In Real Life
description: Friendship, the first novel by Emily Gould, is about, well, friendship: It chronicles the several-years-long platonic love between two just-barely-30 New York City strivers, Bev and Amy. Bev is a classic neer-do-well, an inelegant Midwestern transplant who cant seem to earn any real money or avoid getting trampled by various cads, one of whom she disastrously follows to Madison, Wis., and another of whom gets her pregnant on their first date. (She accepted the invitation only for the free meal, poor thing.) She exists in sharp contrast to the charming, affable Amy, the more stable, interesting and well dressed of the pair, who was once  remember this next part  a blogger on a prominent gossip site, but who now works at another blog, if the term work can be stretched to encompass countless hours of online window-shopping and Wikipedia rabbit holes and . . . Gchatting with Bev.

title: Harms Ways
description: In the era before cheap air travel, those in the English-speaking world who wanted to taste authentic French village life read Gabriel Chevalliers gently satirical novels, published between the mid-1930s and the early 1960s. Clochemerle and Clochemerle-Babylon were deft, wise and celebratory in what people thought of as the French style. On the town of Clochemerle, in the Beaujolais region, the issues of French politics, class difference and coming or past collaboration with fascism lay more lightly than did eccentricity, pride in local wine, cooking and love.

title: Ive Ruined My Boys
description: Anyone want pasta for lunch? I asked, and my 6-, 9- and 11-year-old boys stared at their little screens in front of the big screen and ignored me. Incredulous, I glared at them. And then I repeated the question, the pitch of my voice notably higher.

title: World Leaders on Malaysia Airlines Crash
description: Reaction from world leaders to Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash.

title: Content and Its Discontents
description: Astra Taylor is a documentary filmmaker who has described her work as the steamed broccoli in our cultural diet. Her last film, Examined Life, depicted philosophers walking around and talking about their ideas. Shes the kind of creative person who was supposed to benefit when the Internet revolution collapsed old media hierarchies. But two decades since that revolution began, shes not impressed: We are at risk of starving in the midst of plenty, Taylor writes. Free culture, like cheap food, incurs hidden costs. Instead of serving as the great equalizer, the web has created an abhorrent cultural feudalism. The creative masses connect, create and labor, while Google, Facebook and Amazon collect the cash.

title: Viva la Repblica
description: Theres a certain sense of fatedness that emerges in the 13 espionage novels Alan Furst has written about Europe before and during World War II, even if its never quite enunciated in their wry, reticent storytelling. It has to do with the nature of the genre. Fursts makeshift spies act with courage, but their choices are shaded with a brutal irony, darkened by what we readers, a few paces further along in history, know will be coming for them and the people they care about: the battlefields, the camps. The consolation Furst offers for this knowledge is present in a careful hedonism, which insists on the heightened beauty of the evanescent during wartime  the unexpected pleasure of a meal or a glass of wine, a night in bed with a stranger as it snows outside, anything human.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: Big changes could be coming to the media world after Rupert Murdoch made an $80 billion bid to buy Time Warner. The offer was rejected, but that doesnt mean its the end of the story. If Murdoch succeeds, he would wind up with movie and TV studios like Warner Brothers and HBO. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar consider what would happen if Rupert Murdoch succeeds in purchasing Time Warner.

title: A 70s Childhood
description: In his fourth book of poems, Bicentennial, Dan Chiasson is after beauty of a kind, so his poems are often beautiful, odd and quite moving. He seldom resorts to lilting cadences or glow-in-the-dark imagery to achieve this, and complicates any move toward traditional lyric warmth; his poetry is genially brainy, jokey, casually formal, sometimes essayistic and humorously oracular. Yet Bicentennial is no mere intellectual pleasure. Its also a journey into a 1970s New England childhood haunted by a father Chiasson never knew.

title: Why Myers-Briggs Is Totally Useless  but Wildly Popular
description: If youve ever filled out a Myers-Briggs personality test only to feel the results didnt describe you at all, take heart. According to Voxs Joseph Stromberg, The test is completely meaningless.

title: Line, a Japanese Messaging Service, Teams With New York Venture Fund

Now known as the San Vicente Bungalows, the 29-room property has undergone basic renovations like spiffed-up bathrooms, now stocked with Malin & Goetz products that are attracting the 20- to 30-something international jet set. In addition to bright and cozy digs, guests enjoy free breakfast and can rent beach cruisers ($15 for 4 hours) to ride out to places like Venice Beach and Santa Monica, each just about 45 minutes away by bike. Even the locals are popping in for a swim access to the pool and newly landscaped grounds is $35/day. Eventually, the now-charming place will get a complete makeover. So T checked into the buzzy little oasis to memorialize things as they stand now, while summer is in full swing.

title: Scottish Independence Is Inevitable
description: LONDON  ONE thing is certain: Whatever the outcome, this referendum campaign is changing Scotland irrevocably. Whether the Scots vote yes or no to independence on Sept. 18, their sense of what is possible for this small nation will have been transformed.

title: Yo, One-Word Messaging App, Is Valued at Up to $10 Million
description: As much as $10 million.

title: Technologys Rainbow Connection
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If it werent for the one naked guy, the furries with their articulated ears and the small gaggle of leather-clad members of the Society of Janus, this citys 44th annual Pride parade in June could have been easily be mistaken for a technology conference.

title: An Indian Girl Who Just Wanted to Be Puerto Rican
description: By the end of They Call Me Q, youre apt to like Qurrat Ann Kadwani so much that youll be doubly disappointed that she hasnt written herself a better show. Her easy smile and lively eyes can brighten up a moment, but they cant overcome a shortage of laughs and a wandering story line.

title: Pedaling a Party Back to Life
description: As if to assure us that they are real people, not superheroes or machines, the members of Pilobolus begin each show by warming up onstage. On Thursday at the Joyce Theater, before the program began, Shawn Fitzgerald Ahern fired off a few push-ups, Eriko Jimbo floated into a wide-legged handstand and Jordan Kriston whipped through a series of spiraling falls. The whole group circled up along with someone who appeared to be their stage manager (the technical crew is equally part of this clan), for a chummy preshow ritual that ended with a collective roar.

title: A Bastion of British Tradition Embraces Technology
description: HOYLAKE, England  In an island nation full of old buildings and old sporting events, modernization is a particularly acrobatic juggling act.

title: The Faces of Ford
description: Eileen Ford is remembered for her legacy of scouting models and building her business into an empire.

title: Hundreds in Detroit Protest Over Move to Shut Off Water
description: DETROIT  At least 300 demonstrators marched through downtown streets on Friday, protesting a move by the citys Water Department to force tens of thousands of delinquent customers to pay up or face a cutoff in service. From the Cobo Center to Hart Plaza on the banks of the Detroit River, protesters chanted, Fight, fight; water is a human right. Others carried placards that read Thirsty for Justice.

title: Justices Say Utah Doesn't Have to Recognize Gay Marriages
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday said Utah is not required to recognize the marriages of roughly 1,000 same-sex couples there while state officials pursue appeals.

title: Exceptional Further Lane Estate in East Hampton, New York
description: One-of-a-kind Further Lane estate where every element of this 5-bedroom, 5.5-bath, approx. 7,400-sq.ft. home evokes an Aman resort feel.

title: Breezes Waft, Branches Sway and Bodies Scatter and Swirl
description: As a choreographer, Shen Wei is driven by nature. In both his dancers and in his structure, its all there, just transplanted in bodies: a leafy branch swaying in the breeze, an insect scrambling across a dirt path, powdery clouds floating across a clear sky.

title: After Tough Years, Elevation Partners Rescues Investment in Forbes Media
description: Updated, 6:31 p.m. | Forbes Medias sale of a majority stake in itself to a group of Asian investors will certainly bring some closure to the publishers founding family, which first put the company up for sale last fall.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Gaza City, Israel and India.

title: After a Run of 19 Years, Passing the Baton
description: LONDON  The American conductor David Zinman is a small man, physically  conductors often seem to be  but with a giant profile in the Swiss city of Zurich. People recognize him on the sidewalk. Waiters hover. Strangers wave. And so they might. Hes been the music director of the citys venerable orchestra, the Tonhalle, for 19 years: a long time, given the speed with which most leading figures in his line of work swap partners.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Clashing Holds on Renaissance Art History
description: What if the Renaissance began earlier and elsewhere? That audacious question kindles David Edgars Pentecost, a 1994 play revived by PTP/NYC. No less resonant now than when it had its premiere, the drama is a testament to Mr. Edgars literary skill and a rebuke to the political climate in Eastern Europe and elsewhere.

title: If Theyd Overthrown the Labour Party
description: LONDON  The hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death, as Richard III is described by one of his many detractors, has been thoroughly domesticated. As portrayed by Martin Freeman at Trafalgar Studios here, the most terrifying psychopath in Shakespeare seems dangerous only in the manner of a persistent insurance salesman who might sell you a policy you dont really need.

title: In Santa Fe, An Art Space Reinvents the Biennial
description: Beginning tonight, the adobe walls of the art space SITE Santa Fe will house a re-creation of an illegal 19th-century New Mexico gambling den, complete with dealers staging rounds of the Spanish card game known as monte. Inspired by the casinos that cropped up during the 1830s New Mexican gold rush, its part of a multipronged piece by the artist Pablo Helguera, one of 45 artists in Unsettled Landscapes, the latest edition of SITE Santa Fes contemporary art biennial, opening this Sunday.

title: City Politics Abhors a Vacation
description: From 1926 to 1932, James J. Walker  Beau James as he was known  presided over the city as mayor, succumbing to Jazz Age seductions more easily than he did to the demands of municipal governance. Speakeasies, boxing matches, Broadway, mistresses, expensive clothes  these were his pastimes when he found himself in town, but often he found himself elsewhere. During his first two years in office he is said to have taken seven vacations totaling 143 days.

title: Sass and Slow-Motion Bullets
description: You can always learn something by watching television. On Sunday night, its this:

title: Shakespeares Shipwrecked Twins Settle on the Asphalt and Astroturf
description: The Delacorte it aint.

title: Negotiators Agree to Extend Iran Nuclear Talks Four More Months, Diplomats Say
description: Iran, the United States and the five other countries negotiating the future of the Iranian nuclear program have agreed to a four-month extension of the talks, giving them more time to try to bridge major differences over whether Tehran will be forced to dismantle parts of its nuclear infrastructure, according to a statement released early Saturday in Vienna by all seven nations.

title: A Bridge Deal From the Spingold Knockout Teams
description: LAS VEGAS  The Spingold Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Summer North American Championships taking place here.

title: Under Cover: Silent Picture
description: Michael Sokoloves cover story in this weeks magazine describes the downfall of Penn States former president, Graham Spanier. Gail Bichler, the magazines art director, said that because the article was about Spaniers silence, she cropped Bryan Schutmaats portrait of him. We thought focusing attention on his mouth was a powerful way to illustrate this, she said. And Bichler said that showing him in casual dress (he also sat for photographs in a suit and tie) was a way to reflect the personal nature of Spaniers discussions with Sokolove. The image was shot in color, but it was converted to black and white to give the cover a somber feel and make it more graphic.

title: Bill Cunningham | In Black and White
description: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer.

title: A Broadway Tale: A Little Web Series and How It Grew
description: Although, as Wesley Taylor says, show business is the best platform for humiliation, he and his fellow Broadway performer Mitchell Jarvishave turned their personal and professional setbacks into victories.Their DIY web series, It Could Be Worse, about a struggling and somewhat hapless actor played by Mr. Taylor, seems to be doing better in its career than the fictional character at its center.

title: Bill Cunningham | In Black and White
description: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer. New this year are skirts and dresses of Marimekko dotted fabric. There are stripes, too, in flattering diagonals. A whimsical backless jacket is held together with a ribbon at the neck. And then there are the leopards, zebras, pandas and long-earred furry friends who wear the color combo so well.

title: Theyre on a Boat!
description: As the early-evening sun blazed, the old Navy boat gently pushed into the East River and the 32 passengers were mindfully served cocktails, wine in tumblers and beer in cans. Life aboard the Revolution eased to two knots.

title: Evening Hours | Toasts All Around
description: A week for dancing in the streets and celebrating athletes and artists.

title: Eileen Ford: Through the Years
description: Eileen Ford is remembered for her legacy of scouting models and building her business into an empire.

title: The Pickpockets Tale
description: Wilfred Rose, 58, spent a career studying the pants pockets of New Yorkers, always on the lookout for a nice stiff wallet full of cash, or better yet, the fainter outline of a dozen folded bills.

title: Does Poetry Matter?
Eileen Fords Legacy
description: When Lauren Hutton first arrived in New York in the early 1960s, there was little to suggest she would soon become one of fashions highest-paid models and, later, an alluring actress paired with leading men like James Caan and Richard Gere.

title: Waterfront Developments
description: When Peters Clam Bar first opened in Island Park, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was in the White House, Hitler was menacing Europe, The Wizard of Oz was in movie theaters and Island Parks homegrown politician, former Senator Alphonse M. DAmato, was a toddler. It managed to stick around for 73 years, until it was ravaged by Hurricane Sandy in 2012. In June, Peters reopened, under new ownership.

title: Lost and Found in Space
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  WHEN we think about space missions, what generally comes to mind are large rooms filled with rocket scientists at consoles that control expensive new spacecraft doing unintelligible things. Thats still the norm but, in fact, there doesnt need to be an entrance exam for people who want to explore space, and weve proved it.

title: Dont Blame Malaysia Airlines
description: WASHINGTON  ALMOST as soon as the news broke about the shooting down of a Malaysia Airlines flight over Ukraine on Thursday, in which all 298 passengers and crew members were killed, people began to ask: What was a commercial aircraft doing over a conflict zone in the first place? Was this disaster somehow the airlines fault?

title: Tibetan Leader, a Red Sox Fan, Knows the Value of Taking the Long View
description: DHARAMSALA, India  From his office in the hill station of Dharamsala, where Tibetan exiles have spent the past half-century waiting for the seismic changes that could restore Tibets independence, Prime Minister Lobsang Sangay was reminiscing, a bit wistfully, about a world he had left behind.

title: A Neighborhood Place in the Right Spot
description: Italian food is not hard to come by in Westchester County. Just about every town has at least one pizzeria, and many have several. More ambitious Italian restaurants, those where the wine list includes a Barolo or two and the menu goes beyond calzones, garlic knots and Neapolitan pies, are less common. And good ambitious Italian restaurants are rarer still.

title: Putins Deadly Doctrine
description: OXFORD, England  SOMETIMES, just sometimes, you should pay attention to annoying things said by tiresome people at worthy conferences.

title: White House Opens Door to Exploring Atlantic for Oil
