description: RESULTS OF DETROIT VOTE ON BANKRUPTCY PLAN COMING

title: One Degree of Separation
description: At the entrance to the Kam Shan Country Park in Hong Kong, a sign told us that if we followed the trail we would almost certainly see wild monkeys. The sign was printed in Chinese and English. Sure enough, a hundred yards in, we ran into a band of the long-tailed type.

title: Who Should Pay for Our Highways?
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama to Report Widening of Initiative for Black and Latino Boys
description: President Obama will announce on Monday that 60 of the nations largest school districts are joining his initiative to improve the educational futures of young African-American and Hispanic boys, beginning in preschool and extending through high school graduation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning 3 on Jetliner Who Drew Others to Them
description: AMSTERDAM  Hiding behind glasses of beer and flirting with nihilism, the aspiring writers, the sportsman, the teacher and the childhood friend were trying to cope with their feelings of irreplaceable loss.

description: I happened to click on this John Mauldin post, in which he informs us that GDP is a Keynesian plot, and that without it Hayek would of course have won the macroeconomic debate. Oh, kay  but thats not the horror. Its this:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: With Composure and a Strong Finish, Garca Works to Make Up for the Past
description: HOYLAKE, England  As he made his way to the 18th green, Sergio Garca experienced a sensation that had eluded him in his 17 previous British Opens. He felt no despair, no devastation, no defensiveness. Garca had been defeated, but en route to losing to Rory McIlroy, he had won a hard-earned prize: contentment.

title: Wealthier New Yorkers Arent Fleeing the City for Tax Havens, a Study Says
description: Sean Hannity, the Fox News prime-time host, threatened last month to leave New York for a tax haven down south. Tiger Woods transplanted himself from California to Florida for the same reason. The actor Gerard Depardieu decamped from France and sought citizenship in Russia after complaining that 85 percent of his income was consumed by taxes.

title: Alibabas I.P.O. Could Be a Bonanza for the Scions of Chinese Leaders
description: It was billed as the biggest private financing deal in the history of China.

title: Smaller Cable Networks Plan Their Survival Under the Feet of Giants
description: The flesh-eating zombies in AMCs hit television series The Walking Dead are shambling into a land of even bigger monsters.

title: A Sunday With Friends
description: A group plays cards in the afternoon in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: Court Delays Execution Over Secrecy With Drugs
description: A federal appeals court has delayed the imminent execution of an Arizona man, saying he has a legal right to details about the lethal injection drugs to be used and about the qualifications of the execution team.

title: Curt Gentry, 83, Co-Author of Helter Skelter, Dies
description: Curt Gentry, an author and well-regarded biographer of J. Edgar Hoover who had his biggest commercial success when he teamed up with Vincent Bugliosi to write the 1974 blockbuster Helter Skelter: The True Story of the Manson Murders, died on July 10 in San Francisco. He was 83.

title: The Fiscal Fizzle
description: For much of the past five years readers of the political and economic news were left in little doubt that budget deficits and rising debt were the most important issue facing America. Serious people constantly issued dire warnings that the United States risked turning into another Greece any day now. President Obama appointed a special, bipartisan commission to propose solutions to the alleged fiscal crisis, and spent much of his first term trying to negotiate a Grand Bargain on the budget with Republicans.

title: Economic Classes in Africa
description: There are more than twice as many people considered middle class in sub-Saharan Africa than there were 30 years ago. But in most countries, the poorer and richer classes grew as well, so income distributions have gone largely unchanged.

title: Plan to Rescue Troubled Bulgarian Bank Hits a Snag
description: The fate of Bulgarias Corporate Commercial Bank, which experienced a run last month, has become murkier after officials failed to agree on a rescue plan, prolonging the countrys worst banking crisis since the 1990s.

title: Buon Viaggio, de Blasio
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio is in Rome, vacationing with his family. Though any vacation that includes visits with Italys foreign minister and former integration minister, with daily photo ops for the traveling press corps, hardly fits the common definition of a family getaway. The de Blasio children, Chiara and Dante, will have a right to feel shortchanged if they are forced to spend more time posing in palazzi for paparazzi than eating gelato.

title: Aiming at Glass Ceiling, but Not With Her Jump Shot
description: LAS VEGAS  Professional athletes will frequently do almost anything if they believe it will help them improve. That explained why Billy Knight, an overseas basketball player, was home one summer honing his jumper in a Manhattan Beach, Calif., gym with Natalie Nakase.

title: Americas Test at the Border
description: The crisis of young migrants at the Texas border is a test of American values, one of those surprise exams that history now and then throws our way: Here are 57,000 helpless children. We are a nation of 300 million. Do we spit on them, or give them blankets and beds?

title: A Lifetime on Californias Death Row
description: How has it gone on this long? Justice Antonin Scalia asked a lawyer for the State of Florida during oral arguments in March on a condemned inmates appeal. The legal issue in that case had to do with how states define intellectual disability, but Justice Scalia was troubled that Freddie Lee Hall had been on Floridas death row for more than three decades.

title: Nearly No-Hit, Mets Score and Then Stumble
description: SAN DIEGO  The Mets spent much of Sunday afternoon being bamboozled by the rookie Cuban pitcher Odrisamer Despaigne and his unorthodox delivery. When they were not flailing at his assortment of pitches, which came from a variety of arm angles, they were often fooled into not swinging at all.

title: Missouri Alone in Resisting Prescription Drug Database
description: SIKESTON, Mo.  On his office phone at L & S Pharmacy, Richard Logan listened as a doctors office detailed how a patient had just left with her third prescription for painkillers in only nine days  and was quite possibly getting more, illegally, elsewhere.

title: Microsofts Top Lawyer Is the Tech Worlds Envoy
description: REDMOND, Wash.  Bradford L. Smith, Microsofts general counsel, was in Berlin meeting with government officials this spring when a case kept popping up unexpectedly.

title: Seeing Reasons for Mets Optimism, by Squinting
description: SAN DIEGO  So here we are again, the Mets perched on that cliff wall of possibility.

title: From a Classical Pianist, an App Lets You Graft Your Voice Onto Actual Hit Songs
description: It is not, said the pianist turned software entrepreneur Robert Taub, a karaoke app with video. Instead his new app, Hookd, creates what he described as musical selfies, in which only the voice track sounds like the user.

title: Africans Open Fuller Wallets to the Future
description: JOHANNESBURG  Across sub-Saharan Africa, consumer demand is fueling the continents economies in new ways, driving hopes that Africa will emerge as a success story in the coming years comparable to the rise of the East Asian Tigers in the second half of the 20th century.

title: Return for Ryder Cup Is Far From Sure Thing for Woods and Mickelson
description: HOYLAKE, England  The early-arriving British Open fans formed a receiving line along Royal Liverpools first hole and tried to finagle a greeting from Tiger Woods with their cries. From young voices, old voices, high voices and low voices came a steady stream of good cheer: Welcome back, Tiger; Cmon, Tiger; Go, Tige; I play golf because of you, Tiger.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 20, 2014
Whirlpool Wants Congress to Ban Class-Action Suits Tied to Energy Star Program
description: After government testing showed that scores of consumer products carrying the Energy Star label did not deserve the listing, a wave of class-action lawsuits was filed against the companies that manufacture the products.

title: Trying to Slow the Illegal Flow of Young Migrants
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  The wave of Central American child migrants heading to the United States in recent months, feeding a humanitarian crisis there, is showing some signs of abating.

title: James Garner, Leading Man, Dies at 86
description: Mr. Garner slid seamlessly between television and the movies but was best known as the amiable gambler Bret Maverick in the 1950s western Maverick.

title: Riding the Juggernaut That Left Print Behind
description: Even if you arent one of those people worried about media consolidation  there are many in that number  the big bolt of lightning last week that pierced a summer of ennui in entertainment and publishing news was hard to resist.

title: A Tough Corporate Job Asks One Question: Can You Hack It?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Pity the poor chief information security officer.

title: Comics Sales Rise, in Paper and Pixels
description: Print and digital may have found the ideal place to coexist: the comic book industry.

title: Dutch Grief Abounds, but Mourning Stays Local
description: ROTTERDAM, Netherlands  The Dutch public television station NOS broadcast solemn images on Sunday of mourners gathering at half-empty churches and at the homes of families who died when the Malaysia Airlines jet on which they were traveling was shot down over eastern Ukraine. From across this small country, people interviewed on television were trying to address their grief and growing anger over a tragedy that has propelled the ever compromise-seeking Dutch into the hard world of geopolitics and war.

title: A Street Master of the Claw Prize Game
description: Dear Diary:

title: Hasbro to Collaborate With 3-D Printing Company to Sell Artwork
description: In the not too distant future, 3-D printers may provide the public with anything from a whole new wardrobe, to meat, to furniture  and even human organs.

title: Popular Demand
description: TNT starts its TV season in June and consistently pulls in viewers with popular crime and sci-fi dramas like Rizzoli & Isles, Falling Skies and The Last Ship.

title: Dr. Albert J. Stunkard, Destigmatizer of Fat, Dies at 92
description: Dr. Albert J. Stunkard, a pioneer of eating-disorder research who proved that some people are genetically predisposed to getting fat, died on July 12 at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 92.

title: Despite Bans, the Use of Chokeholds Persists
description: For more than two decades, all manner of chokeholds have been banned by the New York Police Department. Recruits learn not to use them in the academy; officers are periodically reminded of the ban in training materials.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: Its All About the Swaddle
description: Season 2, Episode 2

title: Halt and Catch Fire Recap: Love, Competition and Glory
description: Well, that escalated quickly. After meandering all season, serving up aimless misdirection as frequently as Windows 95 flashed the hourglass pointer, Halt and Catch Fire suddenly got pretty good.

title: True Blood Recap: The Calm Before the Storm?

title: Eataly-Style Food Halls Are Taking Over America
description: Ever since Todd English opened his upscale food court and market at the Plaza Hotel in the summer of 2010, the notion of combining communal dining space and artisan grocery shopping has caught fire in New York. Englishs endeavor was soon followed by Mario Batalis Italian food emporium Eataly, where patrons can snack on charcuterie, drink wine and purchase artisanal produce. At the end of 2013 Gotham West Market opened in Hells Kitchen with stalls serving ramen, tapas and microbrews, in addition to gourmet foodstuffs and sundries. Downtown, Battery Park residents can now patronize Hudson Eats, yet another swanky, upscale food court. And now, other cities around the country are getting in the game. Here are five new (or upgraded) food halls in Denver, Seattle, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., and Atlanta.

description: The Baffler, the magazine of cultural criticism founded under the tagline The journal that blunts the cutting edge, was a talisman of a certain sort of left-leaning person throughout the 1990s, its self-consciously retro cover spotted in graduate student apartments and editors offices and independent bookstores (not to mention at about 1:26 into the video for Veruca Salts 1994 alternative hit All Hail Me).

But to combat the growing threat of online breaches, companies and governments are hiring executives whose main responsibility is to make sure data systems are secure, Nicole Perlroth reports. When things go wrong  and they often do  these executives expect to bear the blame.

title: Morning Views
description: The crisis of young migrants at the Texas border is a test of American values, writes The New York Times editorial board, One of those surprise exams that history now and then throws our way: Here are 57,000 helpless children. We are a nation of 300 million. Do we spit on them, or give them blankets and beds? Its a test the country may be flunking, according to the editorial. In neighboring Arizona, Hearing that migrant children were being sent to the town of Oracle, a county sheriff instigated a protest that ensnared a busload of bewildered YMCA campers. A disbarred former county attorney running for governorhas an adshowing a Mexican flag swallowing up a map of Arizona and the slogan Before Its Too Late.' The crisis emboldens demagogues in Washington as well, the board writes. Mr. Obama has the obligation to act the grown-up when dealing with an obstructionist Congress, but he can be a tepid ally where unauthorized immigrants are concerned, since he sees the issue through a calculating lens that overlooks the moral urgency to act. And urgent the situation is.

title: Farhad Manjoo, Whats in Your Bag?
description: Oh, no. Youre a reporter on assignment and youre riffling through your carryall. You think youve left something behind. Whether you find it can make or break your day. We asked several reporters what they need to do their jobs when they leave home or the office. Well share their answers over the next few weeks.

title: Goodbye to the Republican Wave?
description: Republicans entered this election cycle with high hopes. President Obamas approval ratings had sunk into the low 40s, and the rollout of the Affordable Care Act had been an unmitigated disaster. In an off-year election, Democrats werent expected to fully mobilize the young and diverse coalition that has given them an advantage in presidential elections. Off-years are also when a presidents party typically suffers significant losses.

description: When the Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group completed a $7.6 billion deal in 2012 to buy back half of Yahoos stake in the company, it raised part of the money by selling shares to select investors, notably Chinas sovereign wealth fund and three prominent Chinese investment firms, Michael Forsythe writes in DealBook. title: 1964: Doctors Call for End to Free Treatment
description: LONDON  Britains family doctors have decided to press for an end to free treatment for patients under the socialized health service. The decision, announced by the British Medical Association, is intended to reduce overcrowding in consulting rooms and ease the burden of the countrys doctors. The BMA councils chairman, J.R. Nicholson-Lailey, said that the BMA did not want these payments collected by the doctor. Mr. Nicholson-Laileys statement indicated that the payments might be used to keep persons with frivolous complaints from monopolizing the doctors time.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1964

title: Campaign Tries Tapping Into Hong Kongs Silent Majority
description: A campaign aiming to deter a mass protest by those who favor a more direct election of Hong Kongs top leader collected 380,000 signatures in its first two days. That puts it on a path to challenge the more than 700,000 votes of support the Occupy Central With Love and Peace movement received in an unofficial referendum last month.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Amanda Benfell joined The Gunn Report, London, as director for communications and marketing. She had been head of press and public relations for the Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity and Lions Festivals, London. Camilla Cole, press and public relations manager of Cannes Lions, will succeed Ms. Benfell there.

title: First for the Press, Now for a Rest
description: Billing itself as a place to rest, or not sleep at all, Amsterdams revved-up Volkshotel opened last month in the former headquarters of the Volkskrant, one of the countrys largest and most progressive newspapers.

title: Karl Albrecht, a Founder of Aldi Stores, Dies at 94
description: Karl Albrecht, who with his brother Theo returned from Allied prisoner-of-war camps after World War II to find their mothers corner shop still standing in bombed-out Essen, Germany, then proceeded to build it into the international grocery empire Aldi, died on Wednesday in Essen. He was 94.

title: Probiotic Logic vs. Gut Feelings
description: The label on my bottle of Natures Bounty Advanced Probiotic 10 says it contains 10 probiotic strains and 20 billion live cultures in each two-capsule dose. The supplement provides advanced support for digestive and intestinal health and healthy immune function.

title: A Homeowners Refusal to Cash Out in a Gambling Town Proves Costly
description: ATLANTIC CITY  A stand of blossoming lilac trees and a fresh coat of white paint hardly hide the decrepitude of the three-story boardinghouse half a block from the boardwalk. Ripped screens cover the windows that have not been smashed or boarded up. In the kitchen, refrigerators stand open and empty in a row; dirty plates fill the sink. Some guest rooms look untouched, beds made, while bags of trash and piles of suitcases litter others. What appears to be a crack pipe sits on a dresser.

title: ScienceTake | How an Embryo Grows
description: Mapping what happens to each and every cell as a fly develops.

title: Tracking Life From Its Smallest Form
description: The earliest stages of life have been the subject of intense fascination for eons. Aristotle, for instance, observed and recorded the development of a chicken embryo in its egg.

title: An Elk Is New
description: A Roosevelt elk was born at the Queens Zoo six weeks ago and has now joined the four other elk in the herd in the woodland habitat exhibit.

title: A Style-Setting J.F.K. Appears With a 2014 Congressional Candidate
description: This is not exactly the way people usually recall John F. Kennedy. Wearing spectacular headgear, Kennedy, then a Massachusetts senator, was speaking in October 1959 in Crowley, La., alongside a then-obscure city councilman named Edwin Edwards, who later became the states longest-serving governor.

title: Taking Pledges for a Brooklyn Movie Marathon
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will present a 24-hour film marathon as a way of raising money for its BAM Education program of classroom and after-school arts education, which reaches about 30,000 students, teachers and parents every year. The event is modeled after the marathon walks and bicycle rides for various health causes. Participants must raise a minimum of $250 to join in, and there are prizes for those who raise greater amounts. The marathon takes place on Sept. 5 at 8 p.m. at the Steinberg Screening Room of the BAM Harvey Theater.

title: Uncooked Tomato and Mint Sauce with Poached Eggs
description: My friend and colleague Clifford A. Wright serves this delicious salsa cruda with grilled salmon. Its also wonderful with most other fish, grilled, oven-roasted or pan-cooked, and it makes a terrific sauce for foods like cooked grains, the vegetarian burgers I published a few weeks ago or simply cooked green vegetables. One of my favorite uses is in a Mediterranean huevos rancheros: poach an egg, set it on a lightly charred corn tortilla, sprinkle the egg with a little salt and pepper if desired and spoon on the sauce.

title: Whole Wheat Focaccia With Tomatoes and Fontina
description: Focaccia is a dimpled flatbread that can take a number of toppings, like a pizza but breadier. I used Community Grains whole wheat flour for this half-whole-wheat version, and Im loving the results so much that Im ready to start on a weeks worth of focaccia recipes with different toppings very soon. The bread is fragrant with olive oil, a little crisp on the bottom but soft on the top and the inside. Its a great vehicle for summer tomatoes.

title: A J.Crew Grows in Brooklyn
description: I used to have a studio in Williamsburg, until about 1999, the typography and graffiti artist Greg Lamarche said. And then it went residential. Lamarche, whose graffiti appeared on walls throughout northern Brooklyn in the 1990s, is making a return of sorts. His newest (legal) piece is a colorful jumble of found letter forms spelling out J.Crew, which cascade along a wooden barricade outside the brands coming store on Wythe Avenue in Williamsburg. Set to open in mid-September, it will be the companys first outpost in the neighborhood.

title: Spiced Tomato Ketchup
description: This is inspired by a recipe for a delicious tomato jam in the chef Matthew Kenneys cookbook, Matthew Kenneys Mediterranean Cooking. My version is not as sweet as his; I decided to call it ketchup rather than jam because to me, it tastes like a richly spiced ketchup, with sweet and sour flavors and a little kick from the cayenne. A long simmer is important for cooking the sauce to the right consistency and for concentrating the flavors. After that, I put the ketchup through a food mill to achieve smoother texture, but that step is optional. I salt toward the end of cooking because the mix will reduce quite a lot and its too easy to oversalt if you salt before that happens. However, be sure to use enough salt to balance out the sweetness and bring out the spice.

title: Heirloom Tomato Concass with Wilted Swiss Chard
description: Sometimes, I cant bear to cook sweet heirloom tomatoes. I love this concass with pasta or grains, but this time, I decided to use it as a sauce for Swiss chard. I steamed the chard to wilt it, heated it in a little bit of olive oil, then piled it on my plate and spooned the tomato sauce on top. Its a great combo, and now I think Ill use it as the vegetable and sauce element of a big bowl. A little feta sprinkled over the top would not be lost on this.

title: Ex-Executive of Autonomy Seeks to Block HP Settlement Over Disastrous Deal
description: Hewlett-Packard sought late last month to take a big step toward laying to rest the turmoil over its acquisition of the British software maker Autonomy by settling three shareholder lawsuits over the deal.

title: Risotto with Tomatoes and Corn
description: This is about as colorful and summery a risotto as you can get. The tomatoes and broth team up as a rich medium for the rice. Dont add the corn too soon, or it will develop a starchy texture like the rice. But cook it long enough to bring out its sweet flavor. Simmer the corn cobs for about 20 minutes in your broth to get a great sweet corn flavor.

title: Malaysia and Australia, Still Seeking Missing Plane, Strained by Second Disaster
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Two of the nations most affected by the loss of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine, Malaysia and Australia, are still actively involved in the search for another Malaysian airliner that disappeared over four months ago, juggling two crash investigations that require the involvement of many of the same people.

title: President Calls for a Ban on Job Bias Against Gays
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, declaring himself on the right side of history, called on Congress on Monday to ban job discrimination against gay Americans as he signed an executive order doing so for workers of federal contractors.

title: Israels Gaza Incursion Sets Off Protests in Europe
description: PARIS  The conflict between Israel and Hamas militants in Gaza is spilling into the streets of dozens of cities in Europe, as thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters have depicted Israel as the aggressor and sought to isolate it internationally.

title: The Difficulty in Holding Executives Accountable
description: It is difficult to determine who is responsible for a corporate decision when authority is dispersed throughout an organization, which means that no one can be held personally accountable for violations.

title: Why Writers Are Opening Up About Money (or the Lack Thereof)
description: Writers may always have worried about money, but now seems a particularly fertile time for writing about it.Scratch Magazine, launched last year, takes as its purview Writing + money + life. The Billfold routinely runs stories on how freelance writers and other creative types do money. The novelist Emily Gould opened up about her financial life in a popular Medium essay and subsequent interviews, and The Guardians Alison Flood recently reported on the sorry state of writers incomes (which, in turn, inspired some critique from Gawkers Michelle Dean).

title: The Twelve-Coin Problem
description: Our challenges this week were suggested by Numberplay regular Stephan Peers, an investment banker from Lafayette, Calif. The first is a classic we ran in similar form years ago, and the second is more unusual and a lot of fun. I asked Mr. Peers where he found the two problems.

title: Obama Denounces Russia and Separatists for Obstructing Crash Site
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday sternly denounced Russia and the separatists it supports in Ukraine for blocking access to the site where Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was brought down last week, declaring that time is of the essence to recover bodies and evidence.

title: Its Another Perfect Day in Tibet!
description: BEIJING  Theres a lot to admire about Tom Hugo, and not just the washboard abs that are a glaring feature of his Twitter account profile photo.

title: Dutch Forensics Team Views Bodies
description: Peter van Vliet, the leader of a Dutch forensics team, spoke after inspecting rail cars in Torez, Ukraine, where the bodies of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash victims were being held.

title: Eavesdropping Hasnt Harmed Image of U.S.
description: It almost seems as if President Obama has run into nothing but trouble overseas, facing criticism over electronic eavesdropping, drone strikes and his handling of regional conflicts. Yet the image of the president, and of the United States, have suffered little harm, according to a Pew Global Attitudes survey.

title: The Ultimate Veggie Burger
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make the ultimate veggie burger with the same satisfying texture as a hamburger.

title: Obama on Plane Crash in Ukraine
description: The president discussed developments in the investigation of the Malaysia Airlines crash in Ukraine and urged Russia to push separatist rebels for access to the wreckage site.

title: Ukrainian Military and Rebel Fighters Clash in Donetsk
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  A thick plume of dark smoke could be seen rising into the bright blue afternoon sky here on Monday. One man, a passenger in a blue car that was stopped at a red light, said two people in his building were killed in the days fighting. He said he ran out of his house in nothing but his slippers.

title: Weinstein Company Plans to Release One Chance on Yahoos Free Streaming Site
description: LOS ANGELES  The Weinstein Company said it planned to release the film One Chance, about the British reality-show singer Paul Potts, on Yahoo Screen  a free, advertising-supported streaming site  shortly before putting it in theaters.

title: The Ultimate Veggie Burger
description: I am not a vegetarian, but that hasnt stopped me from embracing the veggie burger. Not to the exclusion of beef burgers, mind you, but to savor in its own right. I turn to veggie burgers when I crave the hamburger experience (soft bun, chewy protein, lots of spicy condiments) but would, at that moment, rather consume vegetables than meat.

title: Poised to Be the Best, and Relishing the Challenge
description: HOYLAKE, England  Lets set one thing as straight as one of Rory McIlroys booming drives on Royal Liverpools par 5s: He is not the new Tiger Woods. If anything, he is the old Rory McIlroy.

title: Britains Serious Fraud Office Joins Extensive Foreign-Exchange Inquiry
description: LONDON  Britains Serious Fraud Office, which investigates and prosecutes fraud and corruption, joined other global regulators on Monday in investigating accusations of abuse in the multitrillion-dollar foreign exchange market.

title: Texas Governor Bolsters Border, and His Profile
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Monday ordered 1,000 National Guard troops to the border with Mexico, seizing on a get-tough immigration message that foreshadows the approach to the current crisis by his party in Congress and that could position him in another bid for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Today in Small Business: A Hamster Wheel for Cats
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: 1939: Sign of Life on Mars Reported
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa  Dr. V. M. Slipher, director of the Lowell Observatory at Flagstaff, Ariz., who is here to take color photographs of Mars from the Lamont-Hussey Observatory, today reported that camera studies definitely indicate the presence of life on the planet  which in six days time will be nearer the earth than it has been for fifteen years. Dr. Sliphers photographs show a gradual change in the appearance of the planet, he said, which prove the growth or decay of vegetable matter. Scientists have long believed that Mars is a planet where all conditions needed for life are to be found.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1939

title: 92nd Street Ys Lineup: Jimmy Page, Amy Poehler and More
description: A centenary tribute to the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas, and an exhibition that includes letters, photographs and memorabilia from Thomass visits to the United States, presented by the Unterberg Poetry Center, will be among the highlights of the 92nd Street Ys wide-ranging 2014-15 season of readings, lectures and discussions. The Y has a particular affinity for Thomas, who made his American debut there in 1950, and returned to give the world premiere of Under Milk Wood in 1953. He will be commemorated in a program on Oct. 26. The exhibition opens the same day.

title: Pitchfork Festival Style
description: Attendees at the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago wore floral jumpers and crop tops to stay cool.

title: Pitchfork Artists Style
description: Pusha T and Isaiah Rashad performed at the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago over the weekend. Here is how they dressed at the shows.

title: Boston Bombing Suspects Friend Is Convicted of Conspiracy and Obstruction
description: BOSTON  In the first of the trials emerging from the Boston Marathon bombing investigation, a college classmate of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect, on Monday was convicted of trying to cover up evidence that could have incriminated his friend in the days after the attack 15 months ago.

title: Rich People Shrug Off High Taxes
description: Despite the common political argument that local governments need to coddle high earners with low taxes, lest they take their wealth elsewhere, rich New Yorkers, at least, seem to accept with equanimity the burden of contributing to civilization.

title: Paul Singers Hedge Fund Expected to Consider Activist Options for EMC

title: The Gene That Turns Worms Into Pavlovs Dogs
description: Like Pavlovs dogs, most organisms can learn to associate two events that usually occur together. Now, a team of researchers says they have identified a gene that enables such learning.

title: For Two Slain Americans, Commitment Came Early
description: LOS ANGELES  Growing up in this citys San Fernando Valley, Max Steinberg was a typical American boy, and not a particularly religious one. But after a trip to Israel two years ago, his life took a radical shift: Just a few months after first setting foot in the country, he returned to Israel, determined to become a combat soldier in the Israel Defense Forces, which he did.

title: Obama on Banning Gay Discrimination
description: The president discussed the executive order he signed on Monday that prohibits federal contractors from discriminating against workers on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity.

title: Tesco Taps Outsider to Spearhead Turnaround
description: LONDON  Tesco, Britains biggest retailer  a grocer being squeezed by premium food purveyors and deep discounters  announced a management shake-up on Monday and warned that its profits would be lower than previously expected.

title: Obama on Casualties in Gaza Conflict
description: President Obama said Israel has the right to defend itself against attacks from Hamas, but he expressed concern about the rising number of Palestinian civilian deaths in the conflict.

title: Shakespeare in Love Makes Stage Debut in London
description: LONDON  When Tom Stoppard created a play a few years ago out of his Academy Award-winning script for Shakespeare in Love, the best picture Oscar winner from 1998, he quickly realized that doing the adaptation was a mistake.

title: Mighty Little Diggers
description: Q.My backyard soil is so rocky that I often need a pickax to dig a hole, yet chipmunks and moles burrow through with apparent ease. How do they do it?

title: Doing Business in China Means Starting From Scratch
description: Professional accomplishments define us. I often start my introduction to new contacts by saying, Hi, Im Deb Weidenhamer, the C.E.O. of Auction Systems America.

title: Beyond Energy, Matter, Time and Space
description: Though he probably didnt intend anything so jarring, Nicolaus Copernicus, in a 16th-century treatise, gave rise to the idea that human beings do not occupy a special place in the heavens. Nearly 500 years after replacing the Earth with the sun as the center of the cosmic swirl, weve come to see ourselves as just another species on a planet orbiting a star in the boondocks of a galaxy in the universe we call home. And this may be just one of many universes  what cosmologists, some more skeptically than others, have named the multiverse.

title: For Alibaba Investors, the Benefits and Risks of Trusting Jack Ma
description: Buy a share in Alibaba and you place your trust in Jack Ma. The Chinese e-commerce giants founder, executive chairman and spiritual sultan will remain a controlling force even after the company completes its huge initial public offering later this year. The $100 billion-plus question for prospective shareholders is whether they can depend on him to always act in their best interests.

title: Coming Off Neck Surgery, Wilson Is Set For Contact
description: Giants running back David Wilson, who has been sidelined since October because of a neck injury that required surgery, announced Monday morning that he had been given a go-ahead to resume full-contact workouts with the team. The Giants first full practice of training camp is Tuesday.

title: An Eye to the Past Can Help Guide the Future
description: Over time, weve come to accept the concept that knowledge is power. In theory, when we have more knowledge, we can make better decisions. Higher-fat milk is gone; schools are required to serve a vegetable and a fruit daily; there can be no trans fat; and half of the grains offered must be whole grains (in the 2014-15 school year, all grains must be whole grains).

title: Study Tracks Millions of Child Brides
description: More than 700 million women alive today were married as children, and about 250 million of them  more than one in three  were wed before they reached 15, Unicef said in a study released Monday, on the eve of an international meeting in London, the Girl Summit, sponsored by Unicef and the British government. It aims to mobilize efforts to end female genital mutilation and child, early and forced marriages. The study said child marriage remains widespread in parts of South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. South Asia is home to almost half of all child brides worldwide, the study found. While an adolescent girl today is about a third less likely to be subjected to genital mutilation compared with 30 years ago because of activism, legislation and changing attitudes, Unicef said that in countries where it is still practiced, parents continue to compel their daughters to undergo the procedure because of strong social pressure.

title: Questions About Tactics and Targets as Civilian Toll Climbs in Israeli Strikes
description: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza  The blast from the Israeli strike was so powerful that it threw an iron door clear over several neighboring houses. It came to rest along with a twisted laundry rack still laden on Monday with singed clothes and a childs slipper.

title: Arizona: Execution Case to Be Appealed to Justices
description: A federal appeals court on Monday denied Arizonas request for a new hearing, by a larger panel, to reconsider the courts stay of the execution of Joseph Wood, and the state said it would appeal immediately to the Supreme Court to permit the execution to proceed. On Saturday, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit delayed Mr. Woods execution, scheduled for Wednesday, until Arizona provides information about the sources of lethal drugs and the training of the administering staff. In previous cases, the Supreme Court has declined to stop executions over similar concerns about drug secrecy.

title: Strength Is Sought at Rites in Israel
description: HOLON, Israel  It was a scene that played out on Monday at military cemeteries across Israel: Family, friends and comrades in arms, some in uniform fresh from battle, others wounded, gathering in the hundreds.

title: Medical Workers Face Scrutiny After Mans Death in Police Custody
description: After Eric Garner died in police custody last week on Staten Island, critics fixed their attention on the chokehold that an officer appeared to use to subdue him during a confrontation.

title: Businessman Wanted in Fatal South Korean Ferry Disaster Is Found Dead

title: Presidents Secret to Handling Criticism? Focus, and No TV
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama had to laugh. He had just been asked how he deals with criticism, and something about the question just struck him as funny. Maybe it is because criticism is one thing he sees no shortage of these days.

description: OSSINING, N.Y.  For all the bleak musings about suburban life in his fiction  the banality and social striving, the emptiness and inebriation  John Cheever had a simple love for his five-acre property here.

description: A family pledges one of the largest private gifts ever for scientific research; why we may never have all the pieces necessary for a theory of everything; sleep apnea tests can now be taken from the comfort of your bed.

description: At the height of a meningitis outbreak last year among gay and bisexual men in New York City, Demetre Daskalakis, a wiry AIDS doctor and gay health activist, spent late nights and early mornings in the citys sex clubs and bathhouses. There, he would strip off his leather jacket and, in his muscle T-shirt, talk the men around him into letting him inject them with meningitis vaccines.

description: GREENWICH, Conn.  In Iowa, he was celebrated. In Connecticut, he was protested.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (ESPN) SLAYING THE BADGER This 30 for 30 documentary, directed and written by John Dower, looks back at the 1986 Tour de France and the rivalry between Greg LeMond, above left, the first American to win the race, and Bernard Hinault, a.k.a. the Badger, right, his friend, mentor and teammate on La Vie Claire. The film is based on Richard Moores book, which describes how Mr. Hinault, then the reigning champion, had seemingly promised to help Mr. LeMond to his first victory in return for his support of Mr. Hinault as he struggled in the 1985 tour. But Mr. Hinault repeatedly attacked Mr. LeMond in the race, because I felt like it, he said. If he doesnt buckle, that means hes a champion and deserves to win the race. I did it for his own good.

Seven soldiers were crammed inside, including Sgt. Oron Shaul, 21, from the Golani infantry brigade, according to Israeli military officials.

title: An Emotional Burden Rarely Discussed
description: The National Center for Health Statistics has published a new report documenting the extent of incontinence among older adults living independently, receiving home health care services or residing in assisted living centers and nursing homes. Buried in the report is an astonishing figure: 37 million seniors who live independently have some type of incontinence.

title: What the Hobby Lobby Ruling Means for America
description: Last month, as youve probably heard, a closely divided Supreme Court  ruled that corporations with religious owners cannot be required to pay for insurance coverage of contraception. The so-called Hobby Lobby decision, named for the chain of craft stores that brought the case, has been both praised and condemned for expanding religious rights and constraining Obamacare. But beneath the political implications, the ruling has significant economic undertones. It expands the right of corporations to be treated like people, part of a trend that may be contributing to the rise of economic inequality.

title: A Love of Land in Egypts Farms
description: Laura El-Tantawy was in her sixth year photographing Egypt when she decided she needed a drastic change. What had started as a project to reconnect with her home country took a decided shift at the spark of the 2011 revolution. Echoing the tumult in Tahrir Square in Cairo, her images had grown menacing and haunting.

title: Flight Delays Expected to Worsen in Eastern China
description: Severe flight delays that have plagued airports serving Shanghai and other parts of eastern China in recent weeks are set to continue until mid-August, the Chinese state media reported on Tuesday. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer turned whistle-blower, was poisoned in London with a radioactive isotope, the British authorities announced on Tuesday that a public inquiry would be held into his death, permitting investigators to explore whether Russian leaders had ordered the killing.

Forensics officials raised the strong possibility that the remains of many victims were still buried in the wreckage and that identification could take weeks or months to complete.

title: Morning Views
description: The New York Times editorial board applauds an executive order signed by President Obama prohibiting federal contractors, which employ 20 percent of the nations work force, from discriminating against gay men, lesbians and transgender people in their employment practices. This is a fulfillment of a 2008 campaign pledge, building on previous moves to combat unfair treatment of gay and transgender people that will have a positive impact on millions of Americans. The act of signature is especially impressive because of his refusal to bow to intense pressure to include an exemption that would have undermined the order by allowing groups with religious objections doing government work to continue discriminatory practices at taxpayer expense.

title: The Tragic Price of Flight 17
description: The downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 is a terrible tragedy, but then we were already well aware of President Vladimir Putins dangerous meddling in eastern Ukraine. What we didnt know about is how the airline industry assesses security risks. I would be interested in reading a thorough piece on how the various civil aviation authorities and airline companies decide which routes are safe to fly. How is it possible that some airlines avoided Ukrainian airspace altogether while others did not? Who in the airline industry is accountable for the demise of Flight 17?

title: Philosophy With a Newsier Edge
description: Peter Catapano, an editor in Opinion, launched the philosophy series The Stone in 2010, in collaboration with the philosopher Simon Critchley. It appears in Opinionator and often draws hundreds of passionate comments. Mr. Catapano has also developed and edited several other series for Opinionator, including Home Fires, Anxiety and, most recently, Menagerie, on the relationship between humans and animals.

title: When Hiring Employees in Poorer Countries, Difficult Moral Questions Arise
description: Earlier this year, I wrote about the issues Id encountered while building an outsourced office in another country. Weve now expanded to a team of 14 in Manila, and we recruited everyone there using processes similar to those we use at home. Ive worked out of the office there and have come to know each employee. We hold regular team lunches at our Manila office, and the whole company meets once a week by video conference. As a result, I had the impression that we were building a strong company culture across both offices.

title: 1939: Film Stars Tyrone Power, Annabella Are Besieged in Cannes
description: CANNES  Tyrone Power and Annabella, honeymooning film actors, arrived today [July 22] and immediately set off a flutter of excitement from thousands who wanted to see the American film idol and his French actress bride. They eluded all but the first 100 autograph- seekers and escaped to the near-by surf. The couple since disembarking ten days ago at Naples had been on a leisurely automobile tour through Italy. The couple will leave tomorrow for Le Pyla to visit Annabellas mother. Later they will see Paris, then sail in August for America to commence work again in Hollywood in September.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 23, 1939

title: Morning Agenda: CIT in Deal for OneWest
description: The CIT Group, the lender to small and midsize businesses run by John A. Thain, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the parent company of OneWest Bank for $3.4 billion in cash and stock, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes. The deal will bolster CITs lending abilities by more than doubling its deposit base. OneWest currently manages $15 billion in deposits, as well as $23 billion in assets, including commercial and home mortgages. It will merge with CITs own bank, creating a subsidiary with $28 billion in deposits and $67 billion in assets.

title: A Power Brokers World Comes Tumbling Down

In A Master Builder, a filmed version of Henrik Ibsens play The Master Builder, which he also freely adapted, Mr. Shawn stars as the despicable title character, Halvard Solness. As is his wont, Mr. Shawn employs insidious sleight of hand to score moral points. Halvard may not be a murderer, but he relishes crushing the hopes and dreams of everyone around him.

Mr. Quinton plays Idris Seabright, a wealthy and eccentric woman whose life with her handicapped ward, Vivien, is upended when a young stranger named Ricardo shows up at their door.

The performances will be at Here, La MaMa, Joes Pub, Trinity St. Pauls Chapel and the Park Avenue Armory, in Manhattan; and at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn.

title: A Supermodel-Approved Downtown Gym Heads to Montauk (and Classes are Free)

This weekend,ModelFIT, the Karlie Kloss-approved workout located on the Bowery in Manhattan, is coming to the Surf Lodge, where trainers will host two mornings of complimentary classes out on the deck as part of the hotels summer wellness program. Available to anyone, even non-hotel guests on a first-come, first-serve basis (theres a limit of 30 people), the one-hour classes will mix cardio with isometric training for long, lean muscles and a strong core.

title: Kay Hagan Sidesteps Democratic Party Turmoil in North Carolina

Billington, the Librarian of Congress, announced Tuesday. Mr. Joel is the sixth recipient of the award, a lifetime achievement prize that honors living songwriters whose work, in the librarys description, exemplifies the standard of excellence associated with George and Ira Gershwin.

title: Researchers Question Expansion of Antarcticas Fringe of Sea Ice
description: Updated, July 23, 1:40 p.m. | A new study of methods used to track Antarctic sea ice trends has raised important questions about whether recent increases in ice there are, to a significant extent, an illusion created by flawed analysis of data collected by a series of satellites. The news release excerpted below offers a good overview of the paper  A spurious jump in the satellite record: has Antarctic sea ice expansion been overestimated?  which was just published in The Cryosphere. The authors are Ian Eisenman and Joel Norris of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and Walt Meier of NASA.

On one end, there are highly skilled jobs like writing software or performing surgery, and on the other are service jobs like child care and cutting hair. He is also an entrepreneur, helping to launch the Kate Spade handbag empire, Jack Spade menswear, Sleepy Jones (a line of pajamas and intimates) and, soon, the Boerum House & Home store in Brooklyn. The new shop, a collaboration with Flank Architects, will feature objects from 130 designers. He also produces movies, shoots photographs and makes books. title: Rulings on Health Law Are Far From Last Word
description: An appellate court ruling issued Tuesday would be very bad news for the Affordable Care Act if it became the law of the land. But its still a long way from a settled issue, as a second appellate decision, issued a few hours later, highlighted.

title: A Singapore Startup Sells Contemporary Art from Southeast Asia, Without the Intimidation Factor
description: Groceries, books, clothing  we buy everything, it seems, from our laptops and phones these days, so why not original art too? Thats the question posed by the founders of Art Loft, a Singapore-based e-commerce art platform with a focus on connecting emerging contemporary artists, largely from Southeast Asia, with collectors around the world.

title: 1964: De Gaulle Refuses to Pay U.N.
description: PARIS  During his talks with U Thant yesterday [July 21], President Charles de Gaulle flatly turned down the United Nations secretary-generals request for payment of French debts to the world organization. U Thant left Paris without illusions and without hope, said an official French spokesman today. Thus, despite the warm praise, which Gen. de Gaulle and U Thant exchanged, all hope disappeared that France would pay the $16 million it owes the UN for the Congo operation, an action France opposed from the start.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 23, 1964

title: Kerry Says U.S. Would Address Hamas Demands After Cease-Fire
description: CAIRO  Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday said that the United States was prepared to address the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip and the political demands of the Palestinians living there, but that a cease-fire first needed to be carried out.

title: London Theater Journal: On Artifice and Oxygen, Earnest and Jeeves
description: LONDON  People often speak of poetic license, but why not theatrical license? Think of the wanton liberties that have been taken with respectable plays over the years in the name of showbiz, box office, star power and intellectual theorizing.

title: Spitzer Returns, Taking Aim Again at Financial Analysts
description: Eliot Spitzer has re-emerged in the public eye.

title: In Praise of the Trusty Rice Cooker
description: Every cook has her trusted tools. Those implements that help you through just about any prep process and make the kitchen feel like home. For many its a special chefs knife that sits just right in the hand, a cutting board with the perfect amount of countertop acreage, or maybe a saut pan that responds to the slightest change in flame.

title: Fluffy. Tasty. Tricky.
description: ATLANTA  Of the many ways I can be humbled in the kitchen, rice is at the top of the list. Im not a bad cook but, oh, the pots of rice I have driven to a gummy, scorched grave.

title: The Whiskey Bar Is Taking a Step Up
description: Multnomah Whiskey Library in Portland, Ore., has a lot of the things youd expect to find in a whiskey bar  leather chairs, dark wood, a certain amber glow. It also has something you dont see every day: a ladder.

title: Senate Panel Takes On Tax Inversions
description: The chorus of voices on Capitol Hill calling for an end to corporate inversions grew louder on Tuesday as the Senate Finance Committee held a hearing on the issue of American companies reincorporating abroad, and legislators proposed new punitive measures against inverted companies.

title: Melodrama in Full Flower (and With a Wink)
description: Meadowlark, the Stephen Schwartz ballad from the musical The Bakers Wife, is a classic example of a song from a flop musical that endures and takes on a life of its own as a semioperatic showpiece. It needs a substantial voice to do it justice, and on a recent night at the Metropolitan Room, Marieann Meringolo, a singer who bears some physical and vocal resemblance to Barbra Streisand, delivered one of the two or three strongest renditions I can remember.

Putin delivered a short but wide-ranging foreign policy speech on Tuesday, pledging to use Russias influence on the separatists in eastern Ukraine while also seeking to reassure his domestic audience that any fallout from the downing of a passenger jet over Ukraine could be contained.

Noah Baumbach writes and directs a story of aging and ambition, called While Were Young. Chris Rock goes one better: He writes, directs and stars in Top Five, about a New York City comedian-turned-movie star.

If the ruling standsa big ifit could deprive millions of enrollees of the support they need to purchase health insurance.

description: BAGNRES-DE-LUCHON, France  Michael Rogers has many cycling titles to his name, including three world time trial championships. But it took until his 10th Tour de France for him to win a stage of the sports most prominent event.

title: Jane Alexander's Bird-Watching Tips

title: Exxon Mobil Moves Ahead With Russian Oil Drilling Project
description: MOSCOW  Exxon Mobil, which is assisting a Russian state energy company in exploring the Arctic Ocean for oil and natural gas, took a pivotal step to further this project over the weekend.

title: A World Teaches and Tugs
description: Enveloped in a sweetness that buffers the depths of its emotions, Hiroyuki Okiuras A Letter to Momo explores the stains of loss and regret on a personality too young to articulate them. Yet the films tiniest viewers are more likely to be entranced than distressed by this magical animated tale  Mr. Okiuras second, after Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade (2001)  even if their parents find themselves surreptitiously sniffling.

title: The High/Low | Tough Sandals at a Gentle Price
description: July in New York means sweaty bangs, sticky skin and seemingly unsolvable fashion challenges  like finding a stylish sandal thats sturdy enough for watching outdoor live shows, trekking to surf spots at the Rockaways and dancing on Brooklyn rooftops. Thankfully, 2014 has been the year of the comfort shoe in fashion, and the heavy-soled sandal trend that walked the spring 2014 Givenchy runway and carried over into such fall 2014 shows as Cline has now trickled down to two go-to sites for all things cool: Asos and Nasty Gal. Dr. Martens, too, is offering a reasonably priced rendition of the tough sandal. These versions are affordable even for 20-somethings, so take your pick and wear them out for whats left of summer.

title: Pizza to Go, and on the Go

title: A Spinster at the Center of a Madcap Swirl. Cue the Double Entendres.
description: In a sweet 1950s peach crocheted dress and matching bolero, Everett Quinton has never looked lovelier. As Idris Seabright, a lonely and overwrought spinster growing old in the Florida Keys, he laments a storm having wreaked havoc on my African hibiscus  and my poor bougainvillea, hitting each syllable with that posh Eastern accent that 1930s actresses favored. When a chord of ominous movie music plays, Idris strikes a terrified pose, and we could easily be downtown at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, where Mr. Quinton and Charles Ludlam starred in the original The Mystery of Irma Vep 30 years ago.

title: Palestinian Family Finds Missing Son in YouTube Video of His Shooting

title: Debt Disaster Dead-Enders
description: I got some correspondence from people telling me to read Rob Portmans op-ed in the WSJ, intended to refute the growing evidence that the budget deficit has been grossly overrated as an issue. And it is an interesting piece  its a very good illustration both of the desperate desire to see a debt crisis, and what happens when someone (Portman, or more likely the staffer who wrote it) tries to be a Very Serious Person without actually understanding the numbers or having followed any of the analysis.

title: A Youthful Vigor, Flowing Through to His Fingertips
description: There is always a downside in describing a young artist like the brilliant New York-based pianist Conor Hanick as a champion of contemporary music. At 31, Mr. Hanick, who holds a doctorate from the Juilliard School, has won acclaim for his exciting performances of new and recent music with orchestras and ensembles around the world. On Monday night he brought his enthusiasm for contemporary music to the two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival, at Mannes College the New School for Music, playing an engrossing and, in his own words, unorthodox program.

title: Chaotic Yet Pensive, Pounding the Keys
description: Villa-Lobos wrote his Rudepoma  a 20-minute solo work sometimes described as The Rite of Spring meets the Brazilian jungle  as a portrait of the pianist Arthur Rubinstein, a friend who had championed his music. Villa-Lobos said he wanted to portray Rubinsteins true temperament in the work.

title: Yearning for Performers Who Transcend Victim and Vamp
description: Much about the current Bolshoi Ballet season at the Lincoln Center Festival is unexplained. Since other Western cities have seen this Moscow companys productions of Copplia, Lost Illusions, Jewels, why isnt New York seeing them? All of them would expand our idea of the troupe. And why has the company not brought Evgenia Obraztsova, Ruslan Skvortsov or Vyacheslav Lopatin? Each has made a striking impression in one or more leading roles in recent live broadcasts by the company; Ms. Obraztsova, in particular, is one of the worlds most exquisite classical stylists. Youd think that a troupe that lost Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev in 2011 would be working harder to prove that it has an abundance of remaining stars.

description: Stephan Asbury leads the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra in a rehearsal of John Adamss Slonimskys Earbox.

title: Where to Eat, Drink, Shop and Stay in Provincetown This Summer
description: To get to Provincetown, Mass., you need time and patience, which are easy things to allot yourself when you remember the towns quaint colonial cape homes, its miles of grassy dunes and the way the light plays off of Cape Cod Bay, making it wink and twinkle like gold in the afternoon and turn to pink glass at sunset. This artists enclave and tourist community, where international film and theater festivals keep the town busy between themed weeks, is also a great place to indulge in good food and shopping when youre not at the beach.

title: Film Has Crowds Swarming to Beijing House, Haunted or Not
description: Chaonei No. 81, arguably Beijings most celebrated haunted house, has seen a steady stream of visitors over the years. Until recently, they were a niche assortment  mostly thrill-seekers, urban explorers and history buffs  looking to experience firsthand the lurid tales of the once-grand French Baroque-style mansion, which has long sat dilapidated and abandoned. Foremost among the many legends associated with Chaonei No. 81 is that the mansion is haunted by the ghost of the mistress of a Kuomintang official who hanged herself there after her lover abandoned her following the Communist victory in 1949.

title: Washington Mudslide Report Cites Rain, but Doesnt Give Cause or Assign Blame

But it was also linked to more recent events, including the destabilization of soil from a slide in the same place in 2006 and, possibly, logging, scientists said Tuesday.

description: TANGIER, Morocco  IN eastern Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin has been playing with fire.

title: Ukrainians, Awaiting International Action After Crash, Fear Complacency
description: KIEV, Ukraine  From the moment it became clear that a civilian jetliner had been shot down over eastern Ukraine, killing 298 people and jolting the worlds attention to the countrys battle with Russian-backed insurgents, many Ukrainians, including senior officials here in the capital, have been awaiting a forceful international response. They are still waiting.

title: Apple Case Over Labor Code Is Granted Class-Action Status
description: A state court in California has granted class certification to nearly 21,000 current and former Apple employees over claims that the company failed to provide timely meal and rest breaks as required by the law, and sometimes denied workers rest breaks altogether.

description: SAN DIEGO  When the bullpen gates open and San Diego Padres reliever Alex Torres is summoned, he takes off in an all-out sprint until he reaches the lip of the infield. Then he abruptly stops and takes a slow, purposeful walk to the mound.

title: Lenders Offer Low-Cost Services for the Unbanked
description: One woman kept her savings  a $100 bill  in the freezer. Another, a single mother in Texas, said she had only enough extra cash each week to buy one wooden letter, for $3, to spell out her daughters name on her bedroom wall. A third, a housekeeper in Brooklyn, lives in a homeless shelter.

title: A 401(k) for All
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  ONE compelling way to turn the ongoing national discussion on wealth inequality into a tangible policy to help Americans increase their wealth and savings would be to fix what I have long called our upside-down tax incentive system for retirement savings. In its current form, it makes higher-income Americans triple winners and people earning less money triple losers.

title: Prosecutors Are Reading Emails From Inmates to Lawyers
description: The extortion case against Thomas DiFiore, a reputed boss in the Bonanno crime family, encompassed thousands of pages of evidence, including surveillance photographs, cellphone and property records, and hundreds of hours of audio recordings.

description: The trust is back, baby.

description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday allowed the execution of an Arizona inmate to proceed, lifting a stay from a federal appeals court that had been based on the secrecy of the states lethal-injection protocol.

description: Deutsche Banks primary regulator in the United States has found serious problems with the banks financial reporting procedures and oversight, a lawyer briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

description: GAZA CITY

title: Amazons Fire Phone: Solid Device Beneath a Layer of Whiz-Bang Frippery
description: When Amazon.com unveiled its first smartphone last month, Jeff Bezos, the companys chief executive, said the device was partly inspired by one of his favorite childhood books, Mr. Pines Purple House. In the book, by Leonard Kessler, friendly old Mr. Pine grows weary of the 50 identical white houses, all in a line, on Vine Street. When he paints his house purple, his radical color scheme sets off an explosion of architectural innovation among his neighbors on Vine Street, which apparently has a pretty lenient homeowners association.

title: Cash, but Not Remedial Tools, in Wrongful-Death Settlements
description: On a Saturday evening in July five years ago, Shem Walker tried to roust a bummy-looking guy from the stoop of his mothers brownstone on Lafayette Avenue in Brooklyn. One thing led to another; a second man came to help the bum. Mr. Walker, 49, was shot dead.

title: Two Countries, No Home
description: Earlier this year, I met a group of young people in Mexico City who call themselves the other Dreamers, undocumented young people taken to the United States as children who returned to their birth countries. Some had been deported, while others had voluntarily returned to Mexico and were working or making their way through college. Many told me of their struggles to adapt to what, for them, was largely a foreign culture. They had left behind friends, family and important parts of their identity in the United States, which for many of them was the only home they had ever really known.

title: Eyes on Gaza, Tensions Flare in Brooklyn
description: The worshipers, young and old, converged on mosques in Brooklyn this weekend, seeking olive green rugs on which to rest their knees, and pray. One week before the end of Ramadan, prayers rebounded off the walls with even more fervor than usual.

title: Spartan Hockey Helmets Going Under Microscope
description: BLACKSBURG, Va.  Hockey helmets may be on the verge of a radical makeover, as scientists and engineers at Virginia Tech prepare a rating system that measures each brands and models ability to reduce the risk of concussion.

title: Plan for Young Migrants at Impasse in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers are deadlocked on a plan to deal with the surge in migrant children who are filling detention centers along the Mexican border, with both Democrats and Republicans saying Tuesday that it was increasingly unlikely they could reach an accord before Congress leaves town for a five-week recess at the end of the month.

title: Reaction to Chokehold Death in New York
description: New York state and city officials demanded a full investigation into the death of Eric Garner after he was placed in a chokehold while being arrested by the police.

title: French Food Goes Down
description: Before my first visit to France, around 45 years ago, I was told that you couldnt find bad food there if you tried. I was of limited experience, so even a hot dog jammed into a baguette bore witness to that fact.

title: New York City Police Study Use of Force; May Issue More Tasers
description: Days after the death of a man who was subdued by police officers on Staten Island, the Police Department is undertaking a sweeping review of its training and tactics, Commissioner William J. Bratton said on Tuesday.

description: Actors, authors and singers weigh in on whether or not Scotland should break away from Britain, ahead of the countrys referendum in September.

title: Reading the Future of Scotland in the Stars
description: LONDON  Sean Connery is in favor, J. K. Rowling is against. Ewan McGregor and Emma Thompson dont really want it, but Annie Lennox and the boss of British Airways sort of do. And everyone is dying to know: Where does Andy Murray stand?

title: An Ominous Health Care Ruling
description: Millions of low- and moderate-income people who signed up for health insurance with the help of federal tax-credit subsidies could find themselves without coverage or facing big premium bills if a destructive decision handed down by a federal appeals court in Washington on Tuesday is not reversed. It would be a crippling blow to the ability of the Affordable Care Act to reduce the ranks of the uninsured with grievous consequences for vulnerable customers.

title: Painful Progress in Detroit
description: If the measure of a good compromise is that everyone is left unhappy, the Detroit bankruptcy plan certainly qualifies.

title: Confirmation Hearing Becomes Debate on Veterans Affairs
description: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers on Tuesday used the confirmation hearing of Robert A. McDonald to lead the embattled Department of Veterans Affairs to debate whether the agency needed more money to remedy its institutional problems.

Here, a decade of no-go security and endless reconstruction has yielded to innocent crowds strolling around what was once scorched earth.

description: Class-action settlements are often messy. When enough aggrieved people are thrown together, it is natural that some of them will be unhappy with a deal that is a result of a negotiation between parties trying to avoid a long, expensive trial with an uncertain outcome.

description: The United States military spent millions of dollars on garbage incinerators in Afghanistan that went unused as tons of trash burned in open piles, wafting toxic smoke over thousands of troops, according to a report released Tuesday by an American watchdog agency.

title: An Exaltation of Moths, Much-Maligned Kin of the Butterfly

title: Turkey: Officers Arrested in Spy Case
description: Dozens of Turkish police officers were detained on Tuesday and accused of spying on Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his top aides, news agencies reported. The Istanbul chief prosecutors office, in a statement carried by the semiofficial Anadolu News Agency, said the officers had fabricated an investigation into a supposed terrorist group as a pretense to spy on top officials. More than 500 prominent figures have been illegally wiretapped since 2010, CNN Turk television reported, citing the prosecutors office. More than 100 officers have been charged with falsifying evidence, illegal wiretapping and espionage, and 67 were taken into custody in a 22-city security operation. Some of those who were detained were involved in a corruption inquiry that ensnared Mr. Erdogans close circle and forced four ministers to resign in December, news reports said. Mr. Erdogan has said the graft investigation was driven by people loyal to Fetullah Gulen, a cleric who lives in Pennsylvania and is a former ally who still has influence in various state institutions. Sinan Ulgen, a visiting scholar at Carnegie Europe in Brussels, called the arrests the latest episode in the war waged against the Gulen community.

title: U.N. Warns of Polio Risk in War Zones
description: The United Nations expressed concern about the possible spread of polio in the war-ravaged countries of Syria and Iraq and beyond on Tuesday despite the biggest vaccination campaign undertaken in the history of the Middle East. A report by the World Health Organization and Unicef said that 36 children had been paralyzed by the polio virus in Syria since the disease first reappeared there last October after a 14-year absence. Polio also has been detected in two Iraqi children in Baghdad, and it paralyzed one of them in April, the report said. Although 25 million children under the age of 5 have been vaccinated multiple times in seven Middle East countries under an emergency campaign, the report said many Syrian children missed out because of fighting and restrictions on distributing medical aid. The report said 765,000 Syrian children under 5 live in hard-to-reach areas. Polio, which is spread by feces, was thought to be nearly eradicated a few years ago, but it has spread in some fragile countries this year. In May, the W.H.O. declared a global health emergency because of the resurgence, imposing travel restrictions on Pakistan, Syria and Cameroon because the virus had spread from those countries to neighbors.

title: Morning Views
description: Millions of low- and moderate-income people who signed up for health insurance with the help of federal tax-credit subsidies could find themselves without coverage or facing big premium bills if a destructive decisionhanded down by a federal appealscourt in Washington on Tuesday is not reversed,writes The New York Times Editorial Board. The ruling, which The Board calls mindless and harmful, seized on poorly drafted language in the Affordable Care Act to end subsidies in the states that opted not to set up a state health exchange and instead relied on the federal exchange. It defies common sense to think that Congress really intended that there be no subsidies at all in 36 states, The Board writes. For now, the outcome is unclear: A second federal appeals court panel ruled the opposite way just a few hours later and the Obama administration is expected to appeal the first decision. Consumers are expected to retain their coverage and tax credits while this and similar suits in other jurisdictions wend their way through the court system. In future decisions, The Board calls for common sense in interpreting the law, not ideological opposition to Obamacare.

For the designer and stylist, known for her sculptural bikinis and chic aprs-beach layers, spending time in exotic maritime locales is not only relaxing, but also a job requirement of sorts. I love to explore and get inspiration, but also, I like to live and breathe this lifestyle, she says.I love holiday clothing  bohemian caftans and sandals and barefoot and bathing suits. Im really that person. This month, on the tail end of a summer European trip that included stops in Paris and Capri, Fernandez traveled for the first time to the mountainous Mediterranean island of Corsica. What was originally planned as a weeklong jaunt stretched out to nearly twice that amount when Fernandez found out that her friend Laure Heriard Dubrueil, the owner of Miamis the Webster boutique whose family has a house on the island, was heading over. Itsreally incredible that you can go to a place so close to France thats so wild and refined and understated and not polluted with too much of anything, Fernandez says. title: Ghost Towns, Puffins and Unspoiled Views

Scattered piles of weathered, gray boards dotted the steep, grassy banks like forgotten kindling. The captain held up a black-and-white 8-by-10 photo that echoed the view circa 1940. Back then, the timber stacks were clearly houses, schooners rested at anchor, and on the farthest hill stood a white church. Now, in the churchs place, a steeple lay in the tall grass. Worshipers last attended a service here in 1965, before a government resettlement policy forcibly moved the 157 residents of the remote fishing village, or outport, to larger communities in order to centralize the population.

Streets bear names like Rue de la Campaigne and Rue Labourdonnais. Buildings in the White Town (also called the French Quarter) are still graced with long verandahs and elegant compound walls, a genteel French-colonial vision straight out of Indochina, inflected with the pastel calm of Indias palm-fringed south. Since 2006 the town has officially been known as Puducherry, but most people here and across India still call it by its original name, Pondicherry, or its loving diminutive, Pondy.

In May, the San Antonio thirty-year-old failed a random urine test administered by her parole officer, and in July, as punishment, she was sent back to jail before being released to house arrest. The same week that Ms. DeSamito was reincarcerated, Mallory Loyola, a twenty-six-year-old with a history of using methamphetamine, gave birth to a child in Tennessee. Two days later, she was arrested and charged with assault  the first woman to be charged under a new law, effective July 1, that criminalizes the use of opiates while pregnant. Ms. Loyola later admitted that she had smoked meth three or four days before the baby was born, and was released on bail.
