description: Martin Tahse, a producer whose television shows examining the troubles and traumas of adolescence were frequent features on the long-running series ABC Afterschool Specials, died on July 1 in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Former Venezuelan Intelligence Chief Arrested in Aruba
description: POTOS, Bolivia  Officials on the Caribbean resort island of Aruba said Thursday that they had arrested a former Venezuelan intelligence chief at the request of the American authorities, who have accused him of involvement in drug trafficking.

title: Tejada Bounces Back After Hit to His Head
description: MILWAUKEE  The fastball hurtling toward Ruben Tejadas head was traveling at about 94 miles per hour, so he had little time to react. The ball struck him square on his helmet, on the front corner, just above the bill in the fifth inning of Wednesdays 3-2 win over the Seattle Mariners.

title: Mr. Trans Messy Life and Legacy
description: Truong Dinh Tran led a mostly uneventful life, unless you count spending two years in a North Vietnamese prison, swimming his way to South Vietnam, building a fortune in wartime, fleeing to the United States with a suitcase full of cash and another full of gold, installing himself and his four paramours and their children in a single-room-occupancy hotel on Manhattans West Side, becoming a subject of the biggest federal seizure of property related to drug charges in American history, and then donating $2 million to the American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund after Sept. 11. When he died, in 2012, Mr. Tran left a fortune valued at $100 million, at least 16 children by five women, one self-described wife, and no last will and testament.

title: Caseworker Shot Dead by Psychiatric Patient, Police Say
description: A psychiatric patient opened fire at a suburban hospital outside Philadelphia on Thursday, killing his caseworker and wounding his doctor, who returned fire, the authorities said.

title: Russia: 2 Activists Sent to Prison Colony
description: A Moscow court on Thursday convicted two prominent activists and sentenced them to four and a half years in a prison colony for their roles in organizing a protest a day before President Vladimir V. Putins inauguration in May 2012. The protest against Mr. Putin ended in violence between the police and demonstrators. A three-judge panel concluded that Sergei Udaltsov, the leader of the Left Front, had tried to organize mass riots in regions across Russia using money provided by a lawmaker from Georgia, with which Russia fought a war in 2008. The prosecutors case was partly based on information from a television special called The Anatomy of a Revolution that was broadcast on a state-funded television station. Mr. Udaltsov, the most prominent of 11 opposition activists sentenced to prison since the May 2012 protest, said the case was politically motivated. Mr. Udaltsovs co-defendant, Leonid Razvozzhayev, accused Russian agents of kidnapping him while he was seeking asylum in Ukraine.

title: After Mets Fall Behind, the Only Uncertainty Is the Margin of Defeat
description: MILWAUKEE  The Mets, as currently constructed, do not appear to be the kind of team capable of coming from behind routinely. They have subtly acknowledged this and seem to have accepted it, citing their lack of the pure power and the consistency up and down the order typically needed to score in bunches.

title: A Ride Across America | In Idaho, Two Sisters Get a Truck Farm Off the Ground
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, theyll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: A Playful, Design-Centric Gallery and Shop Pops Up in East Hampton
description: Two gallerists, a design retailer and a creative director walk into a bookstore. The punch line? One might imagine a battle of egos, but thats not the case for Kyle DeWoody, the community-minded owner and creative director of Grey Area, a Brooklyn-based gallery and design consultancy responsible for a series of exhibitions this summer at Glenn Horowitz Bookseller in East Hampton. After Horowitz asked her to take over the street-level and second-floor spaces within his bookstore, DeWoody opted to bring together people like herself  curators of art and tastemakers of design  to expose the talents they were most excited about. Called Grey East, the project has netted a series of splashy collaborations in an otherwise staid beach town.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) WADJDA (2013) A rambunctious 10-year-old Saudi girl (Waad Mohammed, above) enters a Quran-reciting contest with a cash prize in the hope of buying the bicycle of her dreams  a mode of transportation discouraged for women, with which she intends to race a boy  and in the process overcome her reputation as a troublemaker. Heartbreak hovers over Haifaa al-Mansours sharply observed, deceptively gentle film, reportedly the first feature ever directed by a Saudi woman, with its decorous, deliberate scenes hinting at the difficulties facing her gender, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But with impressive agility, Wadjda finds room to maneuver between harsh realism and a more hopeful kind of storytelling. There is warmth as well as austerity in Wadjdas world, kindness as well as cruelty, and the possibility, modestly sketched and ardently desired, of change. (In Arabic, with English subtitles.)

title: Morning Views
description: These days, even a school  clearly identified as a shelter run by the United Nations  cannot protect Palestinian civilians in Gaza from deadly attacks, writes The New York Times Editorial Board. At least sixteen people were killed, bringing the death toll to above 750, the vast majority being Palestinian civilians. The debate about who is responsible will go on, but what really matters now is that some way be found to stop this carnage. The war is terrorizing people on both sides of the border, fomenting more hatred; it is now past time for an immediate cease-fire and for a political strategy that offers the hope of a more stable future for both Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Morning Agenda: Hedge Fund Managers Headed for Divorce
description: HEDGE FUND MANAGERS HEADED FOR DIVORCE | For a decade, Kenneth C. Griffin and his wife, Anne Dias Griffin, were a financial powerhouse, two hedge fund managers who captivated the Chicago social scene, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. But on Wednesday, Mr. Griffin, the head of the $20 billion investment firm Citadel, filed a divorce petition in Cook County, Ill., citing irreconcilable differences after 11 years of marriage. Ms. Dias Griffin has fired back publicly, claiming to have been blindsided by the move. Now, the domestic dispute threatens to push the private couple into the spotlight.

title: 1914: Servian Nation to Resist Austria
description: BELGRADE  Servia will not shrink from the power of the great Austro-Hungarian Empire, and will reply to force by force. It is a possible case of David and Goliath. Such is the opinion I have gathered here on every side. It may sound at first suicidal on the part of this small country to seek to measure itself against the might of the Dual Monarchy. But the Servians dont seem to have an atom of fear. Undoubtedly  and the opinion of all military experts who have seen them is the same  the officers and men of the Servian army constitute the best fighting material in Europe. I saw them, at the time of the first Balkan war  three divisions, or 60,000 men, march through Mustapha Pasha, to the aid of the Bulgarians. Every man had already been in one, two or more actions. Everything one hears and sees leaves the impression that the Servians know what they are about, and that their lack of fear concerning their traditional enemies, the Austrians and Hungarians, is not without good reason.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 26, 1914

title: Israel Agrees to Pause in Assault on Gaza as Cease-Fire Deal Is Pursued

title: Taking Triathlons Into the Wild
description: BOSTON  The 46.6-mile Otillo race started as a drunken bet among four friends in 2002. The challenge? Race in pairs from Uto to Sandhamn, two islands in Swedens archipelago, which required swimming a total of 6.2 miles between 26 islands and running 40.4 miles across them. The last team to finish had to pick up the winners hotel, bar and dinner tabs on the final island.

title: Sketched Out on the Subway
description: I was sitting next to someone on the subway who was surreptitiously sketching portraits of fellow commuters. I once spotted someone opposite me doing this, and actually changed cars when I suspected he was eyeing me as a subject. Being present in a public space does not seem akin to offering permission to record your likeness without consent, despite the intended (lack of) audience or purpose of the final piece. Unlike being captured in a tourists random photograph, this act seems to involve a level of scrutiny, focus and invasiveness that makes me uncomfortable. Is it ethical to draw someone without his or her permission or knowledge? CHRISTIANA MAVROMATIS, BROOKLYN

description: In Sichuan, were eaters, said Chen Zemin, the worlds first and only frozen-dumpling billionaire. We have an expression that goes, Even if you have a very poor life, you still have your teeth to please.  He smiled and patted his not insubstantial belly. I like to eat.

title: Who Made That Ziploc Bag?
description: It seems hard to believe it now, but people did not know how to open the bag, Steven Ausnit, developer of the original Ziploc, recently told an audience at Marquette University. He recalled that sometime around the early 1960s, his company persuaded Columbia Records to try a plastic sleeve with the zipper on top for albums. At the final meeting, we were all set to go. The guy called in his assistant, handed her the sealed bag and said, Open it. I thought to myself, Lady, please do the right thing! The more she looked at it, the more my heart sank. And then she tore the zipper right off the bag.

title: Hank Greenbergs Triumph Over Hate Speech
description: On a central Illinois baseball field in 1931, a 20-year-old minor leaguer named Hank Greenberg was heckled by the opposing teams third baseman with anti-Semitic insults  language that we in 2014 would call hate speech. When Greenberg could no longer stand the provocations, which were echoed by an angry, roaring crowd, he confronted the third baseman and was rushed out of the park by local police for protection. Greenberg later said the fracas was scary.

And then there are the four chickens and a rabbit named Sugar Daddy.
