title: Marlons Method
description: The title of Susan L. Mizruchis Marlon Brando book is a hassle. You dont want to be seen with anything called Brandos Smile. You just dont. I read the book the old-fashioned way  on paper. I read it in restaurants, on the subway and in the park. I read it with the front cover obscured. To dislike the title of the book is to reject its putative premise  that Brando wasnt just a sexy slob with no technique but an extremely skilled, deeply intelligent, fiercely perceptive public citizen who carefully controlled his smiles. Mizruchi seems to be making a case that the modus operandi of one of the movies greatest performers can be reduced to the strategic concealment of dental work.

title: Devilish Audacity
description: Not so long ago, giants bestrode the British boards. In that theatrically golden 20th century, the stage could boast those wonderful knights, Sirs John Gielgud, Laurence Olivier, Michael Redgrave and Ralph Richardson. Close on their heels were Alec Guinness, John Mills, Paul Scofield, Trevor Howard and Peter OToole, among others. And all along there was that chameleon of genius, Nol Coward.

title: Reports From the Exterior
description: The same week I began reading Amy Rowlands debut novel, The Transcriptionist, a Malaysian jetliner vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. Its a testament to the eerie power of Rowlands fictional world that while I watched and read the news about the search for the plane, hands to my mouth, I wondered: Who will call this story in to Lena? And can Lena bear it?

title: Captivating and Repellent
description: Ben Macintyres A Spy Among Friends, about Kim Philby, the British spy who served as a double agent for the Soviet Union, is reviewed this week by Walter Isaacson.

title: Short Stories
description: THE TAO OF HUMILIATION  Stories  By Lee Upton  BOA Editions, paper, $16.

title: Inside the List
description: Private Lives: Americas most famous literary recluses are back in the spotlight. J. D. Salinger, who died in 2010, is the subject of Thomas Bellers gentle New York-centric biography, J. D. Salinger: The Escape Artist, while Harper Lee turns up at the center of The Mockingbird Next Door, by the former Chicago Tribune reporter Marja Mills, new at No. 4 on the hardcover nonfiction list. There are a lot of superficial similarities between Salinger and Lee: Born seven years apart, both wrote beloved novels that have endured for decades as staples of high school reading lists  The Catcher in the Rye and To Kill a Mockingbird, as if you didnt know  and both quit writing in the early 1960s to retreat into strictly enforced silences. But they probably never met for drinks, to judge from the portrait of Lee that emerges in The Mockingbird Next Door. Mills first met Lee and her sister on assignment for The Tribune, and eventually rented the house neighboring theirs in Monroeville, Ala., for a year and a half, during which she had ample time to observe Lee going about her ordinary daily life: eating at McDonalds, feeding the town ducks, fishing with hot dogs as bait. Contrast those humble details with what weve learned over the years about the deeply eccentric Salinger, whose daughter claimed he sat in an orgone box and drank his own urine, and it becomes clear they dont have much in common after all.

title: Most Migrant Children Entering U.S. Are Now With Relatives, Data Show
description: LOS ANGELES  The vast majority of unaccompanied migrant children arriving in the United States from Central America this year have been released to relatives in states with large established Central American populations, according to federal data released Thursday night.

title: Much Ado About Everything
description: I once met a man with magic in his pocket. He was a former hairdresser named Maurice Ward, and the magic was a material he invented called Starlite. He said it was one of the most astonishing thermal barriers in the world and had been tested in high-profile labs, including a British atomic weapons facility, where it withstood several simulated nuclear flashes. Despite its dizzying potential  fireproof airplanes, laser-resistant tanks  Starlite never ventured far out of Wards pocket, because he refused to sell or reveal its recipe before his death a couple of years ago. I mention this because it still intrigues me, as a good mystery should, and because it was my first encounter with the head-scratching, captivating possibilities of man-made materials.

title: Sneaking Suspicions
description: Lisa ODonnells dazzling new novel transports us to small-town Scotland and into the increasingly volatile mind of an 11-year-old boy. Michael Murray, who narrates the book, lives with his parents and grandmother in Rothesay on the Isle of Bute. As in most small towns, everybody seems to know everybody elses business. Here gossip is something more than a spectator sport.

title: An Architect Gets Busy
description: His buildings might not be the tallest, priciest or zaniest. But in New York, the British architect Norman Foster seems to be having a moment all the same.

title: Those Who Stay
description: Kseniya Melniks accomplished debut collection, Snow in May, takes us deep into the complex fabric of Magadan, an isolated fishing and mining town in the northern reaches of Russia that once served as a transit center for prisoners dispatched to Stalins labor camps.

title: Radical Inquiry
description: I love Ellen Willis, a friend told me upon hearing there would be an anthology collecting the work of the cultural critic, who was also The New Yorkers first pop music writer. She makes me feel less embarrassed to enjoy the Who.

title: The Wealth of Ideas
description: Before it became a political philosophy, liberalism was not that difficult to define: A person was liberal if generous, catholic in taste or even excessively rotund. Liberal people may not have been universally admired, but few took to castigating them as dangerous to the health of the state. The opposite of liberal was not conservative but strict. When Bassanio tells Portia in The Merchant of Venice that he will give her the dearest ring in Venice, she replies, I see, sir, you are liberal in offers. No one in Shakespeares audience would have concluded that the dissolute nobleman with whom she banters stood on the left side of the political spectrum.

title: Against Closure
description: A while ago, on the planet of the novelists, two warring factions argued over whether or not characters had to be likable. Absolutely not, the frowny-face contingent claimed, arguing that one of literatures goals is to illuminate the state of being human, in all its flawed glory. The smiley-face tribe took umbrage: Whats the matter with creating characters readers would like to have as friends? But maybe the question of liking or not liking is the easy one. The harder one, maybe, is what should we make of characters who never really allow us to know them? Characters who are in pain for reasons we understand and behave badly for reasons we can comprehend, but who inspire nothing as strong as liking or loathing. What happens when we close a book with neither a shudder nor a smile, but only a shrug?

title: Off the Reservation
description: As I began Brando Skyhorses Take This Man, I thought, Ah, another New Agonist! New Agonists serve the kettle corn of memoir, candy you cant put down. But often, at books end, theres little to do except swap horrors: Can you believe the part where Brandos mama tries to drown him in the toilet? What about when she tries to put him up for adoption by placing an ad in a magazine? And so on.

title: Love Is Strange
description: My inappropriate nickname for A. L. Kennedy is Dr. Strangelove. Not because shes a devious former Nazi played by Peter Sellers in a movie of the same name, but because her work is obsessed with love and strangeness and, in this particular case, with the strangeness of love. Theres also a strangeness in her writing  both her premises and her sentences  that makes it tricky to situate this prolific Scottish author in any particular literary context. She does things her fellow widely prized and widely translated peers do not: compose whole novels in the second person, write BBC dramas, perform stand-up comedy and ponder in prose the existence of such items as a chocolate-flavored condom, as she does in her new collection of stories, All the Rage.

title: World of Our Great-Grandfathers
description: Back in the days when Jews could travel without having to go anywhere  one minute a house was in Poland, the next in Russia  they lived in places called shtetls, defined neither by physical size nor population, possessing mysterious features both urban and rural. Though Christians lived there too, the shtetl tilted spiritually toward Jerusalem, while performing economic services for the Slavic society to which it also belonged, giving it an Eastern European character all its own. Its amorphous nature has made it the subject of easy mythologizing, so that it often pops up in the American imagination as a kind of Jewish Brigadoon where all the villagers are singing, unless they are running from a pogrom.

title: Insatiable Gaze
description: Was Lucian Freud really a great painter? Im not convinced. But he looms large in the social history of postwar London, an inimitable figure who crossed paths with everyone from Kate Moss to the Kray brothers. Born in Berlin in 1922, Freud was 10 when his family moved to London (well before his famous grandfather, who escaped Austria only in 1938). He showed precocious talent as a draftsman  and as a troublemaker. Quick with his fists, he was a chronic expellee. Eventually he ended up at a private art school in Essex run by Cedric Morris; when the school burned down one night, Freud took the credit. But he remained a protg of Morris, one of a series of gay elders with whom the young Freud knew how to ingratiate himself  though he was conspicuously, not to say voraciously, heterosexual. His looks were as striking as his talent, despite Stephen Spenders observation at the time that he resembled Harpo Marx.

title: Was Warren Harding, In Fact, a Terrible President?
description: The many scandalous letters that Warren Harding wrote to his mistress, Carrie Phillips, which the Library of Congress is releasing on July 29, are deliciously fun to read. Written from 1910 to 1920, before Harding was elected president, the correspondence has helped inspire reassessments of his time in office. Harding is usually relegated to the bottom of presidential rankings. But he shouldnt be, according to Voxs Dylan Matthews and Slates Ronald and Allis Radosh. Harding was hardly a great president,Matthews writes, but he doesnt deserve the overwhelmingly negative reputation hes developed.

title: Decline and Falling
description: Ten floors up in a seedy apartment building on the edge of a city on the edge of a dry continent and a vast ocean, Tim Wintons antihero teeters on the brink of destitution and despair. In the wake of several storms that have engulfed his life, hes been left stranded, a fish flapping uselessly on the sand. Set, as so many of Wintons books are, in Western Australia  which was, you could say, like Texas. Only it was big  his new novel, Eyrie, is a dark but dazzling study of people and places on the edge. These marginal zones are where Winton enjoys spending time, scavenging for driftwood, floats, rope, old sea boots  and characters like Tom Keely, a washed-up environmentalist whos been unceremoniously ejected from the world of idealism and activism.

title: A Contender
description: So much precious time goes by and it seems to me I get so little out of it, Elia Kazan wrote to John Steinbeck in 1955. I ask myself is this it? Is this why? Is this what I wanted to do? Is this why I accumulated what dough I have. I feel like a highly publicized meal ticket, some of the time, doing what the hell my wife and family and society expects of me and not at all  since I dont think originally enough  what Id like to do. I can imagine great excitement to life again. But something prevents my going after it.

title: The Special Challenges of Retiring From a Business You Own
description: RETIRING is challenging for almost everyone. But if youre a small-business owner, preparing to hand your company to your children can create an even bigger knot of anxiety  worries about financial security, the legacy of your lifes work and the prospects for your offspring. The process can touch everything from spreadsheet-driven company valuations to awkward talks about your childrens limitations. It can demand the technical knowledge of a C.P.A. and the soft skills of a psychologist.

title: New Find Hints at More Feathered Dinosaurs
description: A new dinosaur species, one with feathers, has been discovered in Russia. The finding could mean that feathers were more widespread among dinosaurs than previously thought, the researchers say.

title: Are Trophies Really So Bad?
description: Those who see the 21st century as a time of unprecedented narcissismfrequently focus on trophies: Too many kids get them nowadays, the argument goes, and its leading to rampant entitlement and jerkitude.But anyone whos felt the sting of not getting a gold star (especially in our allegedly gold-star-happy times) may relate to Molly Knefels recent examination of the trophy and its discontents.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: India Threatens to Block Global Trade Deal
description: MUMBAI, India  India could put a landmark World Trade Organization deal in jeopardy at hectic negotiations in Geneva after saying that it would withhold support for the agreement unless there was simultaneous progress on resolving a dispute over its food security program.

title: Addressing Caregivers Loss of Retirement Income
description: Earlier this month Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of New York, introduced what shes calling the Social Security Caregiver Credit Act, intended to increase retirement income for middle-class citizens who must reduce their work hours or leave the work force because of caregiving duties.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: July 25
description: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes images from the funeral of Eric Garner, who died after a confrontation with the police on Staten Island, and white flags on the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Today in Small Business: What Its Really Like to Own a McDonalds
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Alan C. Greenberg, 86, Dies; Led Bear Stearns in Good Times and Bad
description: Alan C. Greenberg, a risk-chasing Wall Street titan who built Bear Stearns into a global investment banking powerhouse and shared responsibility, many analysts said, for its collapse as America slid toward a calamitous recession in 2008, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Editors Choice
description: MOTHERLAND FATHERLAND HOMELANDSEXUALS,  by Patricia Lockwood. (Penguin Poets, paper, $20.) Lockwood offers a collection at once angrier, and more fun, more attuned to our time and more bizarre, than most poetry can ever get.

title: A Case of Murder, Streamlined
description: The story of Lizzie Borden  tried and acquitted, yet still often assumed guilty in the 1892 ax murder of her father and stepmother  was a tantalizing spur to artists, inspiring Agnes de Milles 1948 ballet, Fall River Legend, and Jack Beesons 1965 opera, Lizzie Borden. While Beeson, who died in 2010, and his librettist, Kenward Elmslie, created a memorably anxious, creepy work, its three acts all but ensured it would remain a rarity.

title: When Making Sense Was Optional
description: When Jonathan Demmes Talking Heads concert film Stop Making Sense came out 30 years ago, practically everyone agreed that the genre had taken a stupendous leap forward.

title: Original, and Built to Stay That Way
description: Time has often smiled on the art of Henry Threadgill, a composer, saxophonist and flutist who has followed his own labyrinthine path through the realm of avant-garde jazz. The oldest of his albums, made 35 years ago, retains the spark of an unfolding event: It sounds at times as if it could be made by musicians working today, which probably tells you what you need to know about Mr. Threadgills influence.

title: Bite-Size Flights of Fancy
description: Contemporary dance has a reputation for being adult entertainment. Not so much because of heavy themes or graphic images  which are rare  but because we dont trust children to get abstraction (which may just be our own internalized bafflement). The Nutcracker feels safer.

title: Defining Visions, on the Road
description: With the East Building of the National Gallery of Art in Washington closed for a three-year renovation and expansion, curators there have organized a series of exhibitions with works from its postwar and contemporary art collection. One show, Make It New: Abstract Paintings From the National Gallery of Art, 1950-1975, opens Saturday at the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., in its new Clark Center designed by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando.

title: Investigators and Their Secrets
description: Blood is everywhere in Season 4 of The Killing: flowing off the body of Sarah Linden (Mireille Enos), spackled on the jacket of Stephen Holder (Joel Kinnaman), splattered at the scene of their latest case like a Pollock in red and white. We just got to keep our stories straight, Linden, Holder tells his perpetually glowering partner, now in full-on rattled mode. No ones going to find out. No ones got to know what we did.

title: To Pop Legends, He Was a Guitar Hero
description: Rock n roll cult heroes burn brightly and briefly. Such romantic figures as Nick Drake, Syd Barrett, Gram Parsons and Jeff Buckley recorded just a few tracks before they were gone  literally or figuratively  left to be discovered by later generations of cool kids, forever frozen as young, beautiful and alluringly obscure.

title: Of Green Day, Green Hair and Still Green Rock Stars
description: The guys of 5 Seconds of Summer  four lanky Australian youths with a taste for pop-punk, notable hair and a following of millions across social media  would rather not be thought of as a boy band.

title: A Boss Whos Open to Suggestions
description: LOS ANGELES  In the first few episodes of Power, a new series from Starz, one man is shot in the forehead; another is beaten to a bloody pulp; a third is doused with rubber cement and set ablaze. At the center of the mayhem is James St. Patrick (Omari Hardwick), better known as Ghost, a husband and father who manages a swanky nightclub when hes not stepping out on his beautiful wife, Tasha (Naturi Naughton), or running one of New York Citys most powerful drug empires.

title: Todays Hot I.P.O.: El Pollo Loco
description: Updated, 1:39 p.m. | Investors seem to like the taste of chicken.

title: Rand Paul Stands Out in Courting Black Voters
description: CINCINNATI  After Mitt Romney received just 6 percent of the black vote in 2012, the Republican Party said that it could no longer afford to ignore African-Americans. We are never going to win over voters who are not asked for their support, its leaders wrote in a candid election post-mortem.

title: Against Walter Kasper (II)
description: Back in May, I offered some general commentson the question of communion for divorced and remarried Catholics which looms over the Synod on the Family scheduled for this autumn in Rome, and may represent one of the defining controversies of Pope Franciss pontificate and then wrote what was intended to be the first of two posts addressing Cardinal Walter Kaspers high-profile case for admitting the remarried to the sacrament. That post offered theological and sociological reasons to be skeptical of Kaspers broad suggestion, offered in an interview with the editors of Commonweal, that Catholic marriage generally is in a crisis more severe even than divorce statistics would suggest, in which (he argued) possibly as many as half of all Catholic marriages are actually invalid.The second post, which I promised and then didnt deliver, was supposed to be a detailed response to his specific proposal on communion, which he first presentedin remarks to his fellow cardinalsin the winter and then elaborated again in the Commonweal interview this spring.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Old Parts at an Old Show
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Graffiti and the Civil War
description: In September 1864, Cpl. Robert I. Hogue was stationed with his regiment, the 8th Ohio Volunteer Cavalry, at an unassuming church known as Morgans Chapel in Bunker Hill, W.V. Mustered into service earlier that year, the unit had seen hard fighting throughout the Shenandoah Valley that summer. A month later, it would participate in the decisive Union victory at Cedar Creek. But in this interstitial moment, the soldiers had some down time.

title: Paperback Row
description: CATASTROPHE 1914: Europe Goes to War,  by Max Hastings. (Vintage, $17.95.) This is an excellent chronicle of World War Is first months, from the initial diplomatic crisis to the fighting in Belgium and France on the Western Front, and Serbia and Galicia to the east. Hastings, the author of Inferno: The World at War, 1939-1945, finds the argument that Germany bore principal blame overwhelmingly strong. Sean McMeekins JULY 1914: Countdown to War (Basic Books, $17.99) opens with a vivid reconstruction of Archduke Franz Ferdinands assassination in Sarajevo on June 28, then focuses on the actions of a small group of statesmen  Austrian, German, Russian, French  as they sought to capitalize on the fallout.

title: Movie Review: A Most Wanted Man
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews A Most Wanted Man.

title: Movie Review: Lucy
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Lucy.

title: Russia Steps Up Help for Rebels in Ukraine War
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Rather than backing down after last weeks downing of a civilian passenger jet, Russia appears to be intervening more aggressively in the war in eastern Ukraine in what American and Ukrainian officials call a dangerous escalation that will almost certainly force more robust retaliation from the United States and Europe.

title: In Investing, 'When' Matters Just as Much as 'What'
description: Today I brought you the story of four hypothetical savers to show how timing can be unlucky for some investors who are saving for retirement via the stock market. If youre building retirement savings little by little over decades, it matters a great deal not just what the stock market or other investments return, but when those returns materialize.

title: Text and Ride in India
description: PUNE, India  When Praveen Narayan Dusane first started driving an auto-rickshaw in this crowded college town, he had to hustle for every rupee. He could wait hours at a rickshaw stand for passengers. He fought with other drivers and haggled with passengers over the fares. Typically, he earned just 300 rupees, or roughly $5, during a 12-hour shift.

title: A Mac That Keeps Working, Even in Sleep Mode
description: Q. I thought I wasnt getting new mail on my phone when I was out running around, but it turns out my new iMac at home was downloading mail even though I put it to sleep. How is this possible?

title: Taking Stock of Four Years of Dodd-Frank
description: Jennifer Taub is professor at Vermont Law School. Her book Other Peoples Houses was published in May by Yale University Press.

title: In Context or Out of Step?
description: On West 79th Street from Amsterdam Avenue to Broadway is a remarkable holdover from the late 19th century, two facing rows of townhouses on a wide street. In the Upper West Side/Central Park West Historic District, the buildings are almost intact, although four were replaced in the 1970s with a homely apartment house of the same height, 203-209 West 79th.

title: Tomatoes All Summer Long
description: Once summer tomatoes are flourishing in my garden and at farmers markets, capturing their bounty for the rest of the year becomes a weekly ritual. This mostly involves the making of marinara sauce; I try to have enough of it in the freezer to last me through a winters worth of impromptu pasta dinners.

title: On the Upper West Side, a House Divided by Income
description: Even as so many crises roiled the world recently, the news that a development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan would proceed with a brand of distasteful social engineering still managed to command international attention. The building, in what is known as Riverside South, a stretch of land reaching below 72nd Street that seems largely like a pop-up location for people who have never heard of Katzs deli or the G train, had received approval from the city for separate entrances  one for wealthy residents and one for those earning far less who would occupy the projects affordable units, in a separate wing.

title: Best Time of Day for a Testosterone Test
description: Doctors often recommend that men with erectile dysfunction have their testosterone measured from 8 a.m. to 11 a.m., because levels are usually highest then and vary over a 24-hour period. But a new study has found that this variation occurs only in younger men.

title: Letting a Child Make the Small Sacrifice
description: It so happened, recently, that my 10-year-old daughter and I wanted the same thing. It could have been anything  the last brownie, the window seat  but what matters is that there was only one. If our happiness depended on this one thing, there was no way we would both end up happy.

title: British Prosecutor to Pay $5.1 Million in Case Related to Kaupthing Inquiry
description: Updated, 1:02 p.m. | LONDON  Britains Serious Fraud Office said on Friday that it would pay 3 million pounds, or about $5.1 million, to settle civil claims brought by a property developer following a flawed investigation into the collapse of the Icelandic bank Kaupthing during the financial crisis.

title: Big Ticket | Park and River Vistas for $30 Million
description: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath apartment with Central Park and Hudson River vistas from the 33rd floor of the tower at 15 Central Park West sold for $30,003,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: At the Wheel, the Balloonatic
description: To many regular passengers on the weekday morning M-8 crosstown bus, Nick Rotondo, 53, is the consummate city bus driver: a seasoned, cheery fellow with a New Yorkers savvy.

title: Once an Ornamental Hermit, Now a German Media Darling
description: BERLIN  On a hot summer night here, under the twinkling lights of a spinning disco ball, Friedrich Liechtenstein took the stage in a paisley-print silk bathrobe. My dear people, the newly minted German media star said, in a sonorous voice, If things dont work out tonight, dont think of this as an awful show. Rather, I recommend you look at it as if it were a film  one that replicates, very precisely, an awful show.

title: French President on Air Algerie Crash
description: President Franois Hollande of France said there were no survivors in the crash of an Air Algrie jetliner, as the first images of the wreckage site in Mali were released.

title: John Walshs Campaign Sinking Under Plagiarism
description: Its virtually an axiom in Washington politics that when the establishment declares its undying support for a person at the center of a scandal, that person is about to be thrown under the bus. The latest potential traffic victim is Senator John Walsh of Montana, the retired Army colonel who seems to have plagiarized his masters thesis for the United States Army War College.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Kim Philby Case
description: This week, Ben Macintyre discusses A Spy Among Friends; Alexandra Alter and Parul Sehgal talk about the weeks literary news; Donald L. Miller discusses Supreme City; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Transforming the Investment Case for BSkyB
description: British Sky Broadcasting is no more. The company is buying sister Sky units in Germany and Italy for at least 4.9 billion pounds ($8.3 billion) in cash from Rupert Murdochs 21st Century Fox. That transforms the investment case for Britains top pay-television company.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Kim Philby Case
description: This week, Ben Macintyre and Donald L. Miller.

title: Mark Fisher: A Day Away From the Ninjas
description: While acting in regional theater in his 20s, Mark Fisher often shared workout techniques with fellow cast members, and his advice became so popular that he turned it into a regimen, called Snatched in Six Weeks. Two years ago, with residuals from an Allstate commercial, he and his business partner opened Mark Fisher Fitness on West 39th Street in Hells Kitchen  and moved into an apartment upstairs. The gym (known as the clubhouse) draws scores of Broadway performers, including Shina Ann Morris, an actress in Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella who became Mr. Fishers girlfriend. Mr. Fisher, 34, and Ms. Morris, 28, live together in the apartment with Mr. Fishers business partner and his boyfriend.

title: The New Oil Patch: Rail Lines in Albany and Elsewhere
description: In a thorough piece, Albany Nears Oil-Hub Status as 100-Car Trains Jam Port, Bloomberg News does a great job of illustrating why New York State has to work swiftly to get a handle on issues related to the oil-by-rail boom.

title: Taking New Music From Los Angeles to Reykjavik
description: Here is a glimpse of how an enterprising classical new-music ensemble gets projects underway in 2014.

title: An Exclusive New Club in Paris With a No-Social-Media Rule
description: Lisol, a bar in the red light district of Pigalle that will open in time for Paris fashion week, translates to the isolated. Its not exactly antisocial, but it does have a strict No Facebook, No Twitter policy. Co-founders Guillaume Le Donche and Antoine Galabert want it to be a place with a human touch. We manage all our communication with prints and real-life networking, says Le Donche, 27, who honed his skills at Parisian hot spots La Clique, Showcase and LInconnu. With only digital promotion, youre just lost in the maze of the Internet.

title: Is Moores Law Less Important to the Tech Industry?
description: The central organizing principle of much of the tech industry is Moores Law. In one very important sense, it may be of less value than it once was.

title: Before Kubrick Was an Auteur
description: Stanley Kubrick, who would have turned 86 on Saturday, was once known professionally as just Stan Kubrick  an almost comically breezy abbreviation for the man we know as a titanically exacting director. Then again, Kubrick was only 16 at the time, a precocious boy from the Grand Concourse with a Graflex camera, who had somehow blustered his way into the picture department at Look magazine. For the next five years there, before his movie career began, he held his own with the New York photojournalists of the 1940s, covering street life, prizefights, jazz concerts, stars and starlets, and forging a recognizable style of his own.

title: Smooth Dogfish Shark: A Threat, if Youre a Clam
description: The Atlantic shoreline has not been the same since June 1975, when Jaws opened. For many, the movies deep, pulsating theme music remains an ominous reminder that there could be something looking up at us from under our kicking feet. Sightings of great white sharks off our coastlines sell newspapers for weeks each summer  and this year has been no exception.

title: Stepping Into the Frame in the South of France
description: It was Paul Czanne who went to LEstaque first, in 1864. He escaped the gray dreariness of Paris and later avoided army conscription in the Franco-Prussian War of 1870 in this sunny shorefront village outside Marseille. From the windows of a rented house next to the little church on the hill, he could look out on the tile rooftops leading down to the harbor, with its fishing boats, and across the wide bay to Marseille, the low, rocky mountains at its back.

title: 1939: Worlds End Because of Mars?
description: The Mexican astronomer who has seized on the planet Marss approach to the earth to predict the end of the world tomorrow is ignorant of the elements of astronomy, according to Ernest Esclangon, director of the Paris Observatory, who, in a mock-serious vein, yesterday authorized a denial of the publicity-seeking prediction. Why, in the firmaments name, should the approach of Mars be a danger to this planet of ours? M. Esclangon told anxious reporters. It is a simple matter of planetary motions which brings Mars in line with the earth and the sun every sixteen years, and if this geometrical phenomenon were to be the end of the world every time it occurred, there would have been no world long before this. Mere proximity of Mars to the earth is no menace, M. Esclangon explained, since both planets continue to move in their respective orbits, like ships that pass by each other on the high seas, each on its own course.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 26, 1939

title: A Turkish Town Where Baklava Beckons
description: The first thing you notice among passengers departing from Oguzeli Airport in Gaziantep, Turkey, is the profusion of shopping bags containing baklava, the intensely sweet Middle Eastern phyllo pastry and nut confection that is a staple of every Turkish celebration. This city of about a million people, in the province of the same name and situated on the Silk Road about 530 miles southeast of Istanbul, claims some 100 baklava shops, which supply 90 percent of the baklava consumed in Turkey. Last December, Gaziantep baklava, which is made with locally grown pistachio nuts, was awarded protected status by the European Union, a designation that recognizes a specific local food, protects it from imitators and potentially helps boost tourism to the area.

title: Hotel Review: Pestana South Beach Art Deco Hotel in Miami Beach
description: Rates

title: A Secluded Modern
description: Seatuck Cove Farms, a secluded 22-acre estate with 2,000 feet of waterfront on Seatuck Creek and Little Seatuck Creek in Eastport, and panoramic views across Moriches Bay to Dune Road in Westhampton, is entering the market for the first time in 35 years. The asking price is $12 million.

title: Lots of Paul Ryans New Report Is About State and Local Policy
description: Some of the most innovative ideas for conservative reforms are in policy areas controlled by state and local governments. Thats why, beyond its proposals to change how the federal government fights poverty, the new discussion draft from Representative Paul Ryan has recommendations in areas you might not associate with him: education, sentencing, parole and occupational licensing, to name a few.

title: Passions Running to Art, or Infanticide
description: LONDON  You have heard this story before, many times, and its never been pretty. A wife devotes her existence to furthering her husbands career, making countless self-denying sacrifices. And then the bum trades her in for a younger model. The discarded wife gets angrier and angrier and angrier, until theres truly hell to pay.

title: Peach Crumble Slab Pie
description: Melissa Clark makes a delicious deep-dish dessert with fresh peaches that is equal parts crumble and pie.

title: A Stripped-Down Domestic Drama
description: Just why A Dolls House needs stripping down to its essentials, I dont know, but people keep trying. The new production of Nora at the Westport Country Playhouse has a minimalist set and a naked man in the spotlight at the end. Nora is the 1981 adaptation by Swedens genius film auteur Ingmar Bergman of A Dolls House, Henrik Ibsens landmark 1879 feminist domestic drama; Bergman had already eliminated six of the original plays characters (the children and the servants).

title: Studs Terkel Audio Archive to Go Online
description: The creation of a publicly accessible digital archive with nearly 5,000 oral history interviews, conducted by the Chicago journalist Studs Terkel, is one of 177 projects awarded a grant this week by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: The Future Looks Peachy
description: The sad truth about homemade peach pie is that theres never enough.

title: Indian Air Force Helicopter Crashes, Killing 7
description: NEW DELHI  An Indian Air Force helicopter exploded and crashed in northern India on Friday, possibly after hitting a high-voltage electrical cable, killing all seven people aboard, the authorities announced.

title: Setting Sights on Long Island and Wars Past
description: Joshua Ruff, the chief curator of the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, has chosen objects of all shapes and sizes for the exhibitions there  including, recently, a large gun sight from a World War II B-32 bomber that Mr. Ruff estimates weighs about 400 pounds.

title: In Queens, Immigrants Clash With Residents of New Homeless Shelter
description: The crowd of 500 included grandmothers and small children, Chinese immigrants and the president of a local Republican club, all shouting that the mayor had trampled their rights.

title: Long Beach Film Festival Finds a Home
description: After Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012, the fledgling Long Beach International Film Festival, which had just finished its inaugural year, threatened to collapse before ever fully taking off. A prospective screening site had been destroyed, and without a proper venue the festival could not attract filmmakers and sponsors.

title: Popcast: Arto Lindsays Ecstatic Procession
description: Arto Lindsay, the singer and guitarist who was born in Virginia and raised partly in Recife, Brazil, has been an important if inconstant figure in New York music over the last 35 years.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Kim Philby Case
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Walter Isaacson reviews Ben Macintyres A Spy Among Friends: Kim Philby and the Great Betrayal. Mr. Isaacson writes:

title: 1875: The Airplane, Still a Flight of Fancy
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: A Hamptons Bistro Gets an Update
description: If there is such a thing as a restaurant mecca in the Hamptons these days, it would mostly likely be Sag Harbor, the quaint former whaling town located north of Bridgehampton.

title: Top Sprinters Crash Ruins Bid for First Stage Win
description: BERGERAC, France  It was another rainy day at the Tour de France with a rider from the American Garmin-Sharp team at the front as the finish neared. But unlike Jack Bauer, who was caught only yards before the finish line in Nmes on Sunday, Ramunas Navardauskas managed to win alone Friday after a 129.5-mile trek through downpours, thunder and lightning.

title: Employees Who Leave Increasingly Return to the Fold
description: LeBRON JAMES has been called a king, a superathlete, a traitor. And now that the basketball megastar has decided to return to Cleveland and the team he once abandoned, hes earned a new moniker he may not even know about: boomerang.

title: Putting the A in STEAM
description: An arrangement of test tubes containing color-coded genetic material; a wearable garden that purifies the air; an installation inspired by the periodic table  these artworks all incorporate components of STEM, an educational curriculum that is an acronym for science, technology, engineering and mathematics. They are currently among more than 40 pieces on view in Steam, a new exhibition at ArtsWestchesters Arts Exchange.

title: S.E.C. Says Citigroup Unit Failed to Protect Customer Trading Data
description: LavaFlow, a unit of Citigroup that operates an alternative stock trading venue, agreed to pay $5 million to settle charges that it failed to protect the confidential trading data of its customers, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday. The payment includes a $2.85 million penalty that the S.E.C. said was the largest it had levied against an alternative trading system.

title: A Drop in the Long-Term Unemployed
description: THE long-term unemployment rate, which soared in 2009 to heights not seen since the Great Depression, is finally declining rapidly. The proportion of the work force that has been unemployed for at least 27 weeks has fallen to 1.98 percent, less than half the record high of 4.4 percent reached in 2010.

title: At Goldman Sachs, the Right Candidate for a Half-Right Job
description: Goldman Sachs has found the right man for a half-right job.

title: A Greek Summer Treasure
description: In Greece, the summer produce of choice is the sweet, meaty, sun-ripened red tomato. Tomatoes are eaten daily, usually with not much more adornment than a sprinkling of sea salt and a drizzle of fruity olive oil. They can be raw or cooked; either way, they are wonderful.

title: A Landlord Rents Office Space, and Maybe a Picture or Two
description: Many business owners want their offices to reflect good taste, with fine art on the walls. But they must weigh the cost against the vagaries of the marketplace. A few good years, and the millions come rolling in. A few setbacks, and the banks send a crew to pack up the furniture.

title: Vick Teaches Smith Virtually and in Reality
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  After a recent morning practice, Geno Smith, the young quarterback who many presume will be the Jets starter, recalled the first time he was introduced to Michael Vick, the veteran who could well be his backup.

title: How to Charge Your Phone in 15 Minutes
description: Say youve got 15 minutes in an airport between flights and your phone is nearly dead. What do you do?

title: Brooklyn Bridge White Flag Culprits Avoiding Capture, So Far
description: The daredevils who scaled the towers of the Brooklyn Bridge and put white flags in place of the American flags there have eluded capture for three days, and authorities said Friday that they were not much closer to finding them.

title: Documenting Missteps in Death of Peace Corps Volunteer
description: Documents, including emails, letters and investigative reports about the death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old Peace Corps volunteer in China.

title: The 19th-Century Home of Jell-Os Forefather
description: As the historian of Ringwood Manor, a sprawling country home on the grounds of Ringwood State Park, Sue Shutte often deals with the constant quirks and mysteries of this 19th-century estate.

title: Peace Corps Volunteers in Their Own Words
description: To reflect the diversity of experiences in the Peace Corps, The Times asked recent volunteers to share stories about their service.

title: Trail of Medical Missteps in a Peace Corps Death
description: BRENTWOOD, Calif.  Nick Castle had just graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, when he loaded up his backpack with Mandarin-language books and set off for rural China to teach in the Peace Corps. Seven months later, in January 2013, a 2 a.m. telephone call jolted his parents awake.

title: Ezra Klein Asks the Wrong Question
description: He asks, Why should anyone trust Paul Ryans poverty plan? Thats easy: nobody should. This has been another edition of simple answers to simple questions.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: DVFs Enduring Reign, Louboutins Beauty Moment and Zac Posens Candid Confessions
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Are You Fluent in Emoji?
description: Find out how well you communicate using emojis in this 10 question quiz.

title: The Emoji Have Won the Battle of Words
description: It started about six months ago, with a smiley face here and there, a sequence of pictograph red hearts when friends would send baby pictures or a string of blown kisses to say good night. I especially liked the face with a toothy, uncomfortable-looking grimace: Yikes, it seemed to say. Perfect for Im sorry Im late! or Eek, its 1 p.m. and I just woke up.

title: Opaque System Obscures Support for Health Care Ad
description: WASHINGTON  The television ad sponsored by the advocacy arm of the National Federation of Independent Business featured a small-business owner in Arkansas, frustrated at what he said were the higher bills he had seen since the Obama administrations health care plan went into effect  and pointing blame at Senator Mark Pryor, a Democrat considered one of the most vulnerable incumbents facing re-election this fall.

title: No Time to Think
description: ONE of the biggest complaints in modern society is being overscheduled, overcommitted and overextended. Ask people at a social gathering how they are and the stock answer is super busy, crazy busy or insanely busy. Nobody is just fine anymore.

title: Failure Is Our Muse
description: JULY 8, in case you happened to miss it, was Fitz-Greene Halleck Day, a chance to remember the most intensely forgotten writer in American history. No name in the American poetical world is more firmly established than that of Fitz-Greene Halleck, Edgar Allan Poe wrote in 1843. And yet, despite a Central Park statue that still stands in his honor, Fitz-Greene Halleck may now be the most famous man ever to achieve total obscurity.

title: In Wake of Disasters, an Air Travel F.A.Q.
description: In the aftermath of the shooting of Malaysia Airlines flight 17 last week and the rocket strike near Ben-Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv this week, people planning to fly to the Middle East or on a route crossing Eastern Europe have been left wondering whether or not they could  or should  continue with their travel plans.

title: Were Missing the Story
description: LISBON  THE Western news media are in crisis and are turning their back on the world. We hardly ever notice. Where correspondents were once assigned to a place for years or months, reporters now handle 20 countries each. Bureaus are in hub cities, far from many of the countries they cover. And journalists are often lodged in expensive bungalows or five-star hotels. As the news has receded, so have our minds.

title: Bel Kaufman, Who Told What School Was Really Like, Dies at 103
description: Bel Kaufman, a former New York City schoolteacher whose classic first novel, Up the Down Staircase  shot through with despair and hopefulness, violence and levity, bureaucratic inanity and a blizzard of official memorandums so mind-bendingly illogical as to seem almost Kafkaesque  was hailed as a stunningly accurate portrait of life in an urban school when it was published in 1965, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 103.

title: The End of the Cringe
description: Doug Sosnik has an interesting piece in Politico on how the left is taking over the Democratic Party. Of course, what he calls left would be centrist, maybe even right of center, in most other Western democracies; and I think its still true that todays progressive icons  say, Elizabeth Warren  are to the right of where old-line liberals like Teddy Kennedy were.

title: Audubon Seeks a More Bird-Friendly Design for the Vikings New Stadium
description: As if they did not already have their hands full trying to beat the Eagles, the Falcons and the Ravens, the Minnesota Vikings now have to grapple with ruby-throated hummingbirds, song sparrows and hermit thrushes.

title: Finally, a Cocktail Congress Can Agree On
description: Next week, the Senate is expected to pass a bill that will keep the Federal Highway Trust Fund from running out of money for almost a year. Nobodys really happy with the bill, attacked by lawmakers from both parties for including fiscal gimmicks. But at least it means states wont have to start shutting down existing highway projects on Aug. 1 for lack of funds.

title: Following a Very Different Path to Marital Bliss
description: Last month, in anticipation of our 25th anniversary, my husband, Daniel, and I pulled out our wedding video, thinking it would be fun for our now-teenage children to see their parents partying pre-kids and for my parents to remember what a great party they had given that day. But the viewing party soon resembled a game of Duck, Duck, Goose, as my father, now 83, gave the status of their friends in the church as the camera panned over their smiling faces.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Weekend Reading: Waiting on Rupert
description: The only way Rupert Murdochs highly anticipated Time Warner bid could grab any more attention is if 21st Century Fox moved its headquarters from New York to tax-friendly Australia.

title: Broadways Musical Chairs
description: Beneath the stage of Broadways Al Hirschfeld Theater lies a dark space with a low ceiling  a cross between a suburban rec room and a submarine. Shortly before each performance of Kinky Boots, 13 black-clad musicians file to their battle stations, each illuminated by a small light attached to a music stand. The expectant buzz of the audience filters down from a narrow opening at the edge of the stage.

title: Quick, Sloppy and Expensive Background Checks
description: Running security background checks on government job applicants has become a booming private industry in Washingtons war on terror. Its such a busy sector that one of the many workers vetting citizens managed to review 15,152 clearance cases in a single month last year. Thats about one and a half cases per minute handled by the employee, not allowing for bathroom breaks.

title: Remembering Ace Greenberg, Through Good Times and Bad
description: Alan C. Greenberg, who led Bear Stearns through its rise and fall, died on Friday at the age of 86. During his long career on Wall Street, he was known as a colorful character with a penchant for magic tricks and a generous heart.

title: Front-Wheel-Drive Ingenuity
description: Early front-drive passenger cars had an alarming tendency to slip or stall on steep grades. A crucial challenge in the development of the Ruxton was to accommodate both a lengthy reverse-mounted straight-8 engine and conventional transmission so that as much weight as possible would end up over the front wheels.

title: Even After Ruxton, the Drama Continued
description: The years after the death of the Ruxton automobile proved eerily circular for the two men most entwined in its checkered history, William J. Muller and Archie M. Andrews. Briefly reunited in a subsequent automotive venture, a final twist pitted them against each other.

title: Remembering the Ruxton
description: With its pioneering front-wheel drive, low-slung silhouette and cats eye headlamps, the multicolored Ruxton automobile seemed destined for greatness in 1929.

title: Good While It Lasted
description: Ruxtons were beautiful, innovative automobiles, but a little over a year after the first model was produced for 1929, the company was gone.

title: Not Quite an M Car, but Stirring in Spirit
description: Heres a tire-kicking experiment: Pay a visit to your BMW dealer. Weave through the sleek wares on display  but tiptoe around that strange blobby thing called a 5 Series GT. Now, stop when you see a window sticker thats less than $40,000.

title: Under the Hood, More Than Just Horsepower
description: Detroits newest muscle car is best known by the name of the 707-horsepower supercharged Hemi V8 under its hood. The brawniest 2015 Dodge Challenger SRT may as well dispense with the rest of its official nomenclature: As long as its power comes from the Hellcat, thats what people will call this car.

title: 2014 BMW M235i
description: The M235i may not be a full-blown M car, but in many ways it performs like one.

title: The Many Names of Power
description: In automotive marketing, an engine is more than a power plant. Its a Super-Hurricane, a Fire Dome, a Hemi.

title: Panama-Crossed Paths, Far From Brooklyn
description: When Erik King was 26, he outfitted an old school bus with bunk beds and surfboards, transforming it into a roving surf hostel, which he drove along the coast of Mexico and Central America for two years.

title: A Low-Cost Head-Up Option
description: For drivers who have grown dependent on head-up displays to monitor their speed and read navigation instructions, the Garmin HUD+ may be a boon, a disappointment or a bit of each.

title: Top 15 Fantasy Football Quarterbacks
description: The position is deep heading into the 2014 fantasy football season.

title: Fantasy Football: Quarterback Primer
description: Strike early, or wait? That is always the great debate when it comes to drafting a quarterback for your fantasy team. The 2013 season gave us 14 passers who averaged 20 or more standard fantasy points per week. Astonishingly enough, that group excluded flashy names like Colin Kaepernick (19 pts), Matt Ryan (18.8), Tom Brady (18.6) and Robert Griffin III (18.5).

title: Sophisticated, With a Side of Service
description: Many restaurants in downtown Ridgewood, a charming scene full of homegrown boutiques and cafes, open with great fanfare and then suddenly are shuttered. But judging by the robust, enthusiastic crowds, Mmoire, a new, sleek establishment that makes the most of local seasonal produce and an extremely accommodating staff, could have some staying power.

title: Police Stop-and-Frisk in Newark
description: Philip Montgomery found few cinema-worthy stop-and-frisk moments in Newark. Instead, he found distrust and misunderstanding clouding these encounters.

title: Friday Night Music: Hotel California
description: For obvious reasons. Also, still pretty great:

title: Carrie Hessler-Radelet
description: In an interview recorded before The Times learned the details surrounding Nick Castles death, the director of the Peace Corps reflected on her volunteer experience and the agencys future.

title: A Toast? How About a Toke?
description: Earlier this month, when Ellen Epstein arrived at the Devils Thumb Ranch in Tabernash, Colo., for the wedding of her friends Lauren Meisels and Bradley Melshenker, she, like the other guests, found a gift bag waiting for her in her hotel room. But rather than a guide to activities in the area or a jar of locally made honey, the canvas bag contained a rolled joint, a lighter and lip balm infused with mango butter and cannabis, along with this note: We wanted to show you some of the things we love the best.

title: Video: The 2015 Hyundai Genesis Delivers Value, but Not Much Flash
description: The best way to find a cars strengths and weaknesses is to take it on an extended road trip. I recently did just that with the second-generation Hyundai Genesis, traveling from Seattle to Corvallis, Ore., with my 17-year-old son and two of his friends. Boys are great to travel with. They talk sports, point out cool cars, eat junk food and then retreat to their headphones to listen to music their mothers dont approve of.

title: By the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, a Treasure Island
description: Visitors entering the Lowes parking lot from Ninth Street inevitably slow to a crawl as they pass by New York Old Iron. Even along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, you dont expect to see this.

title: Powerful and Coldhearted
description: I FEEL your pain.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, France and Germany.

title: Why We're Likely to See More 'Worst' Presidents
description: How much do members of the opposite party dislike whoever happens to be president? A lot, and the feeling seems to be getting stronger.

title: Kerry Vows to Continue Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
description: CAIRO  Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that an intensive effort to arrange a seven-day humanitarian cease-fire in the conflict in Gaza had fallen short, but he promised to keep trying.

title: A Fans Essential Jenny Lewis Primer
description: Earlier in my career, I worked as a music reviewer, which, as you can imagine, meant listening to a lot of really bad music. But the first time I heard Jenny Lewis, I became an instant fan. She is an indie goddess, as Jeff Himmelman writes in this weeks magazine, a stylish performer who defies genre and salts her songs with a sly and off-kilter intelligence. I love that her lyrics transcend the simplistic tropes of pop music. Instead, each song draws you in and tells a story. Im not ashamed to admit that I cried when I saw Lewis perform with the Watson Twins in 2006.

title: The Brando, Both a Resort and a Lab
description: Marlon Brando first visited Tetiaroa, a 12-island atoll 30 miles north of Tahiti, while filming Mutiny on the Bounty. He bought it five years later, and briefly ran an inn, where he invited conservationists and researchers interested in the South Pacific ecosystem. This month, Tetiaroa continues this legacy with the opening ofthe Brando,a 35-villa luxury resort and scientific research lab.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Challenges for Amazons Cloud Computing Hopes
description: How worried should Amazon be about its biggest hope for the future?

title: Sing a Song, End a War: All in a Supernatural Camp Routine
description: I plan to change the subject when my 11-year-old daughter asks about The Lightning Thief, a new musical at the Lucille Lortel Theater. She was excited to attend, but a last-minute appointment prevented it. To tell her how much fun she missed might be a little cruel.

title: Comic-Con 2014: Animated Star Wars Series Aims to Be True to Original Film
description: SAN DIEGO  Star Wars Rebels, an animated series that marks the start of the Walt Disney Companys stewardship of the space franchise, will not be anything like the last three p movies  you know, the prequel trilogy that took in more than $3.3 billion worldwide but left many hard-core fans fuming.

title: Bill Cunningham | Summer Prints
description: Summer prints took two different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns.

title: Remembered as Victims, Recast as Heroines
description: One womans life is spent mostly in slavery. The other womans death comes at the guillotine. The stories of Sally Hemings and Marie Antoinette are a little short on cheer.

title: Why We Live In Unhappy Places
description: The happiest city in America, at least according to a recent study, is Charlottesville, Va. But that information may not do you much good  the study also found that when we choose where to live, happiness may not matter all that much.

title: A Squeeze From the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs
description: LAS VEGAS  The 64-board final of the Wagar Womens Knockout Teams was played here on Thursday. The winners were China Red: Lu Yan, Wang Hongli, Ran Jingrong, Wang Wenfei, Wu Shao Hong and Zhang Yu. They defeated Lynn Baker, Karen McCallum, Kerri Sanborn, Irina Levitina and JoAnna Stansby by fewer than 2 international match points after an appeal was heard after the end of the match. The full story will be in Mondays column.

title: Bill Cunningham | Summer Prints
description: Summer prints took two different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns suggesting the charm of a picket fence in a cottage garden. A surprising wash of color appeared on a sanitation truck. But the most striking prints echo protruding oriel-like windows or a buildings narrow red-to-yellow column or the Mondrian pattern on a building in Columbus Circle.

title: Evening Hours | Everyone Outdoors!
description: Summer traditions to support the arts and those living with AIDS.

title: No Secret to Creating an Intriguing Cover
description: This weeks cover features three books about spying. After Walter Isaacson agreed to review A Spy Among Friends: Kim Philby and the Great Betrayal by Ben Macintyre, we decided to hold a slightly earlier review by Mark Mazzetti, of two books on spying, in order to run them together on a spy-themed cover.

title: Where Snarl Meets Roar
description: Every Friday this summer, or at least when the weather cooperates, a ritual specific to the very wealthy takes place at the East Hampton Airport.

title: Keeping Secrets in Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  A ripple of dread rolled through Hollywoods power publicist ranks in February. For the first time since its 2012 debut, the anonymous secret-sharing app Whisper had ensnared an A-list star.

title: Russia Sues McDonalds, Questioning Quality of the Food
description: MOSCOW  The McDonalds cheeseburger will have its day in court.

title: New Approach to Being There: Fan-bots Will Cheer Korean Baseball Team
description: Starting with childhood visits to dusk summer softball games in East Greenwich, R.I., and then a couple of memorable trips to Fenway Park, baseball always had a visceral feel for me that was never matched on a television screen.

title: All Tribalism and Treachery, Dude
description: No knowledge of antiquity is required to appreciate Hercules, which assumes a low base line from the start. His father was Zeus, the Zeus, the voice-over explains, in case you were expecting Dr. Zaius.

title: Voices and Vulnerability
description: In the origin-myth prologue to The Fluffy Movie, a child-size version of the comic Gabriel Iglesias chuckles at Eddie Murphy Raw, viewed on a sneaked VHS copy. That may suggest that showboating and shock are in store, but Mr. Iglesiass style in his first theatrical concert film is grounded in a down-to-earth warmth and a nimble mimicry that bolsters even routine subject matter.

title: Under Cover: Math Problems
description: Elizabeth Greens cover story this week about the difficulties of teaching math in American schools was illustrated by Andrew B. Myers, aBrooklyn-based photographer. We went to him, according to Clinton Cargill, a photo editor at the magazine, because hes a strong conceptual thinker, and his pictures have a colorful, playful palette. Recently we put a few questions to Myers about his work.

title: In Rescue Deal, K.K.R. Provides Financing to Troubled Sand Maker
description: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Friday that it would provide $680 million of financing to Preferred Sands, a company that had been on the verge of bankruptcy.

title: A Vortex of Samba, Funk, Hip-Hop and Vivid Hues
description: Watching dance at Lincoln Centers Damrosch Park Bandshell is tricky. While performers look like ants from faraway, if you sit too close, feet have a way of disappearing. Obviously, this is a real hitch. Go for the ants.

title: Youngsters Who Excel at Robotics and Drollery
description: Amazon broke into original childrens programming in May with Tumble Leaf, an animated show for preschoolers that was interesting visually but mind-numbing if you werent a preschooler. On Friday, the online service posted seven episodes of its first live-action childrens show, Annedroids, aimed at slightly older viewers (4 to 9) and explicitly tied to the so-called Steam curriculum (science, technology, engineering, arts, math). And surprise: despite the educational associations and the preteenage target audience, Annedroids is entertaining and amusing, a show that wont drive an adult crazy. Its almost worth watching without a 4-to-9-year-old for company.

title: Insurance Coverage for Fertility Treatments Varies Widely
description: Sarah Patterson, a 27-year-old nurse, suffered four miscarriages over the last four years because of several medical problems, including a condition that causes cysts to form on the ovaries. After her second loss, she said, her husband asked for a divorce because he could not handle the stress.

title: Fastidious Belgian Detective Bows Out
description: You could almost set your clock by it, if you still had to set a clock. In the final five 90-minute episodes of Agatha Christies Poirot, the denouement  the long scene in which the dapper Belgian detective Hercule Poirot explains it all to his puzzled audience, including us  arrives reliably somewhere between 22 and 17 minutes from the end. We have reached our destination, intact and on time.

title: Choosing to Shiver or Not to Shiver
description: The big brains at Discovery Communications apparently enjoy messing with our heads as we search for vicarious relief from the summer heat. One of their channels, Animal Planet, begins a reality show on Sunday that extols the rugged virtues of life in the remote frozen north. Meanwhile another channel, TLC, serves up a series about young people who want nothing more than to get out of there.

title: Chevrolet Impalas Air Bags the Subject of New Safety Inquiry
description: Federal auto safety regulators, continuing their scrutiny of air bags, have opened an inquiry into the failure of passenger air bags in General Motors 2008 Chevrolet Impala sedan.

title: Clapper Tells Lawmakers Congressional Computer Activity Wont Be Monitored
description: Clapper tells Congress that intelligence agencies hunting for officials who make unauthorized disclosures of classified information will not monitor legislative computer systems.

title: A Cozy Screening, Before It Explodes
description: Are we on Ludlow between Houston and Stanton? Maggie Gyllenhaal asked.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Fresh Focus on Siberian Permafrost as Hole Count Rises
description: I had a Skype chat Wednesday about Siberian permafrost in the context of climate change with Marina Leibman, a top Russian permafrost expert who had just returned from examining the unusual crater spotted on the Yamal Peninsula in Siberia late last week.

title: Classic Italian, With Atmosphere
description: There has been no shortage of Italian restaurants in New Canaan, but Barolo Trattoria and Wine Bar, which opened in February, is a worthy addition.

title: Under the Tracks, a Kiosk With a Bronx Beat
description: Jazz and mambo flowed along a stretch of the Bronx in the 1940s and for years after. Lined with nightclubs, theaters and catering halls, Southern Boulevard was a musicians playground.

title: Watching the River Flow
description: Like the other restaurants operated by the Fort Pond Bay Company  Harvest on Fort Pond and East by Northeast in Montauk, and Half Moon in Dobbs Ferry  Harvest on Hudson, in Hastings-on-Hudson, sits on a waterfront with million-dollar views.

title: A Syrian Rebels Improvised Battery
description: A rebel in Syria, Maj. Abu Al-Baraa, seems to have made significant steps toward developing an improved battery that could put many more shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles into use.

title: Bill to Legalize Unlocking Cellphones Passes Congress
description: Soon, you will no longer be breaking the law if you unlock your cellphone.

title: Political Divisions Threaten Kerry-Brokered Agreement in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The political agreement between Afghanistans two rival presidential candidates brokered by Secretary of State John Kerry two weeks ago appeared in trouble on Friday as serious differences emerged between the camps.

title: Grocer Is Open to Buyers Bids Amid Turmoil
description: BOSTON  After an extraordinary outpouring by angry employees, the board of directors of the Market Basket supermarket chain said Friday that it would consider offers to buy the chain, including one from the ousted president, Arthur T. Demoulas.

title: A Proposal for Nonpartisan Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: How ... Are ... You ... Feeling ... Today?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Singer Blends Her Devotion to Jazz and the Bahai Faith
description: One Sunday morning this summer, 10 hours or so after her nightclub gig had ended, Tierney Sutton settled into a molded plastic chair on a small, bare stage. She wore reading glasses and no makeup, a departure from her nocturnal elegance as a jazz singer. Even from a six-time Grammy nominee, this particular spotlight called for humility.

title: Two Perspectives on Subprime Auto Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Plight of Iraqi Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Militants Said to Kill Scores at a Syrian Base
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria killed dozens of Syrian government soldiers in an attack on an army base, a Syrian activist group said on Friday.

title: Solar Industry Is Rebalanced by U.S. Pressure on China
description: Even as regulators continue to wrestle with the protracted trade conflict with China over solar panels, the case has already started to reshape the industry, lifting manufacturers based outside China while also raising prices of panels for developers.

title: Hotel in Manhattan Ordered to Halt Sale of Time Shares After Buyers Complain
description: The state attorney general moved on Friday to stop the sale of time shares in a Midtown Manhattan hotel after buyers complained of being misled and of having trouble reserving rooms they thought they had paid for.

title: Why the Border Crisis Is a Myth
description: EL PASO  TO hear the national news media tell the story, you would think my city, El Paso, and others along the Texas-Mexico border were being overrun by children  tens of thousands of them, some with their mothers, arriving from Central America in recent months, exploiting an immigration loophole to avoid deportation and putting a fatal strain on border state resources.

title: Shootings Redefine Beat of School Police Officers
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  Once, perhaps unfairly, they fit a Mayberry image. School-based police officers were seen as friendly if a bit over-the-hill, a touch out of shape and counting the days to retirement as they watched children head from the lunchroom to recess. If anything serious happened, they were to lock the building and wait for help.

title: Sorted Food, a Cooking Channel, Is a YouTube Hit
description: LONDON  When Jamie Spafford, a 27-year-old Briton, passed through airport passport control during a visit to New York a few months ago, the immigration agent seemed skeptical about Mr. Spaffords stated occupation.

title: Before Signing, Big Stars Seek a Prize Beyond Fortune and Glory
description: After weeks of excitement, rumor and surprise, the N.B.A. free-agency frenzy has cooled. The two-week window around the beginning of July when most transactions occur is a special time for the players, a majority of whom did not have a say in which team drafted them or where they could be traded. Free agency is when players have almost complete control over where they will play and live, and for what price.

title: The U.S. Keeps Trying in Gaza; Russia Says, Who Me?
description: THE debate over whether the United States is or should be the global cop is a hardy perennial around the world. But as Israel and Hamas slugged it out in Gaza for the third time in six years, there was America, once again desperately trying to pry them apart.

title: Hold the Regret? Fast Food Seeks Virtuous Side
description: The numbers were startling: Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill shot up 12 percent on Tuesday after the company reported a nearly 26 percent spurt in its quarterly profit. For the fast-food industry, this was fresh evidence that the world of Big Macs and Doritos Locos Tacos has room for a menu with healthier-than-average food and higher-than-average prices.

title: In Scarred Chinese Tibetan City, Devotion to Sanctity of Life
description: YUSHU, China  With a set of chopsticks in her hands and a Tibetan prayer spilling from her lips, Gelazomo, a 32-year-old yak herder, hunched over the rocky banks of the river that cuts through this city and hunted for the quarry that she hoped would bring salvation.

title: Driven | 2015 Hyundai Genesis 3.8
description: Hyundai builds an ultimate road trip machine.

title: Web Use to Be Unmonitored for Congress
description: WASHINGTON  The executive branch will not eavesdrop on the computer keystrokes and Internet use of members of Congress and legislative staff members with security clearances as part of its stepped-up efforts to prevent unauthorized disclosures of classified information, the nations top intelligence official told lawmakers on Friday.

title: To Save Gaza, Destroy Hamas
description: TEL AVIV  AFTER nearly three weeks of fighting  notwithstanding the 12-hour pause announced early this morning by Israel  it is time to revisit some basic assumptions about Hamas. Until now, Israel assumed Hamas was the devil we know, capable of attacks that were mostly a nuisance; accepting its rule over the Gaza Strip was preferable to risking a vacuum of governance like what we see in Somalia and Libya. But Hamass reckless violence in the current round of fighting severely undermined this thinking.

title: How to Control Student Loan Defaults
description: New federal rules that penalize colleges for excessive student loan defaults offer a powerful incentive for schools to educate students on the complexities of the federal student loan program, including the crucial fact that they can delay or make partial payments if they get into financial trouble. Keeping loan default rates low, a new study of nine community colleges shows, is not rocket science: Schools can do it.

title: New Job Law Misses the Mark
description: The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act, recently passed by large bipartisan majorities in Congress and signed into law this week by President Obama, makes overdue reforms to a Clinton-era job-training law. It emphasizes partnerships that bring together government officials, union representatives and employers to identify and provide training for current and future job openings. These have proved successful in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and elsewhere.

title: Move to Center Divides G.O.P. in North Carolina
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The objective of the Republican Party here last year was clear: Unleash the pent-up conservative revolution in a state where the party had not controlled the state legislature and governors office for more than a century.

title: Israels Outspoken Envoy Is Wise to U.S. Ways
description: WASHINGTON  As an undergraduate at the University of Pennsylvania, Ron Dermer reluctantly accepted an assignment to argue that Israel should be condemned for its treatment of Palestinians.

title: Orchestra Faults Met Chiefs Record as a Lockout Looms
description: Facing a potential lockout that could halt work at the Metropolitan Opera when its labor contracts expire next week, representatives of the companys orchestra sat down with the administration on Friday for their first across-the-table negotiating session since February.

title: For Cano, a Soft Landing in Seattle
description: SEATTLE  Wheres the defector? Homesick and crying into his organic tea and sashimi?

title: Broken Windows, Broken Lives
description: How terrible it would be if Eric Garner died for a theory, for the idea that aggressive police enforcement against minor offenders (he was a seller of loose, untaxed cigarettes) is the way to a safer, more orderly city. Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William Bratton responded swiftly after Mr. Garner was fatally assaulted by officers on Staten Island. They reached out to his family, promising to retrain every officer about the rules against using chokeholds. Two officers have been put on desk duty pending investigations.

title: Ex-Obama Aides Statements in 2012 Clash With Health Act Stance
description: WASHINGTON  A former adviser to the Obama administration on health policy made public statements in 2012 that undercut arguments it is now making in court about the governments authority to subsidize insurance premiums.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 25, 2014
Chamber of Commerce Lost Its Way in Right Turn
description: Twice a year, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce convenes what it calls its Committee of 100  which is composed of heads of regional chambers and Washington trade associations. They hear about the business climate from the chambers longtime president, Thomas J. Donohue, and about the political landscape from Bruce Josten, its chief lobbyist.

title: Junkyards Feel the Sting of a Visit From a Copper Cable Guy
description: One answer to a question that has vexed transit police officers  where exactly do copper thieves sell their stolen cable?  arrived last month in the form of a dirty, shambling man pushing a shopping cart into a busy scrap yard in Queens.

title: Plagiarism Scandal Tests a Senator Still Forming a Rapport With Montanans
description: BUTTE, Mont.  Montanans are not quick to get riled up over politics. Here in this historic copper and silver mining town, the big news this week is the kickoff of Evel Knievel Days  the annual summer festival featuring flying motorcycles and other stunts that recall the famed daredevil, Buttes native son.

title: A Ukrainian Rebel Commander Veers Off-Script
description: Speaking to Reuters this week about the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, a commander of separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine seemed to veer off script, suggesting that pro-Russia militants in the area, who have denied any involvement, were equipped with a sophisticated antiaircraft missile system and might have fired at the passenger jet by mistake.

Director John O. Brennan convened a meeting of the men who had played a role overseeing the program in its seven-year history.

title: Pennsylvania: Carjacker Kills 3 Children
description: Three children died and three women were seriously injured after carjackers lost control of an S.U.V. and plowed across a busy street corner on Friday morning in north Philadelphia, the police said. The victims were brothers ages 7 and 10 and their 15-year-old sister, who were selling fruit for a church fund-raiser. According to the police, the vehicle struck the siblings as they stood at Allegheny and Germantown Avenues with their 43-year-old mother and a 65-year-old woman, who were in critical condition on Friday. The vehicles owner, a 45-year-old woman, was also in critical condition. The suspects had forced her into the back seat of her vehicle at gunpoint before the crash, the police said. The suspects, whom the police described as two armed men in their 20s, fled and remained at large on Friday.
