title: Whats On TV Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Epix) THE HUNGER GAMES: CATCHING FIRE (2013) A camera-ready Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence, above) and Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson) embark on their victory tour of the Panem districts as the Capitol prepares for the 75th games in this franchises second installment, directed by Francis Lawrence from the books by Suzanne Collins. But the champions arent safe yet: this new round of games pits past winners against one another in an ultimate death match. Donald Sutherland returns as President Snow, the target in Katnisss sights; Liam Hemsworth is one of her love interests, Gale Hawthorne; Woody Harrelson is Haymitch Abernathy, the only living Hunger Games victor from District 12; and Elizabeth Banks is Effie Trinket, the tributes escort. Catching Fire isnt a great work of art but its a competent, at times exciting movie and it does something that better, more artistically notable movies often fail to do: It speaks to its moment in time, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Boys (and men) are still boys, of course, including in movies, but the very existence of Katniss  who fights her own battles, and kisses and leaves the boys, only sometimes to save them  suggests cultural consumers are ready for change, even if most cultural producers remain foolishly stuck in the past. Its unlikely Katniss will lead the real revolution the movies need, but a woman can dream. The original Hunger Games (2012) leads in at 6:30.

title: Where Reason Ends and Faith Begins
description: STANFORD, Calif.  NOT long ago, I was at an event in which many people, most of them professors, were arguing for the existence of things that many of their colleagues did not believe in. Someone gave a talk in which he explained that he knew that U.F.O.s existed even though all the best evidence for them turned out to be false. Others spoke sympathetically about shamanic healing, reincarnation and near-death visions. But then a woman described her research on what it was like to be dead, which she had based on reports from mediums who claimed to have had the dead speak through them. She cited, as evidence of the benevolence in the afterlife, an Anglican priest, Msgr. Robert Hugh Benson, who wrote a book attacking spiritualism while alive but who, she said, recanted the book after his death in 1914. The group stared at her in disbelief. This, they felt, was flabby-minded.

description: ROME  The body of Yara Gambirasio, a 13-year-old student, was found on a chilly day in a quiet northern city in Lombardy in February 2011, three months after she was reported missing following a gymnastics practice. The autopsy showed she had been beaten but not sexually abused, stabbed several times and left to die in a field less than 10 miles from her home.

The Yankees have never sent more pitchers to the mound in one season, but they have landed on 28 three other times: in 2005, 2007 and 2011.

description: A car and a pickup truck collided on the Garden State Parkway on Saturday, killing two women and injuring six other people, the New Jersey State Police said.

title: Israel Says Its Forces Did Not Kill Palestinians Sheltering at U.N. School
description: JERUSALEM  Israel and Hamas went back and forth on Sunday over proposals for a new cease-fire in the fighting in the Gaza Strip, and Israel sought to bolster its claim that its forces were not responsible for the deaths of 16 Palestinians reportedly killed in an attack on a United Nations school.

title: Assessing the Damage and Destruction in Gaza
description: Analysis of satellite imagery taken before and after the first two and a half weeks of the Israeli incursion.

title: Sticks and Stones, and a Diagnosis in Words That Cant Hurt Us
description: To reach my eldest daughter at her elementary school, we have to walk down our street, turn on what Google Maps refers to as Unknown Road, cross a bridge over a shallow stream and follow an asphalt path around to the bright red doors of the school. All in all, its a seven-minute walk, but with my 3-year-old in tow it can take twice the time.

title: Troops Move on Crash Site in Ukraine, Foiling Deal
description: ZUHRES, Ukraine  Just hours after the Malaysian government reached an agreement with Ukrainian separatists on Sunday over access to the crash site of a Malaysian airliner shot down in rebel territory, the Ukrainian military launched an operation to recapture the debris fields, again stalling international efforts to secure the site.

title: 1914: German Emperor Backed Austria
description: BERLIN  All Austrian reservists living in Germany have been summoned to join the colors from today [July 27], and all leave of German officers and soldiers has been stopped. According to a despatch from Vienna, one of the highest personages in Germany  whom, I learn, is none other than the Emperor  is said to have written personally to Herr von Tschirschky und Bogendorff, the German Ambassador in Vienna, telling him to stiffen the back of Count Berchtold, who at that time was all for conciliation with Servia. The result was that the Austro-Hungarian Foreign Minister entirely changed his attitude and prepared the drastic ultimatum to Belgrade.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (WGN America) MANH(A)TTAN John Benjamin Hickey and Ashley Zukerman portray the scientists at the center of the race to create an atomic bomb, and Olivia Williams (above, with Mr. Hickey) and Rachel Brosnahan are their smarty-pants wives, in this fictionalized but fact-based accounting set in Los Alamos, N.M., 766 days before Hiroshima, as the show puts it. The atom bomb didnt just end the war, it forever changed the peace, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. Richard Rhodes, the author of The Making of the Atom Bomb, quotes Herbert S. Marks, general counsel of the Atomic Energy Commission, who said the Manhattan Project was a state unto itself that had a peculiar sovereignty, one that could bring about the end, peacefully or violently, of all other sovereignties. Manh(a)ttan provides a cleverly imagined portrait of the men and women who were at the epicenter of that peculiar sovereignty.

title: Republicans Senate Chances Rise Slightly to 60 Percent
description: For the last month, weve been adding one or two polls a day to The Upshots Senate forecasting model. Today, we update all 36 races, based on estimates from a YouGov online panel that covers every congressional and governors race across the country.

title: Explaining Online Panels and the 2014 Midterms
description: A deluge of cheap partisan polls has swamped a shrinking number of high-quality, nonpartisan surveys, making it hard to know who is really ahead in many political campaigns. The solution? More nonpartisan surveys.

title: Man Dressed as Spider-Man Is Arrested After Scuffle With Police in Times Square
description: Spider-Man punched a police officer in the face in Times Square over the weekend, the police said, in the latest episode of children-friendly characters displaying R-rated behavior in front of stunned tourists in the heart of Manhattan.

title: What The Leftovers Says About Climate Change
description: The new HBO series The Leftovers is about what happens after 2 percent of humanity simply vanishes from the earth (this is not really a spoiler; however, some follow). This event has obvious religious connotations, which the show explores. But the story may have secular implications, too: The way the characters reckon with their new, bizarre circumstances has something in common with how some are responding to the threat of climate change.

title: In Coney Island, Weaving a Confection That Tastes Like Long-Ago Summers
description: Every New Yorker has a favorite summertime treat. As a girl, mine was cotton candy, that wondrous melt-in-your-mouth confection that vanishes when it touches your tongue. For me, it still brings to mind bumper cars and roller coaster rides, street festivals and jelly-sandaled strolls.

title: Your Own Choices for Coolest Places on Earth
description: Its summer. So my Sunday column is a bit unusual and offers some travel advice: The coolest places on Earth, as I see them. Im sure some of you disagree with my choices, so post your thoughts belowand include your own recommendations for off-the-beaten path choices for others to take up.

title: Scarlett Johansson Powers Lucy to No. 1 at Box Office
description: Scarlett Johansson punched out Hercules at the weekend box office. Her new science-fiction thriller, Lucy, was No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in an estimated $44 million and proving that her name on the marquee (and pouty picture on the poster) could anchor a wide-release movie. Lucy, which Universal Pictures marketed squarely on Ms. Johanssons shoulders, cost about $40 million to make and was directed by Luc Besson. The film performed particularly well in theaters with screens marketed as Premium Large Format, which charge higher prices.

title: Vows | Game for the Name
description: With no clear convention for choosing a last name for their family once they got married, Martha West and Tanya Kalivas decided to battle it out on the soccer field.

title: Italys Vincenzo Nibali Wins the 2014 Tour de France
description: PARIS  Vincenzo Nibali emerged Sunday as the first Italian winner of the Tour de France in 16 years after a race defined by inclement weather and painful eliminations of other favorites.

title: Learning Lear': A Pitiless Storm, Then the Show Goes On
description: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses and performs King Lear for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: 1939: Britain Set to Deport all Suspects in I.R.A. Blasts
description: LONDON  As the sequel to yesterdays fatal bomb explosions staged by Irish terrorists at two London railroad stations, the British government was reported tonight [July 27] to be planning mass deportations during the week end of hundreds of suspected members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. It was understood that a warship would be sent on Saturday to Fishguard or Holyhead, the two principal Welsh ports on the Irish Sea, to await batches of Irish men, and women, who will be rounded up for expulsion as soon as the government obtains its unprecedented police powers of search and arrest under the prevention of violence bill, drafted specifically to smash the I.R.A. The measure, rushed through the House of Commons in record time last night, was given a hasty first reading by the House of Lords today. Earl Stanhope, First Lord of the Admiralty and leader of the Upper House, said the government wanted the bill passed by the Peers tomorrow, rather than wait until Monday. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 28, 1939

title: Red Bulls Rewind: Painting the Town Red
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Thierry Henry may or may not play in Major League Soccer beyond this season. That he could probably carry on, if he so desires, until he is 40 (he is now 36) is probably not the point.

title: Woman Who Helped Start French Cycling Race Ends It With a Win
description: PARIS  Marianne Vos, who already had no shortage of victories to her name, won the inaugural edition of a race whose riders preceded the men of the Tour de France down the Champs-lyses on Sunday.

title: At Front Lines, Bearing Witness in Real Time
description: My social media feed has taken a bloody turn in the last few weeks, and Im hardly alone. Along with the usual Twitter wisecracking and comments on incremental news, I have seen bodies scattered across fields and hospitals in Ukraine and Gaza. I have read posts from reporters who felt threatened, horrified and revolted.

title: After Losing Province in 2010, Afghan Taliban Strike Back
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A sudden Taliban offensive in the southern province of Kandahar in recent days has led to some of the heaviest protracted fighting there in years, officials said on Sunday. The militants overran a district center on the border with Pakistan, battled government forces near the provincial capital and staged a suicide-bomber attack on a home of the provinces powerful security chief.

title: Rough Ride for the F-35
description: The F-35 fighter jet was expected to be exhibited at an international air show a few weeks ago  a chance for America to showcase its state-of-the-art war plane, the worlds most expensive weapons project. But, in an embarrassing turn of events, the star-crossed, single-engine F-35 was a no-show.

title: Legacy Tarnished by His Own Words
description: A Gallup poll in 2010 assessing the nine presidents from John F. Kennedy to George W. Bush put Richard M. Nixon last with a 29 percent approval rating. In a Quinnipiac University survey at the beginning of July, however, Barack Obama had replaced Nixon as the worst president since World War II: 33 percent assigned that unwanted distinction to President Obama; only 13 percent thought Nixon was that bad.

title: Chasing a Chivalrous Bandit
description: The Hindi movie Kick takes pains to assure us that Devi Lal Singh, its antihero hero, is amazing and has impeccable charisma. Good to know. Otherwise you might think that Devi (Salman Khan), who shakes things up for the fun of it  to feel a kick  was another bad-boy narcissist who cant grow up or keep a job.

title: Winning Ways at the Spingold Knockout Teams
description: LAS VEGAS  The 64-board final of the Spingold Knockout Teams yesterday was between Team Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) and Richard Schwartz, Allan Graves, Boye Brogeland, Espen Lindqvist, Lotan Fisher and Ron Schwartz.

title: Amid the Destruction, Aftershocks of an Emotional Magnitude
description: During the three years Qi Zhao spent filming Fallen City, he captured his subject  the town of Beichuan, wiped out in the 2008 Sichuan earthquake, two-thirds of its people killed and 80 percent of its buildings destroyed  as it slowly disappeared. In time-lapse images, fields of rubble become fields of grass. Part of the old city is turned into an earthquake museum, with railings installed in front of piles of shattered concrete.

title: Steal by Bautista Helps Blue Jays Overcome Three Yankees Rallies
description: In the race for the playoffs, even a seemingly inconsequential mistake can be the difference between a postseason appearance and a lost season. Should the Yankees narrowly miss a berth this season, closer David Robertson might regret ignoring Jose Bautista at first base in the ninth inning of Sundays 5-4 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: An Intricate Combination of Music and Movement
description: Catching the entire performance of Pam Tanowitz Dance at Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Friday took more than the usual effort. After listening to a smart, vibrant set of contemporary music by the sextet Eighth Blackbird in the Damrosch Park Bandshell, I hurried to the opposite end of the plaza to watch the unannounced beginning of Ms. Tanowitzs contribution. There, engrossed by the dancer Lindsey Joness rendering of Ms. Tanowitzs witty steps, I nearly failed to rush back to my seat in time for the main portion of the show.

title: Sloshing in Symphonic Waters
description: The 81 musicians and singers who were about to give the premiere of Sila: The Breath of the World, an alluring, mystical new work by the American composer John Luther Adams conceived for performance outdoors in Lincoln Centers Hearst Plaza, began to take their assigned places early on Friday evening. It was quite a procession.

title: Melodrama, as in Mellow
description: How much good and evil can you take in a night? Watching Spartacus, Yuri Grigorovichs ponderous three-act ballet, is a like being trapped inside a pinball machine and bounced among four protagonists. One team features the noble, valiant Spartacus and the innocently virtuous Phrygia. On the other are the sadistic Crassus and the conniving Aegina.

title: Sure, You Loved Lucy, but Vintage Has Limits
description: Maybe youre one of those irritating people prone to complaining, Why cant they make shows as good as [name of a vintage TV series] anymore?

title: An Israel Without Illusions
description: JERUSALEM  Israelis and Palestinians are imprisoned in what seems increasingly like a hermetically sealed bubble. Over the years, inside this bubble, each side has evolved sophisticated justifications for every act it commits.

title: Adding Fiction to the Fray
description: The fourth episode of The Honorable Woman, a serialized thriller that makes its Sundance TV debut on Thursday, opens on a world-weary MI6 officer, sitting at a dinner party where two other guests are discussing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. As the camera zooms in on the officer, the conversation can be heard degenerating into a vulgar, name-calling argument and then a silverware-rattling wrestling match.

title: A Revolutionary Who Cannot Be Silenced
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  In the opening scene of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, a dramatically assured and lyrical new opera in Mandarin by the Chinese-born American composer Huang Ruo that was given its American premiere here on Saturday by Santa Fe Opera, a group of well-to-do citizens in prerevolutionary Shanghai reflects on the state of the country under the Qing dynasty. Turning to face the audience, the chorus sings:

title: In Every Note, Passion That Needs No Translation
description: Its the quaver that makes the Ethiopian singer Mahmoud Ahmeds voice so arresting. He seizes on a note, brief or sustained, and makes its pitch tremble as if its urgency could barely be contained. Its a show of controlled intensity, and in the course of a song, it happens again and again, making each phrase leap out anew: with sorrow, with anticipation, with a plea. That quaver is coupled with emphatic rhythm and grainy determination in a voice that Ethiopians in and out of the country have prized since the 1970s. Mr. Ahmeds 1975 album, Ere Mela Mela, helped introduce Ethiopian pop to a wider world, and in the 1990s, reissues of his recordings as part of Buda Musiques Ethiopiques series brought him further international attention.

title: Classical Music Group
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Sometimes its good to take a macro view of things. If you focus too much on details, you can lose perspective on whats important. Like family. Family is important.

title: Fast Talking and a Toast to Desire
description: Strictly Dishonorable, the 1929 Preston Sturges comedy revived by the Attic Theater, is an old-fashioned kind of show. You can tell right from its first scene when the speakeasy proprietor, Tomaso (Christopher Tocco), sprinkles bitters onto a sugar cube before adding whiskey, ice and a cherry. Just try and leave this charmer without a fondness for Sturges and a craving for a strong cocktail.

title: A Pianist and Pedagogue, Saluting a Pair of Giants
description: Those who attended the exhibition Viennas Musical Giants at the Rose Museum of Carnegie Hall this spring were present, so to speak, at the creation of Brahmss wonderful Variations on a Theme by Haydn. One invaluable artifact on display was Brahmss scribbled transcription of the St. Anthony Chorale from a divertimento for winds that he and others believed to be the work of Haydn.

title: Chocolate Factory Announces Season
description: The Chocolate Factory Theater in Long Island City, Queens, will feature nine commissioned United States premieres and two first-time collaborations with other New York City arts institutions in its 2014-15 season, the theaters organizers have announced. The performances are to begin with Marissa Perels return to the Chocolate Factory for the first time since the theaters debut season in 2005. She will present More Than Just a Piece of Sky, a work based on the 1983 movie Yentl starring Barbra Streisand. The performances, Sept. 17 through 20, also represents the theaters first partnership with the annual Queer New York International Arts Festival. Other season highlights include Rude World, a duet choreographed and performed by Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith, in January as part of the Coil festival. And in April, the Chocolate Factory will team up with Abrons Arts Center to present the Bessie award winner David Neumanns I Understand Everything Better, a multidisciplinary work exploring the need to report on calamity and the results of a persons proximity to death and trauma. Brian Rogers, the artistic director of the Chocolate Factory, said he hoped that a smaller schedule would better allow the theater to serve its artists. This is our small attempt to value the work of the performers in a different way, Mr. Rogers said recently by phone. More information is at chocolatefactory.org.

title: DeGrom, a Key to the Mets Future, Is Taking Over the Present
description: MILWAUKEE  No matter how the final two months of the season unfold for the Mets, they will at least have the pleasure of following the progress of their rookie starter Jacob deGrom. The way this season has gone, he has come to represent hope for the future, although he already seems to be the one Met who still has a chance to win something this year: the National League Rookie of the Year award.

title: Its Justice and Earth in La MaMa Programs
description: Ecology and social justice will be the focus of La MaMas 2014-15 season, the theaters organizers announced Sunday. With the theme La MaMa Earth, the theaters 53rd season will be inspired by the impact of Hurricane Sandy on local communities, La MaMas artistic director, Mia Yoo, said in a statement. Among the highlights are three performances based on Shakespeares The Tempest, grouped under the collective title Tempest 3: The Tide is Rising. That series is to feature the world premiere of a musical adaptation of the play written by Karin Coonrod with music by Elizabeth Swados and starring Reg E. Cathey (The Wire, House of Cards), Oct. 2 through Nov. 2. Other season highlights include the world premiere of Catherine Fillouxs Selma 65, based on the true story of Viola Liuzzo, a white woman who was killed by the Ku Klux Klan after participating in a civil-rights protest in Alabama (Sept. 25 through Oct. 12); performances by the Belarus Free Theater (April 23 through May 10); and a world premiere by the Venezuelan company Teatro Dramma International (March 5 through 15). More information is at lamama.org.

title: New Cast Members for Game of Thrones
description: With the population of Westeros dwindling, HBO has announced that a crop of new characters will enter the fold in Season 5 of its hit drama Game of Thrones. The stage and screen veteran Jonathan Pryce and Keisha Castle-Hughes, a best actress Oscar nominee for the 2003 film Whale Rider, are among nine new cast members set to join Thrones in 2015. While Season 4 brought the demise of several main characters, the coming season will try to fill the void with the Martells of Dorne. Most of the new characters are relatives or associates of Oberyn Martell (Pedro Pascal), the playboy prince who met a particularly gruesome death while fighting on behalf of Tyrion Lannister (Peter Dinklage). Ms. Castle-Hughes is to portray Oberyns eldest bastard daughter, Obara Sand. She is to be joined by Alexander Siddig (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, Da Vincis Demons) as Doran Martell, the ruler of Dorne and older brother of Oberyn, and Toby Sebastian as Dorans son Trystane. New additions not of the Martell bloodline are to include Mr. Pryce as High Sparrow, a prominent figure in a religious order; Nell Tiger Free, who replaces Aimee Richardson as Myrcella Baratheon; and DeObia Oparei as Areo Hotah, captain of Dorans guards. The series is expected to return in the spring.

title: Privacy and the Pool of Information
description: Its been a while since we all became aware of what the National Security Administration has been up to. But as revelations of government breaches recede and the concerns of daily life resume, the public occasionally needs a reminder. A recent story in The Washington Post was exactly that. It laid out in detail what many had long suspected: that the N.S.A., in targeting foreign nationals, is collecting and storing extremely large amounts of information on many American citizens. This information is not restricted to metadata; it is content  photos, web chats, emails and the like. While United States law prevents targeting American citizens without a warrant (even if it is just a warrant from the secret FISA court) nothing currently prevents the N.S.A. from engaging in this incidental collection and no law prevents the agency  and other United States intelligence and law enforcement agencies  from accessing such content without a warrant into perpetuity.

title: Morning Views
description: The Senate is about to begin debate on a bill that could, at long last, put an end to the indiscriminate bulk collection of Americans telephone records,according to an editorial in The New York Times. The bill will bring needed transparency to the abusive spying programs that have tarnished the nations reputation. Introduced by Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the measure would require the government to disclose how many peoples data was collected by intelligence agencies, and how many of those people were American. Perhaps most important, the bill will create a panel of advocates to argue before the court in support of privacy rights and civil liberties, and would require the court to issue public summaries of its decisions that specifically detail the impact on those rights. It represents a breakthrough in the struggle against the growth of government surveillance power.

It leads to increased health care spending. Changing the payment structure to pay them for achieving goals instead should reduce wasteful spending.

title: Roasted Corn and Tomato Salsa
description: Ive added corn to salsa fresca before, but this time, eyeing generous ears of corn on the cob in the market, I imagined it grilled or roasted in a roasted tomato salsa. I used as a starting point the renowned chef Rick Baylesss terrific roasted jalapeo tomato salsa with fresh cilantro, from a book he published in 1998 called Salsas That Cook. After I had grilled the tomatoes and jalapeo under a broiler (you could also cook them on a grill), I grilled an ear of corn, also under a broiler. The kernels take on a beautiful color, and their sweetness contrasts nicely with the charred and picante flavors that run through this salsa. The corn also contributes crunch. The salsa is great with tacos, chips, and grains, and is particularly good with chicken.

She received kohlrabi one week and was at a loss as to what to do with it. I had some suggestions for ways to use the vegetable in main dishes, and now Ive come up with a way to use it in a side. The kohlrabi has a crisp texture much like that of jicama, with a nice cruciferous flavor. This salsa fresca would be welcome with just about any tostada, nacho or taco, with chips, or as a condiment with fish or chicken.

I love the contrasts in this salsa: the crisp jicama with the soft, juicy mango; the sweet fruit; the spicy chile; and the grassy cilantro. Serve with fish or chicken.

description: A few weeks ago, New York Magazines Jonathan Chait wrote a post that cited the work of Reason Magazines Peter Suderman as an example of how libertarian and conservative journalists have spun a cocoon around their readers, making Obamacares doom seem perpetually inevitable even as the specifics of their doomsaying tell a story of its gradual success. The message of every individual dispatch is a confident prediction of the hated enemys demise, Chait wrote of Sudermans writing, yet the terms described in each, taken together, tell the story of retreat.

title: Roderick Kimballs Path Puzzles
Masterworks vs. the Masses
description: PARIS  One cloudy afternoon this month, the line to enter the Louvre stretched around the entrance pyramid, across one long courtyard and into the next. Inside the museum, a crowd more than a dozen deep faced the Mona Lisa, most taking cellphone pictures and selfies. Near the Winged Victory of Samothrace, Jean-Michel Borda, visiting from Madrid, paused amid the crush. Its like the Mtro early in the morning, he said.

title: Icahn Gets a Speedy Return on His Family Dollar Investment

description: BOSTON  As with many start-ups, the idea was born from trivia that suddenly did not seem so useless  the statistics of professional athletes.

title: Gains Seen for Medicare, but Social Security Holds Steady
description: WASHINGTON  Medicares financial condition improved significantly in the last year, thanks in part to the Affordable Care Act, but the outlook for Social Security is basically unchanged, the Obama administration said Monday.

description: FRANKFURT  A group of euro-skeptics that has opposed Germanys participation in the currency said on Monday that it had filed a lawsuit to block a plan at the heart of efforts to prevent banking crises in Europe.

title: Just as Dangerous as We Think
description: If the British comedy troupe Monty Python had been commissioned to produce a self-help book, they might have come up with something along the lines of The Norm Chronicles, a cheerfully subversive variation on the genre. The authors contemplate not inner peace but outer woe with an encyclopedic guide to lifes risks, among them health care catastrophes, sexually transmitted diseases, auto accidents, plane crashes, mountaineering fatalities, sudden unemployment and the chances that an asteroid will fall from the sky and squash you.

title: Readers Respond to the Editorial Series on Marijuana
description: We knew from polling data that a majority of Americans, 54 percent, favored legalizing the use of marijuana. Now that weve begun publishing an editorial series arguing for an end to marijuana prohibition, we know that a majority of Times readers appear to favor legalization, too, and in far greater numbers than the population at large.

title: 4 Years Later, Still No Answers in Killing of a Long Island Laborer
description: SHIRLEY, N.Y.  On a cool October night in 2010, two immigrant laborers went on a drinking spree in a stand of trees by the side of a road in this suburban hamlet on Long Island. Beer flowed. So did tequila. By the following afternoon, one of the men was dead, his body lying in the woods. The other was in a hospital bed, badly hurt, with a bladder injury and deep cuts in and around his rectum.

title: The Things Traders Say, Lloyds Edition
description: By now, DealBook readers know the drill: A major bank reaches a settlement with United States and British authorities over accusations that its employees conspired to manipulate the benchmark rates known as the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, and transcripts of incriminating conversations among traders and rate setters are released. What emerges are often aggressive and vulgar exchanges, at times in a London argot. It can sound like something from a Martin Amis novel or a Guy Ritchie movie.

title: The Battle Rhythm of Helping to Build a Democracy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Here come the helicopters again. Blackhawks, flying out of the Kabul night, the gunner hanging out the side, scanning the city from behind the sights of an M-240B automatic rifle. The blades thunder their rhythm throughout the compound, too loud to talk over. They land quickly, spill out their passengers and a few bags, and leave. This isnt the place to linger.

title: Filipino Rebels Kill 21 Villagers Over Peace Deal

title: Walkabout: Ukraine Air Space Reroutes to Hike Prices

title: New Generic Ballot Surveys Dont Show Signs of Republican Wave
description: One of the big questions of this election cycle is whether it will turn out to be a wave election, like the one in 2010, when an upswell of anti-Democratic sentiment carried Democrats out of the House. One of the best measures of whether theres a wave is the generic ballot question. Pollsters ask: Do you want Democrats or Republicans to control Congress?

Reuters reported that fire and emergency medical crews from six communities were called in.

title: Introducing Sway Clarke II, R&B Hitmaker With a Canadian Sense of Humor
description: Who on earth would blend a Bennie and the Jets groove, trilling harpsichords evoking the Beatles In My Life and a dance-floor-quaking bass into an exuberant paean to infidelity? Answer: Sway Clarke II. The song, Secret Garden, is one of several by the Berlin-by-way-of-Toronto singer-songwriter that have taken off on the Internet (another is a moody cover of Kendrick Lamars Swimming Pools) and propelled the singer (who plays his first American show this evening at Bardots School Night in Los Angeles) to next-big-thing status. His combination of storytelling and hooks has earned comparisons to the hitmaking likes of Lorde and Frank Ocean, but a streak of naughty humor, often at the singers own expense, is uniquely his own. That comes out of being Canadian, he laughs. Theres a reason why great comedians like Jim Carrey and Mike Myers came from Canada. Its in our DNA to be self-deprecating and funny.

title: 3 Killed in a Facebook Blasphemy Rampage in Pakistan

As I watched him softly turn the pages of his paper, a chill spread like carbonated bubbles through the back of my head, instantly relaxing me and bringing me to the verge of sweet slumber.

Its impact was significant because it gave mainstream support to legalization at the moment when the state of Washington was beginning a serious debate on the issue. In November of 2012, the states residents voted by a 56-to-41 margin to legalize marijuana for recreational purposes.

title: Sweet Rides and Good Vibes at an Underground Biker Rally in the Motor City
description: Every Sunday for the past decade, people have been gathering in a sparse corner of East Detroit for an ad hoc bike rally and block party that has grown solely through word of mouth. The event grew out of jam sessions held in a small shed called Johns Carpet Shack that featured local blues and jazz musicians including Otis Williams, the last surviving member of the Temptations. After the organizer, John Estes, passed away and the property burned down in 2008, the event moved to a vacant lot across the street. Since then it has grown into its current form, drawing people from all over Michigan to eat, drink, listen to bands and show off their cars and motorcycles, while organizers, including neighborhood resident Pete Barrow (a.k.a. Big Time Pete), who nominally runs things now, wend their way through the crowd with collection plates. On July 22, police shut down the event for the first time, citing a lack of permits. These pictures were taken a few weeks earlier.

title: The Injustice of Marijuana Arrests
description: Americas four-decade war on drugs is responsible for many casualties, but the criminalization of marijuana has been perhaps the most destructive part of that war. The toll can be measured in dollars  billions of which are thrown away each year in the aggressive enforcement of pointless laws. It can be measured in years  whether wasted behind bars or stolen from a child who grows up fatherless. And it can be measured in lives  those damaged if not destroyed by the shockingly harsh consequences that can follow even the most minor offenses.

title: That Would Make a Good Novel

The stacks had been picked over, and all that remained were some used cookbooks and a smattering of other genres. I have had moments in used bookstores when I feel destiny pushing me toward an obscure title, but that day I felt nothing, no sign or vibration coming from any of the odd, unwanted books. But because Cornelia was a new friend and had driven me into the city to show me this store that she hadnt known was going out of business, I grabbed a beat-up biography of Margaret Mead and took it to the counter.

title: Iran: Muslims Seek Americans Release
description: Amir Hekmati, an American of Iranian descent incarcerated in Tehran for nearly three years, spent his 31st birthday in prison on Monday, despite new pleas to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei for his compassionate release sent from prominent Muslim American figures in his home state, Michigan. Letters from the Michigan chapter of the Council on American Islamic Relations and from the Imams Council of the Michigan Muslim Community Council, released by Mr. Hekmatis family, beseeched the ayatollah to grant Mr. Hekmati a pardon, invoking the tradition of mercy associated with the end of the Ramadan holiday. It is unclear whether Ayatollah Khamenei, Irans supreme leader, has seen the letters. Mr. Hekmati, a former Marine from Flint, was arrested in 2011 while visiting relatives in Iran for the first time. He was tried and sentenced to death for espionage, but the verdict was overturned and he was later convicted of cooperation with a hostile government  the United States  and given a 10-year sentence. Iranian prosecutors have never explained the substance of their case, and Mr. Hekmati and his family have said he is innocent of any wrongdoing.

title: What Is Chris Christie Doing in Iowa?

Earlier that day, a Malaysia Airlines jet had been shot down in Ukraine; Israel was launching its ground invasion into Gaza. And here was Christie  a tell-it-like-it-is, straight-talking, no-nonsense Jersey guy  telling about 60 members of the media what he really thought. Governor Branstad is a role model for me, Christie gushed, referring to his 67-year-old counterpart from Iowa. Terry Branstad, who is seeking his sixth term in November, is hoping to become the longest-serving governor in the nations history. And Christie  who referred to Branstad as a dear friend, a legend and someone who embodies what public service is all about  hoped to perpetuate his dynasty. In fact, he even offered to return to Iowa, over and over, as often as Governor Branstad wants me to.

title: Morning Views
description: Americas four-decade war on drugs is responsible for many casualties, writes Jesse Wegman for The New York Times, but the criminalization of marijuana has been perhaps the most destructive part of that war. The measure of that destruction can be estimated in billions of dollars, thrown away each year in the aggressive enforcement of pointless laws, and in years, whether wasted behind bars or stolen from a child who grows up fatherless. Decriminalizing marijuana use at the federal level will, first, eliminate costly, futile policing programs and enforcement laws that, each year, cost American taxpayers more than $3.6 billion. Second, it is an important step forward in resolving racial disparity in arrests and mass incarceration: The war on drugs aims its firepower overwhelmingly at African-Americans on the street, while white users smoke safely behind closed doors. And third, it offers an opportunity for state lawmakers to roll back the psychological and social damage already inflicted on drug offenders, such as sealing records of drug convictions in order to make it easier for defendants to get jobs and housing after a conviction.

Seventeen people were acquitted. The state charged that the rebellion was planned by former Gen. Humberto Delgado  defeated candidate in the 1958 presidential election and now regarded as the leader abroad of opposition to the regime. description: Bruce Headlam is the managing editor of video. He oversees a department that The Times is counting on to expand its audience and to generate revenue through ad sales. One of his main tasks: convincing more reporters and editors that video is a critical part of news coverage.

description: Two New York City correction officers and a former officer who resigned this year have been arrested on charges that they smuggled prescription pills and other contraband into Rikers Island, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: Beauty Guru Tata Harpers Guide to Vermont, Her Home State
description: From her 1200-acre farm in the Champlain Valley of Vermont, Tata Harper has built a beauty empire. The Colombian-born entrepreneurs cult organic skincare and aromatherapy products, many made with herbs grown on site, are stocked everywhere from J.Crew to the worlds best boutiques. In August, shell launch her first color cosmetics product, Volumizing Lip and Cheek Tint, in three shades. Whether Harpers radiant glow can be chalked up to her all-natural products or the benefits of rural living, the woman may be her own best advertisement. Just in time for the lazy days of late summer, when urbanites crowd the regions verdant hills and valleys, Harper shares with T her most inspiring destinations for shopping, dining and relaxing around the Green Mountain State.

title: A Crowdsourced Sonnet for a Summers Day in the Office
description: Back in May, The American Scholar invited office time wasters everywhere to help crowdsource a sonnet, starting with the Dilbert-meets-Shakespeare line How like a prison is my cubicle. title: $1.8 Million for Ventura in Defamation Case

More than a decade and a half ago, almost no one thought that a feather boa-wearing former professional wrestler could become the governor of Minnesota. In Mr. Venturas latest turn in the spotlight, some people questioned whether he could prevail in a claim that he had been defamed in a best-selling book, given the relatively high legal standard in such cases for public figures  and given Mr. Venturas lifetime of vivid, blunt and provocative pronouncements.

title: In Paris, a Playful Path Along the Seine
description: A few years ago, Voies sur Berges along the Seine on Pariss Left Bank was one of the busiest two-lane thoroughfares in the city, with up to 2,200 vehicles passing through an hour. But on a warm afternoon in June, a different scene unfolded on the roadway. Along the waters edge, a group of children could be heard singing Joyeux Anniversaire out of a large white tepee, while a glimpse into the canvas structure revealed a woman holding a candlelit birthday cake.

title: In a Singapore Neighborhood, Gritty Mixes With Trendy
description: At first, it was the smell that kept people away. In the mid-19th century, farmers in Singapores Jalan Besar neighborhood used night soil (human waste) to fertilize their vegetable plots, prompting residents to give the main road the tongue-in-cheek name Lavender  still the name today. Jalan Besar has been on the gritty side of gleaming Singapore ever since, known primarily for its divey karaoke bars, cheap hotels and hardware shops. Lately, however, its low rents have lured design stores, trendy coffee shops and the beautifully restored Kam Leng Hotel. With a new metro line set to open in 2017, residents are bracing for the coming real estate boom.

title: Elephants, My Brother and Me
description: The elephant didnt seem particularly confused. It was merely curious. That was the only way to make sense of why, as it meandered down a street in a remote village in Thailand, it had chosen to stick its sizable head into the lobby of the no-frills hotel that I was grudgingly using as my base. My brother Michael and I exchanged glances and smiled.

title: The Right, the Rich and Reciprocity
description: From the pundits perspective, the best thing about Paul Ryans new proposals on poverty is the way theyve surfaced some very interesting debates about the welfare state, debates that tend to go underground when anti-poverty spending is just being discussed in the context of the overall fiscal picture and the quest (or not) for a balanced budget. In particular, its been interesting to watch Ryans liberal critics train so much fire at his blueprints support (not as a universal requirement, as I understand it, but as a potential model for states to follow)for a contractual approach to anti-poverty spending, in which beneficiaries draw up customized life plans, set goals and targets, and have rewards and penalties pegged to their follow-through on those responsibilities. The liberal critiques of this idea, from writers like Annie Lowrey and Jamelle Bouie among many others, have been genuinely informative: I feel (sincerely!) like I have a better handle on the left-of-center view of poverty and anti-poverty policy than I did a week ago, and hopefully my future posts on the subject will profit from that advance in understanding.

title: Rules of Style | DJ Harvey, Dance-Floor Legend and Man of Fashion, on High-Waisted Pants and International Hair
description: If, as the disco act Indeep oncesang, D.J.s can save lives, then Harvey Bassett might be classified as sort of an elite ER surgeon of the profession. A music connoisseurs music connoisseur, the British-born turntablist known as DJ Harvey has spent four decades collecting records and is frequently flown around the world to play them. A teenage punk rocker turned fixture of the U.K. dance-party scene in the 80s and 90s, Bassett has in recent years returned to making his own music (the house-centric album Locussolus, the genre-blending collaborationMap of Africa). His latest project, Wildest Dreams, releases its self-titled debut on Smalltown Supersound today. Its lo-fi psychedelic rock songs were inspired by the mood of Los Angeles and Bassettsnostalgia for his garage-band youth. It sounds like the music I was making 40 years ago when I was 11 years old and we wanted to be like Cream or the Jimi Hendrix Experience, he says. A track from the album, Rollerskates, appears here.

title: Punch Lines, Commentary and Rants

Back then, when the comedy club was still in its infancy, this was more common. Allan Sherman and Bob Newhart both reached No. 1. But if such albums were more prominent then, the scale of the current comedy boom, as well as the many formats available for distribution, mean that there have probably never been more funny specials available than right now. Weird Als success may be a sign of comedys ascent, but the volume of specials released online, on streaming services and even on vinyl represents a more significant shift in this fertile art form. title: Massachusetts: Lawmakers Finalize Bill Aimed at Protesters Outside Abortion Clinics
description: Lawmakers on Tuesday finalized legislation intended to prevent demonstrators from hindering patients and employees who are entering abortion clinics. The bill, proposed after the United States Supreme Court struck down a state law that barred demonstrators from standing less than 35 feet from a clinic entrance, would allow the police to disperse an assembly of one or more that substantially impedes passage to a clinic entrance. It would also require those individuals to stay 25 feet away from the entrance for, at most, eight hours after a dispersal order. The bill would also expand the suite of civil actions the state could take if the law was violated. The bill was sent to Gov. Deval Patrick, a Democrat, who was expected to sign it.

title: Theodore Van Kirk, 93, Enola Gay Navigator, Dies
description: Theodore (Dutch) Van Kirk, the navigator and last surviving crew member of the Enola Gay, the B-29 Superfortress that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in the last days of World War II, died on Monday at his home in Stone Mountain, Ga. He was 93.

title: Colorado Clerk Told to Stop Issuing Marriage Licenses to Gay Couples
description: DENVER  The Colorado Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered a county clerk in Boulder to stop issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples, halting the practice a month after a handful of county clerks had defied a ban in the State Constitution.

title: Loss of Shelter and Electricity Worsens a Crisis for Fleeing Gazans
description: GAZA CITY  When artillery shattered their home near the Israeli border, Ibrahim Hillis, a grandfather, rushed his extended family to the city to seek shelter, but the schools were full and relatives houses were already packed with others displaced by the war.

title: Corcoran Chairman Defends Merger Plan in Court
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the board of trustees of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, which after years of financial struggle is seeking legal permission to dissolve itself into the National Gallery of Art, testified in court here on Tuesday that the 145-year-old museum had essentially lost its ability to attract donors and could not remain a stand-alone institution.

title: Rutgers and Maryland Get Skeptical Big Ten Welcome
description: CHICAGO  Intercollegiate football made its debut 145 years ago this November in New Brunswick, N.J., a fact that Rutgers, that games host, proudly proclaims.

title: Maybe in America

If youre keeping score at home, the world of disorder just added another country: Libya. America quietly folded up its embassy in Libya last week and left, leaving behind a tribal/militia war of all against all. Not good.

title: To Arrest Fugitives, Officers Try to Anticipate the Unpredictable
description: When they entered a cramped Greenwich Village smoke shop to arrest a fugitive on child molestation charges on Monday, the three law enforcement officers were well prepared. They had handguns and Kevlar vests, and, perhaps most important, hours of training on the many situations they might encounter.

title: North Carolina Budget Deal Includes a Raise for Teachers
description: Leaders of the Republican-controlled North Carolina legislature on Tuesday announced details of a tentative budget agreement, including a 7 percent pay raise for teachers in public schools, that could end a monthlong stalemate that has exposed a breach between Republican conservatives and moderates in the state.

title: Suit Filed Against N.H.L.
description: Another class-action lawsuit against the N.H.L. was filed Tuesday by former players saying that the league took insufficient action to reduce brain injuries caused by concussive and sub-concussive impacts. Jon Rohloff, a defenseman for the Boston Bruins from 1994 to 1997, is the lone named plaintiff in the suit, which was filed in United States District Court in Minnesota. The suit says that the league concealed the dangers of concussion and did not pass rules designed to reduce the risk of brain injury until recent seasons. N.H.L. representatives did not respond to a request for comment late Tuesday afternoon. After a similar suit was filed in April, Bill Daly, the deputy commissioner, said, We are completely satisfied with our record on player safety, including as it relates to head injuries and brain trauma.

title: As Sanctions Pile Up, Russians Alarm Grows Over Putins Tactics
description: MOSCOW  Russia, facing the toughest round of Western sanctions imposed since the Ukraine crisis erupted, has adopted a nonchalant public stance, with President Vladimir V. Putin emphasizing the importance of self-reliance and a new poll released Tuesday indicating a What, me worry? attitude among the bulk of the population.

title: New York Educators Fight Back on Attacks to Tenure
description: Education advocates in recent days have assailed job protections for New York teachers as antiquated, unwarranted and unconstitutional.

title: Surgeon General Calls for Action to Reduce Skin Cancer Rate
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top doctor called on Tuesday for immediate action to reduce the rate of skin cancer, the most commonly diagnosed cancer in the country and one that is often preventable.

title: NYU Langone Medical Center to Get $1.13 Billion in Storm Aid
description: NYU Langone Medical Center, which was badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy and had to be evacuated, will receive $1.13 billion in recovery aid, the second-largest award for a single project in the history of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, hospital and federal officials said on Tuesday.

title: Honoring a Filmmaker in the Shadow of Apartheid
description: DURBAN, South Africa  Unknown among his fellow white South Africans, Tonie van der Merwe was the most popular filmmaker among black audiences in the 1970s and 80s. He churned out about 400 movies under an apartheid subsidy system established to produce movies exclusively for blacks  with the right political and moral content. In fact, he helped create the system.

title: Hamels, Repeatedly Finding Strike Zone, Handles Mets
description: This was perhaps Cole Hamelss last start as a member of the Philadelphia Phillies, the team that drafted him and cultivated him and rode his left arm to a World Series title in 2008. But he did not seem to be in a savoring mood against the Mets on Tuesday night.

title: North Korea: Images Show Work on Rocket Site
description: North Korea has nearly completed construction of an improved site for launching long-range missiles and appears to have conducted multiple tests of rocket motors for them, the U.S.-Korea Institute, part of the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, said Tuesday in a report based on assessments of recent commercial satellite images. It said the improvements at the site, the Sohae Satellite Launching Station, near the border with China, suggested that North Korea intended to launch larger rockets with greater ranges and payloads. The report, published on the institutes website, 38north, was the latest indication that North Korea was moving toward another launching at Sohae, where it successfully fired a long-range missile in December 2012 that reached as far as the Philippines.

description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  The reasons the Lakers hired Byron Scott as their latest coach were all around the makeshift stage that was set up on their practice court.

title: A New Fashionable Tote for the Farmers Market
description: Were all at the farmers market at least once a week, says Monica Zwirner, the co-founder of the accessories label MZ Wallace, as she nimbly packs her labels newest offering, a handsome navy blue market tote, full of ears of corn, tomatoes and wild flowers. The we to which she refers includes her business partner, the former fashion magazine editor Lucy Wallace Eustice, and Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs, the food writers and co-founders of the online cooking community Food52. The four women have gathered at the Union Square Greenmarket to test drive their first creative collaboration, what they describe as the ultimate farmers market tote. After filling it to the brim, they head back to the Food52 studio to whip up a celebratory lunch of tomato salad with corn, summer squash and roasted onions.

title: A Former Hedge-Funder Finds His Passion Selling Handmade Turkish Shoes
description: When the young entrepreneur Mickey Ashmore was a student at University of Pennsylvania, he wrote a note to himself that said simply live in Istanbul one day. Then when he graduated in 2009, Ashmore went to work for Microsoft, where he was offered a position abroad  in Turkey. And it was there, in the city of his dreams, that Ashmore found inspiration for what would become his first entrepreneurial venture: sabahs, slip-on footwear made from high-quality leather stitched to a rubber sole, a craft that originated in the old Turkish bazaars.

title: Running 5 Minutes a Day Has Long-Lasting Benefits
description: Running for as little as five minutes a day could significantly lower a persons risk of dying prematurely, according to a large-scale new study of exercise and mortality. The findings suggest that the benefits of even small amounts of vigorous exercise may be much greater than experts had assumed.

title: Morning Views
description: The European Union agreed on Tuesday to a new and higher level of sanctions against Russia, including the closing of European capital markets to Russian state banks, an embargo on new weapons sales and the transfer of sophisticated oil drilling technology, says an editorial in The New York Times.The United States followed suit shortly with measures meant to match the Europeans. These punitive actions are designed to exact a heavy price from President Vladimir Putin for Russias escalation of direct involvement in the wake of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash. Compounding the situation are public charges by the United States that Russia has violated a fundamental arms control accord, the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty. The editorial states that economic sanctions are a flawed and double-edged weapon, but, short of armed force, they are the only tools available to the West to demonstrate that breaking the rules of international behavior carries a cost.

description: The Kaiser Family Foundation has a new survey (pdf) on Obamacare in California, and its full of remarkably good news. For those who havent been following this, CA  with its now-dominant Democratic Party  is where Obamacare was implemented the way it was supposed to be implemented: the website worked pretty well from the beginning, Medicaid expansion was implemented, and the state worked hard on outreach. It was also a place that really needed reform: the uninsured were a high percentage of the population, and an individual market without community rating meant that the mere hint of a preexisting condition was enough to prevent coverage.

title: Senators Offer Bill to Curb Campus Sexual Assault
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of senators on Wednesday introduced legislation designed to curb the startling number of sexual assaults on college campuses. The measure would require schools to make public the result of anonymous surveys concerning assault on campuses, and impose significant financial burdens on universities that fail to comply with some of the laws requirements.

title: A Camera Meant Never to Lose Its Focus
description: In 2006, Ren Ng, a graduate student at Stanford, published a doctoral thesis outlining a revolutionary technology in photography that almost seemed like an illusion.

title: Eurozone Banks More Open to Lending, Survey Shows
description: FRANKFURT  Banks in the eurozone are more willing to lend to businesses for the first time in seven years, a survey by the European Central Bank showed on Wednesday, raising hopes that one essential component of economic growth could be starting to recover.

title: The Case Against a Mammoth Frick Collection Addition
description: New York Citys Landmarks Preservation Commission would do well to turn down the Frick Collections proposed expansion, which imagines replacing a prized garden on East 70th Street in Manhattan with a clumsy addition. The city should avoid another self-inflicted wound, and there are other options.

title: Religious Conservatives Embrace Pollution Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The Rev. Lennox Yearwood punched his fist in the air as he rhythmically boomed into the microphone: This is a moment for great leadership. This is a moment for our country to stand up. This is our moment.

title: A Taste of Barcelonas Evolving Dining Scene
description: Conventional wisdom has it that dining out in Barcelona means bouncing from one Michelin-starred restaurant to the next, with chefs like Ferran and Albert Adri and Albert Raurich leading the way. But as the Spanish economy has suffered in recent years, the fine-dining scene has hit its share of road bumps. Tourism, in large part, has been able to sustain many of the great temples of Spanish cuisine, though not all have survived. Can Fabes, a restaurant outside of Barcelona that earned three Michelin stars every year from 1994 to 2011, closed in August, while Madrids two-star restaurant Sergi Arola Gastro closed months before, after owing back taxes (though it has since reopened). Albert Adri has even gone as far as to say that the high gastronomy formula doesnt work now.

title: Restaurant Report: Coppervine in Chicago
description: As a boy in San Francisco, Don Sritong refused to eat chocolate chip cookies without milk. The decadent richness and gooeyness of the cookie is cleaned up by a crisp glass of milk, said Mr. Sritong, describing his early fascination with food and drink pairings, now matured for adult audiences as the focus of his new Chicago restaurant, Coppervine.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Lame in Vienna
description: Rates

title: Different Ring, Different Fight
description: For that distinctive minority whose tastes run to both boxing and theater, there is now a promising alternative to Rocky, the Broadway musical scheduled to close this month. It can be found in the flyspecked training ring of the Rock and Anvil Boxing Gym, which has been assembled at 59E59 Theaters for the New York premiere of Brett Neveus The Opponent, opening on Aug. 7.

title: Many Reasons to Offer 401(k)s (Including Owners Retirement)
description: Soon after Sabina Gault got her public relations firm up and running in 2008, she asked for a show of hands from employees interested in having a company 401(k) plan. The consensus? Nobody wanted it, said Ms. Gault, whose firm, Konnect Public Relations, based in Los Angeles, had just a few employees at the time.

title: Valeants Cost-Cutting Ethos May Yet Give Wall Street Indigestion
description: Updated, 6:33 p.m. | Wall Street bulls love Valeant Pharmaceuticals lean business model, but there are side effects they arent aware of that might give them pause.

title: Air Force Plans Shift to Obtain High-Tech Weapon Systems
description: WASHINGTON  In an acknowledgment that the military may be pricing itself out of business, the Air Force on Wednesday called for a shift away from big-ticket weapon systems that take decades to develop and a move toward high-technology armaments that can be quickly adapted to meet a range of emerging threats.

title: 1964: President Johnson Jolts Kennedy Camp
description: WASHINGTON  President Johnsons swift and final dumping of Robert F. Kennedy tonight [July 30] was a bitter blow to the attorney general that brought to an end a gay and glittering era that became known as the New Frontier. It really ended with an assassins bullet in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963. But it had been kept alive in the person of Robert Kennedy, the brother of the slain President. Tonight, just an hour after Mr. Johnson had abruptly ruled him out of the vice-presidential nomination, the attorney general issued a terse statement saying it is the Presidents responsibility to make known his choice. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 31, 1964

title: Snapchat Said to Have Had Talks With Alibaba on Potential Investment
description: When Snapchat spurned takeover interest from the likes of Facebook and Google, investors scoffed at the audacity of the photo messaging service. But the start-up may have the last laugh.

title: Understanding Gaza: Correspondents Suggest What to Read
description: The war between Israel and Hamas has entered its fourth week. We asked Times reporters and editors who are covering the current conflict and those who have covered previous conflicts in Gaza to recommend what to read to better understand the history of the region.

title: Libertarians and Reformers
description: My Sunday column divided American conservatisms would-be populist reformers into two camps, reform conservatives and libertarian populists, and tried to briefly describe the overlap and distinctions between the two. Ive made this distinction before, and like any binary its in some sense artificial: You could easily fold both groups into a broad reformist tendency, or disaggregate them further into smaller camps. But I do think the typology is pretty useful, for various reasons  one of which is that it helps clarifytwo of the gravitational pulls (from very different directions) that todays conservative reformers need to at least partially escape.

title: Brooklyn Museum to Offer Free Admission to Visitors Under 20
description: The Brooklyn Museums suggested general admission fees for adults will increase to $16 from $12, and entry for visitors 19 and under will be free starting Sept. 3, the museum announced on Wednesday.

title: Is There a Fair Way for Employers to Match 401(k) Contributions?
description: By offering a company-sponsored 401(k) plan, small-business owners can improve their odds of recruiting and retaining employees  and also make it easier to save for their own retirement in the process.

title: Teaching a Child to Wrangle, Not Reject, Rage
description: My elementary-age daughter wants to wear a skimpy skirt to school. I make her change. My middle-school son who recently smoked marijuana wants to hang out with a friend. I say no. I refuse to sign consent for my 16-year-old to get a tattoo. What do I get? Angry children who may persist until Im mad in both senses of the word. Parenting will eventually produce bizarre behavior, and Im not talking about the kids, said Bill Cosby.

title: Bank of England Sets Tough Rules for Banker Bonuses
description: Updated, 6:00 p.m. | LONDON  After years of debate among global regulators and lawmakers about how to structure pay to curb reckless risk-taking, the Bank of England on Wednesday announced some of its toughest restrictions yet on bonuses while introducing new rules intended to hold managers more accountable for problems.

title: First Data Buys Start-Up for Virtual Gift Cards
description: First Data Corporation, a payments processing giant, is hoping that virtual gift cards will aid its quest to return to profitability.

title: Morgan Stanley Names New Vice Chairman in Global Capital Markets
description: Reza Moghadam, formerly a director at the International Monetary Fund, is joining Morgan Stanley as vice chairman in its global capital markets division, the bank announced on Wednesday. He will assume his new role in the fourth quarter.

description: Forty-five years after astronauts landed on the moon, scientists say they have finally discovered its true shape: slightly flattened, with a bulge on one side.

description: More public transit. Better public spaces.

title: Dozens Feared Dead in Mudslide in Western India
description: NEW DELHI  More than 150 people were trapped Wednesday when a massive mudslide swamped a village of 40 homes in western India during heavy monsoon rains, and officials said they had little hope of rescuing many of those missing as weather conditions were likely to worsen Thursday.

title: The Upside of a Wimpy Handshake
description: Weak handshakes are often frowned upon, but they may be healthier than firm ones. A fist bump, though, may be an even healthier choice.

description: MADRID  The leader of Catalonia, the region that accounts for one-fifth of Spains economy, told Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy during a meeting on Wednesday that he would go ahead with a vote on independence in November that the central government in Madrid has vowed to block.

description: How different do great orchestras really sound from one another in the 21st century?

title: Useless Expertise
description: Justin Wolfers calls our attention to the latest IGM survey of economic experts, which revisits the question of the efficacy of fiscal stimulus. IGM has been trying to pose regular questions to a more or less balanced panel of well-regarded economists, so as to establish where a consensus of opinion more or less exists. And when it comes to stimulus, the consensus is fairly overwhelming: by 36 to 1, those responding believe that the ARRA reduced unemployment, and by 25 to 2 they believe that it was beneficial.

title: Bank of America Raises Its Mortgage Settlement Offer
description: Bank of America and federal prosecutors have accelerated their negotiations to resolve an investigation into the banks sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis. The two sides, however, remain far apart on crucial issues and a settlement remained elusive late Wednesday, even after the bank significantly raised its offer.

Tax Inversions Spinning Out of Control
description: Inversions are starting to spin out of control. A quest for tax savings has made digestible overseas targets attractive to United States buyers. Hospiras potential $5 billion deal for a Danone unit highlights a fresh supply, for spinversions. The odd combination also reflects the perverse incentives distorting corporate decisions.

title: Fed, on Target to End Bond Buying, Stresses Concerns on Jobs Market
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve affirmed its commitment to stimulate the economy on Wednesday in a policy statement that said labor market conditions remained well below the level that most of the central banks officials consider healthy.

description: During his time at the helm of his namesake label, Martin Margiela only gave interviews via fax and refused to be photographed. Despite his departure, Maison Martin Margiela still operates under the same ethos. Recently, after a three-year absence, the Paris-based fashion house decided to venture back into the realm of fine jewelry  and to speak anonymously via email to T about it. It seemed like the right time to reopen this side of our creative world, a nameless representative from the house wrote.

title: China Charges Leading Uighur Scholar With Separatism
description: BEIJING  Authorities in the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang have formally charged the Uighur scholar Ilham Tohti with separatism, a serious crime that carries a potential death sentence.

title: David Wilson Sidelined as Giants Await Evaluation of Injury
description: Giants running back David Wilson, who had off-season neck surgery, will not practice for the remainder of this week and will be held out of Sundays Hall of Fame exhibition game with the Buffalo Bills after sustaining a neck or shoulder injury in practice Tuesday.

title: Steady but Slow Remains the Story of This Recovery
description: The latest G.D.P. report is less interesting for its accounting of the second quarter than for what it tells us about the future path of economic growth.

description: WASHINGTON  The epiphany hit Jeremy Robbins, appropriately enough, while he was riding in a taxi in the nations capital.

description: Life Is Beautiful is scrawled in bold relief on the side of a brand-new apartment building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, pink paint dripping down from its giant letters. But unlike some of the nearby walls of graffiti, this tag was done at the behest of the building owner.

title: How the Federal Government Slows Marijuana Research
description: Politicians who dont want to take a clear position on marijuana legalization often say more research is needed on the effects of consuming the drug. Hillary Clinton called for more research just last month on CNN.

title: Sarah Kane Play Among Offerings at St. Anns Warehouse
description: A production of the British playwright Sarah Kanes 4:48 Psychosis, by the Polish company TR Warszawa (Variety Theater in Warsaw), is among the highlights of the 2014-15 season at St. Anns Warehouse, the presenter of experimental theater and music in Brooklyn. (The playwright, whose best-known work, Blasted, took 13 years to make it to a New York stage, wrote 4:48 Psychosis shortly before she committed suicide in 1999.)

title: Two Dozen Companies on Board for Fall for Dance
description: Fall for Dance, the annual festival at City Center, will include performances by 24 dance companies from around the world for its 11th season. World premieres will be performed by the Mark Morris Dance Group and Music Ensemble and Pontus Lidberg Dance, the Australian Ballet and Lil Buck.

title: Lifted by Economic Growth, Obama Speaks Optimistically of Policies
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  President Obama on Wednesday delivered an optimistic report about the effects of the administrations policies in spite of congressional inaction, buoyed by the announcement that the economy grew more than anticipated in the spring.

title: U.N. Says Evidence Points to Israel in Gaza School Attack
description: UNITED NATIONS  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said on Wednesday that all available evidence suggested that Israeli artillery had hit a United Nations school in Gaza full of civilians who thought they were in a safe zone.

title: Mets Rout Phillies, Making Their Case Ahead of Deadline
description: For almost a month, General Manager Sandy Alderson had stressed the importance of these games as he evaluated where the Mets stood, with the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline drawing nearer. He seemed to be evaluating not whether the Mets were legitimate contenders, but rather how close they were to contending.

title: The Paris Hotel Scene Gets a Glitzy New Player

title: You Can Hate Your Job, But You Still Have to Deal With It
description: Theres a lot of advice out there about how to find the perfect job. But getting a job at all is no easy feat and even if you manage to get one you like, youre all but certain to have bad days. Enter another strain of career advice: how to help you handle your job better, including the parts of it that might not be perfect.

title: In Search of the Conservative Artist
description: Earlier this month, Adam Bellow wrote a cover story for National Review calling on conservatives to contest the terrain of American culture more fully by investing more heavily in the arts  up to and including including writing programs, fellowships, prizes, and so forth, together with newproduction and publishing companies and distribution platforms for music, film, and other forms of conservative-themed entertainment. (Bellow has founded his own imprint, Liberty Island, dedicated to publishing fiction with conservative, libertarian, and contrarian themes.)

description: J. Paul Getty enjoyed his vast fortune but also lamented its downsides, including being viewed as a penny-pincher if he didnt provide a big tip.

description: For nearly 12 years leading up to his sudden death last fall, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Oscar Hijuelos worked obsessively on a novel that few people knew he was writing. The book, an intensively researched 859-page historical novel about the friendship between Mark Twain and the Welsh explorer Henry Morton Stanley, was a departure for Mr. Hijuelos, who is best known for chronicling the lives of immigrants.

The news was not surprising.

title: Dancing and Hoping to Win Fans for Life
description: There was nothing unusual at the New Victory theater last week in a request to turn off electronic devices, except that it was directed at audience members not entirely versed in theatrical etiquette. When the lights went out, they howled. When someone fell, they laughed. In silent sections, they started clapping a beat. In between selections, they tested out moves.

title: Top Long Jumper Loses Ruling on Prosthesis, Reviving a Debate
description: The debate over whether disabled athletes using prosthetic devices should compete alongside able-bodied athletes took an unusual turn this week when a German amputee long jumper qualified for next months European Athletics Championships in dramatic fashion, only to learn that his national federation would not place him on its roster because officials deemed his prosthetic leg advantageous.

title: What Science Says About Marijuana
description: For Michele Leonhart, the administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, there is no difference between the health effects of marijuana and those of any other illegal drug. All illegal drugs are bad for people, she told Congress in 2012, refusing to say whether crack, methamphetamines or prescription painkillers are more addictive or physically harmful than marijuana.

title: Senate Opens Debate on Bill to Halt Surge of Migrants
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats opened debate Wednesday on an emergency measure to help stem the flood of young migrants from Central America, though they still face two uphill votes  another procedural, and one of final passage  before they can head home for the five-week August recess having passed legislation to address the crisis at the southern border.

title: More Than Words Can Say
description: A new crop of statement tops, those dressed-up pieces you wear with tailored pants or jeans for a night out, is trickling into stores. After seasons of logo tees and slogan sweatshirts, the new tops, with striking shapes and pretty, feminine details, look fresh and appealing. The tuxedo style from the French label Atto, for example, would be elegant with cropped trousers at an evening event. As would the flannel shirt with feather trim by Alessandro DellAcqua for N0. 21. Think of them as a party on top, business on the bottom.
