description: EVERY year, antibiotic-resistant infections kill at least 23,000 Americans and make another two million sick, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  Thats why a recent ruling by the United States Second Circuit Court of Appeals is so appalling.

title: Back From Paris, With Beauty Trophies in Tow
description: Who needs the beauty floor of Le Bon March? Walk a few blocks in nearly any Parisian quartier and youll spot the electric-green cross of a pharmacy stocked with beauty elixirs used by generations of Frenchwomen. But if you want to browse one of the largest selections (with some of the lowest prices), head to what was once an unlikely grooming destination: St.-Germain-des-Prs, that hotbed of 1940s existentialist philosophy.

title: Bargains at Canvas, Bobby Berk and Broadway Panhandler
description: All goods at Canvas are at least 15 percent off, through Sunday (a Palm Leaf Basket set, originally $70, is $21); 123 West 17th Street (Sixth Avenue), 212-372-7706, canvashomestore.com.

title: AMC Said to Be in Talks Over Stake in BBC America
description: AMC Networks, the home of AMC, SundanceTV and IFC channels, is in talks to acquire close to a 50 percent stake in BBC America, the United States television network owned by the commercial arm of the BBC, according to people briefed on the discussions.

title: Infant Chic
description: Nursery Works is introducing a collection of cribs it claims is unique in the annals of infant bed design. No one does the kind of experimentation with materials and design you see in the adult furniture world, said Matthew Grayson, the senior designer for Nursery Works. We wanted to be the ones to push the limits.

title: Finding Art That Speaks to You
description: I dont know much about contemporary art, but I know what I like. Actually, I dont really know what I like. ArtKapsule, a London service co-founded by Elaine Ronson that recently extended to New York, is for people like me, with blank walls and exhaustingly endless possibilities. For a $250 consultation fee, I first received a questionnaire designed to reveal my taste. Then, Ms. Ronson, a delightful Glaswegian, and one of her consultants, Wayne Northcross, came to my home, looked around and chatted with me about my needs and $5,000 budget. They showed me about 45 images of contemporary artworks. We want you to look at the art and imagine that its a shape-shifting alien whos desperately trying to communicate with you, but its using means that are beyond any language that youve ever encountered before, Ms. Ronson said. Her point was that if you know a piece is trying to tell you something, youll strain every sense to understand it. Instantly, I went from feeling that contemporary art thinks its better than I am to feeling it was trying to embrace me.

title: Weave to the Beat
description: It was while she was earning a degree in textile design that Nadia-Anne Ricketts discovered a connection between music and weaving. When I used to weave, it felt like I was playing a piano, said Ms. Ricketts, the founder of BeatWoven, a London textile company. I realized that it was very similar in terms of counting, and the mathematics. Working with the help of a software designer, Ms. Ricketts developed a computer program to translate audio patterns into woven ones. The result, she said, looks like a sound wave, but its been granulated.

title: A Hint of Coco
description: Last week, the renovated Georgian Restaurant opened at Harrods in London, with furnishings inspired by Coco Chanel. With this collection, I asked myself, How do I bring elegance into todays world without looking dated? said Christopher Guy Harrison, a British furniture maker who designs under the name Christopher Guy, and who based the collection, called Mademoiselle, on pieces from Ms. Chanels suite at the Ritz Hotel in Paris. Soft contours, metallic glimmers and lush velvet are features of his seven chair and five banquette styles. The collection also includes mirrors, mosaics and a copper statue of a Georgian aristocrat.

title: Everyone Into the Kitchen
description: In 1976, while Johnny Grey was still in architecture school, he cooked up a punk Gothic kitchen for a friend. It was the opening salvo in his war on cookie-cutter kitchens. With encouragement from his aunt, the renowned cookbook author and shopkeeper Elizabeth David, he designed what he calls sociable kitchens and promoted the principles that make them work. Today considered one of the worlds most influential kitchen experts, Mr. Grey, 63, estimates that he has produced more than 500 kitchens, and his company, in Hampshire, England, takes on about 20 projects a year. A recent example  a pool house with cooking capabilities in Cambridge, England  piqued our interest during these dog days of summer. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Low Stools, High Art

title: Britains Crime of Complicity
description: LONDON  THERE is something almost reassuring about the enduring ability of the British establishment to place itself beyond parody. This month, as the government announced an inquiry into historical allegations of child sex abuse by leading political figures, Parliament pushed through a broad surveillance bill with the justification that tapping everybodys cellphones would, among other things, help the state catch pedophiles.

title: Age of Identity
description: Hair is political.

title: Street Style on the High Line in New York City
description: Marika Emi and her boyfriend were recently strolling along the High Line park in Manhattan on a visit from Hawaii. Ms. Emi was dressed head to toe in black, looking more like a native New Yorker than many of the other colorfully dressed tourists who frequent the park. The funny thing is, Im from Hawaii but people ask me if Im from New York when Im there, she said. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: Digital Photography: A Look Back
description: Twenty-five years ago  before people were taking pictures with cellphones  the future of photography was explored at a workshop where photographers encountered early digital tools.

title: A Mothers Ambitions
description: If Im lucky, I might have as long as two hours to work. I riffle through the stack of research articles on substance use, pull out a few relevant ones, and begin revising my papers introduction. Ive just gotten in the groove when a sweet singsong voice drifts over from the room next door: Mommy, I have to go to the baaaa-throom!

title: G.E.s Retail Finance Arm Raises $2.9 Billion in I.P.O.
description: General Electrics retail lending arm, the financial power behind the private-label credit cards for the Gap and Amazon.com, raised about $2.9 billion in its initial public offering on Wednesday, as the industrial conglomerate moves to shrink its once-enormous finance division.

title: Piercings Are Back, Subtle and Sophisticated
description: A few years ago, Sarah Slutsky found an online photo of a delicate gold hoop pierced midway through the ear cartilage. I kept looking at it, she said. I was an assistant at Vogue at the time, and after one stressful day, I said, Im going for it. She took a friend along to get the piercing. That was 2011, said Ms. Slutsky, who is now a fashion stylist. I felt like we were pioneers.

title: Investigators Warn of Possible Perils in Fall With Health Site
description: WASHINGTON  The federal health insurance marketplace, a centerpiece of President Obamas health care overhaul, still suffers from serious problems, raising questions about whether it will be ready to enroll millions more people this fall, federal investigators said Wednesday.

title: Summer Shades at the Makeup Counter
description: Summer blooms are at their seasonal peak. Some new roses, peonies and poppies are available now at beauty counters.

title: Design, With a Gritty Past
description: In a superheated real estate market, Torontos Queen West residents embrace specialty shops and loft apartments, while regretting the flight of artists and the loss of affordable housing.

title: Digital Divide on the Wedding Aisle
description: Welcome to your first Wedding 2.0.

title: Drawing Ire, Not Artists
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  The setting was pastoral, eight gently rolling acres on a water-lily-flecked lake with two dainty islands. Overlooking it was a modestly elegant Tudor-style house built in the 1930s, with a brood of 19 Rhode Island Red chickens, a colony of honeybees and a burly but amiable German shepherd named Brady.

title: When Is Prefall? As Soon as You Want It to Be
description: Clarissa Bronfman has no use for hoary fashion strictures. Ms. Bronfman, a jewelry designer and lanky social figure, was casting a covetous eye on a leopard-spotted Dior dress at a gussied-up yard sale in the Hamptons last week. True, the dress represented the designers prefall line. But Id wear it right now in the city, Ms. Bronfman said.

title: Paying With Your Phone
description: Molly Wood demonstrates how apps from PayPal, Starbucks and Google can help you make purchases with your phone, and explains why you cant do it everywhere yet.

title: Easier Ways to Make Payments With Smartphones
description: AT this point, smartphones are practically permanent attachments to our hands. But that quickly changes the moment you need to pay for something at a store and you take out a credit card.

title: Looking to Rub Elbows With the Kardashians
description: Kim Kardashian and her sisters Kourtney and Khlo did not make an appearance at their Dash pop-up store on Jobs Lane in Southampton, N.Y., on Saturday afternoon, but you could find their likenesses on many of the products, and their aesthetic everywhere.

title: Four Square Blocks: Toronto
description: The Queen West Art and Design District of Toronto occupies the sweet spot between scared off and priced out.

title: Between a Loft and a Hard Place
description: TORONTO  First came the manor houses, then the mental hospital, then the stockyards. By the end of the 19th century, the part of Toronto known today as Queen West had had more reversals of fortune than an entire season of Dallas (the original or the new version).

title: Sweat-Free SoHo Style
description: Women keep their clothes loose, lightweight and stick to light colors to stay cool throughout the sweaty New York City summer.

title: The Looks of Summer
description: Girls in their summer outfits stride on. Even if those dresses these days can be a bit of a mishmash.

title: How the House Decided to Sue Obama
description: Ahead of a summer break, House Republicans have moved forward with plans to sue President Obama.

title: The Looks of Summer
description: Many people regard the Irwin Shaw 1939 short story, Girls in Their Summer Dresses, through the haze of affectionate nostalgia, but its plot is really quite devastating. A young married couple, Frances and Michael, take a post-breakfast walk down lower Fifth Avenue that soon goes south metaphorically as well when she observes him checking out other women. They repair to a bar and knock back three glasses of brandy apiece while the husband, prodded by his wife, expounds on his greed for the bountiful picnic of female pulchritude on display in New York and she cries hopelessly. Seventy-five years after that story was first published in The New Yorker, a descendant of the Brevoort, where the couple lived, still stands. But their argument would probably play out not over Courvoisier but coffee with hearts etched into the foam on top, or complicated green juices. If Michaels leers turned into actual overtures, he might be excoriated on Twitter for street harassment (#HollaBack); safer to examine his quarry on Tinder instead. Frances might be too engrossed in her own iPhone to even notice.

title: Senators Stand Against Sexual Assault
description: A bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation aimed at limiting sexual assaults on college campuses and improving the response to them.

title: Moment (Click) by Moment (Click)
description: AGE 34

title: The Stylist Makes the Man, and the Dandy
description: I divide my life into the years B.C. and A.D.  meaning Before Clothing and After Dresser.

title: Luxury Thats From Africa, and for Africa
description: Around the time the recession rolled through Europe and the luxury consumers left standing fled from logo-mania and toward the authentic and the rare, Hanneli Rupert, a South African artist living in London, said that she began to notice lots of African influences in fashion.

title: The Moonlight Mile in Greenpoint, Brooklyn
description: We have three serious passions: whiskey, beer and music. Thats the ethos of Garry Embrys new bar, the Moonlight Mile, which serves more than 150 American whiskeys and a rotating selection of 12 craft beers. As for the music, not only is the place named after a Rolling Stones deep cut, but there is a rock-heavy jukebox in the back where patrons can play their favorites free.

title: Under Armour Heads Off the Sidelines for a Campaign Aimed at Women
description: ADVERTISING for Under Armour tends to feature elite athletes competing on fields, but to promote its womens line the athletic apparel brand has a new commercial starring a nonathlete.

title: New York State Sheriffs Shying Away From Immigration Detention
description: The New York State Sheriffs Association has recommended that its members refuse requests by federal immigration authorities to hold foreign-born detainees for additional time so that they can be investigated for immigration-related offenses.

title: Our Blind Spot About Guns
description: If we had the same auto fatality rate today that we had in 1921, by my calculations we would have 715,000 Americans dying annually in vehicle accidents.

title: Ending Prohibition 2.0
description: I havent written on it, but the Times editorial board has been doing a major public service by pushing for marijuana liberalization. Read the intro to the series, with links to the articles.

title: U.S. Bars Travel by Top Venezuelan Officials
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The State Department said on Wednesday that it was imposing travel restrictions on Venezuelan officials whom it considered to be responsible for human rights abuses during recent antigovernment protests.

title: Labor Ruling on McDonalds Has Business Worried
description: After a federal agencys decision that McDonalds is jointly liable for the employment actions of its franchise operators, businesses across the United States were puzzling over the decisions potential reach. Many feared that they, too, might fall under that broad umbrella.

title: Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy Have Jack Nicklaus in Sights, at Greater Distances
description: AKRON, Ohio  In the four-month gap between World Golf Championships events, Tiger Woods has played six competitive rounds to Rory McIlroys 38.

title: None Dare Call It Impeachment
description: Lets talk about something cheerful. How about impeachment?

title: Celebrating a Matriarch of Old New York
description: Ten pallbearers were not required to guide the coffin bearing Maureen Spillane down the aisle of the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus in Midtown on Wednesday. But that was how many men stepped forward, barely fitting along the sides and rear. This day, her generation of Hells Kitchen Irish saw the passing of royalty.

title: From Schoolhouse, to Symbol of Servitude, to Dust
description: ATALISSA, Iowa  The old schoolhouse on the hill had announced the farm town of Atalissa to the Iowa flatness for more than a century. But a couple of weeks ago, the prehistoric claw of a John Deere excavator took its first swipe, and soon the building existed only in the landscape of memory.

title: Filling Stomachs to Open Minds on Immigration
description: STOCKHOLM  Last year, when Ebba Akerman, 31, was teaching Swedish to immigrants in the suburbs of this city, she ran into one of her students on the train and asked him whether he enjoyed living in her country.

title: Patagonia Surfing Wet Suits Go Green
description: A new kind of bio-rubber could change the way surf companies make wetsuits.

title: Whats Behind the Possible Met Lockout
description: With a lockout increasingly likely, the show may not actually go on this fall at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Nordstrom Buying a Website for Mens Wear
description: Guys hate shopping, said Brian Spaly, the chief executive of Trunk Club, a shopping website for men, but love to look good.

title: Angels Were Way Ahead of the Trade Deadline
description: BALTIMORE  The closer thrives on responsibility. His job, almost always, is to preserve the work of his teammates. They give him a lead, he keeps it, and with enough victories the team plays into October.

title: Defying Death in Utah Arches: A Thrill Too Far?
description: MOAB, Utah  No outdoor pursuit is too crazy for this desert town built on red sandstone and adrenaline. Mountain bikers careen off rocks. Climbers string lines between towering rock spires and dance out over canyons. People build oversize slingshots and launch themselves skyward, recording every scream and scene to post online.

title: At Patagonia, the Bottom Line Includes the Earth
description: VENTURA, Calif.  Early on a recent Friday, Mitch Taylor, a local surfer, paddled out at County Line Beach off the Pacific Coast Highway near Malibu, wearing a new Patagonia wet suit. After carving a few waist-high waves, he gave it a positive review, pronouncing it indistinguishable from other high-performance gear he had tried.

title: Banco Esprito Santo Posts $4.8 Billion Loss
description: MADRID  Banco Esprito Santo on Wednesday reported a first-half loss of 3.58 billion (or $4.8 billion), the largest ever for a Portuguese institution, wiping out the banks 2.1 billion capital cushion and forcing it to raise new funding.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 30, 2014
Kim Kardashian, an Unlikely Mobile Video Game Hit
description: A Kim Kardashian smartphone game sounds like a joke waiting for a punchline. But Ms. Kardashian and the maker of Kim Kardashian: Hollywood are laughing all the way to the bank.

title: Archbishop, Under Fire Over Abuse, Apologizes but Says He Wont Resign
description: The Roman Catholic archbishop of St. Paul and Minneapolis, under fire for the way his diocese has dealt with sexually abusive priests, apologized Wednesday for his conduct but rejected calls for his resignation.

title: Sorrow in the Stands
description: Hoops love is a New York City affliction, and to play it above the rim, to shoot and run with the best, you couldnt tell James Williams there was much better. Williams, known to everyone as Stixx, was 6-foot-8, blessed with a lean frame and a sweet lefty stroke, and he scored easily enough on more than one N.B.A. star in the citys summer leagues.

title: Businessman Says Former Virginia Governors Wife Sought Money
description: RICHMOND, Va.  The wealthy businessman at the heart of the governments case alleging that former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife used his office to enrich themselves took the stand on Wednesday and began describing how he provided the couple with a river of cash and gifts.

title: Suicide Bomber From U.S. Came Home Before Attack
description: WASHINGTON  When Moner Mohammad Abusalha drove a truck packed with explosives into a restaurant in northern Syria in May, American authorities conceded that they knew little about how a young man who grew up a basketball-obsessed teenager in a Florida gated community had become a suicide bomber.

title: Quest for Demilitarization of Gaza Is Seen Getting Netanyahu Only So Far
description: JERUSALEM  After years in which Israels prevailing approach to the Gaza Strip was a simple quiet for quiet demand, there is growing momentum around a new formula, reconstruction for demilitarization.

title: Despite the Loss of a Star, Liverpool Is Hoping to Build on Its Success
description: At nearly every stop during Liverpools preseason tour in the United States, Manager Brendan Rodgers has been asked how he planned to replace the star forward Luis Surez, who was sent to Barcelona for $130 million shortly after the World Cup.

title: Were Living in It
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  This is a puzzle about SPACE. It involves the most commonly-touched key on your COMPUTER KEYboard and, interestingly enough, it also involves the STAR WARS CANTINA. Because, and say it with me, both are SPACE BARS.

title: Reading Between the Sheets
description: Who are you?

title: Payola Figure Is Charged in Gambino Betting Ring
description: Joseph Isgros rsum tracks a peculiarly American life, a roller-coaster ride through Hollywood and the underworld, with associates ranging from rock stars to mobsters.

title: Roddicks Doubles Comeback Is Dashed
description: To help a friend ease back into the spotlight, Andy Roddick decided to make a comeback this year at the United States Open, where he was a champion in 2003.

title: A Long Slate of Mayoral Candidates Hints at a Rapidly Changing Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  There were 19 candidates on the scorecard for the mayoral forum at the Acts Full Gospel Church here last month. Fourteen of them actually showed up, primed to speak about their plans for public safety and job development, far in advance of the election in November. They are seeking to unseat the incumbent, Mayor Jean Quan, one of the few familiar faces on the panel. As for the others, it was sometimes hard to keep track.

title: Video Released of U.S. Bomber in Syria
description: Jihadist video released from Syria featuring an American suicide bomber, Moner Mohammad Abusalha, provides new details into his mind-set before he died in an attack in May.

title: First Lady Praises Leaders for Progress of Girls in Africa
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obama on Wednesday praised the efforts that African leaders have made in improving educational opportunities for girls, but she emphasized that barriers remained and pledged American support in removing them.

title: Banned Munitions Still in Use, Report Says
description: Cluster bombs, internationally banned weapons that can maim and destroy indiscriminately, not only have been frequently used for the past two years by government forces in the Syrian civil war but also appear to have been deployed this year by antagonists in the South Sudan and eastern Ukraine conflicts, the director of a leading disarmament advocacy group said Wednesday.

title: Argentina Finds Relentless Foe in Paul Singers Hedge Fund
description: The hedge fund firm of billionaire Paul E. Singer has about 300 employees, yet it has managed to force Argentina, a nation of 41 million people, into a position where it now has to contemplate a humbling surrender.

title: Arthur Shafman, 75, Importer of Mummenschanz Troupe, Dies
description: Arthur Shafman, an ambitious concert and theater producer who spotted an obscure Swiss mime troupe at a cafe in Zurich in the 1970s, brought it to Broadway and watched it become one of the longest-running shows in history  Mummenschanz  died on Monday in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 75.

title: Jay Maeder, 67, Newspaperman Who Wrote Annie Comic Strip, Dies
description: Jay Maeder, a columnist and editor for The Daily News and The Miami Herald and the last writer of the comic strip Annie, died on Tuesday at his sisters home in Houston. He was 67.

title: Russia: Officials Deny Violating Treaty
description: Russia denied on Wednesday accusations by the United States that it had violated a significant arms control treaty by testing cruise missiles. The statement from the Russian Foreign Ministry accused Washington of airing old grievances and using megaphone diplomacy to try to score political points during the Ukraine crisis. It said that problems stemming from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty were not new and that Russia also had concerns about American weapons tests, including of missile defense systems slated for deployment in Poland and Romania, as well as armed drones. The Russian statement did not refer directly to an American demand that it allow a delegation to visit Moscow immediately to discuss the United States concerns. But the Foreign Ministry said Washington had previously rebuffed Russian attempts to get an explanation about its questions.

title: Libya: Benghazi March Protests Militias
description: Residents of the eastern city of Benghazi marched Wednesday in protest against Islamist militias, the citys dominant force for years, in a burst of public fury a day after the Islamist fighters seized a local special forces base. Residents marched to a hospital, temporarily routing fighters from the extremist militia Ansar al-Shariah, who had been providing security for the hospital. But the militiamen fired on the civilians when they tried to approach the special forces base, scattering the demonstrations. Protesters said they were especially angered after the leader of Ansar al-Shariah declared Wednesday on the radio that Benghazi was an Islamic emirate. Violence in Libya has sharply escalated in recent weeks, in Benghazi and in the capital, Tripoli, where rival militias have been fighting for control of the international airport. Several countries have closed their diplomatic missions, and thousands of Libyans have fled to neighboring Tunisia in recent days.

title: Man Is Charged in Sale of Pills Linked to a Death
description: In the weeks before the Electric Zoo music festival last year, Jeffrey Russ and two friends pooled more than $1,000 to buy dozens of pills that they planned to take themselves and share with others as they bounced to the thudding bass on the grassy fields of Randalls Island.

title: With Time Dwindling to Make Trade, Yankees Show They Need Help
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Brian Cashman, the Yankees general manager, was still making calls to try to improve the team as the hours before Thursdays nonwaiver trade deadline dwindled.

title: Dcor at Gracie Mansion Now Fits de Blasios Style
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio never looked comfortable amid the formal interiors and ornate staterooms of Gracie Mansion, the museumlike residence where he and his family moved this week. Century-old chandeliers and antique cabinets are not exactly in keeping with the populist de Blasio image.

title: A Rookie as Feisty as She Is Steady
description: Anna Cruz packed two bags for a trip to New York in April to participate in the Libertys training camp, expecting to be back in Spain with her family after two weeks. After Cruzs first practice, Coach Bill Laimbeer and his staff selected her as a starter in the backcourt, extending her stay through the summer.

title: 14 More Brooklyn Convictions Linked to Scarcella Are Examined
description: The Brooklyn district attorneys office has identified 14 more cases on which the former New York City police detective Louis Scarcella worked, expanding the scope of the offices broad inquiry into Mr. Scarcellas work.

title: Skydiving Student Killed in Long Island Jump
description: A New York City correction officer was killed and his skydiving instructor was critically injured during a tandem jump on Wednesday on Long Island, the authorities said.

title: Governors Office Suspends 40 Tax Preparers for Not Filing Own Returns
description: The governors office announced on Wednesday that it had suspended 40 tax preparers who, despite their profession, did not file personal income taxes.

title: $350 Million for New Yorks Affordable Housing Effort
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday announced a commitment of $350 million of public and private funding to pay for the renovation of 7,500 apartments, in what he called a major step toward his 10-year goal of 200,000 new or rehabilitated homes for lower- and middle-income New Yorkers.

title: Suit Seeks to Make Sidewalks More Accessible for Disabled New Yorkers
description: Arguing that New York Citys streets are often inaccessible for the blind or those in wheelchairs, a group of advocates filed suit against the city on Wednesday for what lawyers called violations of federal disability laws.

title: RTL Group, a European Content Producer, Buying Majority Stake in Online Ad Company
description: The RTL Group, a big European media company, announced on Thursday that it had purchased a 65 percent stake in SpotXchange, an online video advertising start-up.

title: GetYourGuide, a Tourism Start-Up, Raises $25 Million in Financing Round
description: A start-up hoping to do for tourism what OpenTable has done for much of the big-city restaurant business  helping it gain popularity on mobile devices and the web  has just received a big vote of confidence from investors.

title: Checking In From Home Leaves Entry for Hackers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The same tools that help millions of Americans work from home are being exploited by cybercriminals to break into the computer networks of retailers like Target and Neiman Marcus.

title: Bothered by a Gummy Smile
description: Susanna Miller-Pences teeth werent the problem; her gums were. When she smiled, her upper lip stretched up so high that a ribbon of pinkish gum was exposed, giving her a so-called gummy smile. She hated it.

title: Live From the Public Library: Joseph ONeill, Joyce Carol Oates and Dr. Funkenstein
description: The novelist Joseph ONeill, the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, the cartoonist and filmmaker Marjane Satrapi and the musician George Clinton  yes, Dr. Funkenstein himself  will be among the headliners at the fall season of Live From the NYPL, which begins on Sept. 16 at the New York Public Library.

title: U.S. Attorney Warns Cuomo on Moreland Commission Case
description: In an escalation of the confrontation between the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over the governors cancellation of his own anticorruption commission, Mr. Bharara has threatened to investigate the Cuomo administration for possible obstruction of justice or witness tampering.

title: E.W. Scripps and Journal Communications to Merge, Then Spin Off Newspapers
description: E.W. Scripps and Journal Communications, the publisher of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, said on Wednesday that they planned to merge and then spin off their combined newspapers, leaving behind a company focused on broadcast television.

title: Pension Smoothing: The Gimmick Both Parties in Congress Love
description: The Federal Highway Trust Fund is set to run out of money. If Congress does not put more money in the fund by Friday, the federal government will start reducing its payments to states for highway projects, and some construction might stop. So the House and Senate are fighting over how to get money in the fund, and the fight has boiled down to pension smoothing, a budgetary gimmick worthy of Rube Goldberg.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE QUEST Grueling challenges, narrative storytelling and special effects collide as 12 people are transported to a fantasy world of dragons and ogres, where they are declared Paladins, defenders of a noble cause. They must compete to save the besieged kingdom of Everealm  with the surviving contestant earning the title of the One True Hero  in this new series whose masterminds worked on The Lord of the Rings and The Amazing Race.

title: Statins May Speed Wound Healing
description: Statins, the widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs, may have a role in surgical wound healing, a new analysis suggests.

title: Deep-Pocketed Bayern Munich Is Open for Business in U.S.
description: Bayern Munich, the mightiest of the clubs in Germanys Bundesliga, picked an appropriate time to begin building a year-round presence in the United States.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 31, 2014
description: It feels like youre cliff-diving, but youre looking down at a solid rock foundation.

title: Editors Note: July 31, 2014
description: The Inside Art column on July 25, about a planned exhibition of the works of the Renaissance painter Piero di Cosimo, started with a description of the artists life and eccentricities. That passage improperly used specific language and details from a Wikipedia article without attribution; it should not have been published in that form. (Editors learned of the problem after publication from a post on FishbowlNY.)

title: Separating the Flies From the Tigers in Beijing Zoo Corruption Case
description: Updated, 4:16 a.m. ET| Among the panoply of officials to be targeted in Chinas continuing crackdown on corruption, the case against a former deputy director of the Beijing Zoo has raised the most unlikely questions.

title: BNP Paribas Posts $5.8 Billion Loss on U.S. Settlement
description: Updated, 7:03 a.m. | LONDON  The French banking giant BNP Paribas reported a record quarterly loss on Thursday after it recently agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty for doing business with countries on which the United States had imposed sanctions.

title: Lloyds Banks First-Half Profit Fell 63% on Legacy Charges
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday that its profit declined 63 percent in the first six months of the year as the bank set aside 1.1 billion pounds for a series of regulatory issues.

title: Santander Profit Rises 38% as Loan Losses Decline
description: LONDON  The Spanish lender Banco Santander reported on Thursday that its second-quarter profit rose 38 percent as the bank benefited from an improving economic environment and from declining charges for bad loans.

title: The Kids Who Beat Autism
description: At first, everything about L.'s baby boy seemed normal. He met every developmental milestone and delighted in every discovery. But at around 12 months, B. seemed to regress, and by age 2, he had fully retreated into his own world. He no longer made eye contact, no longer seemed to hear, no longer seemed to understand the random words he sometimes spoke. His easygoing manner gave way to tantrums and head-banging. He had been this happy, happy little guy, L. said. All of a sudden, he was just fading away, falling apart. I cant even describe my sadness. It was unbearable. More than anything in the world, L. wanted her warm and exuberant boy back.

title: Digital Photography: A Look Back
description: I was there when the first shots were fired in the Photographic Digital Revolution. There were no rifles 25 years ago on Marthas Vineyard, but there were strange-looking prototype cameras that captured images with small sensors and saved them on floppy disks.

title: Emergency Efforts in Africa to Contain Ebola as Toll Rises
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  As the death toll mounted from the worst outbreak of the Ebola virus, West African leaders quickened the pace of emergency efforts on Thursday, deploying soldiers and authorizing house-to-house searches for infected people in an effort to combat the disease.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: Meda to Buy Italian Drug Maker Rottapharm for About $3 Billion
description: LONDON  The Swedish drug maker Meda said on Thursday that it had agreed to pay about $3 billion in cash and stock for the family-owned Italian drug maker Rottapharm, less than a month after that company pulled its plans for an initial public offering.

title: Cease-Fire in Gaza Conflict Takes Effect as Talks Are Set
description: NEW DELHI  A 72-hour humanitarian cease-fire in the Gaza conflict negotiated by the United States and the United Nations took effect Friday morning, a diplomatic bolt-from-the-blue that will suspend the bloody 24-day military campaign and set the stage for arduous negotiations between Israel and Hamas over a more lasting truce.

title: New York Today: Endless Summer Race
description: Good morning on this cloudier Thursday.

title: Eurozone Inflation Continues Its Slide
description: FRANKFURT  Inflation in the eurozone fell in July to its lowest level since 2009, according to an official estimate released Thursday. But separate figures showing a drop in unemployment provided some reassurance that the region was not yet on the brink of a destructive downward price spiral.

title: British Fraud Office Reaches Second Settlement in Inquiry Over Icelandic Bank
description: LONDON  Britains Serious Fraud Office said on Thursday that it had reached a second settlement in a series of civil claims brought by two brothers after a flawed investigation into the collapse of the Icelandic bank Kaupthing during the financial crisis.

title: Morning Views
description: Federal law enforcement policies on marijuana use are out of step with scientific consensus, writes Philip M. Boffey for The New York Times. Marijuana is far less harmful to human health than most banned drugs and is less dangerous than the highly addictive but perfectly legal substances known as alcohol and tobacco. Mr. Boffey concedes that marijuana isnt an entirely harmless substance: The potency of current strains may shock those who havent tried it for decades, particularly when ingested as food. It can produce a serious dependency, and constant use would interfere with job and school performance. It needs to be kept out of the hands of minors. But on balance, its downsides are not reasons to impose criminal penalties on its possession, particularly not in a society that permits nicotine use and celebrates drinking.

title: Recalling the Horror of the Flight 17 Crash Site
description: Sabrina Tavernise is a science reporter and former foreign correspondent. A Russian speaker, she was sent to cover the conflict in eastern Ukraine. She was one of the first journalists to arrive at the scene of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash. This week, she is back at home in Washington, D.C. We asked her about the challenges of reporting on the crash.

title: Brad Maiorino, Targets New Cybersecurity Boss, Discusses Being a Glutton for Punishment
description: Brad Maiorino sounds like a man unfazed by military hackers in Shanghai or cybercriminals in Eastern Europe.

title: Second-Chance Med School
description: Sitting around an outdoor table at the Red Crab, a restaurant on the tropical island of Grenada festooned with palm trees and fiery bougainvillea, a dozen aspiring doctors bashfully conceded that they had been, at best, near misses when it came to getting into medical school in the United States.

title: China Harasses U.S. Tech Companies
description: China has opened what appear to be politically motivated antitrust investigations into American technology companies like Microsoft and Qualcomm. Foreign companies operating in the Communist country could be in for more intense harassment than ever before.

title: Daily Report: Checking In From Home Is a Boon for Hackers
description: The same tools that help millions of Americans work from home are being exploited by cybercriminals to break into the computer networks of retailers like Target and Neiman Marcus, Nicole Perlroth reports.

title: Credit Suisse Is Facing Inquiries Over Its Dark Pool
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse on Thursday became the latest big financial institution to confirm that it was facing regulatory inquiries over its private stock trading platform, known as a dark pool.

title: British Construction Giant Balfour Beatty Calls Off Merger Talks With Rival Carillion
description: LONDON  The British construction and services company Balfour Beatty said on Thursday that it had called off merger discussions with its rival Carillion after a dispute over whether a consulting business that had been put up for sale would remain a part of the combined company.

title: FTI Consulting Names New C.F.O.
description: David M. Johnson, a former executive at the mortgage finance giant Fannie Mae, is joining FTI Consulting as its chief financial officer, the business advisory firm announced on Thursday. He will take over the role on Aug. 25.

title: Shell, ENI and BG Report Strong Earnings
description: LONDON  Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that profit for the second quarter rose 206 percent to $5.3 billion, reflecting gains from asset sales under its new chief executive, Ben van Beurden, as well as improved performance in exploration and production.

title: 1914: Jean Jaurs Assassinated
description: M. Jean Jaurs, the French Socialist leader and Deputy of the Tarn Department, was assassinated last night [31 July] in a caf in the rue Montmartre by a man whose identity is unknown and who declares that he was actuated by patriotic motives.

title: Kerings Acquisition of Ulysse Nardin Means More Than You Think
description: The announcement Wednesday that Kering, parent company of Gucci, Balenciaga, Stella McCartney et al., had bought the independent Swiss watch brand Ulysse Nardin was largely overshadowed by its announcement the same day that its second-quarter revenues had beaten analysts expectations, in part thanks to soaring sales at Saint Laurent.

title: Yee-Ha! Space Cowboy Rides to the Rescue
description: Talking about directing in blockbusters is sometimes nothing more than wishful thinking. Most are such impersonally operated machines  dedicated to the business of brand storytelling  that they tend to obliterate any whisper of individuality. That theres a palpable directorial sensibility in Guardians of the Galaxy, along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons. Here, a pulse, wit, beauty and a real sensibility have been slipped into the fray, alongside the clockwork guffaws, kabooms and splats.

title: Morning Agenda: Bank of America and U.S. Far Apart on Deal
description: Bank of America and federal prosecutors have accelerated their negotiations to resolve an investigation into the banks sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. But the two sides remain far apart on crucial issues, and a settlement remained elusive late on Wednesday, even after the bank raised its offer.

title: Adidas Issues Profit Warning Tied to Ukraine Crisis
description: FRANKFURT  Shares of Adidas, the German sportswear maker, plunged 13 percent on Thursday after the company said it would miss its profit targets for the year, in part because of problems connected to the crisis in Ukraine.

title: Inquiry Into Poisoning of Ex-K.G.B. Officer Opens in Britain
description: LONDON  At a time of icy relations between Britain and Russia, a senior judge in London on Thursday opened a high-profile public inquiry into the poisoning death of the former K.G.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko, saying that allegations of Moscows involvement would be of central importance.

title: After a Series of Setbacks, Target Chooses an Outsider as C.E.O. for the First Time
description: Coming off a series of setbacks, Target named a new chief executive on Thursday, bringing in an outsider to lead the company for the first time as it looked to right itself. The move casts aside Targets longstanding custom of promoting top executives from within the company.

title: End of Ramadan in Queens
description: Dear Diary:

title: Wozniacki Is Lining Up for New York Marathon
description: The aftermath of a failed relationship: Rory McIlroy walks 18 holes; Caroline Wozniacki runs 26.2 miles.

title: An E-Commerce Emporium for Locally Made Goods
description: For four years, Peter Smith watched as chain stores replaced mom-and-pops in his neighborhood of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. A Dunkin Donuts took over the pharmacy and they were tearing down great old buildings for a Whole Foods, recalls Smith, 32, who recently moved to quieter precincts in Greenpoint. At the same time there were these great brands coming out of Brooklyn. The problem was that people just didnt know about them.

title: Making Work Fun Is Not About Table Tennis and Paintball
description: You know something that is often overlooked in business? Having fun at work. No, I am not talking about the make-believe fun of team-building exercises and paintball scrimmages and company picnics. Most of that is a waste of time. Im talking about making the actual work fun so people take pleasure in doing it.

title: An ABC Veteran Is Named PBS NewsHour Producer
description: Sara Just, the Washington deputy bureau chief for ABC News, has been named executive producer of PBS NewsHour, the first major change to the program since it was acquired by the public broadcaster WETA at the beginning of July.

title: Wisconsin Justices Uphold Union Limits, a Victory for the Governor
description: CHICAGO  The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a law that significantly limits collective bargaining rights for most public workers, dealing a decisive blow to labor unions in the state and handing Gov. Scott Walker a crucial victory in an election year.

title: Taking Your Teenagers to Kyoto
description: In a Japanese tea ceremony, youre supposed to bow to the server; rotate the cup to the right; have the sweet bean paste cake before the bitter powdered green tea; and finish in three and a half sips. Slurping is encouraged.

title: 36 Hours in Green Bay, Wis.
description: Few cities evoke a single notion in the minds of locals and visitors alike as does Green Bay. This is Titletown, home for nearly a century to the Green Bay Packers, a place where streets are named Lombardi Avenue and Holmgren Way, after former Packers coaches. On Sundays during the fall, the streets empty out, as residents (the lucky ones) fill up Lambeau Field. The remaining six days of the week are spent discussing the game just played and sizing up the next. Its hard to begrudge the city its love of its home team. Green Bay, with a population of 100,000, is by far the smallest metropolis to boast a professional football team, and the only one with a publicly owned franchise. The Packers are, indeed, Green Bays, and no one elses.

title: Break in Fighting Lets International Team Reach Site of Ukraine Crash
description: SHAKHTYORSK, Ukraine  International monitors finally reached the crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine on Thursday, after being blocked for days by fighting in the area between Ukrainian troops and pro-Russia separatists.

title: The President Could Boost Wages, If He Wanted To
description: At a planned White House event on the economy this Thursday afternoon, President Obama should use his remarks for more than huffing and puffing about the strong economic growth in the second quarter.

title: A Delicately Managed Face-Lift for a Paris Beauty
description: Updated Aug. 5 after hotel reopening.

title: Oaktree Capital Earnings Fell 55% in Quarter
description: Updated, 1:19 p.m. |

title: He Feels Good, Sometimes
description: If musical genius is a gift randomly bestowed, it requires intense monomaniacal cultivation to reach fruition. Witness James Brown, a.k.a. the hardest-working man in show business, as portrayed indelibly by Chadwick Boseman in the viscerally explosive biopic Get On Up. A monumental egotist, perfectionist and harsh taskmaster with a streak of paranoia, Brown reigned as the absolute monarch of his personal kingdom, answering to no one but himself.

title: Amy Bloom: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Lucky Us would like to invite Sappho, George Bernard Shaw and James Baldwin over for a literary dinner. Its not clear to me that everyone will get along.

title: A New Volunteer Program for L.G.B.T. Travelers
description: Global Volunteers, a non-profit organization providing aid to communities around the world with the assistance of short-term vacationers, has launched International LGBT Volunteer Vacations, the first volunteer vacation program directed specifically at L.G.B.T. travelers.

title: Israel on Destruction of Gaza Tunnels
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, and Moshe Yaalon, the Israeli defense minister, discussed their efforts to complete the destruction of Gaza tunnels used by militants.

title: Feeling as if I Failed the Patient
description: On bad nights, I jolt awake at 2 a.m. and settle in for what will be two hours of tossing and turning as I ponder the mundane (did I remember to pack a belt for the meeting Im flying to in the morning?), the profound (will my children grow to be happy and contributing adults?), and the prophetic. On this night, I thought about the patient I had been treating for three years for leukemia. I would be seeing her in clinic in a few hours, and I had a bad feeling about her disease.

title: Synchrony Shares Open Flat After Largest I.P.O. for Year
description: Shares in Synchrony Financial, the North American retail finance unit being spun off by General Electric, opened largely unchanged on Thursday after it raised about $2.9 billion in its initial public offering.

title: In Portugal, Central Bank Moves to Clean Up Banco Esprito Santo
description: MADRID  Portugals central bank stepped up efforts to clean up the troubled lender Banco Esprito Santo and end its family control after the bank reported a stunning first-half loss of $4.8 billion that will force it to raise more capital.

title: From Townhouse to TriBeCa, the Hard Way
description: As their family grew, Benjamin Berkman and Boji Wong knew they would need more space than they had in their two-bedroom Battery Park City condominium.

title: On Eventful Day, the Action Begins With One Ace and Ends With Another
description: In one of the more dizzying days in recent baseball history, 12 deals involving 37 players were completed Thursday before the 4 p.m. deadline for trades without waivers. All-Stars and prospects and many players in between were on the move in a flurry of activity that could change the landscape of the pennant races.

title: And the Moral of the Story Is: Keep It Positive
description: The slower pace of summer means more time to tell stories to our kids, whether its around a campfire or in a car on the long, long trip to our vacation spot. We tell these stories for many reasons: to entertain, to pass the time, to share adventures from our own past. And sometimes we tell stories in order to make a point.

title: Alda, Burnett, Dennehy and Farrow Among Roster of Stars for Love Letters
description: Alan Alda, Carol Burnett, Brian Dennehy, Mia Farrow, Diana Rigg, and Martin Sheen will be among the rotating actors this fall and winter in a Broadway revival of A.R. Gurneys play Love Letters, which will begin performances Sept. 13 at the Nederlander Theater, the producers announced Thursday.

title: Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert Take Aim at Tax Inversions
description: Comedy Centrals The Daily Show With Jon Stewart and The Colbert Report mocked the growing trend of companies seeking to elude taxes through overseas mergers.

title: Argentina Official on Failed Debt Talks
description: After debt talks collapsed, the economy minister of Argentina, Axel Kicillof, characterized the negotiations with an American hedge fund as extortion.

title: A Panorama of After-Hours New York, From the Brooklyn Band Bear in Heaven
description: An error message on a friends broken TV set inspired the title of the band Bear in Heavens fourth album, Time Is Over One Day Old (out Aug. 5 on Dead Oceans). The sentiment, and how it randomly came into our world, seemed connected to our state of mind at the time, says Jon Philpot, the frontman. The album alternates between revving synths and drifting melodies, and between two lyrical ideas: outer space and inner travel. Its an accessible brand of art rock that often gets the band compared to fellow Brooklynites like the National, Grizzly Bear and the Antlers. Were too weird for the straights and too straight for the weirds, jokes the guitarist and bassist Adam Wills.

title: Posthumous Album by Robin Gibb to Be Released
description: An album of unreleased, and in some cases, unfinished songs by Robin Gibb  including his final song, written and recorded shortly before his death in 2012  will be released in September. The album, called 50 St. Catherines Drive (the address of the home on the Isle of Man where the singer was born in 1949) was compiled by Gibbs widow, Dwina Murphy Gibb and his son R.J. (who co-wrote several of the songs), the BBC reported.

title: On the Border, Who Gets to Be a Refugee?
description: A poll by the Public Religion Research Institute asked Americans whether they thought children illegally crossing the United States border from Mexico should be treated as refugees and be allowed to stay. Sixty-nine percent of respondents said yes,according to The New York Timess Julia Preston, and about a quarter of Americans in the survey, 27 percent, said the minors should be treated as illegal immigrants and deported to their home countries.

title: Fortress Investments Results Are Buoyed by Private Equity Gains
description: The Fortress Investment Group, a publicly traded alternative asset manager, said on Thursday that its second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, aided by sales of its private equity investments.

title: Falling Glass From Midtown Office Tower Injures 3
In Real Estate Listings Deal With Zillow, Trulia Bears Most of the Risk
description: The success of Zillows $3.5 billion acquisition of Trulia may depend not on an and but an or that the parties put in their acquisition agreement to deal with antitrust issues. Not only that, but the deal leaves Trulia the loser if the merger fails on antitrust grounds.

title: Inquiry by C.I.A. Affirms It Spied on Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON  An internal investigation by the C.I.A. has found that its officers penetrated a computer network used by the Senate Intelligence Committee in preparing its damning report on the C.I.A.s detention and interrogation program.

title: 1964: Rusk Bars Threat to Soviet Ties
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Dean Rusk vetoed firmly today a suggestion by Sen. Barry Goldwater that the United States try to extract concessions from the Soviet Union by threatening a break in diplomatic relations with Moscow. The United States does not and will not yield to pressure or threats when its vital interests are involved, Mr. Rusk said, and it would be unrealistic to think the Soviet Union might do so. Without mentioning the Arizona Republican presidential nominee by name, Mr. Rusk, who usually avoids partisan political issues, said he does not foresee any shifts in the near future in U.S. policies abroad. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 1, 1964

title: Tell Me About Your Next Job
description: This interview with Jon Bischke, the chief executive of Entelo, a recruiting software platform, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Requests for User Data Rise in Twitters Latest Transparency Report
description: Twitter on Thursday released its bi-annual transparency report, detailing the number of requests for information the company receives from government agencies around the world.

title: Interpreting The Maids Through a Shifting Societal Lens
description: Jean Genets creepy, sexy play The Maids, which had its premiere in 1947, has never gone out of fashion. But in the last several years, it has been riding a new wave of interest, with revivals in Europe and Canada and mash-ups like the Off Off Broadway ensemble Sister Sylvesters forthcoming The Maids The Maids, whose cast, according to the company, will include two professional housekeepers.

title: Sadistic Fantasy in a Fun House Mirror
description: It was a particularly brutal murder. In 1933, the French domestics Christine and La Papin killed the wife and daughter of their employer, gouging out their eyes while the women were still alive and knifing their thighs and buttocks.

title: With Eyes on Seats in Maryland and West Virginia, Politicians Cross Borders
description: CHARLES TOWN, W.Va.  Only 30 miles and the Potomac River separate this bedroom community in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains from Frederick, Marylands second-largest city.

title: Protests Thwart Israeli Troupe at Edinburgh Festival
description: A run of The City, a hip-hop musical being presented at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe by the Incubator Theater, a company based in Jerusalem, has been halted after one performance after protests on Wednesday. A demonstration organized by the Scottish Palestine Solidarity Campaign, reacting to the violence in Gaza, forced organizers at Underbelly, the presenting site, to call off the rest of the run there, saying the demonstration was disturbing other productions at nearby performance spaces.

title: In Final Hours, Metropolitan Opera Extends Contract Deadlines for Unions
description: The Metropolitan Opera postponed a threatened lockout late on Thursday night, saying that it had done so at the request of a federal mediator who was brought in at the 11th hour to try to salvage its contract negotiations with the unions representing its orchestra and chorus.

title: 50 Shades of Blue, Green, Everything
description: Art and adversity are old friends. When Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler, currently the subject of a poignant exhibition at Galerie Perrotin  on Madison Avenue, were starting out as artists, straitened circumstances meant they had to take house-painting jobs to pay the rent. They found themselves fascinated by houses, colors, even the names of colors: subjects that became the focus of a joint career that continued until Ms. Ericsons death from brain cancer in 1995 at the age of 39.

title: Do-It-Yourself Lawyers
Li Out of U.S. Open With Knee Injury
description: Li Na started this year well, winning titles in Shenzhen, China, and at the Australian Open by the end of January. Shortly before her 32nd birthday in late February, Li reached a career-high No. 2 ranking.

title: A Jaguar F-Type, Modified for Tour de France Duty
description: PARIS  The team cars following the riders this month at the Tour de France were, for the most part, large and sensible station wagons. But there was one notable exception. During last Saturdays time trial, as riders raced against the clock, the British Sky team appeared with a modified Jaguar F-Type coupe to carry its riders spare bikes and wheels.

title: Tesla and Panasonic Agree to Build Factory in U.S.
description: Tesla Motors announced on Thursday that it had an agreement with Panasonic to build a large-scale battery plant in the United States.

title: Today in Small Business: Time to Give Raises?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: F.D.A. Acts on Lab Tests Developed In-House
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Thursday that it would start regulating medical laboratory testing, saying that tests used to make important treatment decisions must be vetted and validated before they go into use.

title: Keep the Met Open
description: Whatever happens in the bitter negotiations between unions and management at the Metropolitan Opera this week, heres the bottom line: dont shut the doors, even briefly.

title: When the Fourth Wall Is Nature
description: IN the final scene of the Public Theaters production of King Lear, now in previews and opening on Tuesday at Shakespeare in the Park, the bereft Lear enters, bearing his dead daughter in his arms.

title: Google Details Problems With Handling Right to Be Forgotten Requests
description: LONDON  Google says complying with Europes so-called right to be forgotten ruling is getting complicated.

title: San Diego Symphony Names Chief Executive
description: The San Diego Symphony has appointed Martha S. Gilmer, for many years a mainstay in the administration of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, to be its chief executive, starting in September.

title: What to See and Do in Montreal, From the Local Designer Arielle de Pinto
description: The Montreal-based designer Arielle de Pinto has perhaps single-handedly made crochet cool again through hersignature knitted metal jewelry and footwear, sold at such stores as Dover Street Market. And though she is notQubcois, the Toronto native moved to the poutine capital of the world in 2003 and by now is probably as close as any transplant can get to the real thing. With theOsheaga Festivalhappening this weekend and the Francophone capitals fleeting summer in full swing, now is, she says, the perfect time to visit.Montrealers save it all up in the winter and let it all out in the summer, she says. Its two months of perpetual rejoicing.

title: More Polls in Arkansas, but No More Clarity on Senate Contest
description: Arkansas is one of the states where we could really use more rigorous, nonpartisan polling. Three new polls came out this week, and theyve done little to help clear things up.

title: Wheelies: The Payload Policy Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Why Crucial Vaccines Are Sometimes Unavailable
description: When cases of a potentially fatal strain of meningitis began cropping up at Princeton last year, university officials trying to stop its spread could recommend little beyond precautions like frequent handwashing and not sharing beverage containers.

title: Inversions May Be the Least of U.S. Corporate Tax Issues
description: A couple of home-grown tax breaks in the United States are making inversions look like a diversion. The American authorities are letting Windstream designate its telecommunications cables as real estate, qualifying them for tax breaks. And a partnership will shield assets of the energy firm Hess from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Upstart French Telecom Iliad Bids $15 Billion for a Majority Stake in T-Mobile US
description: Updated, 8:14 p.m. | Sprint and T-Mobile US have been slowly dancing toward a $32 billion merger of the third- and fourth-largest cellphone operators in the United States. Now a French upstart wants to break in on the cozy couple.

title: Grab a Seat, Prepare for the Sizzle
description: Ears, jowls, belly. They come brined, blanched, shattered and fried, each tip blackened and alchemized, each pocket of fat approaching liquefaction. A raw yolk idles on top. Stab it and churn. This is sisig, the greatest pork hash  arguably greatest pork dish  on earth. Say the name with two flicks of the tongue, somewhere between a whisper and a hiss.

title: Having More Than One Set of DNA Carries Legacy of Risk
description: The family seemed to defy the rules of genetics.

title: Rebellion Inside G.O.P. Scuttles Vote on Border Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Conservatives in the House rebelled against their leadership on Thursday to scuttle an emergency spending measure that addressed the migrant crisis at the southern border, pushing the issue to a showdown on Friday as lawmakers prepared to leave for a five-week recess. The unexpected turmoil offered a coda to the dysfunction that has gripped the Capitol for much of the year.

title: For Wings and a Prayer, and Maybe a Pint
description: IT was one of those crazy moments, my brother told me, when he wasnt sure if he was hallucinating or receiving a sign from God. You have to know Greg to appreciate that the words Jakes Saloon could be considered a divine message, but in this instance, it wasnt the saloon invoking reverence. It was Jakes. Because on July 2, Gregs wife, Monica, gave birth to their son, Jacob Benjamin, whom they were thinking of calling Jake.

title: Summer Treats in the Mets European Galleries
description: Before 10 a.m. on a recent steamy morning, lines started forming up the front steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with visitors clutching New York City street maps waiting patiently for the doors to open.

title: London Has Plans for Rowdy Drunks
description: LONDON  Londoners are getting a warning about engaging in alcohol-fueled escapades, which can be disorderly at best or cause serious injuries and criminal behavior at worst.

title: Chief Says Discovery Communications Is Open to Deals
description: With talk of deal-making gripping the media industry, the chief executive of Discovery Communications signaled on Thursday that his company was open to striking deals, particularly outside the United States, while also contending that the television group would be fine on its own.

title: Summer Streets Program Begins in Manhattan
description: While the Miser enjoys a short vacation, let those of us left behind create our own staycation on the cheap, right here in our boiling but beloved asphalt jungle. This weekend, in fact, you can pretty much have an entire getaway right down the middle of Manhattan at the annual Summer Streets celebration.

title: Inquiry Reveals Flaws in Training of Con Ed Workers
description: Federal investigators have not yet announced the cause of a powerful explosion that leveled two buildings and killed eight people in East Harlem in March. But a follow-up inquiry by state regulators has exposed flaws in how Consolidated Edison trained workers who install the vast network of plastic pipes that carry natural gas under New York Citys streets.

title: A Father-Son Fishing Trip on the Chesapeake Bay
description: The breeze came slow and easy out of the west, and the creek was glassy and calm as if it were just waking up, too. From the wharf in Onancock, a hamlet on Virginias Eastern Shore, the Onancock Creek courses for about five miles past stately homes and black water coves to empty in the Chesapeake Bay. Out there the waves would be less than a foot high, perfect conditions for our prey. Those specks really like clear water, said Bob Walter, a 58-year-old fishing guide everyone calls Captain Walt. My father, Bill Neville, stood next to him near the skiffs center console as we motored downstream, the wake fracturing the sunlight into golden tesserae. The captain had been doing this for 43 years, and my father, who is in his 70s, has pretty much spent his entire life within whiffing distance of the bay. For as long as I can remember he has been chasing speckled trout.

title: Zeroing In on the Female Traveler
description: Melissa Braverman, the marketing manager for the Westin New York Grand Central hotel, wanted to create a novel vacation package  a departure from the engagement and babymoon promotions that she helped dream up throughout her career, including a getaway for would-be parents known as the procreation vacation.

title: The Richest Man, and His Mansion
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. 'Richest Man Label Irks Getty appeared on July 30 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: The Reader as Artist, Intuitively Plumbing a Psychic Well
description: Like a TED talk or a lesser Alain de Botton book, Peter Mendelsunds What We See When We Read is friendly and shyly philosophical, filled with news you can almost use.

title: A Tale in Pictures of Pictures
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  In one of Anne Colliers signature works, the photographic diptych Woman With a Camera, we see two stills of Faye Dunaway in the 1978 thriller Eyes of Laura Mars. Ms. Dunaway, playing a fashion photographer who has visions of murder scenes every time she tries to take a picture, is seen staring through her viewfinder and then lowering her camera with a look of horror.

title: Reed Krakoffs East Hampton Essentials
description: For three days next week, Reed Krakoff will fill Glenn Horowitz Bookseller with items from his pre-fall 2014 and fall/winter 2014 collections. It comes as little surprise that the designer chose East Hampton for a summer pop-up; he and his wife Delphine have a home there, once owned by the Bouvier family, which they escape to this time of year. While in town, they often stop into the bookshop, which doubles as a gallery, to view the latest exhibition, which I always find inspiring, he says.

title: A Toxic Menagerie
description: Mark Siddall, the curator of the division of invertebrate biology at the American Museum of Natural History, has spent most of his career studying leeches and the chemicals they use to block the coagulation of blood from their prey. It is, he discovered, a deftly targeted toxicity.

title: Writing His Own Tune
description: This week, the pianist Jeremy Denk reviews Jan Swaffords new biography of Beethoven. Denk, who has written for The New Yorker and blogs at Think Denk, is working on a book of his own for Random House, a mix of memoir and thoughts about music tentatively titled Every Good Boy Does Fine.

title: Immortal Beloved
description: In the show 30 Rock, there was a running joke about tragedy. A character appears, reveals her tearful past, then brightly adds, They made a Lifetime movie about me  the credential of an absurdly pathetic story with a redemptive payoff. Of all the great composers lives, Ludwig van Beethovens seems the most made for Lifetime. The curtain opens on a difficult childhood: an abusive alcoholic father, a boy genius mocked for his dark skin. He survives, makes his way to Vienna for fame and fortune  only to be stricken by (gasp) deafness. In addition, we have impossible passions for mysterious beloveds, side themes of class struggle, freedom, individuality, the backdrop of Napoleonic conquest and a score (what a score!) surging with alternating storminess and tenderness. Beethovens story is almost too good to be true, and almost too bad to be television.

title: Mr. Salingers Neighborhood
description: J. D. Salinger: The Escape Artist, by Thomas Beller, is a story of echoes. In this short, sensitive and irresistible biography, echoes ricochet from Salinger to Beller and back, bouncing off a word, a phrase, an accent, a memory, a chat with an acquaintance. Beller grew up in Salingers far-reaching shadow, that cool, shady place so many kids have discovered in The Catcher in the Rye: the overwhelming relief of shared anxiety. He also grew up in New York. The sidewalks, the gravel paths of Central Park, the elevators and white-tiled bathrooms that figure so prominently in Salingers work are part of Bellers vocabulary, too. He writes about New York in both his fiction and nonfiction with intimacy and patience and wonder. New York City is a unifying theme in J. D. Salinger, almost as much as Salingers life itself, almost as much as Salingers work. It is in New York, the fictional, literary city and the actual city, where the two writers truly meet.

title: A Distant Mirror
description: Next to the more apocalyptic spells of American history, the dismal span of 1973 to 1976 would seem a relative blip of national dyspepsia. A period that yielded the blandest of modern presidents, Gerald Ford  a Ford, not a Lincoln, as he circumspectly described himself  is not to be confused with cataclysmic eras like the Civil War, the Great Depression and the Vietnam 60s. The major mid-70s disruptions  the Watergate hearings and Richard Nixons abdication, Roe v. Wade, the frantic American evacuation of Saigon, stagflation, the dawn of the energy crisis (then a newly minted term)  were adulterated with a steady stream of manufactured crises and cheesy cultural phenomena. Americans suffered through the threat of killer bees, Deep Throat, the Symbionese Liberation Army, a national meat boycott, The Exorcist, Moonies and the punishing self-help racket est, to which a hustler named Werner Erhard (n Jack Rosenberg) attracted followers as diverse as the Yippie Jerry Rubin and the Apollo astronaut Buzz Aldrin. Even the hapless would-be presidential assassins of the Ford years, Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme and Sara Jane Moore, were B-list villains by our national standards of infamy.

title: Imam in China Who Defended Partys Policies in Xinjiang Is Stabbed to Death
description: BEIJING  The head of Chinas largest mosque, a vocal defender of the Communist Partys ethnic policies in the troubled region of Xinjiang, was stabbed to death Wednesday in the Silk Road city of Kashgar, state media reported on Thursday.

title: Romantic Truths Revealed Only in Quieter Moments
description: Wishes are more intimate than hopes and dreams, the singer Karen Oberlin mused on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room. A wish is often a secret, she added, then cited the silent prayers that accompany the blowing out of candles on a birthday cake or gazing at a star.

title: Regulators Still Find Problems in Overdraft Fees
description: Four years after federal regulators passed new rules aimed at curbing overdraft fees, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still finding problems with the high fees that banks charge customers when they overdraw their accounts.

title: Update: President Obama Signs a Fair Pay Order
description: President Obama has given labor advocates and progressive Democrats part of what they have been asking for in their drive to improve pay and working conditions for employees or federal contractors.

title: Prominent Activist Charged With Treason in Azerbaijan
description: MOSCOW  Leyla Yunus, a prominent human rights activist in Azerbaijan, was jailed for three months on Thursday pending a trial. The government prosecutor charged Ms. Yunus with treason, tax evasion, running an illegal business and other crimes, according to other human rights activists reached by telephone in Baku, Azerbaijans capital.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Get On Up
description: The director Tate Taylor narrates a sequence from Get On Up, featuring Chadwick Boseman.

title: In India, Kerry to Meet New Prime Minister and Seek Improved Relations
description: NEW DELHI  In the first high-level American visit to India since the election of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that the Obama administration was seeking a new relationship with India.

title: Judge Rules That Microsoft Must Turn Over Data Stored in Ireland
description: Updated, 8:38 p.m. | Microsoft has suffered a setback in its efforts to block federal prosecutors from seizing a customers data that is stored overseas.

title: Tate Taylor Narrates a Scene From Get On Up
description: A high school auditorium in Natchez, Miss., substitutes for the Apollo Theater in Harlem in this sequence from the James Brown biopic Get On Up. The director Tate Taylor discusses the scene and how he used actual recordings of James Brown for the performance vocals in the film, which stars Chadwick Boseman.

title: Lenders to Puerto Rico Utility Extend Payment Deadline
description: Lenders to Puerto Ricos electric power authority are giving the beleaguered utility another two weeks before it has to make past-due payments on its lines of credit.

title: The White House Tries, Fails to Explain Why Marijuana Should Remain Illegal
description: No sooner had the Times published its opening editorials advocating legalization of marijuana than the White House fired back with an unconvincing response on its website. It argued that marijuana should remain illegal because of public health problems associated (always a slippery word) with increased marijuana use.

title: Cuomos Back-Room Style Draws a Potent Critic
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is a skilled back-room operator, renowned for pressuring allies and foes behind the scenes to achieve results that show him in the best possible light.

title: Boehners Defense on Immigration
description: House Speaker John Boehner defended the work of the Republican Party during a brief news conference on Capitol Hill on Thursday.

title: 10 Questions for Paul Ryan
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin gained a national profile  and a spot on the 2012 Republican presidential ticket  by taking an aggressive approach to budget-cutting. But now the House Budget Committee chairman is aiming to broaden his appeal, as well as that of his party.

title: A Twice-Killed Series Finally Ends It All
description: The Killing returns on Friday for one last somber season, a six-episode coda on Netflix. The snakebit show was canceled twice by its original channel, AMC, the second time after a cliffhanger third-season finale in which the Seattle police detective Sarah Linden killed her lover  a fellow cop  when she figured out that he was a pedophilic serial killer. Thanks to Netflix, we get to find out what happens to Linden and her partner, Stephen Holder, in the aftermath.

title: Gaza Conflict Divides U.N. and Israel
description: A look at the increasingly tense relationship between the United Nations and Israel as the violence continues in Gaza.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Spain and the Philippines.

title: The Kids Who Dont Beat Autism
description: The other day a stranger called our house, out of the blue, to discuss my son Jonahs health. Hed seen my memoir about our family and autism in the library and he wanted to know if Id heard about a treatment that was getting remarkable results. Something to do with ocean water, he explained.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Turning Tables on Market Forces
description: Circa 1960, Germany was newly rich, geographically split, mum about its recent past and churning out young artists by the score. Two of them, Gerhard Richter and Sigmar Polke, would go on to international celebrity. How they began that climb is the subject of a fascinatingly odd exhibition from Artists Space called Living With Pop: A Reproduction of Capitalist Realism, which has the distinction of being an art history survey with no art, or not the sort most museums would acknowledge.

title: Mexican Drug Lord Taunts the Authorities With Videos
description: MEXICO CITY  Drug lords in Mexico normally try to stay out of the limelight, amassing an army to help hide them and employing plastic surgeons to alter their features.

title: Up in the (Rarefied) Air
description: Earlier this summer, George Steinmetz, a photographer based in New Jersey, boarded a small helicopter with cameras in tow and spent several hours peering down on the rooftops of some privileged New Yorkers. (See the resulting photo essay here.) Steinmetz, who is more accustomed to taking pictures of the sandy vistas of the Sahara or the dunescapes of Brazil, recently discussed what it was like to pierce the privacy of Manhattans rooftop sunbathers and gardeners.

title: Summary of Inspector General Report
description: This is the summary page from a report by the C.I.A.s inspector general.

title: Agreeing to Accept and Move On
description: After my mother was told she had incurable cancer, she became obsessed with finding me a husband. One afternoon from her office, between negotiations for a clients book contract, she called three times to tell me about a man my father had met who worked in a SoHo lamp store. My mother, a powerful publisher and literary agent who had championed Stephen King, now wanted to set me up with someone who sold lamps.

title: Words With Friends
description: My husband and I have a good marriage; weve been true partners and best friends for nearly 15 years. But I cant help noticing that when were at dinner parties, for instance, or out with friends, he often jokes about our sex life, implying that its boring or nonexistent. When I question him later, he insists that he was only joking. Its true that many friends join him in this line of humor. But these jokes hurt my feelings. Should I make an issue of it or let it go?

title: Fragments of History That Fit in a Pocket
