description: I HAVE been digging in the kinds of desolate spots where corpses turn up on crime shows. What I have turned up instead, fortunately, are fragments of the plentiful colored glass and molded ceramics that decorated the American skyline a century ago.

title: Credit Scores vs. Credit Reports
description: The advice from most mortgage professionals to first-time home buyers is to begin sprucing up their credit at least six months before applying for a loan. Credit scores and credit reports are readily available for purchase online, but figuring out which is most accurate can be daunting.

title: Johnson & Johnson Praised for Taking Uterine Surgery Tools Off Market
description: Johnson & Johnson, which has come under withering criticism for its response to problems with some of its medical devices, won cautious praise from critics on Thursday for its decision to withdraw three products used in uterine surgery because of a risk of spreading cancerous tissue, only months after the safety issue became widely known.

title: Luster Lost, Atlantic City Home Is Auctioned for $530,000
description: An Atlantic City homeowner who became known for fending off eminent domain, Donald J. Trump and his multimillion-dollar offers finally sold the property at auction on Thursday. The price was $530,000.

title: Get Your Tootsy Frootsy TV Clips!
description: Rich, strange and intermittently fascinating, Shout! Factorys three-DVD set The Marx Brothers TV Collection follows Groucho, Chico and Harpo, or rather their well-known personae, through the decades that postscripted the brothers 1949 Hollywood swan song, Love Happy.

title: Tom Friedman: Paint and Styrofoam
description: The artist Tom Friedman tends to blow our minds and then move on, rarely repeating himself. (A starburst made of toothpicks or a realistic fly, having seemingly alighted on the corner of a pedestal, come to mind.) Nearly each artwork is some one-off feat of concept, technique and common materials. So its unexpected to see Mr. Friedman staying in one place as he does here and to realize that the effect is even more intense.

title: Nancy Rubins: Our Friend Fluid Metal
description: Nancy Rubinss sculpture comes out of the collage and assemblage tradition of artists like Kurt Schwitters, Robert Rauschenberg and John Chamberlain. In the 1980s she used salvaged appliances to make scruffy punk sculptures that occasionally raised the ire of viewers; later she worked with airplane parts and dozens of small boats to create pieces that are more streamlined and elegant.

title: The Intuitionists and Small
description: In 1977 the Drawing Center began a program in which aspiring artists could submit works to be seen by the centers curators. Supplicants might be included in the centers artist registry, and the luckiest would be featured in Selections, an often interesting series of new-talent shows.

title: New Hells
description: In a world laid bare to technological scrutiny, a retreat to the psychological dark side seems like a smart idea, and thats where New Hells, organized by Isaac Lyles, associate director of Derek Eller Gallery, goes. Declaredly pro-weird, the show is a maze of inscrutable references but has nicely sticky visual texture that keeps us looking even when were not sure whats going on.

title: To Russia With Love
description: The rocket attack on Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 killed 298 people and changed the geopolitical landscape. The United States and the European Union have responded with sanctions,while Russia continues to amass troops on its border with Ukraine.

title: A World Without Pity Spawns a Fallen Son
description: Make no mistake: There is nothing pleasant about Child of God, James Francos very fine adaptation of Cormac McCarthys short, pitiless novel. But then, Mr. McCarthy is a bard of the apocalyptic who, in his unsparing period novel Blood Meridian writes that war is the truest form of divination. His is no country for old men, to borrow the title of one of his few books that have been turned into a successful film; neither is it a place for bromides about the triumph of the human spirit, one reason most of the screen adaptations have failed. There isnt a war per se in Child of God, just good and (mostly) evil in a Christ story in reverse about a mystery who becomes a man.

title: Kodak Moments, Deconstructed
description: One of the most telling images in the Museum of Modern Arts beautiful but demanding survey of the Conceptual photographer Christopher Williams represents an act of elegant iconoclasm. It lays bare something most of us rarely see: the guts of a cameras lens. It is an amazing sight.

title: Systematized Postmodernism
description: The art of Charles Gaines is the opposite of hedonistic. Austere, cerebral, coldly formal and elliptically self-reflexive, it wont play to viewers who look for sensual pleasure, emotional expression, imaginative fantasy and traditional craft in art. But if the history of postmodern theory is your thing, you should see Charles Gaines: Gridwork 1974-1989, at the Studio Museum in Harlem.

title: Defending Their Worldly Possessions
description: This was your grandmothers, my mother said to me holding up a china teacup and delicate saucer, admiring its flowery Wedgwood pattern. Its very special.

title: The Steamy Fifty Shades of Grey Trailer Deserves Some Answers
description: Ever since the release of the Fifty Shades of Grey trailer, which opens with the gorgeous heroine interviewing a cool, controlling titan of industry who will ultimately initiate her into S&M, people have been asking me, Is journalism really like that? and I say, Absolutely.

title: Learning Lear': Time to Leave the Nest
description: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses and performs King Lear for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: Yankees Acquire Martin Prado and Stephen Drew
description: BOSTON  When Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman saw on Thursday afternoon that the Boston Red Sox had traded two of their top pitchers, signaling their abdication from the playoff race, he sent a text message to Bostons general manager, Ben Cherington. As long as the Red Sox were unloading players, why not swap Red Sox shortstop Stephen Drew for Kelly Johnson?

title: On the Chinese Militarys New Map, What Borders?
description: In recent weeks, there has been chatter online about a new map of China that the Peoples Liberation Army is issuing to its troops. It is the Chinese militarys first major revision of a physical map in 30 years, the P.L.A. has said.

title: Delicate Chinese Albums for Wealthy Show-Offs
description: DELICATE CHINESE ALBUMS

title: Holiday Visitor Whos a Tough Sort of Gift
description: What a pleasure it is to watch a film showing life as it is, not warped into a fantasy of superhuman power. You can feast on such realism in Richard Linklaters seven-course masterpiece, Boyhood, or sample it in Joe Swanbergs modest but savory amuse-bouche, Happy Christmas. Both films are portraits of white middle-class American families, the first set in Texas and stretching over 12 years, the second during a single Christmas holiday in Chicago.

title: Work to Bolster Health Website Is Raising Cost, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials said Thursday that the cost of the federal health insurance exchange was growing because they were assigning new work to contractors in an effort to prevent a repetition of the problems that crippled HealthCare.gov last fall.

title: Forgive Me, Father, for I Must Sin
description: The Anglo-Irish writer and director John Michael McDonagh opens his cold, mordantly funny murder mystery, Calvary, with a misleadingly pacific image: a close-up of the Irish actor Brendan Gleeson. An imposingly big man whos often called on to suggest authority, Mr. Gleeson has played cops, criminals and Winston Churchill, and had the recurring role of Mad-Eye Moody in the Harry Potter series. In Calvary, he plays a world- and time-tested expert of another sort: Father James, a conscientious priest and widower whose faith isnt shared by his flock, which includes a serial sinner, a hostile Buddhist, a dog hater and other furious souls, including one self-professed future executioner.

title: Mrs. Obama Details Progress in Effort to End Homelessness Among Veterans
description: More than 180 mayors, governors and other leaders have joined the Obama administrations effort to end homelessness among military veterans by the end of 2015, Michelle Obama said Thursday. Mrs. Obama, addressing the National Alliance to End Homelessness, said the military could set an example for American policy, as it did when it desegregated the armed forces. Mrs. Obama also wrote an op-ed on Thursday in which she said that nearly 100 of the local and state officials involved had pledged their support for the Mayors Challenge to End Veteran Homelessness in the last two months. Phoenix and Salt Lake City have already eliminated chronic homelessness among their veterans, and New Orleans is expected to do the same within six months, she said.

title: Ukrainians Forced to Flee
description: People around the world are being displaced on a scale that hasnt been seen in decades. Ukrainians are the latest victims of conflict.

title: Making It Up on Drums, on Piano, on the Fly
description: The drummer Tyshawn Sorey and the pianist Marilyn Crispell played together as a duo only once before Tuesday night at the Stone. It was a couple of months ago, during a Creative Music Studio Workshop in the Catskills, and it lasted about 20 minutes. The reports were positive, and a video appeared online. Its a little compromised. Ms. Crispell is playing a digital keyboard; the subtleties of Mr. Soreys drumming are compressed through YouTube audio. What can you do?

title: The War on New Yorks Waterfront
description: THE New York City waterfront has, as everyone and his uncle from New Jersey whos visiting for the weekend knows, come back to life. Governors Island has sloughed off its dreary Coast Guard skin and now hosts everything from harbor swims to art exhibitions. Cyclists and boaters throng Hudson River Park, which, as of this summer, has its own floating oyster bar. Even actual living oysters, once driven from our waters by billions of gallons of raw sewage, are making a comeback thanks to the Clean Water Act.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 1-7
description: The City by Water  A boat ride is sometimes the best way to appreciate the full landscape of a city. On any given day, excursions are available on all kinds of boats to see a variety of sights, sample food and beverages, hear music or take in a burlesque show. Yes, a burlesque sail  for those 21 and older  on a tall ship is among the fare offered by Manhattan by Sail, with the next one scheduled for Aug. 14 at 9:45 p.m. (the cost is $28), leaving from Slip 2 in Battery Park, Lower Manhattan. Details: 212-619-6900, manhattanbysail.com.

title: The Problem With Not Growing Up
description: THE ALMOST MAN

title: Americas Hidden Credit Card Bill
description: BOSTON  HOUSEHOLDS cant spend, on a continuing basis, more than they earn. Countries cant either, at least not over the long run. But countries can certainly leave the bill for their current spending to the young and to future generations. Official borrowing is the old-fashioned way to do this: Sell Treasury bonds, and other securities, and spend the proceeds. But borrowing in broad daylight has a drawback: The more you do it, the more lenders worry about repayment, and the more interest they charge for their loans.

title: When Wheelchairs Are Cool
description: LOS ANGELES  LAST week, the celebrity gossip site TMZ posted pictures of Justin Bieber in a wheelchair. He was not at a hospital. He was at Disneyland. As everyone knows, Disney patrons in wheelchairs get to cut to the front of the lines. But as a dispute flared over whether this was Mr. Biebers intent, becoming a trending topic on Twitter, one fact remained unassailable: I was there first.

description: PARIS  At least seven times, alone and in secret, Dr. Nicolas Bonnemaison prepared a lethal dose of sedative and quietly ended the life of a comatose patient in his care.

Claire Wilson, 18, who was eight months pregnant, and her boyfriend, Thomas Eckman, also 18, happened to be walking by.
